headline: NewSchools Fund Attracts More Capital
text: NewSchools Venture Fund, a nonprofit that started out channeling philanthropic donations to charter schools and that now invests in a range of education groups and businesses, is entering into a partnership with a new venture capital fund that could result in millions more in financing.

headline: Years Later, Barnes Gets a Big Hit Off Pettitte
text: Shortly after he had been battered by the Houston Astros on Monday night, Andy Pettitte dissected his performance and was particularly upset about a fourth-inning, 0-2 pitch he threw to Brandon Barnes that Barnes turned into a two-run double.

headline: Equipped to Weather Big Storms, a Jersey City Tower Draws Tenants
text: In the six months since Hurricane Sandy hit, office tenants have been flocking to a huge glass tower in Jersey City despite its being right along the waterfront. It may seem counterintuitive for companies to pointedly search for office space near the water, but the 500,000-square-foot building at 111 Town Square Place in Newport is a hybrid data center and office building that offers tenants backup generators, redundant power and an extensive fiber optic network.

headline: Chris Matthews Signs Long-Term Extension With MSNBC
text: Chris Matthews, who has been one of the most prominent hosts on MSNBC for more than a decade, has signed a new long-term deal with the network to continue his “Hardball” program, a network executive confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Advocates Say Managed-Care Plans Shun the Most Disabled Medicaid Users
text: Managed-care companies in New York have come under fire for signing up vigorous older adults referred to them by social day care centers, customers whose health needs are relatively small.

headline: In the World of Content, Web Follows a Trail Left by TV
text: IF in real estate, as the saying goes, the three most important things are “location, location, location,” when it comes to wooing viewers and advertisers to online video from television, the corresponding mantra seems to be “content, content, content.”

headline: Miami’s Condo Market Rebounds, Stoking a Building Boom
text: MIAMI — Of the 22,000 condos created in downtown Miami during the boom years, only about 600 remain unsold — thanks mainly to an influx of Latin American investors seeking a safe haven for their money.

headline: In New Hampshire, Senator Finds Her Vote on Gun Bill Is Hot Topic
text: WARREN, N.H. — It was 45 minutes into Senator Kelly Ayotte’s town hall-style meeting here on Tuesday, and the local Republican official screening question topics had allowed just one query on gun control. A few in the crowd of about 150 started to get agitated.

headline: Chinese Way of Doing Business: In Cash We Trust
text: SHANGHAI — Lin Lu remembers the day last December when a Chinese businessman showed up at the car dealership he works for in north China and paid for a new BMW 5 Series Gran Turismo — entirely in cash.

headline: Massachusetts: Aid Promised for Victims Who Lost Limbs
text: The American Orthotic & Prosthetic Association, a national trade group, has promised to provide artificial limbs to any people who lost a leg in the Boston Marathon bombings if they are uninsured or their insurance fails to cover the cost.  More than a dozen people lost limbs in the blasts; it is not yet known how many will need help paying for prostheses. The cost of an initial prosthesis could be $8,000 to $30,000, said Tom Fise, the group’s executive director. Many insurance plans sharply limit coverage, he said.

headline: Kerry Calls Arab League Plan to Revive Talks With Israel a ‘Big Step’
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry on Tuesday embraced a proposal by the Arab League to revive peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians as “a very big step forward,” but initial reactions suggested that the new initiative might have difficulty penetrating the years-long impasse.

headline: Deanna Durbin, Plucky Movie Star of the Depression Era, Is Dead at 91
text: Deanna Durbin, who as a plucky child movie star with a sweet soprano voice charmed American audiences during the Depression and saved Universal Pictures from bankruptcy before she vanished from public view 64 years ago, has died, a fan club announced on Tuesday. She was 91.

headline: Leader of Hezbollah Warns It Is Ready to Come to Syria’s Aid
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The leader of Hezbollah, the powerful Lebanese Shiite organization, edged closer on Tuesday to acknowledging that its fighters were battling rebels in neighboring Syria, an intervention that threatens to drag Lebanon deeper into that conflict.

headline: Critics of Israel’s West Bank Occupation Say Calm Before New Violence Was an Illusion
text: As my colleagues Isabel Kershner and Fares Akram report, the tension of daily life in the occupied West Bank exploded into deadly violence on Tuesday, when a knife-wielding Palestinian man attacked and killed an Israeli settler at a bus stop. The attacker, identified as Salam Zaghal, a 24-year-old who recently spent three years in jail for throwing stones, then seized the dead man’s pistol and engaged in a shootout with police officers.

headline: The Frankfurter Diaries
text: I ate two hot dogs the other day. And now I’m going to talk about my feelings about junk food.

headline: No Penalty for Singh for Using a Hormone
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Vijay Singh, the 2005 champion of the Wells Fargo Championship, taking place here this week, was asked on the driving range Tuesday morning where his doping case with the PGA Tour stood. It had been 91 days since Singh admitted in a magazine article to taking deer antler spray, a substance included on the tour’s banned list because it contains IGF-1, an insulinlike growth hormone.

headline: With a Friend Like Rudy ...
text: Former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani went to a fund-raiser on Staten Island on Monday for Joseph Lhota, his former deputy who is running for Mr. Giuliani’s old job. Thanks to a blogging reporter, Jacob Kornbluh, there is video of Mr. Giuliani reprising his role as the Mayor of 9/11.

headline: ‘Ghost Money,’ and Lots of It
text: The news that the Central Intelligence Agency has been spending lavishly in Afghanistan should come as no surprise. The agency went to work in the country right after Sept. 11, 2001, and has played a dominant covert role hunting down Al Qaeda and the Taliban ever since, while the Pentagon and other agencies have pursued more transparent military and development operations costing many billions of dollars.

headline: Flooded Factory Is Brought Back by Its Workers
text: The day after Hurricane Sandy, Dal LaMagna drove to his factory in Building 12 at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. His company, IceStone, had been making hard surfaces, like countertops and tables, using recycled glass and cement. As he pulled into the yard, his first sight was of the factory’s new garage door, which cost $21,000, peeled back like the lid of a sardine tin. Inside were six destroyed forklifts. The entire place was drowned.

headline: Koch Brothers Plan More Political Involvement for Their Conservative Network
text: As the country’s leading conservative donors finished off plates of roast lamb and spaetzle in a Palm Springs, Calif., hotel ballroom on Monday, Charles G. Koch delivered a pep talk.

headline: The President and the Hunger Strike
text: President Obama said a lot of important things on Tuesday about the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. It is a blight on the nation’s reputation. It mocks American standards of justice by keeping people imprisoned without charges. It has actually hindered the prosecution and imprisonment of dangerous terrorists. Even if Guantánamo seemed justified to some people in the immediate aftermath of the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, those justifications are wearing thin. It is unsustainable and should be closed.

headline: It’s a 401(k) World
text: It’s hard to have a conversation today with any worker, teacher, student or boss who doesn’t tell you some version of this: More things seem to be changing in my world than ever before, but I can’t quite put my finger on it, let alone know how to adapt. So let me try to put my finger on it: We now live in a 401(k) world — a world of defined contributions, not defined benefits — where everyone needs to pass the bar exam and no one can escape the most e-mailed list.

headline: Banks Rally Against Strict Controls of Foreign Bets
text: WASHINGTON — Wall Street bankers and some of the world’s top finance ministers are waging a bitter international campaign to block Washington financial regulators from extending their policing powers far beyond the nation’s shores.

headline: Bottoms Up, Lame Duck
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Is Cursive Dead?
text: New public school curriculum standards in the U.S. do not require the teaching of script. But should students be taught it anyway?

text: To the Editor:

headline: Tobacco Use by Youths
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: As Bombing Inquiry Proceeds, Obama Offers Measured Praise for F.B.I.
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama offered measured support on Tuesday for the F.B.I.’s handling of a tip from Russian intelligence about one of the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings but said his administration would “review every step that was taken” to see if more could have been done to prevent the attack.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 30, 2013

headline: The Anthony and Smith the Knicks Don’t Want
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

headline: Attention-Deficit Drugs Face New Campus Rules
text: FRESNO, Calif. — Lisa Beach endured two months of testing and paperwork before the student health office at her college approved a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Then, to get a prescription for Vyvanse, a standard treatment for A.D.H.D., she had to sign a formal contract — promising to submit to drug testing, to see a mental health professional every month and to not share the pills.

headline: Harvard Student’s Suicide as a Case Study
text: A lawsuit against Harvard provides rare detail on the issues involving a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder from a student-health department.

headline: The Most Hated Bangladeshi, Toppled From a Shady Empire
text: SAVAR, Bangladesh — Barely 20 miles from the national capital, this gritty suburb is now a dusty, chaotic industrial center littered with factories that produce clothes for leading Western brands. Building codes are often unenforced, regulatory oversight is flimsy and the men wielding power often travel with armed guards.

headline: Retailers Split on Contrition After Collapse of Factories
text: The building collapse in Bangladesh that caused at least 386 deaths has produced some jarringly different responses from Western apparel retailers and brands that obtained goods from factories inside the building.

headline: For Toronto’s Kessel, Just ‘Another Game’ Awaits in Boston
text: TORONTO — A day after causing a stir by not speaking to waiting reporters, Phil Kessel met the Toronto news media Tuesday.

headline: Legislation Would Give Usada Authority Over Drugs in Racing
text: Two lawmakers who contend that the United States Anti-Doping Agency is the most effective agency to regulate horse racing plan to introduce a bill in Congress to give it the authority to enforce antidoping standards and to kick out violators.

headline: With Democratic Mayoral Field in Flux, de Blasio Assails Quinn
text: Bill de Blasio has hammered Christine C. Quinn over her closeness to the mayor, mocked her as the “best friend” of the real estate industry, and accused her of being soft on the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly.

headline: A Fun Holiday to Celebrate
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — ALOHA and happy LEI DAY, everyone! Paula Gamache is back, and her challenge to you is this lovely Wednesday puzzle. Her challenge to me is to figure out how to discuss this without getting fired.

headline: Guatemala: Former Dictator’s Genocide Trial Resumes
text: The genocide trial of a former dictator of Guatemala, Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt, resumed Tuesday, 12 days after a judge ruled to annul the court proceedings. Guatemala’s highest court has yet to issue a clear statement on the legality of that decision, but it made several rulings last week that sent the case back to the chief trial judge, Jasmín Barrios, to restart proceedings. Testimony is almost complete, but Guatemala’s highest court must still consider several more motions related to the trial, and experts say more delays are possible.

headline: Liu Is Prominent Figure in Closing Argument at Ex-Aides’ Trial
text: As closing arguments began on Tuesday in a widely watched political corruption trial in Manhattan, a federal prosecutor asked a jury to convict two former associates of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller and a Democratic candidate for mayor, of conspiring to funnel money to his campaign through an illegal fund-raising scheme.

headline: Jason Collins Took Personal Steps Before Coming Out Publicly
text: LOS ANGELES — When Jason Collins signed with Boston Celtics last year, he was a player in search of a number. His number for years — 34 — was taken, and 35, which he had with the Nets at the start of his career, had been retired by his new team.

headline: Cuba: U.S. Allows President’s Daughter to Travel
text: The State Department will allow President Raúl Castro’s daughter to travel to Philadelphia to receive a gay civil rights award. Mariela Castro, director of Cuba’s National Center for Sex Education, was granted a diplomatic visa to attend United Nations meetings in April, but the State Department did not issue a second visa she requested to attend the Equality Forum 2013 Summit this weekend. Cuban diplomats cannot travel more than 25 miles without prior authorization. Ms. Castro is considered an international leader in the issue of rights for gay and transgender people. The Equality Forum received word on Monday that the State Department decided to lift the 25-mile restriction. “Better judgment prevailed,” said the group’s director, Malcolm Lazin. The State Department did not explain the reversal.

headline: Company’s App Can Now Be Used to Hail Yellow Cabs in City
text: After a series of court hearings and false starts, New York City’s yellow taxi riders can now, for the first time, legally hail a cab with a smartphone app.

headline: Push to Include Gay Couples in Immigration Bill
text: This has been a good year for gay rights advocates — with public opinion shifting in their favor and same-sex marriage advancing in the states — but not when it comes to immigration.

headline: Zimmerman Forgoes Pretrial Hearing, Taking Issue of Immunity to a Jury
text: MIAMI — With a softly spoken, “Yes, Your Honor,” George Zimmerman officially waived his right to a pretrial “Stand Your Ground” immunity hearing on Tuesday, choosing instead to lay out his self-defense case before a jury.

headline: Three Outs From Win, Mets Throw It Away
text: MIAMI — Caught in the baseball vortex that had vaporized their offense and drained their confidence, the Mets searched for an escape route before Tuesday’s game at Marlins Park. Some of the players spent additional time analyzing video. Some took extra cuts in the batting cage. Others simply stuck to routine, hopeful that this would be the night they unearthed the ability to score a couple of runs, maybe more.

headline: Looking Ahead to the Jets’ Quarterback Roulette
text: There were once three quarterbacks: the uninspiring veteran, the free-agent addition and the recent draft pick. They would all compete, team officials said, and compete they did until the winner was selected.

headline: Celtics Rally Around Collins, a Valued Former Teammate
text: WALTHAM, Mass. — Doc Rivers said he received a phone call a few days ago. On the other line was Jason Collins, who had appeared in 32 games for the Boston Celtics this season before being traded in February.

headline: Like His Team, a Wing Who Kept Plugging Away
text: Colin McDonald personifies the resolve of the resurgent Islanders as much as any player on their young roster.

headline: Derby Limelight Doesn’t Fall on Baffert
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — On Tuesday morning, Bob Baffert was in his usual spot on the backside of Churchill Downs, holding court with a group of owners and horsemen, telling stories and making jokes.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 1
text: “The idea that we would still maintain forever a group of individuals who have not been tried, that is contrary to who we are, contrary to our interests, and it needs to stop.”

headline: Body Is Found Buried at Queens Apartment Building
text: The police dug up a body on Tuesday that had been buried in the backyard of an apartment building in Queens, the authorities said, several days after they had received a report of someone missing from that building.

headline: Word of the Day | sidereal
text: sidereal •\si-ˈdir-e-əl, sə-\• adjective

headline: Duke University Withdraws From Online Course Group
text: Duke University has pulled out of Semester Online, an education consortium that will offer online undergraduate courses for credit, after faculty members objected.

headline: The Problem of Breast Pain in Women Who Exercise
text: In the days before the London Marathon last year, scientists from the Research Group in Breast Health at the University of Portsmouth in England approached female racers at the event’s registration center and asked them to complete an anonymous questionnaire about their exercise habits and breast health.

headline: Yankees Find Ways to Win and Finish 16-10 in April
text: The Houston Astros arrived in the Bronx on Monday with the worst record in the American League, losers of four straight games and playing in a manner befitting a $26 million payroll.

headline: Corrections: May 1, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Extinction Nears for China’s ‘River Pig,’ the Finless Porpoise
text: BEIJING — It’s known in China as the “river pig,” the finless porpoise that has lived in the Yangtze River system for about 300,000 years but may become extinct within 10. Why?

headline: Rough Track and Low Stakes in Kenya
text: When Steve Njuguna’s son told his father he wanted to follow in his footsteps as a jockey, Mr. Njuguna did all he could to dissuade him.

headline: E-Books and Democracy
text: WRESTLING with my newspaper on the subway recently, I noticed the woman next to me reading a book on her smartphone. “That has to hurt your eyes,” I commented.  Not missing a beat, she replied, in true New York style, “My font is bigger than yours.” She was right.

headline: Tokyo Official Apologizes for Remarks About Olympics Rival
text: Naoki Inose, the governor of Tokyo, apologized for comments he made recently about Istanbul, a rival city hoping to host the Olympics in 2020. Inose, who is also the chairman of Tokyo’s bid committee, said in a recent interview with The New York Times that Istanbul may be less equipped than Tokyo to host the Games.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 11:30 P.M. (Sundance) NURSE BETTY (2000) Renée Zellweger, above, with Chris Rock, left, and Morgan Freeman, is Betty, a small-town waitress who suffers a nervous breakdown after she witnesses the murder of her husband (Aaron Eckhart) at the hands of two hit men (Mr. Freeman and Mr. Rock). Instead of facing reality, Betty escapes into the idealized fantasy of her favorite soap opera, “A Reason to Love,” which is set in a hospital. She travels to Los Angeles to become a nurse and tries to reunite with her imagined old flame, the fictional Dr. David Ravell (Greg Kinnear). Unfortunately, the hit men are in hot pursuit. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that this dark comedy “takes the most hackneyed dramatic ploy of soap opera, a case of amnesia, and spins it into an irresistibly heady mixture of sadness and hilarity.” He added, “At its giddiest peaks the movie, directed by Neil LaBute, produces that shivery feeling when your heart melts, but at the same moment you want to burst out laughing.”

headline: News Quiz | May 1, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Lawyer to Contest Congress Leader Sajjan Kumar’s Acquittal in 1984 Riots Case
text: NEW DELHI — A Delhi court acquitted the Indian Congress Party leader Sajjan Kumar Tuesday for the murder of five men during the 1984 anti-Sikh riots, but the lawyer for one of the victims said he is already planning to appeal the decision to the Delhi High Court.

headline: IHT Quick Read: May 1
text: The most reviled man in Bangladesh, Sohel Rana, 35, is under arrest. Mr. Rana owned the Rana Plaza, which collapsed last week, killing nearly 400 people. Many others are still missing. On Tuesday, a top Bangladeshi court seized his assets, as the public called for his execution, especially as it appears that the tragedy could have been averted if the frantic warnings of an engineer who examined the building the day before had been heeded. Jim Yardley reports from Savar, Bangladesh.

headline: Roadside Bomb Kills 3 British Soldiers on Patrol in Afghanistan
text: Three British soldiers have been killed by a roadside bomb that detonated near them in Helmand Province in Afghanistan, British officials announced Wednesday, the deadliest attack on British soldiers there in a year.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, May 1, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article “Building a Better Tech School.”

headline: Online Courses and the Challenges of Higher Education
text: In “Colleges Adapt Online Courses to Ease Burden,” Tamar Lewin writes about the ways in which some public universities are harnessing the power of online courses.

headline: Greeks Strike Against Austerity as World Observes Labor Day
text: ATHENS — As workers around the world observed the international Labor Day holiday with demonstrations and rallies, thousands of Greeks walked off their jobs on Wednesday in the second general strike against government austerity measures this year, shutting down tax offices, leaving state hospitals to operate with emergency employees and disrupting public transportation.

headline: How Do You Feel About Rihanna and Chris Brown Getting Back Together?
text: Four years ago, the singer Chris Brown pleaded guilty to felony assault after brutally beating his girlfriend at the time, the pop star Rihanna. Now, the two seem to be back together — and though some people see it as a story of true love and forgiveness, many worry about the example Rihanna is setting in a case that, as one professor said, “defined dating and domestic violence for the hip-hop generation.”

headline: Echoes of Saddam’s War in Dilemma Over Syria’s Chemical Weapons
text: ERBIL, Iraq — A team of United Nations experts was still waiting in Cyprus on Wednesday to hear whether Syria will grant it unfettered access to investigate reports that chemical weapons have been used in the country’s civil war.

headline: The Lions’ Share
text: NEW DELHI — Volunteers from an Indian nature club in the state of Gujarat are threatening suicide over a recent decision of the Indian Supreme Court to relocate some Asiatic Lions from Gir, in Gujarat, to Palpur Kuno, in the state of Madhya Pradesh. The endangered animals number about 400 in all.

headline: How Did You Choose Your College?
text: Just a few weeks ago, many of you gathered around a virtual kitchen table on The Choice blog to share the admission decisions of the colleges to which you applied. Since then, you’ve had until May 1 to choose a college and submit an enrollment deposit.

text: Today’s Times

headline: Powering Up the Cloud
text: A new product from one of Silicon Valley’s legendary engineers also says a lot about where the industry is going.

headline: Health Coverage Worthy of a Senator
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: A Conversation With: Psychiatrist Dinesh Bhugra, Expert on Deviant Sexual Behavior
text: Reports of rapes of very young girls continue to surface in India, appalling citizens and sparking protests. On Monday, a 4-year old girl died from injuries sustained after she was raped by a grown man and left near a crematorium in central India.

headline: Obama and Guantánamo
text: The ties that bind Obama on closing Guantánamo.

headline: Molten Cake, ‘The Big Mac of Desserts’
text: Mark Bittman shows how to make a warm soft chocolate cake with Jean-Georges Vongerichten, who says his restaurants make about a thousand a day.

headline: Higher Cable Bills Help Comcast Increase Profit by 17%
text: Despite a slowdown in the number of customers paying for cable and high-speed Internet subscriptions, Comcast reported a 17.4 percent increase in net income, to $1.44 billion, in the three months that ended March 31.

headline: Almost Half of Americans Say Budget Cuts Will Hurt Economy
text: Nearly half of Americans agree with the Obama administration’s contention that the economy will be hurt by the spending cuts prompted by the sequestration, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: One Entrepreneur’s Favorite Start-Up Tools
text: I recently had a conversation with someone who is starting a social enterprise to connect corporate sponsors with the social networks of activists, athletes, musicians and others. He was asking me for advice on learning to code so that he could start to build his site.

headline: Operation: Mother’s Day
text: Attention, significant others of mothers: Breakfast in bed is a thoughtful, time-honored gesture for Mother’s Day. There is, however, an alternative to a precariously balanced tray of eggs, orange juice and coffee, all of which she eats by herself while the kids hang around watching. That alternative is a simple but wonderful dinner, cooked by you and those same adorable children, eaten together at an actual table.

headline: One Last Cringe for ‘The Office’ Finale
text: LOS ANGELES — Sometime in Season 3 of “The Office,” its creator, Greg Daniels, conceived the premise for what would be the show’s finale.

headline: In Performance: Deborah Cox of ‘Jekyll & Hyde’
text: Frank Wildhorn’s 1997 musical “Jekyll & Hyde,” now being revived on Broadway, is a Gothic pop-opera version of the Victorian tale of Dr. Jekyll and his nefarious other half, Mr. Hyde. In this scene, Deborah Cox, who plays the prostitute Lucy, sings her character’s signature song, the power ballad “Someone Like You.” The show runs through June 30 at the Marquis Theater.

headline: Vyjack Has Learned to Behave, and to Win
text: I’ve seen only one Kentucky Derby starter up close this year. The starter, Vyjack, came to Fair Hill for two weeks or so in April, and he struck me as a lively personality during several visits over a few days.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Age Lowered for Next-Day Birth Control Access
text: The age is lowered for next-day birth control, visiting Paraguay’s landlocked Guairá region, a cab-hailing app now approved in New York and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Apple’s Debt Market Foray
text: It might not seem that Apple, with a $145 billion cash hoard, would need to raise money. But on Tuesday, the company issued $17 billion of bonds, a record amount, paying interest rates that hovered near those on the low-cost debt of the United States Treasury.

headline: Yoga Instructors, Tile Layers, Others Get New Outlet for Web Lessons
text: Online education is a sprawling category that encompasses everything from  open online courses on physics, history and other college subjects to intensive, multiday workshops on photography on sites like CreativeLive.

headline: Daily Report: Hotels, Airports and Airlines Struggle With Demand for Wi-Fi
text: Travelers hitting the road with their mobile electronic devices have three questions about staying connected away from home: will there be Wi-Fi, how much will it cost and how well will it work? Increasingly, it is that last question that matters most, reports Susan Stellin on Wednesday in The New York Times.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway to Acquire the Rest of IMC for $2 Billion
text: Berkshire Hathaway has agreed to buy the 20 percent of the IMC International Metalworking Companies that it does not already own for $2.05 billion, giving it full control of the company.

headline: The Rope Wrangler, Ideas Unfurling

headline: Obama Nominates Congressman to Lead Mortgage Agency
text: WASHINGTON – President Obama on Wednesday nominated Representative Melvin L. Watt, Democrat of North Carolina, to become the overseer of the government-backed mortgage financiers Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

headline: Credit Suisse Is Said to Elevate 2 Investment Bankers
text: LONDON – Credit Suisse named co-heads for its investment banking operations in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, following the resignation of Jamie Welch after a year in the job, a person with knowledge of the appointments said on Wednesday.

headline: In New Chinese Campaign, Concerns Over Morals and Corruption
text: BEIJING — An early glimpse of a political campaign expected to launch in China soon, the homely-sounding “check the mirror, fix your clothes, take a bath, see the doctor,” which aims to improve the morals of Communist Party members and combat corruption, came last December.

headline: Built as an Operating Theater, Soon to Be a Private School
text: When Dr. Charles McBurney, an eminent 19th-century surgeon, was given the opportunity to create the ideal operating room, he insisted that there be lots of light and air. That’s not a bad arrangement for precocious schoolchildren, either.

headline: I Wanted ‘Twins’
text: Taking Sides
