text: Taking Sides

headline: Young Movers, With a Passion for Change
text: I intended to write this column next October, but why wait? As President Obama observed last week, we’ve been through a tough time. And as the Boston Marathon bombing continues to be headline news — and gut-wrenching images continue to circulate — we need to keep in mind what behavioral scientists call the “availability heuristic” — our tendency to mistakenly estimate the probability of events based on how readily examples come to mind. A story that leaves a painful and vivid impression like this one can distort our sense of reality for a long time.

headline: America’s Most Reconsidered General
text: The reputation of Ulysses S. Grant has oscillated wildly through history, almost since the day of his birth, April 27, 1822. A West Point graduate with a middling military career and a series of failed business ventures. From a midlevel command at the start of the Civil War to the very top of the military leadership at its end, followed by a two-term presidency. But from almost the moment he took office, his reputation began to steadily decline. As late as the 1950s his military success was commonly attributed to superior numbers applied with brute force.

headline: ‘Big, Hot, Cheap and Right': Erica Grieder Talks About Texas
text: In her new book, “Big, Hot, Cheap and Right: What America Can Learn From the Strange Genius of Texas,” Erica Grieder, an editor at Texas Monthly magazine, writes about the forces that shaped the state’s attitudes as well as its current economic growth in the face of widespread troubles in the rest of the country. In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Grieder discussed the state’s economic “miracle,” whether the future there bodes well for Democrats and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Baltic Brouhaha
text: Martin Wolf has a very good piece on the attempts to put the Baltic states, Latvia especially, on a pedestal and claim that they prove that austerity works. Mainly he makes points I have made previously: first, that output is still well below the previous peak, and unemployment still very high despite drastic out-migration:

headline: Telling Eyes in the Dark
text: Mary E. Blair is a postdoctoral researcher at the American Museum of Natural History’s Center for Biodiversity and Conservation, where she coordinates the Enhancing Diversity in Conservation Science Initiative.

headline: Orb’s Workout Impresses a Top Observer
text: Before the Kentucky Derby, horses are scrutinized with more intensity than before any other race. No one is more respected for studying these horses than Mike Welsch, who has been watching pre-Derby workouts for the Daily Racing Form since 2000.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Vice: One tub of “I Can’t Believe It’s Not Butter” and chocolate chip cookies; Wonder bread and Dom Pérignon. What do these delicacies have in common? They are what famous rockers want to eat backstage. (You can play match the meal to the rock star.) — Melissa Clark

headline: Dying Long Distance
text: PARIS — The last conversation I had with my father was by Skype. He was in a sunny room in southeastern Pennsylvania; I was in Paris, where I live and work. He was surrounded by my siblings and their spouses; my mother had visited earlier that day.

headline: Home Spending on Entertainment Rises
text: LOS ANGELES — Home entertainment spending on movies and television shows rose about 5 percent in the first quarter, to $4.69 billion, compared with the same period a year ago, as some strong titles including “Skyfall” and “Argo” hit the market, according to figures released Wednesday by the Digital Entertainment Group, an industry consortium.

headline: Image of the Day: May 1
text: International Labor Day observed in India.

headline: The Golden Age of Museum Renovation
text: As Queen Beatrix handed the title of monarch of the Netherlands to her son, Willem-Alexander, on Tuesday, art lovers in Amsterdam had another reason to celebrate. For the first time in a decade, the city’s great museums are all open.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Champions League Semifinals, Bayern Munich 3, Barcelona 0
text: In the end, Barcelona’s mission was indeed impossible.

headline: Film Studios Say New York Gun Law May Ban Props
text: ALBANY — The sweeping gun control measure signed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and hailed by Democratic leaders has a surprising critic: Hollywood.

headline: Failure of Gun Bill Casts Shadow on Immigration Reform
text: WASHINGTON — As a gun safety bill dissolved on the Senate floor last month, a group of eight senators — some who had supported the failed measure — had already moved on to a policy battle they found more promising: reinventing the nation’s troubled immigration system.

headline: The Mean Screens of New York
text: Officials in the movie and television industry say the new gun control laws in New York could prevent them from using lifelike assault weapons and high-capacity firearms. The following are a few famous movies that have prominently featured gun violence in New York.

headline: Extreme Weather in a Warming World, and the American Mind
text: To see the relationship between extreme weather and public attitudes on human-driven climate change, check out the latest report from the Yale Project on Climate Change Communication — “Extreme Weather and Climate Change in the American Mind April 2013.”

headline: Transactions
text: Recent Sale

headline: Q.& A.: Protecting Your Twitter Account
text: Q.

headline: Re-Re-engineering the Corporation
text: Could we be on the verge of another workplace revolution?

headline: Friendly, Maybe Lucky, Skies
text: The passenger in seat 34B has caught your eye? Now on Virgin America flights, you can catch his attention by sending him a drink, snack or meal along with a text via seat-back monitor declaring your intentions. Richard Branson, Virgin’s founder, right, introduced the service last month in a video billed as his “guide to getting lucky at 35,000 feet.” Try it, he said, and your chances of “deplaning with a plus one are at least 50 percent.”

headline: What if You Are Audited by the I.R.S.
text: The April 15 tax deadline is now receding in our collective rear view mirror. Nothing to do now, but to start collecting records for next year. Right?

headline: Questions About Yoga in Your Middle Years
text: This week’s Ask an Expert features Dr. Loren Fishman, who will answer questions about practicing yoga in your middle years. In 1972, before applying to medical school, he studied yoga with B.K.S. Iyengar for a year in Pune, India. Dr. Fishman, 72, has now been a practicing back-pain and rehabilitative medicine specialist for 33 years. From the start he incorporated yoga in patient care, and he teaches seminars in yoga nationally and internationally.

headline: A Different Sort of Egg
text: Every year, springtime brings a flurry of books about birds and birth and babies and, inevitably, eggs. Of course, there’s Easter. And the seasonal school curriculum. And every so often, something that feels quite new. This season, two new books from small presses offer interesting perspectives on the finding and keeping and eventual opening of eggs.

headline: Yahoo Enhances Its Parental Leave Policy
text: Marissa Mayer is trying to repair Yahoo’s image by upgrading benefits for working parents.

headline: Flashing Lights in an Ocean of Sound
text: “Close your eyes and listen to the sound of my big black boots,” Trent Reznor sang midway through the concert by How to Destroy Angels on Monday night at the Apollo Theater. It wasn’t advice many people were taking.

headline: The Gun Report: May 1, 2013
text: Tennessee senators Bob Corker and Lamar Alexander both voted against the failed Senate bill to expand background checks, a safety measure supported by 90 percent of Americans. So it should come as no surprise that a pro-gun group in that particularly gun-friendly state plans to raffle off an AR-15 semiautomatic rifle—the same weapon used by Adam Lanza to mow down 20 children and six adults in Newtown, Conn.

headline: Eric Cantor’s Dilemma
text: One further thought about the House Republicans and health care: In addition to being symptomatic of the Republican Party’s larger policy problems, last week’s defeat of a very modest gesture at something resembling a conservative approach to health care reform was illustrative of the particular problem of trying to rebuild the party’s agenda from within the House of Representatives.

headline: The Options Quarterback
text: No one seems to be quite done with Tim Tebow.

headline: No Remains of Humans in a Search Tied to 9/11
text: New York City officials said on Wednesday that no human remains had been found in the soil behind a building in Lower Manhattan where wreckage was discovered last week believed to be from one of the planes that crashed into the World Trade Center.

headline: Besieged Syrian Leader Makes Rare Public Appearance
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, apparently seeking to counter the impression of a leader in hiding after consecutive days of suspected insurgent bombings in his power base, Damascus, made a rare public appearance on Wednesday, visiting workers at an electric station.

headline: First Book Is Planned on the Tsarnaev Brothers
text: The first major book on the Tsarnaev brothers, the two suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings, has been acquired by Riverhead Books, the publisher said on Wednesday.

headline: After Boston Attack, 3 Friends Covered It Up, Prosecutors Say
text: They were perhaps Dzhokhar Tsarnaev’s closest friends during his two years at college, an American classmate from high school and two Russian-speaking students from Kazakhstan. The Kazakhs seemingly had money and drove expensive cars. They entertained Mr. Tsarnaev at their off-campus apartment, and he partied with them in New York. One of them lent Mr. Tsarnaev a black BMW after he smashed his Honda Civic in an accident.

headline: In Brown-Vitter Bill, a Banking Overhaul With Possible Teeth
text: The biggest banks have done an excellent job of delaying and undermining the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul law and staving off criminal investigations into wrongdoing.

headline: When the Doctor Is Overweight
text: Dr. George Fielding, a pioneer of weight loss surgery in Australia, remembers how patients treated him in the late 1990s, when his weight reached 330 pounds on his six-foot frame. He would meet new patients, dressed in Armani suits and feeling on top of the world, and then be abruptly upended.

headline: Keeping Guns in Circulation
text: While Senator Joe Manchin decides whether to reintroduce his failed background checks bill, other lawmakers are busy passing new gun measures that decrease rather than increase regulation.

headline: Berra Museum to Highlight Inclusion in Sports
text: The Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center in Little Falls, N.J., is creating a new exhibit, Championing Respect, which will detail the evolution of attitudes from Jackie Robinson breaking the color barrier to the latest news of gay athletes openly competing.

headline: Can Every Group Be Worse Than Average?  Yes.
text: My Off the Charts column last week noted that pay disparities had grown in the United States since 2000. The real income necessary to reach the 90th percentile — the top 10 percent of all wage owners — was 9 percent higher in the first quarter than it had been 13 years earlier. The income necessary to be in the 10th percentile was down 3 percent over the same period. The pay needed to be at the median was up 1 percent.

headline: Shell Makes Big Bet on Boom in Natural Gas
text: LONDON — As Big Oil increasingly becomes Big Gas, no major petroleum player may have more at stake in the shift than Royal Dutch Shell.

headline: Feeling For | Hermès Equestrian Collection
text: Although it is perhaps better known for its iconic handbags, the French brand Hermès originated as a harness and bridle maker in the 19th century for European nobility. Last month, the brand introduced its new Cavale saddle and Jumping Lady boot at Le Saut Hermès competition at the Grand Palais in Paris. And starting May 4, these pieces become the focus of the Spanish artist Pamen Pereira‘s windows for the brand’s new boutique in Greenwich, Conn. Pereira, whose previous installations for Hermès stores in Taiwan and Barcelona featured birds, elevated her usual flight concept with an avant-garde interpretation of the equestrian competition by way of winged saddles and motorized riding boots (as pictured above in T’s exclusive peek at the artist’s window plans).

headline: HTML5 Dev Conf Videos
text: A few of the HTML5 Dev Conf talks we recently recommended are now available on the event video sessions page. Don’t miss the two keynotes (Steve Souders and Christian Heillmann).

headline: Observed Earth: A New View of the Sky
text: There’s not much to say about this extraordinary image created by Canadian photographer Matt Molloy:

headline: More Releases of Ailing Prisoners Are Urged
text: WASHINGTON — The federal Bureau of Prisons could save taxpayer money and reduce overcrowding if it better managed a program for the “compassionate release” of inmates who are dying or facing other extraordinary circumstances, according to a new report by the Justice Department’s independent inspector general.

headline: Thieves Break Into a Personal ‘Data Vault’ Company
text: A company that describes itself as a vault for personal data has suffered an embarrassing heist: intruders penetrated its computer system and looted its customers’ names, addresses and in some cases, dates of birth and login passwords.

headline: Truck Sales Led a Strong April for U.S. Automakers
text: DETROIT — American automakers said on Wednesday that sales of pickup trucks rose sharply in April because of a revival in the housing market and increased demand from the oil and gas industry.

headline: Sorry We Drifted Apart, Richie Havens
text: Mark Lutin is a legal-marketing executive and lifelong New Yorker who lives in Bayside, Queens.

headline: Days of the Jackals
text: Gail Collins: David, I just got back from a vacation in Botswana. We were cut off from the outside world for quite a while, just looking at nature. One of our guides showed us a wild dog who had wandered into the area a few years before, apparently lost from her pack. So she stole some jackal pups and raised them. Now they’re a team — the dog does the hunting and the jackals keep a lookout for lions.

headline: The Joyce Announces Its 2013-2014 Season
text: Arthur Pita’s award-winning interpretation of Kafka’s “Metamorphosis,” originally staged by the Royal Ballet in London, will open the fall dance season at the Joyce Theater on Sept. 17, with the Royal Ballet principal Edward Watson dancing the role of Gregor Samsa, and Frank Moon performing his own score live. The production, which runs through Sept. 29, is the first of 16 that the theater has scheduled through February 2014.

headline: Leaving Cars Behind in L.A.
text: Los Angeles’s tourism agency is hoping to entice visitors to find new ways to explore the city. Its “Car Free LA” program offers seven itineraries for tourists up for biking, walking or taking the Metro transit system. Trips include the bike route from Venice to Santa Monica and a walking tour of Hollywood, though you may have to take a taxi to the starting point.

headline: A Wholesaler Decides to Abandon His Most Profitable Sales Channel
text: Last week, we published a case study about an entrepreneur, new to the furniture business, who had expanded his business selling patio and deck furniture to $7 million in annual sales. Instead of selling through sales representatives, Gerald Shvartsman, founder and chief executive of Source Outdoor, which is based in Miami, employed a multichannel sales strategy.

headline: Cancers Share Gene Patterns, Studies Affirm
text: Scientists have discovered that the most dangerous cancer of the uterine lining closely resembles the worst ovarian and breast cancers, providing the most telling evidence yet that cancer will increasingly be seen as a disease defined primarily by its genetic fingerprint rather than just by the organ where it originated.

headline: Striking a Pose Above the Clouds
text: No wonder travelers are bent out of shape.

headline: Gun Law Proponents Focus Ads on 2 Senators
text: WASHINGTON — With members of Congress back in their home states for recess this week, activists pushing for tougher gun laws are hitting two senators with new appeals on television, asking them to change their votes.

headline: How to Weaken a President
text: Republicans came up with all kinds of convoluted and made-up explanations for voting against gun background checks, and some are starting to do the same for the immigration bill. A few are even using the Boston bombing as an excuse. But for many lawmakers, the real reason is depressingly familiar. They don’t want to give President Obama anything he wants.

headline: Gulp (Don’t Gag): Modeling the Complexity of the Digestive System
text: The Times’s Quentin Hardy talks with Mary Roach about her new book, “Gulp: Adventures on the Alimentary Canal.”

headline: Time Warner Revenue Is Flat, Despite Cable Gains
text: Sluggishness at Time Warner’s magazine and movie divisions partly offset gains at its cable television networks, leading to virtually flat revenue and a 13 percent increase in operating income in the first three months of the year.

headline: For Ramirez Hidalgo, Little Glamour but a Lot of Tennis
text: He is 35, a father and wears his cap backward on the court. He is also the oldest man in the Top 100 on the professional tour.

headline: Showing Grass-Roots Support for Immigration Overhaul
text: Tens of thousands of immigrants, Latinos and other supporters of an overhaul of the immigration system turned out on Wednesday for marches, rallies and prayer vigils, hoping to show Congress that momentum is building for a path to citizenship for 11 million immigrants in the country illegally.

headline: ‘Like an Oozing Brownie’
text: We’re imagining sinking a fork into the warm, soft molten chocolate cake described by Mark Bittman in his Eat column this week. The column outlines a three-course menu for Mother’s Day, simple for novice cooks to pull off. The dessert is a version of a recipe by Jean-Georges Vongerichten, who helps Mr. Bittman make these small cakes in fluted molds.

headline: A No-Hitter So Rare It Took 6 Pitchers
text: On June 11, 2003, Roy Oswalt, the ace of the Houston Astros’ pitching staff, had to leave a game against the Yankees with a groin pull after the first inning. The Yankee Stadium crowd sat back and waited for the runs to pile up, figuring that the powerful Yankees lineup — Alfonso Soriano, Derek Jeter, Jason Giambi, Jorge Posada, Hideki Matsui — had the whole game to wear out the Astros’ bullpen.

headline: Girl’s Bones Bear Signs of Cannibalism by Starving Virginia Colonists
text: Archaeologists excavating a trash pit at the Jamestown colony site in Virginia have found the first physical evidence of cannibalism among the desperate population, corroborating written accounts left behind by witnesses. Cut marks on the skull and skeleton of a 14-year-old girl show that her flesh and brain were removed, presumably to be eaten by the starving colonists during the harsh winter of 1609.

headline: Survey Shows Strong Support for Fuel Efficiency Standards
text: A new survey has found that consumers want more fuel efficient cars and also support the new federal fuel economy standards that the federal government plans to reach by 2025.

headline: Nicolas Ghesquière’s Balenciaga Legacy
text: Suddenly there’s a deluge of Nicolas Ghesquière stories. Well, two, but they are meaty, reflective accounts on his departure last year from Balenciaga, his views on the state of fashion, and some hints about his future.

headline: With Initiative, Attorney General Focuses on New York’s Pets
text: ALBANY — Last year, the state attorney general’s office sued an animal hospice center in Delaware County that had been accused of neglect for failing to file required financial reports.

headline: In the Alps of Goethe and James Bond
text: We were hiking in fog and drizzle up the barren slopes of Mount Schilthorn, a 9,748-foot-high peak overlooking the Lauterbrunnen Valley in Switzerland. As I inched along a narrow trail, the mist cleared to reveal a long drop on either side into a boulder-strewn abyss. My legs wobbled; my feet slithered over the soggy ground. I reached out to grasp what seemed like a taut rope line, only to feel it sag beneath my trembling fist. Then the trail widened, I steadied myself, and continued my arduous climb toward the summit.

headline: More Forceful Fed Stands by Stimulus
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve said Wednesday that its economic stimulus campaign would press forward at the same pace it has maintained since December, putting to rest for now any suggestion that it was leaning toward doing less.

headline: French Efforts to Block Sale of Stake in Video Site to Yahoo Are Criticized
text: The government of President François Hollande has expressed its objections to plans by Yahoo to buy a controlling stake in the video-sharing site DailyMotion, which is owned by France Télécom, in an effort to keep one of the country’s most successful technology start-ups out of foreign hands.

headline: Yoga After 50
text: While many yoga classes across the country seem to cater to the youthful enthusiast who wants to sweat his or her way through an hour-and-a-half workout, a growing number of longtime yoga devotees are raising questions about the best way to safely continue a yoga practice into midlife and beyond.

headline: Properties for $5.9 Million
text: Homes include a gated Spanish-style house in Pacific Palisades, Calif.; a midcentury modern outside Boulder, Colo.; and a brick traditional in Charlottesville, Va.

headline: What You Get for ... $5.9 Million
text: PACIFIC PALISADES, CALIF.

headline: Income Guarantee Swells Crop Insurance
text: WASHINGTON — The worst drought in 50 years led to record payouts from a taxpayer-subsidized insurance program created to protect farms from weather-related disasters. But the high costs were mostly a result of policies that guarantee farmers a portion of their projected revenue, rather than coverage that pays them for their damaged crops, according to a study released Wednesday.

headline: Racing Industry Eager to See Bill Allowing Usada Oversight
text: Horse racing industry officials said Wednesday that they were eager to see proposed federal legislation that would give the United States Anti-Doping Agency the authority to create a regulatory plan with meaningful penalties to clean up the sport.

headline: A Study in Chinoiserie Dating to the 18th Century
text: A princess was the first occupant of this five-bedroom brick home, called the Pagoda. Its owners are entertaining offers of at least $4.54 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... London
text: A CHINESE-STYLE HISTORIC HOME IN SOUTHEAST LONDON

headline: Fighting Corruption in China, One Special License Plate at a Time
text: HANGZHOU, China — A photograph in the official newspaper of the People’s Liberation Army over the weekend showed a grinning military officer standing proudly in his green uniform, as if he had single-handedly repelled a foreign invasion.

headline: Criminal Complaints Against Additional Suspects in the Boston Marathon Bombings
text: Court documents related to the additional suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings.

headline: With Upgrade, Headphones Have New Sound, and New Parts
text: Sol Republic, maker of headphones with swappable parts, recently expanded its offerings with the release of its Master Tracks line, which incorporates over-ear headphones for the first time.

headline: ‘Wagonmasters’ Celebrates the Classic American Dream Through Station Wagons
text: Do you remember the last time you saw someone driving their family around in a gargantuan American station wagon as if they meant it? I’m not talking about a college student driving a load of friends around in granny’s hand-me-down or that weird neighbor who’s all “cold dead hands” about his ultimate suburban driving machine. No, I mean run-of-the-mill families of 4.5 who drive to schools, jobs and doctor appointments with mom and dad up front, a surly teenager or two in the back seat and one to one-and-a-half children way in the back, bouncing around on the rear-facing fold down, making faces at people through the back glass.

headline: Shorter Forms for Coverage Under New Health Law
text: Banks and mortgage lenders have made strides in simplifying their disclosure forms so consumers can more easily understand the types of fees and terms they are getting.

headline: New Album From the Civil Wars
text: The Civil Wars will release a follow-up this summer to the duo’s Grammy-winning debut album “Barton Hollow,” but they provided no hint about whether they would reunite or go on tour.

headline: Telecom Investor Named to Be F.C.C. Chairman
text: WASHINGTON — Tom Wheeler, President Obama’s pick to be the next chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, knows all about the most advanced telecommunications systems — of the 19th century.

headline: The Interior Performance Art
text: What is the sound of two heads reading?

headline: N.H.L. Stadium Series Announces Date in Chicago
text: The Chicago Blackhawks and the Pittsburgh Penguins will face off in a regular-season matchup at Soldier Field on March 1, 2014, as part of an expanded set of N.H.L. outdoor games next season.

headline: Online, Everyone Can Be a Makeup Critic
text: Matin Maulawizada, a makeup artist based in New York, used to spend hours prowling department stores’ beauty floors to find out what was new and noteworthy. Now, Mr. Maulawizada, the global artistry director for Laura Mercier, likes to log on to Pampadour.com, a sleek new beauty-focused social network, to see what products colleagues are using — or, in the company’s parlance, “pamping.” “It really saves me time,” Mr. Maulawizada said.

headline: Window Dressing | Tsumori Chisato
text: Attention, Tsumori Chisato devotees: The Paris-based Japanese designer, who’s earned a dedicated following for her whimsical prints and graceful use of manga, is making a rare New York appearance tomorrow evening. She’ll be hosting a cocktail party at Kisan, the SoHo boutique owned by the Icelandic-French couple Thorunn Anspach and Olivier Bremond. In honor of Tsumori’s visit, the two have created a special window display that showcases her Arizona-themed spring collection, pictured above, which was inspired by a visit to Sedona and includes references to the work of the artist Georgia O’Keefe. Tsumori, a tireless traveler who just returned from Italy, says that she is always on the lookout for fresh ideas for her designs. In New York, she’ll be “walking the streets and feeling the very unique atmosphere,” though she’s mainly looking forward to meeting her fans. “That makes my day!” she says. “Every time I meet a woman wearing my clothes I can tell she feels good in them.”

headline: New Home Planned for Los Angeles County Museum of Art
text: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art is planning to build a new home for itself on Wilshire Boulevard, designed by the Pritzker Prize-winning architect Peter Zumthor, The Los Angeles Times reported on Wednesday.

headline: Building Blocks All in a Row
text: GREAT FASHION doesn’t start from the bottom so much as from the outside — kids with ideas and dreams and no clear path to the center. The hungriest of them will study anything they can get their hands on, a bunch of eager would-bes trying to figure out how things work on the inside, faking it until they make it.

headline: Canon Powershot N
text: This new 12-megapixel camera is designed to compete with cellphone cameras.

headline: For Playoffs, Seven Isn’t Necessarily the Best Number
text: It was a perfect snapshot of the drama, pressure and excitement of the N.B.A. playoffs, but it was ultimately meaningless.

headline: The Testament of Toibin: A Tony Nod, and a Closing Notice
text: The Irish writer Colm Toibin was shaving in his bathroom on Tuesday morning, and savoring the news that his “Testament of Mary” had just been nominated for a best play Tony Award, when the telephone rang. The voice on the other end said, “I have Scott Rudin on the line for you.” And so began one of the more surreal phone conversations that Mr. Toibin ever had: He was a freshly minted Tony nominee, but his producer Mr. Rudin was telling him that the play would close on Sunday, after only 43 performances and far earlier than planned, due to poor ticket sales.

headline: A Camera Takes On the Phones
text: Technologies come and go in waves. And lately, the waves are coming and going faster.

headline: Uncertainty Still Clouds Health Care Law
text: Three years after President Obama signed the health care reform law, there are concerns that the process of implementing it will be rocky. Even some of the law’s supporters are worried.

headline: Ticketmaster Accuses 21 of Fraudulent Ticket Buying
text: Ticketmaster, trying to fight the computer tactics used by some of the most advanced ticket scalpers, has sued 21 people, accusing them of fraud and breach of copyright in circumventing the company’s online security system to try to buy huge numbers of tickets.

headline: Does Depression Contribute to Dementia?
text: A large body of research has linked late-life depression to social isolation, poorer health and an increased risk of death. Now, a new study finds that depression is associated with subsequent vascular dementia and Alzheimer’s disease, conditions poised to expand dramatically with the aging population.

headline: HBO Orders Third Season of ‘Veep’
text: Who needs to wait another three years to choose America’s second-in-command? Not HBO, that’s for sure: on Wednesday, that cable network announced it was ordering a third season of “Veep,” its comedy series starring Julia Louis-Dreyfus as the vice president of the United States. In its first season in 2012, “Veep,” created by Armando Iannucci (the author of the political satires “The Thick of It” and “In the Loop”) was an Emmy nominee for outstanding comedy; Ms. Louis-Dreyfus, an Emmy winner for her performances on “Seinfeld” and “The New Adventures of Old Christine,” earned her third such award for portraying the “Veep” title character, Selina Meyer. “Veep” was just three episodes into its second season (which started on April 14) when HBO announced its latest renewal. The network said a third season of 10 episodes will be shown next year.

headline: The Players Meet Those Who Play Them
text: Every year, it seems, someone makes a big to-do over the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner and how it has been overrun with celebrities. (This year, Tom Brokaw and Barbara Walters criticized the event’s star turn.) It’s safe to say they didn’t make it to the annual after-party hosted by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Vanity Fair magazine.

headline: Up Close to Entice
text: Outtakes is a behind-the-scenes glimpse of images in the Dining section. Andrew Scrivani (@AndrewScrivani on Twitter and Instagram) is a freelance photographer and a regular contributor to The New York Times. He writes the blog making SundaySauce.

headline: High Line Decides to Drop Planned Fee for Visits to Final Section
text: The High Line announced on Wednesday that it had begun taking online reservations, at thehighline.org, for visits to the last undeveloped section of the rail line, between West 30th and 34th Streets, where for the next year seven sculptures by the artist Carol Bove will be on view. The High Line originally planned to charge $6 for a visit but decided on Monday to make reservations free.

headline: Goldman Names New Head of Special Situations Group
text: Goldman Sachs has named a new head of its global special situations group, the elite division that invests in and lends to companies.

headline: Michael Bublé Hits No. 1 With ‘To Be Loved’
text: Michael Bublé stormed to the top of the Billboard 200 chart on Wednesday with his new album “To Be Loved” (Reprise), which sold 195,000 copies and gave the Canadian crooner his fourth No. 1 set.

headline: At Least Five Protesters Arrested in May Day Demonstration
text: The police arrested at least five people on Wednesday afternoon as a group of protesters marched from Tompkins Square Park to Union Square in a May Day demonstration meant to criticize capitalism.

headline: Emmy Nomination for Elmo Puppeteer Who Resigned
text: Kevin Clash, who resigned from “Sesame Street” last year amid allegations that he had sexual relationships with minors, found himself back in the news on Wednesday after receiving a daytime entertainment Emmy nomination for his role as the show’s popular Elmo character.

headline: China Is Seen Nearing U.S.’s Military Power in Region
text: TOKYO — China’s growing industrial might is likely to allow it to mount an increasingly formidable challenge to the military supremacy of the United States in the waters around China that include Japan and Taiwan, though it will probably seek to avoid an outright armed conflict, according to a detailed new report by a group of American researchers.

headline: Valdespin Turns on a Pitch and Likes How It Feels
text: MIAMI — Jordany Valdespin had always been a full-time player. Whether it was as a young outfielder in the Dominican Republic or rising through the minor leagues, he was accustomed to taking the field for nine innings. Nobody, he said, wants to spend all game sitting on the bench.

headline: Not Everything Is Political
text: Brad DeLong directs me to a screed by Clive Crook, who sort of admits that I’ve been right about a lot of things but accuses me of being, well, shrill. Where have I heard that before?

headline: Mobile Ads Help Propel Earnings at Facebook
text: SAN FRANCISCO — This time last year, just before Facebook made its public debut, the social network did not show a single advertisement on its mobile applications. And over time, the cries from investors about its mobile strategy grew louder and louder.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Facebook Beheadings and Privacy Champions
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Scouting Report
text: Openings and Events

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Turkey, Indonesia, Chile and Nepal.

headline: Would Anna Settle for a Safety Pin?
text: IT IS HARD ENOUGH for famous people to decide what to wear to the annual Costume Institute gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, fashion’s party of the year, even though Anna Wintour has been known to offer advice. But imagine the pressure facing guests at this year’s ball, on May 6, where the theme, as you might have heard, will be punk.

headline: No Vote Needed on Abortion Bill, G.O.P. Leader Says
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is still hoping to pass the whole of his 10-point Women’s Equality Act during the closing weeks of the 2013 legislative session, which ends in late June. But on Wednesday, the State Senate Republican leader suggested that his conference would not support any effort to bring a key part of the act — a state safeguard of federally recognized abortion rights — to a vote.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: The beauty buzz is all about bees these days. Honey has long been a staple in cosmetics, with Perlier and Laura Mercier making well-loved bath items that contain it. But now other products of the hive, like pollen, venom and royal jelly, are being used as well, and increasingly in creams and serums for the face. Their salubrious properties supposedly include increasing blood circulation, as well as plumping and hydrating the skin. If all else fails, at least you’ll smell sweet.

headline: Year After Resignation, Virginia Quarterly Review Names an Editor
text: More than a year after Ted Genoways resigned as the editor of the Virginia Quarterly Review, the literary journal has named a successor.

headline: British Stars of Yesteryear Are Ensnared in Sexual Offenses Inquiry
text: LONDON — The suspects include a flamboyant pop star, a sharp-tongued comedian, a disc jockey known as “the hairy cornflake” and a quirky Australian-born entertainer who performed at the queen’s diamond jubilee concert. Most are in their 70s or 80s, and most are, or were, household names — celebrities from a bygone era.

headline: A Google Duo and a Media Maven Explore a Hyper-Connected Planet
text: After a goofy introductory chat about the White House Correspondents’ Dinner, this Times Talks conversation involving media columnist David Carr and Eric Schmidt and Jared Cohen of Google, co-authors of “The New Digital Age: Reshaping the Future of People, Nations and Business,” becomes a fascinating walk through the emerging Knowosphere:

headline: Medicaid Access Increases Use of Care, Study Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Come January, millions of low-income adults will gain health insurance coverage through Medicaid in one of the farthest-reaching provisions of the Obama health care law. How will that change their finances, spending habits, use of available medical services and — most important — their health?

headline: Abroad as Her Father Lay Dying
text: Jan Benzel, an editor with The International Herald Tribune in Paris, had one of those impossibly painful decisions to make.

headline: Boîte
text: The modern fixation with speakeasy culture can be traced to Milk & Honey, a clandestine bar that Sasha Petraske opened in 2000, behind an unmarked door with an unlisted phone number on the Lower East Side. Among the novelties now considered the norm: Bars could take reservations. Bars could have rules (No. 1: “No name dropping”). And cocktails could cost $16.

headline: Prom is Easy. The ‘Ask’ Takes Planning.
text: It was almost midnight, and I was perched next to my teenage son at his computer. He was frantically searching the Internet for a Web site that could produce custom Chinese fortune cookies — in 48 hours. Finally he hit upon a company called Tankinz Inc., and his fingers flew over the keys, “Lizzie, will you go to the prom with me?”

headline: Irish Proposal Would Allow Abortions in Emergencies
text: DUBLIN — The Irish government proposed legislation late Tuesday night that, if approved as expected, would allow abortions in cases where a threat existed to a woman’s life, including from suicide.

headline: Doomed, but Still Dedicated to Verdi
text: Extreme deprivation, degradation and abuse are not easily evoked in a concert setting, with relatively comfortable musicians performing for well-fed and highly perfumed listeners. But the conductor Murry Sidlin made a remarkable attempt on Monday in his “Defiant Requiem,” a “concert-drama” presented at Avery Fisher Hall by the UJA-Federation of New York, with ticket sales and sponsorships to benefit Holocaust survivors.

headline: He’s Back From the Dead, With So Much More to Do
text: In Stephen Petronio’s “Like Lazarus Did,” dance is preceded by the stillness of death. As you enter the Joyce Theater, where the hourlong work had its debut on Tuesday, the choreographer is already on stage, lying on his back in a dark suit, corpselike, his eyes closed, the soles of his bare feet gilded with gold paint.

headline: Two Pleas for Sanity in Judging Saneness
text: This month a new edition of the “Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders,” the so-called bible of psychiatry, will be released into the world. This revision, known as the D.S.M.-5, is hovering already on Amazon, its cover an appalling shade of purple, available for advance order at a hardcover price of $189.

headline: On the Aesthetics of the Animated GIF
text: How many hours have I spent looking at loops of acrobatic cats, snowboard stunts, the human insanity recorded by Russian dashboard cameras? The answer, I’m afraid, is many.

headline: Photos Show Vast Destruction of Nigerian Homes in Raid, Group Says
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — Satellite images corroborate the accounts of residents of a fishing village north of here who say that thousands of their homes were destroyed by fire during a recent storm of violence carried out by rampaging soldiers, according to Human Rights Watch.

headline: Speaking of Getting It Wrong
text: My heart goes out to Brad DeLong, who debated Alan Reynolds and discovered that his opponent really doesn’t understand at all how either fiscal or monetary policy work.

headline: Emotional Tugs, Real and Fictional
text: Delicately balanced between fact and fiction, Song Fang’s “Memories Look at Me,” contemplates dying by honoring the living.

headline: G.M. and Mountain Dew Drop Ads After Criticism
text: Both General Motors and Mountain Dew withdrew advertisements on Wednesday after receiving criticism that the ads were racially offensive.

headline: A Novella Emerges Tweet by Tweet
text: With the release of “Side Effects” earlier this year, Steven Soderbergh’s retirement from filmmaking (at least for the big screen), announced in 2011, finally took effect. Liberation might be a better word, since his recent activities seem to belong to a restless person newly freed from the constraints of his profession, rather than a used-up man at rest.

headline: In Store | A Poolside Pop-Up Shop at the Standard Hollywood
text: After a long Canadian winter, the Montreal travel brand Want Les Essentials de la Vie headed south to design a warm-weather-themed temporary boutique in a white-box space next to the pool deck of the Standard Hollywood. The shop, called Poolside, features rattan rugs, beach balls galore and a vintage summer Olympics poster — a perfect setting for Want’s new collection of unisex bags in sea- and sky-inspired colors and natural materials. Dexter and Byron Peart, the twin brothers behind the company, say they strive to design their products so that they’ll fit any lifestyle. “We have a gold and silver zipper on each bag,” Dexter says. “This represents the intersection between structured and relaxed, young and old, men and women.”

headline: The Newest Russia House
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — A few weeks ago, as Valery Gergiev and his Mariinsky Orchestra tested the acoustics of their new $700 million theater here, they played one of the most dramatic selections in the symphonic repertory: the rousing finale of Mahler’s Fifth Symphony.

headline: Yeh Brothers Cup in Yokohama, Japan
text: A few experts — very few — are willing to back their judgment at the table in making what seem on paper to be very much anti-percentage plays. But they are right far more often than not.

headline: Favorites Draw Outside Posts for Derby
text: Orb, the Florida Derby winner trained by Shug McGaughey was made the morning line favorite at 7-2 odds and will start the Kentucky Derby on Saturday from the No. 16 post, the same position Animal Kingdom started from when he won in 2011.

headline: A Score or More of Languages in Your Pocket
text: In Douglas Adams’s “The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy,” the hero sticks a so-called Babel fish in his ear and can understand everything said to him in any language. Today’s apps for language translation try to accomplish the same thing. While not as accurate or instantaneous, they are nevertheless useful and greatly improved from just a couple of years ago. And you don’t have to put anything slimy in your ear.

headline: Becoming a Williamsburg Hipster
text: A writer wanted to see what the demographic behind nanobatched chervil and the continually cited show “Girls” could teach him about life and craft cocktails.

headline: Views of an Adopted Nation in Sharp, Colorful Focus
text: America is a large country, but it looked larger yet on Tuesday night on the stage at New York City Ballet. Its spring season is dedicated to American music, and its opening night presented successive visions of this country that were all enthralling and extraordinary. By turns charming, shamelessly exuberant, romantic, enigmatic, bright and dark: a spectrum of views emerged during the course of four ballets, all of which were choreographed by George Balanchine between 1954 and 1970. Few ballets made in subsequent years have proved so unusual and compelling.

headline: The Digital Stage for Six-Second Zingers
text: What’s the point of a comedy festival on Twitter when every day is a comedy festival on Twitter?

headline: In Vain Pursuit of That 15 Minutes
text: Everyone of a certain age sees life as a reality show, and maybe that’s right: the urge toward documentation is greater than ever, and with Twitter, Tumblr, Instagram, Vine, Snapchat and more, it’s easier than ever.

headline: A Mariinsky Addition
text: The new $700-million, 2,000-seat theater formally opens on Thursday with a gala concert.

headline: Rearranging the Furniture, Minus the Aching Back
text: If you’ve ever sat on your couch and wondered how it would look across the room, or whether the walls would look good in red, that was your inner interior designer speaking. Now apps offer a quick and powerful way to indulge your home design fantasies.

headline: Fighting Global Poverty, One Mosh Pit at a Time
text: When the Global Poverty Project staged a benefit concert with Neil Young, the Black Keys and Foo Fighters in Central Park last fall, skeptics wondered if that nonprofit’s attempt to generate pressure on world leaders to help the poor would fade as soon as the amplifiers and guitars were put away.

headline: How I Became a Hipster
text: You know you’re in hipster Brooklyn when someone who looks like a 19th-century farmer tells you that his line of work is “affinity marketing.”

headline: Come as You Were
text: The year was 1992; the scene, a fitting at Calvin Klein, where Nadja Auermann, the 6-foot fashion Valkyrie, was trying on the nude-tone slip dress she was to model on Mr. Klein’s runway. “She totally filled it out in this voluptuous way,” recalled Nian Fish, whose job as creative director of the KCD public relations agency was to oversee the proceedings.

headline: Tiling 102: The Bathroom Floor
text: What’s practical, durable and a pain in the knees?

headline: Shopping for Espresso Cups
text: Giulio Cappellini, the art director of the Italian furniture company Cappellini, goes shopping for cups for serving his favorite hot drink.

headline: The Home Workshop Gets an Upgrade
text: Inside hacker spaces, where inventors and electronic tinkerers share tools and knowledge.

headline: Espresso Cups
text: Giulio Cappellini has a knack for identifying the design stars of tomorrow. As the art director of the Italian furniture company Cappellini, he was an early supporter of emerging talents like Jasper Morrison, Tom Dixon and Marc Newson in the 1980s, long before they became giants in the field.

headline: One Big Workbench
text: Under different circumstances, or in some earlier America, Yair Silbermintz might have spent his weekday evenings tinkering with a soldering iron alone in the basement of a suburban ranch house.

headline: Carrying a Torch
text: Scenes from a three-day design-build camp.

headline: Lessons in How to Play With Fire
text: AUSTIN, TEX. — Jack Sanders discovered the Newbern Tigers, a century-old sandlot baseball club from the tiny town of Newbern, Ala., one spring weekend in 1998. He was in his second year at the Rural Studio, the breakaway design-build program at Auburn University run by Samuel Mockbee, which paired architecture students with the state’s poorest residents (mostly citizens of Newbern) to create houses and community projects as individual as the folks they were made for.

headline: In a Creative Season, a New Design Fair
text: On May 8, 23 exhibitors will gather on Pier 57 in Hudson River Park for the first Collective design fair. The event, which coincides with the Frieze Art Fair and a gang of Impressionist and Modern art auctions, inaugurates a vigorous two weeks of art and design activity in New York that includes the International Contemporary Furniture Fair and satellite shows. Steven Learner, 52, the architect and designer who started Collective (known as Collective.1 in its first iteration), made a trip uptown to discuss it.

headline: Bespoke Chandeliers Inspired by Bees
text: Last week, Guerlain, the French perfume company, opened a boutique and learning center in La Cour des Senteurs on the Rue de la Chancellerie in Versailles, a hundred yards from the main entrance of the royal chateau. Suspended from the shop’s 22-foot-high arched entrance is a frothy chandelier by Marie Christophe, a sculptor in Toulouse. Ms. Christophe said the light was inspired by the chandeliers of the palace and by the gilded bees on vintage Guerlain bottles. Its wire frame is hung with crystals, some from flea markets and some made by contemporary artisans and embedded with gold paper. The LED chandelier is 7 feet high and 4 feet in diameter and sells for $60,000 through the design retailer Lisa Fontanarosa. Custom sizes are available. Information: (505) 872-1929 or lisafontanarosa.com.

headline: Designing Small Tables for the Big Leagues
text: It was the last day of the Hospitality Design show in Las Vegas three years ago when Chris Hardy ventured into the Design Within Reach booth with his portfolio in hand. There, he stumbled on John Edelman, the company’s chief executive. As a result, Mr. Hardy, a designer in Atlanta, found himself on a short list of hopefuls asked to submit ideas for small tables. He was among those who prevailed, and now his Helix side tables and coffee tables are ready for market. They feature asymmetrical walnut- and cast-bronze bases topped by glass. “The brass not only stabilizes the base but creates a nice movement out from the center, with a layered effect,” said Mr. Hardy, 29. The side table comes with a round top ($1,400), while the coffee table is available with a round or square top ($2,200) or an oval one ($2,400). The tables are at DWR Studios nationwide. Information: (800) 944-2233 or dwr.com.

headline: An Oasis From Everything but Mosquitoes
text: A haven from hectic Ho Chi Minh City.

headline: Where Coconuts Come Calling
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — To Peter Arts and Hedwig Pira, it doesn’t feel all that long since they uprooted themselves from a comfortable existence in their native Belgium and took on the formidable task of building a business, a house and a life in a foreign country.

headline: Carving Nature into a Canvas of Wool
text: Two years ago, Angela Adams, a rug designer in Portland, Me., began using scissors and sheep shears to carve shapes into tufted wool. The second generation of this experiment, a collection called Landscape, is being introduced this week. Ms. Adams described the sculptural rugs as “literal translations of nature,” inspired by her favorite places: “open areas in the woods; a garden in July with big bold bursts of color everywhere; a nice beach I like; and what it feels like to be on the water at night.” The rugs are made in Thailand of hand-tufted New Zealand wool. They are available in four designs (Woodland, Garden, Harbor and Dune) and three sizes (9 by 11 feet for $12,000, 3 by 8 feet for $2,200 and 8-feet round for $8,000). Information: (800) 255-9454 or angelaadams.com.

headline: Clutter Cleverly Put in Its Place
text: Henrybuilt, a Seattle manufacturer of custom kitchens, has plenty of experience helping buyers manage countertop clutter. Now it’s moving on to the rest of the home. The company’s new Opencase Storage System is designed to work in an entry hall, library, office, pantry, closet, laundry room or child’s room, among other places, thanks to an assortment of interchangeable attachments.

headline: Sales at Judy Ross, Doris Leslie Blau and Others
text: Judy Ross is having a sample sale through Sunday, with up to 70 percent off many pillows and rugs (an 18-inch-square hand-embroidered Landscape pillow, shown, regularly $195, is $80; a 6-by-9-foot Tabla hand-knotted Tibetan wool rug, regularly $5,940, is $2,800); 22 East 17th Street, Suite 536, (212) 842-1705, judyrosstextiles.com.

headline: New York Times/CBS News Poll on Gun Control, Immigration and the Federal Budget
text: In a New York Times/CBS Poll conducted April 24-April 28, Americans were asked about their views on gun control, immigration and the federal budget.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 24 through April 28 with 965 adults throughout the United States.

headline: Americans’ Unity on Big Issues Doesn’t Bridge Partisan Gap
text: While the public overwhelmingly supports background checks for gun buyers and a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants, Americans largely retreat into their partisan camps when asked whether President Obama or Congressional Republicans will make the right decisions on those and other domestic issues facing the nation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: U.S. to Defend Age Limits on Morning-After Pill Sales
text: The Obama administration moved Wednesday to keep girls under 15 from having over-the-counter access to morning-after pills, as the Justice Department filed a notice to appeal a judge’s order that would make the drug available without a prescription for girls and women of all ages.

headline: Americans on Obama, Guns and Immigration
text: The Times’s Richard L. Berke and Ashley Parker break down the latest New York Times/CBS News poll and find a disconnect between ideology and political support.

headline: Americans on Domestic Policy
text: The results of a poll by The New York Times and CBS News asking Americans their views on immigration, gun control, and other policy issues.

headline: ING’s U.S. Unit Prices Its Market Debut Below Expectations
text: The American arm of the Dutch financial services firm ING Group priced its initial public offering at $19.50 a share, below its expected range of $21 to $24.

headline: Baby Toys Get an App Extension
text: As more of the very young reach for their parents’ smartphones, toy companies are responding with motion-sensing, app-infused toys like the Fisher-Price Apptivity Gym ($35, www.fisher-price.com).

headline: Court Dismisses Craigslist Suit Against Competitors
text: Craigslist does not have exclusive licenses to the postings on its classified advertising Web site, a federal court ruled on Tuesday.

headline: Boeing Moves to Upgrade Popular 777 Passenger Jet
text: Boeing’s sales force is starting to pitch airlines and jet leasing companies on an updated, larger version of its 777 passenger jet, a crucial step toward winning approval from Boeing’s board to build the plane, Boeing officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Quinn Announces Another Effort to Make Parking Meters More User-Friendly
text: There is a line from Bob Dylan, perhaps history’s most prolific purveyor of misinterpreted lyrics, that reads: “Don’t follow leaders, watch the parking meters.”

headline: May Day Protests Around the World
text: Workers around the globe observed the international holiday with demonstrations and rallies.

headline: Supporters Rally for Immigration Overhaul
text: Tens of thousands of immigrants, Latinos and other supporters of an overhaul of the immigration system turned out on Wednesday.

headline: Custodians of Rules Say Woods Made Error
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — It is the drop that nobody in the golf world seems able to, well, drop. On Wednesday, the sport’s ruling bodies issued their interpretation of Tiger Woods’s rules violation at the Masters, 19 days later.

headline: Subway Delays Were Up in 2012, a Group Finds
text: Almost immediately after Hurricane Sandy delivered unprecedented flooding to New York City’s subway system, transit officials predicted that train delays could increase in the months and even years that followed.

headline: Youkilis, Now on D.L., Gets Diagnosis and Epidural
text: Kevin Youkilis revealed Wednesday that a bulging L4 disk in his spine was the cause of his back pain, forcing him onto the disabled list and necessitating an epidural.

headline: Amid Fealty to Socialism, a Nod to Capitalism
text: HAVANA — In many ways, it was a typical May Day: Hundreds of thousands of Cuban workers — doctors, sailors, dancers, bank clerks — marched Wednesday toward this city’s vast Revolution Plaza, waving flags, holding aloft banners that proclaimed fidelity to socialism and tooting plastic horns.

headline: Viacom and Time Warner Report Lower Revenue
text: Despite strong performances from their cable television channels, Viacom and Time Warner both suffered from sluggishness at their film divisions in the most recent quarter, which hindered the companies’ overall performances.

headline: 13 Years After His Father’s Killing, a Bronx Teenager Meets the Same Fate
text: Two weeks before his fourth birthday, his father was fatally shot leaving a bodega.

headline: Condé Nast Introduces Web Series for Magazines
text: Last year, the latest innovation every magazine wanted to release was an iPad edition. This year, it’s online video content.

headline: Bob Brozman, Guitarist, Is Dead at 59
text: Bob Brozman, a guitarist and self-described “roving guitar anthropologist” who collaborated with musicians from Northern Ireland to Guinea to India to Papua New Guinea, died on April 23 at his home in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 59.

headline: What the Oregon Health Study Can’t Tell
text: The Oregon Health Study — one of the most important public-policy studies of the last decade — released a new round of results on Wednesday, showing that Medicaid coverage does not seem to make low-income adults much healthier, judging by biometric data. At least, that is one fair way to interpret the results, and it is basically the way the authors put it at the top of their new paper.

headline: Trade Policy Notes
text: Just finished the semester (except for the grading); and I did promise to post class notes for WWS543, trade policy. Not all classes included slide shows, but here are the ones that did (for technical reasons, I’ll have to finish a couple of links later this week). All links are pdf.

headline: Orville Slutzky, a Founder of a Ski Resort, Dies at 96
text: Orville Slutzky, who with his brother founded the Hunter Mountain ski resort in upstate New York, known in the 1960s for its celebrity clientele and in the 1970s and ’80s for its unmatched number of snow-making cannons, died on April 18 in Hudson, N.Y. He was 96.

headline: A Commander Seeks to Chart a New Path for Special Operations
text: WASHINGTON — Not long after Adm. William H. McRaven led the mission to kill Osama bin Laden, he was put in charge of the nation’s entire contingent of Special Operations forces, and set to work revamping them to face a widening array of new threats as America’s combat role in the Middle East and southwest Asia winds down.

headline: Is That God Talking?
text: I still remember how startled I was when a young woman I was interviewing told me God had spoken to her, audibly.

headline: U.S. Agency Is Expelled From Bolivia
text: LA PAZ, Bolivia — President Evo Morales expelled the United States Agency for International Development from Bolivia on Wednesday, suggesting that it had conspired against his leftist government.

headline: A Mortgage Agency Pick Is Likely to Cause Conflict
text: President Obama’s overhaul of the mortgage market has been a long time coming.

headline: Who’s Sorry Now
text: Back when Sandra Day O’Connor was still on the Supreme Court, busy saving affirmative action and the right to abortion, liberals who wanted a reason to forgive her vote in Bush v. Gore often asked me — begged me — to assure them that Justice O’Connor was sorry.

headline: Waiting and Waiting ... for Justice
text: LATE in the summer of 2011, police officers in New York City arrested a full-time college student named Luis in the lobby of his apartment building in the Bronx and charged him with two misdemeanor offenses, obstructing governmental administration and resisting arrest.

headline: Cross-Country Solar Plane Expedition Set for Takeoff
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — When Bertrand Piccard was growing up in Switzerland, heady discussions about the boundless potential for human endeavor were standard fare.

headline: A Surprise Favorite for Derby
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Entering Kentucky Derby week, the undefeated Verrazano was expected by many to be the morning-line favorite. But after a blazing workout Monday that had the trainer Shug McGaughey smiling from ear to ear, Orb ran away with that honor when the field was drawn Wednesday.

headline: Cablevision Picks Up Glenn Beck’s Internet Channel
text: Glenn Beck’s Internet channel TheBlaze has been picked up by the cable system operated by Cablevision, giving Mr. Beck television distribution in the New York metropolitan area for the first time since he left Fox News in 2011.

headline: Immigration Is on Agenda for Obama in Mexico
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama flies across the southern border on Thursday to meet with his Mexican counterpart, the most delicate topic on the agenda will be immigration.

headline: Here Comes the Buzz
text: IT may not be as grand as the wildebeest migrations across Africa’s eastern savanna or the march of emperor penguins across miles of Antarctic ice to their inland nesting areas. But it is a wildlife phenomenon not seen elsewhere in the world.

headline: Why I Am Signing Marriage Equality Into Law
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

headline: Defense in Fraud Trial Blames Failed U.S. Effort to Charge Liu
text: Lawyers for two former associates of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, asked a jury on Wednesday to acquit their clients of conspiring in an illegal campaign finance scheme that was to benefit Mr. Liu, now a Democratic candidate for mayor.

headline: Banks Ease Capital Cost of Loans to Brokers
text: To attract financial advisers, brokerage firms often offer them loans. They are loans with a difference, however.

headline: Exorbitant Prices for Leukemia Drugs
text: Last year we were heartened when doctors at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York refused to use an outrageously overpriced drug for treating advanced colorectal cancer because it was no better than a cheaper (but still costly) alternative. Neither did much to extend a patient’s life. Now the revolt against unjustifiably high cancer drug prices has been joined by more than 100 leukemia experts from more than 15 countries.

headline: Preying on Pensioners
text: During the run-up to the mortgage crisis, elderly people were often duped into taking out subprime loans that earned a fortune for the lenders while leaving the borrowers with little or no home equity and headed for foreclosure. A similar brand of wealth stripping is alive and well in a new crop of companies that specialize in separating retirees from their pensions. Unless state and federal regulators get a handle on this problem, ever larger numbers of elderly people who are already battered by the recession will end up even worse off.

headline: Italy’s New Government
text: More than two months after an inconclusive election, Italy at last has a new government, an essential first step on the road to political and economic recovery.

headline: Fairness on Sales Taxes
text: Twenty-one years is a long time to wait. But that is how long local retailers have waited for Congress to undo a 1992 Supreme Court decision that exempted many online retailers, like Amazon.com, from collecting most state sales taxes. The exemption has given online sellers a 5 percent to 10 percent price advantage over Main Street stores.

headline: ‘The Juice,’ the Jousting and the Job
text: During Tuesday’s presidential news conference, Jonathan Karl of ABC News asked the president if he still had “the juice” to get the rest of his agenda through Congress.

headline: Federal Suit Claims Police Distort Marijuana Searches to Create Misdemeanors
text: One man was walking home with groceries. Another was on a break from his job at a meat market. A third was walking down the street listening to headphones.

headline: The Luv Guv’s Last Stand
text: Former South Carolina Gov. Mark Sanford’s fight for post-Appalachian Trail forgiveness ends Tuesday with a big Congressional election. The focus, of course, is on issues, issues, issues.

headline: Taxi-Hailing Apps Blocked by Judge
text: On Wednesday, a day after New York City’s taxi riders were allowed to hail yellow cabs with smartphones for the first time, an appeals court judge temporarily blocked the city’s pilot program for the apps — forcing the Bloomberg administration to delay its plan for the second time in less than two months.

headline: The Right to Speak Out
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mexican Immigrants
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jobs and Fed Policy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama’s Call to Close Guantánamo
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Ethics of Force-Feeding Inmates
text: Is it ethical for nurses and doctors to help force-feed prisoners on hunger strikes, like those at Guantánamo?

headline: Times Names New Editors for Politics and Metro Desk
text: The New York Times on Wednesday named Carolyn Ryan, its metropolitan editor, the paper’s top political editor.

headline: Health Care for the Young
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bloomberg and Police Stops
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Cyberspace, Forever
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
Online Video Woos Madison Avenue
text: During the week-long Digital Content NewFronts, companies like AOL, Hulu and Yahoo present new programming to attract advertising dollars from marketers and agencies.

headline: In the Nets With M.S.
text: ST. PAUL — It happened too fast. Josh Harding, the backup goalie for the Minnesota Wild, never saw starter Niklas Backstrom crumple to the ice during warm-ups Tuesday night. The Wild’s captain, Mikko Koivu, yelled for Harding to take over as trainers helped Backstrom to the dressing room at the United Center in Chicago with an apparent left leg injury.

headline: Web Content Creators Focus on Spanish Speakers
text: For several years, networks and channels with programming aimed at Hispanic viewers have been increasing their presence during the annual television industry ritual known as upfront week, when advertisers and agencies are wooed before the coming fall season. Now, as creators of online video content are seeking the same money from Madison Avenue, they, too, are talking about their efforts to reach Spanish-speaking consumers.

headline: An Effort to Add a Key Ingredient to the Slow Food Movement: Investor Money
text: BOULDER, Colo. — “Welcome, pig lovers, and welcome, earthworms!” Woody Tasch bellowed from the stage of the Boulder Theater, where 650 food entrepreneurs and investors had wedged themselves for the opening day of the fourth Slow Money National Gathering.

headline: Political Chaos Grips Venezuela After Legislative Brawl and Rival Marches
text: LA PAZ, Bolivia — Venezuela stumbled deeper into political chaos this week as legislators brawled in the National Assembly and government supporters and opponents took to the streets for rival marches amid continuing tensions over the narrow election victory of President Nicolás Maduro.

headline: Cellphone Thefts Grow, but the Industry Looks the Other Way
text: When a teenage boy snatched the iPhone out of Rose Cha’s hand at a bus stop in the Bronx in March, she reported the theft to her carrier and to the police — just as she had done two other times when she was the victim of cellphone theft. Again, the police said they could not help her.

headline: Video of Turkmen Leader’s Spectacular Fall Foils Effort to Cover Up Accident
text: The leader of Turkmenistan learned this week just how difficult it can be to maintain a cult of personality in the Internet era, when the official account of his dashing triumph in a horse race on Sunday was undermined by video footage posted on foreign Web sites, showing what state television had failed to mention — the president’s spectacular fall to the track seconds after his horse crossed the finish line.

headline: Crossed by a Center Line
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — I really enjoyed this crunchy, word drop puzzle by Josh Knapp, although it took me a while to tumble to the theme. Thankfully, there’s a very clever reveal in the center of his 15-by-16 grid, and I especially liked the fact that the entry NEITHER/NOR is kind of a whole phrase unto itself even though the complete reveal is NEITHER [HERE] NOR [THERE]. That’s an elegant theme concept right THERE.

headline: Florida Runs Out of Time on Medicaid
text: MIAMI — Prospects for Medicaid expansion in Florida, which was embraced, improbably, by the state’s Republican governor in February, are all but dead this year.

headline: Thumping Barcelona Again, Bayern Eases Into the Final
text: In the end, Barcelona’s mission was indeed impossible.

headline: Libya: 3 Sought for Questioning in Benghazi Attack
text: The F.B.I. on Wednesday released photos of three men whom investigators want to question in connection with the attacks on a United States diplomatic mission and C.I.A. outpost in Benghazi, Libya, last September. A statement by the bureau said the three “were on the grounds of the United States Special Mission when it was attacked.” Four people — including the United States ambassador to Libya — died in the attacks.

headline: Egypt: Critic of Morsi Is Jailed
text: Egyptian authorities jailed an anti-Islamist activist late Tuesday on charges that included insulting President Mohamed Morsi, state news media said. After turning himself in to prosecutors, the activist, Ahmed Douma, was transferred to a prison to be held for four days. Mr. Douma has been a vocal critic of Mr. Morsi and his allies in the Muslim Brotherhood, using social media and joining anti-Islamist protests. Human rights groups have accused Mr. Morsi and his allies of targeting their critics in politically motivated prosecutions — a charge Mr. Morsi’s aides deny.

headline: Court Papers Offer Details in Terror Case
text: The terrorism case landed on the public docket in Federal District Court in Brooklyn last year like a riddle. Prosecutors charged three foreign men arrested overseas with supporting a Somali terrorist group. They did not reveal details of the allegations against the men, their nationalities or even their connections to the United States.

headline: Knicks Leave the Door Open
text: They planned for a funeral, a chance to bury past failures, painful memories and, most of all, the Boston Celtics. It would be a memorial and a celebration all in one, with the Knicks — dressed in black for the occasion — presiding over the last rites at stately Madison Square Garden.

headline: Turned Loose, Ovechkin Once Again Turns Heads
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — Alex Ovechkin was one of the last players on the ice for the Washington Capitals’ first postseason practice Monday, but he quickly made up for any lost time. While his teammates glided in circles around the rink, Ovechkin hit the ice at nearly full speed and dashed toward the first idle puck he saw, slamming it into the back of the vacant net.

headline: In Russian Social Media, Glimpse of Students Accused of Hiding Boston Evidence
text: On April 18, the day before Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was captured as a suspect in the bombings at the Boston Marathon, a friend from the University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth posted photos of them together on VKontakte, the Russian social network.

headline: In Nets-Bulls, Who’s Hurt? Who Isn’t?
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — On the eve of Thursday’s Game 6 of a back-and-forth, battering series between the Nets and the Chicago Bulls, both teams appeared to be surviving on ice, athletic tape and willpower, and not in that particular order.

headline: Guns and Political Suicide
text: Does Bill Daley, a former White House chief of staff, have the right to complain that Heidi Heitkamp, the first-year Democratic Senator from North Dakota, refused to commit political suicide after taking his $2,500 contribution?

headline: Some Retailers Rethink Role in Bangladesh
text: Ever since a building with garment factories collapsed in Bangladesh last week, killing more than 400 people, Western apparel companies with ties to the country have scrambled to address public concerns about working conditions there.

headline: Man Charged After Body Is Dug Up in Queens Yard
text: The search for a missing Queens man took investigators from a Broad Channel bird sanctuary to a Yonkers casino to a trailer on a dirt road in rural West Virginia.

headline: Empty Seats at the State Department
text: Like many other areas of the administration, the State Department has many vacancies in its top ranks. As of the beginning of May, 16 of the department’s 59 top jobs were vacant or filled with men and women performing the duties in an “acting” capacity.

headline: Coach’s Observation Helps Save Yankees
text: Moments before Houston Astros pitcher Wesley Wright threw the pitch, the Yankee first-base coach Mick Kelleher told Lyle Overbay to be careful. Kelleher, a former major league infielder, had noticed something seemingly small, but big enough to determine the outcome of the game.

headline: For North Korea, Another Bargaining Chip?
text: BEIJING — Has North Korea got another American “hostage”? And will a former president have to pack his bags and head to Pyongyang to plead for the hostage’s release?

headline: Parking Rules
text: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday and Friday because of Orthodox Holy Thursday and Good Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: U.S. Rules Bar Aid to Co-ops Hit by Sandy
text: At the Beverly Hills co-op in Brooklyn, the wallpaper in the lobby is peeling by the yard. The walls themselves show cracks and holes, as if assaulted by a sledgehammer. The boiler is barely sputtering along and may not last the year.

headline: Smith Back on Court, but His Shots Are Off
text: J. R. Smith said the word “humble” six times after the Celtics beat the Knicks, 92-86, on Wednesday night in Game 5 of their playoff series. It fit Smith’s demeanor after one of his worst performances of the season.

headline: Lending Web Site Gains a Shareholder in Google
text: A fast-growing marketplace for peer-to-peer loans, Lending Club, has attracted a prominent investor: Google.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, May 2
text: “This is called slave labor.”

text: compliance •\kəm-ˈpli-ən(t)s\• noun
