text: Megan Barringer had no idea that a medical billing mix-up over a $742 charge for a back evaluation six years ago could end up costing her more than $33,000.

headline: Undoing an Honor Code
text: Los Angeles transit officials are planning to institute turnstiles at subway stations to counter years of lost revenue because of an honor system that let unpaid fares go unchecked.

headline: Humorists At The European Commission
text: The EC is many things, but I didn’t think of it as going in for self-mocking sarcasm. But the latest forecast is out; it predicts declining GDP and rising unemployment this year, stabilization next year (but we’ve heard that before), and displays a track record like this:

headline: Party’s On With Our 2013 Kentucky Derby Picks
text: The Rail’s contributors welcome this year’s Kentucky Derby guest picker, Patricia Barnstable-Brown, who each year co-hosts the celebrity-packed Barnstable Brown Gala with her twin sister, Priscilla Barnstable, on the eve of the Derby.

headline: Scenic Views of the Constitution
text: To entice viewers who might be daunted by four hours of television devoted to the Constitution, PBS chose a host known for his comic touch with current events. Producers even put him on a specially decorated Harley-Davidson for jaunts around the country.

headline: Opposition in Tight Race to Take Power in Malaysian Election
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Malaysians will go to the polls on Sunday to decide what appears to be the most closely contested election in their country’s history. Its results will bring either a continuation of decades of leadership by the current government or the nation’s first handover of power.

headline: A Doubleheader at the Met for a Mezzo-Soprano
text: For any opera singer, one performance can be enough to put a strain on her vocal cords. But what about performing two major roles in the same day?

headline: When Medical Billing Errors Weigh on Your Credit Score
text: A single collection action on your credit report can inflict significant damage to your credit score. And that’s the case whether you’re waiting for your insurance company to pay a medical bill that went to collections, or if you’ve simply decided to ignore the bill.

headline: Bryant’s Latest Court Battle: Trying to Stop His Mom’s Auction
text: It has been no secret that Kobe Bryant’s family relationships have gone cold at times, but the latest twist might represent the frostiest moment of all. It seems Bryant’s mother, Pamela Bryant, received a $450,000 advance to auction off some of his memorabilia and Bryant launched a legal fight to stop the auction.

headline: An Unconventional Look at Orthodoxy
text: Rama Burshtein’s new film, “Fill the Void,” takes place in a setting that will be unfamiliar to most viewers: the confined world of the ultra-Orthodox in Israel. In this sphere, gender roles are strictly defined and every aspect of life, from the spiritual to the mundane, is governed by a complex array of laws and customs designed to emphasize the perceived needs of the community over individual desires.

headline: Classical Music Recordings
text: Reynaldo Hahn: Piano Works

headline: Stars’ Picks From Sunny Seasons Past
text: “Stand by Me”

headline: From Ordeal to Fairy Tale, but Not Without Obstacles
text: Russia, where Marc Schleifer spent the better part of a decade after college, is known for its literary tradition of suffering and pessimism. So it was with Mr. Schleifer, whose years there were spent singing in a punk/funk band, Detsky Panadol (Children’s Tylenol, in English) — while working at Moscow law firms and at the Eurasia Foundation.

headline: Treescapes
text: For the past decade, the artist Myoung Ho Lee has been wandering around his native South Korea, shooting trees like some kind of arboreal Avedon, in stark relief against a plain white canvas. His pictures possess the glamour and focus of studio portraits, yet they’re set in the landscape — be it a golden meadow or a cloudy blue sky dotted with balloons. It’s a deceptively simple trick, a way of foregrounding what would ordinarily be background. The purity of the final image belies the incredibly complicated rigging that makes it possible — a process that usually involves industrial cranes, ropes and numerous artisans. Lee, 37, retouches the photographs to erase any trace of his own hand. “If the mechanics of the artwork were visible, it would be easier for people to recognize the scale and the method,” he said. “But I want to hide them, to infuse a magical and vague aspect to my work, so that viewers may question and try to find answers themselves.”

headline: Harden’s Season in a Word: Great
text: Normally, the kind of season that Houston’s James Harden has had would be garnering all kinds of attention and accolades. His combination of raw scoring output, relentless effectiveness, and well-rounded point creation stands with some of the greatest players of the modern era.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Suburbs
text: Apparently it was too much to ask (listen to the lyrics); Win (lead singer) and Regine (drums in this video) just had a baby boy. But congrats — and there’s a new album reportedly coming!

headline: That Old Wildhorn Magic: ‘Jekyll & Hyde’ to Close
text: The producers of the Broadway revival of the musical “Jekyll & Hyde” announced on Friday that the show would come to a premature end, with its final performance on Sunday, May 12, after only 15 previews and 30 regular performances at the Marquis Theater. It was scheduled to run until June 30.

headline: Rose to Gold Makes for an Appealing Underdog Story
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Fans searching for an endearing long shot when the $1 million Kentucky Oaks is run at Churchill Downs Friday may not have to look beyond 15-1 Rose to Gold and jockey Calvin Borel. She was a $1,400 purchase as a yearling who has won 5 of 7 career starts for earnings of $717,889.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A Cos Cob colonial on a cul-de-sac and a restored 1911 lakefront cottage in Ocean Township.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Wonder of Childhood
text: “Marble Season,” by Gilbert Hernandez, arrives at No. 2 on our hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week. Mr. Hernandez is better known for his work on “Love and Rockets,” a critically acclaimed independent comic book series that he worked on primarily with his brother Jaime (and occasionally with their brother Mario). Confession time: “Love and Rockets” is beloved by many, but the parts of the sprawling tale that I’ve read have left me cold. “Marble Season” had the opposite effect. In this semi-autobiographical tale, Mr. Hernandez captures the wonder of childhood — the joy of imagination, an appreciation for comic books and all the ultimately petty but seemingly world-shattering trials and tribulations of friendships during that time in one’s life. The 120-page story is told in six-panel grids that reminded me of Sunday newspaper comic strips, which I devoured in my youth. “Marble Season” is published by Drawn & Quarterly.

headline: Brain, Interrupted
text: TECHNOLOGY has given us many gifts, among them dozens of new ways to grab our attention. It’s hard to talk to a friend without your phone buzzing at least once. Odds are high you will check your Twitter feed or Facebook wall while reading this article. Just try to type a memo at work without having an e-mail pop up that ruins your train of thought.

headline: A Meeting of Two Elizabeths, Not at All Related
text: “All of a Sudden,” the title of the new Jack Ferver show that opened at Abrons Arts Center on Thursday, is a phrase you might use in describing a signature dynamic of any Jack Ferver production. One minute, everything is campy, outrageous, ridiculous, fake, not to be taken seriously. And then — all of a sudden — someone is slapped or spit upon, or real tears seem to flow, and the pain beneath is exposed.

headline: How Diamonds Became Forever
text: Peggy Olson, that emblem of the pioneering ad woman in a man’s world on the television show “Mad Men,” would have been all of 8 years old on the night in 1947 when the real-life copywriter Frances Gerety coined the phrase “A Diamond Is Forever.”

headline: Is There Emergency Contraception in Your Medicine Cabinet?
text: This week, a judge ordered that emergency contraception be available over-the-counter to girls and women of all ages, and the Obama administration announced its intention to appeal that order with respect to girls under 15. The Food and Drug Administration announced that the most widely known morning-after pill, Plan B One-Step, would be available to girls and women ages 15 and older, and that it would be stocked on drugstore shelves, rather than behind the counter. Purchasers will have to show ID to buy the drug.

headline: Sally Bowles Wasn’t Alone
text: It’s evident that Mark Nadler’s “I’m a Stranger Here Myself: Musik From the Weimar and Beyond” has cabaret DNA, but Mr. Nadler has done a thoughtful job of expanding and deepening the piece for its theatrical run at the York Theater Company.

headline: This Woman’s Place Is in Her Kitchen
text: NIEDERMORSCHWIHR, France—It is definitely not a man’s world in the Maison Ferber kitchen in Alsace.

headline: Shakshuka, a Traditional Baked Egg Dish
text: Melissa Clark shows how to make a classic Middle Eastern dish featuring a spicy tomato sauce with eggs baked on top.

headline: A Rich Egg Dish That Satisfies
text: The only time I visited Israel, it was during Passover. Gastronomically, this was not the ideal time, given the dietary restrictions of the holiday. There was no pita bread, no hummus, no falafel. But thankfully, there was shakshuka, eggs baked in fragrant tomato sauce, and a lot of it.

headline: Focusing on Power Play, Nash Aims to End a Skid
text: WASHINGTON — Rick Nash’s career record in the N.H.L. playoffs is 0-5 — four losses with the Columbus Blue Jackets and one with the Rangers — after the Rangers’ 3-1 loss Thursday to the Washington Capitals.

headline: Season Orders and Mixed Ratings for Cable Series
text: Wednesday was a big day for cable television renewals – HBO’s “Veep,” TNT’s “Dallas” and the Sundance Channel’s “Rectify” were all picked up for new seasons that are scheduled to air in 2014. How have those programs fared in the ratings?

headline: Shine Starts to Wear Off a Little for Google Glass
text: The shiny new thing luster of Google Glass may already be wearing off, even before most people have been able to try one on.

headline: 303 Gallery Finds a New Home
text: New York City art galleries tend to move around a lot. But even by those standards, the iconic 303 Gallery has been unusually itinerant. Since it was founded in 1984 at 303 Park Avenue South by its director Lisa Spellman, it has had homes in the East Village and SoHo, and at two addresses in Chelsea. Today, it throws open its brand-new industrial doors at a third Chelsea location, a bilevel space on West 24th Street tucked below the High Line. Designed by the architecture firm StudioMDA for 303, it’s an airy, light-filled space that doubles the gallery’s square footage, with skylights, glass floors and the columns of the High Line running through, all protected by a cast concrete facade.

headline: ‘The New New York’ Ad Campaign
text: New York State has set aside $140 million over the last year-and-a-half for a national advertising campaign. The following commercials were the initial productions of the campaign.

headline: Ad Effort Selling State as a Business Haven Is Criticized
text: ALBANY — The Cuomo administration has set aside nearly $140 million for an advertising campaign called “New York State Open for Business,” with the money drawn largely from a state authority created to lower electricity bills and from federal disaster aid, records show.

headline: Death Toll in Bangladesh Building Collapse Tops 500
text: SAVAR, Bangladesh — The death toll in the Rana Plaza disaster soared to 517 on Friday, as rescue crews spent a 10th day digging through the rubble and investigators continued to interrogate the building’s owner and others arrested in the case.

headline: Visitors From Outer Space, Real or Not, Are Focus of Discussion in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — While President Obama was promoting an immigration overhaul in Mexico, six former members of Congress gathered two blocks from the White House to consider what they see as the enforced government secrecy surrounding another kind of visitor: the kind who come from a lot farther away.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: For home cooks who want to rub elbows with some of the most well-known chefs, the New York Culinary Experience on Saturday and Sunday at the International Culinary Center, 462 Broadway in SoHo, offers a chance to learn from and cook side by side with chefs like Andre Soltner and April Bloomfield. Tickets, at $1,395 per person for the all day affair are limited and can be purchased by calling (646) 314-4413 or e-mailing nyce@nymag.com.

headline: Shakshuka Now or Later
text: In this week’s A Good Appetite column and video, I give a recipe for shakshuka, an Israeli baked egg and tomato dish (with North African roots). I use canned tomatoes since good local tomatoes aren’t available yet. But in season, feel free to substitute chopped juicy tomatoes. You might need to cook the mix down longer (by about 10 or 15 minutes) to reach a thick consistency, but the bright flavor will make the extra time worth it.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: An Unusual Headache Solved
text: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to puzzle their way through the case of a 23-year-old woman who started out with what seemed like her usual migraine but who then became more and more ill. By the time the diagnosis was made, she had double vision and she was shaking and confused. And despite the right diagnosis, there was worse to come.

headline: Queen Esther’s Tale, in Yiddish, With Cartwheels, Puppets and a Union Label
text: Sometimes you could do without the whole megillah. Parts would be just fine.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 3
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

headline: Hip-Hop Producer Recovering After Gunshot Wound During Robbery
text: The hip-hop producer AraabMuzik who was shot in the chest during a a robbery in Providence, R.I., last week remains hospitalized, the police said.

headline: Do-Not-Track Talks Could Be Running Off the Rails
text: After nearly two years of negotiating and little progress, the international group trying to agree on a Do Not Track standard is convening its final official face-to-face meeting next week in Sunnyvale, Calif.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 3
text: More photographs.

headline: Occidental Chairman Agrees to Step Down Ahead of Schedule
text: Conceding to a shareholder revolt, Occidental Petroleum’s longtime chairman, Ray R. Irani, on Friday stepped down from the board, essentially forced into retirement a year ahead of schedule.

headline: Kodak’s Fuzzy Future
text: When Eastman Kodak emerges from bankruptcy this summer or fall, it will be a shadow of the blue-chip corporate giant it once was.

headline: A Diva Inspires Orchards of Sensuality
text: Ann Hampton Callaway, like the great jazz diva Sarah Vaughan to whom she paid tribute at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Thursday evening, has a voice so rich, flexible and extravagantly gorgeous that it hardly matters what use she puts it to. The sound always comes first and is what you most remember.

headline: Take the Plunge With ‘Hamilton’s Pharmacopeia’
text: On Tuesday, a new episode of the Web series “Hamilton’s Pharmacopeia” appeared. Hamilton Morris is a chemist and general expert in the field of psychedelics and all things mind-bending. In past episodes, he has investigated rare hallucinogenic tree frogs in the Amazon, an abandoned missile silo in Kansas that became the world’s most productive LSD lab and a Haitian drug that supposedly turned people into zombies.

headline: South Africa Is Outraged by a Shortcut to a Wedding
text: JOHANNESBURG — It was to be an affair to remember. The bride was a daughter of a powerful and politically connected immigrant family. Her parents booked all 338 rooms in one of South Africa’s most lavish resorts, complete with exclusive access to its artificial beach. Kathakali dancers with painted faces and turbaned Rajasthani musicians from the family’s native country, India, performed for the guests. A pontoon carried the happy couple across an imitation Roman bath to greet their guests.

headline: Pictures of the Day: California and Elsewhere
text: Photos from California, Pakistan, Iraq and Bangladesh.

headline: Summer Movie Release Schedule
text: All dates are subject to change.

headline: Too Many Lives to Live: Old Soaps Reborn Online
text: An older gentleman proposes to a woman he has apparently known for a long time, though we have no idea who either one is. An angry man is released from prison, though it’s not clear why he was there or what he’s angry about. Some surly guy with a scar on his cheek annoys everyone he encounters by his mere presence. There are repeated references to dead babies, and DNA testing would help sort out the parentage of almost everyone under 25.

headline: Coney Island, 1:51 P.M.
text: Photo: the arcade of the long-shuttered Childs Restaurant provided a nice spot for sunbathing.

headline: A House of Drone, Ecstatic and Raw, With a Potent Aura of Largess
text: There’s an irreducible element of music that connects metal, industrial music, power electronics and classical minimalism, and no word exists for it. It involves deep pulsations; excited provocation through sound and concept more than traditional technique; low-end frequencies rarely encountered in life; long sustained tones enlarged through overdrive; or distortion or just force of hands on instruments.

headline: Israel Tightens Border Defense as Syria Erupts
text: MOUNT HAZEKA, Israel — Elite infantry and reconnaissance units have been moved into the long-quiet Golan Heights this spring. Bulldozers are making way for new military shelters. And at an Israeli Army outpost on a strategic hilltop here, a Merkava tank sits pointing toward Syria — poised to race up a dirt ramp at a moment’s notice.

headline: A Dark Time in Hungary, Remembered
text: Time has shown that no subject or context is too complex or provocative for the conductor Leon Botstein to investigate in his programming for the American Symphony Orchestra, nor any topic so clear-cut that he will not muddy the waters by incorporating elements likely to prove provocative. “Hungary Torn,” presented on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, offered a textbook example of Mr. Botstein’s professorial zeal for dislodging convention.

headline: Artifacts | The Dinosaur in Anselm Kiefer
text: In person, Anselm Kiefer is much more self-mocking and relaxed than his enormous, heart-of-darkness German history paintings and titanic lead or concrete sculptures might suggest. On Thursday morning, clad in white yoga pants, a dark shirt and thin black flip-flops, the 68-year-old artist showed a light spirit as he walked through “Morgenthau Plan,” his exhibition opening tonight at the Gagosian Gallery on West 21st Street.

headline: Beethoven’s Transcendental Meditations
text: “Resignation, what a wretched resource! Yet it is all that is left to me,” Beethoven wrote in 1801, despairing at his encroaching deafness and other physical ailments. A sense of resignation and acceptance pervades the triptych of sonatas that he completed in 1822, given majestic, profound readings by the pianist Richard Goode on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Unheralded Filly Beats Star-Studded Oaks Field
text: LOUISVILLE — Princess of Sylmar, overlooked among the galaxy of stars trained by Todd Pletcher, launched a prolonged rally to overtake Beholder by one-half length and pull a stunning upset in the $1 million Kentucky Oaks on Friday at Churchill Downs.

headline: Little Ideas, Big Trouble
text: The other day I was chatting with a colleague (no, I won’t implicate him) about what to wear to the punk-themed gala at the Met on Monday night, jewels or safety pins, and he suggested I visit a trimmings shop on Sixth Avenue.

headline: Gourmet Twists on Tavern Food
text: Chiboust opened in Tarrytown in 2004 and quickly became popular for its imaginative Mediterranean-inspired menu. Jill Rose, the chef and owner, was especially loved for her desserts, which were announced by a huge refrigerated display case at the entrance to the restaurant.

headline: Education and Employment
text: Employment for college graduates has increased by 9 percent since the start of the recession in 2007, while for those without a high school diploma, it has decreased by 14 percent.

headline: Coming Soon
text: Images of select films releasing this summer.

headline: Tapas That Tease the Eye and the Tongue
text: Widespread and varied as tapas have become in Connecticut, the arrival of Ibiza Tapas Wine Bar in Danbury in January serves as a refreshing reminder of the heights — and delights — this quintessential Spanish bar food can achieve. Ibiza is the fourth in a growing family of like-named restaurants owned by Ignacio Blanco (other Ibizas are in New Haven, Hamden and Northampton, Mass.). In contrast to the understated, rustic elegance of Mr. Blanco’s earlier venture in Norwalk, Maison Galicia (renamed Meigas and later sold), Ibiza brings a vibrant Barcelona-meets-Caribbean splash of bold colors to the dining experience.

headline: Working Alone, Together
text: Whitney Tingle, a New York entrepreneur, once had the common fantasy of ditching the 9-to-5 world, starting her own business and working in the serenity of her home. It did not quite work out as planned.

headline: Stories From Sons of a Storyteller
text: The brothers Bellow are the three sons of three different wives, and have never lived together for more than a weekend.

headline: Urban Gardening: An Appleseed With Attitude
text: Ron Finley was home by the pool recently when his thoughts once again turned to dirt. “People need to realize how powerful the transformation of soil can be,” he said, with a hint of evangelism. “We’ve gotten so far away from our food source. It’s been hijacked from us. But if you get soil, plant something in it and water it, you can feed yourself. It’s that simple.”

headline: Documentary Is as Murky as Vietnam Itself Was
text: TORONTO — A new documentary strongly suggests that a man who’s been living in Vietnam for the last 40 years is a former American prisoner of war, John Hartley Robertson, a Special Forces soldier who was aboard a helicopter that crashed in 1968 in Laos after coming under fire.

headline: All of This Restraint in the Service of Beauty
text: Flourishing their hands like fans, the dancers of the Royal Ballet of Cambodia create a measured world of complete etiquette. Everything is recollected in tranquillity. Even a battle is depicted with patterned composure. Nothing is fast. Yet stasis seldom occurs; some flow of movement is almost always in evidence. The planting of the heel or the ball of a bare foot; the flexing of a foot raised behind; the soft, S-bend adjustment of the torso at hip and shoulder in certain prolonged balances: these are all sensuous ingredients of the style.

headline: Seeing Sylvia Plath With New Eyes
text: This year, as anyone of a poetic temperament cannot fail to have noticed, is the 50th anniversary of Sylvia Plath’s suicide. Her death occurred a month after the publication of her autobiographical novel, “The Bell Jar,” and not long after she completed a manuscript of her influential poetry collection, “Ariel.” Plath’s estranged husband, the poet Ted Hughes, published a version of “Ariel” in 1965, ordering and choosing its poems as he saw fit, assuring her posthumous fame — and directing the shape that fame would assume.

headline: Cyberparenting and the Risk of T.M.I.
text: It may be a timeless curse of parenthood to know simultaneously too much about one’s teenager and yet never access the information one actually wants. But the unruly morass of today’s social media and cellphone-infested landscape seems to have made both aspects of the curse worse.

headline: Sandwiches, Rocket-Fast
text: Wild Rocket, a new sandwich shop in Huntington, is the first fast-food venture from the Reststar Hospitality Group, which also owns Bistro Citron in Roslyn and Bistro Cassis and Café Buenos Aires in Huntington, among others. Wild Rocket, which opened in March, is run by Jason Machado, 34, of Huntington, and his brother, Eric, 41, two of the partners in Reststar. They hired Marc Anthony Bynum, a consultant and chef, to create a menu of sandwiches, salads and smoothies that took inspiration from the company’s restaurants.

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 3
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a five-alarm fire in the Bronx, a motorcycle club in Queens and the cherry blossoms blooming in Brooklyn.

headline: Remembering Where They Came From
text: Ever dream about what you would do if you won the lottery? Richard and Mary Morrison, winners in 2010, decided to open a restaurant, Graceful Rose, in Port Jefferson, a tribute to Richard’s mother, Rose, and his grandmother Grace.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Internet Cats Sue, and Google Games
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Go the Same Way, or Go the Wrong Way
text: Not long ago, a friend of mine, a dear man with exquisite taste, took me to dinner at Momofuku Má Pêche in Midtown Manhattan. I point out his taste because, being from out of town, he chose the restaurant on the fly, based on some reviews he had read on Yelp, the social networking site that rates everything from eating establishments to vacuum cleaners to gastroenterologists. The supertrendy place had gotten some raves.

headline: The Right Stance Can Be Reassuring
text: Watch celebrities on the red carpet, or models on a runway, and you’ll undoubtedly see the classic stop-for-the-flashing-cameras stance: chest open, legs apart, head level, usually with a hand on the hip.

headline: Savoring the Exotic Spices, and the Heat
text: At Sigiri Sri Lankan Cuisine, ignore the folding tables with awkwardly placed legs.

headline: The Real Rock of Ages
text: LOOKING AT THE STRANGE formation of mighty, 20-foot-tall bluestone totems outside Rockefeller Center, you might imagine them to be the unearthed ruins of some ancient temple: Stonehenge come to Saks. Upon learning that they are the work of the artist Ugo Rondinone, you might wonder if these sculptures (and the tabletop versions in a show opening Friday at Gladstone Gallery) are some kind of mystical portals to the Paleolithic.

headline: In Broadway Tunes, Ballet Finds Its Inner Showgirl
text: Igor Stravinsky is a composer synonymous with New York City Ballet and its co-founder George Balanchine, but what about Richard Rodgers? On Thursday, as part of the company’s American Music Festival at the David H. Koch Theater, City Ballet unveiled an all-Rodgers evening that opened a door to ballet’s jazzy, sensuous side. As the three-week festival continues, others, from Philip Glass to Nico Muhly, will be heard, revealing ways that music gains — or loses — flavor through ballet.

headline: From Triple-A to the Mets’ Lineup
text: ATLANTA — The Mets were hitting .191 in the seven games before the start of the weekend series with the Braves, so they could use a serious jolt for their offense, especially among their outfielders. They called up Andrew Brown from Class AAA Las Vegas and immediately put him in the lineup to hit eighth and play right field against the Atlanta left-hander Mike Minor on Friday night.

headline: Missionary Zeal, Baroque Style
text: Jesuit missionaries founded settlements in eastern Bolivia using European music as a means of rendering Roman Catholicism more palatable to the indigenous people. Choir directors, musical instrument makers and composers, including the Italian Baroque composer Domenico Zipoli, moved to South America and taught the locals.

headline: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams Final
text: ST. LOUIS — Bold bidding often needs to be backed up with accurate card reading. The diagramed deal occurred during the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in March. It resulted in a gain of 10 international match points for the winners, Sabine Auken and Morten and Dennis Bilde (father and son) from Denmark, and Roy Welland of New York City.

headline: Early Wildfire Drives Thousands From Homes in Southern California
text: LOS ANGELES — Walls of wind-driven fire swept across Ventura County on Friday, forcing thousands of home evacuations, shutting down schools and offices and ravaging acres of woodland as firefighters struggled for a second day to bring an ominously early California wildfire under control.

headline: New Yorkers Walked Over, for Once
text: You may like to look at art, or perhaps collect it. But if you’ve ever had fantasies of being an art piece, the Parisian street artist and photographer known as J R is offering you the chance, by way of his “Inside Out” project.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Crisp Images From a Faded Long Island Past
text: In 1897, before the commuter age began, the Long Island Rail Road hired Hal B. Fullerton, formerly a business executive, to lure more visitors and settlers to Long Island. During his 30 years as a special agent for the L.I.R.R., he produced many books, pamphlets and promotional events for the railroad, and he started two experimental farms to demonstrate how productive the Island’s land could be.

headline: New York Expands Its Recycling Bin
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Waning Weeks of the Legislature, It All Can Change
text: No issue is really dead as long as the Legislature is in town.

headline: The Day of the Locusts
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cost of Cancer Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Bias and a Settlement With Black Farmers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Digital, Not Dusty: The Archivist’s Tale
text: To the Editor:

headline: A 24-Hour Race for Sightings
text: At 12:01 a.m. on May 11, the first of around 1,000 birders in about 100 teams will fan out across New Jersey to see as many species as they can in 24 hours. They will be compiling checklists, raising money and awareness for conservation and, most important for some of them, trying to beat the competition.

headline: Yankees’ Bullpen Takes Another Hit
text: This season, while the rest of his roster seemingly dwindled day after day because of injuries, Manager Joe Girardi could always depend on the sturdy back end of the bullpen. Now, the vaunted Joba Chamberlain-Dave Robertson bridge to Mariano Rivera has also collapsed.

headline: A Romantic Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man
text: Given that James Joyce was a leading avant-garde author of his day, it is a tad paradoxical that “Himself and Nora,” written and composed by Jonathan Brielle, has been devised as a conventional musical theater piece. Still, the intimate chamber musical, at the 199-seat Hamilton Stage in Rahway, is a lively, sometimes lusty, spin through the love life, troubles and literary times of the great Irish writer.

headline: Library of Congress Treads Water
text: The budget cuts imposed by sequestration are likely to hamper the Library of Congress’s efforts to copyright, digitize and store millions of books, photographs and other precious materials.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Hats Off
text: At the Frederick Law Olmsted awards luncheon of the Women’s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy, a favorite hat shape was the satellite dish, defying gravity on the side of the head.

headline: Revival of Europe’s Economy Falls to German Leader
As Works Flood In, Nation’s Library Treads Water
text: WASHINGTON —   The Sea Creatures, who recently sent their recording “Naked in the Rain” to the Library of Congress, probably did not ponder the impact of sequestration on their music’s journey from dream to copyright.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: To Race’s Owner, Track Is No Longer at Center of the Business Universe
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Last year, Churchill Downs Inc., the company that runs the most famous track in horse racing, moved its corporate headquarters from beneath the track’s iconic twin spires to the top floor of a glass office building 15 miles away. Robert L. Evans, the company’s chairman and chief executive, has frequently assured investors that while hosting the Kentucky Derby may be the company’s most celebrated endeavor, it is hardly the most important.

headline: JPMorgan Directors Feel Heat in a Vote
text: As JPMorgan Chase’s annual meeting nears, much of the tension surrounds a critical vote to split the chairman and chief executive roles — a decision that could strip Jamie Dimon, the bank’s influential leader, of the dual titles he has held since 2006. Behind the scenes, though, another battle is brewing.

headline: A Lawyer’s Story, as Only He Could Tell It
text: Always open with a joke.

headline: Where Have All the Jobs Gone?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Last of a Breed: Postal Workers Who Decipher Bad Addresses
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Inside a plain warehouselike office building filled with rows of cubicles, Melissa Stark stares at the image of an envelope on a computer screen. The handwriting is barely legible and appears to be addressed to someone in the “cty of Jesey.”

headline: A Grandson Visits China in Footsteps of Nixon
text: BEIJING — Christopher Nixon Cox retraced his grandfather’s historic 1972 trip to China on Friday, trailed through Tiananmen Square by an entourage of aging Nixon administration luminaries, state-news-media paparazzi and Chinese security agents.

headline: Caravaggio, and Some of His Admirers
text: In spite of a life that was brief and often rowdy, Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio changed the face of painting. Rejecting the idealized and decorous classicism of his predecessors, he dramatized his compositions with his use of vivid lighting and insisted on humanizing his subjects by painting from life with all its particulars. Even his saints had dirty feet.

headline: An Ode to Helium
text: We have not been paying nearly enough attention to helium legislation.

headline: With Help of Two Veterans, Blues Maintain Their Composure
text: ST. LOUIS — Jay Bouwmeester is not overly excited about the first Stanley Cup playoff action of his career.

headline: Prison Conditions Eased for Ex-Marine Held in Iran
text: A former Marine incarcerated in Iran for nearly two years on suspicions that he was an American spy has been granted monthly visitations by an uncle in Tehran since March and has been permitted to send letters to his family for the first time, according to his sister, who interpreted the eased conditions as possible signs that Iran eventually could release him.

headline: As Old as the Bottles
text: Corey Kilgannon’s Character Study column about a long-serving Brooklyn seltzer man prompted the following letter.

headline: Foreign Students to Face New Checks at U.S. Borders
text: The Department of Homeland Security has ordered new security checks for all foreign students entering the United States, according to officials familiar with instructions issued Friday to customs inspectors.

headline: Warriors Use Hint of Lee, and Lots of Curry, to Win
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The end came the way the Denver Nuggets feared it could, with Golden State’s Stephen Curry lobbing 3-pointers, Andrew Bogut crashing the basket and a hyper-charged crowd shaking the arena with earsplitting noise. By the time the first scrap of yellow celebratory confetti fell Thursday night, the Nuggets were off the court and through the tunnel, ushered out of the playoffs.

headline: Mississippi Inmate’s Bid for DNA Tests Is Denied With Tuesday Execution Set
text: The State of Mississippi has denied requests for DNA testing of evidence made by a prisoner set to be executed on Tuesday, potentially setting up what experts said would be a rare case in recent years in which a person is put to death with such requests unmet.

headline: Send Judges to Guantánamo, Then Shut It
text: NEW HAVEN

headline: Consuming Colonists
text: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.

headline: Drug to Cut Cholesterol Is Approved by the F.D.A.
text: The Food and Drug Administration approved on Friday a combination drug developed by Merck that lowers a patient’s cholesterol but has not been shown to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease or death, the company said.

headline: Leading at Midpoint, Mickelson Looks Sharp
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The surprise is not that Phil Mickelson is part-owner of a Kentucky-bred thoroughbred that once was considered a potential entrant in the Kentucky Derby. Mickelson, who enjoys placing wagers on major sporting events like the Super Bowl, grew up in San Diego, not far from the Del Mar racetrack. The surprise is that the horses never grabbed hold of Mickelson’s imagination or wallet.

headline: 2 Killings and 2 Guns, Unattended
text: On the afternoon of Aug. 7, 2012, Greg Imhoff — a big, friendly 61-year-old construction superintendent from Madison, Wis., who had moved to Florida with his partner, Shari Telvick — went to check on the home of a neighbor.

headline: Stand Up, Cast Off, Reel In
text: Relaxing with a rod and a beer is not the way someone named Pierre A. Champion goes about landing a prize catch.

headline: Winning the Field, but Not the War
text: One hundred and fifty years ago this week, more than 133,000 Union soldiers squared off against more than 60,000 Confederates in the Battle of Chancellorsville. Though the battle swung back and forth for several days, it ended with a decisive Southern victory. And yet the war ground on, for another two years. The war only ended when the devastation spilled off the battlefield, as Sherman and his army took the conflict to the farmland and cities of the South.

headline: Florida Lawmakers Approve Overhaul of State’s Problem-Ridden Voting Process
text: MIAMI — Six months after Florida became the butt of late-night jokes for a chaotic voting process that bedeviled the 2012 presidential election, the State Legislature passed a bill on Friday to remedy many of those problems.

headline: Jobs, Wages and the Sequester
text: The employment report released on Friday showed some economic resilience. Job growth for March was revised upward to 138,000 new jobs, while the tally for April, at 165,000 jobs, was stronger still.

headline: Small, Cute Sinkhole Swallows Menu and Soda Bottle
text: If you’re like us, you’ve probably read more than enough stories about horrible nightmare sinkholes that swallow up trucks and kill people. Join us, then, in praise of the Little Sinkhole of West Tenth Street.

headline: City Futures, a Poet’s Past
text: One in eight Americans lives in metropolitan New York or Los Angeles, so exploring and comparing the regions is an instructive exercise in where the nation is heading. And in “New York and Los Angeles: The Uncertain Future” (Oxford University Press, $34.95), Andrew A. Beveridge and David Halle, sociology professors at Queens College and the University of California, Los Angeles, enlist experts from the social sciences to do just that.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 3, 2013
text: “It is the baby boomer group where we see the highest rates of suicide. There may be something about that group, and how they think about life issues and their life choices that may make a difference.”

headline: The Mayor on Stop-and-Frisk
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg trotted out shopworn, discredited arguments this week while defending the constitutionally suspect police program under which hundreds of thousands of innocent New Yorkers have been detained and questioned on the streets every year. His speech, at 1 Police Plaza, castigated civil rights lawyers who oppose what they say is the practice of stopping people based on race instead of reasonable suspicion; Democratic mayoral candidates who want to rein in the stop-and-frisk program; and the City Council, which is considering a perfectly reasonable bill that would create the position of Police Department inspector general, with broad powers to review department policies.

headline: Funeral Home Accepts Suspect’s Body, and Problems
text: WORCESTER, Mass. — Peter A. Stefan sat straight up in a leather chair in the funeral home he owns and looked purposefully at the city councilor who had come to ask him why he of all people was storing the body of Tamerlan Tsarnaev.

headline: College Graduates Fare Well in Jobs Market, Even Through Recession
text: Is college worth it? Given the growing price tag and the frequent anecdotes about jobless graduates stuck in their parents’ basements, many have started to question the value of a college degree. But the evidence suggests college graduates have suffered through the recession and lackluster recovery with remarkable resilience.

headline: As Senators Head for Exit, Few Step Up to Run for Seats
text: WASHINGTON — The retirement of Tom Harkin, a Democrat who has represented Iowa in the Senate for nearly 30 years, should be the kind of rare opportunity that sends the best and brightest of his state’s political class scrambling to get on the ballot.

headline: Dear College Graduates...
text: I’m scheduled to deliver the commencement address Friday at my alma mater, Grambling State University in Louisiana, so I’ve been giving quite a bit of thought to the America into which these students are graduating.

headline: Judge Says Cuban Who Spied on U.S. Can Stay in Cuba
text: MEXICO CITY — A Cuban man convicted in the United States of spying on behalf of Cuba can stay in Cuba, where he was allowed to go last month for his father’s funeral, if he renounces his American citizenship, a federal judge ruled Friday.

headline: Before Mayweather’s Fight, a Conflict of Story Lines
text: LAS VEGAS — Floyd Mayweather Jr. entered the MGM Grand Garden Arena flanked by camera crews and boom microphones and four bodyguards roughly the size of Fiats. Sunglasses on, cellphones in hand, he trailed them upstairs, where a series of interviews would simultaneously bolster and diminish the chosen narrative for his latest fight.

headline: A British Pub’s Offense? Favoring the British
text: Longbow Pub and Pantry, an oak-paneled haven of sport and imbibition on a busy strip in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is a British pub through and through, from the Welsh national rugby jersey framed by the bar to the Old Speckled Hen ale in the fish-and-chips batter to the accents that ring loud off the walls during soccer broadcasts.

headline: Early Voting Means Easier Voting
text: New York State is a national laggard when it comes to voting. The state has one of the worst voter turnout records in the country, not least because the act of voting is cumbersome and uninviting. In November, 53.6 percent of registered voters cast ballots, leaving New York 44th among the 50 states and the District of Columbia for voter participation.

headline: Shooting His Own Foot
text: President François Hollande of France has recently been on a campaign to change the widely held perception that his administration is hostile to business. He has sounded more welcoming to foreign investment and has promised to lower capital gains taxes. But barely days into his charm offensive, one of Mr. Hollande’s ministers was triumphantly claiming credit for preventing Yahoo from buying a controlling stake in a successful French online video streaming company, DailyMotion.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: Bangladeshis bury their dead as apparel companies discuss factory safety, China’s factories slow down and American job growth exceeds forecasts.

headline: A Sadrist Governor Is a Folk Hero to Iraqis
text: AMARA, Iraq

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 4, 2013
text: “I’m so jaded at this point that I’m not surprised. And from my perspective, let them all wear wires. Let’s catch everybody. Maybe if we clean out the whole system, we can move forward.”

headline: Amid Pending Investigation, President of St. John’s Says He Will Retire
text: The longtime president of St. John’s University, the Rev. Donald J. Harrington, announced his retirement on Friday, ending a tenure that included successes like soaring student enrollment and campus expansion, but also financial scandal: he acknowledged going on trips with a former dean who committed suicide while on trial for corruption.

headline: May 3: Churchill Downs Replay
text: Images from Churchill Downs leading up to the Kentucky Derby.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A 19-Horse Kentucky Derby
text: Post positions for the 19 horses in Saturday’s Kentucky Derby.

headline: Corrections: May 4, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Almost There
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Here’s when I knew I was in trouble: at 23 Across, the devilishly wicked clue “Resident of Angola, Brazil or Lebanon” taunted me mercilessly as I tried to figure out who might reside in all of those countries. Sure, there were a few brain cells nagging at me that Lebanon was the name of a couple of American towns, but I ignored them. Big mistake.

headline: Knicks Falter in Fourth Before Closing Out Celtics
text: BOSTON — The wait had been long, humiliating, often torturous, and it would not end without one final jolt of stress, one last anxious sensation before the moment of exhilaration finally, mercifully arrived. Delayed gratification never felt this good.

headline: Seeking Flexibility During Storms
text: A preliminary map of expanded New York City evacuation zones includes nearly three million residents.

headline: Questions Linger for Liu After Ex-Associates’ Trial
text: When John C. Liu hastily announced late Thursday that he would hold a news conference that night to discuss the convictions of two former associates in an illegal campaign-finance scheme, speculation began to build: Would he criticize the guilty parties and vow not to tolerate similar conduct? Would he be rattled, or even abandon the race for mayor?

headline: Jeff Hanneman, Guitarist, Dies at 49
text: Jeff Hanneman, a guitarist for the influential metal band Slayer, who helped shape the group’s sonic assault and wrote some of its most popular — and controversial — songs, died on Thursday at a hospital near his home east of Los Angeles. He was 49.

headline: Adding Evacuation Zones in Response to Hurricane
text: The Bloomberg administration announced on Friday that it would double to six the number of evacuation zones along New York City’s coast and expand them to include an additional 640,000 residents, saying that the new map would provide more flexibility when major storms hit.

headline: Trading Handshakes for Home Cooking
text: In his former life as a city councilman and candidate for city comptroller, David S. Yassky, 49, saw many weekend hours sacrificed to political events; handshaking, crowd stirring, park-cleaning. But though his current job, as commissioner of the city’s Taxi and Limousine Commission, can intrude on any given weekend, he seems to have recaptured his Sundays. Now they begin with a trip to the dog run near his Brooklyn Heights home and an exercise outing with his wife, Diana Fortuna, the chief financial officer of the Metropolitan Opera. They typically end with a dose of classic television. In between, Mr. Yassky strives to prove his culinary chops to the couple’s 14-year-old daughter, Margaret, a Food Network fan with a discerning palate. Their other daughter, Susan, 19, is finishing her freshman year at Yale.

headline: A Place for Vandals Turns Outdoor Gallery
text: The Brooklyn neighborhood of Bushwick had long been a target for graffiti until a lifelong resident decided to change that.

headline: Mike Gray, ‘China Syndrome’ Writer, Dies at 77
text: Mike Gray, a writer and filmmaker who tackled thorny contemporary issues in his work, including race relations in Chicago, American drug policy and, most notably, the safety of nuclear power plants — the subject of the 1979 film “The China Syndrome,” for which he wrote the original screenplay — died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 77.

headline: Tom Knapp, Crowd-Pleasing Sure Shot, Dies at 62
text: Tom Knapp, an exhibition shotgun virtuoso who broke world records by picking off flocks of airborne clay targets with the flair of a western movie hero and dazzled crowds with his effortless precision shattering of golf balls, radishes, aspirin and other flying targets, died on April 26 in Rochester, Minn. He was 62.

headline: Bushwick Gets a Fresh Coat
text: Growing up, Joseph Ficalora would sit on the roof of his family’s steel fabrication business. In Bushwick, Brooklyn, in the 1980s, it was one of the few safe places outdoors. The view was grim. The streets were dirty. Graffiti was endless.

headline: Sabathia’s Early Mistake Is All Griffin and A’s Need
text: In the moments leading up to his start Friday against the Yankees, Oakland Athletics pitcher A. J. Griffin serenaded his teammates by playing his guitar and singing in the middle of the clubhouse. The free-spirited Griffin even sang a song in Spanish for the Cuban outfielder Yoenis Cespedes.

headline: Racing Family Dares to Dream of Victory
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — With an advertisement in a Pittsburgh newspaper — “a willing boy wishes work” — Henry Phipps Jr. entered the world of 19th-century industry and set out on a career that epitomized the American dream.

headline: Keeping Troubled Youth Near
text: New York City’s juvenile delinquents used to be sent upstate to be incarcerated, but a new program is offering rehabilitation closer to home.

headline: Google’s Palestinian Home Page Recognizes ‘Palestine’
text: Five months after the United Nations General Assembly voted to upgrade Palestine’s status to a nonmember observer state, Google has followed suit, labeling its local home page “Palestine” instead of the “Palestinian territories.” The Palestine Liberation Organization and the Palestinian Authority began using “State of Palestine” on official documents immediately after the Nov. 29 United Nations vote, and urged international organizations to do the same. A Google spokesman said Friday that the company was making the change “across all our products.” Sabri Saadat, a spokesman for President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority, called the move a step in the right direction, but Yigal Palmor, a spokesman for Israel’s Foreign Ministry, voiced displeasure. “It has no diplomatic or political significance,” Mr. Palmor told an Israeli news Web site on Friday. “Precisely because Google is not the U.N. or any international diplomatic institution, this begs the question of whether there is room for any political stance on controversial issues.”

headline: Path From ‘Social Butterfly’ to Boston Suspect’s Widow
text: When Katherine Russell arrived as a freshman at Suffolk University just over five years ago, she seemed to bond so well with her new roommates in their lively dorm opposite Boston Common that one classmate likened them to sitcom characters. “They reminded me of the show ‘Sex and the City,’ ” he recalled. “Two of them were free-spirited, one was materialistic and Katherine was the social butterfly.”

headline: Another Chance for Mone’t
text: The end of the road is a yellow brick house in East New York, Brooklyn, that was once a rectory. Mone’t arrived there on Dec. 28 with a bad attitude and four years of baggage.

headline: As Nets and Bulls Go the Distance, the First Round Feels Like the 15th
text: The Nets’ first-round series against the Chicago Bulls will end exactly two weeks after it began, at Barclays Center on Saturday night, after seven games that twisted and stretched and tested the teams in ways they probably never could have imagined.

headline: Braves’ Bullpen Falters, and Mets Take Advantage
text: ATLANTA — The Mets roughed up the National League’s best bullpen. They handled the league’s best hitter in a key situation, and they beat the best team in the East. So it took Manager Terry Collins no time at all when asked if this was the Mets’ best win of the season.

headline: Out, but Not About That
text: Thirteen years ago, Corey Johnson, then an 18-year-old high school student in Middleton, Mass., the son of a truck driver and a cafeteria worker, came out about his homosexuality, and it was no small thing. The captain of his football team, Mr. Johnson also wrestled and played lacrosse and baseball. Not long after his disclosure, he was asked to speak at the Millennium March for Equality in Washington. He became the subject of a  column by Robert Lipsyte in The New York Times, which, to Mr. Johnson’s great surprise, ran on the paper’s front page on a Sunday. A certain celebrity quickly attended him.

headline: A Roller-Coaster Game Mirrors a Tough Season
text: BOSTON — They played “Don’t Stop Believin’ ” before the game, perhaps a prophetic tune for the Celtics. But as it was for “The Sopranos” six years ago, the song proved to be endgame music for the Celtics on Friday night.

headline: Game 6: Knicks vs. Celtics Replay
text: After blowing most of a 26-point lead, the Knicks stopped the Celtics’ comeback attempt to advance to the Eastern Conference semifinals.

headline: City Hall Pushed Noted Women to Sign Letter Supporting Candidate for Chancellor
text: The idea was simple: a letter signed by some of the country’s most prominent women endorsing Cathleen P. Black, chairwoman of Hearst Magazines, to lead New York City’s schools.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (Showtime) SALMON FISHING IN THE YEMEN (2012) The director Lasse Hallstrom transforms Paul Torday’s absurdist political satire — the tale of a visionary sheik (Amr Waked, above left, with Ewan McGregor) with unlimited financial resources intent on creating a recreational paradise for fishermen in a Middle Eastern desert — into a whimsical romantic comedy. Mr. Hallstrom “is a shrewd commercial alchemist with a soft heart,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, and the result “is the cinematic equivalent of turning salt into sugar.” Mr. McGregor plays Dr. Alfred Jones, a British fisheries expert who is approached to evaluate the feasibility of the concept, which would involve either importing 10,000 North Atlantic salmon to Yemen from Britain, or using farmed salmon. Kristin Scott Thomas is Patricia Maxwell, the press secretary for the British prime minister, who seizes on the opportunity to distract the public from political conflicts and score points for her boss. And Emily Blunt is Harriet, the sheik’s assistant, and the unspoken object of Fred’s affection, whose soldier boyfriend (Tom Mison) has gone missing in action. “Whether Harriet and Fred will get together is a question that hovers over the movie,” Mr. Holden said. “The appeal of the film depends on the charm of Mr. McGregor and Ms. Blunt, whose polite but discreetly charged connection is the story’s emotional center.” And although the sheik is the target of an assassination plot by Islamic extremists, “the biggest moment of suspense has nothing to do with international politics or terrorism,” Mr. Holden said. “It comes when those farmed salmon are finally released into the waters of their new home. Will they mill around in confusion or will they jump? It is enough to say that for this moment to be the film’s dramatic turning point is an indication of its softness.”

headline: IHT Quick Read: May 4
text: NEWS Even as the United States economy displays unanticipated resilience, with a healthy jobs report released on Friday, the outlook for Europe’s economy grows ever dimmer. As it does, the pressure builds on Europe’s most powerful leader, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, and her economic team to find a way to get the Continent growing again. But this puts Ms. Merkel in a bind, as she has to answer to German voters in September when the country holds parliamentary elections. While the European economy may be deteriorating at an alarming rate, the electorate here is still enamored of her as the Iron Chancellor, advocating the austerity policies that are rapidly falling into disfavor elsewhere, among economists as well as the public. Nicholas Kulish reports from Berlin.

headline: Israel Targeted Iranian Missiles in Syria Attack
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A series of powerful explosions rocked the outskirts of Damascus early Sunday morning, which Syrian state television said was the result of Israeli missile attacks on a Syrian military installation.

headline: Pakistani Prisoner Beaten Up in Indian Jail
text: NEW DELHI — A day after the death of Sarabjit Singh, an Indian national who died from his injuries from a brutal attack by inmates of a Pakistani prison, Sanaullah Ranjay, a Pakistani national imprisoned in Jammu, Jammu and Kashmir, was severely beaten up Friday morning by a fellow prisoner.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: One man was killed and more than 50 people, mostly school children, were injured in Kashmir when an earthquake measuring 5.8 on the Richter scale rocked parts of northern India on Wednesday, Hindustan Times reported.

headline: The Weekend Word: Loyalty
text: Today’s Times

headline: 2 Big Changes Make Derby More Difficult to Predict
text: The Kentucky Derby, one of the most tradition-bound institutions in sports history, will leave the gate on Saturday without two of its time-honored customs. The changes are both good and bad, but they both make the winner more difficult to predict.

headline: 2 Bodies Found at Crash Site of U.S. Tanker
text: MOSCOW — The authorities said Saturday that two bodies had been found in the wreckage of an American tanker airplane that crashed soon after taking off from the Manas airport in the Central Asian country of Kyrgyzstan on Friday.

headline: A Bold New Morrokide Era: Classic Cars Then, Now and in Between
text: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x5Vml8hf5HM

headline: The Gods Themselves Contend In Vain
text: The basic idea behind Keynesian support for stimulus/opposition to austerity under current conditions is that when private demand is weak and monetary policy is up against the zero lower bound, there is no offset to changes in government spending. This shouldn’t be a hard concept to grasp — in particular, you would think that anyone posing as an economist could grasp the conditional nature of the statement. But, well … some short takes just from the past few days:

headline: Berkshire Hathaway’s 2013 Shareholder Meeting
text: OMAHA — Even with the addition of a hedge fund manager meant to inject additional skepticism into Berkshire Hathaway‘s annual meeting, Warren E. Buffett managed to escape making big news here on Saturday.

headline: The Most Active ‘Friends of the Court’
text: According to an analysis of briefs filed over a recent three-year period, groups who favor business interests file the most friend-of-the-court briefs encouraging the Supreme Court to review a case.

headline: One Year Into Hollande Presidency in France, ‘a Sense of Drift’
text: PARIS — The former French president Nicolas Sarkozy recently gave a speech to a telecommunications conference in Montreal. “I feel good,” he said, grinning. “And when I look at those who succeeded me, I even feel very good.”

headline: Graduating to Next Level of Hard Lessons
text: BOSTON

headline: When Attackers Become Defenders, Innovation Is Lost
text: This interview with  Steve Case, chief executive of Revolution, an investment firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. Mr. Case was also a founder of America Online.

headline: A Pro-Business Court
text: The court led by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has been friendlier to corporate interests than any other recent court, according to a new study of the votes of 36 justices serving since 1946.

headline: Autistic Twins Are Hoping for Calm Races After the Trauma of Boston
text: BETHPAGE, N.Y. — Alex and Jamie Schneider run seemingly on instinct, saying nothing and drifting into a cone of concentration. They are autistic 22-year-old identical twins from Long Island whose passion is to run for miles at a time. The twins, who are nonverbal and can exhibit severe behaviors like self-injury and tantrums, have completed more than 120 races, including five marathons and eight half-marathons, over the past seven years.

headline: The Branding of Rory McIlroy
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — It was time for Rory McIlroy to face the television cameras after another well-played round at the Wells Fargo Championship. Emerging Friday from the scoring area at Quail Hollow, McIlroy reached into his golf bag and slipped on an Omega Seamaster Planet Ocean watch with a blue rubber strap.

headline: Variety: An Ephemeral Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — One of the things I really like about acrostic puzzles is that it is virtually impossible to fail completely at them. Even if you’ve never heard of an OVEN BIRD, for example, perhaps you might toggle back and forth from the entry to the quote just enough to complete the word. And now, thanks to Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, you will always know what an OVEN BIRD is.

headline: Karzai Says He Was Assured C.I.A. Would Continue Delivering Bags of Cash
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The C.I.A.’s station chief here met with President Hamid Karzai on Saturday, and the Afghan leader said he had been assured that the agency would continue dropping off stacks of cash at his office despite a storm of criticism that has erupted since the payments were disclosed.

headline: In Latin America, U.S. Focus Shifts From Drug War to Economy
text: SAN JOSÉ, Costa Rica — In February 2009, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. declared that international drug trafficking posed “a sustained, serious threat” to Americans. Two months later, President Obama, in his first visit as president to Mexico, made it clear that no issue dominated relations between the two countries more, saying drug cartels there were “sowing chaos in our communities.”

headline: Lockout Hangover Is Persistent in Montreal
text: MONTREAL — Outside Bell Centre on Friday, it was as it should be. The Canadiens were in the playoffs, the unseasonably warm weather created a demand for beer that street vendors could not satisfy, and the usual small army of children in jerseys were filling tin cans with donations for their hockey teams.

headline: ‘The Game That Never Ends’
text: Manny Schellscheidt likes to keep the game simple. He recalls setting up countless pickup games over the years, saying: “We divide the kids up, whatever the numbers, play to five goals, and sometimes put conditions on them like two-touch. They can remember the rules and just keep going. It’s the game that never ends.”

headline: Seeking to Lure Tourists to a Rugged Outpost Famed for a Deadly Feud
text: SARAH ANN, W.Va. — Standing on the back of an Appalachian hillside, Reo Hatfield fixed his gaze over the land of his infamous forebears, a scowl etched across his face.

headline: Resorts Reborn in Decay
text: They were the grand palaces of her childhood, the fortress hotels where her family celebrated Jewish holidays, where a girl from the Catskills could run wild or hear stories about how her grandparents met. She learned to swim in the pool at one hotel and worked as a summer lifeguard at another. Then, when she left for college on the West Coast, Marisa Scheinfeld, 32, found herself “grappling with homesickness.”

headline: This Year, No Waiting For Crackdown
text: The first games of this year’s Stanley Cup playoffs may be as belligerent as last year’s, but the N.H.L.’s initial response has been far more proactive, and may signal a stricter stance against checks to the head.

headline: Tobacco Lovers Discover Mystique of Perique
text: GRAND POINT, La. — About 15 years ago, the world supply of the pungent Cajun tobacco perique was down to about five barrels. One of the rarest tobaccos in the world, it comes from St. James Parish, about 50 miles west of New Orleans.

headline: California Wildfires May Be Controlled This Weekend, Official Says
text: Wildfires gripping Ventura County, Calif., spread on Friday night but will most likely come under control during the weekend with the aid of favorable weather, a fire official said Saturday.

headline: Hudson Joins a Club That Becomes Harder to Make
text: ATLANTA — Mark Mulder flew here Tuesday night, found a steakhouse for dinner and sat at the bar to watch his old friend Tim Hudson pitch on television. Mulder, 35, is two years younger than Hudson. Each won 81 games for the Oakland Athletics from 2000 through 2004. But Mulder is a broadcaster now for ESPN, nearly seven years removed from his last victory.

headline: Keynes, Keynesians, the Long Run, and Fiscal Policy
text: One dead giveaway that someone pretending to be an authority on economics is in fact faking it is misuse of the famous Keynes line about the long run. Here’s the actual quote:

headline: Braves’ Formula: Swing, Miss and Win
text: ATLANTA — The strikeout has become an epidemic in major league baseball, and the Braves are one of the clubs most affected by the outbreak. Atlanta’s hitters are striking out 9.2 times a game, which puts them on a pace to become the second team to strike out more than 1,400 times in a season.

headline: Chinese River’s Fate May Reshape a Region
text: Those who treasure the Nu River in Bingzhongluo, China, say the construction of proposed dams would alter what guidebooks call the Grand Canyon of the East.

headline: Plans to Harness Chinese River’s Power Threaten a Region
text: BINGZHONGLUO, China — From its crystalline beginnings as a rivulet seeping from a glacier on the Tibetan Himalayas to its broad, muddy amble through the jungles of Myanmar, the Nu River is one of Asia’s wildest waterways, its 1,700-mile course unimpeded as it rolls toward the Andaman Sea.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Jimmy Connors: From Lone Wolf to Open Book
text: Jimmy Connors showed signs of obsessive compulsive disorder and ocular motor sensory deficit as a child, long before he realized they were serious problems. He tried Gamblers Anonymous to curb a “fix” that still itches and took his grandmother’s advice as a mantra: “Keep a little mystery about yourself in life.”

headline: Welcome to Erbil, Tourism Boom Town
text: ERBIL, Iraq — Erbil is preparing to greet visitors as the Arab Capital of Tourism in 2014, a singular honor for a non-Arab city. It won out over Beirut, Sharjah and the Saudi resort of Taif.

headline: Celtics Contemplate Future, Which May Include Swan Song for Their Core
text: BOSTON — Ear-splitting music is now as much a part of the N.B.A. experience as the game itself. It certainly was Friday night at TD Garden for Game 6 of the Celtics’ first-round playoff series against the Knicks.

headline: Indecisive Battles (Feeding My Civil War Obsession)
text: I’ve been loving the Times’s Disunion blog, partly because it plays into my U.S. Grant obsession. And James Q. Whitman’s post about how battlefield victories didn’t seem to settle anything was definitely interesting.

headline: Management, to the Barricades!
text: THE annals of business history abound with stories of entrenched corporate executives building fortifications to maintain their plush status quo. But recent maneuvers by the board of the CommonWealth real estate investment trust put the company in a class by itself. CommonWealth REIT owns office buildings in and around major metropolitan areas in the United States. Founded in 1986 and based in Newton, Mass., CommonWealth, like many REITs, is not taxed on its income, which it distributes to shareholders. Its hefty payouts — 4.75 percent based on its share price of $21.04 — have made it a favorite among individual investors looking for income.

headline: It Takes James to Stop a Village
text: MILWAUKEE — The Heat were looking to sweep the Bucks last Sunday, but with about five minutes remaining in the third quarter, Miami’s lead was down to 4 points. LeBron James, irritated by his team’s lack of intensity on defense, punched the chair next to him during a timeout, inserted his mouth guard and methodically halted Milwaukee’s momentum.

headline: The Apprentices of a Digital Age
text: JASMINE GAO, who is 19, just wasn’t the classroom type. So instead of languishing in college, she dropped out after her freshman year.

headline: With an Old Factory, Philadelphia Is Hoping to Draw New Teachers
text: PHILADELPHIA — A Victorian-era dye factory is taking on a new role to help this city’s troubled public school system attract and retain teachers.

headline: This Time, There’s No Reggie Miller for the Pacers
text: The Knicks and the Indiana Pacers have faced each other six times in the N.B.A. postseason, with each team winning three series. They first met in 1993; they last played in 2000. This will be their first playoff meeting without Reggie Miller hitting 3-pointers and taking on the role of Indiana’s comic-book villain. Without him, this series will probably not have the same edge, although the Knicks and the Pacers had some pointed moments this season in splitting four games.

headline: Does Class Size Count?
text: As states cut education budgets in response to the nation’s continuing economic woes, student-to-teacher ratios are again on the rise after decades of decline. This resurrects an age-old debate in American education: does class size really matter?

headline: Autopsy Says Boston Bombing Suspect Died of Gunshot Wounds and Blunt Trauma
text: WORCESTER, Mass. — Tamerlan Tsarnaev, the 26-year-old man who the authorities say is one of two brothers who carried out the Boston Marathon bombing, died of gunshot wounds and blunt trauma, according to his death certificate.

headline: Electronics Dump
text: Most outdated electronics are thrown away rather than recycled. Charts show the percentage of U.S. electronics, by weight, that wound up in landfills or incinerators in 2006-10.

headline: 102 Floors, 10 Million Bricks and One Tangled History
text: The Empire State Building stands as an enduring symbol of New York City — and of the mayhem and legal conflict to which New York City real estate titans are prone. The most recent conflict, however, seems to be inching toward a resolution.

headline: N.R.A. Leadership Rallies Members for 2014 Elections
text: HOUSTON — In speech after speech at the National Rifle Association’s annual convention here this weekend, its top leaders and political allies blasted President Obama and other gun control advocates, warned against “all-out, historic attacks” on the constitutional right to possess firearms, and issued a rallying cry to members to become a political force in next year’s midterm elections and the 2016 presidential race.

headline: Trevor the Goat: A Stubborn Sweetheart
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — In a world of flashy, lean thoroughbreds, skinny jockeys, slender exercise riders and bony barn kitties, Trevor stands out from the moment you see him. Trevor looks like a heavy, swollen water barrel balanced precariously on four skinny legs and swings his head around to stare at you when you say hello. Whether curled up on a bale of hay or standing between barn rows, Trevor surveys all he sees through his raccoon-masked face with weird horizontal eyes that would seem more appropriate in a science fiction movie. If he decides to move, it might be with purpose. But then again, he might just stop and stare as he decides whether he wishes to move. You might swear that he is smiling at you the entire time.

headline: More Tech Magic, if You Can Afford It
text: LAST week, I glimpsed the future. I tried on Google Glass, the much-anticipated computer eyewear that lets you skim e-mail and shoot video.

headline: Am I an ‘Immigrant Writer’?
text: I learned recently, to my surprise, that I had written a novel about the immigrant experience. The novel I thought I’d written was simply about a mother and daughter, but the inside flap of the book jacket made it clear I had “written anew the immigrant experience.”

headline: National Rifle Association Holds Annual Meetings
text: Advocates of the second amendment met at the National Rifle Association’s meetings and exhibits in Houston.

headline: Another Order to Vacate at Site Threatened by Crane
text: One of the more dramatic moments as Hurricane Sandy raged last October took place in Midtown Manhattan when hundreds of people were forced to leave their homes because the winds accompanying the storm had damaged the boom of a crane that loomed 1,000 feet above the sidewalk from a soaring residential tower under construction just south of Columbus Circle.

headline: Dow 15,000, and the Big Disconnect
text: IT’S a ho-hum economy, at best. Four years after the end of the Great Recession, gross domestic product appears to be growing at a lackluster pace, labor productivity is lagging and, despite a slight improvement last month, the unemployment rate is still a painfully high 7.5 percent.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: A Talent for Teaching
text: Readers discuss what goes into making a gifted teacher.

headline: David Benioff
text: David Benioff is a novelist and screenwriter who co-created the popular HBO series “Game of Thrones.”

headline: The Cancer of Optimism
text: BOSTON

headline: Lost in the Geometry of California’s Farms
text: I drove down the San Joaquin Valley along Interstate 5 the other day. It was a tour of the less populous California, a route that — to borrow a 50-year-old phrase from Joan Didion — is also “the trail of an intention gone haywire.”

headline: Repairing the Credibility Cracks
text: THE scandal that exploded 10 years ago last week was epic, as world-class as the newspaper where it happened.

headline: European Stagnation
text: Economic conditions in Europe, especially in troubled nations like Spain, Portugal and Italy, have deteriorated sharply in recent months. Worse, new data released last week provides no hope for a recovery soon. The unemployment rate in the 17 countries that use the euro hit a record of 12.1 percent in March, up from 11 percent a year earlier. In Spain and Greece, more than half of the labor force under 25 is looking for work.

headline: The House Prefers Chaos to Order
text: “Regular order!” That has been the demand of House Republicans for three years, insisting on a return to the distant days when Congress actually passed budget resolutions and spending bills, instead of paying for the government through shortsighted stopgap measures.

headline: Academy Extends Voting Privileges in Foreign-Language Category
text: LOS ANGELES — Breaking with a practice that had narrowed Oscar voting in certain categories to those who had seen films on the big screen, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Saturday said it would provide members with DVD versions of nominees in the best foreign film and best documentary short categories, while allowing all voters to cast a final ballot in those races.

headline: Warriors and Grizzlies Play to Strengths
text: There was not one right way to reach the second round of the Western Conference playoffs. Two teams that won in first-round upsets, Golden State and Memphis, embraced their strengths and waited for the other team to slip up.

headline: Where’s My Ghost Money?
text: I WAS very excited to read, last week, about the “ghost money” that the C.I.A. is paying to the president of my country, Hamid Karzai. I’d like to know: would it be possible for the C.I.A. to give me some, too?

headline: Mr. Obama, Don’t Draw That Line
text: “THE use of chemical weapons is and would be totally unacceptable,” President Obama warned Bashar al-Assad’s government last December. “If you make the tragic mistake of using these weapons, there will be consequences and you will be held accountable.”

headline: A Child’s Wild Kingdom
text: IN a couple of weeks, my daughter will turn into a dolphin. Right now, she’s a fox. Last year, she was a cricket.

headline: This Ain’t Yogurt
text: AN Arab friend remarked to me that watching the United States debate how much to get involved in Syria reminded him of an Arab proverb: “If you burn your tongue once eating soup, for the rest of your life you’ll blow on your yogurt.”

headline: Worker Safety in Bangladesh and Beyond
text: The death toll from the collapse of a building in Bangladesh that housed several garment factories now stands at more than 500, with many still missing. While staggering, this tragedy is, sadly, not rare.

headline: In a Gaudy Theme Park, Jay-Z Meets J-Gatz
text: WHEN I started out in journalism, I spent five long years as a reporter in Montgomery County, Md., a cosseted suburb of Washington.

headline: What Health Insurance Doesn’t Do
text: IN one of the most famous studies of health insurance, conducted across the 1970s, thousands of participants were divided into five groups, with each receiving a different amount of insurance coverage. The study, run by the RAND Corporation, tracked the medical care each group sought out, and not surprisingly found that people with more comprehensive coverage tended to make use of it, visiting the doctor and checking into the hospital more often than people with less generous insurance.

headline: Beyond the Code of the Streets
text: ONE evening last week, I joined some friends for recreational beverages after work. These friends were all natives of a certain tribe — black men raised in the crack-era inner cities, now thriving in some other America. They were all college graduates (except me) and upstanding citizens of virtuous reputation. And like me, they were haunted by codes that aided their rise in the old world but might stunt their growth in the new.

headline: Sexism and the Single Murderess
text: “SEX game gone wrong,” “sex game gone awry,” “sex-mad flatmate,” “sex-crazed killer.”

headline: Where Do Old Cellphones Go to Die?
text: AMERICANS replace their cellphones every 22 months, junking some 150 million old phones in 2010 alone. Ever wondered what happens to all these old phones? The answer isn’t pretty.

headline: Capitals Take 2-0 Series Lead Over Rangers
text: WASHINGTON — The Rangers will remember their bitterly disappointing 1-0 overtime loss to the Washington Capitals on Saturday as a failure of their power play.

headline: 8 Soldiers Die in Attacks in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Eight soldiers with the American-led military coalition were killed Saturday, making it the bloodiest day this year for Western troops fighting here.

headline: When the Global Economy Was on the Brink
