text: NEIL IRWIN admires central bankers, and maybe he has a point. With the interplay of Congress and the presidency bordering on the dysfunctional these days, is there a more accomplished Washington figure than the scholarly and respected Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve?

headline: To Fight Pandemics, Reward Research
text: THAT frightening word “pandemic” is back in the news. A strain of avian influenza has infected people in China, with a death toll of more than 25 as of late last week. The outbreak raises renewed questions about how to prepare for possible risks, should the strain become more easily communicable or should other deadly variations arise.

headline: The Groundwork for Good References
text: Q. Of the many ways that companies evaluate job candidates, references still hold much weight. How can you ensure that managers or co-workers will say the right things when asked about you?

headline: A Family Perspective
text: I’M the second-youngest of six brothers. My dad owned a packaging company in Stratford, Conn., and most of my brothers worked there at some point, along with our aunts and uncles. I never did. Dad was selling the business by the time I reached my midteens, and he wanted me to get some experience elsewhere.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Orb Wins Kentucky Derby
text: Orb rallied down the homestretch on Saturday to win the 139th running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky.

headline: In First Victory, a First-Class Outing for Hughes
text: Even though Phil Hughes had not recorded a win, he still felt good about the beginning of his season. And for good reason: his fastball had been alive, his confidence was up, and the Yankees had been victorious in his previous two starts.

headline: A Simpler Bank System
text: To the Editor:

headline: Prizes With a Message
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Malaysia, a Historic Chance for Reform
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

headline: Corporations Find a Friend in the Supreme Court
text: NOT long after 10 a.m. on March 27, a restless audience waited for the Supreme Court to hear arguments in the second of two historic cases involving same-sex marriage. First, however, Justice Antonin Scalia attended to another matter. He announced that the court was throwing out an antitrust class action that subscribers brought against Comcast, the nation’s largest cable company.

headline: Crunch Time
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — This is going to be a divisive one, and I’ll tell you why. There’s nothing offensive in this puzzle, but there are those solvers who feel that if they are going to commit their time to a bigger grid on the weekend than they do for the daily puzzles, then the larger puzzle should be that much more entertaining. The theme should sparkle, nay, gleam. The entries should be lively and the clues should be both witty and spot on.

headline: Wise Dan Wins 6th Straight
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Wise Dan, reigning Horse of the Year, earned his sixth consecutive victory dating to last season when he took the $546,400 Woodford Reserve Turf Classic by 4 ¾ lengths over Optimizer on Saturday as a prelude to the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs.

headline: Latest Product From Tech Firms: An Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The television advertisement that hit the airwaves in Florida last month featured the Republican Party’s rising star, Senator Marco Rubio, boasting about his get-tough plan for border security.

headline: British M.P. Is Questioned in Rape Inquiry
text: A senior lawmaker from Britain’s ruling Conservative Party was arrested and questioned by the police on Saturday over allegations of rape and sexual assault involving two men, according to a person familiar with the investigation.

headline: Highlights From the N.R.A. Convention
text: A sampling of the speakers — including Sarah Palin and Senator Ted Cruz — at the National Rifle Association’s annual convention in Houston.

headline: John Williamson, Co-Founder of the Sandstone Retreat, Dies at 80
text: John and Barbara Williamson always insisted that Sandstone Retreat was about more than sex. By all means, help yourselves to each other, they would say. But the goal was larger than spouse-swapping or fulfilling forbidden lust.

headline: Alaska Media Battle Pits Old Power vs. Cable Rival
text: ANCHORAGE — Yes, Alaska is woolly and wild. But here is the paradox: it functions in many ways like a medium-size city with a big backyard. Nearly 54 percent of the population, in a state more than twice the size of Texas, clusters here in the largest metropolitan area. That degree of single-city dominance is matched in only a few other places in the United States, notably Nevada, where a tail named Las Vegas wags its dog.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, May 5
text: “The carriers are not innocent in this whole game. They are making profit off this.”

headline: Emil Frei III, Who Put Cancer Cures in Reach, Dies at 89
text: Dr. Emil Frei III, an oncologist whose trailblazing use of combination chemotherapy — in which anticancer drugs are administered simultaneously rather than singly — helped make certain cancers curable for the first time, died on Tuesday at his home in Oak Park, Ill. He was 89.

headline: Orb Finds Joy in Mudville
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The revelers were sloppy, the grounds were sloppy and the racetrack was sloppy, but Orb apparently did not mind much, and afterward his owners and trainer could not have been happier with the way the day played out.

headline: State Sale of 100 Longhorns Stirs Debate, and Proposed Law, on the Breed’s Future
text: The resilient longhorn, able to survive on sparse foliage and water, has endured in Texas for more than 100 years. But the recent sale of about 100 longhorns by the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department has spurred debate about the breed’s future in the state.

headline: Texas Legislators Set to Restore Women’s-Health Budgets
text: The political fireworks and high-octane drama that accompanied lawmakers’ 2011 fight over women’s health care and abortion have been absent this legislative session. They have been replaced with some semblance of concession, as legislators on both sides of the aisle work quietly to restore financing for women’s health services.

headline: Revisiting L.B.J.’s Austin, One Address at a Time
text: Long before Austin became a bustling hub of live music, technology and food trucks, it was a simple capital city, dominated by politicians and lobbyists. That city was the Austin of Lyndon Baines Johnson’s day. Though Johnson did not live in Austin for much of his life, the city made a mark on him from an early age. He was only 10 when he began accompanying his father, a state representative, to the Capitol, where he became enchanted with the legislative process.

headline: Small-Town Mayor’s Millions as Exhibit A on Graft in Spain
text: LA MUELA, Spain — In the good times, the former mayor of this small, wind-swept village of 5,000 in northern Spain was busy building: the olive oil museum, the wind museum, the museum of life. If that were not enough, there was the new bullring, the sports center with 25,000 seats and the zoo with the exotic-bird park.

headline: The Last Refuge From Scandal? Professorships
text: After a sex scandal forced Eliot Spitzer from the governor’s mansion in Albany, he turned up at City College, teaching a course called “Law and Public Policy.” After another sex scandal forced James E. McGreevey from the governor’s mansion in New Jersey, he turned up at Kean University, teaching in the global M.B.A. program.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 5
text: With April’s jobs report easing concerns about an economic slowdown, Warren E. Buffett, chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, joins ABC’s “This Week” to share his thoughts on the economy.

headline: Federation Agrees to Lead Effort Against Cheating
text: The Association of Chess Professionals announced on Monday that the World Chess Federation had finally agreed to create a committee to come up with ways to detect and stop cheating.

headline: Kentucky Derby Replay
text: Orb, ridden by jockey Joel Rosario, found a way to win despite muddy conditions at the 139th running of the Kentucky Derby.

headline: Berkshire’s Bear on Tangling With a Master of Question-Dodging
text: OMAHA — When Douglas A. Kass first learned that Warren E. Buffett had selected him to be the official skeptic at Berkshire Hathaway‘s annual meeting this year, the hedge fund manager knew he had a lot of work to do.

headline: Winning Battle of Nerves Against Himself, a Player Takes On the Tour
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Robert Karlsson’s round of three-under-par 69 Saturday at the Wells Fargo Championship began with a single swing, which is not as simple as it sounds. Karlsson, who moved into a tie for fourth at Quail Hollow at six-under 210, had to pull out of last year’s British Open after developing a nervous tic that made it torture to take the club back. During practice rounds, he stood frozen over his ball, unable to make a swing as the seconds turned into a minute or more.

headline: Rangers Fall as Pucks Sail Into Stands
text: WASHINGTON — Delay-of-game penalties loomed large for the Rangers in a 1-0 overtime loss to the Washington Capitals on Saturday.

headline: Song Critical of Pakistani Generals Is Blocked Online, With No Official Explanation
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani band with a reputation for satirizing the country’s military may have finally gone too far.

headline: Life in North Korean Complex: A Glimmer of Hope
text: SEOUL, South Korea — When the order came last weekend to evacuate an industrial park in North Korea, Kwak Kyung-dock, a South Korean factory manager, said he was forced to flee with the suit on his back — and his car filled with so many boxes of the plastic machinery parts made at his factory that he had to tie several on the roof.

headline: How Wright Prevailed in Duel With Top Closer
text: ATLANTA — David Wright smiled and offered no rational explanation for crushing a 97-mile-per-hour fastball from Craig Kimbrel 10 rows deep over the center-field wall in Turner Field on Friday night. Wright was an accidental hero, he said. He made it sound as if he simply ran into Kimbrel’s pitch. It was luck, he said.

headline: Off-the-Cuff Obama Line Put U.S. in Bind on Syria
text: WASHINGTON — Confronted with evidence that chemical weapons have been used in Syria, President Obama now finds himself in a geopolitical box, his credibility at stake with frustratingly few good options.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 5, 2013
text: “I’m worried about the broader damage to U.S. credibility if we make a statement and then come back with lawyerly language to get around it.”

headline: Islanders Looking to Ride Momentum in Front of Home Crowd
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — There was a buoyant atmosphere in the Islanders’ locker room after practice and their surprising Game 2 victory at Pittsburgh. Now they had a chance to contemplate Sunday’s afternoon matchup — their first playoff game at home since 2007 — at what is expected to be a raucous Nassau Coliseum.

headline: Two Are Arrested in Fatal Shooting of Bronx Teenager
text: The police on Saturday arrested two suspects in the fatal shooting of Alphonza Bryant III, the Bronx teenager whose death last month has helped fuel an increasingly rancorous debate over police anti-crime tactics.

headline: Up Next for Knicks: a Young, Healthy Copy of the Celtics
text: Before they departed the postseason stage Friday night, the Boston Celtics dealt the Knicks a warning shot: a furious fourth-quarter rally to remind them of their frailties. Before he left the postgame podium, Coach Doc Rivers delivered his own warning, shrouded in a compliment.

headline: The Dark Side, Carefully Masked
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — On the day after two bombs exploded near the finish line of the Boston Marathon, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev tapped out an early-afternoon text message to a classmate at the University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth. Want to hang out? he queried. Sure, his friend replied.

headline: Corrections: May 5, 2013
text: NATIONAL

headline: Nets Show Up Late And Miss Out on Celebration
text: The Nets fought back from a three-games-to-one deficit against the Chicago Bulls to earn this opportunity, a win-or-go-home game in their new arena and another chance for their black-clad fans to shower this rebranded franchise with full-throated adoration.

headline: Divided Over Bangladesh
text: A look at two companies with different responses to the tragedy in Bangladesh.

headline: Su Casa Es Mi Casa
text: You may not get room service or a terry cloth robe, but what Airbnb vacation rentals lack in amenities, they make up for in unbelievable, sometimes rather bizarre experiences.

headline: Game 7: Nets vs. Bulls Replay
text: The banged-up Bulls held off the Nets to advance to the second-round series against the Heat.

headline: For Capitals, It’s Pass First (and Often)
text: WASHINGTON — No matter how many times they eagerly drew up a new offensive plan Saturday afternoon, the Washington Capitals found themselves in the same old spot.

headline: Jennifer Maxwell, Robert McBride
text: Jennifer Lauren Maxwell, the daughter of Theresa M. Maxwell and John G. Maxwell of Warren, N.J., was married Saturday to Robert Lane McBride, a son of Barbara A. McBride and David F. McBride of North Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Elias R. Lorenzo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Holy Rosary Church in Washington.

headline: Samantha Jacobs, Andrew Miller
text: Samantha Alexandra Jacobs and Andrew Nathan Benbasset Miller were married Saturday evening in Old Westbury, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik officiated at the Old Westbury Golf and Country Club.

headline: Jennifer Lieber and Kathryn Murray
text: Jennifer Beth Lieber and Kathryn Lynn Murray were married Saturday evening at the Venetian Yacht Club in Babylon, N.Y. Denise Munoz, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Anna Diehn, Benoit Bewley
text: Anna Katharina Diehn, the daughter of Barbara Charlotte Diehn of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Dietrich Arndt Diehn, was married Saturday evening to Dr. Benoit Richard Bewley, a son of Anne-Françoise Lamine Bewley and Truman Fassett Bewley of Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Dennis Andrews, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Community Presbyterian Church in Deerfield Beach, Fla.

headline: Christina Daniels, William Schweitzer Jr.
text: Christina Learson Daniels, a daughter of Elizabeth L. Daniels and Leslie B. Daniels of New York, was married in Palm Beach, Fla., Saturday evening to William Hoefler Schweitzer Jr., a son of Leslie M. Schweitzer and Mr. Schweitzer Sr. of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. James R. Harlan performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea, where he is the rector. The Rev. Brenda Husson, another Episcopal priest, took part.

headline: Christina Lee, Kevin Wong
text: Christina Ling Yin Lee and Kevin Wong were married Saturday by the Rev. John Flack, a Lutheran minister, at the Queens Botanical Garden in Flushing, Queens.

headline: Diana Uhimov, Christopher Leahy
text: Diana J. Uhimov, a daughter of Mila Uhimov and Joseph G. Uhimov of Langhorne, Pa., and Christopher Michael Leahy, a son of Blitz F. Leahy and Michael J. Leahy of Manhattan, were married Saturday evening in Brooklyn. The father of the bride, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at Milk and Roses, a restaurant.

headline: A Silly Question From the License Clerk
text: Gabrielle Rae Marcus, a daughter of Madelynne and Howard Marcus of Miami, is to be married Sunday evening to Brian Adam Marcus, the son of Judith and Andrew Marcus of Manhattan. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas is to officiate at the Pierre in Manhattan.

headline: Nicole Lonsway, Alan Schindler
text: Nicole Stephanie Garber Lonsway and Alan Daniel Schindler were married Saturday evening in Middletown, Md. Rabbi Kenneth B. Block officiated at the Stone Manor Country Club.

headline: Alexis Oliver, Alan Wilkis
text: Alexis Eden Théroux Oliver and Alan Joshua Wilkis were married Saturday in the lobby of the Woolworth Building in New York. Geordie Broadwater, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Rebecca Lambert, Michael Kalin
text: Dr. Rebecca Lynn Lambert and Michael Hart Kalin were married Saturday evening at the Tarrytown House Estate in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Guy Greene officiated.

headline: Rebekah Enderle, Erin Simonds
text: Rebekah Elizabeth Enderle and Erin Forbes Simonds were married Saturday at the Alger House, an event space in New York. Dr. Kara L. Davis, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, performed a ceremony that included poetry readings.

headline: Burgers and Other Burning Issues
text: Dr. Jessica Kraft Sayre, a daughter of Marcia Kraft-Sayre and Steven E. Sayre of Charlottesville, Va., was married there Saturday to Dr. Matthew John Meyer, a son of Teresa Canal Meyer and John H. Meyer of Shelburne, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Barry Penn Hollar, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at Panorama Farms, an event space.

headline: Devon Giddon, Jason Bordenick
text: Devon Lindsay Giddon and Jason Scott Bordenick were married Saturday evening at Fresh Meadow Country Club in Lake Success, N.Y. Rabbi Matthew A. Reimer officiated.

headline: Hilary Horvat, Lisa Mody
text: Hilary Laura Horvat and Lisa Jean Mody were married Saturday in Manhattan. The Rev. Rosemary Bray McNatt officiated at the Fourth Universalist Society, where she is the senior minister.

headline: Alison Speranza, Casey McGrath
text: Alison Jo Speranza and Casey Thomas McGrath were married Saturday. The Rev. Mary-Rose Engle, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Grounds for Sculpture, a sculpture garden in Hamilton Township, N.J.

headline: Sarah Daniels, Kevin Cook
text: Dr. Sarah Ruth Daniels and Dr. Kevin Andrew Cook were married Saturday at the Ashford Estate, an event space in Allentown, N.J. Noah S. Daniels, a brother of the bride, who was ordained by the American Marriage Ministries, officiated.

headline: Jacqueline Friedman, Benjamin Brogadir
text: Jacqueline Leigh Friedman, the daughter of Susan Pilch Friedman and Richard A. Friedman of New York, was married Saturday evening to Benjamin Tureck Brogadir, a son of Ilene Brogadir and Dr. Stuart Brogadir of Bedford, N.H. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein performed the ceremony at the Central Synagogue in New York.

headline: Margot Kearney, Creighton Navins
text: Margot Helen Kearney and Creighton Lee Navins were married Saturday at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Thomas E. Collins, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Ingi Lee and David Yoon
text: Dr. Ingi Lee and David Seungro Yoon were married Saturday in Blue Bell, Pa. The Rev. Byeong Eun Lee, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Normandy Farm, a hotel and conference center.

headline: Jessica Oliff, Robert Daly
text: Jessica Lee Oliff and Robert Michael Leo Daly were married Saturday evening at the Rittenhouse Hotel in Philadelphia. The Very Rev. Msgr. Jim St. George of the Old Catholic Apostolic Church of North America performed the ceremony.

headline: Alyssa Beaver, Daniel Gomez II
text: Alyssa Leid Beaver, a daughter of Thea S. Beaver and William S. Beaver of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there Saturday to Daniel James Gomez II, a son of Alexis D. Gomez and Mr. Gomez of Wayne, Pa. The Rev. Dr. William P. Crawford performed the ceremony at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church, where he is the senior pastor, with Msgr. Thomas F. Petrillo, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

headline: A Charity Auctioneer Gets First Dibs
text: Willa Jane Bernstein and Kevin Michael Murphy were married Saturday evening at the Down Town Association, an event space in New York. The Rev. Ann V. Corbett, a minister ordained by the New Seminary for Interfaith Studies in New York, officiated.

headline: Hannah Richard, Robert Coody
text: Hannah McBride Richard and Robert Andrew Coody were married Saturday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Greenville, Ala. The Rev. M. Dow Sanderson, an Episcopal priest and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jennifer Piston, Ki Whelan
text: Jennifer Sarah Piston and Ki Aron Whelan were married Saturday aboard the yacht Atlantica, which was docked at Pier 61 in New York. Peter Tulba, a friend of the couple who was ordained by American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

headline: Clare Smith, John Kerrigan
text: Clare Elizabeth Smith and John Joseph Kerrigan were married Friday in Brooklyn. The Rev. Marek W. Sobczak performed the ceremony at the St. Stanislaus Kostka Roman Catholic Church, where he is pastor.

headline: Virginia Harper and Tomas Foulger
text: Virginia Italia Harper and Tomas Foulger were married Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Joseph G. Marina, a Roman Catholic priest and an associate pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Julie Greilsheimer, Ryan Silverman
text: Julie Bennett Greilsheimer and Ryan David Silverman are to be married Sunday evening at Battery Gardens Restaurant in New York. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein is to officiate.

headline: Bombings at Marathon Lead to Tighter Security
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Churchill Downs thought its security policy for the Kentucky Derby, in the planning since last autumn, was in place when spring arrived. But after the Boston Marathon bombings on April 15, everything changed.

headline: With Mental and Physical Mastery, Mayweather Stays Undefeated
text: LAS VEGAS — Floyd Mayweather Jr.’s latest boxing triumph followed a familiar pattern. For weeks, he toyed with Robert Guerrero, made him angry, made him jumpy, drew him right into the usual vortex of opponent overconfidence.

headline: Noah, Hobbled, Wills Bulls Into the Second Round
text: The emotion that Bulls center Joakim Noah showed as he walked off the court victorious, hugging his mother before triumphantly marching down the tunnel, was gone by the time he sat down to discuss the game. He simply had no energy left to expend.

headline: Australia Strives to Balance China and the United States
text: BEIJING — The official Chinese news media responded in a low-key, if apparently approving, fashion to a shift by the Australian government toward a more conciliatory strategic approach to China, judging by reactions over the weekend.

headline: A Billionaire Who Breaks the Mold
text: PARIS — Xavier Niel is not what you would expect in a billionaire.

headline: Palestinian Leader Seeks Chinese Support
text: HONG KONG — The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, arrived in Beijing on Sunday seeking support from Chinese leaders, days before Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is to make a visit of his own, although Israeli officials have said there are no plans for a meeting between them.

headline: C.I.A. ‘Ghost Money’ and the Fight Against Terror
text: It’s game-on for Karzai with C.I.A. “ghost money.”

headline: Naive Fiscal Cynicism
text: Expansionary austerity has been refuted and even the IMF sayis that short-run multipliers are big. The 90 percent red line on debt was an artifact of fuzzy math. The bond vigilantes remain invisible, and the confidence fairy refuses to make an appearance. Clearly, austerian economics has imploded (and some prominent austerians seem to be personally imploding too).

headline: Talking With My Daughter About My Service in Iraq
text: “Mom, what did you see over there? What was it like? Did you have a gun? Did you kill anyone?”

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Caravan magazine digs deep in a profile of the attorney general of India, the federal government’s top law officer, the “Inside Man.” It’s an important piece and one that’s long overdue, as the story correctly and articulately points out: “In an era when fortunes can be made and lost on the whims of government policy (or the manipulation thereof), billions of rupees hinge on the decisions of the Supreme Court, which has become the ultimate arbiter in innumerable disputes between corporates and the state. Today, the country’s top lawyers, who charge upwards of Rs. 10 lakh (Rs 1 million) for a single court appearance, are some of the capital’s most powerful figures, Delhi’s closest equivalent to the Wall Street investment bankers that Tom Wolfe once dubbed ‘masters of the universe’.”

headline: Syria Blames Israel for Fiery Attack in Damascus
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government publicly condemned Israel for a powerful air assault on military targets near Damascus early Sunday, saying it “opened the door to all possibilities,” as fear spread throughout the region that the country’s civil war could expand beyond its borders.

headline: North Korea Says Prisoner Won’t Be Used as Leverage
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said Sunday that it would not use an imprisoned American citizen as a political bargaining chip, rejecting the possibility of allowing any prominent Americans to visit the North to request his release, as it has in similar cases.

headline: Disruptions: New Motto for Silicon Valley: First Security, Then Innovation
text: At Facebook’s headquarters in Palo Alto, Calif., are stark white posters with bright red statements like “Done is better than perfect” and “Move fast and break things.”

headline: The Board of Education Lives On, if Only to Be Sued
text: On Jan. 9, 2003, Jamie Perez was slashed by two fellow students at Evander Childs High School in the Bronx. He recovered, and his mother, Nancy Torres, sued the City of New York for negligence, claiming lax security.

headline: McCain Says Airstrikes in Syria Put Pressure on Obama to Act
text: Senator John McCain, who has long advocated for more forceful United States support of the Syrian rebels, said Sunday that the two airstrikes just outside of the Syrian capital in recent days — which the Syrian government said were carried out by Israel — were likely to increase pressure on President Obama to act.

headline: British M.P. Rejects Accounts of Assaults
text: LONDON — Nigel Evans, the senior Conservative member of Parliament who has been questioned by the police over accusations of rape and sexual assault involving two men, said Sunday that the allegations were “completely false.”

headline: Regulation Scoreless Ties Are Rare for Rangers in Playoffs
text: Saturday’s 1-0 overtime loss at Washington marked the first time in 80 years that a Rangers playoff game went scoreless through regulation.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: NOON (13) UN BALLO IN MASCHERA Marcelo Álvarez, above with Kathleen Kim, performs the role of the ill-fated King Gustavo III; Dmitri Hvorostovsky is his best friend and eventual rival, Count Anckarstrom; and Sondra Radvanovsky is Amelia, Anckarstrom’s wife and the object of the king’s secret passion, in this Metropolitan Opera production of Verdi’s drama about political intrigue and thwarted romance. “The most interesting aspect of David Alden’s disappointing, metaphor-laden new production,” Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times of this “Great Performances at the Met” presentation, “is that he uses an early-20th-century setting and film noir imagery to emphasize not just the work’s darkness but also its strangeness.” Still, he said, Ms. Radvanovsky was “splendid,” and Mr. Hvorostovsky sang “with his trademark dark sound and supple phrasing, which poignantly brought to life this suffering husband’s love.”

headline: Neighbors Resist a Plan to Clean a Toxic Canal
text: Almost everybody wants the Gowanus Canal cleansed of its toxic gunk.

headline: A New Way to Care for Young Brains
text: BOSTON — The drumbeat of alarming stories linking concussions among football players and other athletes to brain disease has led to a new and mushrooming American phenomenon: the specialized youth sports concussion clinic, which one day may be as common as a mall at the edge of town.

headline: Anecdotal Evidence Provides Clues to Youth Concussions
text: Youth sports concussion clinics operate at the center of America’s heightened awareness and increasing worry about concussions among young athletes. Listening to the hundreds of stories of how concussions have occurred, examining patients and monitoring their recoveries, the doctors and staff members are a repository of anecdotal and medical concussion information.

headline: Frederic Franklin, Inventive and Charismatic Ballet Star, Is Dead at 98
text: Frederic Franklin, a charismatic British-born dancer and ballet master who was known for his stylistic versatility and his inexhaustible energy — he performed into his 90s — died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 98.

headline: Flubbing a Baseline Test on Purpose Is Often Futile
text: In 2011, quarterback Peyton Manning suggested he purposely flubbed a preseason neurocognitive baseline test to make the results of any postconcussion test look better, which might have improved his chances of returning to play sooner.

headline: Obama Delivers Message of Optimism to Class of ’13
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Acknowledging that commencement addresses are no place for partisanship, President Obama nonetheless skirted close to that political line on Sunday, telling graduates at Ohio State University to ignore antigovernment voices that “gum up the works” and instead aspire to be citizens who value both individual rights and community responsibilities.

headline: Slovenia Falls From Economic Grace, Struggling to Avert a Bailout
text: LJUBLJANA, SLOVENIA — Only a few years ago, Bine Kordez was feted as Slovenia’s star entrepreneur. After transforming a home-improvement chain, Merkur, into a regional giant, he drew on easy credit from state-run banks to help orchestrate a €400 million management buyout of the company, the largest in the country’s history.

headline: Obama Comments on Airstrikes in Syria
text: President Obama speaks about the airstrikes in Syria, which the country immediately blamed on Israel.

headline: On the Town: Glimpses of Americana, Through the Young
text: Jerome Robbins’s first two dances mapped out his creative life. After choreographing “Fancy Free,” a 1944 hit about three sailors on shore leave, he was clearly headed down the golden path of musical-theater. But a year later he created the playful “Interplay,” which integrated classical steps with a jazzy, American style of moving. This showed his range; Robbins’s other foot belonged in ballet.

headline: In Russia, a Modern Theater Is the Star
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Let no one say Valery Gergiev doesn’t know how to give a party.

headline: Nets Will Replace Carlesimo After Being ‘Out-Toughed’ by Bulls
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Nets’ off-season began late Saturday, after a Game 7 loss that will sting long into summer. Less than 24 hours later, the team took its first step toward the future, announcing that the interim coach P. J. Carlesimo would not return.

headline: Last Hope in Ruins: Bangladesh’s Race to Save Shaheena
text: SAVAR, Bangladesh — The rescuers discovered her by a faint, distant sound. They had spent four days crawling through the wreckage of Rana Plaza, tons of concrete and steel pressing down, saving hundreds of people. Now only the dead remained. Except for a lone woman, a garment worker.

headline: Man Accused of Lying Seeks Release as Cemeteries Reject Tsarnaev Family
text: BOSTON — Robel K. Phillipos, the former University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth student who is accused of lying to the authorities investigating the Boston Marathon bombings, will seek to be released from federal custody on Monday, his lawyers said in court papers filed over the weekend.

headline: Tensions Rise After Airstrikes in Syria
text: Syria blamed the airstrike Sunday on Israel, and it was believed to be Israel’s second in three days.

headline: Succession at Berkshire Is Minor Concern for NetJets’ Chief
text: OMAHA — Many of the questions at Berkshire Hathaway‘s annual shareholder meeting here dwelled on what life after Warren E. Buffett will look like.

headline: In ‘Iron Man,’ Hopes for Strong Summer for Movies
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s all-important summer season began with a sonic boom over the weekend as “Iron Man 3” flew to a superheroic $175.3 million in ticket sales in North America, for a new global total of $680.1 million.

headline: Spring North American Championships
text: ST. LOUIS — The Spring North American Championships here in March featured a lot more excellent deals than is usual for a Nationals. In some ways the diagramed deal was the best of them all, although, to be fair, declarer had one opportunity to ruin the story. It was first reported by Sven-Olov Flodqvist from Sweden.

headline: Stories of Struggle and Creativity as Sequestration Cuts Hit Home
text: Facing the task of cutting 142 children from the Head Start program in Colorado Springs this fall, the teachers and administrators came up with a creative response: Have the children decorate empty chairs, then sell them for $500 apiece to stave off the worst of the across-the-board federal cuts heading their way. So far, in a month, their “Fill a Seat” fund-raiser has filled just two slots in the program.

headline: A Ring Virtuoso, Fighting for Respect
text: LAS VEGAS

headline: For a Night, Three-Part Harmony and Multipart Orchestra Are One
text: “This is sort of like three children being let loose at NASA,” David Crosby said. “But boy, is it fun.” With his longtime colleagues Graham Nash and Stephen Stills, Mr. Crosby was the most voluble participant in an outlandish musical experiment at Rose Hall at Jazz at Lincoln Center on Friday evening: the conjoining of Crosby, Stills and Nash with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra. Talk about worlds colliding.

headline: Up Two, Down Two, Isles Tie It and Lose
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Pittsburgh Penguins forward Chris Kunitz is exceptionally glad that Sidney Crosby is back on the ice. So are his teammates, who escaped with a win Sunday over the pesky Islanders.

headline: Evoking a Time and Place for Daring Experiments
text: From the end of the 19th century through the first decades of the 20th century Vienna was a hotbed of cultural, social and political ferment. The soprano Renée Fleming chose this era as the focus of the final program in her Perspectives series this season at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night.

headline: An Intentional Spectacle
text: “I hate the harpsichord, it reminds me of a sewing machine,” the composer John Cage is reported to have said. Yet a commission from Antoinette Vischer, a Swiss harpsichordist who specialized in modern music, prompted Cage to conceive one of his most audacious creations: “HPSCHD,” fashioned in collaboration with another composer, Lejaren Hiller.

headline: Accessories No Longer Tethered to Apple
text: For years, Apple’s clout in the electronics world could be gauged by how easy it was to bump into devices tailor-made for a connection to an iPhone or iPod.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: A Return to the Nine-Hole Round
text: Less than 30 years ago, nearly half of the golf courses in America had nine holes. There was no stigma to that number. The nine-hole golf round was as common as a slice off the first tee.

headline: Foreign Bride as a Fetish and a Person
text: Steven is a 60-year-old parking-garage attendant who lives in a small apartment above a store in the Northern California suburbs. He’s white, which is significant because he has what is politely known as an Asian fetish and popularly known as yellow fever. “They’re all so beautiful,” he says, looking at a display of thumbnail images of prospective Asian brides.

headline: Honoring Songbook’s Dean
text: What would the composer Jerome Kern have made of Woodstock? That question was asked but not answered on Saturday evening at the 92nd Street Y by Deborah Grace Winer, the artistic director of the venerable Lyrics and Lyricists series, in the opening-night concert of its season’s second-to-last program.

headline: With Pettitte Missing His Touch, Yankees Fall to Athletics
text: After more than 18 seasons in the major leagues, Yankees starter Andy Pettitte knows what the ball is supposed to feel like once it leaves his hand. There is a certain subtlety that makes it difficult for him to explain the feeling, but he knows by touch. He knows almost immediately after he throws a pitch how it will arrive at home plate without even seeing it land in the catcher’s mitt.

headline: On Script and Off, Giving Voice to the Yankees
text: The day after the Boston Marathon bombings, the New York Yankees honored the fallen in a pregame ceremony at their stadium in the Bronx. The task of leading the fans in this tribute went to Paul Olden, the team’s public-address announcer. He felt something was missing, though.

headline: Mail Letters
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Warning: vowel run. But not the kind you’re thinking of.

headline: A Fund-Raiser’s Finale
text: There are many artists at Lincoln Center. Reynold Levy, president of the performing arts center, likes to think of himself as one of them. His art is putting the arm on donors, and he is acknowledged to be one of the very best nudges in New York. “I’ve asked everyone for money,” Mr. Levy said in an interview. “They hide behind pillars when they see me.”

headline: Fighting Words Against Big Data
text: As its title indicates, Jaron Lanier’s new tech manifesto asks, “Who owns the future?” But for many of those who will be captivated by Mr. Lanier’s daringly original insights, another question comes first: Who is Jaron Lanier? He is a mega-wizard in futurist circles. He is the father of virtual reality in the gaudy, reputation-burnishing way that Michael Jackson was the king of pop. Mr. Lanier would undoubtedly be more of a household name if he were not a large, dreadlocked, anything but telegenic figure with facial hair called “mossy” in a 2011 profile in The New Yorker.

headline: A Dancing Queen Extends Her Reign
text: Dance-floor hits like “Waterloo,” “S.O.S.” and “Gimme! Gimme! Gimme! (A Man After Midnight)” hardly seem to be any less ubiquitous in the more than 30 years since they were first recorded by Abba, the best-selling Swedish pop quartet. But if its music is everywhere, its band mates are not: in particular, it’s been almost a decade since listeners last heard from Agnetha Faltskog, the singer whose distinctive voice helped give Abba its carefree Scandinavian charm.

headline: TED Teams Up With PBS on Ideas for Education
text: Television viewers — even those who watch the more sober-minded PBS — are generally not keen on sitting through long speeches. But TED, the nonprofit group that sponsors conferences on ideas, thinks it has found a way to bring its signature 18-minute talks to a TV audience that may not have found them on the Web or through mobile apps.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Mets’ Fielding Miscues Lead to Loss to Braves
text: ATLANTA — The Mets wrestled with themselves all afternoon Sunday. Wild pitches, misplayed balls, bad swings and walks ruined them. The team that looked spectacularly poised Friday night in a dramatic victory over Atlanta lost to the Braves, 9-4, at Turner Field.

headline: Compensation Compared
text: The pay of top media company chief executives compared with other industries.

headline: Wrongfully Convicted Often Find Their Record, Unexpunged, Haunts Them
text: In Wisconsin, Audrey Edmunds served 11 years in prison in the shaking death of an infant girl for whom she had been baby-sitting. In 2008, a mountain of new medical evidence cast so much doubt on the case that a higher court overturned her conviction and set her free. Leaving prison, Ms. Edmunds hoped that would be the end of it.

headline: George Osborne’s Fear of Ghosts
text: Truly, we live in bizarro world. The stern taskmasters of the IMF are coming to Britain, to demand that the government live it up and spend more; the government, defiantly, will insist on continuing to impose suffering.

headline: Kierkegaard’s ‘Antigone’
text: Perhaps the most central theme in Soren Kierkegaard’s religious thought is the doctrine of original sin: the idea that we share in some essential human guilt simply by being born. But guilt is an important concept also in Kierkegaard’s secular writings. He thought that the modern era was defined by its concept of guilt. Kierkegaard’s 200th birthday gives us an occasion to assess the modern relevance of his legacy and the viability of his own view of modernity.

headline: Media Giants Chase Online Ads With Original Shows
text: Everyone wants to be in show biz, and these days — on the Web at least — it seems as if everyone is.

headline: With Aggressive Defense, Pacers Shut Down Knicks
text: The challenge necessarily grows bigger as the N.B.A. playoffs progress, and the Knicks are a seasoned enough group to understand this basic truth. It was, however, not the size of the challenge but the actual size of the players standing in their path that put the first real crimp in the Knicks’ postseason thrill ride.

headline: A Call for New Blood on the JPMorgan Board
text: An influential shareholder advisory firm has recommended that investors withhold their support for three JPMorgan Chase directors, citing “material failures of stewardship and risk oversight” in the wake of a big trading loss last year.

headline: Eleanor R. Adair, Microwave Proponent, Dies at 86
text: Eleanor R. Adair, a scientist who spent decades exposing monkeys and eventually people (including herself) to microwave radiation to determine whether it posed serious health risks — she concluded, emphatically and somewhat controversially, that it did not — died on April 20 in Hamden, Conn. She was 86.

headline: Airstrikes Tied to Israel May Be Message to Iranians
text: JERUSALEM — The twin airstrikes in Damascus on Friday and Sunday attributed to Israel appear to be more about Jerusalem’s broad, mostly covert battle with Iran and Hezbollah than about the bloody civil war raging in Syria.

headline: Mickelson Fades Late as Tour Rookie Secures First Victory in Playoff
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Who can take some rainfall, create cover with his smile and give fans the thumbs-up on Quail Hollow’s thorny Green Mile? Phil Mickelson can. But on a damp, dreary Sunday, Mickelson’s sunny demeanor could not light his way to victory at the Wells Fargo Championship.

headline: Buyout Consortium Said Near a Deal for BMC
text: 8:28 p.m. | Updated

headline: BuzzFeed Takes Steps to Expand Foreign News
text: BuzzFeed, the swiftly growing social news site, has decided it is time to move beyond top 10 lists, animal videos and political coverage. It is going foreign.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Information to be released includes the euro area purchasing managers’ index for April (Monday); United States consumer credit for March and China trade data for April (Tuesday); China inflation for April (Wednesday); and weekly initial jobless claims and United States wholesale inventories for March (Thursday).

headline: Malaysia’s Governing Coalition Keeps Hold on Power
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Malaysia’s governing coalition won a majority of parliamentary seats in national elections on Sunday after the largest turnout in the country’s history, but a bitter coalition of opposition parties claimed that the result was tainted by illegal voting and other irregularities.

headline: An End to Scrounging for Plus-Size Clothing
text: NEARLY three in four American men over 19 are overweight, so it should come as no surprise that most men shopping at big-and-tall stores are of average height but considerable girth. Marketing for such stores, however, features models built more like professional football players than their beer-drinking fans.

headline: Cabinet Pick’s Finances May Foreshadow Battle
text: WASHINGTON — In November 2008, as President-elect Barack Obama began putting together his cabinet, reports emerged that he was considering nominating Penny Pritzker, the billionaire Hyatt Hotels heiress and businesswoman who had served as his chief campaign fund-raiser, as commerce secretary. But faced with awkward questions about her financial dealings, she declared that she did not want the nomination.

headline: Merkel’s Flagging Coalition Partner Tries to Bolster Its Image
text: MUNICH — The struggling junior partner in Germany’s coalition government tried over the weekend to overcome its image as a bickering party lacking in leadership and solid policies at a party congress in Nuremberg where delegates heard rousing speeches, sharp attacks on the opposition and an election plan intended to attract voters concerned about maintaining German prosperity.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Poetry of the Streets, Written by Those Who Know Them Best
text: The poets work from 5 to 5, day shift or night, conducting their research with the meter running.

headline: Strict Limits on Giving in City Races Are Upheld
text: A judge on Friday rebuffed an attempt by George T. McDonald, a first-time Republican mayoral candidate, to overturn New York City’s strict limits on campaign contributions, ruling that the city had the right to try to reduce the influence of money in politics.

headline: Behind the Scenes at Fox
text: A few days before the presidential election last November, Roger Ailes, the chief executive of Fox News, ordered that Geraldo Rivera’s microphone be cut off after Mr. Rivera angrily defended the Obama administration against charges levied by others on Fox. So says a forthcoming book about the 2012 campaign by Jonathan Alter, a columnist for Bloomberg View and a contributor to MSNBC, a Fox competitor.

headline: One Race Down, It’s Off to Next for Orb
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — By noon Sunday, Barn 43 at Churchill Downs had been practically wiped clean. There were no horses in the stalls, no signs of what had happened there throughout the week, culminating in Orb’s thrilling come-from-behind Kentucky Derby victory, save for a few scribbled notes on a message board that included a veterinarian’s phone number and the horses’ feed schedules.

headline: Extremists Pursue Mainstream in Pakistan Election
text: KHALID WALID, Pakistan — Dust swirled as the jeep, heralded by a convoy of motorcycle riders and guarded by gunmen in paramilitary-style uniforms, pulled up outside the towering tomb of an ancient Muslim saint.

headline: Israeli Attacks on Syria Fuel Debate Over U.S.-Led Effort
text: WASHINGTON — The apparent ease with which Israel struck missile sites and, by Syrian accounts, a major military research center near Damascus in recent days has stoked debate in Washington about whether American-led airstrikes are the logical next step to cripple President Bashar al-Assad’s ability to counter the rebel forces or use chemical weapons.

headline: For Media Moguls, Paydays That Stand Out
text: What’s the difference between a media mogul and a chief executive elsewhere in the business world? About $10 million in compensation, give or take.

headline: Caught in Methodism’s Split Over Same-Sex Marriage
text: NEW HAVEN — It started out as a deeply personal act, that of a father officiating at the wedding of his son.

headline: Rangers Are Looking for Solution on Offense
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Washington goalie Braden Holtby made a statement Saturday that the Rangers have taken as a rallying point as they look to overcome a 2-0 deficit in their first-round playoff series.

headline: New Law in Libya Bans Some From Office
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Young Libyans call their government “rule of the mooq-mooq,” a nonsensical neologism used to mock the armed militias left over from the uprising against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. And on Sunday, some said, Libya’s transitional General National Congress handed a new triumph to the mooq-mooq.

headline: Kennedy Library Gives Courage Award to Giffords
text: BOSTON — Caroline Kennedy was not even 6 years old when her father was assassinated 50 years ago. And on Sunday, she said the hurt never heals.

headline: Closing the Social Gap in Schools
Q. and A. With Penny Pritzker in 2008
text: In November 2008, after Senator Barack Obama won the presidential election, reports circulated that he was vetting one of his major campaign donors, the businesswoman and Hyatt Hotels heiress Penny Pritzker, as his commerce secretary nominee. The New York Times sent a list of detailed questions to Ms. Pritzker, through her publicist, about her business dealings. Several hours later, she issued a statement saying she did not want to be considered for the position, but she still answered The Times’s questions. On Thursday, President Obama announced that he was nominating Ms. Pritzker to be commerce secretary for his second term. Here are her written answers from 2008.

headline: German Outpost Born of Racism in 1887 Blends Into Paraguay
text: NUEVA GERMANIA, Paraguay — The year was 1887 when two of the best-known German anti-Semites of the time put down stakes here in Paraguay’s remote jungle with 14 German families screened for their racial purity.

headline: USA Network to Explore Sitcoms and Reality Shows
text: For most of the past decade the USA Network has lived by the mantra “blue skies,” which has translated into programming a string of upbeat hourlong drama hits, like “Burn Notice” and “Royal Pains.”

headline: An Unfair Barrier to Employment
text: Sixty-five million Americans have criminal records that might cause them to be denied jobs, even for arrests or minor convictions that occurred in the distant past. Last year, the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission reaffirmed a longstanding ruling that it was illegal to screen out employees unless the offense was directly related to the job.

headline: Real Gun Control From Sacramento
text: A continent removed from Washington’s shameful resistance to new gun controls, California has just enacted a law that will speed up the confiscation of firearms from an estimated 20,000 people who bought them legally but were later disqualified because of a conviction for a violent crime, a finding of mental illness or a restraining order for domestic violence. The law, signed Wednesday by Gov. Jerry Brown after passage by the Democrat-controlled Legislature, is a sign that enlightened lawmaking unhindered by gun lobby scare tactics and Capitol Hill filibustering is possible in American politics.

headline: A Bit of Sunshine Returns at Last for Fans in the Twilight of an Era
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y.

headline: In Place of Compassion, Cruelty
text: The Justice Department’s inspector general last week issued a report on the appalling failure of the Federal Bureau of Prisons to do its duty in assisting in the release of terminally ill inmates and others in extreme situations. The 85-page report by the inspector general’s office criticized the bureau’s “compassionate release” program, which has been “poorly managed and implemented inconsistently, likely resulting in eligible inmates not being considered for release and in terminally ill inmates dying before their requests were decided.”

headline: A Disappointing Debut
text: Mary Jo White, the new chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has gotten off on the wrong foot. Last week, in her first commission vote, Ms. White led the commissioners in approving a proposal that, if finalized, could leave investors and taxpayers exposed to the ravages of reckless bank trading.

headline: Transformation of a Town Underscores Immigrants’ Impact
text: PORT CHESTER, N.Y. — Nearly 20 years after he arrived penniless in this country from Mexico, Moises owns two restaurants, with a third on the way. He has five employees, an American wife and a stepdaughter. His food even has a following on Yelp.com.

headline: Syria Is Not Iraq
text: IN the search for an American response to the civil war in Syria, the favorite guidebook seems to be our ill-fated adventure in Iraq. We have another brutal Middle East autocrat holding power on behalf of a sectarian minority. We have another dubious cast of opposition factions competing for foreign patronage. We hear some of the same hawks — John McCain, Paul Wolfowitz — exhorting us to intervene, countered by familiar warnings of “quagmire.” We even have murky intelligence claims that the regime has used weapons of mass destruction.

headline: How Social Networks Drive Black Unemployment
text: It’s easy to believe the worst is over in the economic downturn. But for African-Americans, the pain continues — over 13 percent of black workers are unemployed, nearly twice the national average. And that’s not a new development: regardless of the economy, job prospects for African-Americans have long been significantly worse than for the country as a whole.

headline: The Chutzpah Caucus
text: At this point the economic case for austerity — for slashing government spending even in the face of a weak economy — has collapsed. Claims that spending cuts would actually boost employment by promoting confidence have fallen apart. Claims that there is some kind of red line of debt that countries dare not cross have turned out to rest on fuzzy and to some extent just plain erroneous math. Predictions of fiscal crisis keep not coming true; predictions of disaster from harsh austerity policies have proved all too accurate.

headline: Harvey to Get Extra Rest Because of Rainout
text: ATLANTA — The last thing the Mets wanted was a day off.

headline: Finding Traces of a Failed Aryan Colony
text: Nueva Germania was founded in the late 1800s by German immigrants looking to start an Aryan colony in Paraguay. It failed, but remnants of German culture remain.

headline: Jet Makers Avoid Risk by Redoing Old Models
text: After a decade of pushing hard on the edge of technology, Boeing and Airbus are turning more cautious in building new jetliners.

headline: Denmark's Work-Life Balance

headline: Egyptian Premier’s Motorcade Comes Under Attack
text: CAIRO — An armed man fired birdshot pellets at a motorcade escorting the Egyptian prime minister on Sunday, but officials characterized it as an accidental episode of road rage rather than an assassination attempt.

headline: ‘The Piano Lesson’ and ‘The Whale’ Win Lortel Awards
text: Signature Theater’s revival of August Wilson’s “Piano Lesson” and the Playwrights Horizon production of “The Whale” were the big winners on Sunday night at the ceremony for the Lucille Lortel Awards, which honors Off Broadway works. “The Piano Lesson” won the most awards in competition — four — for outstanding revival, director (Ruben Santiago-Hudson), lead actress (Roslyn Ruff) and featured actor (Chuck Cooper). “The Whale,” by Samuel D. Hunter, won for outstanding play and lead actor for Shuler Hensley, who played a morbidly obese man coming to terms with his mistakes and fears. Jessica Pabst also won for her costumes for “The Whale.”

headline: Solving Equation of a Hit Film Script, With Data
text: LOS ANGELES — Forget zombies. The data crunchers are invading Hollywood.

headline: A Homemade Style of Terror: Jihadists Push New Tactics
text: WASHINGTON — Aware that intensified American counterterrorism efforts have made an ambitious Sept. 11-style plot a long shot, Al Qaeda propagandists for several years have called on their devotees in the United States to carry out smaller-scale solo attacks and provided the online education to teach them how.

headline: Cross-Dressing Onstage Isn’t What It Used to Be
text: Strange as it may seem in these days of increasingly blurred gender norms, watching a woman dressed as a man singing songs of love for women may actually be a more exotic entertainment today than it was a century ago. In “The Girl I Left Behind Me,” a lovely show that opened on Sunday night at the 59E59 Theaters, the gorgeously gifted singer Jessica Walker and the writer Neil Bartlett conjure a vanished novelty of the theater, the cross-dressing female performers who once fascinated large audiences in England and America in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

headline: By Himself, Hibbert Seems to Outnumber the Knicks
text: The Knicks tried to challenge Roy Hibbert from every angle. J. R. Smith tried to drive past him. Tyson Chandler attempted to go above him for rebounds. Carmelo Anthony, his jump shot inconsistent, at one point tried to dunk over Hibbert. But Hibbert, the Indiana Pacers’ 7-foot-2 center, stood his ground.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Girl’s Death by Gunshot Is Rejected as Symbol
text: BURKESVILLE, Ky. — Last Monday, Kristian Sparks and his sister, Caroline, visited a Fred’s Super Dollar store here. A store manager recalled that it was an ordinary shopping trip, saying that the boy was outgoing and energetic, his little sister was cute and their grandmother was “like any grandmother — she bought them anything they wanted.”

headline: Corruption Charge Expected for Senator
text: John L. Sampson, a state senator from Brooklyn and a former leader of the Democratic caucus, will be charged on Monday in connection with a continuing public corruption inquiry, according to law enforcement officials close to the investigation.

headline: Sport of Many Nations Finds a Home in the Bronx
text: The ball came flying. The batter, in crisp game whites, slammed it into the ground, then bounded across a clay strip and back again, bat still in hand. His teammates cheered. And there was not a stray soccer ball or an invading rugby player in sight.

headline: Walsh’s Past and Present Clash, and He Wins Either Way
text: A generation ago, the small-market Indiana Pacers had to climb a figurative mountain inside Madison Square Garden before realizing they had what it took to win a playoff series in the big, forbidding city.

headline: A Court Rule Directs Cases Over Friskings to One Judge
text: After an attempted police stop in 1999 led to the shooting of an unarmed Guinean immigrant named Amadou Diallo, a civil-rights group sued the New York Police Department over the stop-and-frisk practices of its elite Street Crime Unit. From one of the wooden wheels used to assign cases in Federal District Court in Manhattan, a judge’s name was drawn: Shira A. Scheindlin.

headline: Dinosaur Skeleton to Be Returned to Mongolia
text: After a little detour through the American criminal justice system, Mongolia’s celebrity dinosaur, Tyrannosaurus bataar, is heading home, the most recent stage in a journey spanning some 70 million years.

headline: Houlihan Lokey Hires Lazard Banker to Lead Its Asian Unit
text: HONG KONG — Houlihan Lokey, a privately owned investment bank based in Los Angeles that specializes in advisory services, has hired a former top regional banker from Lazard to lead its business in Asia.

headline: Griner Says She Is Part of Mission to Help All Live in Truth
text: When the N.B.A. center Jason Collins announced he was gay last week, I was thrilled. Not only was I extremely happy for him, I thought that maybe, just maybe, his courage and the wave of positive reaction meant that we were on the verge of an era when people accept and celebrate one another’s differences. I think that’s what makes life beautiful: everyone is different and we can all learn from one another.

headline: The Baselworld Watch Fair Gets an Extreme Makeover
text: Baselworld, the annual watch fair in Basel, Switzerland, got a face-lift this year, care of Herzog and De Meuron, the local architecture firm best known for creating the “Bird’s Nest” Stadium for the 2008 Beijing Olympics and converting a London power station into the Tate Modern in 2000; the firm completed its three-year transformation of the vast exhibition space just in time for the show, which concluded last week. The building’s exterior is now clad in a woven skin of undulating, interconnected bands of aluminum, while its interior is more open and easily maneuverable. Many exhibitors got in the spirit, hiring star designers to redesign their booths. Above, six of the best.

headline: Beauty and the Beast
text: The artist Joshua Abelow creates a drawing inspired by Gabrielle Calvocoressi’s poetic encounter with a deer in the twilight.

headline: A Musical Message for Children on Healthy Eating

headline: Sucking Your Child’s Pacifier Clean May Have Benefits
text: For years, health officials have told parents not to share utensils with their babies or clean their pacifiers by putting them in their mouths, arguing that the practice spreads harmful germs between parent and child. But new research may turn that thinking on its head.

headline: How Colonoscopies Are Like Home Renovations
text: IT’S a law of nature: Everyone who undertakes major home renovations ends up loathing their contractor. When I was recently redoing my kitchen and bathroom, I finally figured out why. It has nothing to do with the contractor’s honesty, quality of work, punctuality or the mess they make. It’s about behavioral economics and human psychology — in particular, the unusual way that we assess pain.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 10 P.M. (Lifetime) DEAR MOM, LOVE CHER In what started as an 86th birthday gift, Cher chronicles the life of her mother, Georgia Holt, (above right, with Cher) from her childhood in rural Arkansas through her eight tumultuous marriages (to six men) as she pursued a career in Hollywood as a singer and actress. Among those interviewed are Cher’s sister, Georganne LaPiere Bartylak, and her children, Chaz Bono and Elijah Blue Allman. Ms. Holt has just released her first album, “Honky Tonk Woman,” featuring tracks she recorded in the 1980s with Elvis Presley’s band as well as a duet with Cher.

headline: Moving Walls — and Minds

headline: Syrian Rebels Say They Downed Helicopter Amid New Claims on Chemical Weapons
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian rebels said Monday that they had shot down a government helicopter in the east of the country, killing eight security troops, as new accusations emerged that insurgents seeking to overthrow President Bashar al-Assad may have used an illegal nerve agent in the country’s grinding civil war. The rebels denied the assertion.

text: The first of our new Retro Report series revisits the 1987 voyage of a barge loaded with New York garbage. It became an international fiasco, but foreshadowed the modern recycling movement.

text: Jeff Opperman, a senior freshwater scientist with the Nature Conservancy, is taking a once-in-a-lifetime trip down the Mekong River in Southeast Asia with his wife and two children, ages 8 and 10. Previous posts can be found here.

headline: Europe Rules Against Patent Move by Google’s Motorola Unit
text: BRUSSELS — The European Commission on Monday made a preliminary antitrust finding against Google’s mobile communications unit, Motorola Mobility, for seeking and enforcing an injunction against Apple in Germany over patents essential to smartphones and tablets.

headline: The Ballot Against the Bullet
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — At the start of last week I was in the nation’s capital, Islamabad, which adjoins the country’s most populous and most powerful province, Punjab. Almost all the political talk there was about Punjab, the home province of former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, where he and his Pakistan Muslim League-N (P.M.L.-N) have been holding rallies, urging supporters to vote them into power. Most analysts believe that is exactly what will happen, even though Sharif won’t have the easy ride that he might once have expected: The cricketer-turned-politician Imran Khan and his Pakistan Tehrik-e-Insaf (P.T.I.) party have strong support in Punjab, and Khan has been traveling the length and breadth of the province to prove the pundits wrong. This is as it should be in a democracy the week before an election.

headline: Some Celebrity Sponsors of Rival Products Can’t Give Up Their iPhones
text: Just as sports brands like Nike pay basketball players to wear their sneakers, phone makers occasionally pay celebrities to use their phones. Apple, though, has not sought those endorsements. It seems to be getting them anyway as several of the sponsored celebrities have let it slip that, oops, they’re using iPhones.

Mark Sanford, a Republican, 46 percent to 47 percent, in the special election to represent South Carolina’s First Congressional District.

headline: Genius in Helsinki!
text: I wrote the other day about some of the technological advances that are commonplace in Europe, but not yet in America. As I flew home, I had a layover in the Helsinki airport, where I saw one more really smart idea.

headline: Finding Fault With JPMorgan’s Directors
text: Institutional Shareholder Services, the influential advisory firm, has recommended that JPMorgan Chase investors withhold their support for three directors, citing “material failures of stewardship and risk oversight” after last year’s huge trading loss, Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. The directors, David M. Cote, James S. Crown and Ellen V. Futter, serve on the board’s risk policy committee. Only under “extraordinary circumstances” does I.S.S. consider recommending that shareholders oppose directors, the advisory firm said in its report.

headline: Tech Lobby Pushes for Tweaks to Immigration Bill
text: Lobbyists for the technology industry, having gained much of their wish list in the immigration bill drafted in the Senate, are now pushing to modify language they consider onerous.

text: Yoga for airplane travelers, the benefits of sucking your child’s pacifier clean, loan qualifications for retirees and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Crestwood to Merge With Inergy to Create $7 Billion Firm
text: As the boom in drilling continues to foster deal-making, Crestwood Midstream Partners L.P. agreed to buy control of a fellow gas pipeline operator, Inergy L.P., on Monday to form a company with a combined enterprise value of about $7 billion.

headline: Giulio Andreotti, Premier of Italy 7 Times, Dies at 94
text: Giulio Andreotti, a seven-time prime minister of Italy with a résumé of signal accomplishments and checkered failings that reads like a history of the republic, died on Monday. He was 94 and lived in Rome.

headline: Publishers Clearing House Imagines Handing a Big Check to Gilligan and Mike Brady
text: For years, Publishers Clearing House — the company that uses sweepstakes to help sell merchandise and magazine subscriptions — has devoted a good deal of its marketing efforts to television commercials showing prize winners being taped for television commercials. Now, in a campaign that is to begin on Monday, the company’s commercials will be devoted to a different aspect of television: sitcoms.

headline: Cuba Challenges Australian Tobacco Rules
text: PARIS — Cuba is seeking to overturn Australia’s tough tobacco-labeling rules at the World Trade Organization, the trade body said Monday, the first time that Havana has used the forum to directly confront another nation over its commercial laws.

headline: Senator in Corruption Case Spoke of Silencing Witnesses, Prosecutors Say
text: Accusations of wrongdoing have swirled around State Senator John L. Sampson for years. But when he became concerned that his actions were under scrutiny by federal prosecutors, he allegedly took a step that stands out even in the growing annals of wrongdoing by New York lawmakers.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap: With a Merger, the Show Rights Itself

headline: Investor Group Buys BMC for $6.9 Billion
text: BMC Software Inc. agreed on Monday to sell itself to a group of investors led by Bain Capital and Golden Gate Capital for about $6.9 billion, completing a campaign by an activist hedge fund to push the company into a deal.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Outside: If you like to drink beer on a camping trip, will that attract bears? — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Sweet and Easy Vegetable Pickles
text: I share a lot of dinners with my closest friends, Maggie and Steve, and over the past year I’ve sampled some wonderful sweet pickled vegetables at their house — radishes and turnips, cauliflower and cucumbers — laid out with other nibbles that we enjoy with drinks before dinner. Every time I ask about the recipe and every time Steve tells me it’s from the Momofuku cookbook. Then I go home and forget about it.

headline: Borne Back Ceaselessly Into Gatsby’s Embrace
text: It is a book that brims with longing, with romance and with recklessness, a vivid cocktail that has been a favorite in high schools and movie studios for nearly a century. It is F. Scott Fitzgerald’s “The Great Gatsby,” and the newest Hollywood remake will be released at the end of the week.

headline: Further Thoughts on Employee Rehabilitation
text: In a recent post, the members of the She Owns It business group talked about the prospects of successfully rehabilitating an employee who isn’t working out. That discussion continues in this post.

headline: What It’s Like Covering Congress
text: The Times’s Richard L. Berke speaks with the Congressional correspondents Ashley Parker and Jeremy W. Peters about the ins and outs of reporting on the Hill.

headline: Fortunes Change in a New York Minute
text: It is occasionally startling just how fast things change. Yes, this seems to be a particular phenomenon in New York, where the minute is now officially down to about 20 seconds, faster if there is a cab involved. One minute you are a triumphant Knicks team celebrating dispatching the pesky Boston Celtics and the Empire State Building is aglow in your colors. The next minute some guy named Roy Hibbert is stealing your lunch money and people are talking up the Pacers as potential upset contenders, five minutes after realizing Indiana was in the playoffs.

headline: Helen Mirren Is Not Amused as Drummers Disrupt Performance
text: Marching drummers in London’s West End were surprised to learn that their parade had disrupted a nearby performance of “The Audience” at the Gielgud Theater on Saturday night, but the real shock came when the actress Helen Mirren appeared on the street, dressed in full costume as Queen Elizabeth II, and berated them for doing so.

headline: Keeping Watch Over the Kosher Kitchen
text: Back of House, an occasional column, celebrates the unsung characters who animate the restaurant universe.

headline: U.S. Open Cup: 1939 to 1957
text: This is the second of a series on the U.S. Open Cup.

headline: The Dull Task of Decoding 401(k) Fees Matters
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: Juventus Repeats as Serie A Champion
text: Juventus won its 29th Serie A title Sunday with a 1-0 win against Palermo. Arturo Vidal’s penalty was the decisive goal as Juventus successfully defended the league title with three games to spare.

headline: Aerosmith Cancels Show in Indonesia
text: Aerosmith has canceled a show in Indonesia because of security concerns after the police stopped an alleged plot to bomb the Myanmar Embassy, news agencies have reported.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Have an N.F.L. Question? Judy Battista Has Answers
text: 10:57 a.m. | Updated How good is No. 1 pick Eric Fisher? Was Geno Smith selected too early–or too late? Which teams had the best drafts (and which teams the worst)? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers this week. Put your question in the Comments section below, and answers will appear on The Fifth Down.Comments for this feature have been closed. Answers will appear Monday on The Fifth Down.

headline: Indictment of John L. Sampson
text: Read the full indictment of John L. Sampson on embezzlement charges.

headline: Statins Tied to Better Prostate Cancer Outcomes
text: A new study suggests that men with prostate cancer who take statins may have a lower risk of dying from the disease than those who do not.

headline: In a Spiritual Outpouring, a Return to the Holy Land
text: There is a woodcut map by Heinrich Bünting dating from 1581 that shows the world as a clover, with Europe, Asia and Africa as the leaves, and Jerusalem at the center, confirming its position as the emotional and spiritual nexus of the great monotheistic cultures. On Wednesday evening the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine hosted a concert by its Cathedral Choir and the outstanding instrumental ensemble Rose of the Compass, offering the musical equivalent of the clover map. The fascinating and well-researched program encompassed Coptic and Armenian chant, Sephardic songs, Sufi melodies and Thomas Tallis’s “Lamentations of Jeremiah” on the historic destruction of Jerusalem.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Businesses for Innovative Climate and Energy Policy, Boston, which is a project of the nonprofit organization Ceres, selected Captains of Industry, Boston, as its first agency of record. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Marathon Suspect’s Body Is Ready for Burial. The Question Remains: Where?
text: BOSTON — Even some of the worst criminals are claimed at their death by someone and given a proper burial.

headline: Area Attack!
text: This week we’ll be featuring a set of geometry challenges regularly featured at the Julia Robinson Mathematics Festival, a half-day math event held throughout the year at various locations. The festival is designed for sixth- through 12th-graders who are interested in math, games and puzzles; participants include students who enjoy exploring problems collaboratively as well as math contest competitors looking for a more relaxed setting. (The next festival will be held this Saturday at Stanford University. Check the bottom of this post for details.)

headline: Feeling For | Jennifer Meyer’s Bejeweled Bobby Pins
text: The Los Angeles jewelry designer Jennifer Meyer makes her first foray into hair accessories next month with an elegant trio of flapper-inspired, 18-karat gold bobby pins adorned with diamonds, rubies and turquoise. “I had just spent six months in Australia on ‘The Great Gatsby’ set immersed in the most beautiful Tiffany jewelry imaginable,” says the Malibu-reared mother of two, whose husband, Tobey Maguire, stars in the forthcoming Baz Luhrmann film that has already inspired a Jazz Age revival in fashion. “The arrow shape was often featured in that period, and I wanted to bring it back with a contemporary spin,” says the 2013 CFDA Fashion Award nominee, adding that she plans to roll out new styles in the coming months. “I’ve always loved hair jewelry but haven’t challenged myself until now.”

headline: What Pakistan’s Election Means to Its People
text: The New York Times is interested in hearing from Pakistanis as the general election campaign comes to an end this week, promising the first democratic transfer of power from one civilian government to another in the country’s history.

headline: And the Judges for the New York Times Summer Reading Contest Are …
text: We’re delighted to announce that this year our Summer Reading Contest will be judged not by Learning Network staff members, but, instead, by a powerhouse panel of fellow young-adult literacy organizations.

headline: New American Bill Threatens Indian Outsourcing Companies
text: MUMBAI — A new American immigration bill threatens the future of Indian outsourcing, Indian companies say, because it will limit the number of foreign workers they can bring to the United States.

headline: Two Actors Join Repertory Pairing of Pinter and Beckett on Broadway
text: Billy Crudup (“The Coast of Utopia”) and Shuler Hensley (“The Whale”) have been added to the cast for the two-play repertory of Harold Pinter’s “No Man’s Land” and Samuel Beckett’s “Waiting for Godot” coming to Broadway this fall, the producers said Monday. Mr. Crudup will play Foster in “No Man’s Land” and Lucky in “Waiting for Godot,” while Mr. Hensley will take on Briggs in “No Man’s Land” and Pozzo in “Godot.” They will join the previously announced cast members Ian McKellen and Patrick Stewart for a 14-week run at the Cort Theater that is scheduled to begin with previews on Oct. 26 and an opening night set for Nov. 24. Both works will be directed by Sean Mathias. The specific schedule and performance dates for each play have not been announced.

headline: Taking Stock of the Emerging Preakness Field
text: 3:21 p.m. | Update The Derby contenders Vyjack and Normandy Invasion are also being considered for the Preakness. Fear the Kitten is no longer in the mix.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Wind, Rain and Wrecks Fuel Wild Talladega Upset
text: The weather was foul at Talladega Superspeedway when David Ragan and David Gilliland, Front Row Motorsports teammates, hooked up in a draft that gave them the momentum to finish one-two in the Aaron’s 499 Nascar Sprint Cup race on Sunday.

headline: Chase for Escaped Prisoner Shuts Subway Lines for 2 Hours
text: Updated, 6:20 p.m. | It has been an eventful few days for Vincens Vuktilaj.

headline: Anti-Blasphemy Protests in Bangladesh Turn Violent
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Violence erupted across Bangladesh on Monday as Islamist fundamentalists demanding passage of an anti-blasphemy law clashed with security forces, leaving a trail of property damage and at least 22 people dead after a second day of unrest.

headline: YouTube Is Said to Plan a Subscription Option
text: Newspapers have digital subscriptions. Record labels have iTunes and Spotify. And YouTube is about to have special programming for paying customers.

headline: On Trial for His E-Mails, Interrogating Witnesses, and Himself
text: On the eighth floor of the Brooklyn Criminal Courthouse – a place where misdemeanors are adjudicated and court proceedings consist mostly of brief appearances in front of a judge – the bizarre trial of Christopher X. Brodeur is now entering its third week.

headline: Weaned: A Bittersweet Victory
text: Visions of riesling and NyQuil danced in my head. I missed them so much, especially the medicine, by the time I caught my third severe cold of the winter.

headline: Image of the Day: May 6
text: Watermelons being transported on camels in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: May 3-5, 2013
text: Children.

headline: Close Election Leaves the Fate of Malaysia’s Premier Uncertain
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Though it held on to power in the election on Sunday, the governing National Front coalition suffered an important loss: For the first time in 44 years, it failed to win more than 50 percent of the popular vote. Analysts said the results left Prime Minister Najib Razak’s position far from secure.

headline: Rising Domestic Airline Taxes
text: A table of some domestic airline ticket taxes that may increase.

headline: Decoded: Rush Limbaugh and Cumulus
text: The Times’s Brian Stelter discusses the broadcaster Cumulus Media ahead of its earnings report and whether it sees a future beyond conservative talk shows.

headline: Street Style: Rain Gear
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of April 29.

headline: Obama’s Latest Senate Outreach: Monday Golf Date
