text: 7:50 p.m. | Updated Washington was overcast and rain threatened on Monday. But President Obama figured it was a good day for golf nonetheless, inviting three senators to complete his foursome rather than the usual staff aides.

headline: Bulking Up on Bankers for Hong Kong I.P.O.’s
text: HONG KONG — After a lackluster 2012 and slow start this year, Hong Kong’s financiers are hoping to revive interest in initial public offerings. To test investor appetite, many companies are hiring armies of investment bankers in their efforts to market new shares.

headline: Low-Risk Skin Cancers Often Treated Too Aggressively in Elderly, Study Finds
text: The patient who made Dr. Eleni Linos wonder about the way we treat small, nonthreatening skin cancers in the elderly was 95 years old. “He was truly suffering,” recalled Dr. Linos, a dermatologist at the University of California, San Francisco.

headline: ‘Orphans’ to Close Early on Broadway
text: 3:44 p.m. | Updated The Broadway revival of Lyle Kessler’s “Orphans,” starring Alec Baldwin, Ben Foster and Tom Sturridge, will close on May 19 at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, the show’s producers announced on Monday.

headline: Government by Random Comment
text: Senator John McCain was at it again on Sunday, attacking President Obama for not taking military action in Syria, especially after Israel struck Syrian missile sites. “We need to have a game changing action,” Mr. McCain said on Fox News. “And that is no American boots on the ground, establish a safe zone, and to protect it and to supply weapons to the right people in Syria who are fighting for obviously, the things we believe in.”

headline: Young, Urban, Educated…and Choosing Not to Vote
text: BANGALORE– On an unusually warm Sunday, a large number of young, first-time Bangalore voters stood in line at voting booths around the city. Later they laughed as they showed off their ink-marked fingers, proof that they did their civic duty, for cellphone camera pictures.

headline: The Rangers Are Close, but Does it Matter?
text: John Tortorella addressed a philosophical quandary Monday morning before Game 3 of the Rangers-Capitals playoff series: should a coach judge his team on how it played, or on the result? He weighed that perplexity in light of two narrow losses that have left the Rangers desperately needing a win Monday night.

headline: Ads Proclaim, ‘Hail, Finlandia’
text: A common approach in advertising is called “product as hero,” which celebrates the sponsor’s soup, soap or soda as the be-all, end-all, cure-all and whatever-all-else. But in an era when skeptical consumers dismiss straightforward chest-thumping as hopelessly outdated, what’s a marketer to do?

headline: Video: Bill Cunningham On the Street, Hats Off
text: Louisville has its Kentucky Derby. England has its Royal Ascot. And New York has its Frederick Law Olmsted awards luncheon of the Women’s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy. The luncheon drew more than 1,200 elaborately hatted guests, and all of the garden flowers were in tiptop bloom. A favorite hat shape was the satellite dish, defying gravity on the side of the head — a look that in the late ’30s was called the profile brim. The most amusing headdress was one of veiling that covered the face and had an appliquéd eye and lips, evoking a Dadaist mood. The most interesting fashion silhouettes were the revival of Dior’s New Look of 1947 and the Chanel nipped waists, full skirts and flyaway boleros.

headline: Inspiration for Art in the Glowing Seas
text: In an 1853 letter, the glass sculptor Leopold Blaschka described the first time he was mesmerized by what is known today as bioluminescence. The letter was translated from Old German by Henri Reiling, a scholar at Utrecht University in the Netherlands:

headline: Glass Mirrors Life in the Seas
text: A rescued collection of intricate glass models first crafted in the late 1800s provide a time capsule to test the health of today’s oceans.

headline: A Glass Ocean
text: Diving into today’s oceans, one scientist looks for modern day mirrors to sea creatures frozen in glass in the late 1800s.

headline: In Pursuit of an Underwater Menagerie
text: MAUNA LANI REEF, Hawaii — After a long, cold swim in the dark, we spotted it on the night reef with our dive lights: Octopus ornatus, the ornate octopus, a foot-long creature in an amber shade of orange with bright white spots and dashes along all its arms.

headline: Thousands in Moscow Rally Against New Trials
text: MOSCOW — Thousands of people turned out Monday for a protest here that was intended to draw attention to what organizers said was the return of political prosecutions in the Russian courts.

headline: Where the Jobs for the Young Are and Aren’t
text: In three regions – the upper Midwest, New England and the area around Washington – the job market for younger adults is considerably stronger than in the rest of the country. These three regions are the closest thing to an exception to the trend I described in a Sunday column: the sharp decline in employment rates for adults 25 to 34 years old. Whereas the United States had perhaps the highest employment rate for this age group among large, wealthy economies in 2012, it has one of the lowest today.

headline: China’s Changing Internet Landscape
text: China was on vacation much of last week for the May 1 Worker’s Day holiday, but executives at two of China’s most important online companies were busy completing a deal that could reshape the country’s Internet.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Solicits Public Comment on Vehicle Safety Evaluations
text: In an effort to improve its New Car Assessment Program, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is seeking comments from the public on several areas of vehicle safety, including new rules to protect pedestrians and children.

headline: Walkabout – 5/6: Sungnyemun Gate Reopens in Seoul; Stockholm Welcomes Back ABBA
text: Restoration Celebration The 600-year-old Sungnyemun Gate in Seoul, which was destroyed in an arson attack in 2008, reopened this weekend with great fanfare, including a visit from President Park Geun-hye of South Korea. (Gadling)

headline: On Wall Street, Recovering Money From Rogue Employees
text: It seems it should be a fairly intuitive policy: employees who violate the law should not be entitled to keep big bonuses earned based on illegal behavior.

headline: Questions and Answers on Syria and the U.S.
text: Syria’s bloody civil war took a dramatic turn over the weekend, with the government blaming Israel for strikes on military targets near the capital, Damascus. And questions about the use of chemical weapons became even murkier after a United Nations official suggested that the Syrian rebels, not the government, had used sarin gas. Here are some questions and answers on the debate over how the United States should respond.

headline: A Warm, Messy Take on Meatless
text: When Mary McCartney and her three siblings were young and vacationing on a family farm in Scotland, their father endeavored to teach them about all the beautiful food that sprang from the earth.

headline: Tax Proposals Open a Debate on Airline Industry’s Troubles
text: A $300 domestic airline ticket now includes about $60 in taxes — or 20 percent of the total fare — which pays for things like air traffic controllers, airport improvements, customs and immigration inspections and checkpoint screening.

headline: The Monday In-Box: What Readers Are Telling the Public Editor
text: Here’s a look at what readers of The Times had to say over the weekend, based on what came across my desk.

headline: About Half of Adults Lacked Adequate Health Coverage in 2012
text: About half of United States adults ages 19 to 64 didn’t have health insurance for at least part of last year or were underinsured, a new report from the Commonwealth Fund says.

headline: Raising Awareness About Maternal Deaths
text: Last year at this time, Christy Turlington Burns, the fashion model turned maternal-health advocate, asked mothers across America to celebrate No Mothers Day by not answering their phones or e-mail all day, even when their children called.

headline: A House Built Close to the Train, but Only Temporarily
text: Among the items that have passed through or made a temporary home in Grand Central Terminal in the last 100 years: Three elephants on the way to a circus in Boston; an art school; a tennis court; a Redstone rocket; a Philippe Petit tightrope walk; a model train show. And now, a two-story house.

headline: A Forgotten Pioneer of Vaccines
text: We live in an epidemiological bubble and are for the most part blissfully unaware of it. Diseases that were routine hazards of childhood for many Americans living today now seem like ancient history. And while every mother could once identify measles in a heartbeat, now even the best hospitals have to call in their eldest staff members to ask: “Is this what we think it is?”

headline: Really? Most of the Added Sugar in Our Diets Comes From Sugary Drinks
text: THE FACTS

headline: Harper Lee Sues Agent Over Copyright on ‘Mockingbird’
text: Harper Lee, who skillfully chronicled courtroom drama in “To Kill a Mockingbird,” is tangled in a legal drama of her own. Ms. Lee, 87, filed a lawsuit last week accusing her literary agent, Samuel Pinkus, of improperly collecting royalties from “Mockingbird” since 2007. According to the complaint, filed in federal court in New York, Mr. Pinkus “engaged in a scheme to dupe Harper Lee, then 80 years old with declining hearing and eyesight,” into assigning the book’s copyright to his company. Ms. Lee does not recall signing the document or discussing it with Mr. Pinkus, the complaint said.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Wandering Cheese Truck

headline: Illustrator Nigel Peake Brings His Mysterious World to Colette
text: Nigel Peake’s rural Irish roots were the muse for his 2011 book of drawings, “In the Wilds.” This year, the artist moved to Lausanne, the Swiss city on the shores of Lake Geneva, to teach architecture. The new setting influenced a series of 26 pen drawings that will be on view for a month starting today at the Paris boutique Colette. Peake’s “story of drawings,” as he calls it, tells the tale of a young boy who is afraid of the dark and takes solace in building boats. As with his other work, there is no visible human presence—the boy is only implied through images that hint at a larger narrative. For those who can’t make it to Paris to see the originals, Peake has self-published a limited-edition compilation of the images, called “In the Dark.”

headline: Workers Claim Race Bias as Farms Rely on Immigrants
text: VIDALIA, Ga. — For years, labor unions and immigrant rights activists have accused large-scale farmers, like those harvesting sweet Vidalia onions here this month, of exploiting Mexican guest workers. Working for hours on end under a punishing sun, the pickers are said to be crowded into squalid camps, driven without a break and even cheated of wages.

headline: BMC Deal Shows How an Activist Strategy Can Work
text: Elliott Management has once again pushed a technology firm into selling itself.

headline: Photo Replay: May 6
text: A look at the day in sports, including boxing in Tokyo and snooker in England.

headline: Fast Food
text: Q. Other than increasing the risk of choking, is eating fast bad for you?

headline: After Years of Battling, Bank of America and MBIA Settle Mortgage Dispute
text: 8:29 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Remote-Controlled Robot the Size of a Fly
text: Researchers have developed a remote-controlled robot about the size of a fat housefly that mimics a fly’s aerial prowess.

headline: Want Your Name on a Building? Prepare to Be Generous
text: Don’t look back, Donald Trump; when it comes to having one’s name emblazoned all over New York City, Ronald Perelman might be gaining on you.

headline: Print Your Own Gun
text: In the 1993 movie “In the Line of Fire,” the deranged would-be assassin played by John Malkovich builds a plastic gun that he smuggles past the metal detectors and into a presidential campaign event to kill the President. Clint Eastwood, thankfully, is on the spot to foil that dastardly plot.

headline: David Ferrucci: Life After Watson
text: To the degree there was a human face of Watson, the “Jeopardy!” computer champion, it was David Ferrucci. He was the I.B.M. researcher who led the development of Watson, an artificial intelligence engine. The goateed computer scientist was always articulate and at ease in front of a camera or a microphone.

headline: Boneworms’ Secret Revealed
text: Boneworms are gutless and mouthless, but somehow they live off the carcasses of whalebones. Now researchers say that the worms produce and secrete an acid that can dissolve bone.

headline: Frank Bascombe Back in Short Form, for Now
text: When Richard Ford read from a story featuring his beloved character Frank Bascombe at 92nd Street Y last week, one had to ask if this meant Bascombe would soon return in a fourth novel. Mr. Ford had told interviewers he was done writing about Bascombe when he concluded his trilogy of novels, “The Sportswriter” (1986), the Pulitzer Prize-winning “Independence Day” (1995) and “The Lay of the Land” (2006).

headline: Christian de Duve, 95, Dies; Nobel-Winning Biochemist
text: Dr. Christian de Duve, a Belgian biochemist whose discoveries about the internal workings of cells shed light on genetic disorders like Tay-Sachs disease and helped give birth to the field of modern cell biology, earning him a Nobel Prize, died on Saturday at his home in Nethen, Belgium. He was 95.

headline: Abdication, Dutch-Style
text: For someone who makes a special trip to the Netherlands, nominally timed to the investiture of a new monarch; for someone who has always been a fan of regalia; for someone who enjoys a costumed parade of nations as much as the next person — you’d think I’d at least get to the Dam on time.

headline: World Science Festival; Cicada Songs; Coffee, Deconstructed
text: Starting this week, The Scan will appear monthly, previewing events and books for the entire month. Updates can be found at nytimes.com/science.

headline: A Drone’s-Eye View of Nature
text: Monte Vista National Wildlife Refuge, Colo. — An electric whir filled the air of this high desert valley as Jeff Sloan, a cartographer for the United States Geological Survey, hurled a small remote-controlled airplane into the sky. The plane, a four-and-a-half-pound AeroVironment Raven, dipped; then its plastic propeller whined and pulled it into the sky.

headline: Amid the Tenements of New York, 2 Immigrants From Very Strange Lands
text: The title characters of Helene Wecker’s inventive novel, “The Golem and the Jinni,” are only slightly more bewildered than the thousands of other immigrants who end up in the teeming tenements of New York in 1899. Despite a handful of unusual powers, these two mythic creatures are still strangers in a strange land, caught between the folk traditions from which they spring and the modern world.

headline: Studying Birds, With a Drone’s Help
text: Drone technology, developed for warfare, is now being used to study the natural world. In Colorado, sandhill cranes are counted with a small drone called the Raven.

headline: Samsung Could Soon Surpass Apple in Handset Profit
text: Apple and Samsung Electronics are sucking up every penny of profit in the handset business. But Samsung’s mobile business is growing fast, and the question is: Could it surpass Apple in profit next quarter?

headline: Zero to Hacking in Five Months
text: This is pretty great.

headline: Knowingly Navigating the Unknown
text: LOS ANGELES — On a recent morning the novelist Rachel Kushner stood in the parking garage of the Petersen Automotive Museum, where the Green Monster, a lean, turbo-jet-powered vehicle used to set land speed records, was displayed in a roped-off corner. In her new, rapturously reviewed novel, “The Flamethrowers,” set in the 1970s, the narrator finds herself driving just such a vehicle on the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah, where those records are set.

headline: A Quartet, Changing, Looks Ahead and Back
text: The Kronos Quartet took to the stage of a sold-out Zankel Hall on Friday evening with what would be its last Carnegie Hall performance with Jeffrey Zeigler, its cellist of eight years who will leave this month. As the ensemble celebrates 40 years of blazing trails in the string-quartet repertory, it was appropriate that the program was largely about looking back. Just as appropriately, it was entirely made up of new music.

headline: When Madison Avenue Went Public, as Seen on ‘Mad Men’
text: 8:22 p.m. | Updated

headline: Slowdown in Health Costs’ Rise May Last as Economy Revives
text: WASHINGTON — One of the economic mysteries of the last few years has been the bigger-than-expected slowdown in health spending, a trend that promises to bolster wages and help close the wide federal deficit over the long term — but only if it persists.

headline: Triple Play: Week 5 Results
text: Chris Sale, the answer to Question No. 1, struck out seven Texas Rangers in the Chicago White Sox’ 5-2 victory Wednesday on his way to improving to 3-2. When Steve Carlton helped the Philadelphia Phillies beat the San Francisco Giants, 6-4, on May 4, 1981, he struck out eight.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iran and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Iran, Bangladesh, Turkey and Pakistan.

headline: Now Arriving From Taiwan, Kinetic Salutations
text: The Asian Cultural Council turns 50 this year, and at New York Live Arts on Sunday four Taiwanese choreographers presented works to show their gratitude for the organization’s support. The program, “Dance Taipei,” was an evening of obscurity and obviousness, brilliance and frustration.

headline: The Philosophical Rumble of That Living Document
text: Peter Sagal begins “Constitution USA,” his four-part exploration of the founding American document, with look-at-me gimmicks that are more annoying than enlightening, but the series, which begins on Tuesday night on PBS, grows more substantive as it goes along.

headline: Art Meets Science Deep Underwater, Drones Learn to Count Birds, Pregnancy and Dentistry
text: One scientist uses a glass time capsule to check the health of today’s oceans; the government undertakes a new kind of unmanned aerial surveillance; dispelling some of the misconceptions surrounding dental care during pregnancy.

headline: Needing to Solve Pacers’ Big Man in the Middle
text: Of all LeBron James’s marvelous talents, his capacity for adaptation may be the one most vital to his postseason success. In no series was this more evident than last year’s second-round bout with the Indiana Pacers, when he suddenly revealed a new weapon in his arsenal of offensive moves. After hardly ever having attempted the shot in his career, James began deftly dropping in 12-foot running floaters over the outstretched arms of Roy Hibbert, the Pacers’ 7-foot-2 center.

headline: ACT to Move Toward Computer-Based Testing
text: High school students will take the ACT college admissions exam by computer starting in the spring of 2015 — but at least for a while, the paper and pencil version will be available, too.

headline: Oral Health and Pregnancy
text: The Times's Catherine Saint Louis reports on the misconceptions many pregnant women have about going to the dentist.

headline: Medicaid and Mortality
text: As a rejoinder to my Sunday column, which cited the new Oregon Medicaid data to cast doubt on the oft-heard promise that health care reform will save tens of thousands of lives annually, Brian Beutler of Talking Points Memo offers an interesting thought experiment. He notes that the study (or at least this year’s version) looked at health indicators but not mortality rates, and then goes on:

headline: Israel and Turkey in Talks Over Deadly Flotilla Raid
text: JERUSALEM — Talks here on Monday between Israeli and Turkish officials over compensation for a deadly Israeli commando raid on a Gaza-bound flotilla almost three years ago demonstrated that while relations between the two countries are improving, they will not be as warm as they once were.

headline: RuPaul Revealed
text: The world’s most famous drag queen tells The Times’s Marcus Mabry that despite progress on gay rights, the pendulum could swing the other way.

headline: A Magazine or a Living Fossil?
text: A new kid has arrived on the science journalism block, a monthly magazine named Nautilus: Science Connected. Its first issue, which appeared online on April 29, focuses on a single theme: what does or does not make the human race special.

headline: Medical Devices Fall Short for Children
text: Only 15 months old, Vivian Andorf underwent her sixth cardiac catheterization. Her cardiologist inserted a flexible tube through a tiny artery in her leg and wended it to her heart in an attempt to treat her narrowed veins and arteries, the result of a congenital condition.

headline: Promises From the Powder Room
text: Light-reflecting. Acne-fighting. Energizing. Face powder, long associated with grandmothers and a dusty, chalky look, has been remade. Some companies say the product is not only a cosmetic, but also a face treatment, and are loading it with SPF, antioxidants and vitamins.

headline: In Performance: Alan Cumming
text: Alan Cumming plays Lady Macbeth in a scene from a reimagining of Shakespeare’s tragedy “Macbeth,” now on Broadway at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

headline: Another Side of RuPaul
text: LOS ANGELES — “Have you ever worn a wig or done drag?” RuPaul Charles, the host of “RuPaul’s Drag Race,” asked me recently as he shopped for wigs on Hollywood Boulevard.

headline: Kindness Amid the Slaughter
text: On the afternoon of May 2, 1863, Cpl. Rice Bull looked out over the position that his newly formed regiment, the 123rd New York Infantry, was assigned to defend, just south of the Chancellorsville crossroads. He and his fellow upstaters had not yet “seen the elephant” – the soldiers’ expression for experiencing combat – and he was reassured to see that they were supported by more veteran units, including the Second Massachusetts and the 27th Indiana. He noted the striking contrast between those units’ faded, bullet-ridden battle flags and the crisp, spotless condition of his regiment’s colors.

headline: Long a Staple of Fox, ‘Cops’ Lands in the Eager Arms of Spike TV
text: “Cops,” one of the original reality shows on television, is moving to cable after 24 years on network television.

headline: Omega-3s Don’t Provide Extra Eye Protection
text: Adding omega-3 fatty acid supplements to a vitamin regimen to protect against age-related macular degeneration, the leading cause of blindness in the United States, did not slow progression of the disease, a large new study has found.

headline: F.D.A. Proposes New Tanning Bed Warnings
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Monday proposed new regulations for tanning beds that would require their makers to affix labels warning young people not to use them.

headline: No Joke: Syrians Hack The Onion
text: On Monday, The Onion, a news parody site, became the latest publication to have its Twitter account hacked by the Syrian Electronic Army.

headline: Jeweler Is Charged in KPMG Insider Case
text: A Los Angeles-area jeweler has been formally charged with making illegal stock trades based on secret information obtained from a former senior partner at the accounting giant KPMG.

headline: Hope Seen for Afghanistan After Coalition Exits
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Under Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., the new commander of international forces here, the American-led military coalition is no longer aiming to change Afghanistan. Its focus now is on a far more narrow goal: readying Afghan forces to withstand the Taliban regardless of the country’s looming political and economic troubles.

headline: Sorting Through the New Political Alignments in Small Business
text: In a post for our colleagues at Economix on the divide between small and big — and local and global — businesses, Nancy Folbre, an economics professor, raises a number of issues important to You’re The Boss readers.

headline: Obstacles for Pregnant Women Seeking Dental Care
text: In pain because of infected teeth, Luatany Caseres, 34, then a factory worker in Durham, N.C., was desperate to see a dentist.

headline: Objects | Star Light, Star Bright
text: A colorful gem added to a simple white shirt and slicked-back hair creates a look as classically decadent as a long summer night.

headline: Intel’s Impressive Design Meets a Tricky Market
text: Intel formally introduced on Monday a new semiconductor architecture for its Atom chip, with all sorts of advanced features and technology that the company says will give it an edge in the operation of computer servers, lightweight personal computers, tablets, phones, cars and perhaps a whole lot of other things.

headline: Iran Warns Syrian Rebels After Report of Shrine Desecration
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s Shiite leaders warned of regional sectarian conflict after reports that Syrian rebels raided a Shiite shrine in a suburb of Damascus last week, destroying the site and making off with the remains of the revered Shiite figure buried there.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,196 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: A Stunning Error in Mississippi
text: Mississippi is scheduled to execute Willie Manning on Tuesday for his 1994 conviction for two murders. Mr. Manning is seeking DNA testing of hair, fingernail scrapings and other evidence connected to the crimes. His lawyers argue that no physical evidence links him to the crimes and that DNA testing could prove him innocent and identify another killer.

headline: Bike Share 101
text: As New York City’s long-awaited bicycle-share program approaches its start date, riders are signing up for lessons about how it works, and how to ride safely.

headline: Lil Wayne Puts Mountain Dew in Crisis Mode
text: How much street cred is too much?

headline: No Exit
text: “If You Give a Mouse a Cookie,” the popular children’s story about a demanding rodent, has given rise to more than a dozen sequels and now one architectural parody. Described as a “house-warning gift” by its author, Seth Kaufman, “If You Give an Architect a Contract” (Sukuma Books) adapts the style of Laura Joffe Numeroff’s 1985 illustrated classic in presenting a series of anxiety-provoking hypothetical statements about home renovation.

headline: New Albums by Rod Stewart and the Uncluded
text: ROD STEWART

headline: Celebrating the Web; an Atomic Movie; a Hurricane Over Saturn
text: So many piquant tidbits this week: We were able to see a revival of the world’s first Web site (which had no funny cat photos), watch the first movie starring tiny atoms, and view the first images of a surprisingly Earth-like hurricane swirling over Saturn.

headline: In Angola, a Dollar and a Meal
text: In the last slanted softening of late afternoon light, against the squealy repeated note of one small insect’s cheep, under the bird-haunted acacia tree towering over the bare trampled compound, and near Camillo’s derelict-looking car, dirt footprints on its doors — Camillo had been kicking it barefoot in fury for its refusal to start — an old woman approached through the sunlit risen dust.

headline: Early Images of American Indians Found in a Vatican Fresco
text: ROME – Vatican officials say they have found what could be the first European images of American Indians in a fresco painted within two years of Christopher Columbus’s first voyage to the so-called New World.

headline: The Doors Play Again in an Encore for the iPad
text: A new iPad app chronicling the rock legends the Doors has all the bells and whistles you would expect of electronic entertainment in 2013: immersive multimedia, cloud integration with iTunes, a ready connection to Facebook. The driving force behind it, however, is no 20-something Silicon Valley consultant. It is the 81-year-old Jac Holzman, who started Elektra Records as a teenager in 1950 and remains one of the music industry’s most passionate and punctilious tech nuts.

headline: The Nuns Who Revolted Against the Revolution
text: It is only natural for the Metropolitan Opera to refresh its offerings regularly with new productions, even when an old one has been successful. But it is hard to imagine the Met retiring John Dexter’s 1977 staging of Francis Poulenc’s masterpiece “Dialogues des Carmélites” (“Dialogues of the Carmelites”).

headline: Lauryn Hill Sentenced to 3 Months in Tax Case
text: Lauryn Hill, the Grammy-winning singer and songwriter, was sentenced to three months in prison on Monday afternoon for failing to pay income taxes on about $1.8 million in earnings.

headline: Spoiler Alert: ‘Mad Men’ Shifts Gears
text: Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce, the fictional advertising agency portrayed on the AMC series “Mad Men,” has given up Jaguar for a new automotive client: Chevrolet. The agency’s mandate, as seen in Sunday night’s episode, is to introduce a hot new model referred to as the XP-887.

headline: A Place to Hang Out (Read, Too)
text: It is definitely not your mother’s Donnell.

headline: Protesters Target Weiner on School Discipline Stance
text: Anthony D. Weiner has not yet entered the New York City mayor’s race, and may never become a candidate. But that did not stop some protesters from converging on his doorstep on Monday afternoon to challenge one of his educational policies should he decide to run.

headline: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
text: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan coalition in the Senate easily passed legislation on Monday to force Internet retailers to collect sales taxes for state and local governments, sending the issue to the House, where antitax forces have vowed to kill it.

headline: Questioning Farms’ Reliance on Migrant Labor
text: Workers who live near farms in Georgia that use immigrant labor say they want the field work but cannot get it because it is going to Mexicans.

headline: A Push for a Bitcoin Buttonwood
text: Amid the incense, cheap art and herbal remedies for sale in Union Square in Manhattan on Monday, a very different kind of product was changing hands: bitcoins.

headline: A Key Senator on Drones and Aiding Syria
text: Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island, speaks about increasing American action in Syria and revising the use of drones worldwide.

headline: Death Row Inmate’s Request for DNA Testing Is Rejected
text: The State of Mississippi rejected on Monday a DNA testing request made by a prisoner scheduled to be put to death Tuesday evening.

headline: Estimate of Immigration Overhaul’s Cost Gets Mixed Reviews on Right
text: A researcher whose fiscal calculations have provided crucial support in the past for conservative opponents of an immigration overhaul released a report on Monday, predicting that a proposal now in the Senate would vastly increase the government deficit in coming decades. But this year the estimates, by Robert Rector of the Heritage Foundation, have received decidedly mixed reviews from conservatives.

headline: Jail’s Broken Elevators Delay High-Profile Sentencing
text: There are all sorts of reasons, legitimate and otherwise, why a trial or court proceeding might be delayed. But seldom does a high-profile sentencing in Manhattan get waylaid by something so mundane: a broken elevator.

headline: A Taste of Spring That Reeks of Tradition
text: CAIRO — Every year, Egyptians mark the arrival of spring by flocking to the rare patches of green in this sprawling, crowded megalopolis to celebrate a holiday believed to be passed down from the pharaohs. Sham el-Nessim, the holiday’s Arabic name, means literally “smelling the breeze.”

headline: In Egypt, a Pungent Ritual Divides Noses
text: As Egyptians celebrate spring with Sham el-Nessim, the holiday’s central meal of aged fish brings pride to some and a case of olfactory overload to others.

headline: G.O.P. Opponents Plan Immigration Bill Attack
text: WASHINGTON — Republican opponents of legislation to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws are readying an offensive intended to hijack the newly released bill as the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday begins a review that will offer the clearest sign yet of how difficult a path the legislation faces.

headline: Social Media Images of Protesters in Moscow
text: As our colleague Andrew Kramer reports, about 26,000 protesters rallied in Moscow’s Bolotnaya Square on Monday, on the first anniversary of a protest in the same location that was marred by violence and followed by mass arrests and a police crackdown.

headline: Video of Police Hunt for Drug Trafficker Raises Concern in Brazil
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — A video taken from a Rio de Janeiro police helicopter depicting the frenzied hunt for a fugitive drug trafficker, involving heat-seeking technology and spraying the suspect’s car with gunfire from the air in a densely populated residential area, is raising new concerns in Brazil over the heavy use of force by the police against some adversaries.

headline: Israel Allows Gazan Children to Visit Imprisoned Parents
text: BEIT HANOUN, Gaza Strip — Raghed Hilless was 6 months old when Israel arrested her father, Ahmed, for being involved with Hamas, the militant Islamist group that rules the Gaza Strip. Now 5 ½, Raghed saw her father on Monday for the first time since then, one of the first young Gazans allowed to visit their parents in Israeli prisons since 2006.

headline: Suit Claims Energy Drink Maker Markets to Children
text: The city attorney of San Francisco sued Monster Beverage Corporation, the nation’s biggest maker of highly caffeinated energy drinks, claiming Monday that it was marketing its products to children who might suffer ill effects from them.

headline: Speedy Customs Program Works, at Least Usually
text: IS the popular Global Entry program working as advertised? That’s the program that gives members who have been prescreened quick re-entry into the United States at major international airports.

headline: Limousine in Deadly Fire Carried an Added Passenger
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The limousine that burst into flames Saturday night on the San Mateo Bridge, killing five female passengers on their way to a wedding shower, was carrying more people than was authorized, the authorities said, adding that they did not know if this had contributed to the deadly outcome.

headline: Trailing in Series, Islanders Like Their Odds Better at Even Strength
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The Islanders could be demoralized after a wrenching 5-4 overtime loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins on Sunday, but that did not appear to be the case as they prepared for Tuesday’s Game 4.

headline: From Jungle, Brazil Aims to Extend Its Reach
text: MARECHAL RONDON BASE, Brazil — Maj. José Maria Ferreira smiled as he listed the threats to human survival in the canopied jungle enveloping this remote military outpost in the Brazilian Amazon.

headline: Brazilian Military’s Crucible: Jungle Warfare Instruction
text: In courses lasting about nine weeks, soldiers endure long hikes, swim in waters infested with piranha and survive for days without rations, hunting or foraging for their own food.

headline: Foxconn Tries to Move Past the iPhone
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Terry Gou did almost everything that Apple could ask for. He made all those iPhones — and he made them cheap. When Apple was subsequently criticized for low wages and poor working conditions at his factories in China, it was Mr. Gou’s company, the Foxconn Technology Group, and not Apple, that caught the most heat.

headline: Sheik’s Vision Could Trump Plan for Park in Queens
text: There is a grand plan to be found for Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, a face-lift for this dowdy old dame.

headline: An Outspoken Punter Finds Himself Out of Work
text: No one had to interpret the situation for Chris Kluwe, the opinionated Minnesota Vikings punter. Kluwe, who gained national attention last fall for his support of same-sex marriage, figured his time in Minnesota was coming to an end when the Vikings chose Jeff Locke, a U.C.L.A. punter/kicker, in the fifth round of the N.F.L. draft.

headline: Assault-Prevention Officer in Air Force Is Arrested
text: The officer in charge of sexual assault prevention programs for the Air Force was arrested early Sunday and charged with sexual battery, the Arlington County, Va., Police Department said on Monday.

headline: Intelligence on North Korea, and Its New Leader, Remains Elusive
text: WASHINGTON — The black hole of North Korea intelligence gathering is getting blacker.

headline: U.S. Hopes Russian Aid in Inquiry on Boston Bombings Signals Future Collaboration
text: WASHINGTON — Despite years of differences on how to approach the terrorist threat, Obama administration officials said Monday that the American authorities investigating the Boston Marathon bombings were working effectively with their Russian counterparts and that they hoped the experience would usher in a new era of cooperation on counterterrorism.

headline: In Manhattan Real Estate, Wealth and Power Are Relative
text: AT 10 p.m. Friday, my wife, my dog and I will be forced to evacuate our home because the boom of a construction crane atop a luxury condominium tower going up next door might possibly destroy our building. It won’t be the first time: Last October, we had to evacuate for six days after Hurricane Sandy left the boom dangling precariously over West 57th Street, a situation that drew headlines worldwide. But this time, we’re being forced out merely because the city government wants to save the developer of the tower money and time.

headline: The Best Little Boy in the World — That’s Me
text: WASHINGTON

headline: New Rules Proposed for Tanning Beds
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Monday proposed new regulations for tanning beds that would require their makers to affix labels warning young people not to use them. Nearly 28 million Americans use tanning beds every year, according to the American Academy of Dermatology. The agency said the proposal was its first step toward potentially restricting access to the beds altogether for minors. Manufacturers would have to apply to the F.D.A. to get approval for their tanning bed products before selling them, “The science is clear,” said Dr. Mary Maloney, vice president of regulator policy at American Academy of Dermatology. “The risk of developing melanoma increases by 75 percent for individuals who’ve been exposed to ultraviolet radiation from indoor tanning.”

headline: California: Court Upholds Ban on Marijuana Dispensaries
text: The California Supreme Court on Monday upheld the right of local governments to ban medical marijuana dispensaries. As dispensaries have proliferated since 1996, when California became the first state to allow medical marijuana, many municipalities across the state have used zoning laws to prohibits dispensaries from opening inside city limits. Patients and dispensary owners have argued that these local laws violate the state medical marijuana statutes by reducing patients’ access to the drug. But the court unanimously upheld a ban in the City of Riverside, paving the way for more municipalities to prohibit marijuana dispensaries.

headline: Vigilante Copy Editor
text: A filmmaker searches for a mysterious vandal who has been correcting grammar on placards in the sculpture garden of the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn.

headline: ‘Vigilante Copy Editor’
text: In the sculpture park at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, one of the nation’s oldest art schools, a clandestine struggle is under way — over grammar. In recent months, a vandal (or team of vandals) has used permanent markers to correct grammar and punctuation mistakes on the informational placards near the sculptures.

headline: White House Holds Firm on Cautious Path in Syria Crisis
text: WASHINGTON — The White House insisted Monday that it would not be thrown off its cautious approach to Syria, despite Israeli military strikes near Damascus and new questions about the use of chemical weapons in the civil war there.

headline: Google Glass Picks Up Early Signal: Keep Out
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google’s wearable computer, the most anticipated piece of electronic wizardry since the iPad and iPhone, will not go on sale for many months.

headline: Religion Beyond the Right
text: As the Boy Scouts of America reassesses its ban on gay scouts and leaders, we’re hearing a lot about the organization’s need to remain sensitive to people whose religions condemn homosexual behavior. Their morals must be properly respected, their God aptly revered.

headline: Facing Black Market, Pfizer Is Looking Online to Sell Viagra
text: Pfizer has taken the unusual step of selling its erectile dysfunction drug, Viagra, to consumers on its Web site, in an effort to establish a presence in the huge online market for the popular blue pill, considered to be one of the most counterfeited drugs in the world.

headline: Psychiatry’s Guide Is Out of Touch With Science, Experts Say
text: Just weeks before the long-awaited publication of a new edition of the so-called bible of mental disorders, the federal government’s most prominent psychiatric expert has said the book suffers from a scientific “lack of validity.”

headline: A Succession of Items, Lost in Transit
text: MY family traveled a lot when I was growing up, and one of the more memorable trips was to Tanzania. We went on this amazing safari, and I don’t know if it was the jet lag or just some bad curry, but I convinced myself that I had caught malaria.

headline: As Midterms Loom, Democrats Worry About Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — As the administration struggles to put in place the final, complex piece of President Obama’s signature health care law, an endeavor on a scale not seen since Medicare’s creation nearly a half-century ago, Democrats are worried that major snags will be exploited by Republicans in next year’s midterm elections.

headline: A Carbon Trading System Worth Saving
text: The European Union became a pioneer in tackling climate change by starting the first major cap-and-trade system designed to reduce carbon-dioxide emissions by putting a price on them. But analysts are increasingly worried that technical mistakes, Europe’s prolonged recession and the failure of policy makers to strengthen the system is undermining its effectiveness.

headline: Taliban Bomb Kills at Least 20 at a Pakistan Political Rally
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Taliban bomb ripped through a crowded political rally in Pakistan’s tribal belt on Monday, killing at least 20 people and wounding 45 in the deadliest attack so far of the campaign for next Saturday’s national election.

headline: Mr. Watt, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
text: There are many reasons to be bullish on housing. Valuations, affordability and supply and demand are moving in the right direction. But there are also causes for concern. Home sales and home prices can rise only so far given today’s high level of unemployment and low level of wage gains. And millions of homeowners are still in financial distress. At the end of 2012, some 11.3 million homeowners — nearly one-fourth of all those with a mortgage — still owed more on their mortgages than their homes were worth, according to Moody’s Analytics. Of those, three million are currently in or near foreclosure.

headline: Corruption in Albany
text: For all the talk among Gov. Andrew Cuomo and other leaders about cleaning up New York’s rancid state government, it is the F.B.I. that is doing the cleaning — indictment by indictment. State Senator John Sampson is the latest Albany politician to face corruption charges. On Monday, he was taken into custody by federal agents on charges of embezzling about $440,000 from the sale of foreclosed properties, obstruction of justice and witness tampering.

headline: Several in New York Take Top Beard Awards
text: Danny Bowien, who owns Mission Chinese Food in New York and San Francisco, was named the Rising Star Chef for 2013 at the annual James Beard Foundation awards ceremony Monday night. It’s one of the most significant of the many awards and medals handed out by the foundation for achievement in the world of restaurants and their chefs.

headline: Professor Apologizes for Remarks on Keynes
text: The Harvard professor and economics commentator Niall Ferguson issued “an unqualified apology” over the weekend for suggesting that John Maynard Keynes was indifferent to the long-term implications of his economic theories because Keynes was gay and had no children.

headline: For Buffett, the Past  Isn’t Always Prologue
text: OMAHA – A little under an hour into the question-and-answer session at Berkshire Hathaway’s annual meeting here on Saturday, a name searing with history but now largely forgotten was mentioned: Henry E. Singleton.

headline: Changing Sex, and Changing Teams
text: LOS ANGELES — Not so long ago, Toni Bias dreamed of playing in the W.N.B.A. But after starring on the girls’ junior varsity basketball team as a high school freshman, Toni came out as transgender last summer, began going by the name Tony and started transitioning to male.

headline: Germany: Ex-Nazi With Link to Auschwitz Is Arrested
text: German authorities on Monday arrested a 93-year-old former Nazi soldier, saying that they had “compelling evidence” that he had worked as a guard at the Auschwitz concentration camp and was complicit in murders there. The man, Hans Lipschis, whose name is fourth on the Simon Wiesenthal Center’s list of “most wanted Nazi war criminals,” was taken into custody at his home in the southern German state of Baden-Württemberg, according to Claudia Krauth, a spokeswoman for the prosecutor’s office there. Mr. Lipschis, who emigrated to the United States after the war but was deported in 1983 after an investigation by the Office of Special Investigations brought his Nazi past to light, admitted to the German newspaper Die Welt last month that he had served with a Nazi SS unit at Auschwitz but only as a cook. Charges have not yet been filed, Ms. Krauth said, adding that prosecutors are still investigating Mr. Lipschis’s role at the camp. They believe he worked there from 1941 to 1945.

headline: More Medicaid, More Health?
text: Do the mixed results of an Oregon health care study show that government medical insurance should provide only catastrophic coverage?

headline: An Educational Hybrid
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Rise in Suicide Among Boomers
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Museums Decide to Return Looted Art
text: To the Editor:

headline: Preventing Megafires
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pharmacy Sales of Tobacco
text: To the Editor:

headline: Beyond the Fence
text: The opponents of immigration reform have many small complaints, but they really have one core concern. It’s about control. America doesn’t control its borders. Past reform efforts have not established control. Current proposals wouldn’t establish effective control.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 7, 2013
text: “We are all now going to be both the paparazzi and the paparazzi’s target.”

headline: A Candidate With a Store Chain Around His Neck
text: Katie Couric was discussing the New York City mayor’s race with Donald Trump in the Pool Room of the Four Seasons the other day when the topic of John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire Republican candidate, came up.

headline: Does Gomez Have a Real Chance in Massachusetts?
text: A common cognitive bias in political analysis is what Daniel Kahneman calls the availability heuristic: the tendency to focus on recent or familiar examples as opposed to the broader course of history and the richer volume of precedents.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Knicks’ Shooting Problems Start With Top Scorers
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The search for answers began anew on Monday, the first day in two months that the Knicks were forced to confront their imperfections, rather than accent their strengths.

headline: Surveillance Footage of Painter
text: The house painter Joselito Vega is shown stealing some art from a waterfront mansion in Long Island.

headline: House Painter Is Charged in Long Island Art Thefts
text: He painted houses for a living, but prosecutors say Joselito Vega had a discerning eye for the more rarefied practitioners of his craft — Pablo Picasso, Jean Dubuffet and Frank Stella.

headline: Father Is Charged With Assaulting His Son’s Training Partner
text: Volatile parents have long posed a problem for tennis. Jim Pierce, Damir Dokic and Arsalan Rezai are among those who have received extended bans for abusive behavior.

headline: Mayoral Hopefuls Express Support for Animal Rights
text: Bill de Blasio bragged that his two children were vegetarians.

headline: Corrections: May 7, 2013
text: THE ARTS

headline: A Weekend With the Boss and Co-Workers? Such Good Fun
text: Anyone who has done time in a corporate environment will recognize the soul-killing atmosphere conjured all too precisely in “Core Values,” a wan comedy by Steven Levenson that opened on Monday night at Ars Nova.

headline: Famous Russian House Guests, With Plenty of Baggage
text: What is it with Lincoln Center Theater and Russians who take their time? Six years ago, New Yorkers fought for the chance to spend nine precious hours watching the late-imperial-age intellectuals of Tom Stoppard’s “Coast of Utopia” talk about revolution. Now we have been invited to a leisurely confab with the transplanted post-revolutionary Russians of Richard Nelson’s “Nikolai and the Others,” which lasts only two and a half hours, but feels closer to nine.

headline: Story That Goes On and On
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Are you feeling a little bloated? That may seem like a personal question, but it would make perfect sense after doing Jeff Chen’s puzzle.

headline: Bicycling in the City and Living to Tell a Skittish Class
text: If a taxi’s window is down, listen for the sound of a receipt being printed. It means a door is about to open.

headline: Intersection: Dumbo’s Style Mash-Up
text: Martin Medina, a visual designer, draws fashion inspiration from his youth in the Lower East Side and bright colors.

headline: The Chancellor’s Lament
text: By most measures, Holden Thorp’s five-year tenure as the chancellor of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, which is coming to an end next month, was a roaring success. The university went from 19th to 9th in federal research grants. Undergraduate applications rose 43 percent. And, at a time when university budgets are under extreme pressure, Thorp helped keep U.N.C. an affordable public university.

headline: U.S. Blames China’s Military Directly for Cyberattacks
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Monday explicitly accused China’s military of mounting attacks on American government computer systems and defense contractors, saying one motive could be to map “military capabilities that could be exploited during a crisis.”

headline: Worst of the ‘What Were They Thinking?’ Contracts
text: The sense that New York teams operate with Monopoly money rather than actual cash was never more prevalent than when Alex Rodriguez tore up the largest contract in American sports history, only to be handed back one by the Yankees that was even larger.

headline: Heat May Have M.V.P., but Bulls Have Series Lead
text: MIAMI — When Nate Robinson chased after a loose ball in the second quarter of Monday’s second-round playoff game, he quickly discovered that he had company in the form of the 6-foot-8, 250-pound LeBron James. At 5-8, Robinson paid the price. He retreated to the locker room to receive 10 stitches on his upper lip, and the Bulls pressed on without him.

headline: Teacher Pay Hurt by Recession, Report Says
text: During the recession and its aftermath, public schools took a hit as both state coffers and local property taxes shriveled. That showed up in shrinking employment, but also in teacher salaries.

headline: Victims in Boston Marathon Bombings Turn to Crowdfunding for Support
text: It was Brittany Loring’s 29th birthday. She and a fellow graduate student at Boston College, Liza Cherney, were making their way to the finish line of the Boston Marathon to meet a runner when the two bombs exploded.

headline: The Scar Miller Left in 1995 Is Still Fresh
text: Reggie Miller still hears about the game whenever he comes to New York. Fans recognize him and want to talk about that Game 1 of the Knicks-Pacers playoff series in 1995, the one that became Page 1 of his New York legend. They all want to know how he scored 8 points in 18.7 seconds, flipping a 6-point Knicks lead into a preposterous Pacers victory.

headline: Two Men Are Charged With Murder in Shooting of Bronx Teenager
text: The authorities charged two men with murder on Monday in the shooting of a Bronx teenager whose death the Bloomberg administration singled out in its campaign against gun violence.

headline: Augustin Has Breakout Game Against Friend and Former Teammate
text: D. J. Augustin realized how far he and his friend Raymond Felton had come.

headline: A Night When Chic Met Tough
text: Shortly after 6:30 p.m. Monday, waiting for the first of 800 celebrities and supermodels to make their way up the long staircase of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the annual Costume Institute gala, Anna Wintour tapped a young man with a spiky blond mohawk on the shoulder. He wore a red blazer with the words “the government is lying” scrawled on the back.

headline: Toronto Enjoys Moment, Despite Home Playoff Loss
text: TORONTO — George W. Bush was in his first term as president. Twitter was two years from appearing. The last time the Maple Leafs hosted a Stanley Cup playoff game was May 4, 2004.

headline: Three Women, Missing for Years, Found in Cleveland
text: Three young women from Cleveland who disappeared about a decade ago, and who friends and relatives feared were gone forever, were found on Monday and appeared to be physically unharmed, the authorities said.

headline: A Late Goal, and Then a Late Stand
text: Everything could have gone wrong for the Rangers on Monday. But everything went right. Marc Staal returned from a serious eye injury and gave his teammates and the Madison Square Garden crowd a huge emotional boost. The power play awoke from its slumber. Derek Stepan and Rick Nash, the Rangers’ top scorers during the regular season but blanked in the playoffs, combined for the winning goal with time running down and a 3-0 series deficit looming.

headline: Delft Touch
text: The enduring, evolving and utterly beguiling influence of blue-and-white porcelain.

headline: Keynes’s Biggest Mistake
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Quinn Offers Plan to Add Slots for Gifted in City Schools
text: Seeking to address pervasive racial disparities at the top echelons of New York City schools, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, plans on Tuesday to propose a significant overhaul of gifted and talented programs that would provide space for more children and loosen admissions requirements.

headline: Word of the Day | barefaced
text: barefaced •\ˈber-ˈfast\• adjective

headline: M.L.S. Salary Figures Are Out, and One Star Shares Some of His
text: Major League Soccer’s players union released salary figures for the league’s players on Monday, an annual rite that opens a window into how much (and how little) value the league gets for its money.

headline: Rodriguez Returns to Field, but Nowhere Near the Yankees
text: TAMPA, Fla. — It felt like March at the Yankees’ training facility. Balmy weather. Postcard blue sky. An assortment of star players working out on various practice fields, and the parking lot outside lined with luxury vehicles.

headline: Some ‘Silent Protests’ in Malaysian Malls After Disputed Election
text: BEIJING — After the Malaysian opposition parties failed to win in Sunday’s election, some Malaysians staged “silent protests” in the country’s malls, dressed in black with their mouths taped shut, according to photographs posted online and #TheSilentWalk, a Twitter feed.

headline: Tortorella Said It Was Close, and He Was Right
text: John Tortorella was right after all: the Rangers-Capitals series is a lot closer than a lot of people thought.

headline: Even With Extra Attacker, Capitals Can’t Find Opening
text: The Rangers had a daunting task. Ahead by a goal in the closing two minutes but down two games to none against the Washington Capitals, they were skating shorthanded by two men.

headline: Met Gala Red Carpet
text: The biggest names in fashion turned out for the The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute benefit celebrating “PUNK: Chaos to Couture.”

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 10 P.M. (13) TED TALKS EDUCATION In this first television special from TED, the nonprofit devoted to “ideas worth spreading,” speakers address the nation’s high school dropout rate. Among them are Pearl Arredondo, a sixth-grade teacher in the Los Angeles Unified School District; Geoffrey Canada, president and chief executive of the Harlem Children’s Zone; Bill Gates, the philanthropist and Microsoft chairman; Malcolm London, a Chicago slam poet; Rita F. Pierson, an education and antipoverty advocate; and the social activist Ken Robinson, whose presentations on creativity in education have been viewed on TED.com more than 18 million times. The singer-songwriter John Legend hosts and performs.

headline: A Night of Karaoke, and Mom’s in the Lead
text: It was my husband’s first trip to my hometown of Snellville, Ga., and to ensure that we’d return, my mother was determined to show us a good time.

headline: A Whistle, a Punch, and a Soccer Referee Is Dead
text: A little more than a week after a 17-year-old soccer player punched a recreation-league referee in the head in suburban Salt Lake City, the referee is dead, the player faces charges, and youth sports are left with questions about the seeming rise in severity of assaults on officials.

headline: News Quiz | May 7, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Missing for Years, Three Women Are Found in Cleveland
text: “Help me, I’m Amanda Berry,” the woman said to a 911 operator. “I’ve been kidnapped and been missing for 10 years. I am here. I’m free now.”

headline: Anthony Gets Fashion Assist From Brooklyn Stylist
text: When Carmelo Anthony joined the Knicks in 2011, he joined the ranks of New York’s most debonair athletes, with a rotating collection of pocket squares, tailored suits, chunky glasses and skinny ties.

headline: China’s Baidu to Pay $370 Million for Internet Video Business
text: HONG KONG – Baidu, China’s biggest search engine company, announced on Tuesday that it would pay $370 million for the online video business of PPStream.

headline: After Bumpy Start, Microsoft Rethinks Windows 8
text: REDMOND, Wash. — Windows Blue, the code name for an update to the Microsoft’s flagship operating system, sums up the current melancholy in the PC business pretty well, though Microsoft didn’t intend it that way.

headline: Game 3: Rangers vs. Capitals
text: Derek Stepan and Arron Asham scored tie-breaking goals, Henrik Lundqvist had 28 saves and the Rangers survived a late power play by the Capitals to win Game 3.

headline: IHT Quick Read: May 7
text: NEWS The Obama administration on Monday explicitly accused China’s military of mounting attacks on American government computer systems and defense contractors, saying one motive could be to map “military capabilities that could be exploited during a crisis.” David E. Sanger reports from Washington.

headline: White House Holds Firm on Cautious Path in Syrian Crisis
text: WASHINGTON — The White House insisted on Monday that it would not be thrown off its cautious approach to Syria, despite Israeli military strikes near Damascus and new questions about the use of chemical weapons in the civil war there.

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 7, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “With an Old Factory, Philadelphia Is Hoping to Draw New Teachers.”

headline: Syria Accuses Israel of Powerful Air Assault
text: In “Syria Blames Israel for Fiery Attack in Damascus,” Anne Barnard writes about a new development in the ongoing Syrian civil war.

headline: A Conversation With: Bollywood Actor Ranbir Kapoor
text: LONDON — Ranbir Kapoor, 30, was in London recently to promote “Yeh Jawani Hai Deewani,” or, loosely translated, “Being Young, Being Crazy,” in which he co-stars with his former girlfriend Deepika Padukone. Directed by Ayan Mukherjee, the movie follows the lives of four young college graduates and the evolution of their relationships over nearly a decade. Bunny (Ranbir Kapoor) and Naina (Deepika Padukone) meet at two separate points in their lives in the film, first when they are just out of college and then as 30-year-olds, holding on to certain unfulfilled dreams. (Spoiler alert: Somewhere along the line, they also fall in love.)

headline: Societe Generale Announces New Cuts as Profit Falls 50%
text: Paris – The French bank Société Générale announced on Tuesday that it was planning a new-cost cutting drive that would result in hundreds of job losses in France, as its first-quarter net income fell sharply.

headline: Atop a Mountain, South Africa’s Ghosts
text: High up in the Amatola Mountains in South Africa’s Eastern Cape province, the village of Hogsback sits atop a plateau, surrounded by mist and a primeval forest. It’s a small place, with one main road, a handful of shops and a large, aching history.

headline: The Food-Truck Business Stinks
text: Stefan Nafziger seemed oddly downbeat for a guy watching a dozen or so hungry people line up to buy his falafels. Three years ago, when it seemed as if food trucks might take over Manhattan, he planned to have a fleet of his Taim trucks dispensing Middle Eastern fare throughout the city. He even got a Wall Street investor. Now, he says, his one truck barely justifies the cost.

headline: How Do You React When Provoked?
text: When someone provokes you — with verbal taunts, a rude comment, a shoulder “bump” or even a push — how do you react? Are you likely to respond in kind, escalating the conflict? Or do you try to let it pass or defuse the situation?

headline: Missed a Play on Broadway? Catch It in London
text: LONDON — Don’t look now, but the London theater is suddenly looking very American. A swift glance through the current and imminent lineup of openings indicates a neat baker’s dozen of American titles alighting in the British capital for the late-spring/summer season.

headline: Another British TV Personality Is Identified in Child Sex Investigation
text: LONDON — Another well-known television personality was drawn into Britain’s growing child sexual abuse scandal on Tuesday when British news media identified a 73-year-old man arrested over allegations dating from the late 1970s as the entertainer Jimmy Tarbuck.

headline: HSBC Profit Surges as Restructuring Plan Gains Traction
text: 8:42 a.m. | Updated

headline: May College Checklist for Juniors
text: This week, The Choice is publishing our monthly Counselor’s Calendar, which is intended to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

headline: Ireland Pardons Wartime Deserter ‘Heroes’
text: LONDON — The Irish government is to reverse what has been described as a historic injustice by granting a pardon to soldiers who deserted their units to fight the Nazis in World War II.

headline: Q.& A.: Setting the iPad’s Side Switch
text: Q.

headline: Where the Happy Talk About Corporate Culture Is Wrong
text: “Tell me something I don’t know,” is what I think every time I see another article, blog post or book on the value of happy employees. And here is what I find disturbing about these happy-employee propagandists. They are mostly off about what it takes to motivate employees and keep them happy in a fast-growth culture.

headline: Keynes’s Not So Big Mistake
text: Bruce Bartlett, unusually, gets one wrong, although not in too bad a way. In his post Keynes’s Biggest Mistake, he misconstrues what Keynes meant by calling his book the “General Theory” of employment etc., and seems to imply something untrue about Keynes’s views on the liquidity trap.

headline: The Stimulus Debate, Revisited
text: Brad DeLong finds Clive Crook making some easily refuted claims about the nature of the stimulus debate in the winter of 2008-2009, and my role in particular.

headline: Standoff on Bolotnaya Square
text: MOSCOW — Under a menacing gray sky, people walked across the Great Stone Bridge, which spans the Moscow River at one end of the Kremlin. Dressed mostly in dark clothing, they walked purposefully, with somber faces, almost as in a funeral procession.

headline: Three Noteworthy Apps for Children
text: Here are three noteworthy apps for children.

headline: Lately, It’s All Orb All the Time
text: Too much Orb? Not enough Orb? Just the right amount of Orb? When you run a racing Web site with only three writers, you ask about the formula – all the time.

headline: Pondering a Berkshire Without Buffett
text: At the Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting, Warren E. Buffett rejected the notion that the company would go the way of Teledyne, a conglomerate that was broken up after its leader, Henry E. Singleton, stepped down as chief executive. Mr. Singleton, who might be called the Buffett of his time, decided Teledyne had become too big and unwieldy for a single manager to effectively oversee and expand, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. A breakup of Berkshire, “I’m convinced would create a poorer result,” Mr. Buffett said.

headline: Verizon to Move 1,100 Workers From Lower Manhattan to Brooklyn
text: Verizon announced on Tuesday that it would move 1,100 employees out of its headquarters and switching center at 140 West Street in Lower Manhattan and offer half of the 31-story tower for sale or lease.

headline: In Performance: Alan Cumming of ‘Macbeth’
text: Alan Cumming is on Broadway playing the title role — and every other major one — in “Macbeth,” a reimagined version of Shakespeare’s tragedy set in a mental institution. In this scene Mr. Cumming plays the ruthless Lady Macbeth asking the spirits to “unsex me here.” Directed by John Tiffany and Andrew Goldberg, “Macbeth” continues through June 30 at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

headline: China Cuts Ties With Key North Korean Bank
text: HONG KONG — The state-controlled Bank of China said on Tuesday that it had ended all dealings with a key North Korean bank in what appeared to be the strongest public Chinese response yet to North Korea’s willingness to brush aside warnings from Beijing and push ahead with its nuclear and ballistic missile programs.

headline: Tuesday Reading: A New Way to Care for Young Brains
text: Also, two big banks face suits on mortgage pact abuses, Pfizer begins selling Viagra online and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Training a Subway Musician
text: Dear Diary:

headline: In Tamil Nadu, Politics Meets Idlis
text: NEW DELHI—Politicians in India are employing an archaic strategy – trying to win the hearts of voters through their stomachs.

headline: Markets vs. the Economy
text: When the markets and the economy are out of sync.

headline: Weight Led Governor to Surgery
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey ascended to become one of the country’s top political stars almost in spite of his weight — dismissing those who questioned whether his size disqualified him for higher office as “ridiculous” and “irresponsible.”

headline: GE Capital Puts on a Lending Roadshow
text: GE CAPITAL this week is embarking on an elaborate advertising campaign with Slate.com featuring a six-month roadshow across the United States meant to stimulate its lending to midsize businesses.

headline: Mayoral Candidate Says Clintons Have Used His Private Jet
text: The Gulfstream IV, an airborne lap of plush-leather luxury, hopscotched around the country over the past few days, breezing into Chicago; Orlando, Fla.; and Little Rock, Ark.

headline: Torture Against Terrorism
text: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania — Outside our tent on a beach about 100 miles north of the capital, the Atlantic Ocean was glittering under the midday sun and a fresh tuna was searing on a grill. Inside, the conversation with my Mauritanian friends turned to torture and detention. One described how he’d been chained up naked for weeks; another talked about his brother who had a pin inserted under his fingernails. Both victims had been arrested during a crackdown on political dissidents in 2003, in the twilight of the 21-year dictatorship of Maaouya Sid’Ahmed Ould Taya.

headline: Before Escape, Fleeting Clues to Long Ordeal
text: CLEVELAND — One neighbor remembered occasional late-night deliveries of groceries to the boarded-up shoe box of a house in a rough-edged West Side neighborhood here.

headline: The N.B.A.’s Improbable Night
text: For a night at least, the N.B.A. was to be ruled by the stubborn. Forget youth, spunk, talent, a four-time league most valuable player in his prime, logic and common sense. No, instead you had the San Antonio Spurs, who have personified stubbornness since cellphones were as big as bread boxes, and the Chicago Bulls, a collection of spare parts being held together by duct tape and baling wire, and whose official team fragrance is an antiseptic.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Narratively: A day in the life of a third-generation New York City hot dog vendor. “You really have to be in tune with the cart,” she says. — Julia Moskin

headline: Fill-In | Prom is Easy. The ‘Ask’ Takes Planning.
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first six paragraphs of the article “Prom is Easy. The ‘Ask’ Takes Planning.” by Nancy M. Better.

headline: Ted Cruz: The ‘Schoolyard Bully’
text: Unable to hide his anger behind the usual facade of Senate brotherhood, Majority Leader Harry Reid stretched protocol last night and called Senator Ted Cruz of Texas “a schoolyard bully.” Actually he diluted it just slightly by saying, “My friend from Texas is like a schoolyard bully.” But there was no friendship involved, and it’s not hard to see why.

headline: From 2010: Christie on Health and Weight
text: In a 2010 interview, The Times’s Michael D. Shear asked Governor Chris Christie about his struggles with his weight.

headline: Looking Past Sex Scandal, South Carolina Returns Ex-Governor to Congress
text: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C. — As political rehabilitations go, few can match what happened to Mark Sanford on Tuesday night.

headline: Otis R. Bowen, Governor and Health Secretary, Dies at 95
text: Otis R. Bowen, who served two terms as governor of Indiana and later became the first physician appointed as secretary of health and human services, serving under President Ronald Reagan amid the rising debate about AIDS, died on Saturday in Donaldson, Ind. He was 95.

headline: A Film to Help Students Face Their Debt
text: It’s that dreadful, suffocating feeling you get when you know you have something difficult to face, but you don’t want to admit it.

headline: Foreign Food Inspections on Decline as Illnesses From Imported Goods Rise
text: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. — Inside a warehouse near the Canadian border, boneless hams bound for Philadelphia are coming off a tractor-trailer from Toronto under the gaze of a federal food inspector. Each week, about 20 of the 150 food trucks from Canada are rejected because of paperwork problems or contaminated meat.

headline: Jeeves Lives, as New Author Picks Up Where Wodehouse Left Off
text: Nearly 40 years after the last book by the comic novelist P.G. Wodehouse, the aristocratic Bertie Wooster and his faithful valet, Jeeves, are making a comeback.

headline: After Auction, the 1967 2000 GT Is Now the Most Expensive Toyota in History
text: It received little more than passing mention in the Lavishly Expensive Roadster Edition of Wheelies, but something significant happened a couple of weekends ago. It wasn’t earth shattering, but it was noteworthy: RM Auctions sold a 1967 Toyota 2000 GT for nearly $1.2 million. It ended up being one of the higher priced cars in a batch that included Ferraris, Porsches and one-off concept cars like a 1954 Chrysler GS-1 Special that sold for $616,000.

headline: Candidate Hoping to Be First Hispanic Mayor May Be 100 Years Too Late
text: The demography of the New York City mayoral campaign may already have shifted under at least one candidate’s prospective feat, even before November, when Adolfo Carrión Jr. hopes to be elected the city’s first Hispanic mayor.

headline: Rank Something! The Top 5 Most Talented ‘American Idol’ Contestants Ever
text: In last weekend’s Riff, Heather Havrilesky examined what the difference between Mariah Carey and Nicki Minaj (hint: think anodyne glamor versus outsize freakiness) can tell us about our changing notions of musical talent.

headline: Alzheimer’s Treatment Failed Trial, Maker Says
text: In yet another setback for the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease, Baxter International said Tuesday that its drug, Gammagard, had failed to halt the mental decline caused by the disease in a late-stage clinical trial.

headline: Exploring Environmental Issues and Communication With Students in Japan
text: Dot Earth is relatively quiescent at the moment because we’re in the final sprint finishing the spring term at Pace University, including preparing for the launch of ¡Viva La Tortuga! Meshing Conservation and Culture in Magdalena Bay, our documentary on sea turtle conservation in Mexico’s Baja region (there are public screenings this afternoon on the Westchester County campus and Wednesday in New York City, and of course you’ll be able to watch the video here on Dot Earth, as with previous efforts).

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Bangladesh Lessons
Amanda Berry’s 911 Call
text: Amanda Berry told a dispatcher Monday that she had been kidnapped and pleaded for the police to come before the man who was holding her captive returned. Ms. Berry, who is now 27, was last seen leaving her job at a Cleveland Burger King in April 2003.

headline: Costume Institute Gala Is an Experience, From Head to Toes
text: As I bid goodnight to my friend Jessica Diehl, the Vanity Fair style director, on the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, she wailed, “My feet are on fire.” And well they should be after a night of punk and couture.

headline: Air Bag Recall Spreads to BMW; G.M. Recalls Some eAssist Models
text: The widespread air bag recall affecting about 3.3 million Japanese vehicles last month has apparently spread to BMW as well. BMW says it will recall about 42,000 of its 2002-3 3 Series models because a passenger side air bag defect could send shards of metal into the passenger compartment.

headline: U.S. and Russia Plan Conference Aimed at Ending Syrian War
text: MOSCOW — Russia and the United States announced on Tuesday that they would seek to convene an international conference within weeks aimed at ending the civil war in Syria, jointly intensifying their diplomatic pressure on the combatants to peacefully settle a conflict that has taken more than 70,000 lives and left millions displaced and desperate.

headline: The Gun Report: May 7, 2013
text: We’ve written several times about an anti-gun violence organization called Evolve, which aims to change the culture around gun violence by reframing it as a public safety issue. A big part of these efforts is enlisting responsible gun owners in the movement to reduce gun deaths.

headline: A Wunderkind Artist Summons a Barely Bygone New York
text: He’s just 24, but Lucien Smith has arrived. In the past two years the assemblage artist, known for canvases that mix paint with found objects, has shown in prestigious galleries from L.A. to Milan, including Half Gallery, OHWOW and Brand New. Smith’s new solo show at the Suzanne Geiss Company, “A Clean Sweep,” which opens tomorrow, is an homage to Giuliani-era New York in three parts. The first is a group of free-standing brooms, “collected” off New York City streets by Smith and his friends, that are meant to signify the city’s gentrification. The second is a series of Polaroid grids featuring relics of the city’s urban landscape, including trash cans, crosswalks and playground signs. The third is a film (seen here) made in collaboration with a New York institution: Glenn O’Brien.

headline: India’s Parliament Descends into Chaos, Threatening Landmark Bills
text: NEW DELHI— India’s lower house of Parliament, under pressure to pass two pieces of legislation this week deemed crucial to the poor, farmers and development projects, descended into a shouting match Tuesday before adjourning.

headline: Daily Report: The Google Glass Resistance
text: Months before it goes on sale, Google Glass, a wearable computer, is already generating resistance, David Streitfeld reports Tuesday in The New York Times.

headline: Queen Elizabeth to Skip Commonwealth Meeting
text: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth, 87, will skip this year’s meeting of the heads of the Commonwealth governments, the first time she has failed to attend since 1973, Buckingham Palace said on Tuesday. She will be represented at the biennial meeting, which this year is to be held in November in Sri Lanka, by her son Prince Charles, 64, the heir to the throne.

headline: G.I. Stones a Portrait of Karzai, Causing a Stir
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An American soldier would have been well served to remember the childhood adage about sticks and stones before he threw rocks at a wall-size portrait of President Hamid Karzai that graces a town square in northeastern Afghanistan.

headline: Senegalese Singer and Finnish Composer Share the Polar Prize
text: The Senegalese singer Youssou N’Dour and the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho were named the winners Tuesday of the 2013 Polar Music Prize. Each will be awarded one million Swedish kronor, or about $150,000, and will be invited to a ceremony in Stockholm on Aug. 27.

headline: For Democrats, Corruption Arrest Is One More Barrier to Control of the State Senate
text: ALBANY — There are many more Democrats than Republicans in New York State. There are even more Democrats than Republicans in the State Senate.

headline: SAP Takes It All to the Cloud
text: SAP, the German software giant, is making one of the largest pushes into cloud computing yet seen from a large incumbent company. It may even be destroying its own business, in order to build for a new one.

headline: Son of Cleveland Kidnapping Suspect Wrote About Missing Girl in 2004
text: The son of Ariel Castro, the Cleveland man suspected of abducting three women and keeping them hidden in his home for years, wrote about the disappearance of one of the victims, Gina DeJesus, for a local newspaper in 2004.

headline: The Challenges Ahead for HSBC
