text: HSBC is digging in for a low-interest-rate world. Economic malaise in the West has depressed demand for loans. Central bank money printing is weighing on the lender’s large deposit base. With no pickup in sight, HSBC’s returns depend on its ability to keep cutting costs.

headline: Fox News Anchor Megyn Kelly Renews Contract
text: Two of the best-known anchors on the Fox News Channel, Greta Van Susteren and Megyn Kelly, have renewed their contracts, possibly foreshadowing the first change to the channel’s prime time schedule in over a decade.

headline: A Clean Sweep
text: An exclusive premiere of a film by Lucien Smith and Glenn O'Brien.

headline: A Main-Course Salad With Spinach and Chickpeas
text: In What’s for Dinner?, a column appearing every other week on Diner’s Journal, Melissa Clark answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Why I Would Rather Pay My Employees Too Much
text: Thank you to everyone who commented on my last post, “Why I Pay What I Pay,” about the performance I expect from workers at different wage rates. I was surprised by the number of comments, but I guess that any discussion of pay is going to push someone’s button. That said, I’d like to respond to a couple of points that were raised and also make a few new ones.

headline: Limited Options for Airline Check-In
text: Back when air travel was new and glamorous, the check-in desk, where an elegant air hostess would greet you, was a delightful way to start your journey. Nowadays, it is more often the site of overwhelmed agents contending with long lines of frustrated travelers.

headline: How to Tell Google Now to Stop Peeking
text: It used to be that every new phone was heralded as “the iPhone killer.” Now the preoccupation is with “the Siri killer,” the app that will replace the sometimes frustrating Siri personal assistant on the iPhone.

headline: In the N.B.A., Celebrate at Your Own Risk
text: Celebrations in the N.B.A. exist at the margins. They might not be as rigorously scrutinized as touchdown dances in the N.F.L., but there are consequences. When LeBron James stared down Jason Terry after knocking him to the floor on an alley-oop, he received a technical foul. When Kevin Durant topped off a slam in transition with a throat slash, the league fined him $25,000. But their transgressive nature is what gives these gestures their power. This goes double when they’re taken from an opponent, as when the Knicks’ Iman Shumpert stole Jason Terry’s flight plan and broke out Terry’s signature “JET” celebration after draining a 3-pointer in the Knicks’ Game 6 win over the Celtics.

headline: Celebs Channel Punk With Bleached Hair and Studded Jackets at the Met Ball
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: If You Like the Sex Pistols, Try Green Day or the Gaslight Anthem
text: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: South Carolina Voters Think Economics
text: In Charleston, S.C., voters in a special election pitting Elizabeth Colbert Busch against the state’s former governor, Mark Sanford, care most about jobs.

headline: Bernardaud’s New Collection of Tableware
text: To celebrate its 150th anniversary, the French porcelain manufacturer Bernardaud has created a collection of tableware designed by several artists, including Sophie Calle, Jeff Koons and David Lynch. “We’ve always worked with the world of creators, whether they’re artists or designers,” said Michel Bernardaud, the company’s chairman. “But this year, we decided to put a special emphasis on this relationship.”

headline: Revisiting Post-9/11 Law
text: Politico reported today that senators from both parties want to revisit the Authorization for the Use of Military Force, the Congressional resolution passed in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: New Video Games
text: INJUSTICE

headline: Thompson Gets Key Endorsement From Bronx Borough President
text: In another sign of his deep ties to established leaders in minority communities, William C. Thompson Jr. collected a key endorsement in his bid for mayor Tuesday from Ruben Diaz Jr., the Bronx borough president.

headline: Liberal Party Backs Catsimatidis
text: John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire businessman and Gristedes supermarket owner running for mayor of New York City, picked up the endorsement of an obscure but potentially influential political group on Tuesday, adding another wrinkle to the Republican primary.

headline: Sexual Assaults in Military Raise Alarm in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — The problem of sexual assault in the military leapt to the forefront in Washington on Tuesday as the Pentagon released a survey estimating that 26,000 people in the armed forces were sexually assaulted last year, up from 19,000 in 2010, and an angry President Obama and Congress demanded action.

headline: Men’s Final Four Is Moving to TBS
text: TBS will start televising the Final Four of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament in 2014 and 2015, advancing the schedule contemplated in its 14-year, $10.8 billion contract with CBS that went into effect three years ago. In those two years, CBS will continue to carry the championship game.

headline: Video of Imran Khan’s Fall at Election Rally in Pakistan
text: Last Updated, 2:36 p.m. Imran Khan, a former cricket superstar who has been drawing huge crowds to campaign rallies in Pakistan ahead of Saturday’s election, was rushed to a hospital in Lahore on Tuesday after he was knocked off a forklift at the edge of a stage and fell headfirst to the ground, nearly 15 feet below.

headline: Congress Set to Begin Work on Farm Bill
text: The Senate Agriculture Committee announced on Tuesday that it would begin working on a new farm bill next week, reviving efforts to pass the once-every-five-years spending bill that sets the nation’s food and farm policy. The last farm bill was passed in 2008.

headline: Cherry Jones to Return to Manhattan Theater Club in New Play
text: The two-time Tony Award winner Cherry Jones will return to Manhattan Theater Club next spring to star in a new drama by Sarah Treem, “When We Were Young and Unafraid,” playing a woman in the early 1970s who turns her bed and breakfast into a refuge for women in need. It will be the first time Ms. Jones has acted on Manhattan Theater Club’s Off Broadway stage since her critically acclaimed, Tony-winning performance as Sister Aloysius in John Patrick Shanley’s play “Doubt,” which began there in 2004 before moving to Broadway a few months later.

headline: Albanese Criticizes 2 Elected Rivals Over Office Staff Hiring
text: Sal F. Albanese, a former city councilman and a Democratic candidate for mayor, on Tuesday accused two of his rivals, Christine C. Quinn, the Council speaker, and Bill de Blasio, the public advocate, of having hired political operatives at taxpayer expense as they readied their own campaigns.

headline: Recognition Grows for Poets of Streets, Main or Otherwise
text: FRESNO, Calif. — This city has long been an object of ridicule. Even seemingly innocuous details like the flatness of the land, reinforced by the sea of ranch-style houses, take on a pejorative hue. Midway between San Francisco and Los Angeles, the western gateway on Highway 99 to Yosemite National Park, Fresno is not a destination but “a bathroom stop,” in the words of its poet laureate.

headline: New York State Investigating Pension-Advance Firms
text: New York’s top banking regulator has begun an investigation into pension advance firms, the lenders that woo retirees to sign over their monthly pension checks in return for cash.

headline: Hasty Deal to Save Chrysler in Depths of Crisis Returns to Haunt
text: All deal makers have a number they want to hit. In the case of Chrysler, the United Automobile Workers union has one number, and Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of both Chrysler and Fiat, has another.

headline: President Obama on North Korea
text: Meeting with President Park Geun-hye on Tuesday, President Obama reaffirmed America’s ties with South Korea and said North Korea’s days of eliciting concessions were over.

headline: Autistic and Coming (Reluctantly) of Age
text: In the last few months, my 14-year-old son, Jonah, has grown taller than his mother. Which means just one thing: I’m next. In our below-average-size family, this doesn’t exactly qualify him for March Madness; still, it should be cause for celebration.

headline: Amanda Knox: By the Book

text: If there’s a story – or even a word – that’s more fraught with divisive American politics than “Benghazi,” I’m unaware of it.

headline: Ray Harryhausen, Whose Creatures Battled Jason and Sinbad, Dies at 92
text: Ray Harryhausen, the animator and special-effects wizard who found ways to breathe cinematic life into the gargantuan, the mythical and the extinct, died on Tuesday in London. He was 92 and lived in London.

text: Images from the wedding of Miho Walsh and Roy Prieb at the Penninsula hotel in Bangkok.

headline: Living South of Delancey
text: Venturing south of Manhattan’s East Village, one finds a neighborhood where a quiet residential atmosphere prevails.

headline: Reasons for Crossing Delancey
text: The Lower East Side, whose tenements teemed with immigrants for generations beginning in the 19th century, has in recent years become known north of Delancey Street for crowds of a different sort: the whooping revelers who stream down its streets and cascade from its scores of bars, restaurants and falafel shops on weekends. Indeed, the density of raucous nightspots has earned the nickname Hell Square for the area between East Houston and Delancey from Allen Street east to the Delancey, a club near Clinton Street.

headline: Rap, Both Good and Bad for Business
text: In hip-hop, as in all things, you get what you pay for, even if you don’t read the fine print.

headline: New Head of C.I.A.’s Clandestine Service Is Picked, as Acting Chief Is Passed Over
text: WASHINGTON — John O. Brennan, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, has replaced the acting head of the agency’s clandestine service, a woman who was at the center of the agency’s detention and interrogation program and played a central role in the destruction of interrogation videotapes, American officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Bulls’ Star Standing Out for Not Toughing It Out
text: In Los Angeles, Kobe Bryant tore his Achilles’ and limped out to shoot free throws in a valiant effort to make the playoffs. In Oakland, after being injured in his first postseason game after an eight-season wait, David Lee suited up with a torn hip flexor and took a minute to rise up for a rebound.

headline: Be Wary of Debt Settlement Calls
text: It may sound like a solution: You are mired in debt and a telemarketer calls, offering to help reduce the amount you owe, in exchange for a fee.

headline: Pleased by Apple’s Move, Einhorn Raises His Bet
text: When Apple  agreed to extensively expand its stock buyback program last month, David Einhorn was pleased.

headline: O’Melveny & Myers Hires 3 Senior Bankruptcy Lawyers
text: Three partners in the bankruptcy group at the law firm Cadwalader Wickersham & Taft are leaving to join O’Melveny & Myers.

headline: Cooking Fried Chicken
text: Julia Moskin makes a fried chicken recipe from Norman King’s new cookbook, “The Way to Fry.”

headline: Five Travel Problems and the Sites That Try to Solve Them
text: Ah, the problems budget travelers used to have. Hours on the phone with the airlines trying to pin down the cheapest fare. A bargain B&B that looked great in the brochure – if only there were a way to access feedback from previous guests. I wish there was a way to tell the world in 140 characters or less that I made it to the top of this Mayan temple!

headline: Guest Post | ‘Sliding Into Homelessness': A Student Essay and Teaching Resources
text: Occasionally we collaborate with an organization called Youth Communication to feature true stories by young people that help add a new voice or angle to a topic we’ve covered on the blog.

headline: The Art of Frying
text: Recipe Lab, a monthly feature, invites you to cook with the Dining section. We’ll publish a standout recipe from a new cookbook for you to try; the next week, the book’s author will join Julia Moskin and readers in a live video chat about the recipe and cooking techniques. This month we’re making Southern fried chicken from “The Way to Fry,” by Norman King; you can watch the video chat here on Diner’s Journal on Wednesday, May 15, at 8 p.m. Eastern. If you’d like to appear in the video chat, more details are here.

headline: Sweet and Spicy or Assertive Wines With Eggplant
text: Eggplant is often described as a polarizing food, one that people either love or hate. I’m the counterexample. I like it well enough, unless it’s overcooked, which emphasizes the mushy texture and slight bitterness that seem to repel so many. That tendency toward bitterness, especially when combined with the spinach in Mary McCartney’s dish of eggplant wraps, makes it a difficult pairing. I think of reds first, but nothing too tannic, which would clash with the bitterness. The sweet and spicy fruit of a lighter-weight zinfandel would work well. So might a lively Sicilian red like a nero d’Avola or a cerasuolo di Vittoria. Assertive whites would work well, too, like a sauvignon blanc, even a flamboyantly styled example, or a good, dry chenin blanc, like a Vouvray or Savennières.

headline: The Garden He Left Behind
text: My dad John and I started growing garlic about 20 years ago. I purchased my planting stock at a harvest festival, John through mail order. Eventually I came to admit his variety was much nicer than ours for both marketing and culinary purposes. He’d always announce sometime in April that it was up and about a foot high. Even though dad lived south of us in the upper Hudson Valley, my husband Jim and I assumed he was just embellishing, and we’d smirk to each other. He was always positive and optimistic, whether gardening, dealing with three different cancer episodes or rooting for Philadelphia sports teams. I finally grew enough garlic from his stock to completely replace my varieties. And yes, it is quick to emerge in the spring, gaining good height early. This year’s is already up. It looks good — a summer harbinger of the grilling season ahead.

headline: Shorter Hours, but Not for Truckers and Temps
text: One of the more disappointing data points in last Friday’s jobs report was the decline in average weekly hours worked, which fell to 34.4 hours in April from 34.6 hours in March. It’s not clear what was behind the decline, which occurred in multiple industries across the private sector. (The monthly jobs report does not include the length of the workweek for government workers.)

headline: Ruling Clears Way for $7 Billion A.I.G. Suit Against Bank of America
text: A California judge has opened the door for the American International Group to pursue a fraud claim of more than $7 billion against Bank of America for losses it suffered on mortgage securities sold under duress after the federal government rescued A.I.G. in 2008.

headline: ‘The Office’ Gets an Extra 15 Minutes to Say Goodbye
text: NBC is having a hard time saying goodbye to its most successful comedy of the last decade, “The Office.” Its one-hour finale just got longer.

headline: An Encounter in Overtime Highlights the Rise of Swiss Hockey
text: DETROIT — After more than an hour of tense playoff hockey Monday, the Game 4 fates of the Detroit Red Wings and the Anaheim Ducks came down to two players who grew up 29 miles apart in Switzerland.

headline: Father Barred From Receiving Credentials for ATP Events
text: The ATP, the governing body of the men’s tennis Tour, announced Tuesday that it had barred John Tomic, the coach and father of the rising Australian player Bernard Tomic, from receiving credentials at all of its events until further notice.

headline: In Store | Amanda Hearst’s Ethical Fashion Pop-Up
text: “I think some people still don’t really know what ethical fashion is,” Amanda Hearst says. The editor and activist, a contributor to Town and Country and a former Marie Claire columnist, has for several years sought to spread the word by promoting (and wearing) labels that use organically grown, recycled and sustainably harvested fabrics and employ artisan collectives in the developing world. When Hearst met the young New York designer Hassan Pierre — whose Way It Should Be and Basic collections use materials ranging from organic cotton jersey to discarded cassette tape — the two discovered a shared wish to create a retail platform for the movement’s best offerings. The resulting collaboration is Maison de Mode, a series of ethical fashion pop-up boutiques whose second event happens this weekend at the Hole Gallery as part of the Frieze Art Fair.

headline: Roving in the Bronx
text: The New York Times' roving runner, Brian Fidelman, takes a running tour of The New York Botanical Garden.

headline: The Roving Runner: The New York Botanical Garden
text: These are glorious days to run in New York City.

headline: Wheelies: The Flying Car Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Chris Christie’s Surgery and 2016 Hopes
text: The Times’s Carolyn Ryan on Gov. Chris Christie’s weight-loss surgery and what it means for how he might approach the 2016 race.

headline: Untimely Metaphysics
text: The Stone’s weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

headline: No Easy Answers on Syria, Obama Says
text: WASHINGTON – President Obama on Tuesday defended his cautious response to evidence that the Syrian government had used chemical weapons on its citizens, saying that he could not make high-stakes decisions based on a “perceived” use of those weapons.

headline: Play Hurt, or Play Smart
text: The Bulls' Derrick Rose has taken a lot of criticism for not returning sooner from a serious knee injury. William C. Rhoden says Rose has to look out for himself.

headline: Backing Grows for European Bank Plan
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s halting effort to create a more unified banking system, which many experts consider necessary for avoiding future financial crises, received fresh impetus on Tuesday.

headline: Brazilian Tapped to Lead World Trade Organization
text: PARIS — Roberto Carvalho de Azevêdo of Brazil will be the next leader of the World Trade Organization, a Brazilian official said Tuesday, and will take the reins at a time when the group is fighting to remain relevant.

headline: Japan Says It Will Abide by Apologies Over Actions in World War II
text: TOKYO — Japan’s conservative government will abide by official apologies that the country’s leaders made two decades ago to the victims of World War II in Asia, top officials said Tuesday, backing away from earlier suggestions that the government might try to revise or even repudiate the apologies.

headline: Barrage of Beef, Argentine Style
text: Sometimes disappointments lead to happy accidents. By any measure, a long-anticipated fishing trip to the Iberá Marshes in Argentina was a bust. The week before we arrived in February, a biblical rainstorm inundated a half-million acres of wetlands, scattering the fish into deep cover. In such conditions you can tough it out (a resolutely macho course of action that rarely ends well), or you can bow to fate and head to Buenos Aires for a few days.

headline: The Horrors of Chechnya, With Humor
text: Some good novels catch fire immediately, as if a writer had simply opened a Zippo lighter. Others come into being more gradually. The author cautiously tends to his or her kindling.

headline: Video: Play Hurt, or Play Smart
text: The Bulls’ Derrick Rose has taken a lot of criticism for not returning sooner from a serious knee injury. But Rose has to look out for himself because no one else is going to do it for him.

headline: At Home on the Range and in Tasty Suburban Backyards

headline: Pakistani Sports-Star-Turned-Candidate Is Injured in Fall

headline: Tradition Performed With a Twist
text: At the center of Sonia M’barek’s concert on Friday night at the French Institute Alliance Française in Manhattan was a song she performed a cappella: “Al Kalimat” (“The Power of Words”), with lyrics by the 20th-century Tunisian poet Mnaouer Smadeh: “Speak up and suffer, even if you die for the sake of the words,” it urged. She sang it with delicacy and strength, with mourning and determination, with intricate ornament and open passion — and, perhaps, with thoughts of the Arab Spring, which began in Tunisia, and its Islamist aftermath.

text: The American food revolution has reached the Rust Belt by way of ambitious chefs who are cooking sustainably and supporting local agriculture.

text: Photos from Afghanistan, Bangladesh, South Korea and Italy.

headline: Searching for Clues in Cleveland
text: Three young women, who disappeared about a decade ago and who friends and relatives feared were gone forever, were found on Monday after a frantic 911 call made by one of the abductees.

headline: Gains at Disney Parks Help Lift Profit
text: LOS ANGELES — The Magic Kingdom is on fire.

headline: One More Field Where the Continent Trails Germany
text: BERLIN — France’s finance minister, Pierre Moscovici, warned on Tuesday against caricatures and misunderstandings over Germany’s handling of the euro crisis, but quickly qualified his conciliatory statement about the European Union’s most powerful country.

headline: More Islamists Join Cabinet in Shuffling Within Egypt
text: CAIRO — President Mohamed Morsi swore in nine new cabinet members on Tuesday in a reshuffle that increased the role of Islamists in the upper ranks of the government but is not expected to herald any immediate policy shifts.

headline: A Slipper Made of Glass, Worn to a Fateful Ball
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On Wednesday the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon will present a world premiere and an update of an old ballet at New York City Ballet’s spring gala. Yet over this past weekend he was presenting a different premiere in the Bay Area: the North American one of his three-act Prokofiev “Cinderella,” danced by three casts at San Francisco Ballet; two further casts will perform it this week. The ballet, which has a scenario by the playwright Craig Lucas, is a co-production with the Dutch National Ballet in Amsterdam, where it had its world premiere last December.

headline: Once Upon a ‘Woods,’ Stripped Down
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — Little Red Riding Hood turns into Rapunzel. A feather duster turns into a living creature. A prince turns into a stepsister who turns into a cow.

headline: Delaware, Continuing a Trend, Becomes the 11th State to Allow Same-Sex Unions
text: Delaware on Tuesday became the 11th state to permit same-sex marriage, the latest in a string of victories for those working to extend marital rights to gay and lesbian couples.

headline: Aboriginal Artworks to Return to Australia
text: In a homecoming sweetened with poetic justice, a collection of drawings and paintings by Aboriginal children living in a settlement camp in the 1940s and 1950s will be returned to Australia.

headline: A Bit of Party for the Home
text: An owner as well as the creative director of the New York event-design firm Fête, Jung Lee has spent more than a decade producing lavish weddings and parties. But when the events are over and the distinctive tablescapes have been cleared, her clients often ask to take elements from the festivities into their everyday lives.

headline: Marginalia, Added by the Author
text: Here at the magazine, you might say we have a thing about marginalia. So perhaps it’s not a surprise that I’m mildly infatuated with Nieman Storyboard’s Annotation Tuesday! (That’s not an unwarranted exclamation mark.) It’s a series produced every other week in which authors answer questions about their reporting and writing, which is obviously cool. (Who doesn’t want to know how a reporter got a witness to talk? Or where that detail about the marigolds came from?) But Annotation Tuesday! serves up the answers in the body of the story itself — kind of like the obsessive highlights and notes I tend to make with my Kindle, but in this case with actual answers.

headline: Replanting the Rust Belt
text: Pittsburgh in springtime is an edible city.

headline: Coty Said to Seek $700 Million in I.P.O.

headline: White Makes Case for Bigger S.E.C. Budget
text: Mary Jo White cleared a rite of passage on Tuesday: she asked Congress for more money.

headline: Judge Criticizes Obama Administration as It Appeals Contraception Decision
text: A federal judge on Tuesday angrily accused the Obama administration of hurting poor and minority women by seeking to restrict their access to morning-after contraceptive pills.

headline: White House Plans to Add Technology Adviser
text: The White House is looking to Silicon Valley to expand its team of technology advisers.

headline: A Spiritual and Musical Journey
text: Meditation is a way to practice letting go of expectations. In that spirit, “One Track Heart: The Story of Krishna Das” is a fine enough documentary, a nice enough introduction to a charismatic figure with a fascinating life, an unusual art and worldwide fans.

headline: Staying Up Late at the Met
text: After the last tables had been cleared, the loins of lamb with mint mustard sauce devoured, the flutes of Paul Goerg premier cru brut rosé quaffed and the dinner portion of the Costume Institute gala ended, that is when things really got interesting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Rubio’s Letter to Heritage Foundation on Immigration
text: Senator Marco Rubio wrote to the Heritage Foundation ahead of its report on the economics of the immigration proposal encouraging it to use a different type of fiscal analysis.

headline: Yanking Broadband From the Slow Lane
text: It has been almost two decades since @Home Network offered perhaps the first broadband plan in the country. It was right after the 1996 Telecommunications Act allowed cable companies to get into the business. Milo Medin, one of @Home’s co-founders, still recalls the price of the pioneering service, offered to residents of Fremont, Calif.: $34.95 a month — $51.85 in today’s money — for a maximum speed of 10 megabits per second. The memory inspires not a little frustration about the Internet’s progress since then: 17 years after @Home plugged in its first customer, the residents of Kansas City pay Time Warner, their local cable company, $46.90 for a 3 Mbps connection and $55.40 for a top speed of 15 Mbps.

headline: Met Gala 2013: Punk Done Well Pinterest Board
text: Granted, interpreting punk style for the red carpet is challenging. It’s probably why some at the Met Gala last night chose to forgo the idea altogether, so many so that there were moments where it was difficult to distinguish the punk-themed Met Gala red carpet from say, the Golden Globes. Others, like Taylor Tomasi Hill, Cameron Diaz and Carey Mulligan treaded lightly by including touches of punk flair on dress details or through their hair or makeup choices — a few studs here or a faux hawk there.

headline: No Teaching Gig for Galliano
text: After receiving a volley of complaints and support for a planned classroom discussion with the designer John Galliano, Parsons the New School for Design said on Tuesday that it would not go forward with the class after all.

headline: Red Bulls Put Streak on the Line
text: One month ago the Red Bulls appeared to be a team on the verge of an early-season meltdown. But as they say, it’s a marathon, not a sprint.

headline: South Korea’s President Visits the U.S.
text: As President Park Geun-hye makes her first visit to Washington, South Koreans discuss the importance of their country’s relationship with the United States in light of the conflict with North Korea.

headline: A Coach Takes ‘Dunk City’ Style to Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — As a special guest for Southern California’s spring football game on April 13, Andy Enfield had a sideline pass. After taking care of his news media responsibilities, which have become part of his daily routine, he wanted to pay close attention to the game. Enfield considers himself a big football fan.

headline: Celebrate Brooklyn Summer Concert Schedule Announced
text: The folksinger Patty Griffin will give the opening concert of the 35th annual “Celebrate Brooklyn!” festival in Prospect Park on June 5, kicking off an eclectic 29-performance series featuring acts like Big Boi, Calexico, Os Mutante, the Waterboys and the gospel star Bebe Winans.

headline: Test Run: Dots, a Simple but Addictive Game From Betaworks
text: A couple of years ago, the Apple iPhone’s graphics reached a point that allowed developers to make video games for mobile phones that felt as immersive and complex as those for traditional hand-held game systems. But as the games became ever more complicated, I stopped downloading them.

headline: At Hurricane-Ravaged Seaport, New Forecast Calls for Glitter Rain
text: This summer at the almost defiantly unhip South Street Seaport, there shall be pop-up boutiques housed in shipping containers. There shall be outdoor film screenings with lounge-chair seating. There shall be SmorgasBar. And, the lords of artificial weather willing, there may be glitter rain.

headline: A Mets Twitter Account Strikes Again
text: During the winter, the Mets’ chief operating officer, Jeff Wilpon, invited the team spokesman, Jay Horwitz, to have fun with his newly created Twitter account. Since then, Horwitz has used the account to poke fun at himself and to jokingly report false news items. Recently, he claimed that the Mets would be playing a tripleheader against the Colorado Rockies to make up for the snowed out series in Denver.

headline: With Hours to Go, Execution Is Postponed
text: A Mississippi man scheduled to be put to death on Tuesday was granted a stay of execution by the State Supreme Court, after the United States Department of Justice sent lawyers and officials involved in the case several letters disavowing the degree of certainty expressed by F.B.I. forensic experts at the man’s trial.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,201 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Bodies Pour In as Nigeria Hunts for Islamists
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — A fresh load of battered corpses arrived, 29 of them in a routine delivery by the Nigerian military to the hospital morgue here.

headline: Woods Takes a Stroll Down the Red Carpet
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — On Monday night, a tuxedo-clad Tiger Woods accompanied his girlfriend, the Olympic ski champion Lindsey Vonn, to the Costume Institute Gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Woods, the world No. 1 who has traditionally been red carpet-shy, met Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue, which hosted the event, the theme of which was Punk: Chaos to Couture.

headline: Group Says Netanyahu Has Put Hold on Settlements
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has quietly suspended the issuing of bids for new settlement construction, according to a watchdog group, in an apparent gesture to Secretary of State John Kerry as he works to restart Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

headline: Melanie Meyers
text: Ms. Meyers, 53, is a partner at the law firm Fried Frank, specializing in land use. She represents several large developers, including the Related Companies, Forest City Ratner and the Rudin Management Company.

headline: Butler Shows He Is No Mere Fill-In for Bulls
text: MIAMI — Before the 2011 N.B.A. draft, Jimmy Butler’s junior college coach, Mike Marquis, received a phone call from Matt Lloyd, who was part of the Chicago Bulls’ scouting department. Lloyd, who now works for the Orlando Magic, had a highly specific question for Marquis.

headline: A Humbled Kleiner Perkins Adjusts Its Strategy
text: During the dot-com boom, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the venture capital investment firm, all but minted money, making prescient early investments in Netscape Communications, Amazon.com and Google and delivering astonishing returns to investors. Along the way, it became a symbol of Silicon Valley.

headline: Syria Loses Access to the Internet
text: Syria’s access to the Internet was cut on Tuesday. The most likely culprit, security researchers said, was the Syrian government.

headline: In 2005, Kidnap Suspect’s Daughter Spoke of Seeing Her Friend for the Last Time
text: A year after 14-year-old Gina DeJesus vanished in 2004 while walking home from her middle school, America’s Most Wanted interviewed her classmate, one of the last people believed to have seen her alive. On Tuesday, the DeJesus family learned that the classmate, Arlene Castro, is also the daughter of the Cleveland man accused of kidnapping Ms. DeJesus and hiding her and two other women in his basement for years.

headline: Snedeker Not a Fan of Fans Having a Say in Policing Players
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Five years before a television viewer flagged Tiger Woods for a violation at the Masters, Brandt Snedeker was summoned to a Saturday meeting of the rules committee at Augusta National, same as Woods last month, to explain something they said raised a red flag after his Friday round.

headline: Lee and Miller, 18 Years Later
text: Spike Lee walked to his courtside seat on Tuesday night, smiling as he was greeted by fans, security guards and Madison Square Garden employees. He wore an orange fedora hat, a neon orange Knicks jacket and blue and orange dress shoes.

headline: Men’s Fifth Major May Remain Mythical
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.

headline: China Blasts Hacking Claim by Pentagon
text: HONG KONG — China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Tuesday criticized a Pentagon report that explicitly accused China’s military of staging attacks on the computer systems of the American government and military contractors.

headline: Washington Gardeners Battle a Persistent Pest: A Flower Thief
text: WASHINGTON — It starts each April with the violation of lilacs. Peonies are the next to fall, then Asiatic lilies. Then, in a painful botanic denouement, hydrangeas meet their demise, yanked at times straight from the roots.

headline: Iraq’s Worsening Sunni Protests Revolve Around Antiterrorism Tactics
text: BAGHDAD — The Sunni protest movement here is turning increasingly violent, freshening memories of the brutal sectarian conflict of 2006 and raising troubling parallels to the Syrian civil war.

headline: Colorado: Massacre Suspect Pursues Insanity Defense
text: Defense lawyers for James E. Holmes, who is charged with opening fire in an Aurora movie theater last summer, said in court filings Tuesday that he intended to plead not guilty by reason of insanity. Mr. Holmes is accused of killing 12 people and wounding dozens more. Earlier this year, after Mr. Holmes’s defense team said it was not ready to enter a plea, Judge William B. Sylvester entered a standard not guilty plea on Mr. Holmes’s behalf. A new judge in the case, Carlos A. Samour Jr., will rule on the plea change.

headline: Some Complications as U.S. Soccer Enters a Busy Summer
text: Ladies and gentlemen, start your DVRs. Or at least clear them out. There is a big summer of soccer approaching.

headline: Mexico: Gas Tanker Explodes; 22 Dead
text: A double tanker transporting gas struck a containment wall on a highway in a Mexico City suburb on Tuesday and burst into flames, killing 22 people and injuring 31, the authorities said.

headline: Public Hearing in Albany Is Held Without the Public
text: ALBANY — Something was missing at a public hearing held by the State Senate on Tuesday to examine New York City’s campaign finance system: the public.

headline: Adobe Sends Boxed Software to the Cloud
text: Adobe Systems this week announced that its popular Creative Suite, which bundles Photoshop, Illustrator and a number of its other products, will be available only by subscription through Adobe’s cloud service, Creative Cloud. No more boxes and disks.

headline: A Historic Textile Mill Begins a New Chapter
text: After a complicated 20-year effort to save a redbrick mill in North Carolina that was once considered the largest in the world for textiles and that played a significant role in the South’s textile history, the plant is finally moving toward a new life as a multiuse complex.

headline: Start-Up Diplomacy
text: IN 2011, a group of American high-tech executives and angel investors traveled to North Africa as part of an innovative State Department economic development program. Local entrepreneurs flocked to workshops in Tunisia, Morocco and Algeria, where the Americans judged their business proposals and encouraged them to open start-ups. The initiative embodied the “economic statecraft” at the heart of Secretary Hillary Rodham Clinton’s vision for American foreign policy.

headline: Kitchen Little
text: When you argue, as I frequently do, that cooking has the potential to help us deal with many of our dietary problems, you often elicit a kind of “I don’t care, I hate cooking” response in addition to the expected “I don’t have time.” And that’s fine; cooking isn’t the only route to eating better, and besides, those who hate cooking, or can’t make the time for it, may be lucky enough to have someone else cook for them. As long as they wash the dishes.

headline: Small Firm Could Turn the Vote on Dimon
text: 8:08 a.m. | Updated

headline: SoHo Nonprofit’s Expansion Upsets Some Neighbors
text: After spending several years searching for a larger home, God’s Love We Deliver, a charity that prepares and delivers meals to the sick and homebound, decided that the best place for it to grow was in the building it already owned. To help pay for the major expansion, the group plans to sell about $4 million of its development rights to a developer to build a 14-story condo next door.

headline: Four Legs Are Good
text: A mayoral forum on animal rights, held at the Union Theological Seminary on Monday, offered the strange sight of New York politicians trying to outdo one another in gentleness and compassion. Five candidates sat beneath organ pipes, professing their love of four-legged creatures and easily eliciting cheers, claps, woos and hoots from an audience that seemed neither to know nor care how expertly it was being played.

headline: A 30-Month Legal Fight to Conceal E-Mails About a 95-Day Schools Chancellor
text: If you have lost three consecutive times in court on the same legal fight, with not a single judge giving you the time of day, and one of them saying that your main argument is “particularly specious,” what would you do?

headline: Back Home, Pacers’ Stephenson Is Leaving Fresh Marks on Garden’s Hardwood
text: During a game against the visiting Knicks in February, Lance Stephenson of the Indiana Pacers sent home a postcard of sorts: a Statue of Liberty dunk, the ball held high in his right hand for an extra second before he jammed it through the net in the midst of a Pacers onslaught.

headline: China and Cyberwar
text: Despite denials from Beijing, there seems little doubt that China’s computer hackers are engaged in an aggressive and increasingly threatening campaign of cyberespionage directed at a range of government and private systems in the United States, including the power grid and telecommunications networks.

headline: Hezbollah Takes Risks by Fighting Rebels in Syria

headline: Mexico: U.S. Penalizes Drug Traffickers
text: The Treasury Department announced sanctions against eight Mexicans on Tuesday whom it identified as the main bosses for the Sinaloa Cartel just south of Arizona and Mexicali, Calif. A joint investigation including the Drug Enforcement Agency and United States Customs and Border Protection identified the cartel leaders, and law enforcement officials said they expected additional penalties to follow, including the freezing of assets and bank accounts. “We rely on these types of enforcement actions to really lower the hammer,” said Adam Szubin, director of the Office of Foreign Assets Control at the Treasury Department. He added, “These are some pretty serious players.” Several other Sinaloa operatives have already been penalized, including Joaquin Guzmán, also known as El Chapo, the cartel’s leader.

headline: Rubio Disputes Report on Immigration Bill Costs

headline: Russia: F.B.I. Director in Moscow to Discuss Boston Bombings
text: The F.B.I. director Robert S. Mueller III met with Russian law enforcement and intelligence officials in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the bureau’s investigation of the Boston Marathon bombings, according to American officials. The investigation has focused in part on intelligence the Russian government provided the F.B.I. in 2011 that one of the bombing suspects was a Muslim extremist. Since the attacks, President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia have pledged to work closely together as law enforcement officials in both countries have tried to determine how they could have thwarted the attacks. In 2011, the F.B.I. investigated the Russian warning about one of the suspects, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, but ultimately told the Russians that it had not found any information to back their assertions. In response to several follow-up requests from the F.B.I., the Russians declined to provide more information about the intelligence. In recent weeks, however, the Russians have provided F.B.I. agents with that additional information.

headline: California: 4 Will Share Reward in Manhunt
text: Four people will share the $1 million reward for the capture of Christopher Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer who is suspected in four murders and became the subject of a manhunt across Southern California this year, the police said Tuesday. Karen and Jim Reynolds will receive 80 percent of the reward. Mr. Dorner tied them up and stole their car, after they found him hiding in their Big Bear Lake condominium. They freed themselves and called the police. He killed himself hours later, surrounded by law enforcement officers. Daniel McGowan, who reported seeing Mr. Dorner’s burning truck, will receive 15 percent of the reward. Lee McDaniel, who spotted Mr. Dorner and his truck in Corona, Calif., will receive 5 percent.

headline: A Bar That’s Also a Piece of Art
text: One of the most exciting installations in New York City the week of the Frieze Art Faircan be found not on Randall’s Island but in Chelsea, in the basement of the Hôtel Americano. There, the German artist Tobias Rehberger has constructed Bar Oppenheimer, a facsimile of his favorite Frankfurt watering hole, which he describes as both a sculptural artwork and a utilitarian space. The space, which opens May 10 and will remain open until July 14, dazzles the senses with its salonlike atmosphere, tight dimensions and prismatic black-and-white stripes; it’s also a functional bar where anyone can stop in for a drink during the life of the project.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) DON’T SAY NO UNTIL I FINISH TALKING: THE STORY OF RICHARD D. ZANUCK (2013) Laurent Bouzereau chronicles the life of Richard D. Zanuck (1934-2012), the Oscar-winning producer, through recollections of his childhood on the 20th Century Fox lot as the son of the studio head Darryl F. Zanuck and his wife, the actress Virginia Fox. When Richard had the chance to produce his first film, “Compulsion,” starring Orson Welles, he said his father told him: “You know I had it a lot easier than you will have it. You have to overcome the circumstances of your birth. You carry baggage with you — I am the baggage you carry.” When Darryl Zanuck was installed as chairman of the studio in the 1960s, he asked his son for a list of possible names to be appointed president of the company. Richard, above, submitted a piece of paper that read, simply, “Me.” Films like “The Sound of Music” (1965), “Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid” (1969), “M*A*S*H” (1970) and “The French Connection” (1971) followed. But films like “Doctor Dolittle” (1967) and “Hello, Dolly” (1969) resulted in debt, and just before Christmas 1970, Richard was fired by his father. Shortly afterward his father also lost his job. This documentary, with Steven Spielberg as an executive producer, is followed at 9:45 by “Driving Miss Daisy” (1989), the Oscar best picture winner starring Jessica Tandy as a Southern widow and Morgan Freeman as her driver; it was the first movie produced by the Zanuck Company, which Richard and his wife, Lili Fini Zanuck, founded in 1988. “Cocoon” (1985), about a group of elderly people rejuvenated by aliens, follows at 1:15 a.m., and “Compulsion” (1959), Richard Fleischer’s take on the Leopold-Loeb case, at 3:30.

headline: The Tarot Sees a Full Battery in Your Future

headline: Where Private School Is Not a Privilege
text: In the United States, private school is generally a privilege of the rich. But in poorer nations, particularly in Africa and South Asia, families of all social classes send their children to private school. The private schools within reach of the poor, however — usually a single classroom a woman runs in her house — are not a big improvement. But two school systems — Bridge International Academies in Kenya and BRAC in Bangladesh — are offering something different: they are making decent education accessible to the world’s poorest on a giant scale.

headline: How We Keep Our Mentors and Investors on Board
text: When I came up with the idea for Fashioning Change, I had no idea what it meant to create a technology start-up. I just knew that I wanted to create something that would rival big fashion brands and e-commerce sites like Amazon, and I knew there was a lot I needed to learn. So I sought out resources to help me.

headline: Who Would Kill a Monk Seal?
text: The Hawaiian monk seal has wiry whiskers and the deep, round eyes of an apologetic child. The animals will eat a variety of fish and shellfish, or turn over rocks for eel and octopus, then haul out on the beach and lie there most of the day, digesting. On the south side of Kauai one afternoon, I saw one sneeze in its sleep: its convex body shuddered, then spilled again over the sand the way a raw, boneless chicken breast will settle on a cutting board. The seals can grow to seven feet long and weigh 450 pounds. They are adorable, but also a little gross: the Zach Galifianakises of marine mammals.

headline: If Practice Makes Perfect, Why Don’t Companies Practice More?
text: In his terrific book “Outliers,” Malcolm Gladwell writes about the importance of practice and, specifically, the necessity of completing 10,000 hours of practice in a particular field to become proficient. This makes sense to me. Everything I did before starting in business taught me that practice was essential to achieving success. In school, I had two or three exams each semester, but I went to class every day. Moreover, I had voluminous amounts of homework each night to refine my skills in a particular subject. In football, there were 10 games in a season, but nearly 100 practices.

headline: Objects | Towel Off With Designer Pieces for One Kings Lane
text: Continuing its series of philanthropic collaborations with fashion and interior designers, the online home marketplace One Kings Lane tapped eight talents to create limited-edition prints for its inaugural Designer Series Beach Towels sale. The prints range from kitschy silhouettes of beach gear and diamonds (by Robert Verdi) to floral motifs (by Tracy Reese and Nanette Lepore) to geometric patterns (by Rebecca Minkoff, Celerie Kemble, Steven Alan and Jenni Kayne). Because they’re produced in the same basic colors, they can be mixed and matched easily. Beginning Monday, each designer will take a turn having a sale on OneKingsLane.com, offering several prints each for a few days at a time, with the proceeds benefiting a charity of the maker’s choosing. The first is Tracy Reese’s collection in support of AIDS Fund-New York Community Trust on May 13; the last is Jenni Kayne’s set to benefit Baby 2 Baby on June 18.

headline: California Modern
text: The Los Angeles architect A. Quincy Jones (1913-79) was equally at home designing middle-class housing developments as he was creating luxurious dwellings for celebrities like Gary Cooper and wealthy couples like Walter and Leonore Annenberg. This month, a retrospective examines his extraordinary body of work, which is as influential in its own way as that of better-known West Coast Modernists like Charles Eames and Richard Neutra. The show, at the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles, spotlights Jones’s innovations in indoor-outdoor design and includes photos and original blueprints of a number of his notable projects, like the colorful, airy Burbank headquarters of Warner Bros. Records (above) — an embodiment of the California dream if ever there was one.

headline: Advice on Practicing Yoga in Middle Age, Part 1
text: More than 100 readers submitted questions about aging and yoga to Dr. Loren Fishman, a back-pain and rehabilitative medicine specialist who has long incorporated yoga into patient care. In 1972, before applying to medical school, he studied yoga with B.K.S. Iyengar for a year in Pune, India. Dr. Fishman is medical director of Manhattan Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation in New York City, an assistant clinical professor at Columbia Medical School and an associate editor of the journal Topics in Geriatric Rehabilitation. He is also an author of eight books, including “Yoga for Osteoporosis: the Complete Guide.”

headline: Comeback Achieved, Sanford Takes Spotlight
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — After getting a few hours’ sleep, Mark Sanford made a victory lap Wednesday morning. He showed up on several national television news programs not only as the newly elected congressman from South Carolina’s First District, but also as a symbol of a political comeback many here and across the country thought could never happen.

headline: With Bleak Job Prospects, Parents and Their Children Buy Into Franchises
text: Late one night in January 2012, Paige Palmer called her mother at home, crying. She was entering her final semester as a communications major at St. Mary’s College of California in Moraga, and neither she nor her friends were finding work. The job market was terrifying.

headline: One Perspective on the Best Places to Retire
text: When people dream of places where they’d like to retire, chances are that North Dakota is not at the top of the list. Or South Dakota, for that matter.

headline: Manchester United Investors See Risk in Manager’s Exit
text: 5:37 p.m. | Updated LONDON – When a successful chief executive finally bows out, investors often fret that his replacement won’t be able to replicate past glories.

headline: A Love of History and Horses
text: As many racing fans look forward to the classics, some of us like to look back, preoccupied as much with racing heroes of the past like Harry Bassett and Colin as we are with who will win the big races in 2013. Annie Johnson is one of these people. She runs the Web site Antebellum Turf Times, which looks like a vintage racing broadsheet and contains features such as “How To Catch A Wild Turkey, Circa 1831″ — and the 1845 Constitution of the Adams County, Mississippi, Jockey Club.

headline: Who You Say You Are
text: Ever think twice about using Airbnb, the Web site for short-term home and apartment stays, for fear the traveler or host could be posing under a false name to run a Nigerian prince-style scheme on you? To put your mind at ease, Airbnb added identity verification last month to its site so you can be sure the person you’re e-mailing is who he says he is. Users can upload a photo of their driver’s license or passport and confirm personal historical data about themselves, and Airbnb will compare that information with their Facebook or LinkedIn profiles or Airbnb reviews to verify their backgrounds.

headline: Former Aide to Putin Is Out at Kremlin
text: MOSCOW — The Kremlin on Wednesday announced the resignation of Vladislav Y. Surkov, in recent years a close aide to Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev and one of the architects of Russia’s highly centralized political system, now under strain from protests and a slowing economy.

headline: Calpers Calls JPMorgan’s Combined Top Roles a ‘Fundamental Conflict’
text: As shareholders consider whether to press for splitting JPMorgan Chase’s top two roles, one big investor has made it very clear where it stands.

headline: Republicans, Reporters, Drug Addicts and an Orphaned Mural
text: Having a hard time imagining a palatial Republican Club in the middle of blue Manhattan — with a sumptuous main lounge, fireplaces at either end, that offers a panorama of Bryant Park through its great windows, and an oak-trimmed dining room where each of the pilasters is topped by an “RC” crest?

headline: Commander’s View of the Afghan Endgame
text: In an interview with The New York Times, Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., the supreme military commander in Afghanistan, discussed the readiness of the Afghan security forces, his optimism that the Afghan Army will be a unifying force for the country, the Taliban’s tactics this summer and winning over the Afghan people. Following are extended excerpts from the interview.

headline: The Gun Report: May 8, 2013
text: This just in: two and a half months after California’s state pension funds voted to sell off their gun stocks, New York has followed suit. This morning, Comptroller John Liu announced that the New York City Employees’ Retirement System has sold $16.3 million worth of gun stocks. In his press release, Liu noted that another New York retirement fund, the Teachers’ Retirement System, had also dumped its gun stocks.

headline: South Carolina Voters Get It
text: So they just convincingly voted for Mark Sanford, a man who cheated on his wife, tried to cover his actions with an absurd story about hiking the Appalachian Trail, and trespassed on his ex-wife’s property, over an exemplary Democratic candidate. And you know what? Given their preferences, this was the right thing to do.

headline: Foes Suggest a Tradeoff if Pipeline Is Approved
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s first major environmental decision of his second term could be to approve the Keystone XL pipeline, profoundly disappointing environmental advocates who have made the project a symbolic test of the president’s seriousness on climate change.

headline: Wheelies: The Supercar Cops Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: In California, Push for Diversity in College Starts Earlier
text: As the future of affirmative action in college admissions is being considered by the Supreme Court, my colleague Richard Pérez-Peña describes how universities are working to diversify their student bodies in states like California, which has eliminated race-conscious admissions:

headline: Can Technology and Tourism Sustain Mexico’s Sea Turtles?
text: Sea turtles have roamed the oceans for close to 200 million years, surviving assaults that doomed the dinosaurs. Around the world different species now face threats ranging from coastal building to poaching and drowning in fish nets.

headline: Fergie Time Runs Out at Manchester United
text: Some will remember the 13 league titles. Others the five F.A. Cups or the financial growth that turned a club from northern England into an international empire that trades on the New York Stock Exchange. But any list of Manchester United Manager Alex Ferguson’s contributions to the game must surely include the concept of Fergie Time, though it may not be an official part of global soccer’s vernacular.

headline: Image of the Day: May 8
text: Schoolchildren waiting to receive free meals at a government-run primary school in New Delhi.

headline: Genetics Reveal Europe Is One Big Family
text: LONDON — From Ireland to Turkey, Europeans are all related, sharing a link with ancestors who were alive just 1,000 years ago, according to a new genetic study.

headline: A Mother’s Day Gift
text: Adults with older parents or even grandparents will soon be searching for suitable Mother’s Day and Father’s Day gifts. If these presents are not consumables — a box of chocolates or a bottle of spirits — then they will only enlarge the material convoy that accompanies Mom and Dad through their later years.

headline: Romantic Triangle: Star, Director, City
text: An address on Vanderbilt Avenue in Brooklyn. An F train that never comes. Unfinished on-spec scripts for “Saturday Night Live.” The artistically inclined friend of yours who, incongruously, is dating a man who works at Goldman Sachs. That exorbitant $3 fee at the Bank of America A.T.M. — and the long unpalatable walk to the next deli, to find a cheaper option.

headline: The Fix the Debt Fix Is Still In
text: So, Bill Clinton says that I’m right in the short run while Simpson-Bowles are right in the long run; he’s half right. But what’s interesting is to see the Peterson juggernaut still rolling along despite the enormous intellectual hit the cause has received.

headline: Beatles Concert Show ‘Let It Be’ Coming to Broadway
text: For a group that split up more than four decades ago and never reunited, the Beatles are certainly finding plenty of opportunities to appear on Broadway. “Let It Be,” a popular British concert show based around the band’s music, will make its mop-topped way from the West End to Broadway this summer, press representatives for the production said on Wednesday.

headline: Decisive Moment That Ended a Kidnapping
text: The Times’s Serge F. Kovaleski talks about the decisions made by bystanders like Angel Cordero to help the release of three women held against their will in Cleveland.

headline: A Double Dose of Harry Potter Planned for Universal Theme Parks
text: LOS ANGELES -- Harry Potter transformed Universal’s Islands of Adventure theme park in Florida when he arrived in 2010. Now Universal hopes the boy wizard can shower its aging adjacent park with some of the same magic.

headline: Touching Up the C.I.A.
text: The Central Intelligence Agency announced on Tuesday that it had replaced the acting head of the clandestine service. The day before, Gawker published a memo from the C.I.A. pinpointing all the ways it had managed to get Mark Boal to change scenes in his screenplay for “Zero Dark Thirty” that did not “promote an appropriate portrayal” of the Agency — in other words, things that made it look worse than it did in the final version of the movie, which depicts the hunt for Osama bin Laden.

headline: A ‘New Louvre’ North of Paris
text: On a Friday evening this winter, 250 paired-off revelers — from couples young and old to mothers with small children — were dressed in varying interpretations of Renaissance-style costume: many were in masks, some wore full-skirted, floor-skimming gowns. They filled a stripped-down auditorium and twirled energetically to instructions belted out in French by the renowned Parisian choreographer Christine Corday.

headline: Eating Locally on the Road
text: Sarah Elton is a regular at the farmers’ market near her home in Toronto. She religiously checks labels and menus to make sure her food hasn’t traveled far before arriving on her plate. Yet, while traveling to organic farms in India, China and even food-obsessed France to research her new book, “Consumed: Food for a Finite Planet,” she found that her locavore ways were not always sustainable.

headline: House Holds Hearing on Benghazi Attack
text: Eight months after four Americans died in a terrorist attack on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, a House committee held another hearing on Wednesday to examine whether the Obama administration mishandled the tragic events. What follows is an update on what is known about the Benghazi episode and why it has become such a political flash point:

headline: The Joy of Toys
text: New picture books about children and their toys, including an age-old problem: Two children, one ball.

headline: Properties for $870,000
text: A 1905 cottage in Louisiana, a Cape in Vermont and mountain views in Montana.

headline: What You Get for ... $870,000
text: BOZEMAN, MONT.

headline: Police Quell Protest in Beijing Over Woman’s Death
text: BEIJING — Hundreds of police officers in riot gear were deployed into the streets surrounding a shopping mall in southern Beijing on Wednesday to contain a large protest that was ignited by the death of a 22-year-old woman rumored to have been raped by security guards.

headline: A Nearly Perfect Night
text: Who had the better New York night?

headline: Israeli Police Question Muslim Cleric After Scuffle
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli police on Wednesday detained the Palestinians’ top Muslim cleric for questioning about disturbances a day earlier at a fiercely contested holy site in Jerusalem known to Jews as Temple Mount and to Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘The Great Gatsby’
text: Baz Luhrmann, the director of “The Great Gatsby,” narrates a scene from his film featuring Leonardo DiCaprio and Tobey Maguire.

headline: The Joy of Toys
text: PEANUT AND FIFI HAVE A BALLBy Randall de Sève.Illustrated by Paul Schmid.40 pp. Dial. $15.99.  (Picture book; ages 3 to 5)

headline: Some Retailers Say More About Their Clothing’s Origins
text: The revolution that has swept the food industry is expanding to retail: origins matter.

headline: An Ethnic Map
text: David Brooks: On Tuesday I was on a panel with Representative Xavier Becerra, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus, and Janet Murguía, who is the head of the National Council of La Raza.

headline: Teamwork for a Channel
text: DoubleTree by Hilton has teamed up with Google to create a YouTube channel called DTour, which allows travelers to post their photos and videos from other social-networking sites like Facebook, GooglePlus and Instagram. The site’s map displays locations of DoubleTree hotels, with the ability to book rooms and allows users to link photos, videos and written recommendations to those destinations.

headline: As Candidates Vow to Hire Educator as Chancellor, Quinn Keeps Options Open
text: Several candidates for mayor on Tuesday pledged to hire an educator as the next schools chancellor, breaking with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who three times tapped leaders from business and government for the post.

headline: Metal Band’s Frontman Charged With Attempting to Hire Hit Man
text: The frontman for the Christian metal band As I Lay Dying was arrested on Tuesday in Oceanside, Calif., and charged with attempting to hire a hit man to kill his estranged wife, the San Diego County Sheriff’s Department said.

headline: The Fire in the Rear
text: One of the Civil War’s most unusual surrenders took place on May 25, 1863. Accompanied by two Union officers, a former Ohio congressman named Clement L. Vallandigham approached a Confederate soldier on picket duty outside Murfreesboro, Tenn., and recited a short speech: “I am a citizen of Ohio, and of the United States. I am here within your lines by force and against my will. I therefore surrender myself to you as a prisoner of war.”

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘The Great Gatsby’
text: In this video, the director Baz Lurhmann narrates a scene from “The Great Gatsby,” featuring a conversation between Jay Gatsby (Leonardo DiCaprio) and Nick Carraway (Tobey Maguire). Mr. Lurhmann discusses the location of the shoot (an area of Sydney, Australia, made up to look like Long Island) and how a rainstorm almost prevented the scene from happening.

headline: Go Daddy Lures an Executive From K.K.R.
text: When Scott Wagner stepped up as the Go Daddy Group’s interim chief executive last summer, he viewed the move as temporary. He already had a day job, as a senior executive at an arm of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Trouble in the Hive: Researching the Decimation of Honeybee Colonies
text: Overview | What is colony collapse disorder, and why is it a growing concern to farmers and beekeepers? In this lesson, students learn about the ongoing decimation of honeybee colonies across the country, discuss its possible causes and potential solutions, and participate in a citizen science project to census honeybees in their neighborhoods.Materials | Computers with Internet connections, a variety of fruits

headline: In Immigration Bill, Deportees See Hope for Second Chance in U.S.
text: TIJUANA, Mexico — Erik García arrived at the metal gate of a migrant shelter here, deported from Los Angeles just hours earlier. After 23 years in the United States illegally, he suddenly found himself separated from the country where he had moved as a boy, and from his two teenage daughters, both American citizens.

headline: The Man With the Golden Ear
text: The 75-year-old businessman Chris Blackwell has made a fortune betting on the charms of his beloved Jamaica. In 1959, Blackwell started Island Records, which brought reggae and Bob Marley to a worldwide audience. (He also signed U2, Cat Stevens, Grace Jones, Nick Drake and Roxy Music.) When Blackwell sold Island 30 years later, he turned his attention to hotels: both in Miami’s South Beach, which he helped put on the map when he transformed blighted Art Deco properties into luxury destinations; and, more enduringly, at home, where his current holdings include GoldenEye, the former home of the James Bond author Ian Fleming (a longtime lover of Blackwell’s mother, Blanche), which attracts the likes of Kate Moss and Naomi Campbell. His latest venture? Jamaican rum, naturally.

headline: Opening Up Networking’s Black Box
text: The Open Compute Project, a Facebook-led effort to remake the computer servers and data storage of the biggest computing centers, is broadening its aims to include networking as well.

headline: A Timeline of Events in Benghazi
text: The defense actions carried out on Sept. 11-12, 2012, as the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, was under attack.

headline: Ex-Lawyer in State Department Criticizes Drone Secrecy
text: WASHINGTON — A former legal adviser to the State Department has sharply criticized the secrecy surrounding the Obama administration’s use of drones for the targeted killing of terrorism suspects, saying it is unnecessary and has backfired.

headline: Mayoral Hopefuls Divided on How to Punish Prostitutes’ Patrons
text: Yes, there were the usual questions focusing on term limits, pensions, education and temperament. But after dozens of forums over the last few months for mayoral candidates, Tuesday night’s back-to-back debates earned the distinction of coming up with an apparent original: What would you do to punish men who patronize prostitutes?

headline: Opponents Rally Against New York Public Library Plan
text: More than 100 people gathered in front of the New York Public Library’s Fifth Avenue flagship building on Wednesday afternoon to register opposition to the library’s renovation plan.

headline: New Diplomatic Push to End Civil War in Syria
text: ROME — As new reports of violence flowed from Syria, Secretary of State John Kerry telephoned leaders in Europe and the Middle East on Wednesday to lay the groundwork for a conference between rebels and the Syrian government, sponsored by the United States and Russia, that he hoped would begin within a month.

headline:
For Officials on
Tape, Legislator’s
Invitation Was Ruse
text: ALBANY — Over three months last year, Shirley L. Huntley, a longtime schools advocate then serving in the State Legislature, invited several of her fellow Senate Democrats, as well as a Democratic New York City councilman, to visit with her at her tomato-red Cape Cod-style house on a residential street in Jamaica, Queens.

headline: Critic of Immigration Proposal Cited Lower I.Q. of Immigrants in Dissertation
text: A co-author of a new Heritage Foundation study highly critical of the Senate’s bipartisan immigration proposal also wrote a doctoral dissertation in which he argued that immigrants generally had an I.Q. that was “substantially lower than that of the white native population.”

headline: Military Courts Are Called Outdated on Sex Crimes
text: WASHINGTON — An aviation commander for the Navy was raped by a co-worker, but there was no prosecution and the female accuser was denied re-enlistment. A noncommissioned officer was assaulted by a captain, who was found guilty but then granted clemency without explanation.

headline: Twitter Adds Tweets You Can Hear
text: Now you can hear the Twittering.

headline: What Do Mothers Want?
text: LET HOLDEN CAULFIELD have his naked-bosomed “squaw,” Noah Baumbach his squid and whale. For me, the central attraction of the American Museum of Natural History has always been the hall of gems and minerals. Darkened, plush-carpeted — there is no greater serenity than staring into one of its giant amethyst geodes, split open like a mangosteen.

headline: French Open Will Bar Tomic’s Father
text: John Tomic, the father and coach of Australian tennis star Bernard Tomic, will not be granted accreditation to this year’s French Open, according to the tournament director Gilbert Ysern.

headline: Letter Disclosing Those Recorded by Shirley L. Huntley
text: Read the full letter listing those officials recorded by Shirley L. Huntley.

headline: He Made Her Who She Is
text: First there’s the enormous chest, which seems to enter the room a few seconds before the rest of her. Then there’s the hand that curls into a claw as her anger rises. And finally the voice. A pinched staccato that carries menace and a barely contained hysteria.

headline: The Foreign Bribery Law Comes to Wall Street
text: It was almost inevitable that the government’s crackdown on bribery would hit a Wall Street firm.

headline: Rangers’ Lundqvist Is Vezina Finalist Again
text: When Henrik Lundqvist talks about his craft as a goaltender, it is almost as if he is giving a seminar about how to succeed at any endeavor requiring work, devotion and concentration.

headline: Older Workers Say Age Bias Is Common
text: About two-thirds of older workers say they have seen or experienced age discrimination in the workplace, and most of them say it’s common, a new survey from AARP finds.

headline: The Politician as Telemarketer
text: Federal elected officials spend only a fraction of their time engaged in what might loosely be called the business of governing — even when they belong to the party that believes in government. Oh, sure, they write the occasional bill, and talk with their constituents, and go out to dinner with lobbyists, and yell at other politicians on Sunday talk shows. Mostly, though, they beg for cash.

headline: Video: Intersection, Dumbo’s Style Mash-Up
text: In the latest Intersection video, we headed to Dumbo, Brooklyn, and met people who work in the area and draw style inspiration from music festivals and furniture design. Martin Medina, a visual designer, draws fashion inspiration from his youth in the Lower East Side and bright colors.

headline: A Three-Bedroom Among Palms and Rice Paddies

headline: House Hunting in ... Bali

headline: Apple’s Peter Oppenheimer Is Highest Paid Finance Chief
text: Being a tax ninja pays off at Apple. Its chief financial officer, Peter Oppenheimer, who has helped the company sidestep billions of dollars in taxes, was the highest paid chief financial officer of 2012, according to data compiled by Bloomberg News.

headline: German Orchestra to Bring ‘Symphony for Palestine’ to West Bank
text: A few years in the making, a Middle East tour of a work called “Symphony for Palestine” will come to Ramallah, East Jerusalem and Jenin from May 30 through June 2, a German orchestra announced this week.

headline: Stock Markets Rise, but Half of Americans Don’t Benefit
text: The stock market has been doing well, reaching new nominal highs in recent weeks. Economists have been arguing that such equity gains make people feel richer, which might encourage consumers to pick up their spending despite their stagnant wages and recent tax increases.

headline: Powe Is Out for Rangers as Clowe Nears Return
text: It seemed likely that Ryane Clowe would take Darroll Powe’s place in the Rangers’ lineup for Game 4 against the Washington Capitals on Wednesday night. Powe left Game 3 with an undisclosed injury, though he appeared to sustain a concussion from a hit by Washington’s Joel Ward. Clowe left a game April 25 with what was also believed to be a concussion, but he has been practicing recently.

headline: Enron’s Skilling Strikes Deal for Shorter Sentence

headline: Lhota Facing Anger After He Likens Port Authority Police to ‘Mall Cops’
text: It was a simple question about improving airport security, the kind that candidates for mayor field up to three times a day at campaign forums across New York City.

headline: Food Stamp Program Faces Deeper Cuts Under House Farm Bill
text: A new farm bill being crafted by the House Agriculture Committee includes deeper cuts to the food stamp program than those included in last year’s version of the bill, setting up a potential fight with House and Senate Democrats who oppose additional cuts to the program.

headline: Middle Ages Men
text: Portraits of some of the men who will represent the United States this week at the Battle of Nations in France, a full-contact armored fighting event.

headline: Knicks’ Defense: Same Plan, Better Execution
text: The Knicks’ offense may rise and fall with their 3-point shooting, but their attack is a straightforward mix of efficient pick-and-rolls and wing isolations for Carmelo Anthony. As the team proved in the regular season, its personnel and style are suited for high scoring. With Anthony at power forward and relatively unathletic players on the perimeter, however, defending requires a bit of smoke and mirrors.

headline: Diplomat Says Questions Over Benghazi Led to Demotion
text: WASHINGTON — A veteran diplomat gave a riveting minute-by-minute account on Wednesday of the lethal terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya, last Sept. 11 and described its contentious aftermath at a charged Congressional hearing that reflected the weighty political stakes perceived by both parties.

headline: Riding a Fast Sled to the Tonys
text: Benj Pasek and Justin Paul were brought in to write the music and lyrics for “A Christmas Story” after the original composer was replaced. This opportunity resulted a few years later in unexpected Tony Award nominations for the Broadway hit and for the duo, who have been touted as theater wonder boys since graduating from the University of Michigan in 2007. They’ve seen their song cycle “Edges” performed around the world, had songs featured on NBC’s “Smash” and watched another of their musicals, “Dogfight,” get a high-gloss production at Second Stage Theater.

headline: Depression May Raise Risk of Gut Infection
text: Two studies have found that depression and the use of certain antidepressants are both associated with increased risk for Clostridium difficile infection, an increasingly common cause of diarrhea that in the worst cases can be fatal.

headline: Legal Memo Advised Postal Service Against Ending Saturday Delivery
text: An outside law firm hired by the Postal Service warned its nine-member board that they risked being removed from office if they proceeded with plans to end mail delivery on Saturdays, according to a memo the firm prepared for the agency’s legal department.

headline: The Holy Grail of Battle Re-enactments
text: ATLANTA — Inside Craig Ivey’s travel bag are objects reminiscent of the Middle Ages.

headline: The Price of Fast Fashion
text: Even before the tragedy in Bangladesh, pressure was growing on retailers to balance Americans’ appetite for cheap clothes with the human costs of making them, the author Elizabeth Cline says.

headline: Syria, and Pro-Government Hackers, Are Back on the Internet
text: Syrian Internet and cellphone access resumed Wednesday morning after an Internet failure pulled the company offline Tuesday.

headline: Singh Sues PGA Over Handling of Doping Case
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Vijay Singh filed a lawsuit against the PGA Tour on Wednesday — a day before the start of the tour’s flagship event, the Players Championship — saying the tour’s mishandling of his doping case had caused him severe emotional distress.

headline: Hypertension in Youths Is Tied to School Success
text: High blood pressure in adolescents may have a bright side. A new study suggests that hypertensive teenagers have higher academic achievement and fewer emotional and behavioral problems than peers with normal blood pressure.

text: “Most people think I go shopping all day long,” Cecilia Dean said.

headline: One Wet Dog
text: Workers installing Paul McCarthy’s “Balloon Dog” (2013) on the grounds of the Frieze Art Fair, which opens Friday on Randalls Island.

headline: New Zoo Rarity: Hogs With Uncloven Hooves
text: What’s new at the Queens Zoo these days is three female mulefoot hogs.

headline: How Normal Are Cruise Mishaps?
text: Its name is Triumph, yet this year has been anything but that for the 14-year-old ship owned by Carnival Corporation, the world’s largest cruise company.

headline: Stephen Hawking Joins Boycott Against Israel
text: JERUSALEM — Stephen W. Hawking, the University of Cambridge physicist and cosmologist, has pulled out of a high-profile conference to be held here in June in order to support an academic boycott of Israel, conference organizers and the university said on Wednesday.

headline: Next W.T.O. Head Wants a New Look at Body’s Role
text: PARIS — Roberto Carvalho de Azevêdo, the next head of the World Trade Organization, said on Wednesday that the institution needed to adapt as the United States and other nations turn away from the multilateral forum to regional trade agreements.

headline: China’s Economy Unexpectedly Stumbles Again on Weak Export Results
text: HONG KONG — Brightly hued men’s underwear in a rainbow of colors is no longer selling well in Europe for the Zhongtian Garments Company in Xiamen, China. Exports are down 30 percent in the last year.

headline: Harvey Is Hard to Hit; Will No-Hitters Follow?
text: Pitching for a franchise that has had a complicated relationship with no-hitters, the Mets’ Matt Harvey has seemingly become a threat to throw one every time he pitches. It is as if the franchise that traded away Nolan Ryan before his record run of seven no-hitters is getting a second chance to have a player regularly flirt with the accomplishment that eluded it for 8,019 games before Johan Santana threw the team’s first no-hitter last season.

headline: The Buzz
