headline: Amalfi’s Legacy of Lemons
text: Along Italy's Amalfi Coast, one family struggles to carry on its heritage of lemon cultivation.

headline: Bowie Video Is Restored to YouTube
text: Even in 2013 David Bowie can shock people. The singer’s latest video, featuring women in stripper costumes cavorting in a bar with priests, was briefly pulled from YouTube on Wednesday, then returned with an adults-only label, according to Reuters and Mr. Bowie’s publicist.

headline: The iPhone: Smart, but Sometimes Rude
text: The Apple iPhone sure is smart. You can talk to it through its fancy Siri interface, or take and organize gorgeous photos based on location and time. But when you’re making a phone call, the iPhone isn’t that bright, and can be incredibly rude.

headline: How We Designed the Monk Seal Murder Cover
text: Evoking the mysterious killings, without seeming too … bloody.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Inside Google Glass, and a Cyberattack Report
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Seeing Mississippi Sight Unseen
text: From its opening pages, “Southern Cross the Dog” has all the markers of a novel written in the finest Southern gothic tradition. The Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 sweeps in, taking a few unlucky characters with it. There are references aplenty to race, poverty, the blues, voodoo and an ill-fated brothel.

headline: This Business Is a Lemon, and a Family Wants to Keep It That Way
text: AMALFI, Italy — On a recent spring morning, Luigi Aceto, a hale 78, climbed a ladder in a terraced lemon grove that stretched up the hillside in one of Italy’s most picturesque towns and expertly began snipping lemons into a wicker basket. The sun was shining. The lemons were ripe and as big as fists. The scent of blossoms was intoxicating.

headline: Mark Sanford and the Future of Marriage
text: While watching Mark Sanford win election to the House of Representatives last night, I thought back to a piece Megan McArdle wrote during the Supreme Court’s gay marriage deliberations earlier this year, in which she made the case that the battle over same-sex unions would ultimately strengthen “the forces of staid, bourgeois sexual morality,” and tip American society in a kind of “neo-Victorian” direction. Once gay couples are assimilated into the institution of marriage, she argued, it could become easier for upper-middle class liberals to preach what they already tend to practice, and promote stronger marital norms:

headline: Labor Dispute Effectively Ends Minnesota Orchestra’s Season
text: The Minnesota Orchestra, where musicians have been locked out in a labor dispute since October, announced on Wednesday that it had canceled its concerts through June 2 – effectively, the rest of its season. At the same time, Michael Henson, the orchestra’s president and chief executive, announced a series of concerts for late July and early August, with repertory drawn from this season’s unperformed programs, saying in a statement that the concerts were added because “we are not willing to give up on our entire season.”

headline: On Piano, a Point of View
text: Admirers of the Italian pianist Maurizio Pollini are set in their lionization of this singular artist; his detractors, likewise, are steadfast. Were you not an aficionado of his methods before the recital he gave at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, nothing that he played during the all-Beethoven program was likely to change your mind. Equally, were you a devotee, nothing Mr. Pollini did on Sunday changed that condition.

headline: When a Prince Comes to Town
text: Greenwich, Conn., is filled with masters of the universe. But none of them can trump a prince.

headline: China Dips a Toe Into Middle East Peace
text: BEIJING — China took a modest step into Middle East diplomacy this week, hosting back-to-back visits from Mahmoud Abbas, the leader of the Palestinian Authority, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

headline: This Is Food Shopping
text: http://vimeo.com/theglossary/thisiswater

headline: T’s Newest Columnists Dine in Blue and White
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Scouting Report
text: Mother’s Day

headline: Eisman Is Gloomy on Canadian Housing
text: The hedge fund manager Steven Eisman rose to prominence in the financial crisis after betting against mortgages in the United States. On Wednesday, he turned his focus to Canada.

headline: Red Bulls’ Roxburgh on Ferguson
text: In the Great Hall of the world’s soccer minds, there is undoubtedly a special wing for the practitioners from Scotland.

headline: Keeping His Fans Happy With a Half-Century of Classicism and Virtuosity
text: The popularity of the Russian pianist Evgeny Kissin, who has impressed listeners with his immense gifts since his days as a child prodigy, remains as strong as ever, evident from the capacity audience at his recital on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall. The stage was crowded with extra seating to accommodate listeners, as it occasionally is for a handful of celebrity artists.

headline: For First Time on Record, Black Voting Rate Outpaced Rate for Whites in 2012
text: WASHINGTON — The turnout rate of black voters surpassed the rate for whites for the first time on record in 2012, as more black voters went to the polls than in 2008 and fewer whites did, according to a Census Bureau report released Wednesday.

headline: Outsmarting Smartphone Thieves
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In the month since two men violently shoved him to the ground and stole his iPhone 5, Dalton Huckaby has almost completely stopped calling his mother. It usually takes him a full day to text his friends back. Nothing personal, but Mr. Huckaby is just too frightened to take his replacement iPhone out in public.

headline: The Dwindling Deficit
text: Bad news for Dr. Evil fans: the days of a ONE TRILLION DOLLAR deficit are over. In fact, the deficit is falling fast.

headline: A Solitary Soul Whose Pained Voice Heads Into Strange Realms
text: James Blake could easily have been a ballad singer. He showed how with his last encore on Tuesday night at Terminal 5, alone on piano, singing and playing “A Case of You” by Joni Mitchell in his sustained and tremulous voice, rapt in melancholy and need. But Mr. Blake has other ambitions.

headline: Prospect of Iran’s Election Stirs Little Hope This Time Around
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s state television broadcast a live program on Tuesday in which passers-by were placed in a chair and asked what they would do if they were president.

headline: On Stubborn Bulls, Robinson Is a Standout
text: Cool. Calm. Collected.

headline: The Shop That Punk Built
text: To anyone passing by Trash and Vaudeville, the rock-and-roll emporium on St. Marks Place, the sinewy peacock with a bleached shag on the outside steps is a familiar sight.

headline: House Hearing Puts Benghazi in Spotlight
text: In a show of partisan politics, a House committee held a hearing on the Sept. 11, 2012, terrorist attack on the American compound in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans.

headline: The Season for a Program to Be the Star
text: A simple idea lies behind Spring for Music, the six-day festival at Carnegie Hall that began on Monday with the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and continued on Tuesday with the Albany Symphony Orchestra. Ensembles from North America are chosen to participate based not on their institutional prestige but for the originality of their proposed programs.

headline: Icon’s Re-imagination of a ’65 Dodge Pickup
text: Restoring classic cars and trucks with modern mechanical guts is nothing new. But trying to get inside the heads of the people who designed those vehicles in order to re-create them without the interference of corporate bean counters is quite something else. That’s where Jonathan Ward’s lively imagination comes into play. He takes a vehicle that has always possessed a charismatic aesthetic and focuses on its details, doing his best to make each one perfect.

headline: Teenager Charged With Homicide by Assault in Referee’s Death
text: The 17-year-old Utah soccer player accused of punching a referee who later died was charged Wednesday with homicide by assault, a charge that could carry a penalty of up to five years in prison if he is convicted.

headline: A Quantum Computer Aces Its Test
text: The long-sought quantum computer, a machine potentially far ahead of today’s best supercomputers, is almost as hard to define as it is to build. For at least a few particular uses, however, the unusual computer made by D-Wave Systems now seems to be very fast indeed.

headline: From Crashes to Exorcism, His Own Cut
text: When William Friedkin was doing research for his controversial film “Cruising,” he showed up on jockstrap night at the Mine Shaft, the famed gay bar in Manhattan, dressed for the occasion. When he shot the car chase in “The French Connection,” he took few precautions for the safety of drivers and bystanders. And when he prepped for “Rampage,” about a bizarre serial killer, he watched a Rorschach test being given to a man convicted of killing his mother. The killer saw angels and butterflies; Mr. Friedkin saw monsters.

headline: Verizon Wireless Chief Sees Demand for New BlackBerry Phones
text: BlackBerry’s phones have been off to a weak start in Canada, the home turf of the struggling handset maker. But the new BlackBerrys are getting a warm welcome from Verizon Wireless, the biggest American carrier.

headline: ‘Salinger’ the Documentary, Craftily Promoted With a ‘Psst’
text: LOS ANGELES — J. D. Salinger was good at keeping secrets.

headline: Thompson Picks Up Backing of a Fiscal Repairman
text: In recent weeks, William C. Thompson Jr. has been increasingly unfurling mayoral endorsements from African-American and Hispanic leaders, hoping to solidify his base.

headline: A Shifting Electorate
text: The overall turnout rate fell by nearly two percentage points from the 2008 to 2012 election, driven in part by a large drop in the youth vote. Black voters turned out at a higher rate than any other group in 2012, passing whites for the first time on record.

headline: Chesney Tops Album Chart
text: Kenny Chesney has his seventh No. 1 album on the Billboard 200 chart as “Life on a Rock” sold 153,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Garth Brooks is the only country act with more No. 1 songs on the chart, with eight. Last week’s No. 1, Michael Bublé’s “To Be Loved,” slipped to No. 2 in its second week, with 96,000 in sales. Justin Timberlake’s “20/20 Experience” holds at No. 3 with 68,000. Fantasia’s “Side Effects of You” was No. 4 in its second week, with 36,000, while “The Heist,” from Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, rose from No. 11 to No. 5, with 35,000.

headline: Iron Man’s Iron Men
text: A look at the visual effects process for creating Tony Stark’s suits in “Iron Man 3.”

headline: Manic Duets, Sometimes in a Mist
text: A man and a woman stand in the mist. Sheepish at first, they pull each other into embraces, the woman wrapping her legs around the man or straddling him. As the precipitation increases, the loose, long hair of both partners gradually dampens. Their clothing turns transparent. Except perhaps for when they stick out their tongues to lap the moisture, the scene might be a racy commercial for shampoo. But it is the end of “Horizons,” by the Greek choreographer Andonis Foniadakis.

headline: It’s Lunchtime: Let’s Dance
text: When lunchtime comes around, Laurie Batista often grabs a salad near the Flatiron ad agency where she works as an executive assistant and eats it at her desk.

headline: A Father’s Passage, Set to New Movements
text: In February 2011 the choreographer and dancer Jonah Bokaer was to perform a duet, “Replica,” in Carthage, Tunisia. The performance, significantly, would have been Mr. Bokaer’s first visit to his father’s native land.

headline: The Public May Now Comment
text: At a little after 7 on a recent evening, the mayor of Bismarck, N.D., banged a gavel to call the city’s board of commissioners to order. They were a motley group — mostly young, clad in jeans and sneakers or boots — and seemed ill at ease. They glanced cluelessly at the agendas before them, checked their name plates as though reminding themselves of their names, and waited for an indication of what to do.

headline: For Ackman, a Day Without Drama
text: For a hedge fund manager who has had his share of drama in recent months, William A. Ackman was notably subdued in a presentation on Wednesday.

headline: Rally Turns Deadly in Southern Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan – A demonstration that officials said had begun as a peaceful pro-government rally in southern Afghanistan on Wednesday instead turned into a bloody melee, with as many as 10 people killed and 14 wounded as the police fired on demonstrators.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Bangladesh, Italy, Pakistan and Boston.

headline: Sales at Jonathan Adler, Pollack and Others
text: Jonathan Adler’s warehouse sale, through Sunday, will include furniture, lighting, pottery and home décor at up to 70 percent off (the Whitaker sofa, regularly $2,800, is $1,400; the Charade Wave vase, regularly $250, is $75); 513 Irving Avenue (Eldert Street), Brooklyn, jonathanadler.com.

headline: The Allure of Simplicity in Leather and Wood
text: Robin Standefer and Stephen Alesch, of the design firm Roman and Williams, have created interiors for such era-defining buildings as the Ace and Standard hotels in New York. But their new furniture collection doesn’t stray from tradition. The couple have worked with the SoHo design store Matter in creating a chair, a side table, a coffee table and a series of lights, all in alluring woods like walnut, teak and reclaimed oak. Ms. Standefer described the style as American vernacular. “We’re embracing simple structures,” Mr. Alesch added. This leaves room for laserlike attention to details. The chair, shown, with its custom brass hardware and fine leather ($6,500), makes that point. Information: (212) 343-2600 or mattermatters.com.

headline: A Second Roche Bobois for New York
text: Forty years ago, Roche Bobois, the French producer of lush modern furniture, opened its first American showroom on Madison Avenue and 35th Street in New York. Gilles Bonan, the company’s chief executive, said that, after the French, Americans are the most avid Roche Bobois customers, drawn by the furniture’s comfort, quality and “what I call the French flair.”

headline: Boxes Full of Secrets
text: These days, the jewelry, mirrors and small boxes designed by the French artist Line Vautrin (1913-1997) are much in demand among collectors, commanding thousands. But not so long ago Ms. Vautrin was passé. “Like everything in fashion,” said Benoist Drut, an owner of the New York gallery Maison Gerard, “the trend had changed.”

headline: She Won’t Put Away Her Toys
text: One day last summer, Leah Dumigan noticed an open call on Twitter urging New York designers to submit their American-made products. The Museum of Modern Art Design Store, which in its international Destination: Design series has presented goods from countries including Finland, Mexico and Japan, was finally getting around, in its 11th iteration, to featuring hometown talent. Ms. Dumigan, a graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology’s toy design program, and a new mother, sent in nearly every piece in her line, then added a couple of ideas still percolating but not produced.

headline: Life Among the Dolls
text: Four generations of the author’s family contributed to a collection of more than 700 dolls.

headline: Who’s More Vulgar? The Performer or the Crowd?
text: About halfway through Kitty’s opening set at Irving Plaza on Tuesday night, a pair of young women walked into the room, looked onstage and squealed, turning to each other and talking animatedly about how happy they were to see her.

headline: The 700-Doll Question
text: Ten years ago, when my mother was in the throes of dementia, I left New York, bought a home in North Carolina near my brother, and moved her in with me.

headline: Face-off Circle Is Focal Point of Leafs-Bruins Series
text: TORONTO — As the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Boston Bruins prepare for Wednesday’s Game 4, the gamesmanship between the two veteran coaches is in full swing.

headline: Google’s Aggregator Gives Way to an Heir
text: Well, if we didn’t get it before, we get it now: Google giveth, and Google taketh away.

headline: Best Dressed
text: A selection of rooms from the Kips Bay Decorator Show House.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. There’s a large window near my shower that’s covered by a temporary blind. I’d like to fix it up before showing my home to buyers. What’s the best treatment for such an awkwardly placed window?

headline: House of Your (Vivid) Dreams
text: Desire is a reliably unreliable guide to happiness, as Alain de Botton notes in “The Architecture of Happiness,” the fifth or sixth book from the prolific professional intellectual who has tackled everything from status anxiety to sex. In it, the author observes that bad buildings are like bad relationships, “an example expressed through materials of the same tendency which in other domains will lead us to marry the wrong people, choose inappropriate jobs and book unsuccessful holidays: the tendency not to understand who we are and what will satisfy us.”

headline: Political Handouts Thrive in Pakistan
text: MULTAN, Pakistan — In Multan, a self-described city of saints in central Pakistan, one holy politician is banking on more than prayers to ensure victory in Saturday’s national elections.

headline: Why Hit a Flower When It’s Down?
text: A selection of comments from readers of the Home section, drawn from letters and postings at nytimes.com, about Anne Raver’s article on a mysterious strain of downy mold killing one of the home gardener’s favorite annual flowers, Impatiens walleriana.

headline: Microsoft Names First Female Finance Chief
text: Microsoft named Amy Hood, an executive at the company, as its chief financial officer, the first woman to hold the top finance job at Microsoft.

headline: 2013 Tony Awards: ‘I Told You So’
text: The New York Times asked selected Tony Award nominees who they would like to tell, “I told you I’d get a nomination one day.”

headline: Shopping for Home Spa Accessories
text: Jamie Ahn, the owner of Acqua Beauty Bar and the Townhouse Spa, goes shopping for home spa accessories.

headline: Home Spa Accessories
text: Living in a city like New York can be stressful, and retreating to a spa isn’t always an option. Unless it’s a home spa.

headline: Every Fixture Has a Story
text: Inside Gere Kavanaugh’s Los Angeles home.

headline: If It Has a Shape ...
text: LOS ANGELES — Someone once asked Gere Kavanaugh what she liked to design best, and with a typical mix of humor and bluntness, she answered, “Anything I can get my hands on.”

headline: The Legendary Gaetano Pesce on Work and Life
text: At the cavernous entrance to Pier 57 in Chelsea, an ancient loading dock has become a makeshift stage for the work of Gaetano Pesce, the 74-year-old Italian design legend who moved to New York 32 years ago because the city “was the capital of the 20th century.” He arrived with a splash, one of a who’s who of modern Italian designers included in MoMA’s groundbreaking 1972 show “Italy: The New Domestic Landscape.” But Pesce hasn’t had a comprehensive solo show in his adopted hometown since a 1999 exhibit tucked away at Columbia University’s School of Architecture. “He’s a legend and a New Yorker, so that tragedy needed to be corrected,” said Steven Learner, the creative director of the new Collective.1 Design Fair, where Pesce’s retrospective opened today.

headline: On View | The Designs of Gaetano Pesce
text: The 74-year-old Italian design legend discusses his highly personal career retrospective at the inaugural Collective.1 Design Fair in New York.

headline: Now Showing | Saturdays Surf NYC
text: Danny DiMauro and Colin Tunstall talk surf, New York and the release of issue two of their hit magazine.

headline: A Defense Play by Jeremy Flint and Jonathan Cansino
text: Monday’s column, in which Bjorn Fallenius discarded his high diamond queen to deprive declarer of an entry to his hand, reminded me of the diagramed deal. It was played in 1970 during a match between England and the Netherlands.

headline: Raids Yield Stolen Gems and Arrests in Europe
text: PARIS — More than 200 Belgian police officers and authorities in two other countries on Wednesday swept up more than 30 people and recovered some of the $50 million in diamonds stolen in a carefully orchestrated robbery in Brussels in February, investigators said.

headline: A Soaking to Talk About
text: Ladies, gentlemen and children, fold your umbrellas for a moment and take a bow. You have just lived through the fifth-rainiest May day in the modern history of New York and the rainiest day since Tropical Storm Irene battered the city two summers ago, according to the weather historian Steve Fybish.

headline: Austria Is Pressured to Reveal More About Tax Evaders
text: BRUSSELS — Austria faced renewed pressure on Wednesday to reveal more about tax evaders after senior officials of the European Union called for automatic information sharing to apply more widely and rapidly within the bloc.

headline: Europe Inches Closer to Establishing a Banking Union
text: BERLIN — Europe inched closer Wednesday to establishing a European banking union for the Continent’s largest lenders after the German cabinet approved legislation that would grant to the European Central Bank oversight of such institutions.

headline: Turning a Smartphone Into a Workout Buddy
text: Summer is coming at last. Like me, you may be thinking that a few improvements to your fitness and physique might be in order before you hit the beach. It’s also possible that, like me, you find it hard to motivate yourself to exercise or to head to the gym, and you don’t like the idea of a personal trainer. Time for an app, in other words, and there are many out there to help us get in shape.

headline: Versace x Haas
text: A look at the home collection by the Haas Brothers for Versace.

headline: Faces in the Crowd, Printed in 3-D
text: Imagine someone collecting a strand of your hair from the subway floor. What would that person do with it? Frame you for a crime? Weave it into a wig?

headline: Cable Channels Lift News Corp.’s Profit
text: Fueled by the strength of its cable channels and retransmission fees at Fox Broadcasting, News Corporation reported a 4 percent increase in operating income, to $1.36 billion, in the three months that ended March 31.

headline: Jabra Revo Lets You Shape Your Sound
text: Jabra, best known for its Bluetooth phone accessories, is making its first foray into Bluetooth premium headphones with the $250 Revo Wireless.

headline: Vijay Singh v PGA Tour
text: Vijay Singh filed suit in New York’s state supreme court, charging the PGA Tour with “violating its duty of care and good faith” in suspending the golfer for his use of deer antler spray.

headline: Senate Panel Postpones Vote on Obama’s Labor Nominee
text: Senate Republicans on Wednesday forced Democrats to postpone a committee vote on the nomination of Thomas E. Perez to lead the Labor Department after the chamber’s top Republican raised doubts about Mr. Perez’s ethics.

headline: Brad Drewett, President of Men’s Tennis Tour, Dies at 54
text: Brad Drewett, a former professional tennis player who became president of the ATP last year and won a greater share of Grand Slam tournament revenue for players, died on Friday at his home in Sydney, Australia. He was 54.

headline: Tesla’s Disappearing Data
text: Tesla Motors regularly gave out a crucial number that gave the public a good idea of how much demand existed for its electric cars.

headline: Ferguson’s Tenure With Manchester United
text: Alex Ferguson, in his 26 years as manager, transformed United into one of the world’s most lucrative, and dominant, soccer clubs.

headline: Jeanne Cooper, ‘Young and the Restless’ Star, Dies at 84
text: Jeanne Cooper, the enduring actress on “The Young and the Restless” who had much in common with her character, the forthright Katherine Chancellor — apart from everyday occurrences in the soap opera universe like being stranded on a desert island with nothing but her jewelry, having a shopping center fall on her and inadvertently giving one of her grandchildren away — died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 84 and continued to appear on the show until her death.

headline: A Chance to Return
text: Senators have proposed an immigration bill that could give a legal second chance to tens of thousands of deportees.

headline: State Department Official on Demotion
text: Gregory Hicks, a State Department veteran, explained how raising questions about the Benghazi attack negatively affected his career.

headline: Court Upholds Berlusconi Tax Fraud Verdict
text: ROME — An appeals court in Milan upheld a conviction on Wednesday of former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi for tax fraud, sentencing him to four years in prison and imposing a five-year ban on holding public office.

headline: Einhorn Is Beaten to the Punch
text: Just days before David Einhorn was to present his latest investment idea, another hedge fund manager stole his thunder.

headline: Israel Moves to End Gender Segregation in Public Spaces
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s attorney general on Wednesday advised ministers across the government to immediately end gender segregation in public spaces, issuing guidelines that would change many aspects of daily life here — from buses to burials, health care to radio airwaves.

headline: Colorado Lawmakers Approve Driver’s Licenses for Illegal Immigrants
text: DENVER — In one of their final acts before wrapping up the Colorado legislative session on Wednesday, lawmakers approved a bill allowing immigrants who are in the country illegally to obtain driver’s licenses, making the state one of only a handful to have passed such a measure.

headline: A Day Later, Everyone Still Talks About Harvey
text: Matt Harvey’s starts these days always seem to overshadow whatever the Mets do. After Tuesday’s nine-inning, one-hit start, Harvey is now overshadowing the team on the days when he does not start. On Wednesday, Harvey was still the topic of conversation.

headline: Recent Winners Meet at the Podium
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Adam Scott exited the interview podium Wednesday morning to make way for Billy Horschel. As Scott stepped down and Horschel got ready to step up, they shook hands and exchanged congratulatory greetings. Each won his last start: Scott at the Masters, and Horschel at the Zurich Classic of New Orleans.

headline: Paper on Immigrant I.Q. Dogs Critic of Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — The revelation that a co-author of a Heritage Foundation study critical of the Senate’s bipartisan immigration proposal had recently argued that Hispanic immigrants are less intelligent than white Americans touched off a furor on Wednesday, undercutting the conservative foundation’s attempt to become a major force in the immigration debate.

headline: Census Report on 2012 Voter Turnout
text: The Census Bureau released a report on voter demographics and turnout rates in the 2012 election.

headline: Bryan Forbes, ‘Stepford Wives’ Director, Is Dead at 86
text: Bryan Forbes, an English film director best known for “The Stepford Wives,” the 1975 Hollywood thriller about women transformed into docile electronic incarnations of themselves, has died at his home in Surrey, England. He was 86.

headline: Hedge Fund Impresario Plays Host in Las Vegas
text: LAS VEGAS — Just outside the grand ballroom at the Bellagio hotel early Wednesday morning, Anthony Scaramucci, the backslapping host of the country’s largest hedge fund conference, spotted Gregory J. Fleming, president of Morgan Stanley Investment Management and one of Mr. Scaramucci’s most important business relationships.

headline: 60 Feet 6 Inches From Disaster
text: On Tuesday night, hours after a line drive in St. Petersburg, Fla., crashed off the head of Toronto Blue Jays pitcher J. A. Happ, Brandon McCarthy took the mound in Los Angeles and made his best start of the season for the Arizona Diamondbacks. McCarthy fractured his skull last September at Oakland, a victim of another line drive. He earned a two-year, $15 million contract before pitching his next game.

headline: An Effort to Thwart Sale of Papers to the Kochs
text: LOS ANGELES — An effort by two conservative billionaires to take over The Los Angeles Times and seven other newspapers is setting off a firestorm of opposition here. Public employee unions, the leaders of the State Legislature and liberal advocacy groups are moving to block the sale, denouncing it as a threat to public workers and Democratic Party issues.

headline: City Council Approves Bill Mandating Sick-Day Pay
text: The New York City Council, after years of impassioned debate, approved a bill on Wednesday that will require many businesses to offer paid time off to sick employees.

headline: Former Detainee’s Appeal Cites Long Wait for a Trial
text: A lawyer for the only terrorist detainee to be held at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and then tried in the civilian court system asked a federal appeals court on Wednesday to overturn his conviction, on the grounds that his long detention violated his right to a speedy trial.

headline: Preparing for Watershed Elections in Pakistan
text: In a country where politicians have competed with military generals for power, patronage is a prominent tool of civilian influence.

headline: Predator and Prey, a Delicate Dance
text: IN Lake Superior lies a remote island, Isle Royale National Park, 134,000 acres of boreal and hardwood forests where a life-or-death struggle between wolves and moose has been the subject of the world’s longest study of predators and their prey, now in its 55th year.

headline: Weekly Doses of Survival and Competition to Build Viewer Loyalty
text: THE National Geographic Channel will begin a branding campaign on Sunday to introduce its new programming strategy to viewers and advertisers.

headline: The Jamie Dimon Witch Hunt
text: THE Jamie Dimon lynch mob is growing. It calls for the separation of the role of chairman and chief executive officer, attacking him for holding both at JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Amid Navy Yard’s Ruins, Space for a Comeback in Manufacturing
text: Across the partition from the roboticist who was making coffee tables with magnetized cubes, an artist was boxing up woodcuts that, when held to the ear, sounded like a forest. Beyond him, just past the software designer on the treadmill, a muscular man in a T-shirt tinkered with his design for a motorcycle.

headline: Guess Who’s Back!
text: Right now you are undoubtedly asking yourself: What does the return to Congress of the disgraced ex-governor Mark Sanford mean to me?

headline: Banks Still Behaving Badly
text: Attorney General Eric Schneiderman of New York announced this week that he plans to sue Bank of America and Wells Fargo for failure to adhere to the terms of a $26 billion settlement that was supposed to provide relief to homeowners and end foreclosure abuses.

headline: In China, Power Is Arrogant
text: BEIJING

headline: Against High-Scoring Penguins, Isles’ Defense Leads the Way
text: Stifling the offensive arsenal of the Pittsburgh Penguins is a challenge under optimal conditions. Losing a defenseman midway through a tight playoff game multiplies the stress exponentially.

headline: Terms of Art
text: Many on the political right simply can’t get this diversity thing right — and I deeply doubt that they want to. Theirs is a bone-deep contempt for otherness, a congenital belief in the superiority-inferiority binary, a circle-the-wagons, zero-sum view of progress, prosperity and power.

headline: Mothers Convicted of Felonies May Get Chance to Stay Out of Prison
text: There are few experiences more unsettling for a child than watching a mother being taken away to prison for months or years. For years, women’s advocates have worked to establish alternatives for mothers convicted of crimes, saying the lives of their children become so upended they often end up in jail themselves.

headline: Allegations of Corruption Swirl Against Sarkozy Ally
text: PARIS — A small tempest of allegations has gathered in recent days over one of the closest allies of former President Nicolas Sarkozy, who is himself under investigation on charges he manipulated France’s richest woman for donations to his 2007 campaign, charges he denies.

headline: Silicon Valley Group’s Political Effort Causes Uproar
text: “Move fast and break things” has been the motto at Mark Zuckerberg’s Facebook, embodying the Silicon Valley ethos of unapologetically finding new ways to solve old problems. His latest foray into politics in Washington, however, might be characterized as “Move fast, play hardball and be prepared for blowback.”

headline: Diplomatic Stirrings on Syria
text: There are reasons to be skeptical about plans by Russia and the United States to hold an international conference on Syria — diplomats often propose meetings when they don’t have solutions. But, at a time when the civil war is worsening in every way, this initiative counts as a hopeful sign.

headline: An Industry Man for the F.C.C.
text: President Obama has picked a former telecommunications lobbyist and campaign fund-raiser to serve as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, raising serious questions about his 2007 pledge that corporate lobbyists would not finance his campaign or run his administration.

headline: The Cleveland Kidnapping, and Domination of Women
text: To the Editor:

headline: Effects of Sequestration
text: To the Editor:

headline: For the Elderly, Is Managed Care a Good Option?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Poets for the Cities
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Menagerie of the Child’s Imagination
Applying Lessons of the Past to Syria
text: To the Editor:

headline: Iran Hostages See Renewed Focus on Their 17-Year Bid for Compensation
text: WASHINGTON — When the hostages came home from Iran 32 years ago, after 444 days in captivity, they were heroes, and their release was unalloyed good news, a national triumph, observed with ticker-tape parades, speeches, awards and miles of yellow ribbons.

headline: Daily News Lays Off 12 Opinion Writers and Reporters
text: The Daily News, which has lost circulation, is laying off roughly a dozen well-known columnists and editorial writers.

headline: Boston Bomb Inquiry Looks Closely at Russia Trip
text: MAKHACHKALA, Russia — During a six-month visit to his Russian homeland last year, the parents of  the Boston bombing suspect Tamerlan Tsarnaev said, he spent his time reading novels and reconnecting with family, not venturing into the shadowy world of the region’s militants.

headline: Teacher’s Facebook Post Didn’t Warrant Firing, a Panel Upholds
text: The day after a sixth grader from Harlem drowned in the Atlantic Ocean on a class outing, a fifth-grade teacher in Brooklyn posted some rather impolitic comments about her own students on Facebook.

headline: On Facebook, Cleveland Kidnapping Suspect Hid Secret Under ‘LOL’
text: Ariel Castro, the kidnapping suspect in Cleveland, opened a Facebook account in February, adding 41 friends in the ensuing months. He “liked” a handful of other Facebook pages, including a tourism page for Virginia Beach, another for the musician Rey Ruiz and a page devoted to Chinese Cresteds, described by the American Kennel Club as a “fine-boned, elegant toy dog that craves human companionship.”

headline: Chelsea and Tottenham Leave Matters Unsettled
text: LONDON — On a day when from dawn until darkness everything in English soccer circled around a manager — Alex Ferguson — Wednesday night finally returned the ball to the players. Chelsea and Tottenham Hotspur, each battling for vital points toward Champions League qualification, went at it, and neither could win.

headline: Voices From Zaatari
text: Ruqaya Mohammad al-Ahmad, a refugee from Syria, brought her two children, Sindra, 7, and Tariq, 3, to the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan.

headline: In a Letter, State Lawmakers Demand Edits to a Sex-Scandal Report
text: ALBANY — Last August, the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said he welcomed an investigation into the Assembly’s handling of sexual harassment allegations brought by four women against one of its most prominent members, Vito J. Lopez.

headline: Senate Bill Would Halt Iran’s Access to an Estimated $100 Billion in Cash
text: Seeking to escalate pressure on Iran, a bipartisan group of senators introduced legislation on Wednesday that would deny the Iranian government access to its foreign exchange reserves parked in the banks of other countries, estimated to be worth as much as $100 billion, mostly in euros.

headline: Voices From Zaatari
text: Ahmad Ojan, 14, sells cups of hot tea for 15 cents apiece to people waiting at the registration camp and in the open-air market.

headline: Goal of the Year (So Far) in M.L.S.?

text: NEW DELHI — Another deadly accident struck Bangladesh’s export garment industry late on Wednesday night, when a fire swept through a factory, killing at least seven people, including top managers, according to news media reports.

text: MIAMI — The game was 21 seconds old when Dwyane Wade got wrapped up in the open court by Marco Belinelli, a Chicago Bulls guard who was merely trying to prevent a layup. Wade revealed his irritation by firing the basketball at Belinelli’s ankles.

headline: WTA Championships Find Home in Singapore
text: Once a Manhattan staple at Madison Square Garden, the WTA Championships have traveled the planet since then: from Munich to Los Angeles to Madrid to Doha, Qatar, to their current location in Istanbul.

headline: Three Held in Theft of $75,000 Lottery Ticket
text: He was a Guatemalan immigrant who spoke little English and had a fondness for scratch-off lottery tickets; they were two clerks at a Long Island gas station who saw an opportunity.

headline: In Switch, City Says It Can Speed Up Replacing School Lights Containing PCBs
text: On Sept. 6, drops of an oily substance leaked from a light fixture on Staten Island and landed on a fifth grader seated for her first day of school. Last Friday, a light in Public School 170 in Brooklyn oozed a similar liquid onto floor tiles, forcing kindergartners to leave the class.

headline: Was Alex Ferguson a Better Coach Than the N.B.A.’s Phil Jackson?
text: A graphic comparing Manchester United’s Alex Ferguson to American coaches and managers.

headline: Reports of Cheating at Barnard College Cause a Stir
text: The Barnard College course called Major English Texts II was known by students as an easy A, a low-stress literature survey taught by a popular instructor.

headline: Poll Shows Strong Lead for Democrat in Massachusetts Senate Race
text: In the special Senate election in Massachusetts, Representative Edward J. Markey, the Democratic nominee, is starting with a strong lead over Gabriel Gomez, the Republican, according to a new poll from Suffolk University.

headline: The Teardrop Shot, Up Over the Giants
text: A sequence revisiting how Chicago’s Nate Robinson, one of the best at teardrop shots, scored over the Nets’ Brook Lopez in a game at the end of the season.

headline: Undercover Video Targets Abortion Doctor
text: An anti-abortion group released an undercover video on Wednesday showing what it says were offensive and inhumane remarks about abortions by one of the country’s most prominent abortion doctors.

headline: Hefner Struggles in Harvey’s Shadow
text: Mets starter Jeremy Hefner has one of the most difficult tasks on his team: following Matt Harvey in the rotation. When Hefner takes the mound, often in front of much smaller crowds, the focus is still usually on the younger, more accomplished Harvey.

headline: Serious Investigations, or Partisan Ploys?
text: Have Congressional hearings become mere political devices to smear one party and attract voters?

headline: In Data We Trust
text: The announcement on May 1 by the Republican National Committee that it had awarded a multimillion-dollar contract for data management and collection services to Liberty Works, a firm run by Richard Boyce, an associate of Karl Rove, has driven a new wedge between establishment and conservative forces battling for control of the party.

headline: Officer Had Clean Record, Air Force Says
text: WASHINGTON — Air Force officials scouring the personnel records of the officer who ran its sexual assault prevention and response branch and was arrested last weekend on a sexual battery charge have found no sign of trouble, an official familiar with internal discussions said on Wednesday.

headline: With Hop and Flick, Little Guys Get Upper Hand
text: MIAMI — The slam dunk has captivated the basketball world for a generation with its combination of raw ferocity and balletic grace, but this year a different shot is sweeping the N.B.A. playoffs.

headline: Six Generations in the Lemon Business
text: A family’s bid to keep its small business going mirrors Italy’s debate about the value of local traditions.

headline: Her Personal Playwright
text: The first collaboration between Kristine Nielsen and Christopher Durang failed, dismally. In 1989 they appeared together in a famously reviled production of Alfred Jarry’s “Ubu Roi,” which the critic Mel Gussow described as “almost relentlessly unfunny” in The New York Times. Ms. Nielsen played the queen. Mr. Durang, in a rare outing as an actor, played Ubu’s conscience.

headline: Economists See Deficit Emphasis as Impeding Recovery
text: WASHINGTON — The nation’s unemployment rate would probably be nearly a point lower, roughly 6.5 percent, and economic growth almost two points higher this year if Washington had not cut spending and raised taxes as it has since 2011, according to private-sector and government economists.

headline: Fiscal Policies Take a Toll
text: Recent fiscal tightening through budget cuts and tax increases will slow economic growth for 2013 and prevent the unemployment rate from falling.

headline: 17 Officers Removed From Nuclear Watch
text: WASHINGTON — The Air Force removed 17 officers assigned to standing watch over nuclear-tipped Minuteman missiles after finding safety violations, potential violations in protecting codes and basic attitude problems.

headline: Russian and Asian Bidders Buoy Christie’s Art Auction
text: In a season where top Impressionist and modern art has been scarce, Christie’s managed to cobble together a modest evening sale on Wednesday night, with respectable prices for Soutine and Chagall. It was the second consecutive night of Impressionist and modern art auctions, and while there were few fireworks, and thin bidding, the geography of buyers told an interesting story.

headline: Okinawa Piques Chinese Papers
text: HONG KONG — Chinese state-run newspapers began carrying commentaries on Wednesday and Thursday questioning Japan’s sovereignty over the island of Okinawa, the latest sign of growing nationalism and territorial ambitions among a significant sector of China’s elite.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Fears Russia May Sell Air-Defense System to Syria
text: WASHINGTON — The United States, which is trying to bring Syrian rebels and the Syrian government to the negotiating table, is now increasingly worried that Russia plans to sell a sophisticated air defense system to Syria, American officials said Wednesday.

headline: California: Oakland Police Chief Quits
text: Amid a surge in violent crime, the Oakland police chief, Howard A. Jordan, resigned Wednesday, citing unspecified medical reasons. For years, the city’s beleaguered Police Department has suffered from low staffing and management problems. Last year the city narrowly avoided becoming the first in the country to cede control of its police force to federal authorities. Gov. Jerry Brown had to deploy California Highway Patrol officers to help patrol city streets. Chief Jordan, who was appointed in 2011, made his announcement a short time before a police consultant, William Bratton, a former police commissioner for New York City and a former Los Angeles police chief, was to announce his recommendations for fighting crime.

headline: Syrian Refugees Cross Into Uncertainty
text: Refugees fleeing fighting in Syria in May 2013 relocated to the Zaatari refugee camp in northern Jordan, where they faced dusty days and cold nights in an uncertain existence with no end in sight.

headline: Syrian Refugees Struggle at Zaatari Camp
text: About 120,000 Syrians are calling the tents and trailers of the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan home, at least for the foreseeable future.

headline: New Ranger Injects New Life Into Team’s Power Play
text: When the Rangers explored trade possibilities with the Columbus Blue Jackets as the April 3 deadline approached, they insisted that Derick Brassard be included as part of what became a multiplayer deal. Now it is clear why.

headline: A Lost Generation: Young Syrian Refugees Struggle to Survive
text: SABHA, Jordan — The parents were petrified the oldest of their seven children would be drafted into the Syrian Army. For their teenage girl, they feared rape and kidnapping. And the next oldest, verging on adolescence, had begun rabble-rousing at school and in the street against the government.

headline: Lost in Time
text: Far from Morocco’s well-trodden tourist route lies Taroudant, a remote market town where a colorful group of expats have create a most stylish haven.

text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Arizona: Conviction in Murder
text: Jodi Arias was found guilty of first-degree murder on Wednesday for the killing of her onetime boyfriend, Travis Alexander, in a trial marked by months of salacious evidence and testimony depicting the couple’s tumultuous relationship. Ms. Arias was accused of stabbing Mr. Alexander almost 30 times, shooting him in the head and slashing his throat from ear to ear during a fit of jealous rage in 2008. Her lawyers argued he had been abusive to her, and that she killed him in self-defense. Jurors, who reached their verdict after roughly three days of deliberations in Phoenix, will next decide whether Ms. Arias, 32, receives the death penalty. There are currently three other women on Arizona’s death row.

headline: Rangers Knock Down Shots and Push Past the Capitals
text: The Rangers hit every Capital in sight Wednesday night. They fearlessly blocked 33 shots. They won almost twice as many face-offs as Washington. They made Alex Ovechkin irrelevant. And with the outcome in doubt late, again, the defense and goaltending were stout.

headline: House Democrats Finally Have Their Dinner
text: WASHINGTON — House Democratic leaders had been feeling left out of President Obama’s second-term strategy of outreach to Congress, but on Wednesday night they got their turn, joining him for a longer-than-expected dinner at a hotel near the White House.

headline: In Malaysia’s Election, a Free Press Was Elusive
text: HONG KONG — American presidents have built-in advantages when running for re-election. Corporations and other interest groups tend to give financially to their cause to stay in the good graces of the leadership. The president enjoys the bully pulpit that comes with being in the White House. Throw a healthy economy into the mix, and it’s an almost unbeatable combination.

headline: A Return by Racing Royalty
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Racing royalty visited the Churchill Downs paddock on May 2 as the Kentucky Derby champions Funny Cide (2003) and Mine That Bird (2009) returned for a visit. As they walked quietly across the plaza from the Kentucky Derby Museum, the crowd parted at the unusual sight of two thoroughbreds parading outside the customary tunnel entrance.

headline: Sony Posts Annual Profit for First Time in 5 Years
text: TOKYO — Sony said on Thursday that it had eked out an annual profit for the first time in five years, thanks to belt-tightening and the weakening yen. But the company’s future continued to hinge on turning around its unprofitable electronics business.

headline: Tip of the Week: Getting Wireless Network Details
text: Want quick information about your computer’s wireless connection? Clicking the Wireless Network Connection icon in the Notification area of the Windows desktop taskbar opens a panel that shows the name of the current network. Passing the mouse cursor over the network’s name displays a ScreenTip listing the signal strength, type of encryption security and other details. A link at the bottom of the panel opens the Network and Sharing control panel for wireless-network management and settings.

headline: What Kind of ‘Little Free Library’ Would You Create for Your Community?
text: Last weekend, 10 “little free libraries” popped up in and around Lower Manhattan. As you can see in the slide show above, they are installed in different places and take different forms, but each is a miniature lending library where anyone can take or leave a book under the honor system.

headline: A Student on the Wait List Asks to Be Removed
text: Some of you may recall that I was waitlisted at Brown and Stanford Universities, and that their final decisions about me have yet to arrive.

headline: Soccer Coach’s Departure Trumps British News
text: LONDON — In a week that saw the state opening of Parliament and an intensified debate over membership in the European Union, another news item dominated Thursday’s headlines in Britain — the retirement of a veteran soccer coach.

headline: A Conversation With: Mount Everest Guide Norbu Sherpa
text: NEW DELHI — Norbu Sherpa, 32, has been working as a climbing guide in the high mountains of Nepal, over 6,000 meters (19,685 feet) for more than a decade. He has been a member of seven expeditions to Everest, the highest peak in the world, at 8,848 meters (29,029 feet), and reached the summit five times. Norbu, who was educated in Darjeeling, is currently part of a National Cadet Corps Everest team from India.

headline: AT&T’s Ads With Cute Kids Are a Neat Fit for Mother’s Day
text: The popular campaign for AT&T featuring commercials with interviews of cute schoolchildren in the style of “Kids Say the Darnedest Things” is being expanded to help children, of whatever age, celebrate Mother’s Day on Sunday.

headline: Daily Report: Zuckerberg’s Lobbying Group Is Criticized Over Tactics
text: The advocacy group Fwd.Us, created by Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg and others, has shocked some liberals with its tactics in a campaign to support immigration reform, Somini Sengupta and Eric Lipton report in The New York Times.

headline: One Social Media Start-Up Rises From the Ashes of Another
text: One of the hardest things for an entrepreneur to do is to admit defeat. But in the case of Apu Gupta and Nick Shiftan, failure was likely the best thing that could have happened to them.

headline: 17 Years to Hatch an Invasion
text: From North Carolina to Connecticut, billions of creatures with eyes the color of blood and bodies the color of coal are crawling out of the earth. Periodical cicadas are emerging en masse, clambering into trees and singing a shivering chorus that can be heard for miles.

text: Scene 63. INT. BATHROOM. NIGHT.

headline: Network TV Is Broken. So How Does Shonda Rhimes Keep Making Hits?
text: “I love that the gay White House chief of staff is threatening to pretend the first lady is a closeted lesbian,” Shonda Rhimes said to a roomful of writers. “It is so wrong. In the best way.” Ten of the writers — seven men, three women, five plaid button-down shirts and two pairs of outsize hipster glasses frames — were sitting in her bright Hollywood office, pens in hand, scripts in laps, going through notes for the 20th episode of “Scandal,” Rhimes’s gonzo political melodrama, which is about to finish its second season on ABC.

headline: A Century of Cicadas
text: Periodical cicadas live underground for 17 or 13 years before emerging to sing, mate and die. This year’s cicadas are Brood II, one of 15 surviving regional broods.

headline: Gunmen Abduct Pakistani Ex-Premier’s Son as Campaign Nears End
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Unidentified gunmen kidnapped a son of former Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani on Thursday, officials said, throwing an already violence-ridden election campaign into more tumult.

headline: Bank of England Leaves Benchmark Interest Rate Unchanged
text: LONDON — With the British economy showing feeble signs of resilience and a new central bank governor waiting in the wings, the Bank of England decided on Thursday to keep its benchmark interest rate and its economic stimulus program unchanged.

headline: Cancer Vaccines Get a Price Cut in Poor Nations
text: The two companies that make vaccines against cervical cancer announced Thursday that they would cut their prices to the world’s poorest countries below $5 per dose, eventually making it possible for millions of girls to be protected against a major deadly cancer.

headline: Carlyle’s First-Quarter Profit Barely Budged
text: The private equity giant Carlyle Group reported on Thursday that earnings rose less than 1 percent the first quarter, a gain that came largely thanks to a rise in the value of its investments.

headline: Hedge Funds Step Into the Limelight
text: In two separate events in Las Vegas and New York on Wednesday, the hedge fund faithful gathered to hear investment advice and rub elbows with some of the biggest names in the industry. The newer of the two events, the SkyBridge Alternatives Conference, or SALT, is a Wall Street schmooze-fest in Sin City that lets the world’s richest investors mingle with funds peddling their services, DealBook’s Peter Lattman reports. Overseeing the star-studded event is Anthony Scaramucci, a hedge fund impresario, or, as Mr. Lattman puts it, a P.T. Barnum in a Ferragamo tie. “In a gilded industry that has preferred to stay below the radar, Mr. Scaramucci embraces the white-hot center of it all.”

headline: Of Post Doctors and Glorious Geniuses
text: PHNOM PENH — Late last month, the prime minister of Cambodia awarded his long-serving finance minister the title “Kitti Setah Banditt,” which roughly translates to “Glorious Economist of Genius” and is the supposed equivalent of a doctoral degree. It was a variation on an obscure “Glorious Genius” honor that seemingly came out of nowhere in 2011, when it was given to two senior leaders of the governing Cambodian People’s Party as well as the prime minister’s wife.

headline: Why Am I Dining Out So Often?
text: They were counting us out. They figured it was the millennials who were going to come in and save their bacon. But at the end of the day who’s filling up the booths at T.G.I. Fridays? Who’s getting the Lumberjack Slam breakfast at Denny’s? Who’s dialing up for pizza because, really, who feels like cooking tonight?

headline: Shimmying Off the Literary Mantle
text: The best way to enjoy Baz Luhrmann’s big and noisy new version of “The Great Gatsby” — and despite what you may have heard, it is an eminently enjoyable movie — is to put aside whatever literary agenda you are tempted to bring with you. I grant that this is not so easily done. F. Scott Fitzgerald’s slender, charming third novel has accumulated a heavier burden of cultural significance than it can easily bear. Short and accessible enough to be consumed in a sitting (as in “Gatz,” Elevator Repair Service’s full-text staged reading), the book has become, in the 88 years since its publication, a schoolroom staple and a pop-cultural totem. It shapes our increasingly fuzzy image of the jazz age and fuels endless term papers on the American dream and related topics.

headline: The Moral Equivalent of Space Aliens
text: To almost everyone’s surprise, Japan — Japan! — has emerged as the advanced country most willing to break with austerian orthodoxy and try a combination of aggressive monetary and fiscal stimulus. The verdict on Abenomics is, of course, still out, although early indications are good. But how did this happen?

headline: Thursday Reading: What to Do With a 700-Doll Inheritance
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

text: BEIJING — China’s most celebrated film director, Zhang Yimou, is being investigated for a potential violation of family planning laws, an official said Thursday, confirming reports in the state news media.

text: It’s no surprise that Paula Scher’s graphic design work since the 1970s, for cultural, corporate and educational institutions (like a Queens public high school, shown), has won her a 2013 National Design Award for communication design from the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum.

text: With her impeccable eye and philanthropic largess, Carla Fendi is aiming to revive the faded glories of the once majestic Spoleto Festival.

headline: Officials, Citing Miscarriages, Weigh Death Penalty in Ohio Case
text: CLEVELAND — As more grim details emerged Thursday about the long captivity of the three women rescued from imprisonment in a dilapidated home here, one official compared the victims to survivors of a P.O.W. camp, and prosecutors said they would seek murder charges against the man held in the abductions, accusing him of forcing at least one of the women to miscarry.

headline: Barnes & Noble Shares Jump on Sign of Microsoft Interest in Nook
text: 5:29 p.m. | Updated Shares of Barnes & Noble skyrocketed in early trading on Thursday after a report said Microsoft was offering $1 billion for the digital assets of the bookseller’s e-reader business.

text: In a season when Broadway often seemed to be losing its mind and its mojo, the wisest advice came from a 5-year-old: “If you’re stuck in your story and want to get out/You don’t have to cry and you don’t have to shout!”

headline: At Brooklyn Library’s New Center, Books Are Secondary
text: The young couple burst through the great bronze doors of the main Brooklyn Public Library 15 minutes before closing time one recent Sunday with an unusual request: Was there somewhere they could recite their vows?

headline: Delta Sees New Terminal as Symbol of an Air Travel Makeover
text: As Delta Air Lines executives tell it, the carrier’s bright and spacious new terminal at Kennedy Airport in New York reflects the industry’s new priorities.

headline: De Blasio’s Wife Gives Candid Interview
text: The New York City mayor’s race has failed to attract much attention in the glossy world of national magazines, save for a handful of soft-focus features about Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, who would be the first woman and first openly gay person to run City Hall.

headline: Books to Give Your Mother (and Yourself)
text: Memoirs. Cookbooks. Novels. Memoir-cookbook-novels. (O.K., I haven’t actually seen one of those. Yet.) Grabby nonfiction for those passionate about everything from eating to Jane Austen. Summer book season is nearly upon us, and that means if you’re book-shopping for your mother, your partner or yourself, your problem won’t be finding something good, but choosing among the options. Here are a few (a very few) of the books I’m sharing with my mom and friends this year.

headline: Ottavio Missoni, Who Made Zigzags a Symbol of High Fashion, Dies at 92
text: Ottavio Missoni, the patriarch of an esteemed Italian fashion house whose outré, multicolored knits and zigzag stitches became an insider status symbol for the ultra-wealthy, died on Thursday at the family’s home in Sumirago, Italy. He was 92.

headline: R.B.S. Names Chief of Citizens Financial
text: LONDON – Bruce Van Saun, Royal Bank of Scotland’s finance director, has been appointed chief executive of the Citizens Financial Group, the company’s United States unit, two years ahead of its planned initial public offering.

headline: Syrian Refugee Crisis Growing
text: Having just returned from a visit to refugee camps in Iraq and Turkey, Marc Hanson, a senior advocate for Refugees International, talks to The Times about what he saw on the ground.

headline: Proposals Seek to Curb Bias by Co-op Boards
text: Real estate agents in New York City have long complained that co-op boards mistreat potential buyers they do not like. The boards sit on applications and never make a decision. If they turn down an applicant, they never explain why. And sometimes, the agents suspect, rejections are based on an applicant’s race or national origin.

headline: Neil Patrick Harris to Host Tony Awards for a Fourth Time
text: It doesn’t actually say this in the official announcement that the organizers of the Tony Awards sent around on Thursday morning, but you can almost hear them telling it to their industry colleagues at the Oscars: find a host who works, and stick with him. While the choosing of an Academy Awards host is an annual cycle of wondering who’s available to do it; wondering if the person or people chosen are up to the task; and then wondering what went wrong the morning after, the Tonys have dispensed with such uncertainty by naming Neil Patrick Harris to host the awards program for a fourth year.

headline: No Right to Know Your Rights
text: There’s a big poster in the pantry on the floor where I work about federal laws in the workplace. There’s information on equal opportunity, health and safety, as well as a notice that my employer can’t require me to take a lie-detector test.  It would be disturbing if the powers that be at the Times wanted to hook me up to a polygraph, and it’s good to know they would be out of line if they tried.

headline: This Year, Off Broadway Dug Deeper
text: The season just concluded was a terrific, even inspiring one for new American playwriting. But if you confined your theatergoing to Broadway, you really wouldn’t know it. Actually if you only ventured north of 42nd Street come curtain time, you would be more likely to draw precisely the opposite conclusion: that American playwriting was moribund, consisting primarily of empty vessels that had somehow been floated onto the city’s big stages by the presence of name-brand actors.

headline: Why I’m (Sort of) Ignoring Mother’s Day
text: About this time, many spouses and children, including those who are grown, are hurrying to buy or create a gift for Mother’s Day.

headline: The Gun Report: May 9, 2013
text: Two of today’s shootings involve men who allegedly gunned down their wives and other family members. In fact, many shootings covered in our daily report are domestic. This sad fact has apparently not gone unnoticed by Zombie Industries, an N.R.A. convention vendor famous for marketing a target that resembles President Obama. The company is under fire this week for marketing a mannequin shooting target in the likeness of a bleeding woman. Dubbed “The Ex,” the blond mannequin is clad in a tight white shirt and violet bra and actually bleeds fake blood when shot. After an outcry, Amazon just yesterday stopped selling it.

headline: Remember the Vulture
text: Celebrating bad behavior, good pets (and pecs) and other fleeting pleasures of the Broadway season.

headline: Pressing Patients to Change Their Minds
text: When my patient Suzy took herself off the active liver transplant list, she was too embarrassed to tell me. I found out from her liver doctors.

headline: Bombing Suspect’s Body Interred in Undisclosed Location
text: BOSTON — The body of Tamerlan Tsarnaev, the suspect in the Boston Marathon bombing who died after a shootout with the police last month, has been interred in an undisclosed location, the Worcester Police Department said in a statement on Thursday morning.

headline: A Treasure Trove of Documents, Courtesy of the City Council

headline: Celebrating a Wife Who Has Had to Spend Mother’s Day Alone
text: Mother’s Day has almost arrived, and as I struggle to come up with gift ideas, my thoughts turn toward the many holidays and family events I missed due to training, field operations and deployments. My four years in the Marines Corps included two combat tours in Afghanistan that included trials and tribulations that I will remember for the rest of my days. But I have come to realize that, compared to my wife, I had the easier job.

headline: I Am Become Ben, Destroyer of Worlds

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘To Any Reader’
text: To honor Mother’s Day, celebrated in the United States this Sunday, this week’s Poetry Pairing matches “To Any Reader” by Robert Louis Stevenson with the article “On the Road, With Mothers” by Joyce Wadler.

headline: Fox Offers an Early Glimpse of Its New Season
text: The Fox network Wednesday night got a jump on next week’s announcements of new fall television shows by releasing the details of the four new dramas and five new comedies it has ordered for the next television season.

headline: The Wrath of the Heat

headline: Cool Tools: pdf2html
text: A PDF does one thing very well: it presents an accurate image that can be viewed on just about any device. Unfortunately, PDFs also cause grief for anyone who wants to use the data they contain. Governments, in particular, have a habit of releasing PDFs when the information would be more useful and accessible as a spreadsheet. The tools for extracting text from PDFs can be flaky, but Lu Wang’s pdf2htmlEX project solves this problem. Pdf2htmlEX takes PDFs and converts them into HTML5 documents while preserving the layout and appearance of the original.

headline: Pakistan’s Pivotal Elections
text: Declan Walsh, The Times’s Islamabad bureau chief, previews the upcoming election on May 11, which promises the first democratic transfer of power from one civilian government to another.

headline: Storm Leaves Residue of Questions
text: Last fall, after Hurricane Sandy sent water sloshing through her storage container in New Jersey, Ulla Pitha began to worry whether any of her 27 artworks had been damaged. But she worried in particular about one piece: a Mary Cassatt etching.

headline: Living With Cancer: Good News Soup
text: People with incurable cancer do sometimes receive good news, as I have. Why is it harder for me to share good news than bad news? During treatment, good news produces elating highs, but also anxious lows.

headline: British Tabloid’s Web Site Makes Foray Into America
text: In recent days, one of the most comprehensive destinations for gossip about the Cleveland kidnapping victims was not an American news outlet. It was Mail Online, the Web site of The Daily Mail, a British tabloid that has taken a distinctly gossipy approach to all news.

headline: Senate Bipartisanship on Display, Briefly, as Committee Focuses on Border Security
text: WASHINGTON — As the Senate Judiciary Committee began plowing through more than 300 amendments intended to reshape — and, in some cases, derail — legislation to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws, signs of bipartisanship emerged Thursday, with the committee accepting at least eight Republican proposals to strengthen border security.

text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans continued a campaign to delay confirmation of President Obama’s second-term cabinet nominees on Thursday, blocking a committee vote on Gina McCarthy, the president’s pick to lead the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: House Vote on Debt Ceiling Gives Priority to Creditors

headline: Karzai Says U.S. Bases Can Stay, Raising Some Eyebrows in West
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan is ready to let the United States and its allies keep military bases here after the end of the NATO combat mission next year, President Hamid Karzai said on Thursday, offering a concrete public signal that foreign troops would remain welcome in the coming years.

headline: House Republicans Call on White House to Release Benghazi E-Mails
text: House Republicans on Thursday called on the Obama administration to release a new batch of e-mails that they believe will shed more light on how the White House and the State Department responded in the days after the attacks on American facilities in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: Rangers Remain Quiet on Staal’s Condition
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Defenseman Marc Staal was not at the Rangers’ optional practice Thursday after sitting out Wednesday’s Game 4 unexpectedly and without explanation from the team. But it seems as if Staal pulled himself from the lineup out of concern that his damaged eyesight might cost the Rangers.

headline: Farewell, Taylor Mead

headline: Bottled Water? It’s Not Free
text: For airline passengers who wonder what carriers will think to charge for next, Frontier Airlines has an answer that is threefold: nonalcoholic drinks, carry-ons and using Expedia. Soda, coffee, tea and juice will soon cost $1.99 for basic- and economy-fare ticket holders. Water in a glass will be free, but not bottled water. Some members of Frontier’s frequent-flier program are exempt from the fee, which was announced in conjunction with a $25 to $100 fee to stow carry-ons for basic passengers who booked their ticket through a third-party site. The fees are expected to take effect this summer.

headline: Everton Coach Is Selected as Ferguson’s Replacement
text: The breach left by Alex Ferguson’s retirement did not linger, as Manchester United announced Thursday that it had agreed to terms on a contract with Everton Manager David Moyes, who will take charge of one of the world’s most famous soccer clubs beginning July 1.

headline: F.B.I. Did Not Tell Police in Boston of Russian Tip
text: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. did not tell the Boston police about the 2011 warning from Russia about Tamerlan Tsarnaev, one of the two brothers accused in the Boston Marathon bombings, the city’s police chief said Thursday during the first public Congressional hearing on the terrorist attack.

headline: For Islanders, a Long Island Presence Is Still a Possibility
text: The Islanders are heading to Brooklyn in two years, but they will keep one skate on Long Island if Bruce C. Ratner is chosen to redevelop Nassau Coliseum, the team’s current and soon-to-be former home.

text: “If you told me six months ago that I could find 40 lunatics to buy that wine, I would have told you you were crazy,” said St. John Frizell, owner of Fort Defiance, a restaurant-bar in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

text: The federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is urging the creation of a market for the refinancing of private student loans, though how that happens remains to be seen.

text: Homeownership is a good thing, for the individual and for society. Or so American governments, whether Republican or Democrat, have long believed. The benefits have been cited repeatedly in justifying the existence and expansion of the tax breaks given to home buyers.

headline: From the U.S. Attorney’s Office: Putting a Face on $30,000 in A.T.M. Withdrawals in 6 Hours
text: A map and surveillance photos provided by federal prosecutors show one thief withdrawing some of the $2.4 million stolen from 2,904 automatic teller machines in New York City in about 10 hours starting on Feb. 19.

headline: A Cheese Shop in a Slim Crown Heights Space
text: The new cheese shop in Crown Heights may be called Wedge, but Sliver would be more like it. The owners of the narrow but well-equipped storefront, Kate Blumm and Michael de Zayas, have done their homework. And with the expertise of Lilith Spencer, who had been at Bklyn Larder, the cheese and provisions shop, they are stocking their bright little place with some real finds. Among them are a goat’s milk ricotta from Edgwick Farm in Cornwall, N.Y.; a couple of tommes from the Kokoborrego Cheese Company in Mount Gilead, Ohio; and an organic Parmigiano-Reggiano from Italy. They also carry pistachios and almonds from Sicily, a mead vinegar from Italy, breads from Bien Cuit in Brooklyn, and a sweet white miso made in Conway, Mass. Charcuterie is sliced on what Ms. Spencer says is the Rolls-Royce of slicing machines; Wedge, 728 Franklin Avenue (Sterling Place), Crown Heights, Brooklyn, wedgeonfranklin@gmail.com, facebook.com/wedgeonfranklin.

headline: Convulsions - First Aid
text: A slide show depicting the first aid procedure for convulsions.

headline: Minor Burn - First Aid
text: A slide show explaining proper first aid to treat a minor burn.

headline: Delayed Bike-Share Program Is to Start on Memorial Day
text: New York City’s bike-share program has a starting date: May 27.

headline: Fall for Dance Festival Celebrates 10th Anniversary With Performances at the Delacorte Theater
text: New York City Center’s Fall for Dance Festival will celebrate its 10th anniversary with performances by 24 companies at the center, as well two evenings of free performances, hosted for the first time in the festival’s history by the Public Theater at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

headline: Getty Museum Acquires Paintings by Rembrandt and Canaletto
text: Two paintings — a Rembrandt self-portrait that was rediscovered in 2007 and one of Canaletto’s dazzling views of Venice — are the latest acquisitions made by the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, officials there announced on Thursday.

headline: YouTube Offers ‘Sesame Street’ and Martial Arts, for a Fee

headline: U.S. Man Is Stabbed at Embassy in Cairo
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian man stabbed an American man outside the United States Embassy in Cairo on Thursday. It was not clear why.

headline: To Raze or Not? MoMA Rethinks Plan
text: AFTER impassioned protests from prominent architects, preservationists and design critics, the Museum of Modern Art said on Thursday that it would reconsider its decision to demolish its next-door neighbor, the former home of the American Folk Art Museum, to make room for an expansion.

headline: Young Girls, Real Fire

headline: Overfed on a Mother’s Affection
text: My mother held out a Tupperware container of chicken thighs and drumsticks, roasted with kimchi, bell peppers, onions and scallions. It’s a great dish, one of my favorites.

headline: Pro-Inflation Policies Show Signs of Helping the Japanese Economy
text: TOKYO — For almost two decades Japan’s economic fortunes have deteriorated, and little seemed to be done about it.

headline: Dish’s Results Hint at Trouble for Sprint Bid
text: Dish Network’s pay-TV pain signals trouble for its $25.5 billion bid for Sprint Nextel. Weak quarterly results announced on Thursday show why the company covets Sprint. But the poor earnings — net income dropped 40 percent — also show why Sprint shareholders should be skeptical of Dish’s offer.

headline: What Gives, Mom?
text: Six years ago, my mother-in-law gave me a large stainless steel roasting pan at my bridal shower. I thanked her in person and wrote her a note. I like having it. It’s much nicer than my other kitchenware, but I’ve hardly used it because I rarely cook for a crowd. Over the years, she has asked about it frequently: Am I using it? How often? Last year, she asked for it back. I told her she could borrow it. Now she’s sent me a text message asking if she can buy it back. But it was a gift. What should I do? Should I stop accepting gifts from her?

headline: Up Front
text: Sir Harold Evans (otherwise known as Harry) has spent his life around words — reporting, editing and writing books. Born in Manchester, England, in 1928, he began his career as a journalist when he was only 16, rising rapidly through the years and accumulating honors as he went. He was the editor of The Sunday Times of London from 1967 to 1981, moved to the United States in 1984 and became — to mention only a few of his positions — editorial director of U.S. News and World Report, president of Random House and founding editor of Condé Nast Traveler. In 2001, British journalists voted him the all-time greatest British newspaper editor. He was knighted in 2004.

headline: Imran Khan Gives Speech From Hospital as Pakistan Vote Nears
text: Imran Khan, who was rushed to the hospital this week after falling from a forklift during an election event, addressed supporters of his party at a rally on Thursday via video link from his hospital bed, taking advantage of a final opportunity to campaign before Pakistan’s general elections on Saturday.

headline: On the Brink
text: Nobody at the time called the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo on June 28, 1914, “a shot heard round the world.” The phrase, filched from Ralph Waldo Emerson’s “Concord Hymn,” epitomizes a judgment that crystallized only as the horrendous sequels played out. Some parts of the international community weren’t listening at all. America was serene in its isolation and prosperity. “To the world, or to a nation,” The Grand Forks Herald in North Dakota declared, “an archduke more or less makes little difference.” President Wilson, pacing the lonely corridors of the White House, was distraught over the first lady’s failing struggle for life. Paris was engrossed in a murder trial brimming with sex and political scandal. London was too obsessed with Irish home rule to sustain attention until closer to midnight.

headline: Market Report | Things Mom Wants But Doesn’t Know It Yet
text: Still in search of a memorable Mother’s Day gift? Keep it personal with customized and indulgent presents that are just for her. From a bespoke jewelry box to monthly floral deliveries, these thoughtful treasures will have Mom patting herself on the back for raising you so well.

headline: Ottavio Missoni’s Legacy

headline: Orb Stays Loose in Mud as Preakness Field Comes Together

Eight Kentucky Derby starters are being considered for the middle jewel of the Triple Crown, and they will be joined by three or four horses who did not race in the Derby. It remains possible one or two more horses may come under consideration.

text: This show traces the evolution of punk from the streets of London to fashion runways.

headline: As Latinos Make Gains in Education, Gaps Remain
text: After lagging behind other Americans in education for generations, Latinos have significantly narrowed the gap, and last year they passed a milestone, with new Hispanic high school graduates more likely than their white counterparts to go directly to college, according to a new study.

text: Scenes from the film originally produced for the 2012 Havana Biennial, by the Cuban-born, Madrid-based Los Carpinteros. Directed by Pavel Giroud.

text: The Bats blog again tests our readers’ predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

headline: Comfortable Out of Their Own Skin
text: A man and woman, stripped of skin, are balanced in a balletic embrace, but their skulls and thoracic and abdominal cavities are open from behind and their spines are pulled backward, with organs and muscles attached.

headline: Creations, Both Cutting-Edge and Double-Edged
