headline: More on the Roots of Bernanke Hatred
text: Matthew O’Brien follows up on the hedge-fund-guys-who-hate Bernanke question, and points out that hedge funds have actually done quite badly for a decade, and especially since the crisis began. He also suggests that what the hedgies really hate isn’t Bernanke so much as the IS-LM framework he (and I) basically work in, and hate it all the more because it has worked so well.

headline: When a High Bid Isn’t Enough
text: In a housing market starved for inventory, buyers are stepping over one another to bid on desirable properties. But a high bid may not be enough — sellers are also seeking offers without mortgage contingencies.

text: You can’t help thinking that this is how Ramona Quimby would have turned out when she was all grown up.

text: John Lennon once wondered in song, “Imagine no possessions; I wonder if you can?”

text: Ben Wheatley, the director of “Sightseers,” discusses his film.

headline: After Verdict, Sentencing Is a New Trial for Jurors

headline: You Might Call Him the Decorator of the Met
text: There are two kinds of historic figures: those whose names are forever attached to their achievements, and those whose names slip away, even as their contributions live on.

headline: The Latest G.O.P. Temper Tantrum
text: Moments before a scheduled vote on Thursday on the nomination of Gina McCarthy to lead the Environmental Protection Agency, Republican members of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee announced a boycott. One result was to delay her confirmation, which still seems virtually certain in the long run since Democrats control the committee as well as the full Senate. The other result was to make the Republicans look not only vindictive but supremely childish.

headline: This Showboat Knows How to Be Herself
text: Some people give the impression that they’re always making an entrance. This is true no matter how long they’ve been in a room or whether they are standing, seated or lying down. Take Vera Baronova, the most enchanting, attention-grabbing egotist to be spotted in many a moon in Manhattan, where there’s no shortage of competition in entrance-making.

headline: Harmonics, Smoothly Blended and Aged
text: There are three main reasons Take 6, the pop-gospel a cappella group, has thrived as long as it has, and they all factored in an encore at the Blue Note on Wednesday night. That song, capping off a sold-out first set, was the spiritual “Mary Don’t You Weep,” performed in a near facsimile of the version that first appeared (as the track “Mary”) on the group’s self-titled debut album 25 years ago.

headline: Fixations of a Fabulist, Hermetic and Mystical
text: The Morgan Library, with its Gospels, missals and reliquaries, is just the right place for “Subliming Vessel: The Drawings of Matthew Barney,” the first survey of graphic work by the most medievalizing of American contemporary artists.

headline: Going to Pains for Love in a Flashy Urban Jungle
text: NEW HAVEN — What does Elvira want? Caresses and tenderness. What does Elvira get? Beaten up by gay hustlers and left prone, pants around her ankles, bra exposed.

headline: These Two Really Need a Vacation, So Beware
text: Nasty, brutish and mercifully short, the woozy comedy “Sightseers” tells the tale of two ordinary British eccentrics who initially bring to mind the gargoyles, both amusing and alarming, that populate Mike Leigh movies. A droopy, passive-aggressive frowner, Tina (Alice Lowe), lives with her hectoring mother, Carol (Eileen Davies), in a house crammed with kitsch and collectibles, many dog-themed and portraying a beloved, recently deceased terrier. It’s the kind of domestic horror show that certain British filmmakers either mock or sentimentalize, and which the British director Ben Wheatley (“Down Terrace”) takes to with a very heavy, very unforgiving ax.

headline: Hezbollah Threatens Israel Over Syria Strikes
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The leader of Hezbollah, the powerful Lebanese militant group, escalated tensions with Israel on Thursday over the recent Israeli airstrikes near Damascus, suggesting that the Syrian government would respond by providing Hezbollah fighters with the same weapons that Israel wants to keep out of their hands.

headline: American Music, Abloom, Pollinated by Multiple Steps
text: American music! What’s its stylistic range, and what’s its dance potential? New York City Ballet’s spring gala on Wednesday — with no fanfares, no speeches and no onstage toasts — focused simply on this theme. Though too few of the principals danced, it was an entirely happy occasion to open the company’s season.

headline: New York Public Library to Begin Spending City Funds on Renovation
text: Even as demonstrators were outside the New York Public Library’s flagship Fifth Avenue building on Wednesday, protesting the library’s renovation plans, the library’s trustees were inside deciding to make the first public expenditure on that plan: $9 million for the project’s architect, Norman Foster.

headline: From Lands of Soviets, Exploring the Mystic
text: Any politician or public figure who ever cited elitism as a reason to brush off supporting the local orchestra would have done well to attend a concert by the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night. The event was part of Spring for Music, a laudable series that has brought some of America’s most ambitious regional orchestras to New York City with their most inventive programs.

headline: ‘Historic’ Doesn’t Rule Out ‘New’
text: Since it was designated a historic district in 2001, the Madison Square North neighborhood, with its row houses and Art Deco-style towers, has undergone a striking transformation. Hotels and offices have replaced many of the warehouses and garment showrooms that once populated the 10 blocks around the northern end of Madison Square Park.

headline: No Red Carpet, but the Stars Are Out
text: AS shadows gathered in Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx on a recent evening, visitors began making their way deep into the park, past the Gilded Age mausoleums and onward to a circular grass plot with a stone obelisk in the center.

headline: Schumer Voices Concern Over Immigration and Same-Sex Couples
text: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said on Thursday that an amendment that would allow American citizens to seek permanent resident visas, known as green cards, for same-sex foreign partners keeps him up at night.

headline: A Culinary Memoir Spiced With Newsroom Anecdotes
text: When Raymond Sokolov became the food editor of The New York Times in 1971, replacing Craig Claiborne, some people still felt that writing about kitchens and restaurants wasn’t man’s work.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Pakistan, China, Bangladesh and Guatemala.

headline: Owning a Dog Is Linked to Reduced Heart Risk
text: The nation’s largest cardiovascular health organization has a new message for Americans: Owning a dog may protect you from heart disease.

headline: Goldman’s Cohn Can’t Escape the ‘Squid’
text: Gary D. Cohn, the president and chief operating officer of Goldman Sachs, was sitting on stage at a conference in Manhattan on Thursday when the speaker introducing him cracked a joke.

headline: Food Matters | A Can’t-Miss Artisanal Pizzeria in Hollywood
text: “I’m cooking a little more aggressively,” said Jeff Mahin of his new restaurant, Stella Barra, which opened last night in Hollywood. The chef had garnered praise for his artfully crafted, Neapolitan-style pizzas at Stella Rosa in Santa Monica, but he found himself wanting a kitchen where he could experiment. “Santa Monica is relaxed, a real pizza town,” he explained. “Hollywood is more open and edgy, so I needed to expand the menu.”

headline: 36 Hours in Las Vegas
text: From a tourism perspective, Las Vegas is ever the chameleon. New restaurants, shows, clubs and hotels are constantly reinventing Sin City with the aim of getting repeaters back to the tables. Big construction projects continue, and there are currently two competing Ferris wheels under construction on the Strip. But lately, developments have eschewed kitschy copies of foreign landmarks like an Egyptian pyramid in favor of celebrating Las Vegas’s own swinging style, as indicated by two new downtown museums. Yes, traffic still snarls the Strip, but a new terminal at McCarran International Airport has eased congestion for fliers.

headline: Learning Las Vegas
text: You can study subjects like neon and the mob, or stick to more visceral pleasures.

headline: New Bells and Whistles at the Old Firehouse
text: Firemen’s Hall, at 155 Mercer Street, is an odd, squat thing stripped of detail, a puzzling eyesore among the tony galleries and spiffed-up shops of SoHo. Now a new owner, Thor Equities, is working not to restore the 1855 building, but to recreate it.

headline: S.B.A. Budget Pits the Small Against the Less Small
text: The Agenda has often recounted efforts at the Small Business Administration to shift attention to larger businesses, a particular interest of the outgoing administrator, Karen Mills. Now The Washington Post reports that a program that the Obama administration has proposed to provide counseling to midsize businesses would come at the expense of counseling programs for much smaller companies.

headline: By a 75-59 Vote, the Minnesota House Approves a Same-Sex Marriage Bill
text: The Minnesota House of Representatives on Thursday voted to permit same-sex marriage, clearing the way to add Minnesota to a string of states that have recently made it legal for gay and lesbian couples to wed.

headline: Family Opens Its Diary, With Mother as Subject
text: For many of us, I suspect, our first sense of the past begins with the simple childhood request for a story about our families and ourselves. In her quietly moving, intelligent documentary “Stories We Tell,” the Canadian actress and director Sarah Polley sat down with relatives and friends and asked them to talk about her mother, Diane Polley, who died in 1990 when Ms. Polley was 11. The idea, or so it first seems, is that every fondly unearthed detail, anecdote and memory will fill in the biography of a woman whose seemingly ordinary life — of tending children, husband and home — contained multitudes and mysteries, and with tugging and shaping can be tidied into a story.

headline: Exploring the Homeland of Pope Francis I
text: Argentina’s religious sites have never been in such demand. The elevation of Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio in Buenos Aires to Pope Francis in March has sparked interest in the Roman Catholic markers of his homeland. There has been an increase of visits to the Catedral Metropolitana, where the pope celebrated Mass before his elevation, and to Flores, the neighborhood where he grew up and home to the basilica where he was a priest, said Pamela Resnik of the tourism ministry’s development office.

headline: One-Year Prison Sentence for an Ex-State Senator Who Taped Her Colleagues
text: Shirley L. Huntley, the former state senator whose secret recordings of some of New York’s most prominent politicians heightened concerns about widespread corruption in Albany, was sentenced Thursday to a year in prison for stealing from a nonprofit organization she ran.

headline: When the Ship Comes In
text: In a post-Potter, post-Katniss era, the line between young adult and mainstream fiction often blurs. Novels that once would have slipped beneath the radar of adult readers are now proudly displayed by middle-aged commuters on public transit; books that not so long ago wouldn’t have made it past the P.T.A. into the middle school library are, for a generation raised on endless reruns of “Law and Order: SVU,” just another day at the office. Thirteen isn’t what it used to be — nor, apparently, is the 30 it’s become.

headline: Q & A
text: Rules for Co-op Subletting

headline: Turn a Colorblind Eye to Your Spring Wine
text: I don’t have a favorite season. Each offers its particular joys. Mostly, I love the parade of four distinct seasons, which makes me happy to be a Northeasterner.

headline: Removal of Gravestones Stirs Emotions Among Mexicans
text: More than 500 urban gravestones have been built in the city of Culiacán over the past five years.

headline: A City of Violent Deaths Tries to Change Its Image
text: CULIACÁN, Mexico — The shrines have sprouted up virtually everywhere, scores of them, in front of universities, next to churches, on the main avenues — constant reminders of this city’s unenviable distinction as a cradle of narco-trafficking and drug violence.

text: Comedy

text: Movies

headline: Leave a Place Setting for Ann
text: On the surface, Christine Quinn and Holland Taylor would not seem to have much in common. One comes from a middle-class Irish-Catholic family on Long Island; the other is the daughter of a well-to-do lawyer and artist mother in Philadelphia. One has spent her life in politics, starting as a community organizer, and is now speaker of the New York City Council. The other has worked in show business for nearly 50 years, first as a stage actress in New York, winning acclaim in plays like “Butley” and “The Cocktail Hour,” before taking roles in television, on “Bosom Buddies” (starring a then-unknown Tom Hanks), “The Practice” and “Two and a Half Men.”

headline: Theater Listings for May 10-16
text: Theater

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter in the Valley and  iPhoto Trouble
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Using Darkness, With Enlightenment in Mind
text: The Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas has written several works to be performed in pitch darkness, including “In Vain,” his hourlong masterpiece for chamber orchestra. With artificial light everywhere, “we do not have any night in our modern life,” he said in an interview in 2011. “But I think our body and our souls desire night, and I give this in my art.”

headline: Pop and Rock Listings for May 10-16
text: Pop

headline: Youthful Charisma Unleashed, Violin in Hand
text: In college I used to drive a matchbox-size Volkswagen Polo with, according to the manual, a maximum speed of 142 kilometers (about 88 miles) per hour. But on empty stretches of a speed-limit-free German autobahn, I would floor the gas pedal until the needle climbed past 160 kilometers, and the car shook so hard that the keys jingled in the ignition, and the cassette threatened to pop out of the stereo.

headline: A Cuban Art Collective’s Revelations in Reverse
text: Since the early 1990s, the Cuban art collective Los Carpinteros has been creating elegant sculptures, drawings and installations that engage the public with a mix of wry humor and political resonance. For last year’s Havana Biennial, the artists directed a film called “Conga Irreversible,” in which 100 performers enacted a traditional Cuban comparsa — a ceremonial procession — down Havana’s historic Paseo del Prado, entirely in reverse. Marco Castillo, one of the group’s founders, compared the experience to directing an opera. “An original score was composed,” he recalled. “All of the costumes were custom designed.”

headline: Jazz Listings for May 10-16
text: Jazz

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for May 10-16
text: Classical

headline: Deportation Agents and Sheriffs Oppose Immigration Bill
text: The leader of a union representing federal immigration deportation agents has joined two dozen sheriffs in sending a letter to Congress warning that the sweeping immigration bill under consideration in the Senate is weak on border security and would hamper the work of law enforcement officers.

headline: Dance Listings for May 10-16
text: Dance

headline: Capitals’ Holtby Focuses on Ending a Losing Streak
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — Until Games 3 and 4 of a series with the Rangers this week, Washington Capitals goaltender Braden Holtby had not lost consecutive playoff games.

text: Art

text: ‘Adventures From Ezra Jack Keats’

text: Mother’s Day Weekend

headline: NBC Announces 5 New Shows, With Familiar Names Attached
text: NBC began its latest rebuilding effort on Thursday by announcing that it had ordered five new series: three comedies and two dramas. These shows do not represent the network’s entire list of new entries; more series are expected to be announced on Friday.

headline: Randy Jackson to Leave ‘American Idol’
text: Randy Jackson, the longest-serving name associated with “American Idol,” has announced his intention to leave the show at the end of this season. News of his impending departure comes as reports swirl that the Fox network has decided to clean house on its onetime prime-time powerhouse by removing all its on-air judges and its executive producer.

headline: SAC Is Said to Extend a Deadline for Clients
text: 8:51 p.m. | Updated

headline: Merrill Brockway, Producer of TV’s ‘Dance in America,’ Dies at 90
text: Merrill Brockway, a director and producer who brought high art to millions of Americans by presenting many of the 20th century’s greatest dancers and choreographers on the PBS television series “Dance in America,” died on May 2 in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 90.

headline: Fredrick L. McKissack, 73, Children’s Book Author, Dies
text: Fredrick L. McKissack, who quit a career in construction to join his wife in writing more than 100 children’s books about African-American history, a piece of which his family owned as distinguished builders and architects, died on April 28 in Chesterfield, Mo., a St. Louis suburb. He was 73.

headline: Back to the Future Portraiture
text: Not long ago, I came across a very old photograph on Facebook that seemed to be a formal portrait . . . of someone’s back. Intrigued, I tracked down the owner of the image, Paul Frecker, who runs a Web site called the Library of Nineteenth-Century Photography. A Londoner, Frecker is a former fashion stylist who used to work for magazines like The Face and i-D in the 1980s, and then on music videos and commercials in the 1990s. In 2001, he stumbled on an album of carte de visites in an antiques store, and soon after that he gave up styling for collecting and trading photographs from that era. Some of his favorite images in his collection, he says, are his 60 or so “back to camera” carte de visites, small, mounted photographs — mostly portraits — that became popular in the second half of the 19th century.

headline: Sixth Suit Filed by Client Against Former Knoedler Gallery
text: The once-celebrated Knoedler & Company gallery has been closed for more than a year and a half but the lawsuits keep coming. Last week, the philanthropist and former ambassador to Romania, Nicholas F. Taubman, became the sixth former client to sue the gallery in federal court in Manhattan, charging that Knoedler’s former director Ann Freedman duped him into buying a fake painting by Clyfford Still for $4.3 million in 2005.

headline: A Creative Buzz Charges a Montreal Neighborhood
text: Trend-obsessed Montrealers are now strolling Saint-Henri’s once-sleepy sidewalks.

headline: This Week’s Movies: May 8, 2013
text: The New York Times critics on “The Great Gatsby,” “Stories We Tell” and “Venus & Serena.”

headline: Flushing, 3:32 P.M.
text: N.Y. See: Tex, a horse, looked on as a crowd gathered at the Western Riding Club in Flushing, Queens, on Thursday.

headline: A Neighborhood Nearly Obliterated by a Blast
text: A map showing the extent of damage from a fertilizer plant explosion in West, Tex.

headline: Electronic Music in Chelsea
text: The Miser can’t leave home these days without encountering the AutoTuned pipes of one pop star or another. But while AutoTune’s vocal effect may seem like just the latest pop music craze, historians of electronic music point out its distinguished antecedents, in, say, Elvis Presley’s slapback echo, Peter Frampton’s talk box, or the vocoder used by Laurie Anderson in her unlikely 1981 pop hit, “O Superman.”

headline: For International Students, College Checklists for May
text: This week, The Choice published our monthly Counselor’s Calendar, intended to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

headline: With Francisco Coming Back, Decisions Loom
text: The Mets may soon face a difficult decision regarding their back end of the bullpen as Frank Francisco, on the disabled list with a right elbow injury, continues to pitch well in his minor league rehabilitation for Class A Port St. Lucie.

headline: In Praise of Public Libraries (Personal and Trivial)
text: Nothing professional or deep here, just an interesting (to me) discovery I’ve made. For complicated reasons, mainly family-duty-related, I’ve lately had to do a lot of hopscotching around central New Jersey, with various appointments and tasks here and there but often with gaps of several hours in between. And, as always, lots of work to get done in the cracks. What to do?

headline: Olympian Dies in America’s Cup Training After Yacht Flips
text: Andrew Simpson, a 36-year-old British sailor and Olympic gold medalist, died Thursday after a 72-foot America’s Cup yacht owned by the Swedish team Artemis Racing capsized during training in San Francisco Bay.

headline: Singh Plays in Relative Peace
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — By the time Vijay Singh arrived at the par-3 17th hole Thursday afternoon, the fans who had blanketed the grassy areas around the island green minutes earlier were gone, leaving behind a trail of empty water bottles. Tiger Woods, who was playing in the group directly ahead of Singh, is like a magnet, pulling fans to whichever hole he is playing.

headline: Lawmakers Promise Review of Popular Workout Booster
text: Three Republican members of a powerful House subcommittee have opened an inquiry into the safety of an amphetaminelike substance in some popular workout and fat-burning products sold at GNC.

headline: Raise a Judge’s Pay, Ease a Lawmaker’s Retirement
text: Twenty-three dollars is not a lot of money, but that small figure could have big political consequences.

headline: A Proposal to Curb Access to Photos of Murder Victims
text: To illustrate articles about Preston Hughes III, who was convicted and sentenced to death in the 1988 stabbing deaths of a 15-year-old Houston girl and her 3-year-old cousin, several bloggers published graphic crime scene photographs last November, around the time of Mr. Hughes’s execution.

headline: Star Finds Groove at the Right Time
text: TORONTO — Three weeks ago, Boston Bruins Coach Claude Julien benched left wing Milan Lucic to send him a message about his poor play. Julien said it was a last resort to inspire Lucic, who had only six goals at the time.

headline: Suspect in Boston Bombing Talked Jihad in Russia
text: KIZLYAR, Russia — It’s not every day that a well-dressed American shows up in this town, where shaggy cows meander over deeply rutted roads, so people remember Tamerlan Tsarnaev. Among the things that made the young visitor stand out, two acquaintances recalled on Thursday, was his avid interest in waging jihad.

headline: One Mistake, and a Life Derails
text: “You know I know that you know, and you’re breaking our hearts again for not speaking up.”

headline: Bombings Make a Bitter Bookend for F.B.I.’s Director
text: WASHINGTON — Robert S. Mueller III was awakened at home close to 1:30 a.m. on April 19 as one suspect in the Boston Marathon bombing was in cardiac arrest and the other was on the run.

headline: Chemical Depots Fall Under a Patchwork of Rules
text: NEW BRAUNFELS — Off a dirt road connected to ever-flowing Interstate 35, a little metal sign on a wooden fence is the only indication of what lies ahead. Nearby, Buckley Powder, a mining and construction supply company, stores large quantities of ammonium nitrate, the source of the explosion at a fertilizer depot that killed at least 14 people and injured hundreds more last month in West.

headline: Champions Face Challenges, Too
text: “Venus and Serena,” a new documentary by Maiken Baird and Michelle Major, focuses on 2011, when the Williams Sisters Era of women’s tennis seemed to be coming to an end. Flashing back to earlier moments of glory, the film follows Venus and Serena through injuries and other health problems. Venus, the older sister and the first to rise to prominence, seems to be fading quietly from the scene, while Serena, always more dramatic and more controversial, struggles with frustration and disappointment.

headline: A Mad Man Someone Should Hire
text: To describe “And Now a Word From Our Sponsor” as a one-joke skit stretched well beyond the breaking point isn’t entirely fair, because when used ingeniously, which is very seldom, the joke lands. The movie’s unwitting clown, Adan (Bruce Greenwood), is the chief executive of an advertising agency who is found unconscious in front of an electronics store. He wakes up in a hospital, and the only words to come out of his mouth are familiar advertising slogans. Asked how he is feeling, Adan replies, “Please don’t squeeze the Charmin.”

headline: Playing Jazz in High Heels and Skirts
text: “The Girls in the Band” is everything a worthwhile documentary should be, and then some: engaging, informative, thorough and brimming with delightful characters. Shining a long-overdue spotlight on the shamefully forgotten women who flourished as jazz musicians at a time when men ruled the beat, Judy Chaikin’s beautifully assembled film gives voice to performers whose names are too often unknown even among their musical sisters of the present day.

headline: GTT ★
text: ​Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: F.C.C. Advances Plan for Faster In-Flight Wi-Fi
text: WASHINGTON — It may soon be easier and faster to surf the Web at 30,000 feet.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Those Aiding Iran
text: The United States on Thursday expanded its roster of those violating Iran sanctions, blacklisting four Iranian companies and one individual suspected of helping the country enrich nuclear fuel. It also singled out two other companies, including a Venezuelan-Iranian bank, accused of helping Iran evade other Western-imposed prohibitions on oil sales and financial dealings.

headline: How Not to Impress Your Girlfriend’s Snobby Family
text: Tyler Perry “presents” Tina Gordon Chism’s “Peeples,” but this pleasing ensemble comedy, while manifesting Perry trademarks, is very much Ms. Chism’s own. And that is to its benefit.

headline: The Wilderness Next Door
text: MOUNT ST. HELENS, Wash. — You’re on the crater rim of a volcano that is in a tenuous snooze. You expect the few burps of steam coming from the lava dome down below. You expect the sense-surround view of the Cascade Mountains on a day from perfection’s vault. What you don’t expect is finding a New Yorker, sitting near a snow cornice, munching a bagel.

headline: New Man at Old Trafford
text: Well, that didn’t take long.

headline: The Next Contagion: Closer Than You Think
text: MINNEAPOLIS

headline: How to Heal Balkan Wounds for Good
text: AFTER months of talks mediated by the European Union, Serbia and Kosovo signed an agreement last month to resolve disputes dating from the 1990s, when Kosovo, a former province of Yugoslavia, effectively won independence following a Western-led military intervention.

headline: Now the TV Heavyweights Have Their Week
text: IMAGINE that a heavyweight championship fight was preceded by three months of preliminary bouts. Wouldn’t everyone be punchy by the time the big event arrived?

headline: Bernanke, Blower of Bubbles?
text: Bubbles can be bad for your financial health — and bad for the health of the economy, too. The dot-com bubble of the late 1990s left behind many vacant buildings and many more failed dreams. When the housing bubble of the next decade burst, the result was the greatest economic crisis since the 1930s — a crisis from which we have yet to emerge.

headline: Far From China’s Bustling Cities, the Grind of Poverty
text: Not for the faint of heart or weak of bladder, Wang Bing’s two-and-a-half-hour “Three Sisters” documents extreme poverty in rural China with the compassionate eye and inexhaustible patience of a director whose curiosity about his country’s unfortunates never seems to wane.

headline: Started at the Bottom
text: Not long ago, I devoted a column to the mostly upper-middle-class students at elite universities — the empirical kids. I thought it would be interesting to devote a column to students who at least started at the other end of the social scale. So the Times researcher Anne Snyder and I interviewed a bunch of young people whom we had met earlier through the Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute.

headline: After Plant Explosion, Texas Remains Wary of Regulation
text: WEST, Tex. — Five days after an explosion at a fertilizer plant leveled a wide swath of this town, Gov. Rick Perry tried to woo Illinois business officials by trumpeting his state’s low taxes and limited regulations. Asked about the disaster, Mr. Perry responded that more government intervention and increased spending on safety inspections would not have prevented what has become one of the nation’s worst industrial accidents in decades.

headline: In Its Efforts to Integrate Roma, Slovakia Recalls U.S. Struggles
text: SARISSKE MICHALANY, Slovakia — Gazing out his window during morning recess on his first day at work, the principal of an elementary school here, Jaroslav Valastiak, was caught up short: all the children playing in the asphalt-covered yard were white, a strikingly monochromatic scene at a school where a majority of pupils are dark-skinned Roma.

headline: Civilization Comes Crashing Down
text: The first face we see in “Aftershock” belongs to Eli Roth, a sighting that will, depending on your moviegoing preferences, make you grin with anticipation or run for the exit. Yet despite Mr. Roth’s blood-drenched directing rap sheet (including “Cabin Fever” and both “Hostel” movies), this latest project — which he helped write and produce but left to Nicolás López to direct — is far more fixated on gasps than on gore.

headline: Slovakia Struggles to Desegregate Its Schools
text: An elementary school in eastern Slovakia is a microcosm of one of Europe’s biggest challenges: how to bring its most disadvantaged and fastest-growing minority into the mainstream.

headline: The Next Pandemic: Not if, but When
text: BOZEMAN, Mont.

headline: Former PTA Official Jailed After Failure to Repay Funds
text: Still owing more than $17,000 to the Parent-Teacher Association she stole from for two years, Providence Hogan, a former PTA treasurer at Public School 29 in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, was taken back into custody on Wednesday after she failed to make scheduled payments.

headline: Wartime Enemies Do an About-Face in Peacetime
text: In 1999 Dale Zelko, a husband and father from New Hampshire, was part of a NATO operation, flying an F-117A Nighthawk stealth fighter over Serbia. Zoltan Dani, a husband and father from Skorenovac, was a colonel in the Yugoslav Army. He shot down Mr. Zelko’s stealth bomber, becoming a national hero, having proved that there is no such thing as an invisible plane.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Neighborhood Joint: Scooter Bottega
text: The mechanics at Scooter Bottega in Brooklyn cater to an ever-growing clientele of riders across the city; the shop specializes in repairing vintage scooters, but also services new ones.

headline: How to Generate Distrust on Drones
text: President Obama says he wants greater transparency for the clandestine killing of terrorists overseas, largely using missiles fired by drones. There has been little public action on this pledge, but if he is serious, he should consider many of the recommendations made this week by a former legal adviser to the State Department, Harold Koh.

headline: A Sandy Hook Parent Finds His Voice in Moving Beyond ‘the Darkest Horror of It All’
text: NEWTOWN, Conn.

headline: The N.L.R.B.’s Contested Poster
text: The subject of the latest outrageous ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit is an 11-by-17-inch poster. The National Labor Relations Board requires nearly six million private employers to display the poster, which informs employees of their right to join or form a union or to take action together to improve their working conditions.

headline: The Republicans’ Benghazi Obsession
text: Before Wednesday’s hearing on the attack in Benghazi, Libya, Republicans in Congress promised explosive new details about the administration’s mishandling of the episode. Instead, the hearing showed, yet again, that sober fact-finding is not their mission. Common sense and good judgment have long given way to conspiracy-mongering and a relentless effort to discredit President Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: The Man They Trust With Their Keys
text: On a recent Saturday afternoon at the edge of Red Hook, the sun shone on a small flock of Vespas parked in front of Scooter Bottega’s electric-blue storefront. The block was quiet, but the tiny garage buzzed with machinery and the steady stream of riders rumbling up to the curb to hand their keys to Robbie Rhodes.

headline: From an Unfinished Canvas, a World Springs to Life
text: Ramo loves Claire, but he is an Alldunn, and she is a Halfie, and their romance is forbidden in the world of “Le Tableau,” a French animated film now released in English as “The Painting.”

headline: Emotional Recovery Seen Possible for Victims of Prolonged Abuse
text: Day after day, it was his voice they heard, his face they saw.

headline: Mideast Peace Talks
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Remedy for School Sports
text: To the Editor:

headline: Generic Biotech Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Health Law and Its Incentives
A Lost Soul Packs His Fiddle and Hits the Trail
text: One of the oldest human impulses when things turn bad has been to go for a walk: If life is confounding and overwhelming, if you’re just plain stuck, take a hike — it’ll clear the head, ideally the spirit.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 10, 2013
text: "The segregation here was as obvious as fireworks.”

headline: App-Armed and YouTube-Educated, Taking Care of My Baby
text: I took my car, after its winter storage, to a Manhattan dealership last month for a spring tune-up. This is the shop that years ago charged me about $99 — its hourly rate at the time, as I recall — to make a replacement ignition key. That won’t happen again; the hourly rate is now $129.95.

headline: Rivera Returning to Scene of His Injury
text: DENVER — Fifty-three weeks after Mariano Rivera sustained a season-ending knee injury in Kansas City while shagging fly balls, he vowed to return to the very site of the incident.

headline: Scott, Masters Champion, Guards Against Letdown
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — The high of winning the Masters lasted 24 days, 12 hours and 48 minutes, until Adam Scott stepped to the 10th tee at T.P.C. Sawgrass on Thursday for his first competitive shot since defeating Ángel Cabrera on the second playoff hole at Augusta National. To Scott’s mild dismay, he was introduced as the 2004 Players Champion but not the Masters champion.

headline: After the Breakup, the Revenge Movie
Citrus Disease With No Cure Is Ravaging Florida Groves
text: AVON PARK, Fla. — Florida’s citrus industry is grappling with the most serious threat in its history: a bacterial disease with no cure that has infected all 32 of the state’s citrus-growing counties.

headline: Francisco’s Progress May Force Mets to Choose
text: The Mets may soon face a difficult decision regarding the back end of the bullpen because Frank Francisco, on the disabled list with a right elbow injury, continues to pitch well in his minor league rehabilitation for Class A Port St. Lucie in Florida.

headline: Corrections: May 10, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Woods Was Behind Before He Even Started
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Tiger Woods had not hit a shot and he was nine strokes behind the first-round leader at the Players Championship. Roberto Castro finished his round of nine-under 63, which tied the course record, before Woods recorded a stroke in his round of 67, his lowest score here since the final day in 2007.

headline: Bollywood Without the Happy Ending
text: Though it sounds as if it should be a hoot, “Bunty Berman Presents ...” is mostly only a whimper. Watching the New Group’s amiable but listless musical sendup of Indian moviemaking, which opened on Thursday night at the Acorn Theater, you can discern the reproachful outlines of the bigger, brasher and more satisfyingly outrageous show it might have been.

headline: Where to Come to Grips With Things
text: Administrivial Really Cool Book Alert! Have you ever wondered how your favorite puzzles are made? The constructors have pulled back the curtain to allow you a glimpse into their craft, so you can learn to do it too! “Puzzlecraft” is an astounding collection of how-to’s written by puzzlers Mike Selinker and Thomas Snyder, and well worth the price. Check it out here.

headline: Bills Would Prevent Rise in Student Loan Rates
text: Congress now has an array of legislative options to prevent the interest rate on student loans from doubling to 6.8 percent on July 1, as scheduled.

headline: A Little Song and Dance for Survival
text: Brian Herzlinger’s “How Sweet It Is,” an ode to the healing powers of musical theater, misfires so badly at the beginning that it takes a while to notice when it goes from godawful to sweetly awful. Mr. Herzlinger, who wrote the script with Jay Black, comes out swinging, with cut-rate gags and unpleasant clichés, not to mention the treacly number that plays over the opening credits. (Sample lyric: “We still have a song to sing.”) It all but announces: Adjust your credibility meter and expectations way down.

headline: His Knee Fine, Knicks’ Shumpert Is Soaring Again

headline: Ex-Dictator Denies Role in Guatemalan Massacres
text: GUATEMALA CITY — Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt, the former dictator who ruled Guatemala during one of the bloodiest periods of its long civil war, faced the court trying him for genocide on Thursday and denied any role in the horrors narrated by Mayan survivors of massacres committed in the remote highlands three decades ago.

headline: Freed, but Not Really Out of Prison
text: Crime may not pay, but prison is the gift that keeps giving. According to “Released,” a stark documentary by Philip F. Messina, two-thirds of all inmates in the United States return to jail within three years of being freed. When ex-convicts re-enter society without having learned any coping skills, it’s small wonder that they wind up in trouble again.

headline: Yanks Show Resilience, Limiting Rockies Again

The expectations raised by the first 20 minutes, however, make it all the more disappointing when incoherent slaughter replaces soul-chilling dread.

He was 88.

headline: Texas: Web Site Removes Do-It-Yourself Gun Plans
text: A Web site run by a Texas law student has removed downloadable design files that can be used to make a gun with a 3-D printer after the State Department said that posting the files may violate arms-exporting regulations. In a letter to the student, Cody Wilson, a department official wrote that by posting the files, the site, defcad.org, may have released “technical data” without authorization. The files, for a simple gun called the Liberator, were posted this week along with a video showing the weapon, which is largely made of plastic, being fired. Mr. Wilson, who had earlier used 3-D printers to make parts of assault rifles, said that he would try to claim an exemption for the regulations because on the Internet the files would be in the public domain.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 12:45 P.M. (MoreMax) RUBY SPARKS (2012) Zoe Kazan wrote and stars in this variation on the Pygmalion myth as Ruby, a smart, saucy, 26-year-old redhead from Dayton, Ohio, who magically appears in Los Angeles seemingly without much control over her emotions. Paul Dano (above, with Ms. Kazan), Ms. Kazan’s real-life partner, is Calvin, a literary whiz kid turned blocked writer who breathes life into this figment of his imagination, and then directs her every move. The cast is filled out by Chris Messina as Calvin’s worried older brother, Harry, who finally confirms to Calvin — now concerned that he has gone crazy — that Ruby is not a hallucination. Annette Bening is the brothers’ mother, living a hippie life in Big Sur, Calif., with her lover (Antonio Banderas) and intent on seeing her youngest son happy, however odd the arrangement.

headline: Gin Doesn’t Make You Sad
text: Few spirits bear so heavy a semiotic burden as gin, which is regarded by many as mother’s ruin, the destroyer, the devil, the drink that shall not be named. More often than not, when I try to nudge wary customers gently toward gin (instead of, you know, vodka), they look at me as if I’ve offered them a live grenade. This bad rap, I think, is partly the fault of the English artist William Hogarth. The gin of 18th-century England — harsh and cheap — is very different from what we drink now, but anyone who was shown a slide of Hogarth’s “Gin Lane” in history class is unlikely to forget the images of those dissolute Londoners: here, a man fighting a dog for a bone; there, a woman dropping her baby over a railing.

headline: Should I Protect a Patient at the Expense of an Innocent Stranger?
text: I am a physician. Years ago, I saw a young patient with headaches, who disclosed — reluctantly — that he had committed a serious crime and that somebody else took the fall for it. I believe he was telling me the truth (his headaches soon resolved after the confession). Before his admission, I assured him that whatever he told me would not leave the room. Later, without giving specifics, I consulted our hospital lawyer, who told me that we were under no obligation to report the incident, because the patient wasn’t in danger of hurting himself or others. But the future of an innocent man hinges on two people’s consciences, my patient’s and my own. I feel like a coward, hiding behind the Hippocratic oath, doing nothing. NAME WITHHELD

headline: What Cecile Richards Has Learned From Todd Akin
text: In 2008, for only the second time in history, Planned Parenthood endorsed a presidential candidate in Barack Obama. Do you think this resulted in Congress’s efforts in 2011 to defund the organization?  Not at all. In 2010, the Tea Party came after everything — Roe, birth control, they tried to overturn the family-planning law that Nixon signed into law and Planned Parenthood too. We were just part of a much bigger effort to repeal decades of progress on women’s health and rights.

headline: Confessions of an Art Conservator’s Sidekick
text: Out in Malibu, the billionaire’s gardener has nicked a bronze with his weed whacker. In Echo Park, the Lady of the Lake is missing her benediction hand. Who knows how long it was there? No matter. A few brush strokes with warm distilled water, and she is returned to immodesty once more.

headline: Who Made That Digital Camouflage?
text: “I was basically designated the weird-projects officer,” says Timothy O’Neill, who worked with an Army team to improve the camouflage painted on tanks in the early 1970s. At the time, the military covered its vehicles with suitcase-size splotches of green and brown. The pattern could trick the eye at a distance, but it didn’t work well at close range. O’Neill set out to find a better solution. At the Aberdeen Proving Ground, a test site in Maryland, he and his team put an armored personnel carrier out in a field and painted it with two-inch squares in woodland colors. From far away, the flecks seemed to coalesce into a large pattern, so that the vehicle blended with the trees behind it. The tiny squares also mimicked close-up details: individual leaves, tufts of grass and shadows on a branch. O’Neill’s tests showed that this digital camouflage — as it would later be called — fooled the eye into seeing tank and landscape as one.

headline: The “OMG, Who Is O.M.D.?” Playlist
text: When I was a teenager, there was nothing in the world I liked half as much as my Walkman. I listened to it compulsively, like an addict, blasting music into my head and causing major damage to my ears. As mind-blowingly wonderful as it is to now carry 25,000 songs in my pocket, the Walkman forced a deeper engagement with the music you loved. Nobody carried around lots of cassettes. Maybe one or two extra. And if you were like me, you often kept the same one in there for weeks at a time, creating an intimacy that seems quaint now. Fast-forwarding and rewinding were a drag, so you tended to listen through entire albums, sometimes falling in love with songs you hated on first listen. This was commitment. The melodies and lyrics on these albums in particular — “Hatful of Hollow,” by the Smiths; “Murmur,” by R.E.M.; “Let It Be,” by the Replacements; “Head on the Door,” by the Cure; and “Architecture & Morality,” by Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark — are practically etched on the inside of my skull.

headline: Inside the List
text: RESETTING THE CLOCK: What current best seller has been on the list the longest? At 287 weeks, the winner is “Percy Jackson & the Olympians,” by Rick Riordan, which you’ll find on the children’s series list at No. 8. Second place goes to “The Devil in the White City,” by Erik Larson, at No. 18 on the paperback nonfiction list after 267 weeks, while another children’s series, Jeff Kinney’s “Diary of a Wimpy Kid” (at No. 3 on that list), has stuck around for 225 weeks.

headline: Regrets Only
text: What does it mean to say “I’m sorry”? Increasingly, in this age of ceremonial, highly ritualized apology, it’s hard to distinguish between true remorse and savvy public relations. Jonathan Dee’s sixth novel, “A Thousand Pardons,” was written before Lance Armstrong’s public shaming, but it speaks to something similar in the zeitgeist: the idea of confession as business strategy. Is reputation just a form of capital? What does it mean to apologize publicly for private sins, or privately for public ones? When one person grants another forgiveness, which of them is redeemed?
