headline: Seussian Software
text: Judging by the frequent sight of youngsters grabbing for Mom’s smartphone at the table and toting Dad’s tablet on car trips, it’s a safe assumption that touch screens have captured the attention of many children. But for parents (or grandparents) overwhelmed by the abundance of age-appropriate software, it helps to look for familiar faces in the crowd. Several internationally popular 20th-century children’s book characters have expanded beyond the confines of the printed page into the world of apps.

headline: Eternal Flame
text: “Are you or are you not a good girl?” Edna O’Brien’s mother wants to know. The options are telling; they imply a less-than-even division of territory. Imagine a small saintly island, surrounded by a raging, pagan sea of non-goodness, mortal sin and diabolical decadence. The miniature haven is, of course, Ireland. And at the time Lena O’Brien poses the question, in the early hours of the morning, from the bed in which she has listened for her delinquent daughter’s footsteps, Edna O’Brien has fled the country, at least physically.

headline: Trash and the City
text: If the Police Department represents New York’s Finest and the Fire Department New York’s Bravest, what about the Sanitation Department? Could New York’s Strongest also qualify as New York’s Most Invisible? Writing about Sanitation’s “consistent state of not-there-ness,” Robin Nagle comments that workers are “willfully unseen by the public.”

headline: Bad News for Baby
text: Americans, you may have noticed, live in a capitalist society. In practical terms, this means someone is often trying to sell us something. John Updike saw a kind of glory in this: “America is a vast conspiracy to make you happy,” he wrote. Jennifer Margulis sees a vast conspiracy too, only its purpose is to make you miserable, sick and quite possibly dead, especially if you are a pregnant woman or a new mother.

headline: Planet Waves
text: Set in the scorching heat of the Egyptian desert at the end of the 19th century, Ken Kalfus’s new novel follows a fictional British astronomer’s attempt to make contact with Mars. Hundreds of thousands of men are digging the gigantic equilateral triangle with which Sanford Thayer intends to send a signal to his fellow astronomers on the red planet. Once finished, each side will consist of a paved trench more than 300 miles long and exactly one seventy-third of Earth’s circumference. The trenches, five miles wide, are deep enough to be filled with a 12-inch layer of petroleum that will flow from 309 taps connected to a pipeline. The huge black triangle set against the white desert sand will prove the existence of terrestrial intelligence to the Martians, Thayer argues, because the equal-sided triangle is part of the two planets’ “shared knowledge of trigonometry.” The equilateral triangle is, he believes, the “basis for all human art and construction.”

headline: Killing Machine
text: It’s hard to remember, but for the last quarter of the 20th century, the C.I.A. took no part in assassinating bad guys. How the agency transformed itself into “a killing machine, an organization consumed with manhunting,” is the subject of Mark Mazzetti’s fascinating, trenchant, sometimes tragicomic account, “The Way of the Knife.”

headline: The Graduate
text: Pop quiz: you are writing an insightful, strange, funny and dark investigation into a family of four coming together for the younger daughter’s high school graduation. Who will be your point-of-view character?

headline: The Postcolonial
text: Albert Camus was that rare writer who enjoyed a celebrity usually reserved for rock stars, even while being taken very seriously as an artist and a public intellectual. His first novel, “The Stranger,” published in 1942 when he was 29, made him famous; after that came more novels, plays, lyrical essays, short stories, two major philosophical works (“The Myth of Sisyphus” and “The Rebel”), and countless newspaper articles, editorials and political commentaries. In 1957, at age 44, he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature, the second-youngest writer ever to receive the prize (after Rud­yard Kipling). Less than three years later, in January 1960, he was killed in a car crash; people the world over mourned.

headline: Spectral Souls
text: Over the past century, the Russian writer Nikolai Leskov (1831-95) has been repeatedly rediscovered. As Richard Pevear points out in the introduction to “The Enchanted Wanderer” — a collection of 17 stories vibrantly translated by Pevear and Larissa ­Volokhonsky — this has happened at least three times. The first rediscovery took place during Leskov’s own lifetime: in the 1880s, after he had suffered for years “an almost total critical neglect,”the young Chekhov hailed his oeuvre, declaring him “a mixture of an elegant Frenchman and a defrocked priest.” Leskov, Chekhov continued, “was considerable.”In the 1920s, the formalist critic Boris Eikhenbaum discerned Leskov’s influence in the work of such diverse writers as Andrei Bely, Isaac Babel and Maxim Gorky, who frankly “declared himself Leskov’s disciple.”And again, at the hands of critics like Walter Benjamin and Irving Howe, Leskov was the subject of yet another revival. “To go back to certain earlier writers is to regain a sense of human possibility,” Howe wrote. “To go back to Leskov is to regain a sense of the passion, sometimes the joy, that can be part of the human enterprise.” Now, thanks to this delicious new collection, the time is once again ripe for Leskov’s resurgence.

headline: Ask Well: Replacing a Dental Crown
text: Question:

headline: Lost and Found
text: Nao, a 16-year-old schoolgirl, is in a cafe in Tokyo, writing in her diary. She is, she declares, a “time being,” with all the ambiguity that phrase implies. Many months later, after Japan’s devastating earthquake and tsunami, a Japanese-American novelist named Ruth, living on an island off the coast of British Columbia, finds a barnacle-encrusted freezer bag washed up on the beach. It contains, it appears, a copy of Proust’s “In Search of Lost Time” and a broken watch, along with some letters. But Proust’s book is no more than a cover. Inside is Nao’s diary, written in purple ink.

headline: Things Haven’t Gone Exactly as Planned
text: “For a certain kind of teenager, a small town is a prison. For another kind, it is a stage.” The speaker is a smart high school girl working at the town’s diner, watching “the athletes and beauty queens who’d blossomed early and fierce,” and the setting is Bakerton, a western Pennsylvania coal-mining town, where Jennifer Haigh’s 2005 novel “Baker Towers” was also set. The 10 stories in “News From Heaven” move chronologically from the town’s modest boom before World War II to its postindustrial depletion as the mines close, one by one:

headline: Late Bloomers
text: From the knowing grandmother in the novel “Tending to Virginia” to the failing mother stressing out her daughter in the short story “Going Away Shoes,” elderly characters have always played their parts in Jill McCorkle’s small-town, intergenerational fiction. But the “manly voice” with “pipes and whistles in his sound,” as Shakespeare put it, reverberates in its own distinctive fashion in the retirement home setting of McCorkle’s new novel, where the yoga class finds “a whole roomful of old folks breathing deeply and chanting — one sounding like a sewing machine and another a squirrel.”

headline: Packing the Courts
text: More than two decades ago, when I was a law student, I used to sneak into meetings of the conservative Federalist Society for lunchtime conversations about constitutional issues. Although neither conservative nor a Republican, I had libertarian leanings and appreciated the society’s openness to debating its political opponents. I felt slightly illicit in crossing ideological lines: once, when the dean spotted me leaving a meeting, I felt as if I’d been caught walking out of an X-rated movie. But the discussions themselves were always intellectually engaging, and my fellow law students seemed more interested in converging around a shared approach to interpreting the Constitution than in squabbling about partisan differences.

headline: NBC News Is Said to Pick a Woman as Its Chief
text: NBC News is on the verge of naming Deborah Turness, the head of ITV News in Britain, as its next president, according to several people with knowledge of the appointment.

headline: The One Least Likely
text: There’s always a boy, and there’s always a girl. They may not like each other at first, but they find a way to work together. Friendship always blossoms, sometimes romance. There’s a society they have to fight against and a secret to uncover that changes the world. They win in the end, though there’s heartbreak along the way and more danger ahead.

headline: What Price Beauty?
text: When I was 5 years old, my mother explained the world to me: “Beauty is pain,” she said, yanking my hair into submission with Dippity Do-slimed fingers and some bobby pins. If I didn’t sleep in scalp-scraping pin curls to look my best for Sunday school, the terrorists would win.

headline: Over, Under and Through
text: Spring is for busting out and rediscovering the world, so these four picture books come along just in time to help kids do some exploring — from the backyard to overseas to underseas to outer space — and they all let the visuals lead the charge.

headline: Endangered Daughters
text: Middle-grade and adult fiction share territory largely ignored by young adult literature: the exploration of countries and eras beyond the borders of the contemporary teenager’s navel. Two new middle-grade novels, “The Vine Basket,” by Josanne La Valley, and “A Girl Called Problem,” by Katie Quirk, are set, respectively, in a Uighur community in Central Asia and rural Tanzania in the late 1960s.

headline: The Playing’s the Thing
text: Leopold Mozart shuttled Wolfgang Amadeus around Europe for years, parading his son in front of endless royalty to secure commissions and performances. More than two centuries later, a bullying stage father helped propel the Chinese pianist Lang Lang to superstardom.

headline: The Stuff of Legend
text: Want to write a middle-grade fantasy adventure series? It’s easy! First, conjure up a plucky, prickly team of three — children who have to learn to trust one another and work together. Make the stakes really high; saving the world is always good. Use lots of wisecracking humor. Ensure the parents are absent (dead, missing, away — you’ll figure it out). Invoke classic themes and figures from folklore and mythology, but don’t bother becoming slavishly wedded to them. Be sure to include an intellectually or physically butt-kicking girl.

headline: Rites of Passage
text: For some girls who grew up in suburbia in the ’80s and early ’90s, the defining cultural touchstone of the time might be New Kids on the Block or “Saved by the Bell.” For me, it’s “The Baby-Sitters Club,” Ann M. Martin’s block­buster middle-grade series.

headline: Fragile Things
text: In Holly Black’s newest middle-grade novel, “Doll Bones,” the main characters, Zach, Poppy and Alice, are at that intermediate stage between childhood and adolescence, when alliances shift and friendships subtly develop into something more, when children outgrow identities as quickly as they outgrow clothing, when boys and girls sometimes appear awkwardly patched together with emotional and physical features from various stages of development, like an evolutionary experiment gone haywire. For years, the three best friends have played a continuous, ever evolving game of make-believe embracing fictional kingdoms, characters and allegiances, using toy figurines and hastily assembled objects to stand in for the real thing. The Queen, a porcelain doll with vacant eyes and blond ringlet curls, presides over the kingdoms from her position in Poppy’s mom’s glassed-in cabinet.

headline: Ordinary Courage
text: Historical fiction has an interesting place in the world of children’s literature. Regularly celebrated by adults with awards like the Newbery, these books nonetheless raise the question of whether the intended audience feels the same enthusiasm. What I’ve observed as a classroom teacher is that while not in the multitudes that flock to the goofy fun of Wimpy Kid or the wild fantasies of Percy Jackson, there are still plenty of young readers who can’t get enough of the past.

headline: Uneven Field
text: Of all the young adult genres — the Dystopian Hellscape, the ­Human-Monster Romance, the Elite School-or-Camp for Nonmortals — the most popular right now may be the quietest: Aspiring John Green. GreenLit, as I like to call it, consists of realistic stories told by a funny, self-aware teenage narrator. These novels tend to have sharp dialogue, defective authority figures, occasional boozing, unrequited crushes and one or more heartbreaking twists.

headline: Make No Mistake
text: James, a scrawny, thoughtful 15-year-old, is trapped in brutal penury in upstate New York. His father walked out long ago. His defeated mother, a barely functioning cocktail waitress, has brought home an abusive addict of a boyfriend. And his older brother, Louis, who left in a fury, is a muscle-bound drug dealer whom the police have in their sights.

headline: All in the Family
text: Extended family is not in the full-time business of being your family, and that is mostly to their advantage. They visit, they leave — even when they live with you, it is rarely forever.

headline: The Stratospherians
text: No sooner do acquisitive urbanites negotiate their peace with the manic pulse of New York City than some escape it without actually leaving. The strategy is an aggressively vertical lifestyle, and prescient developers are enabling it.

headline: Common Core Practice | Hit Films, Glowing Trees and an Underwater Menagerie
text: A few weeks ago, Mrs. Gross, Mr. Olsen and their students explored how they might pair Times content with basic computer coding to practice Common Core skills. This week they show how the news and the standards can be jumping-off points for exploring video design and gaming.

headline: Married With Children, a Dedication That Held It All Together
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Gatsby in a Duesenberg? More Fiction
text: Jay Gatsby, the mysterious title character of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s “The Great Gatsby,” fancied luxury cars, but he would not have been driving a 1929 Duesenberg Model J.

headline: Paperback Row
text: HOUSE OF STONE: A Memoir of Home, Family, and a Lost Middle East,  by Anthony Shadid. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $15.95.) In 2006, after years spent covering the Iraq war, Shadid began renovating the abandoned house of his great-grandfather in the Lebanese town of Marjayoun. (A correspondent for The New York Times, Shadid died last year while reporting from Syria.) This elegiac memoir combines stories of Shadid’s struggles with workmen, tales of his ancestors and their world, and reflections on his family’s journey to America.

headline: Considering the Universe From Deep in West Texas
text: FORT DAVIS, Tex. — With a lime-green fleece blanket over his shoulders, Samuel David, 10, of Houston, bounced on his toes as dusk raced over the mountains. Attending his first Texas Star Party this week with his family, Samuel could not wait for a rare phenomenon in a lighted-up, night-denying world — a sky full of nothing but stars.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: A DELICATE TRUTH,  by John le Carré. (Viking, $28.95.) Le Carré seems to hold the moral relativism of his old cold-war heroes up to a harsh light in his 23rd novel, in which — to the benefit of a private American security firm — “war’s gone corporate.”

headline: The Demented Imagineer
text: “Now, I see this as pantsless,” the artist Paul McCarthy announced one winter morning to a group of male actors standing at the edge of a massive soundstage in a warehouse east of downtown Los Angeles, flanked by a plumbing supply and an auto impound yard. Normally, McCarthy looks like a hipster carpenter, broad and bandylegged, with gnarled fingers and wiry white hair poking out around his baseball cap. But this morning he was nearly unrecognizable in a tuxedo and gray toupee, a regal prosthetic nose glued over a neatly trimmed mustache.

headline: Singing Proust
text: Kelli O’Hara sings the love song “If It Is True,” accompanied on piano by composer Ricky Ian Gordon. Gordon’s music was inspired by the work of Marcel Proust.

headline: Rummaging Among Skins and Skulls
text: Mary E. Blair is a postdoctoral researcher in the American Museum of Natural History’s Center for Biodiversity and Conservation, where she coordinates the Enhancing Diversity in Conservation Science Initiative.

headline: Getting the Full Picture on Annuities and Insurance
text: LIFE insurance and annuities are supposed to accomplish straightforward goals: life insurance provides for your family if you die unexpectedly and annuities guarantee a steady stream of income in retirement. But right now, both are being promoted for their tax benefits.

headline: When Taxes Aren’t the Only Consideration
text: Paul Sullivan’s Wealth Matters column this week is about the marketing of two straightforward financial products — life insurance and annuities — for their tax benefits. As Paul has written before, the increase in taxes this year is prompting many people to make taxes their priority — it’s determining what to invest in or how to set up their estate or buying life insurance — when taxes should be only one factor in the decision.

headline: Set to Lead, From the Podium Anyway
text: It’s one week and counting until James Levine’s return to the podium.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Origins of World War I and More
text: This week, Harold Evans discusses two new books about the events leading up to World War I; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Pamela Paul talks about the spring children’s books section; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: If You Knew Then What You Know Now
text: When you live in a foreign country, a lot more than you might have expected can be foreign.

headline: In Big-Dollar Philanthropy, (Your Name Here) vs. Anonymity
text: One hundred million dollars. As The New York Times reported this week, that’s how much Ronald O. Perelman pledged to Columbia University for the planned Ronald O. Perelman Center for Business Innovation. It’s the amount Stephen A. Schwarzman promised to the New York Public Library, which renamed its main building after him.

headline: Kicking Off Uncomfortable Toe Shoes
text: For the past year, Pam Tanowitz has been haunted by a ballet. Her own.

headline: Blind Teenagers Compete in Pole Vault
text: The legally blind students Charlotte Brown and Aria Ottmueller practice and compete in the pole vault.

headline: It’s Just Another Hurdle for Blind Athletes
text: CHANDLER, Ariz. — Holding a fiberglass pole, Aria Ottmueller bent and touched the runway to locate her starting mark. A coach helped position her front foot. The foam vaulting pit at her high school appeared only as a blue smudge. The crossbar was invisible to her.

headline: In Nature | Room With a View
text: Some of the most thrilling nuances of a great landscape only become apparent in the brightness of dawn or when the afternoon light casts sharp shadows. But since many of the best gardens are private, gaining access to them at these magic hours can be a challenge. Thankfully, this is changing, as hoteliers across the globe have tapped major landscape architects to plant and design the greenery around their hotels. The result: a set of properties with outdoor spaces that are destinations in and of themselves. From the manicured grounds of a manor house in the Cotswolds, to a walled courtyard in Stockholm, to a working Cape Dutch farm in South Africa (and even to the lush tropicals planted by Arnaud MauriËres and Eric Ossart at Dar Al Hossoun in Morocco), these are gardens worth traveling for.

headline: Student Debt Slows Growth as Young Spend Less
text: The anemic economy has left millions of younger working Americans struggling to get ahead. The added millstone of student loan debt, which recently exceeded $1 trillion in total, is making it even harder for many of them, delaying purchases of things like homes, cars and other big-ticket items and acting as a drag on growth, economists said.

headline: Think of It This Way: Stairs Are an Amenity
text: Having visited Manhattan on several occasions, Sofia and Christian Hasselberg of Stockholm knew New York was one place they wished to live.

headline: Own a Mysterious Artifact? Go Show It to a Scientist
text: Life is full of mysteries. Some lives are full of mysterious objects. The necklace-looking thing you found on the beach that looks as if it probably came from an animal or maybe a plant. That rock your grandfather always told you was a meteorite. The dead turtle in a box on your desk — bog turtle or box turtle?

headline: A ‘Cagney & Lacey’ With Constables
text: One of the more interesting crime dramas currently on either side of the Atlantic started with a concept that was only about three decades old.

headline: Garbled Noise, Playful Blues and Whispery Echoes
text: The Fall

headline: TowerBrook to Purchase True Religion Apparel for $835 Million
text: It’s a high-priced deal for high-priced denim.

headline: “Maxwell”
text: A new song by Terre Roche.

headline: In a Pickle
text: Barbecue season is just around the corner, which means that it’s time to break out the Mason jars and make some crisp, briny pickles to accompany your smoky sandwiches and slaw. But why should pickling be relegated to cucumbers alone? In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman writes:

headline: The Gun Report: May 10, 2013
text: Did you know that some sex offenders in Iowa can openly carry guns? An astute reader pointed us to this recent exclusive in The Des Moines Register, which revealed that 50 sex offenders in Iowa are currently carrying a gun in public. It’s news that has surprised some state lawmakers and alarmed a few Iowa and national law enforcement officers, Jason Clayworth reported.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Tyler Brûlé and Jan Morris
text: A dual review of what’s new, by magazine impresario Tyler Brûlé and Welsh historian Jan Morris. See the chart, and watch the stop-motion airplane safety video for VistaJet, below.

headline: Hip-Hop Stars as Disposable Spokesmen
text: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the conflicts between commercial interests and art in several recent cases of rappers losing corporate endorsement deals over their edgy content.

headline: United Nations Agency to Discuss Internet Governance Again
text: Here we go again. The United Nations is trying to take over the Internet! Or maybe it isn’t.

headline: A Pioneer, Reluctantly
text: SCHAUMBURG, Ill. — Fallon Fox climbed inside the steel cage, past the sign that read “The Beating Will Continue,” and onto a black mat. She followed right jabs with left hooks and kicks flung at imaginary kneecaps, safe, if only for a moment, from the questions and insults and the suffocating fame that descended overnight.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Everyone’s Nostalgia
text: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about how we’re permanently nostalgic for everything: music, clothing, our own lives, and now, the World Wide Web.

headline: Rescue in Bangladesh
text: How a woman trapped beneath the rubble of a collapsed building in Bangladesh was able to survive for over two weeks before being rescued.

headline: Airplane Safety Video
text: Tom Sachs and Van Neistat's stop-motion safety video for VistaJet.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Stratford, Ontario; Nashville; Venice
text: Venice Biennale This biennial exhibition, dedicated to chronicling contemporary art, opens June 1, with artists’ works (colorful gondolas from 2011, above) showcased in pavilions divided according to country. Angola, Maldives and the Republic of Kosovo are among the 10 countries that will participate for the first time in the exhibition, which spreads across the Giardini park and the winding galleries of the Arsenale.

headline: How to Stop Government
text: In a recent Pew Poll, 80 percent of respondents said the president and Republican leaders were not working together to address important issues — and, by a two-to-one margin, said the G.O.P. was more to blame for gridlock.

headline: Obama to Bookend Group of Eight Summit With Belfast and Berlin Visits
text: President Obama and his wife, Michelle, will make a three-day trip to the United Kingdom and Germany around the Group of Eight summit in June, the White House said Friday.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Origins of World War I
text: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Harold Evans reviews two new books about the complicated web of events leading up to World War I: “The Sleepwalkers,” by Christopher Clark, and “July 1914,” by Sean McMeekin. Mr. Evans writes:

headline: Wheelies: The Best-Car-Ever Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Dream Is a Wish Your Id Makes
text: There’s certainly a twinkle in Uncle Walt’s blue eyes, but it’s not the glimmer of benevolence you’d expect from the man who brought joy to countless children as the creator of Mickey Mouse and the Magic Kingdom.

headline: Hey Mom, Call Me When You Find My Wife
text: Some mothers — and some fathers, too — will do just about anything to see their marriage-age offspring settle down, even if that means going where parents ordinarily should never go — online and into their children’s posted dating profiles.

headline: Heat-Trapping Gas Passes Milestone, Raising Fears
text: The level of the most important heat-trapping gas in the atmosphere, carbon dioxide, has passed a long-feared milestone, scientists reported Friday, reaching a concentration not seen on the earth for millions of years.

headline: Sport Gains Hoofhold on a Scholastic Level
text: Many polo players will tell you that it is not really the horses that most effectively propel them across the field, it is the adrenaline.

headline: Popcast: Hip-Hop Stars as Disposable Spokesmen
text: Advertisers, theoretically, love hip-hop. They love it until it gets loud and messy, challenges taste and morals, causes offense. And then advertisers pull away.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Going Way Back
text: In this week’s video, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about how we’re permanently nostalgic for everything: music, clothing, our own lives, and now, the World Wide Web.

headline: Technology as a Driver of Growth (or Not)
text: 4:21 p.m. | Updated with table on relative adoption levels.

headline: Charles Read’s Raider
text: On May 6, 1863, the same day that Gen. Joseph Hooker’s Union Army retreated northward over the Rappahannock River following defeat at Chancellorsville, Va., Second Lt. Charles Read of the Confederate commerce raider Florida began one of the most astonishing adventures of the war.

headline: Caregiver and Patient, Bound by Blood and Whining
text: “We’re on the same side.”

headline: Rangers’ Staal Says He Decided to Sit Out Game 4
text: WASHINGTON — Speaking to reporters for the first time since his surprising absence from Game 4 because of the lingering effects of an eye injury, defenseman Marc Staal explained Friday that it was his decision to sit out, and that he was not sure when he would come back.

headline: Russian Revelation
text: Not long ago, a woman in Florida contacted Vika Gazinskaya, a designer in Moscow, and bought $12,000 worth of clothes. Ms. Gazinskaya’s designs can be seen online, and purchased at Net-a-Porter, Moda Operandi and the Manhattan boutique Fivestory, as well as Forty Five Ten in Dallas. Maybe it didn’t occur to the Florida woman to contact those outlets, or maybe there were sizing or availability issues, but she ended up writing a letter to the designer.

headline: A Social Media View of the Davos of Hedge Funds
text: A look at some of the social media dispatches from SALT conference in Las Vegas. The SkyBridge Alternatives Conference brings together more than 1,800 wealthy investors and hedge funds for four days of conferences, concerts and revelry.

headline: A Creative Partnership, in Life and in Art
text: The first time Yotam Haber was introduced to Anna Schuleit, in 2010 at the MacDowell artists retreat in Peterborough, N.H., she was helping a fellow artist bend steel spikes over a flame. She wore a bandanna over her blond hair and seemed utterly dedicated to her task — so much so that she took no notice of him. Still, he thought “she had an aura.”

headline: Singer Accused of Trying to Hire Hitman Pleads Not Guilty
text: Prosecutors say the lead singer of the band As I Lay Dying, who is accused of trying to hire someone to kill his estranged wife, handed an envelope containing $1,000 in cash to an undercover officer, along with instructions, a photograph, an address, security gate codes and dates when he would have an alibi, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Mockumentary Digs for Roots
text: When Christopher Guest has his director’s hat on, as for films like “Best in Show” and “A Mighty Wind,” droll is generally the order of the day. He carries that tradition to the small screen with “Family Tree,” a new comedy series that he created with Jim Piddock, which has its premiere Sunday night on HBO. The show, shot mockumentary style, centers on a 30-year-old named Tom Chadwick (Chris O’Dowd) who inherits a trunk that is full of family memorabilia. He begins poking through it and tries to learn more about the family members he encounters, beginning in the premiere with the man in full uniform whose photograph he finds.

headline: Indie in Brooklyn, Electric in Queens
text: It’s May, and dueling outdoor festivals have arrived. There’s a clear aesthetic choice — synthetic and transnational versus handmade and local — between Electric Daisy Carnival, at Citi Field on Friday and Saturday, and the Great Googa Mooga Festival, in Prospect Park Friday to Sunday. Electric Daisy presents more than 80 electronic dance music acts on five stages in and around the stadium. Trance, house, techno and dubstep dominate the lineup, with acts like Steve Angello, Dirty South, Afrojack, Richie Hawtin and 12th Planet. (electricdaisycarnival.com; two-day tickets are $239.83 general admission, one-day $132.05.)

headline: Sweden and Israel Via Chicago
text: When it comes to trendy, glamorous repertory, it’s hard to think of an American company as well stocked as Hubbard Street Dance Chicago. The list of choreographers who have worked with this immaculately technical group reads like an international who’s who of contemporary dance. Take, for instance, Sweden’s Mats Ek, revered in Europe but rarely seen in the United States; Aszure Barton, originally from Alberta, Canada; and Israel’s Ohad Naharin, the director of the Batsheva Dance Company, whose improvisation method, Gaga, has a global following.

headline: From Romanticism To Apocalypse
text: Though the conductor Simon Rattle’s work has been defined for over a decade by his adventurous tenure as principal conductor of the great Berlin Philharmonic, he has continued to maintain associations with other important ensembles, especially the Philadelphia Orchestra. As a guest conductor, Mr. Rattle will lead the orchestra in its Carnegie Hall concert on Friday night. The program opens with Webern’s Passacaglia, Op. 1, a glittering score written in 1908 when the composer was in his mid-20s and still under the allure of lush, late Romanticism. Then Mr. Rattle conducts Three Fragments from Berg’s opera “Wozzeck.”

headline: New Cooking Show on Fox to Feature Children as Chefs
text: How else to tinker with cooking reality shows? How about putting children in the kitchen?

headline: At Met, Park Views Big and Small
text: In 1998 when Ellsworth Kelly became the first living artist to exhibit on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he called the picture-postcard setting “an instant background.” When his sculptures — as tall as 14 feet — were installed there they looked enormous and the skyscrapers behind them tiny. Mr. Kelly compared this reversal of scale to Chinese landscape painting in the way it played with perspective.

headline: Judge Refuses to Drop His Order Allowing Morning-After Pill for All Ages
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Friday stepped up his criticism of the Obama administration, accusing the Justice Department of making “frivolous” and “silly” arguments in its attempt to delay making the morning-after emergency contraceptive pill available to women and girls of all ages without a prescription.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. to Investigate Corvette Headlight Failures
text: After receiving complaints from owners of 2005-7 Chevrolet Corvettes about low-beam headlights failing, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is opening an investigation, according to a report posted on the agency’s Web site. The action comes as the agency continues to mull over whether to investigate low-beam failures on about 248,000 General Motors crossovers.

headline: Early Salvos From ‘Bloody Sam’
text: Sam Peckinpah’s life, like many of his movies, ended in a kind of apocalyptic debacle. Too many arguments with producers, too much alcohol-fueled misbehavior and (always the real problem) too many disappointments at the box office had rendered the director of “The Wild Bunch” (1969) effectively unemployable by the time he died in 1984, at 59.

headline: Small-Batch Pulled Pork
text: Melissa Clark demonstrates a way to make tender pulled pork slathered in a tangy barbecue sauce for a smaller crowd.

headline: A Midsummer Day’s Dream in Sweden
text: “Bring wine? To Midsummer? That is a funny joke,” said my Aunt Anna-Greta with a hearty peal of laughter and a knee slap. “Maybe you think you are in Italy!”

headline: A Long, Lively Swedish Party
text: Welcome to Midsummer, where the fun includes everything from flowers to a feast.

headline: I.R.S. Apologizes to Tea Party Groups Over Audits of Applications for Tax Exemption
text: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service apologized to Tea Party groups and other conservative organizations on Friday for what it now says were overzealous audits of their applications for tax-exempt status.

headline: Tasting ‘Modern Hungarian’ in Budapest
text: Budapest is a city of coat-takers. Walk into any restaurant, no matter how humble, and you will barely be through the door before someone is graciously easing you out of your wrap. That warm hospitality, coupled with menus filled with creamy soups and meaty stews, can make dining in this city feel like stepping back in time. But all is not so sepia-tinged. A movement that began several years ago toward lighter and brighter food, served in more modern environs, has been gathering steam.

headline: Bookshelf: Bicycles
text: New picture books about people of all ages and their bikes.

headline: Bookshelf: Misbehavior
text: New picture books about throwing things, pitching fits and breaking the rules.

headline: Smaller Forkfuls of Pulled Pork
text: The first time I made pulled pork, it involved a huge seven-pound bone-in pork butt and an entire day of gentle smoking on the barbecue. It fed a backyard full of guests, and there were plenty of leftovers, too.

headline: James Levine Returns
text: On May 19 at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Levine will conduct the Met Orchestra in his first performance in over two years.

headline: Bookshelf: Misbehavior
text: TIME-OUT FOR SOPHIE  Written and illustrated by Rosemary Wells.  32 pp. Viking. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

headline: An Indiana Town Where Big Names Built
text: Before he helped bring the Finnish architect Eliel Saarinen to his hometown to design one of the first contemporary churches in America; before he commissioned Eliel’s son, Eero, to design an elegant midcentury modern house for his young family; and before he turned Columbus, Ind., into a living museum of striking 20th-century modern architecture, J. Irwin Miller lived in a large 19th-century house that could not have been more of a contrast to the Modernist buildings that have put this rural city on the map.

headline: Bookshelf: Bicycles
text: EVERYONE CAN LEARN TO RIDE A BICYCLE  Written and illustrated by Chris Raschka.  32 pp. Schwartz & Wade. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

headline: An Unlikely Architecture Hub
text: In Columbus, Ind., the buildings are a star attraction.

headline: Blogger Emerges From Hiding After Fleeing Bahrain
text: After months of secret plans that involved disguises, code names and a body double, a prominent blogger who had been sentenced in absentia to 15 years in prison for his activism in Bahrain has fled the country by hiding in a compartment in a car, according to media reports and human rights groups.

headline: Common Sense: The Fight for Cooper Union
text: Cooper Union, once a premier institution of higher learning with free tuition, will begin charging students. The Times’s James B. Stewart and Marcus Mabry discuss how it mishandled its endowment.

headline: Still Licensed to Be Indie
Food Matters | When Eating and Art Became One
text: A few months before the artists Carol Goodden and Gordon Matta-Clark opened their restaurant-slash-art installation, FOOD, on the corner of Prince and Wooster Streets in New York City in the fall of 1971, they roasted a pig beneath the Brooklyn Bridge. Alanna Heiss, who would soon found P.S.1, installed work by Matta-Clark, Carl Andre, Sol Le Witt and Keith Sonnier in a raw, junk-filled space. On nearby Pier 14, Philip Glass performed and the year-old avant-garde theater company Mabou Mines staged a Samuel Beckett play. The artist Tina Girouard, who would cook at FOOD during its nearly three-year run, helped out with the hog. “The pig burnt on the outside,” she recalled, “and raw on the inside.”

headline: How Cooper Union’s Endowment Failed in Its Mission
text: Since Peter Cooper’s heirs gave the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art the land under the Chrysler Building in 1902, the school’s endowment has enabled it to offer students a high-quality, tuition-free education through two world wars, the Great Depression and multiple stock market crashes and financial crises.

headline: A Jay-Z Sighting … in 1939 Harlem
text: Yes, the New York Public Library swears, the old photo of the guy who looks scarily like Jay-Z really is an unretouched, un-Photoshopped image from 1939. “We’re 100 percent certain it’s legitimate,” Adenike Olanrewaju, a library spokeswoman, said on Friday. Here’s the original:

headline: Jaydens and Aidens Are Taking Over
text: It’s not your imagination: Jaydens, Aidens, Ethans and Masons really are taking over, at least among baby boys.

headline: In the Darkness, a Parade on the Rails
text: Sixteen vintage cars were pulled through Harlem to Grand Central Terminal by two separate locomotives, late Thursday night and into Friday morning.

headline: Pulled Pork, for Crowds Large or Small
text: In this week’s column and video, I give a recipe for a small batch of pulled pork. Instead of the usual 7-pound bone-in hunk of meat, I use a 3-pound chunk. That said, if you want to use the same recipe with the larger cut, you certainly can. Double the spice rub and barbecue sauce, and if you love coleslaw, consider making one and a half times that recipe. You will very likely need to cook the meat longer. Just check it every 30 minutes or so after the four-hour mark, and when it reaches an internal temperature of 200 degrees, it’s done. The recipe for pulled pork is here.

headline: Katherine Boo’s ‘Beautiful Forevers’ Headed to the Stage
text: Katherine Boo brought the Annawadi slum to vivid life in “Behind the Beautiful Forevers: Life, Death, and Hope in a Mumbai Undercity,” one of the most acclaimed books of 2012. The National Theater in London hopes to do the same in a stage version of the book next year.

headline: A Parade of Vintage Trains, Unnoticed in the Harlem Night
text: The trains lurched through the Harlem darkness, rattling above an all-night pawnshop, a swell of reggaetón music and a man in a headdress, squawking from his bicycle.

headline: ‘Great Gatsby’  Is Poised for a  Strong Opening, No Thanks to Critics
text: LOS ANGELES — As very early box-office numbers for “The Great Gatsby” rolled in — a strong $3.25 million from the Thursday late-night shows, Warner Brothers said on Friday morning — it was already becoming clear that the audience has a mind of its own.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Santa Teresa, a Venezuelan rum producer, will conduct four free tastings of its flagship rum, Santa Teresa 1796, at Union Square Wines and Spirits, 140 Fourth Avenue. The rum will be served neat, on the rocks and in cocktails. The first session is on Friday from 6 to 9 p.m., paired with chocolates for Mother’s Day. The three other sessions are on May 17, 24 and 31.

headline: An Eclectic Automotive Wish List From ‘Counting Cars’
text: If you’ve seen “Counting Cars,” the reality show on the A&E Network’s History, you’re used to the sight of Danny Koker, known as the Count, and his best buddy, Kevin Mack, cruising the streets of Las Vegas in search of restoration projects for their Count’s Kustoms shop. They spot old cars and trucks in parking lots, peeking out of garages and sometimes even cruising in the next lane. Some they restore and pass on to new owners whose smiling faces are displayed prominently on the show. Other cars Mr. Koker keeps; he owns at least 58 cars and 10 motorcycles.

headline: Health Law Is Defended With Vigor by President
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama came out fighting in defense of his health care law on Friday, saying that he was “110 percent committed” to delivering its benefits on schedule, and that consumers should not be bamboozled by critics spreading misinformation about the law.

headline: A Brazilian Designer Finally Gets Her Due in New York
text: Brazilian designers have reached higher levels of recognition (and sales) lately, but for every Oscar Niemeyer and Sergio Rodrigues there are flocks of Brazilian designers flying under the radar. Claudia Moreira Salles could be considered a real find by many, despite more than 30 years’ creating furniture and interiors for architects including Ricardo Legorreta and projects like the rooftop bar of the Hotel Americano in Chelsea.

headline: A Tongue Made for Slurping
text: How does Pallas’s long-tongued bat collect nectar mid-flight? Using a long, barb-lined tongue, of course.

headline: Tables Inspired by African Stools
text: Though they’ve been in business for five years, the product designers behind Grain, a firm based on Bainbridge Island off the Seattle coast, have only just gotten around to doing furniture. Before this, the team — Chelsea Green, 32, and James Minola, 30 — designed what they call “personal accessories,” like a recyclable shower curtain and a hand mirror. At the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, May 18to 21 at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, they plan to introduce two versions of their Dish table (one is a side table, the other a coffee table). The models were hand-carved African stools that Ms. Green received from her parents and grandparents, who grew up in Africa (her father was born in Nigeria; her mother lived for a time in Ethiopia and Ghana). “We were a bit inspired by the scooped-out shape but wanted it to be more functional, so we flattened it out and cleaned it up a bit,” she said. The tables are made of ash and available in either a clear oil finish or black stain; the side table is $1,950, and the coffee table is $2,500. Grain also plans to present a new mirror and candlesticks at the fair. Information: (206) 965-9302 or graindesign.com.

headline: A Strong Response to Paying Board Nominees
text: The stakes just got higher for shareholder activists.

headline: Tongue Like a Mop
text: Certain bats, like Pallas’s long-tongued bat, hover over flowers and suck nectar. Hovering takes a lot of energy, so the bats need to gather as much liquid as possible with each flick of their long tongues. Scientists have long known that hairlike structures known as papillae at the tips of the bats’ tongues help trap the nectar. Now, using high-speed video cameras, researchers at Brown University have seen that as the tongues extend, the papillae flare outward, becoming perpendicular.

headline: Kiefer Sutherland and Fox Ratings
text: Fans of the Fox drama “Touch,” which stars Kiefer Sutherland, would be wise to savor the Season 2 finale on Friday. A day before, the network announced that this episode would in fact be the series finale.

headline: Week in Review: Big Names and Big Money in Las Vegas
text: Hedge fund manager and S.E.C. reach deal. | JPMorgan sued over credit card debt cases. | Enron’s Skilling strikes a deal for a shorter prison sentence. | Hedge fund impresario plays host in Las Vegas. | Errors afflict more checks issued to aid homeowners. | Small firm could turn the vote on Jamie Dimon. | New York investigates advances on pensions. | A humbled Kleiner Perkins adjusts its strategy. | Two big banks face suits in mortgage pact abuses. | Andrew Ross Sorkin says that for Warren Buffett, the past isn’t always a prologue. | A call for new blood on the JPMorgan board.

headline: Food for the Epicurean Cinephile
text: LOS ANGELES — For four hours, the filmmakers Natasha Subramaniam and Alisa Lapidus constructed a four-tiered dessert out of whipped cream, amaretto cookies, baked meringue and locally sourced edible flowers. “It’s a Pavlova meets a croquembouche,” Ms. Subramaniam said.

headline: Karl Rove Versus Hillary Clinton
text: American Crossroads, the Karl Rove-led super PAC, has released the first attack ad of the 2016 campaign, accusing Hillary Clinton of mishandling the Benghazi killings. It’s a pretty shameless spot, filled with innuendo and as many unflattering pictures of the former secretary of state as possible.

headline: Big Ticket | $16.295 Million for Wraparound Views
text: A pristine 12-room sponsor unit at 535 West End Avenue, a 1920 brick building reinvented, expanded and marketed as a luxury destination by the Extell Development Company, sold for $16.295 million and was the most expensive residential sale of the week, according to city records. The 6,637-square-foot residence, No. 16, had an original listing price of $16.9 million.

headline: NBC Adds 3 More Shows, Including an Updated ‘Ironside’
text: The busy rounds of television shows coming and going continued on Friday as NBC added new series to a growing list for fall, while others found themselves facing a last roundup.

headline: In Immigration Bill Talks, House Group Raises Voice
text: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group in the House of Representatives has been meeting on and off for four years behind closed doors, working on its own version of legislation to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws. But with a comprehensive bill already making its way through the Senate Judiciary Committee, the House group is fast losing its chance to shape the debate percolating on Capitol Hill, let alone put forth a proposal of its own.

headline: In Vancouver, It’s Time to Re-evaluate
text: Mike Gillis, who took over as the general manager of the Canucks in April 2008, says it is time to hit the reset button after Vancouver was swept in the first round of the playoffs by the San Jose Sharks.

headline: A Director Who Doesn’t Fake It
text: The Icelandic director Baltasar Kormakur made his international reputation with such offbeat films as “101 Rekjavik,” a comedy about a sexually confused slacker, and “The Sea,” about dark family secrets in a remote fishing village. Yet he is making an impressive transition to American filmmaking with action fare like “Contraband,” a hit last year, and the comic-book-based “2 Guns,”coming this summer.

headline: When Helping Hurts
text: AMERICAN parents are more involved in our children’s lives than ever: we schedule play dates, assist with homework and even choose college courses.

headline: What Lies Ahead for Dell After Icahn’s New Demand
text: The new proposal by Carl C. Icahn and Southeastern Asset Management for Dell presents some new complications that a special committee of the computer company’s board must consider.

headline: Week in Pictures for May 10
text: Photographs include a Cinco de Mayo celebration in the Bronx, art on Randalls Island and a new cooperative space at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

headline: About Last Night | Neville Wakefield’s Arty Bash for Playboy
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Activist Is Detained in Egypt for ‘Inciting Protests’ Against Morsi Government
text: The Egyptian police arrested Ahmed Maher, a high-profile figure from the country’s 2011 revolution, at Cairo International Airport on Friday as he returned from a 13-day trip to the United States. The authorities ordered that he be detained for four days pending investigation into charges of “inciting protests” in connection with a demonstration held in March, according to local media reports.

headline: Mammas by Isabella Rossellini
text: Ms. Rossellini explores the concept of maternal instinct in “Mammas,” a series of shorts she conceived and directed, which will be broadcast Mother’s Day on the Sundance Channel.

headline: A Day in the Gym, a Life in Transition
text: Fallon Fox, the first openly transgender athlete in mixed martial arts, considers the training center her second home and her fellow fighters her replacement family.

headline: A Record-Setting Gala for Lincoln Center, With a Bonus Tribute for Reynold Levy
text: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts raised $9.4 million at its spring gala on Thursday night, a record for the organization. The gala honored Lincoln Center’s president, Reynold Levy, who is stepping down in December after 11 years. The evening started with the total at $8.2 million, but during the speeches, Katherine Farley, Lincoln Center’s chairwoman, announced that an additional $1.2 million had been raised for the creation of the Reynold Levy Fellowship for Harvard Business School graduates interested in nonprofit organizations.

headline: On Eve of Pivotal Election, Pakistan Orders Times Reporter to Leave
text: Pakistan’s Interior Ministry has ordered the expulsion of the Islamabad bureau chief for The New York Times on the eve of national elections, the newspaper said Friday. The Times has strongly protested the move and is seeking his reinstatement.

headline: Despite Convictions, Brazil Corruption Case Drags On
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Just six months ago, Brazil’s highest court handed down stiff prison sentences to powerful political figures found guilty in a vast vote-buying scheme, a move widely praised here as a watershed moment in a country where citizens long expected little more than impunity from politicians caught in corruption scandals.

headline: Image of the Day: May 10
text: A traders’ strike in Mumbai, Maharashtra, to protest new tax.

headline: Band Members Say Slayer Guitarist Died of Cirrhosis of the Liver
text: The surviving members of the metal band Slayer said that the guitarist Jeff Hanneman had died of alcohol-related cirrhosis of the liver, not from an infection of flesh-eating bacteria.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Bangladesh, Pakistan, Egypt and Israel.

headline: In Celebration of Food, and Art
text: The iconic SoHo restaurant FOOD, run by Carol Goodden and the artist Gordon Matta-Clark in the 1970s, was recreated at the Frieze Art Fair on Randalls Island on Thursday, offering a $15 prix fixe meal for survival: beef jerky, hardtack, dried fruits and cheese on a divided paper plate, along with a pickle; a cup of Jjigae, or Korean stew, and a cup of Tang.

headline: Straying a Bit Beyond Its Own Comfort Zone
text: Big, puffy and comfortable, the Avalon has served Toyota like a trusty Barcalounger. Since 1995 it’s been a staid sedan, in a staid full-size class, from a staid company.

headline: Toyota’s Once-Sleepy Sedan Gives a Wake-Up Call
text: The 2013 Avalon finds itself the unlikely avatar of a purportedly new — more adventurous and design-driven — Toyota.

headline: Using a Trowel to Erase Time
text: Mohammed Ashraf Uddin grew up in a round wooden house on the Bangladeshi island of Sandwip, on a 30-acre farm where his family grew rice, eggplant, peas and green peppers. The farm’s inhabitants included cows, goats and chickens — “so many animals,” Mr. Uddin said, “that we never had to buy anything from the market.” While helping till the soil, he studied accounting at the local college, where he also learned English.

headline: Creating an Ad Campaign for Oreos, as They Turn 101
text: The question “What do you do for an encore?” may be asked after a hit almost as often on Madison Avenue as it is in Hollywood or on Broadway. No sooner does a popular advertising campaign conclude, it seems, than everyone begins to wonder what an appropriate follow-up or next step would be.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: 3-D Smartphone and Hacking the Onion
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Tavares, Islanders Star, Is Hart Trophy Finalist
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The Islanders had just lost, 4-0, in Game 5 of their playoff series with the Pittsburgh Penguins, but there was some good news for the star center John Tavares.

headline: A Change of Plans, Thanks to a Bird
text: Sandra Lee, 46, is the host of “Semi-Homemade Cooking,” in its 15th season on the Food Network. Her first novel, “The Recipe Box,” will be out this summer. Born in Santa Monica, Calif., she lives in Manhattan and shares a home in Westchester County with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: A Roving Art Fair Finds a Home Court Advantage
text: The roving NADA art fairs have set up camp at some distinctive places, including an oceanfront hotel in Miami Beach and a former factory in Hudson, N.Y. But they have found their best home yet on a set of basketball courts on the Lower East Side. On Thursday, a day before the fair opened to V.I.P.’s at Basketball City, a complex on Pier 36, gray carpet covered the hardwood, and white wallboard had been erected to create neat grids. The scoreboards were still up, but that somehow felt right in this packed week of fairs, shows and events.

headline: On the Market in the Hamptons
text: Properties include an 1800s village cottage, a house with a lush garden, a barn conversion near the beach, a home with Montauk water views and a five-bedroom near the village.

headline: A Peasant Pie Comfortable at Any Table
text: In the sunnier climes of Italy, Greece and the south of France, there’s a long tradition of frugal, savory pies made with a humble filling of cooked greens (usually wild foraged ones, like dandelion or nettles), stewed onions and a little grated cheese. Though tasty, they were meatless — this was peasant food. The family cook probably heard, “What, pie again?” more often than not. But it was a way to stay alive.

headline: Exploring His Tunisian Roots, With His Father by His Side
text: At the start of “The Ulysses Syndrome,” Jonah Bokaer and Tsvi, his Tunisian-born father, take their places at the back of a stage illuminated by six fluorescent tubes, arranged in a hexagon, each dangling like a low swing. Sitting on the floor, the men remain still, leaning against the wall with one knee up.

headline: The Trek to a Yogurt Less Sweet
text: WHITE PLAINS — Dannon yogurt had a secret it didn’t want you to know. Until recently.

headline: 2 Key JPMorgan Directors Back Dimon’s Dual Roles
text: Jamie Dimon has received a spirited defense against calls by some shareholders to split his jobs of chief executive and chairman of JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Author of Study on Immigrants’ I.Q. Leaves Heritage Foundation
text: Jason Richwine, a senior policy analyst at the conservative Heritage Foundation who argued in a graduate school dissertation that Hispanic immigrants were less intelligent than white Americans, resigned from his post with the foundation on Friday.

headline: Inside the Frieze Art Fair
text: A parade of the fine and fancy made an appearance at Frieze Art Fair, including Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Renee Rockefeller.

headline: At Frieze, the Elite Browse and Forage
text: “Just go with it,” Patty Smyth, the rocker, said to her husband, the tennis legend John McEnroe, urging him to tip up a coupe of Bobby Burns, a potent cocktail of whiskey, sweet vermouth, Bénédictine and a twist of lemon. “Go with the flow.”

headline: Complaint Against Bryce Reed
text: Bryce Reed, a paramedic who helped evacuate people after the fertilizer plant explosion in West, Tex., was charged with possessing bomb-making materials.

headline: Student Debt’s Impact on Young Graduates
text: Student loan debt now exceeds $1 trillion, and as Annie Lowrey writes, that debt is an increasing burden to the financial lives of young graduates. It is forcing them to delay purchases of things like homes, cars and other big-ticket items and acting as a drag on growth, economists say.

headline: All the Rage | This Year’s Frieze New York Artists Are Mad About Plants
text: Considering the dozens of languages, thousands of artworks and billions of dollars coursing through the tent at Frieze New York — the second edition of which opened to the public on Friday and runs through Monday — you might expect the fair to offer a decisive statement about what matters in art right now. In truth, that’s probably expecting too much from what is ultimately a highbrow pop-up shopping mall, but certain motifs always emerge from these extravaganzas, and what’s more fun than sussing out the pattern? This year, the predominant trend is flora, with plant life sprouting up in photographs and potted into sculptures. A reflection of the mania for sustainability and urban gardens? A nod to the season? Decide for yourself. We’ll see if the greenery rakes in the green, but watch out for some of these leafy highlights as you venture past the air kisses and hipster restaurants into Frieze New York’s white cube jungle.

headline: Actavis in Preliminary Talks With Warner Chilcott
text: Actavis is in talks with another drug maker about a potential merger after talks with Valeant Pharmaceuticals International fell through.

headline: Printable-Gun Instructions Spread Online After State Dept. Orders Their Removal
text: The State Department, citing possible compliance concerns regarding the export of firearms, has ordered a Web site to remove what are believed to be the world’s first online instructions on how to build a 3-D printable handgun.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 10
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

headline: El Museo del Barrio’s Board President to Leave
text: El Museo del Barrio’s board president, who was named in a recent discrimination claim by the museum’s former director, will leave her position at the end of her term on June 30, museum officials said on Friday. The official, Yaz Hernández, is departing as the museum searches for a new director and struggles to find its fiscal footing.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 10
text: More photographs.

headline: Searching for Roots, Finding Characters
text: “Family Tree” is a half-hour HBO comedy about a lethargic, unemployed young British man who becomes obsessed with tracking down his ancestors. It’s largely improvised and poses as a documentary, though to such a slight degree that it hardly matters. That this does not sound like a terrible idea for a television show is largely because of the past work of Christopher Guest, who, as it happens, created and wrote “Family Tree” with Jim Piddock. Depending on your taste, that’s either a tribute or a reproach.

headline: Keeping Peace in a Vertical Village
text: As director of operations and compliance for AKAM Associates, a property management company for luxury co-op and condominium buildings in New York City, Doug Weinstein is responsible for all physical projects in 125 buildings. He fields daily calls from cooperative and condominium boards about everything from code issues to job bids. Mr. Weinstein started in the business nearly 30 years ago, working for his cousin, Martin Raynes, of M. J. Raynes Inc., a large real estate developer in the city in the 1980s.

headline: Using Darkness, With Enlightenment in Mind
text: The Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas has written several works to be performed in pitch darkness, including “In Vain,” his hourlong masterpiece for chamber orchestra. With artificial light everywhere, “we do not have any night in our modern life,” he said in an interview in 2011. “But I think our body and our souls desire night, and I give this in my art.”

headline: The Boy Toy’s Story
text: RENO, Nev. — Soon after moving into Liberace’s gaudy Las Vegas mansion in 1977, Scott Thorson, then a teenage hunk in the foster care system, learned that the jewel-smitten showman could love just as extravagantly as he decorated. Touring the premises before their relationship began, Liberace pointed out some decorative highlights, which included 17 pianos, a casino, a quarry’s worth of marble and a canopied bed with an ermine spread. On the ceiling was a reproduction of the Sistine Chapel with Liberace’s face painted among the cherubs.

headline: Details Emerge About Syrian Electronic Army’s Recent Exploits
text: At The Onion it’s all fun and games, except when the company’s Twitter account gets hacked.

headline: Braving Frostbite in Search of Ratings
text: The weather in much of the United States is finally beginning to warm up, but on television things are getting noticeably colder. A burst of new and returning reality series seem intent on leaving us envious of, or in awe of, or terrified for, those who live where the wind blows cold almost year-round.

headline: A French Jet Maker Is Approaching a Crossroad
text: SAINT-CLOUD, FRANCE — As Jérôme Camps, an engineer at Dassault Aviation’s main design center, showed off a ghostlike 3-D model of one of the company’s small jets here recently, his hand passed through the plane’s skin to reveal an intricate web of support structures as well as a jumble of multicolored cables and pneumatic tubes, rendered in vivid detail.

headline: 40 Nations, 1,000 Artists and One Island
text: Some people hate art fairs all of the time, and most people hate them some of the time. It’s fashionable to be snarky and condescending about them, but that’s too easy. Art fairs are here for the foreseeable future and represent the collective efforts — if not the hopes and dreams — of thousands of people who want art to be at the center of their lives.

headline: In Blow to NBC News, ‘Rock Center’ Is Canceled
text: Among the cancellations announced this week in anticipation of Monday’s unveiling of a new prime time schedule, surely the hardest to take for NBC News is the closing notice for “Rock Center,” the ambitious newsmagazine program that hoped to stake out new territory for both the news division and its chief anchor, Brian Williams.

headline: A Line Between Sweet and Skimpy
text: It first happened to me this spring. My daughters, who had just turned 8, came bounding into the room to show off new outfits they were wearing to an extended-family gathering. My eyes bulged. The dresses drooped provocatively off the shoulder and offered other peekaboos of their bodies. Sure, as a parent, I figured I would one day face clothing battles with my children. Politicians aren’t the only ones who draw red lines.

headline: Ever Separated by Sound
text: The man looks like an aging bachelor bank teller in a 1962 episode of “The Twilight Zone.” Or like the hopelessly square dad in a midcentury sitcom. But Michael Bonnabel — in his suit, narrow tie and eyeglasses — is the son in the Abingdon Theater Company’s production of his autobiographical solo show, “The Good Boy.”

headline: Fort Lauderdale Regional Play
text: The most successful players at the Fort Lauderdale, Fla., regional over the first seven days of April were Robert Rosen of Delray Beach, Fla.; Alan Osofsky of Palm Beach, Fla.; David Berkowitz of Boca Raton, Fla.; and Alan Sontag of Gaithersburg, Md.

headline: E.M.T. at Fertilizer Plant Blast Faces Charge of Possessing Bomb Parts
text: Texas authorities said on Friday that they had opened a criminal investigation into last month’s deadly explosion at a fertilizer plant that killed 14 people and injured some 200 others.

headline: Not Just the Standards, but Storytelling, Too
text: Absolutely thrilling. That describes Audra McDonald’s Avery Fisher Hall performance at Lincoln Center’s spring gala on Thursday evening. The very sound of the word “thrilling,” with its suggestion of an embedded trill, evokes qualities inherent in Ms. McDonald’s soprano, which seemed to unfurl in ever-richer textures as she imbued songs with a sense of bursting possibility.

headline: An Artist Recreates a Smoking Room With Flowers and Perfume
text: Maria Loboda’s newest installation, an artfully arranged flower bed called “Smoking Room in a Private Palais in Brussels as Seen From the Entrance, 1905,” greets visitors as they exit the tents of the Frieze Art Fair on Randalls Island in New York. The outdoor exhibition is a tribute to two early 20th-century design phenomena: a smoking room in Vienna, designed by the secessionist production cooperative Wiener Werkstätte, and color-charted gardens, a bygone fad for mapping flowers by shade to create a plot that feels almost like a Pantone chart. Loboda potted groups of different plants in an arrangement that mimics the floor plan of the smoking room. “The idea is to take the domestic situation, an interior, and to translate it into something wild, into a landscape,” she said.

headline: Bumpy Road for Trophy Cars
text: MUMBAI — It’s not easy being the owner of an exceedingly expensive car in India. Just ask Rishabh Jain, whose Lamborghini Murciélago LP640, in a shade of metallic gray called Grigio Telesto, spends an inordinate amount of time under a cover in the parking lot of his apartment building in the affluent Malabar Hill neighborhood here.

headline: Conspicuous Consumption, With a Few Caveats
text: Facing rough streets and high taxes, India’s owners of supercars and high-end luxury vehicles are finding that riding in style isn’t always easy.

headline: Country Stars Playing Musical Chairs
text: For Lady Antebellum, lipstick represents optimism. For Pistol Annies, it’s a tool of the oppressor.

headline: A New Town, a New Focus on Dinner
text: Sweet Basil’s Cafe and Grill made its reputation as a place for brunch and lunch, first in West Orange and later in Livingston, where it moved last July. An expanded menu and new talent in the kitchen now make it an equally fine place for dinner.

headline: Recalling Chimps and Brel, in Her Own Way
text: Not many people know that the grandiose Sinatra anthem “My Way,” had an earlier life in France under the title “Comme d’habitude” (“As Usual”) whose morose narrator describes a deteriorating relationship that has settled into a chilly routine. Juiced up with new lyrics by Paul Anka, it became the triumphal ego trip we all know and have learned to tolerate.

headline: 13-Year-Old Playwright Awaits His Big Night
text: Kyle Abrahams had never tried to write a play before his drama teacher, John McEneny, required him to try for a middle school class in Brooklyn. Kyle had always liked acting – he recently performed in a production of “Frankenstein.” Now, though, he’d be the one giving other actors instructions.

headline: Kobe Bryant’s Sentimental Shot
text: Yesterday a friend and fan of all Philadelphia sports directed me to a Philly.com story about the former Notre Dame football player Manti Te’o’s “girlfriend” making the Maxim Hot 100; his reaction was basically “Phew, glad the Iggles didn’t draft this guy.”

headline: Isabella Rossellini’s Sly Maternal Instinct
text: Some Mother’s Day tributes are less wholesome than others, and thank heaven for that. “Mammas” — a set of short films, two to three minutes each, appearing Sunday on the Sundance Channel and sundancechannel.com — reflects the distinctive character of its creator, Isabella Rossellini: a blend of innocence, sophistication and sly smuttiness. It’s a long way from flowers, chocolates and brunch.

headline: Lots of Room, and a Festive Vibe
text: The Rose Room, which opened in Mount Kisco in February, is a place of hits and misses.

headline: Umpire Suspended for Blown Call
text: In a week in which umpires twice became the story of games because of high-profile mistakes, Major League Baseball took action on Friday, handing a two-game suspension to Fieldin Culbreth, the umpire who on Thursday incorrectly allowed an illegal pitching change in a game between the Houston Astros and Los Angeles Angels.

headline: Thai Discoveries in a Spare Setting
text: Two suggestions if you visit Rainbow Thai in Westport: first, reserve ahead, as this tiny place seats only 40, and second, request, if it is available, a table overlooking the Saugatuck River. If you are lucky you might even catch a glimpse of crews rowing below you on the river.

headline: Friday Night Music: Sarah Jarosz, Tell Me True
text: I was looking for a live version with the full trio, and here it is. They’re performing in New York in a couple of weeks.

headline: Editor’s Letter | Away We Go
text: Travel journalism often falls into one of two camps — the highly didactic and servicey piece, “go here, stay there, see that,” or the long-winded narrative in which the writer has the experience and we are meant to be satisfied by the first-person blow-by-blow he or she has brought back for us: “the road into town was dusty and unpaved and the driver kept getting lost.” The former is best served up by the Internet on demand. (You can find all of our hotel and restaurant suggestions for the stories in this issue at tmagazine.com.) And the pure version of the latter is perhaps best left to brilliant writers who promise to reward you for coming along (Edith Wharton, Patrick Leigh Fermor, Evelyn Waugh, Jan Morris). There are of course also intellectual and cultural histories of locales, in which the writer seeks to tease out the influences — historical, economic, social, stylistic, culinary and political — that make the place uniquely what it is (V. S. Naipaul, Bruce Chatwin, Ryszard Kapuscinski). The type we favor at T is a hybrid of the three, in which great writing and personal narrative is done in the service of not just traipsing along with the writer who got to go on an amazing journey that we didn’t, but of bringing you back a new understanding of a place that is enlightening and satisfying regardless of whether you ever plan to visit. And yet, if you do choose to go, we’re there to guide you.

headline: For Casual Crowds, Second Labels
text: When the number of guests at a party or a barbecue threatens to overwhelm the wine budget, second labels can come to the rescue.

headline: A Lively Little Party of Plenty
text: As we walked into La Cucina, a year-and-a-half-old Italian restaurant in Hewlett, on a recent Saturday night, something resembling a dinner party was in full swing. The owner, Luigi Muto, greeted us with a warm smile and a worried glance over his shoulder. Behind him, the small minimalist dining room — awash in soft jazz, seductive aromas and animated conversation — was packed.

headline: Where the Musical Meets the Visual
text: It may look at first like a simple compilation of abstract art, but the new show at the Art League of Long Island in Dix Hills possesses an extra dimension: It is actually a collection of 63 musical scores or parts of scores by composers from around the world.

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 10
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a Cinco de Mayo celebration in the Bronx, art on Randalls Island and a new cooperative space at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

headline: Meals of Imagined Bounty
text: Sometimes it’s easy to tell which part of the 20th century we are seeing in “The Dining Room.” When one man mentions the horrors of “instant coffee on Eastern Airlines,” for instance, you know we’re in the era of the beloved hourly shuttle to Washington or Boston. At other times, it can be more difficult, as when a father complains, “The government is systematically ruining this country.”

headline: The Secret of Baxter’s Success
text: In trying to figure out why Mike Baxter has been such a good pinch-hitter for the Mets, Manager Terry Collins pointed to his attention to detail. It is a rare player who pays such close attention while being stuck on the bench. But Baxter does. This season, he is 5 for 9 as a pinch-hitter, including leading the Mets to two final-inning wins this week. After Thursday’s hit, Baxter became the first pinch-hitter since 1991 to have game-ending at-bats twice in a three-day span.

headline: T Summer Travel 2013
text: T’s Summer Travel issue is all about trying something new: whether it’s staying in a stranger’s home (Gideon Lewis-Kraus writes about Airbnb), taking a trip alone (Andrew O’Hagan delights in traveling solo) or considering a place off the beaten path (Adam Sachs has a love-hate relationship with Marin County, Calif.). Inside, there is T’s usual mix of art, entertainment and fashion with a profile on the artist James Turrell by Edward Helmore, a visit with the actor Rupert Everett by Sarah Lyall and a round-up of black bikinis and leather cover-ups photographed by Craig McDean and styled by Joe McKenna. And don’t forget to drop in on Saturdays Surf NYC in Japan, check out our selection of hotel gardens or read about Italy’’s Spoleto Festival. See all from the issue >>

text: Amateur astronomers gathered for the 34th Texas Star Party, which offered them a chance to gaze at a sky full of nothing but stars.

headline: An Actress, a Director and a Power Struggle
text: “Venus in Fur” is a smart, seriously sexy comedy by David Ives that has steamed up three successive New York playhouses in recent seasons. The George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, where the play is currently onstage, is among the dozen regional companies that have put it on their 2013 schedules, with good reason.
