headline: Why Federal Efforts to Ensure Clean Tap Water Fail to Reach Faucets Nationwide
text: MONSON, Calif. — Laura Garcia was halfway through the breakfast dishes when the spigot went dry. The small white tank beneath the sink that purified her undrinkable water had run out. Still, as annoying as that was, it was an improvement over the days before Ms. Garcia got her water filter, when she had to do her dishes using water from five-gallon containers she bought at a local store.

headline: Missing: Jonathan Winters. Badly.
text: (This is the second part of a two-part article.)

headline: Egypt: Prominent Activist Jailed
text: A prominent Egyptian activist was jailed Friday on accusations of inciting protests in front of the Interior Ministry in March, state news media said. The activist, Ahmed Maher, was arrested at the Cairo airport upon arriving from abroad and transferred to a high-security prison where he will be held for four days while the accusations are investigated. Mr. Maher is a leader in the April 6 Youth Group that help organize the protests that ousted President Hosni Mubarak in February 2011. He has recently spoken out against President Mohamed Morsi and his allies in the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Pre-1492, Artistic Notions Worth Borrowing
text: If modern art was characterized by the shock of the new, recent decades have seen an obsession with recycling. History is treated like an archive from which images and objects can be borrowed, appropriated, and repurposed — just like in popular music, where sampling was born, and which is alluded to in the title of “Pre-Columbian Remix: The Art of Enrique Chagoya, Demián Flores, Rubén Ortiz-Torres, and Nadín Ospina” at the Neuberger Museum of Art, Purchase College.

headline: Pakistan’s Tyrannical Majority
text: JUST after the stroke of midnight on Aug. 14, 1947, the Peshawar broadcast station of All India Radio crackled to life: “This is Pakistan Broadcasting Service.” Next came the words of the Urdu-language poet Ahmed Nadeem Qasmi: “Pakistan bananay walay, Pakistan Mubarak” — “Oh, maker of Pakistan, congratulations on Pakistan.”

headline: Rebuilding After Sandy, but With Costly New Rules
text: It’s been more than six months since Hurricane Sandy hit the East Coast, yet many people whose homes were ravaged by the storm still do not know how to put all the pieces back together.

headline: Shunned Elsewhere, Body of Marathon Bombing Suspect Is Buried in Virginia Cemetery
text: BOSTON — The mystery surrounding the burial of the body of Tamerlan Tsarnaev has come to an end. The Boston Marathon bombing suspect was buried this week at a small Muslim cemetery in Doswell, Va.

headline: Report Your Hurricane Sandy Repair Stories
text: This week’s Your Money column looks at the tough position of many homeowners whose houses were severely damaged by Hurricane Sandy. They are still figuring out the best way to put their homes back together, and how they will pay for the repairs.

headline: CBS to Add 4 Comedies, Including Another From Chuck Lorre
text: CBS joined other networks in sending out orders for new series Friday and, for CBS, that list was longer and included some untraditional ideas.

headline: George Sauer, Jets Receiver and Rebel, Is Dead at 69
text: George Sauer, who as a wide receiver for the Jets played a pivotal role in the team’s stunning victory in Super Bowl III, and who later quit professional football because he considered it dehumanizing, died on Tuesday in Westerville, Ohio. He was 69.

headline: The Hitless Songwriter
text: Michael Tannen, The Roches’ manager, was yelling into the phone at me. Why don’t you just listen to the radio and figure out how to write a commercial song? Then the phone went dead.

headline: The Family Unfriendly Act
text: There are two good things to say about the Working Families Flexibility Act, which passed the House this week with 220 Republican and three Democratic votes.

headline: Samuel Noyes, Mountaineer
text: Few Union units were as esteemed for their collective strength as the 12th New Hampshire Infantry. It was magnet for strapping young fellows from the farms that dotted the state’s White Mountains. “No wonder that a regiment, having so many giant-like men, should have been called the ‘New Hampshire Mountaineers,’” mused one of its captains, Asa Bartlett, about the origin of the unit’s nickname.

headline: Privacy Breach on Bloomberg’s Data Terminals
text: A shudder went through Wall Street on Friday after the revelation that Bloomberg News reporters had extracted subscribers’ private information through the company’s ubiquitous data terminals to break news.

headline: New Technology and Risks Enter a Venerable Event
text: On a sun-kissed afternoon in the Bay Area last week, Larry Olson, a 39-year-old from San Francisco, backed his car into a parking space next to Marina Green, flipped up the hatch to create a viewing platform and watched with his young children as Artemis Racing’s America’s Cup catamaran sped by in the stiff breeze on San Francisco Bay.

headline: Former Leader of Guatemala Is Guilty of Genocide Against Mayan Group
text: GUATEMALA CITY — A Guatemalan court on Friday found Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt, the former dictator who ruled Guatemala during one of the bloodiest periods of its long civil war, guilty of genocide and crimes against humanity.

headline: Retailers Are Pressed on Safety at Factories
text: A wide spectrum of government officials, investors and religious groups are warning major retailers like Walmart, Benetton and Gap that they could face financial repercussions from consumers, damage to their stock value or sustained public protests if they do not adopt stricter garment manufacturing standards.

headline: Technology Industry Lobbying Group Loses Supporters
text: Elon Musk, a founder of the electric carmaker Tesla and one of the technology industry’s most outspoken exponents of clean energy, has stepped down from a prominent Silicon Valley advocacy group that is pushing for changes to the nation’s immigration laws and that has sponsored advertisements that promote a contentious oil pipeline.

headline: A Meal in Borough No. 5: Manhattan
text: Consider the crush of publicity and the lines that have formed on Second Avenue outside Wylie Dufresne’s newest restaurant. Note that Mr. Dufresne and his muttonchops are television celebrities. Add that last week Mr. Dufresne won the James Beard Award for New York’s Best Chef. So how refreshing it was that not everybody in Alder’s rustic-chic dining room on Wednesday was caught up on the place’s reputation. One food-loving couple transplanted from San Diego and Venice (Italy) came for their own adventure: the end of a five-borough birthday tour. They were delightfully unaware of WD-50, Mr. Dufresne’s celebrated flagship. And instead of debating the hype, they reveled in the whimsy of the evening and Alder’s modernist spin on comfort food, savoring their journey as much as the dehydrated pastrami.

headline: Former Major Winner Provides Tough Love as a Caddie at the Players
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — A seven-time PGA Tour winner missed the Players Championship cut by two strokes without even hitting a shot. Mark Brooks, whose tour victories include one major, the 1996 P.G.A. Championship, caddied for J. J. Henry, who finished at two over, 13 strokes higher than the 36-hole leader, Sergio García.

headline: Troubled Life in Malcolm X’s Shadow Comes to a Violent End
text: Last week, Malcolm Shabazz, the grandson of Malcolm X, was talking to his friend Daniel Stevens when he learned that Mr. Stevens was worried that his fledgling rap career was going nowhere. Mr. Shabazz vowed to help, saying that he could get Mr. Stevens’s music into the right hands.

headline: With Many Despairing, Bulgaria Heads to Polls
text: VARNA, Bulgaria — Early one morning this past winter, Plamen Goranov, a 36-year-old photographer, stood on the steps of City Hall in this once grand and now crumbling port city on the Black Sea and held up a sign demanding that the mayor and City Council resign. He then took a bottle of gasoline from his backpack, poured it over himself and set himself on fire. He died 11 days later in a hospital.

headline: A Composer’s Best Friend
text: On Wednesday, Lucy Mann was out there again, standing behind her table just inside the entrance to the Manhattan School of Music.

headline: New Error Found in Scoring of Test for Gifted Programs
text: Three weeks after New York City disclosed that thousands of students had been wrongly excluded from eligibility in public school gifted programs, the Education Department said that roughly 300 additional students received incorrect scores because of another mistake by the testing company.

headline: Rodman Says He’ll Ask North Korea to Free American
text: Dennis Rodman, the flamboyant former basketball player who has managed to engage with North Korea’s leader — something United States officials have been unable to do — said he planned to return to the North to try to gain the release of an imprisoned American citizen, according to a video posted Friday on the celebrity news Web site TMZ.

headline: Pay People to Cook at Home
text: THE home-cooked family meal is often lauded as the solution for problems ranging from obesity to deteriorating health to a decline in civility and morals. Using whole foods to prepare meals without additives and chemicals is the holy grail for today’s advocates of better eating.

headline: Storm Plans for Disabled Are Inadequate, U.S. Says
text: New York City is in violation of federal law because its emergency management plans “do not adequately protect the rights of individuals with disabilities,” federal authorities said in a court filing on Friday.

headline: Five Children. Any Questions?
text: On Sundays, the comedian and actor Jim Gaffigan, 46, takes a day off from stand-up. Instead of performing, he collects new fodder during family outings with his wife, Jeannie Noth Gaffigan, and their five children, Marre, 9; Jack, 7; Katie, 4; Michael, 22 months; and Patrick, 7 months, and time spent at their home, a fifth-floor walk-up on the Bowery. Some of this material can be seen and heard in Mr. Gaffigan’s Grammy-nominated, downloadable comedy special, “Mr. Universe,” and on his national tour. It also fills the pages of his new book, “Dad Is Fat,” which was released last week.

text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

headline: The Man at the Piano
text: This Monday evening, a small, vibrant arts organization, The New York Festival of Song, which I’ve long treasured, will be celebrating its 25th anniversary with a gala concert.

headline: After Malaysia Election, Political Attacks Continue as Opposition Calls for Protests
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — If there was a moment after the nail-biting national election on Sunday when Malaysians could envision a respite from five years of political turmoil, it did not last long.

headline: Protecting Cinnabon and the Gap, and Still Getting No Respect
text: Earlier this year, somebody noticed a black suitcase on the ground floor of the Manhattan Mall in Herald Square. The response was immediate.

headline: China Officials Seek Career Shortcut With Feng Shui
text: ZOUMAJIE, China — Outraged peasants protesting land grabs. Jilted mistresses plotting revenge. Provincial investigators seeking out graft.

headline: In A.T.M. Robbery Case, a Splashy Trail of Big Spending
text: Three worked as bus drivers for special-needs children, two worked at Kmart and another delivered pizza for Domino’s.

headline: From the Archives: Letter From Malcolm Shabazz, 2003
text: An excerpt from a letter Malcolm Shabazz sent to Michael Wilson, a reporter for The New York Times, in 2003.

headline: Giants Rookies Find Familiarity in Camp
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was a crowded Giants rookie minicamp Friday, with more than 60 players — most of them undrafted free agents — swarming multiple practice fields. There was a lot of young, energetic football muscle parading back and forth, a throng that often ran the wrong way or looked lost in the middle of an assignment.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Corrections: May 11, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Taking Things Into Account
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I know. It will be O.K., I promise. Here comes the explanation.

headline: Music for Violin, With Faustian Strings Attached
text: Everyone knows that the Devil has the best tunes. And we also know what he plays them on: a fiddle. From Tartini’s “Devil’s Trill” Violin Sonata of 1713 to the Charlie Daniels Band’s 1979 country music ballad “The Devil Went Down to Georgia,” the instrument most readily associated with the Crafty One is a violin.

headline: Before You Can Plant, Dance Through the End of the World
text: There is a vigorous dance component in “Last Days/First Field,” but its choreographer, Jill Sigman, has even bigger ambitions in mind. The two-hour work, as she explains in program notes, “is a movement ritual for our time.” In the first half, “Last Days,” the focus is on dancing: there’s an apocalyptic feel as performers move frantically in packs or alone, gesticulating wildly as their feet slap soundly onto the floor. The ritual part comes to light in the second half, “First Field.” Ms. Sigman attempts to alter the landscape, both physically and spiritually, by bringing nature inside.

headline: Expelled by Pakistan
text: Pakistan is facing daunting challenges, including a violent insurgency that threatens the state and a critically important general election on Saturday. Yet its Interior Ministry this week had nothing better to do than to expel Declan Walsh, The Times’s bureau chief in Pakistan. The move was unjustified and should be reversed.

headline: Racism in a Texas Death Case
text: In the annals of racism in the Texas criminal justice system, seven death penalty cases are in a class by themselves. In 2000, after the Supreme Court ordered a new sentencing hearing in one of them, Senator John Cornyn, who was then the state attorney general, called for new sentencing hearings in the other cases for the same reason: because race was improperly and explicitly considered as a factor in determining the sentence.

headline: Beyond Basketball and Bigotry
text: The overwhelmingly supportive response to Jason Collins, who came out last week as the first openly gay male athlete playing in a major American team sport, is an encouraging measure of the nation’s civil rights progress. But his barrier-breaking announcement a dozen years into his N.B.A. career also carries a reminder of a reality millions of gay people live with every day: being open about their sexual orientation could put their job and career at risk.

headline: Ceaseless Pressure on Whales
text: Since 1986, when the International Whaling Commission imposed a moratorium on whaling, there has been a steady resurgence in whale populations. The recovery of several species pushed to the brink of extinction by commercial whaling is a reminder of the resilience of nature. Even so, there is a nearly constant push to ease the restrictions that have protected the whales and, in some cases, to resume hunting. There are two cases in point: fin whales near Iceland, a nation that has never accepted the I.W.C. moratorium, and humpback whales near Hawaii.

headline: France: Concern Over New Virus
text: French officials said Friday that they are examining three people who came into contact with a man hospitalized with a new respiratory coronavirus related to SARS, to see if they have also contracted the disease. The man, 65, hospitalized in late April, got the disease on a package tour to Dubai. Officials are now examining a nurse at the hospital, a doctor and a former roommate of the man, all of whom are being monitored  by doctors. The concern is how easily the new virus might spread from one person to another. Since the virus emerged last year, 18 people have died worldwide, but the man is so far the only confirmed case in France. He is in serious but stable condition.

headline: Rivera Is Able to Laugh It Off
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — About two hours before the first pitch of the Yankees’ game against the Kansas City Royals, and nearly 53 weeks after Mariano Rivera suffered the worst injury of his career, two men carried a 12-foot sign out to the spot where Rivera went down.

headline: Europe’s Careless Dithering
text: EUROPE’S economic problems are growing steadily worse, with unemployment in parts of the Continent now above the level reached in the United States during the Great Depression.

headline: Benghazi E-Mails Put White House on the Defensive
text: WASHINGTON — A long-simmering dispute over the White House’s account of the deadly assault on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, flared up on Friday, with a disclosure of e-mails that show the White House was more deeply involved in revising talking points about the attack than officials have previously acknowledged.

headline: Britain: Cleric May Head to Jordan
text: After years of battling in Britain’s courts to avoid deportation to Jordan and a retrial there on terrorist bombing charges, a militant Islamist preacher of Palestinian descent known as Abu Qatada told an immigration court through his lawyer on Friday that he will fly home voluntarily if Britain and Jordan ratify a treaty concluded last month that will ensure that no evidence obtained by torture will be used in the case. The two countries have said they expect the ratification process to be completed within months. The 52-year-old cleric, whose real name is Omar Mahmoud Mohammed Othman was sentenced in absentia to life imprisonment on the bombing charges by a Jordanian court in 1990. In Britain, where he sought refugee status, he has become a symbol for many in Britain of the exploitation of the country’s immigration, welfare and justice systems by migrants seeking to use Britain as a haven for terrorist activities. Mr. Othman’s new pledge was met with widespread skepticism, with some legal experts saying he might be seeking to pre-empt a move favored by some in the government who have urged that Mr. Othman, currently held in prison for breaking bail conditions forbidding his use of cellphones and computers, be flown back to Jordan peremptorily, in defiance of British and European court rulings in his favor.

headline: Baxter’s Attentiveness Helps in the Pinch
text: In trying to figure out why Mike Baxter has been such a good pinch-hitter for the Mets, Manager Terry Collins pointed to his attention to detail.

headline: Year Later, Rivera Is Back on His Feet and Stingy as Ever on the Mound
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — About two hours before the first pitch of the Yankees’ game against the Kansas City Royals, and nearly 53 weeks after Mariano Rivera sustained the worst injury of his career, two men carried a 12-foot sign out to the spot where Rivera went down.

headline: An Eyeglass Store Moves Across the Street
text: Moscot, which has been selling glasses at the corner of Delancey and Orchard Streets since 1936, will have a new, nearby, location.

headline: Head of Teachers’ Union Tests Candidates’ Views
text: When Michael Mulgrew, the president of the city’s teachers’ union, looks out on a ballroom at the New York Hilton Midtown on Saturday, he will deliver a stinging speech about “mayoral dictatorship” and call for an investigation into 11 years of Department of Education data.

headline: Alan Abelson, Who at Barron’s Was a Thorn in Wall Street’s Side, Dies at 87
text: Alan Abelson, a former top editor of Barron’s magazine who made waves — sometimes tsunamis — by writing a pugnacious, sagacious stock market column that denounced Wall Street hucksterism and routinely rocked share prices, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Trying to Be Hip and Edgy, Ads Become Offensive
text: Madison Avenue is learning a painful lesson: cutting edge advertising can slice both ways.

headline: F.D.A. Rejects Request to Block Sales of Generic Painkiller
text: The Food and Drug Administration announced Friday that generic versions of the painkiller Opana ER can remain on the market, dealing a blow to the brand-name manufacturer, Endo Health Solutions, which had asked the agency to declare the generic versions unsafe.

headline: Environmental Review to Delay Two Engineered Crops
text: Genetically engineered crops that could sharply increase the use of two powerful herbicides are now unlikely to reach the market until at least 2015 because the Department of Agriculture has decided to subject the crops to more stringent environmental reviews than it had originally intended.

headline: Saying Zei Gezunt to an Eyeglass Store
text: Abe Schneider has been buying eyeglasses at the same store on the Lower East Side for more than 20 years, so when he needed new lenses, where did he go? Where else?

headline: Fortuneteller Pleads Guilty to Grand Larceny Charge
text: It began with a simple offer from a stranger on a Manhattan sidewalk, a promise to introduce a woman who appeared to be carrying a heavy emotional load to someone with spiritual powers.

headline: Dissatisfied Supporters of Manchester United Built Their Own U
text: MANCHESTER, England — The e-mails and phone calls flow in regularly from all over the world, as soccer players, parents and fans want to get in touch with the club here known as United. The club’s staff members understand the interest in the team that famously wears red and black, so they do their best to reply to each request, whether it comes from Africa or Asia or America.

headline: Fourth No Confidence Vote for the President of N.Y.U.
text: Two recent overwhelming votes of no confidence against the president of New York University have brought to four the number of N.Y.U. schools or campuses whose faculties have rejected his leadership.

headline: Father Held for Letting His Children Fire BB Guns

headline: Twice-Deflected Overtime Shot Puts Rangers on Brink of Elimination

headline: Do They Really Tawk Like That? Not Now
text: Years ago, a friend who had moved to New York from Minneapolis to go to college marveled that the people she met who had been raised on the Upper East Side spoke with “no accent.” Although she hadn’t expected them to sound like Buddy Hackett, she was intrigued by the notion that members of the city’s upper classes didn’t particularly sound as if they were from anywhere. As someone who had grown up in a well-to-do Midwestern family, she hardly sounded like Marge Gunderson in “Fargo,” but there were certain subtle pronunciations and inflections, she argued, that still marked a wealthy Midwesterner as a Midwesterner, signifiers absent in an analogous population here.

headline: NBC Saves ‘Community,’ but Drops Two Other Series

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) MADAGASCAR 3: EUROPE’S MOST WANTED (2012) Those escapees from the Central Park Zoo — Alex the lion (Ben Stiller), Marty the zebra (Chris Rock), Gloria the gorilla (Jada Pinkett Smith) and Melman the giraffe (David Schwimmer) — depart Africa to join a European circus, the better to evade a French animal-control officer (Frances McDormand) literally after Alex’s head, in this franchise’s latest installment. They also try to play nice with their new friends Vitaly (Bryan Cranston), a tiger; Gia (Jessica Chastain), a jaguar; and Stefano (Martin Short), a sea lion. “Life lessons in the script (partly by Noah Baumbach, Mr. Stiller’s ‘Greenberg’ director) are desultory, but a late twist is surprising,” Andy Webster wrote in The New York Times about this film directed by Eric Darnell, Tom McGrath and Conrad Vernon, and styled after Miroslav Sasek’s illustrations. “Where ‘Madagascar 3’ soars is in its visuals: A Monte Carlo chase is vertiginously madcap; a Cirque du Soleil-style spectacle dazzles with rich pastels; the 3-D effects have wit and invention,” Mr. Webster added. “Kids will be stimulated. And, parents, you’ll enjoy the sights.”

headline: IHT Quick Read: May 11
text: NEWS Day after day, the grim drudgery of digging for bodies had progressed at Rana Plaza. Talk of rescuing survivors had faded. This was the recovery phase, and what was being recovered were corpses, the numbers spinning remorselessly forward: 700 dead became 800, then 900, with no end in sight. By Friday morning, the number had pushed above 1,000. And then, late in the afternoon, a soldier from the Bangladeshi Army, standing atop the rubble of the wrecked building, noticed an iron rod that seemed to be moving. There was a noise, a voice. Rescuers hurriedly carved a hole through a concrete pillar. Television stations in Bangladesh cut to the scene: a woman, gasping, was alive in the wreckage, nearly 17 full days after Rana Plaza had collapsed. A new number was announced: One. A female garment worker named Reshma. A survivor. A miracle. “Save me!” rescuers heard her shout, before they pulled her into the afternoon light, her face powdered in dust as she was placed on a stretcher. Julfikar Ali Manik reports from Dhaka, Bangladesh and Jim Yardley reports from New Delhi.

headline: Why Putin Can’t Solve Syria
text: MOSCOW – After marathon meetings with Secretary of State John Kerry here this week, the Russian foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov, hinted that Moscow might finally pressure President Bashir al-Assad of Syria to leave office.

headline: South Korean Ex-Aide Denies Improper Conduct on Trip

headline: Ex-Premier Is Set to Regain Power in Pakistan Vote

headline: Tropical Cyclone Could Threaten Refugees in Myanmar
text: BANGKOK — A tropical cyclone in the Andaman Sea is headed close to an area in Myanmar where tens of thousands of victims of ethnic and religious violence are living in makeshift camps, adding urgency to fears of what the United Nations has termed a looming “humanitarian catastrophe.”

headline: This Week in the Global Arts Guide
text: The notoriety of the French-American artist Niki de Saint Phalle (1930-2002) came when she left her family to devote herself to art, starting with her ‘‘shooting paintings’’ for which she fired at pockets of paint affixed to canvases. They earned her a place in the New Realism movement with Arman, Klein, Christo and others. “The Girl, the Monster and the Goddess” at the Moderna Museet in Stockholm assembles works that evoke her traumas and reflect the creative way she coped with them. Her Freudian film ‘‘Daddy, 1973’’ about her relationship with her father in a mélange of autobiography and fantasy, is also in the show.

headline: Mille Miglia Reignites Italy’s Racing Passions
text: BRESCIA, Italy – “It is very certain the accomplishment of Stirling Moss with the new Mercedes 300 SLR sports car in the 22nd Mille Miglia will stand as one of the finest of this or any racing season,” wrote the noted motoring journalist Bernard Cahier in the immediate aftermath of the 1955 race.

headline: Pakistanis Explain What the Election Means to Them
text: Pakistanis go to the polls on Saturday in a general election, marking the first time in the country’s history that one elected civilian government will complete its term and hand over power to another elected government.

headline: Who’s Afraid of Gin?
text: If I had a dollar for every time someone told me “Tequila makes me crazy,” I would have a pretty hefty wad of cash. And just yesterday a man told me he doesn’t drink whiskey because it makes him angry. (I’ve heard that one before, too. Plenty.) Still, I believe gin has the most fearsome reputation of all liquors, and it just doesn’t seem deserved. In my Drink column this week, I admit that for many years I forswore gin because I thought it made me sad. But the gin was not to blame; normal life circumstances were — and so were the lingering effects of having seen William Hogarth’s “Gin Lane.”

headline: In Praise of Econowonkery
text: Mike Konczal has an interesting piece on the general question of whether wonk-blogging — the practice of putting up fairly analytical data-heavy posts bearing on policy issues directly on the web, rather than going through more traditional publication channels — is a good thing. He puts it in the context of liberal politics, which it mostly (though not entirely) is; but I’d like to think about it more generally as a way in which data and analysis can be brought quickly to bear on policy discussion.

headline: Pakistanis Vote as Violence Breaks Out
text: Voters turned out for a historic election as threats of attacks were borne out, with violence across the country leaving at least 21 people dead.

headline: Harpooning Ben Bernanke
text: Brad DeLong has the best piece I’ve seen on Bernanke rage among the hedge funders. His point is that the hedgies keep thinking of the Fed as if it were a rogue trader driving prices away from their natural value, like JP Morgan’s London Whale, rather than as a central bank trying to achieve full employment and target inflation. Hence their rage at the failure of bond prices to collapse the way they “should”.

headline: A People Without a Story
text: FOUR years ago this week, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam announced that their struggle for an independent homeland in northern Sri Lanka had “reached its bitter end.” The group had been fighting on behalf of the Tamil people for more than a quarter-century, and its defeat was absolute.

headline: Inflation Madness
text: One thing I gather from various economic discussions as well as some of the trolls on this blog is that there’s a widespread view that the kind of monetary policy I advocate — which includes a higher inflation target — isn’t just wrong; it’s madness. It is, I am told in no uncertain terms, proof that I am no longer a real economist, if I ever was.

headline: Why the Fuss Over the D.S.M.-5?

headline: Anglers Follow the Bugs to the Trout

Thousands of female specimens circled 30 feet above the water’s surface, preparing to descend and drop their eggs. Occasionally, a bug would spiral slowly down to the river, flutter awkwardly on the surface, then disappear in a sudden splash.

headline: America the Clueless
text: THE problems with our country’s political discourse are many and grave, but an insufficient attention to Obamacare isn’t among them. We have talked Obamacare to death, or at least into home hospice care. The “Obamacare” shorthand itself reflects our need to come up with less of a mouthful than “Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act,” given how regularly the topic recurs. “Obamacare” is like “J. Lo” or “KFC.” It saves syllables and speeds things along.

headline: China’s Evolving ‘Core Interests’
text: Whenever China wants to identify the issues considered important enough to go to war over, it uses the term “core interests.” The phrase was once restricted to Taiwan, the island nation that China has threatened to forcibly unify with the mainland. About five years ago, Chinese leaders expanded the term to include Tibet and Xinjiang, two provinces with indigenous autonomy movements that Beijing has worked feverishly to control.

headline: Shortcomings of a Psychiatric Bible
text: Patients and parents concerned about mental illness have every right to be confused. The head of the federal agency that finances mental health research has just declared that the most important diagnostic manual for psychiatric diseases lacks scientific validity and needs to be bolstered by a new classification system based on biology, not just psychiatric opinion. The hitch is that such a biology-based system will not be available for a decade or more.

headline: The Zombie Next Door May Be the Scariest of All
text: The term “zombie” has traditionally referred to a corpse that has been reanimated through supernatural means and rendered into an automaton that does its master’s will. Look it up in a dictionary and you will find the traditional definition firmly in place. But pop culture, of course, has its own definition.

headline: Tasty, and Subversive, Too

headline: Brothers, Stars, Rivals

text: The St. Louis Cardinals played 13 postseason games last October, falling one win short of returning to the World Series. Seven of those games were started by Kyle Lohse or Chris Carpenter, and another by Jaime Garcia, who hurt his shoulder in the third inning.

headline: Social Media in China Fuel Citizen Response to Quake

headline: A Voucher Deal That Wasn’t So Sweet
text: LET’S start with a final Whirlpool update. Last we heard from Shira London — the woman who was told by a third-party warranty company that her refrigerator had a “pre-existing condition” and therefore was not covered for repairs — she’d been sent a new fridge. Unfortunately, it was damaged, so her husband declined delivery.

headline: A Life of Science Was in the Cards
text: I AM a proud member of a small, emerging class of minority women with careers in science, technology, engineering and mathematics — the STEM fields for short. As a professor at Yale University and a scientist in the field of tissue engineering, or regenerative medicine, I’m often asked how I got to where I am. I usually respond with stories of my early interest in problem-solving and puzzles.

headline: Neither Teacher Nor Nurse
text: I GREW up in Grosse Pointe Woods and Bloomfield Hills, Mich. My father, who immigrated from Germany in 1925, worked in the automotive industry for 35 years, retiring from Chrysler. He was a brilliant inventor and businessman who occasionally took me with him when he visited engineering companies on Saturdays.

headline: On a College Waiting List? Sending Cookies Isn’t Going to Help

headline: Dean Jeffries, Car Customizer and Painter, Dies at 80

headline: Review of 50 Brooklyn Murder Cases Ordered
text: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office has ordered a review of some 50 murder cases assigned to an acclaimed homicide detective, an acknowledgment of mounting questions about the officer’s tactics and the legitimacy of the convictions.

headline: The Mellowing of Maxine Waters
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Timeline: Maxine Waters, the Firebrand Overseeing Finance
text: Representative Maxine Waters of California has softened her tone since becoming the top Democrat on the House Financial Services Committee in January.

headline: Simply Put
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I won’t lie to you: I didn’t enjoy this one. And I wanted to, really I did.

headline: Niese Stays Consistent, Just Not in the Way the Mets Had Hoped
text: Before the season, the Mets’ pitching staff was loaded with question marks, with Matt Harvey entering his first full season, Dillon Gee and Shaun Marcum working back from injuries and the unproven Jeremy Hefner at the back of the rotation.

headline: More Science Fiction for Economists (Seriously Time-Wasting)
text: Noah Smith has a list; all good stuff, although not all to my taste. (I just can’t read Cory Doctorow, and don’t know why). Definitely definitely The Dispossessed, which never seems to lose its relevance.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 12
text: As scrutiny of the September attacks on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, intensifies, Representative Darrell Issa of California, chairman of the House oversight committee, and Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, chairwoman of the Intelligence Committee, will join NBC’s “Meet the Press” on Sunday.

headline: Hidden Threats to Young Athletes
text: In February, hundreds of youth sports safety advocates convened at a Washington hotel. They were determined to talk about something other than concussions, a counterintuitive ambition considering the rampant worry about the effects of head trauma in young athletes.

headline: Man Takes Hostages in Trenton
text: A standoff between an armed man and dozens of police officers at a house in Trenton continued into a second day, the police said on Saturday, amid reports that the man had killed at least one person inside the home and was holding children hostage.

headline: Netanyahu and Putin to Discuss Syria
text: JERUSALEM — Amid growing concern in Israel and the West that Russia may soon deliver a sophisticated air defense system to Syria, Israeli and Russian officials confirmed on Saturday that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu would meet with President Vladimir V. Putin as early as this week.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: 3 Arrested in Plot to Bomb Egyptian Cities and Embassy
text: CAIRO — Egyptian security forces have arrested three militants with ties to Al Qaeda who were planning terrorist attacks in Egyptian cities and against a foreign embassy, the interior minister said Saturday.

headline: Berlusconi Rallies Supporters, With Defiant Words for Judges and Prosecutors
text: BRESCIA, Italy — A rally in this northern Italian city on Saturday to protest two court rulings against former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi — and organized by Mr. Berlusconi’s party, one of the partners in Italy’s uneasy new government — became a fresh test of the coalition since it was formed under pressure two weeks ago.

headline: Foreign Nations Push for Special Immigration Treatment
text: A closer look South Korea’s lobbying effort to secure beneficial provisions in the immigration bill.

headline: Some Countries Lobby for More in Race for Visas
text: WASHINGTON — The government of South Korea hired a former C.I.A. analyst, two White House veterans and a team of ex-Congressional staff members to help secure a few paragraphs in the giant immigration bill.

headline: Championship Drama, Months Early
text: The World Chess Federation has decided that the World Championship match in November will be held in Chennai, India, the hometown of the titleholder, Viswanathan Anand, and that the prizes will total $2.55 million.

headline: Stars Are Feeling Down With Rangers on Verge Of Being Knocked Out
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — After practice Saturday afternoon, Rick Nash and a glum Brad Richards talked about their scoring slumps. Coach John Tortorella declined to talk about his struggling stars.

headline: Paramedic Denies Role in Deadly Texas Blast
text: WEST, Texas — A volunteer paramedic who became a public face of mourning after last month’s deadly blast at a fertilizer plant in this Central Texas town denied having any involvement in the explosion, his lawyer said on Saturday.

headline: For Gritty Grizzlies, Their Kind of Win
text: MEMPHIS — Zach Randolph screamed at Lionel Hollins. Marc Gasol screamed at the officials. Tony Allen screamed at himself. No one will ever accuse the Grizzlies of being a quiet, understated team. They like to share their feelings. Hollins, the team’s coach, prefers it that way.

headline: García Loses Concentration and the Lead at the Players Championship
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Nineteen other times Sergio García had been paired with Tiger Woods, and on most of those occasions García staggered off the course at the end of the round with the look of someone who had seen a ghost. Only three times in those meetings had García finished with the better score.

headline: Texas Advocacy Group Wields Charter-Policy Power
text: As his legislation expanding the state’s virtual school network reached the floor of the Texas House in early May, Representative Ken King was focused on what it was not.

headline: Yankees Consider Putting Nunez on Disabled List
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The Yankees are getting closer to placing Eduardo Nunez on the 15-day disabled list with a strained left rib cage muscle. Manager Joe Girardi said he spoke to General Manager Brian Cashman on Saturday and a decision will most likely be made before Monday’s doubleheader in Cleveland. But, as Girardi noted, the Yankees cannot afford to go into that day short-handed.

headline: Just Before Summer Tours, a Burst of New CDs
text: As the midpoint of 2013 approaches, an impressive array of high-profile releases from Texas artists has already emerged, highlighted by an octogenarian legend (Willie Nelson), a cult favorite (Iron and Wine), an embattled Dixie Chick (Natalie Maines) and a promising country starlet (Kacey Musgraves). Who’s next? A Beyoncé album, still unscheduled, is somewhere on the horizon. But more immediately there is a robust selection of Texans releasing new music — from hip-hop to country and indie rock to Top 40 — in advance of the summer touring season.

headline: A Bill to Bolster the Fight on Wrongful Convictions
text: Clinton Bamberger lost the most important case of his career, but most legal experts consider that 1963 United States Supreme Court decision a crucial victory for criminal justice.

headline: Out of Egypt’s Chaos, Musical Rebellion
text: CAIRO — One washed towels in a barbershop. The other sold fast food. Some nights, they would grab the microphones at outdoor weddings and try out raps they had written, only to earn a hail of stones.

headline: Egypt’s Music Revolution
text: A youth-driven and socially conscious music genre called mahraganat reflects social shifts spurred by the revolution that toppled President Hosni Mubarak in 2011.

headline: Texas Bill Would Let Doctors Get Data From Driver’s Licenses
text: Health care providers in Texas could soon collect or verify patient information by swiping that patient’s driver’s license.

headline: G.O.P. Delays on Nominees Raise Tension
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s latest cabinet-level nominees are running into deep resistance in the Senate, pitching Democrats and Republicans into another tense standoff over White House appointments.

headline: Trailing Early, Late and in Between
text: INDIANAPOLIS — From the moment they took the court last fall, the refashioned Knicks held certain truths to be self-evident, that they were endowed with the inalienable right to shoot and score at will, the farther from the basket the better.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 12

headline: Islanders Put On a Show, but Then the Penguins Drop the Curtain

headline: Pettitte Gets on Track and Keeps Team in Groove
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Andy Pettitte was closely following his son’s high school baseball team in its playoff series through various hand-held devices. Pettitte’s son Josh had thrown a no-hitter for his team in Deer Park, Tex., on Friday night. On Saturday, hours before Pettitte took the mound, he learned that his son’s team had staged a late-inning comeback, with Josh providing two key hits, to win the series.

text: Images from Indiana’s 82-71 victory, which gave it a 2-1 lead in the series.

headline: Yankees’ Chamberlain Gives Rivera a Dugout Rebuke
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Mariano Rivera has been the focus of adoring affection everywhere he has gone in baseball since announcing that this would be his final season. As part of his farewell tour, he has been meeting with fans and team employees in each city he visits.

headline: Lao She’s Art Collection Auctioned Amid Enthusiasm
text: BEIJING — For China’s newly rich and hungry art collectors, the combination of Lao She, one of the country’s most beloved 20th-century writers, and Qi Baishi, one of its most famous 20th-century painters, was irresistible: on Saturday evening, the second day of the China Guardian 2013 Spring Auctions in Beijing, 16 paintings from the private collection of the writer who killed himself during the Cultural Revolution sold for 167.6 million yuan, or $27 million, the auction house said.

headline: South Korea Seeks Journalist’s Arrest in Defamation Case
text: SEOUL, South Korea — State prosecutors are seeking to arrest a South Korean journalist on charges of violating election laws for reporting an unconfirmed suspicion ahead of December’s presidential vote that the brother of the leading candidate might have been involved in the killing of a relative, the journalist’s lawyers said Sunday.

headline: After a Journalist’s Prodding, China Investigates a Top Official
text: HONG KONG — China’s top anticorruption agency said Sunday that it was investigating Liu Tienan, a senior economic policy maker, in an abrupt turn in a case that openly pitted him against a campaigning investigative journalist.

headline: Two Killings Preceded 37-Hour Trenton Standoff
text: Just before she disappeared two weeks ago, Carmenlita Stevens went to a cousin’s house not far from her own in Trenton, and complained that her boyfriend, Gerald Tyrone Murphy, had become volatile. She feared that she and her five children were in danger, and by the time she left, at 3 a.m., she had resolved to leave him.

headline: After Fair Trade Coffee, Fair Trade Shea
text: A few of the estimated 16 million African women who pick shea nuts for a living are going to be making their case for fair trade to the giant corporations who buy their nuts in New York City on Monday.

headline: Malaysia’s Close Elections
text: Malaysia’s elections end in controversy.

headline: From Isabella Rossellini,  Creature Moms
text: Isabella Rossellini does nothing by half measures. She didn’t hesitate to shed her glamour, and her clothes, exposing a battered body in “Blue Velvet,” or to play a withered matron in “Two Lovers.” Now the actress-director and model has cast herself as, of all things, a spider with a multitude of eyes and teats; a scruffy hamster that devours her babes; and a cuckoo that deposits her eggs in a rival’s nest.

headline: Arrests and Calls for Calm in Turkey
text: REYHANLI, Turkey — Turkish officials said Sunday that they had arrested nine people accused of carrying out twin bombings in this town near the Syrian border the day before, as the investigation moved at a clip that underscored the intense pressure on the government to contain the fallout from the attacks.

headline: How We Do It: Time Diaries of Family Life
text: “I don’t know how you do it.”

headline: How Debbie Wasserman Schultz Does It
text: Friday, April 19, 2013, Weston, Fla.

headline: Few Vote in Bulgaria as Apathy Prevails
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Bulgarians turned out in record low numbers on Sunday to choose a government to replace the one that resigned after angry and unfocused demonstrations and a bloody crackdown here in the capital this year.

headline: Disruptions: Even the Tech Elites Leave Gadgets Behind
text: If you were to meet 32-year-old Robin Sloan of San Francisco, you might think him a Luddite unable to get his head around new technologies. He owns an old Nokia phone with one main application: making phone calls. He takes notes using a pen and paper notepad. And he reads books printed on paper.

headline: Little Pigs, Little Pigs, Let Us In on Your Mysterious Past
text: Joe Diaz remembers the call on his two-way radio. About eight years ago, he was beckoned down to the crawl space under the auditorium at the Stern School of Business at New York University. His team of facilities workers had found something he needed to see: a box full of little ceramic pigs.

headline: Jacqueline Brookes, Actress and Teacher, Dies at 82
text: Jacqueline Brookes, an actress who appeared in films and on television but who won her widest acclaim on the stage in New York and around the country, performing the work of Shakespeare, Molière, Pirandello, Edward Albee and other dramatists over a 60-year career, died on April 26 in Manhattan. She was 82.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 10:30 P.M. (HBO) FAMILY TREE In this new, largely improvised series from Christopher Guest and Jim Piddock, Chris O’Dowd plays the down-on-his-luck Tom Chadwick, a 30-year-old Briton grappling with his identity since losing his girlfriend and his job. But when his Great-Aunt Victoria bequeaths him a chest of curios, he starts investigating his lineage to understand better who he and his unconventional family actually are. The ventriloquist Nina Conti plays his sister, Bea, who speaks through a monkey hand puppet; Michael McKean, above right, with Mr. O’Dowd, is their father. In this premiere episode, Tom finds a black-and-white portrait thought to be of his great-grandfather Harry and tracks down Neville St. Aubrey (Christopher Fairbank), an oddball antique photography expert. Tom’s best friend, Pete (Tom Bennett), meanwhile, fixes him up with a model. But what kind, exactly, no one is sure. “There is a familiarity to the series,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “As in Mr. Guest’s films, its story is less important than the presentation of a gallery of eccentrics, ranging from mildly odd to completely loony.” One result, Mr. Hale said, is that the series “can feel a little loose and inconsequential” as Tom “unearths one dotty, inglorious relative after another.” But “that also means that we get to spend more time with Mr. Guest’s crack cast of improvisers,” he added, “and there are moments in each half-hour that pay off.”

headline: Nevillenomics
text: Nicholas Crafts has a really interesting piece about UK economic policy in the 1930s. The gist is that monetary policy drove recovery through the expectations channel; the Bank of England managed to credibly promise to be irresponsible, that is, to generate inflation.

headline: Chairman of Benghazi Board Defends Its Decision Not to Question Clinton
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department board that reviewed last year’s attack on a diplomatic outpost in Libya never questioned Hillary Rodham Clinton, the secretary of state at the time, because it had already decided responsibility lay below her level, the board’s chairman said Sunday.

headline: Maintaining an ‘SNL’ Link, Meyers to Succeed Fallon on NBC’s ‘Late Night’
text: Seth Meyers will be the next host of NBC’s “Late Night,” the network announced on Sunday.

headline: Seeking College Edge, Chinese Pupils Arrive in New York Earlier
text: Weiling Zhang, a sophomore at the Léman Manhattan Preparatory School, yearned to communicate with more conviction and verve than her peers back home — the “American way,” she said.

headline: I.R.S. Focus on Conservatives Gives G.O.P. an Issue to Seize On
text: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service’s special scrutiny of small-government groups applying for tax-exempt status went beyond keyword hunts for organizations with “Tea Party” or “Patriot” in their names, to a more overtly ideological search for applicants seeking to “make America a better place to live” or “criticize how the country is being run,” according to part of a draft audit by the inspector general that has been given to Capitol Hill.

headline: Building a $325,000 Burger
text: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands — As a gastronomic delicacy, the five-ounce hamburger that Mark Post has painstakingly created here surely will not turn any heads. But Dr. Post is hoping that it will change some minds.

headline: A Strong ‘Gatsby’ and Stronger ‘Iron Man 3’
text: Moviegoers ignored naysaying critics and swarmed to Baz Luhrmann’s stylized 3-D adaptation of “The Great Gatsby” over the weekend. But “Iron Man 3” (Walt Disney Studios) repeated as the No. 1 box office draw in North America, taking in $72.5 million, for a two-week total of $284.9 million. “Gatsby,” adapted from F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic novel and starring Leonardo DiCaprio in the title role, sold about $51.1 million in tickets in second place — an astounding result for a period drama.

headline: A Fitting Farewell at Old Trafford, Right Down to the Ending
text: The Manchester rain fell relentlessly on the end of Alex Ferguson’s extraordinary reign at Old Trafford.

headline: Nadal and Williams Dominate in Madrid Open Finals
text: MADRID — In front of an adoring crowd and on his cherished clay surface, Rafael Nadal defeated Stanislas Wawrinka to win the Madrid Open on Sunday, securing his fifth title since returning in February from a knee injury.

headline: Yankees Play Down Chamberlain-Rivera Exchange as Family Squabble
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Yankees closer Mariano Rivera tried Sunday to defuse any fallout from a testy exchange the night before in which his fellow reliever Joba Chamberlain rebuked him in front of fans and reporters.

headline: In Taiwan, Lamenting a Lost Lead
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Jonney Shih, the chairman of Asustek Computer, has epitomized the Taiwanese electronics engineer for a generation: a slender figure in rumpled, baggy trousers, he once helped Intel solve heat problems in its Pentium 4 microprocessors.

headline: For Witness to Nagasaki, a Life Focused on Science
text: LOS ALAMOS, N.M. — Sixty-eight years ago, Osamu Shimomura was a 16-year-old high school student working in a factory seven and a half miles from Nagasaki, Japan. Sitting down to work, a light flashed, briefly blinding him, and the pressure wave from an explosion came rolling through.

headline: Pop, American Songbook and Young Charm
text: If the young women who packed 54 Below at 11 p.m. on Friday didn’t emit the piercing screams you would hear at a Justin Bieber concert, it was because Aaron Tveit, the handsome 29-year-old star they came to adore, is a decade older, and these fans were in their late teens and 20s. But the atmosphere suggested a more restrained version of the fervor exhibited by Beliebers.

headline: 2 Presidential Candidates in Iran Draw Resentment
text: TEHRAN — A day after two game-changing politicians signed up at the last minute as candidates for Iran’s presidential elections in June, the country’s governing establishment reacted angrily, predicting that they would not be allowed to participate or that they would definitely lose.

headline: Orb’s Exercise Rider Shares Insight Before Preakness
text: Jenn Patterson, an exercise rider for Shug McGaughey, has a morning set list that reads like a who’s who of elite equine athletes. It includes the multiple Grade I winner Point of Entry, the Virginia Derby winner Air Support, and Imaging, who is scheduled to contest the Dixie Stakes on the undercard of the Preakness Stakes next Saturday.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Defending a Scrap of Soul Against MoMA
text: Last week was a good one for common sense and manning the barricades in New York. The City Planning Commission recommended limiting the special permit that allows Madison Square Garden to operate at its current site, which opens the door to fixing Penn Station, trapped below it.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Information to be released includes retail sales for April, business inventories for March, and China industrial production and retail sales for April (Monday); the import price index and euro area industrial production (Tuesday); the Producer Price Index and industrial production for April; capital flows for March, and the euro area gross domestic product for the first quarter (Wednesday); the Consumer Price Index for April, initial jobless claims, and housing starts for April (Thursday); the University of Michigan’s preliminary consumer sentiment index for May, and leading indicators for April (Friday).

headline: A Card Game at Lunchtime
text: It was raining cats and dogs last Thursday at noon when audience members filed into the Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92nd Street Y, spreading the odor of wet coats and umbrellas. It was the lunchtime performance of the final run of chamber-music concerts presented and, in part, performed by the violinist Jaime Laredo with a program encompassing works by Dvorak, Brahms and Franck. The auditorium was divided into two camps. In the front half, the musically literate, as evidenced by the significant number of musical scores spread out on laps. In the back, 150 high school students. For the former, chamber music was a necessity on par with a well-brewed cup of coffee; for the latter, a novelty.

headline: D.J. Crews Strut Through Four Rounds of Battle
text: The sound clash is a 60-year-old Jamaican tradition in which D.J. crews work the same crowd in the same space. It’s a completely sturdy carnival-culture, art-as-battle ritual: the audience declares the winner, deciding through body reflex and intellectual surprise, voting with hands and lungs.

text: Accounts

headline: Burying Victims and Hunting for Suspects After a Bombing in Turkey
text: The Turkish authorities said Sunday that nine people had been detained in twin car bombings the day before in Reyhanli, near the Syrian border.

headline: On a Scavenger Hunt to Save Most Humans
text: One of the first characters to appear in “Inferno” is a spike-haired, malevolent biker chick dressed in black leather. She looks like trouble in more ways than one. What is the girl with the dragon tattoo doing in Dan Brown’s new book?

headline: Imperfect Harvey Gets Little Help From Offense
text: The margin of error for the Mets, in the midst of an offensive slumber, is minuscule. The slightest misstep — an uncharacteristic inning from their ace, Matt Harvey, or a badly placed pitch by the usually reliable closer Bobby Parnell, or an unlucky bounce to a Pirates infielder — can spell disaster.

headline: Yeh Brothers Cup in Japan
text: At the Yeh Brothers Cup in Japan last month, teams eliminated from the main event dropped into two subsidiary events, a Swiss teams and a pairs.

headline: A Lament for the Wrath of a Storm and the Losses It Wrought
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The idea of a collaboration between the idiosyncratic New York multimedia artist Laurie Anderson and the Kronos Quartet, a musically omnivorous San Francisco ensemble, seems so obvious that you wonder why it never happened before now. “Landfall,” a new 70-minute piece Ms. Anderson designed to perform alongside Kronos, came to Montclair State University here on Friday night, as part of that institution’s reliably invigorating Peak Performances series.

headline: Martin Short to Write Memoir for Harper
text: “Although I’ve never read a book all the way through, I’m sure excited to write one.” This is how Martin Short, in a statement from his publisher, announced Sunday that he had struck a deal to write his first book, a memoir of his life and enduring career in show business. Harper, the imprint of HarperCollins that published an autobiography of Amanda Knox last month, will release the book in fall 2014. Mr. Short, a comedian and actor who created some of his most famous characters on SCTV and “Saturday Night Live,” will write about those years, as well as his time working on films like “The Three Amigos.” He will also cover his 30-year marriage to Nancy, who died in 2010, and his longtime friendships with fellow Hollywood stars. A title is forthcoming, Mr. Short added: “I haven’t named my book yet, but I’m toying with the title ‘If I’d Saved, I Wouldn’t Be Writing This.’ ”

headline: In Suit Over Death, Boogaard’s Family Blames the N.H.L.
text: The family of Derek Boogaard has filed a wrongful-death lawsuit against the National Hockey League.

headline: An Orchestra in the Throes of a Lockout
text: When the Finnish conductor Osmo Vanska took over as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra in 2003, he told the players that he wanted it to be “the best orchestra in this country in four or five years,” he recounted in a 2006 interview.

headline: Music for Violin, With Faustian Strings Attached
text: Everyone knows that the Devil has the best tunes. And we also know what he plays them on: a fiddle. From Tartini’s “Devil’s Trill” Violin Sonata of 1713 to the Charlie Daniels Band’s 1979 country music ballad “The Devil Went Down to Georgia,” the instrument most readily associated with the Crafty One is a violin.

headline: Rocking and Rapping in Assorted Spots Below Houston Street
text: Why throw a music festival? There are so many easier things to do. An undertaking of such scale requires aesthetic vision, pinpoint organization, an ability to corral like-minded listeners into one place and at least a little hubris, but hopefully not too much.

headline: Searching for Meaning With Britten as a Guide
text: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center concluded its Britten centennial series with a program at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night that, on paper, looked like a curious collection of pieces. In the first half there were four chamber works, three written when Britten was in his early 20s. One was composed when he was just 18: the Phantasy Quartet for oboe and strings, played dazzlingly by the virtuosic young oboist James Austin Smith and three members of the Orion String Quartet.

headline: There Is Something Rotten in the Kingdom of Rome
text: It’s been a strong few weeks for productions of operas from the 1930s and ’40s at New York conservatories. First, on April 24, came a powerful vision of Brecht and Weill’s “Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny” at the Manhattan School of Music, a reminder of the continued relevance of that sharp and moving work.

headline: ABC to Live-Stream Its Shows via App
text: This week ABC will quietly revolutionize its app for iPhones and iPads with a button called “live.” Users around New York and Philadelphia will be able to live-stream all the programming from ABC’s local stations there, the first time that any major broadcaster has turned on such a technology.

headline: You’ve Heard It Many Times Before
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Mondays are tough enough, but did Allan E. Parrish have to get us all mixed up as well?

headline: Greek Crackdown on Tax Evasion Yields Little Revenue
text: ATHENS — If ignominy were tax revenue, Greece might be a big step closer to ending its budget problems.

headline: Rivera Again Finishes Where He Left Off
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — As Mariano Rivera jogged in from the Kauffman Stadium bullpen in the ninth inning for the 28th and probably final time, the fans gave him a loud ovation, even if it meant they were cheering for the opposing team.

headline: It’s Ballet, With Booze and Bulls
text: WASHINGTON — The very idea of a ballet adaptation of Ernest Hemingway’s novel “The Sun Also Rises” ought to invite snickers. I confess that I was looking forward in cynical spirit to solemn ballet mime grandly indicating Jake’s erectile dysfunction — not to mention the war wound that caused it — and, of course, a frisky dance version of the running of the bulls at Pamplona.  Yet there was no derision in evidence on Thursday night, when the Washington Ballet gave the world premiere of Septime Webre’s two-act staging at the Kennedy Center’s Eisenhower Theater.

headline: The Outlook for the Next TV Season, as Presented to Advertisers Upfront
text: A roundup of what worked — and what didn’t — in the 2012-13 television schedules, and what to expect from the coming upfronts.

headline: NBC Looks to Past Stars as It Rebuilds Its Schedule for a Turnaround in Prime Time
text: Looking for what has been an elusive turnaround in prime time, NBC announced an aggressive new schedule on Sunday, crowded with new shows and familiar names both in front of and behind the camera.

headline: Public University Presidents Are Prospering, Annual Compensation Study Finds
text: In the 2011-12 fiscal year, the nation’s highest paid public university president was Graham B. Spanier, the president of Pennsylvania State University, who was forced out in November 2011 over his handling of a child sex abuse scandal involving a football coach.

headline: Warriors Young and Old Help Square the Series
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — When Golden State Coach Mark Jackson spotted guard Stephen Curry on Sunday morning before the Warriors faced the San Antonio Spurs, he asked Curry for an update on his injured left ankle.

headline: Big Vote on Dimon May Hinge on Views on JPMorgan’s Top Director
text: In his 12 years as chief executive of Exxon Mobil, Lee R. Raymond had a reputation for bulldozing analysts and long-winded shareholders and going toe-to-toe with government authorities.

headline: Giving Voice to Women’s Game
text: SUMMERFIELD, Fla. — When Rhonda Glenn was a young woman in 1966, she was the publicity coordinator for the L.P.G.A.’s Louise Suggs Invitational in Delray Beach, Fla. She was an amateur at that event and was paired in the first round with Mickey Wright and Betsy Rawls, who went on to become Hall of Famers.

headline: No Rest and No Margin of Error for the Rangers
text: The fans were tense and worried in the second period at Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon. The Rangers were locked in a scoreless tie in an elimination game against the Washington Capitals. They began to nervously overpass, declining to shoot, flubbing scoring chances. The crowd responded with chants of “Shoot the puck! Shoot the puck!”

headline: Afghans Say an American Tortured Civilians
text: MAIDAN SHAHR, Afghanistan — The authorities in Afghanistan are seeking the arrest on murder and torture charges of a man they say is an American and part of a Special Forces unit operating in Wardak Province, three Afghan officials have confirmed.

headline: Officials Say Homophobia Motivated Murder in Russia
text: MOSCOW — The brutal murder of a 23-year-old man in the southern city of Volgograd was motivated by homophobia, investigators said Sunday, a rare acknowledgment that comes during a period of rising conservative and antigay sentiment from Russian officials.

headline: Sophomore Slump Afflicts Once-Promising TV Shows
text: The last thing network television needs is a sophomore slump.

headline: Hospital Mergers Reset Abortion-Access Battle
text: MOUNT VERNON, Wash. — Politicians seeking to restrict access to abortion, a marked trend this year from North Dakota to Arkansas, tend not to get much traction in this part of the country.

headline: Higher Bid for Kings Adds Twist to Battle
text: The fight for ownership of the Sacramento Kings, one of the N.B.A.’s most beleaguered franchises, will take a big step toward resolution Wednesday when the league’s owners vote on a recommendation that the team be prohibited from moving to Seattle.

headline: Newspaper Monopoly That Lost Its Grip
text: A year after announcing a plan to reorganize The Times-Picayune of New Orleans into a more digitally focused enterprise that produced a newspaper just three days a week — enraging local residents — its owners have added a new innovation: they will go back to producing a printed product every day.

headline: Jack Butler, an Undrafted Football Hall of Famer, Dies at 85
text: Jack Butler, who was ignored in the National Football League draft but became a Hall of Fame defensive back with the Pittsburgh Steelers and was chosen for the league’s all-decade team of the 1950s, died on Saturday in Pittsburgh. He was 85.

headline: Catskill Cultural Center Saved, and Renewed, Thanks to a Fiddler’s Tune
text: OLIVEBRIDGE, N.Y. — On a spring Sunday in the Catskill Mountains, Jay Ungar, a fiddler wearing a black vest and hiking boots, and his wife, Molly Mason, playing guitar, stood on a stage in a barnlike performance hall that did not exist a year ago. “Can you stand to hear this tune one more time?” he asked the audience.

headline: A New Direction for a Hasbro Stalwart
text: Hasbro, the toy company that brought its Transformers and G.I. Joe properties to movie theaters, has set its sights on its next summer blockbuster: My Little Pony.

headline: A Self-Defeating Change in Course for the Knicks
text: INDIANAPOLIS

headline: Cyberattacks Against U.S. Corporations Are on the Rise
text: WASHINGTON — A new wave of cyberattacks is striking American corporations, prompting warnings from federal officials, including a vague one issued last week by the Department of Homeland Security. This time, officials say, the attackers’ aim is not espionage but sabotage, and the source seems to be somewhere in the Middle East.

headline: ‘Equestria Girls’ Trailer
text: Hoping to build on the popularity of My Little Pony, Hasbro is planning a theatrical release as part of a campaign for its brand extension, Equestria Girls.

headline: Seeking Clues to Heart Disease in DNA of an Unlucky Family
text: Early heart disease ran in Rick Del Sontro’s family, and every time he went for a run, he was scared his heart would betray him. So he did all he could to improve his odds. He kept himself lean, stayed away from red meat, spurned cigarettes and exercised intensely, even completing an Ironman Triathlon.

headline: Ace’s Moral Victories Move the Mets Closer to Real Ones
text: None of the Pittsburgh Pirates had faced Matt Harvey before Sunday, but they were familiar with him. It is hard to miss the first pitcher in the last 100 years to strike out at least 125 and allow fewer than 25 runs in his first 17 career starts.

headline: Pakistani Party Leader Looks Forward, as Claims of Vote-Rigging Swirl
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif began talks on Sunday to form a new government, as partial election returns suggested that he and his party would have a commanding hold on Parliament. But Pakistani election officials said final results would take days, even as outrage grew over accusations of rampant vote-rigging, particularly in Karachi.

headline: E Pluribus Me
text: Logic, thy name is not Ted Cruz. The very junior senator from Texas is a well-credentialed windbag, with degrees from Princeton and Harvard Law, and a stint clerking at the Supreme Court. After a few months in Congress promoting Ted Cruz, smartest guy in the room, it looks as if he now wants to be Ted Cruz, extremely obnoxious president. But he keeps saying things that make no sense.

headline: New York State to Ask Smartphone Makers to Help Prevent Thefts
text: Concerned about an increase in smartphone thefts, the New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, is trying to get the nation’s largest cellphone makers to do more to discourage the thefts.

headline: Pilotless Planes, Pacific Tensions
text: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: How Austerity Kills
text: EARLY last month, a triple suicide was reported in the seaside town of Civitanova Marche, Italy. A married couple, Anna Maria Sopranzi, 68, and Romeo Dionisi, 62, had been struggling to live on her monthly pension of around 500 euros (about $650), and had fallen behind on rent.

headline: Google’s Offer to Europe
text: Google’s competitors, like Microsoft, Expedia and Yelp, have long complained that the company uses its dominant search engine — it has more than 90 percent market share in Europe and about 70 percent in the United States — to promote its own services, like YouTube, Google Maps and others, at the expense of rivals.

headline: Last Word to Woods as García’s Game Sinks on Last 2 Holes
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — As the Players Championship wound down Sunday, there were as many compelling stories on the leader board as there were golf balls in the water surrounding the tournament’s signature hole, the par-3 17th.

headline: Student Debt and the Crushing of the American Dream
text: A CERTAIN drama has become familiar in the United States (and some other advanced industrialized countries): Bankers encourage people to borrow beyond their means, preying especially on those who are financially unsophisticated. They use their political influence to get favorable treatment of one form or another. Debts mount. Journalists record the human toll. Then comes bewilderment: How could we let this happen again? Officials promise to fix things. Something is done about the most egregious abuses. People move on, reassured that the crisis has abated, but suspecting that it will recur soon.

headline: San Diego Mayor Building Economic Bridges to Tijuana
text: SAN DIEGO — Opening a satellite city office in a far-flung neighborhood is not unusual in sprawling cities like this one. But one thing sets apart Mayor Bob Filner’s newest outpost: it is in another country.

headline: Another Round of Promises in Bangladesh
text: Under pressure to respond to the collapse of a factory building that killed more than 1,100 people, the government of Bangladesh recently pledged to impose reforms to its labor laws and safety standards. If carried out fully, the much-delayed changes could go a long way toward improving working conditions in the country’s garment industry. But that is a big if.

headline: Scrutiny on Prosecutors After Questions About Brooklyn Detective’s Work
text: As the Brooklyn district attorney’s office pledged a complete review of about 50 murder cases after questions arose regarding the conduct of the detective assigned to them, renewed scrutiny has also focused on the role prosecutors play in what turn out to be wrongful convictions, and whether they should be held responsible when justice goes awry.

headline: Who Can Take Republicans Seriously?
text: It is time for President Obama to abandon his hopes of reaching a grand budget bargain with Republicans.

text: As impressive as the Rangers were against the Washington Capitals on Sunday, their strong all-around performance left them to face a grim reality.

headline: City Plans New Approach to Disciplining Mentally Ill Inmates
text: New York City will soon change the way mentally ill inmates are disciplined after breaking rules while in jail, creating alternatives to the more traditional approach of solitary confinement used for most inmates.

headline: Cabinet Secretary Solicits Large Donations to Publicize Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, has solicited sizable donations from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and H&R Block, the tax preparation service, as part of a multimillion-dollar campaign to ensure the success of President Obama’s health care law, administration officials said Sunday, even as a leading Senate Republican raised questions about the legality of her efforts.

headline: As Minutes Add Up for Bulls’ Starters, Time Seems to Be on Heat’s Side
text: CHICAGO — The Chicago Bulls want to play rough, and they have made no secret of it. They have turned their second-round Eastern Conference playoff series against the Miami Heat into a black-and-blue affair, defined by bumps, bruises, elbows and shoves.

headline: Alarm Bells in Albany
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo, who promised to clean up state government in his 2010 campaign, has now become so alarmed by the latest scandals in Albany that he has issued a threat lawmakers ought to take seriously. If the Legislature does not pass a package of electoral reforms, including public financing, before the session ends in June, he says he will consider appointing a Moreland Act Commission that can investigate and subpoena government officials suspected of misconduct. The commission would be able to make public its findings and pass those findings on to local or federal investigators.

headline: Dark Heritage
text: Last week the Heritage Foundation delivered a report claiming that legalizing undocumented immigrants will create a more-or-less permanent underclass of benefit-sucking, wage-lowering, economy-crippling parasites, with a cost to American taxpayers of — megaphone, please — SIX POINT THREE TRILLION DOLLARS! The report was promptly denounced, not least by reputable conservative economists, for example here and here and here. Then one of the report’s co-authors resigned from Heritage after The Washington Post discovered that he had once proposed blocking immigrants with low I.Q. scores. (More on that later.)

headline: As TV Ratings and Profits Fall, Networks Face a Cliffhanger
text: As the major television networks prepare to unveil their new fall lineups in New York this week, they face threats from seemingly every corner.

headline: What Racial Profiling? Police Testify Complaint Is Rarely Made
text: He had naturally heard the accusations of racial profiling, from civil rights organizations and some politicians. But in more than a decade as the top chief in the New York Police Department, Joseph J. Esposito said he never once heard a private citizen complain about a racially motivated stop-and-frisk encounter.

headline: Central Park Group Is Seeking Better Playgrounds
text: The Central Park Conservancy, the nonprofit group that manages Central Park, said it would initiate a $40 million fund-raising campaign on Monday to pay for the restoration and improvement of the park’s 21 playgrounds.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Stranger Bearing Gifts
text: Domestic disintegration seems to be taking place in real time in “A Family for All Occasions,” a grindingly dull new play by Bob Glaudini that opened on Sunday night at the Bank Street Theater in a production directed by Philip Seymour Hoffman.

headline: Walters to Announce 2014 Retirement on ‘The View’
text: On the program she invented, on the network where she worked for the past 37 years, on the medium where she broke barriers and rules for more than 50 years, Barbara Walters will announce on Monday morning, definitively and with no regrets, that she is calling it a career.

headline: Detroit’s Emergency Manager Offers Dire Report on City
text: DETROIT — An emergency manager assigned to lead this city back from the brink of financial ruin has taken his first detailed look at Detroit’s woes, and the picture of debt and disarray he paints may be bleaker even than earlier grim portrayals.

headline: A Groundbreaking Career
text: Barbara Walters, who announced her retirement Monday, made headlines over more than 50 years with interviews with Fidel Castro, Michael Jackson and others.

headline: Newark Archbishop Is Criticized for His Handling of an Abuse Case
text: COLTS NECK, N.J. — With 10 children knelt around the altar for their first communion and the pews at St. Mary’s Church packed with families gathered for Mother’s Day, there was little sign on Sunday of the turmoil that has struck the parish, and threatens the Archdiocese of Newark.

headline: When the Pinstripes Get Ruffled
text: The Yankees have long gone by the nickname the Bombers, but they could just as easily be known as the Bronx Bickersons. And this weekend’s latest version is no exception.

headline: Valuable as Art, but Priceless as a Tool to Launder Money
text: According to the air bill slapped on the crate that arrived at Kennedy International Airport from London, an unnamed painting worth $100 was inside. Only later did federal investigators discover that it was by the American artist Jean-Michel Basquiat and worth $8 million.

text: “We need to make the border the center, not the end — but the biggest problem we have is not security, it is openness and communication.”

text: Goalie Henrik Lundqvist made 27 saves as the Rangers defeated the Capitals, 1-0, and forced a Game 7 in their first-round playoff series.
