headline: Travel Essentials | Marin County, Calif.
text: In our Summer Travel issue, which hit newsstands on Sunday, Adam Sachs professes his love for Marin County, a place he calls “the most beautiful, bucolic, privileged, liberal, hippie-dippie place on the earth.” Here’s where to eat, sleep and shop in San Francisco’s neighbor to the north.

headline: Bottled Secrets of the Geisha
text: The San Francisco-based skin care expert Victoria Tsai has built her business by studying the beauty secrets, passed down over generations, of the traditional Japanese entertainers known as geisha. After many trips east and countless hours studying makeup regimens, Tsai founded Tatcha, a line of 95-percent-natural products made and formulated in Japan. One of her first discoveries was aburatorigami, the traditional handmade blotting papers used in ancient Japan to protect gold as it is hammered into delicate gold leaf. Several centuries ago, geisha realized that the papers could also absorb facial oil, without disturbing their signature stage makeup. “I tried to do exactly what the geisha were doing, but also make products that are a little bit easier to use,” Tsai said. “And they use our stuff now.”

headline: Bloomberg Admits Terminal Snooping
text: Reporters at Bloomberg News were trained to use a function on the company’s financial data terminals that allowed them to view subscribers’ contact information and, in some cases, monitor login activity in order to advance news coverage, more than half a dozen former employees said.

headline: The Care and Feeding of Small Business
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: 2 Award-Givers’ Thumbs Turn Up for Durang
text: Two associations of theater writers and reviewers, the Outer Critics Circle and the New York Drama Critics’ Circle, have named Christopher Durang’s comedy “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” with David Hyde Pierce, as the best play of the 2012-13 season. They did not agree, though, on best musical: The Outer Critics gave that award to “Kinky Boots,” and the New York Drama Critics went with “Matilda the Musical.”

headline: How Formula Can Complement Breast-Feeding
text: Good news for new mothers: A study suggests that carefully regulated formula feeding before your milk comes in will not harm your baby’s ability to breast-feed, and done properly, it may even help in the long run.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 10 P.M. (13) THE INVISIBLE WAR (2012) The Department of Defense estimates that there were 22,800 sexual assaults in the United States military in 2011. Veterans Affairs studies have shown that one-third of women seeking assistance have been sexually assaulted, and that more men than women are assaulted while in service. This Academy Award nominee for best documentary feature, directed by Kirby Dick and produced by Amy Ziering, uses interviews with retired and active service members to investigate the epidemic of rape within the military. (A female soldier in a combat zone is more likely to be attacked by a fellow soldier than killed by enemy fire.) “Military service is often a family tradition, and the military itself, with its customs of loyalty, solidarity and shared sacrifice, can be a kind of family for its members,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “This means that the violations chronicled in ‘The Invisible War’ are compounded by a deep and terrible betrayal, which ripples outward from the various branches of the service into the society as a whole. This is not a movie that can be ignored.” (Above Kori Cioca, who served in the Coast Guard, and her husband, Rob.)

text: We’ve heard it time and again: rigor is one of the most important aspects of a college student’s application. headline: Behind the Cover Story: Jon Mooallem on Disentangling the Politics of a Hawaiian Murder Mystery
text: Jon Mooallem, contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about a mysterious rash of monk-seal killings in Hawaii. His new book, “Wild Ones: A Sometimes Dismaying, Weirdly Reassuring Story About Looking at People Looking at Animals in America,” comes out this week.

headline: Taking the Russian Police for a Ride
text: MOSCOW — I will take part in almost any activity that involves bicycling, so when I saw that someone was organizing a protest ride in Moscow, I knew I would go even though its purpose and logistics were not entirely clear.

headline: Daily Report: New Wave of Cyberattacks Against U.S. Corporations
text: A new wave of cyberattacks is striking American corporations, prompting warnings from federal officials, including a vague one issued last week by the Department of Homeland Security. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth report in The New York Times on Monday.

text: LONDON — His visit to the White House overshadowed by toxic divisions at home over Europe, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain won the support of President Obama on Monday in seeking to calm a clamor within the Conservative Party for further and faster moves toward an exit from the European Union.

headline: A Few More Ways to Enjoy the Derby
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. – The Super Bowl of horse racing, the Kentucky Derby, is the longest continuously held sporting event in the United States. It was first run in 1875, and it truly is a spectacle to behold. More than a week removed from the festivities, I’ve had time to reflect on this year’s experience.

headline: Many Happy Returns
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — Defying threats from Taliban suicide bombers,  almost 60 percent of registered voters in Pakistan headed to the polls on Saturday. It was the greatest turnout since 1970.

headline: JPMorgan’s Lead Director in Focus
text: The shareholder vote at JPMorgan Chase on splitting Jamie Dimon’s roles of chairman and chief executive could hinge on whether Lee R. Raymond, the lead director, is seen as strong enough to stand up to Mr. Dimon, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Susanne Craig report in DealBook.

headline: Fox Looks to Shore Up Comedy Lineup on Tuesdays
text: The Fox network unveiled a prime-time schedule on Monday that includes sweeping changes and — like the schedules expected from its network competitors — a copious injection of new programming.

headline: Before It Built the Enclave, Buick Built Tanks
text: Tank is a word sometimes used, both affectionately and otherwise, to describe the massive and sturdy Buick vehicles of the mid-1950s. Powered by V-8 engines and built with liberal amounts of steel and cast iron, those Buicks handily earned the name. But just a decade earlier, Buick built a real tank: the M18 Hellcat tank destroyer that helped Allied forces defeat the Axis powers in both Europe and the Pacific.

headline: China Warns Officials Against ‘Dangerous’ Western Values
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese Communist Party has warned officials to combat “dangerous” Western values and other perceived ideological threats, in a directive that analysts said on Monday reflected the determination of China’s leader to preserve top-down political control even as he considers economic liberalization.

headline: Monday Reading: Parents Seek Mates for Their Children on Dating Sites
text: Also, the college aid shell game, when to replace a dental crown and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Dell Demands More Details From Icahn and Southeastern
text: The special committee of Dell’s board overseeing the sale of the computer maker asked Carl C. Icahn and Southeastern Asset Management on Monday to furnish more information about their recent demand for a special dividend.

headline: Pakistani Leader Moves Quickly to Form Government
text: LONDON — Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif moved confidently to form a new government in Pakistan on Monday, signaling his choice to be the next finance minister even as votes from Saturday’s election were still being tallied and protests continued over alleged vote-rigging in some cities.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap: The Woman in Room 503
text: Season 6, Episode 6

headline: In the Family: Heart Disease
text: How can a former Ironman triathlete get heart disease? For Rick Del Sontro and most of his family, there’s no escape. It’s a genetic defect that has plagued generation after generation.

headline: After DVD Shipping Error, BBC Asks Fans Not to Spoil ‘Doctor Who’ Finale
text: Ah, if only the BBC had some sort of device — possibly one that’s bigger on the inside than it appears from outside — that would allow it to traverse time and space so it could prevent a few lucky viewers from getting their hands on the season finale of “Doctor Who” ahead of schedule. But it does not, and instead the broadcaster can only plead with those audience members not to reveal the details of that episode before it is shown on Saturday, and thus not risk shattering the fabric of the science-fiction fan community.

headline: Major Retailers Join Bangladesh Safety Plan
text: Three weeks after a building collapse in Bangladesh that killed more than 1,100 workers, several of the world’s largest apparel companies – including the retailing giant H&M and Inditex, owner of the Zara chain — agreed on Monday to sign a far-reaching and legally binding plan that requires retailers to help finance fire safety and building improvements in the factories they use in Bangladesh.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates Ford Super Duty Steering Loss
text: Citing a concern over possible steering loss, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether about 340,000 2008 F-250 and F-350 Super Duty pickup trucks should be recalled. According to a report posted over the weekend on the safety agency’s Web site, it has received five complaints about “an internal failure of the steering gear box resulting in a complete loss of steering control.”

headline: Mike Keenan Will Coach in K.H.L.
text: Mike Keenan, who coached the Rangers to the Stanley Cup in 1994 as part of a long and controversial N.H.L. coaching career, has signed as coach of Metallurg Magnitogorsk on the K.H.L.

headline: Which Textbook Is That, Exactly?
text: OK, on the road, and a quick post over coffee.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Guardian: Yotam Ottolenghi helps you figure out how to cook with sorrel. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Weekend Gun Report: May 10-12, 2013
text: As our report today grimly documents, the Mother’s Day weekend offered no reprieve from gun violence. Rebecca Bond, a mother of three and the co-founder, with her husband Jon, of Evolve, a group attempting to change the culture around gun safety and gun violence, wrote this piece over the weekend about how a mother’s fierce love for her children might be the best tool we have to reduce the horrifying number of senseless killings in America. It is well worth reading.

headline: Tough Times at Homeland Security
text: A new wave of cyberattacks is hitting American companies at a particularly vulnerable time for the Department of Homeland Security, the federal agency charged with fending them off.

headline: Performance at De Blasio Fund-Raiser
text: Bridget Everette, an actress, danced on stage with Bill de Blasio at a fund-raiser on Sunday night.

headline: What Will Go Unsaid at the Upfronts
text: The Times’s Brian Stelter offers a preview of television’s upfronts, highlighting what network broadcasters will leave unspoken.

headline: A Second Chance for Sea Lions
text: A video from 2013 when an an epidemic of starvation struck Southern California’s baby sea lions. Some animals had died, but the Pacific Marine Mammal Center was nursing many of them back to health.

headline: After Vote in Pakistan, Some Hope in India
text: NEW DELHI — The bitter and sometimes violent rivalry between India and Pakistan shows no signs of abating, but many in New Delhi greeted Sunday’s election results in Pakistan with measured optimism on Monday.

headline: At a Racy Fund-Raiser for de Blasio, the Target Is Quinn
text: An ample-bodied drag queen (stage name: Flotilla DeBarge) declared that “just because it’s gay doesn’t mean it thinks our way.”

headline: Focaccia: One Basic Bread, Endless Delicious Options
text: A couple of weeks ago I gave you a recipe for a walnut fougasse, or focaccia. The bread was so easy to make, and such a great vehicle for the walnuts, that I got onto a focaccia kick and started making it just about every day, topping it with vegetables and sometimes filling it with them. I tried different proportions of whole-wheat and all-purpose flour, never using less than half whole-wheat, and found that the same overall recipe worked no matter how I varied the proportions. I’m working with a terrific whole-wheat flour produced in California, available online and now carried by Fairway, called Community Grains. But I also made the focaccia with King Arthur white whole-wheat flour (I used 100 percent in that version; the result had a slightly denser, tighter texture than the other focacce).

headline: Overtimes, Game 7s and Déjà Vu in the N.H.L.
text: Apparently, the remedy for everything wrong in the N.H.L. is a Game 7. It’s as if the league went to a doctor — O.K., a faith healer, because hockey’s gatekeepers are not keen on all that actual medical information — and said: “We had this shameless money grab of a lockout, our players keep trying to take one another’s heads off even though we’ve mildly suggested they stop, our tickets are astronomically expensive and casual sports fans have to keep being reminded we exist. So what do we do?”

headline: In Soccer and Investing, Bias Is Toward Action
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: Really? Never Go Grocery Shopping on an Empty Stomach
text: THE FACTS:

headline: Triple Play: Week 6 Results
text: Three of the players in Question No. 1 greeted May with hot streaks, collecting hits in every game they played last week. Adam LaRoche was the correct answer, going 8 for 19 for a .421 average.

headline: Building Condos by the Numbers, Skipping Some Along the Way
text: Belvedere LXX is a brand-new condominium on Eckford Street in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, built of burgundy brick. It is so new that its permits still hang in the window, the closets are bare of clothes, and the apartments have yet to hit the market.

headline: I Was Groped on the Subway
text: I was late as usual, weaving through the 72nd Street subway station, rushing down the stairs to catch a departing train, and managed to squeeze into one of the packed cars just in time. It was Friday, a few weeks after my 29th birthday. I was on my way downtown to my job at my family’s taxi business, casually dressed in leggings and a striped orange dress. I pushed my still wet hair out of my face and found a sliver of space to stand. As the doors were closing, one more person shoved his way in and the car let out a collective groan.

headline: YogaFit Tries to Escape the Discount Trap
text: At the last She Owns It business group meeting, Beth Shaw, who owns YogaFit, started the discussion by sharing some painful lessons she has learned from discounting her company’s yoga teacher training.

headline: Global Retailers Join Safety Plan for Bangladesh
text: Under mounting pressure to improve working conditions in Bangladesh’s garment factories, several of the world’s largest apparel companies agreed on Monday to a landmark plan to help pay for fire safety and building improvements after the collapse last month of the Rana Plaza factory complex, which killed more than 1,100 people.

headline: Supreme Court Supports Monsanto in Seed-Replication Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled unanimously on Monday that farmers could not use Monsanto’s patented genetically altered soybeans to create new seeds without paying the company a fee.

headline: The Birth of the ‘Stainless Banner’
text: On May 1, 1863, the Confederate Congress approved a new national flag – colloquially dubbed the Stainless Banner – to replace the so-called Stars and Bars, the Confederacy’s national flag since March 1861. The new flag was a plain white field emblazoned with what was already a powerful and famous Confederate symbol, the Southern Cross, the star-bedecked blue saltire, or diagonal cross, that had been a famous battle flag since the fall of 1861. Its incorporation into the national flag confirmed the Southern Cross as the de facto symbol of Confederate nationalism.

headline: Street Style: Overalls
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of May 6.

headline: Test Tube Burger, A Lucky Stroke, Coming of the Cicadas
text: Can you get the burger without the cow? A clot in Andrew Revkin’s brain pushes him to learn about strokes — from his hospital bed. The (insect) buzz around Carl Zimmer’s new column.

headline: As China’s Economy Stumbles, Government Eyes Reform
text: Another week, another set of weak economic data out of China. Fixed-asset investment slowed and industrial production grew less than projected. And while retail sales growth met expectations, it was driven almost entirely by a 72.2 percent increase in jewelry purchases, apparently by consumers taking advantage of the drop in gold prices.

headline: Triangle Mysteries
text: This week’s puzzle is based on a beautiful discovery by Steve Humble, who teaches primary and second school trainee teachers in the education department at Newcastle University in northeastern England. The conundrum is based on Mr. Humble’s research that appears in the current issue of The Mathematical Intelligencer.

headline: New Amtrak Engines Unveiled for Northeast
text: WASHINGTON — Amtrak rolled out three new locomotives on Monday, the first step in the railroad’s plan to modernize its aging fleet of trains.

headline: An iPhone Jury-Rigged as a Microscope
text: By sticking a little $8 lens to an iPhone with a piece of double-sided tape, a Canadian doctor has produced a microscope that works reasonably well at diagnosing intestinal worms in children.

headline: The Bruins Make an Unhappy Trip to Game 7
text: TORONTO – Not only did Toronto become the 48th team to rally from down 3-1 in a playoff series to force a Game 7 with its 2-1 victory over Boston Sunday, the Bruins were stuck in Toronto overnight, forcing the team to travel home Monday morning for Monday night’s game in Boston.

headline: Science Bookshelf
text: 1 BRAIN ON FIRE by Susannah Cahalan. Simon & Schuster. A medical mystery in which doctors struggle to discover why a young reporter suddenly experiences seizures, hallucinations and eventually near catatonia.

headline: Astronaut Covers ‘Space Oddity’ From Space
text: The Canadian astronaut Chris Hadfield, who has documented his five months in charge of the International Space Station in great detail in Twitter photographs and YouTube videos, celebrated his last day aboard the craft by releasing an elaborately produced cover version of David Bowie’s “Space Oddity.”

headline: President Obama on I.R.S. Scrutiny
text: Speaking at a news conference at the White House on Monday, President Obama addressed the topic of the I.R.S. targeting and auditing of conservative groups applying for tax-exempt status.

headline: Cuccinelli’s Déjà Vu Tax Plan
text: Ken Cuccinelli, the Republican candidate for governor of Virginia and current state attorney general, has been running a classically aggressive, Nobama sort of campaign. In his book, “The Last Line of Defense,” he calls the Obama administration “the biggest set of lawbreakers in America,” and the E.P.A. an “agency of mass destruction.” He is perhaps most notorious for trying to reinstate Virginia’s “Crimes Against Nature” law, which made both oral and anal sex a felony.

headline: Cyprus Gets First Installment of Bailout Funds
text: PARIS — After striking an unprecedented deal in March to make many bank depositors help pay for an international bailout, Cyprus on Monday received €2 billion, the first installment of that money, aimed at buttressing the economy after the near-collapse of its banking sector.

headline: New Plan to Auction Banksy Mural Rekindles Battle
text: For a work scarcely a year old, “Slave Labor (Bunting Boy),” by the British graffiti artist Banksy, has been at the center of more than its share of battles, and a new one has broken out with the Sincura Group announcing that it will auction the mural at the London Film Museum on June 2.

headline: Hearing of Moths Surpasses All Others
text: Don’t say anything that you wouldn’t want the greater wax moth to hear. Researchers from the University of Strathclyde in Glasgow, Scotland, reported that the moth has the world’s most extreme hearing.

headline: President Obama on Benghazi
text: At a news conference at the White House on Monday, President Obama answered questions about his administration’s handling of the deadly terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya, on Sept. 11, 2012.

headline: Obama Dismisses Benghazi Furor but Assails I.R.S.
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, facing re-energized Republican adversaries and new questions about the administration’s conduct, on Monday dismissed a furor over the handling of last year’s attacks in Benghazi, Libya, as a political “sideshow” but joined a bipartisan chorus of outrage over disclosures that the Internal Revenue Service had singled out conservative groups for special scrutiny.

headline: Landlords Double as Energy Brokers
text: The trophy high-rises on Madison, Park and Fifth Avenues in Manhattan have long commanded the top prices in the country for commercial real estate, with yearly leases approaching $150 a square foot. So it is quite a Gotham-size comedown that businesses are now paying rents four times that in low, bland buildings across the Hudson River in New Jersey.

headline: After an Artist Steps Away From His Bag, a Summons and a Legal Battle
text: Enrico Miguel Thomas, 42, an artist who has been drawing subway stations for years, arrived at Grand Central Terminal one night in February, plopped down his bags and began drawing.

headline: Readers Are Bothered by I.R.S. Coverage, an Amanda Knox Feature, and Too-Thin Models
text: Here’s the Monday roundup:

headline: Cleveland: Disappointing Fans Since ’64
text: CLEVELAND — As a Cleveland sports fan, I hold these truths to be self-evident: no matter how promising the plan or how high the draft pick, someone will screw it up.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Alonso Brings Formula One Victory to Spain
text: Fernando Alonso, driving for Ferrari, deftly executed a four-stop pit stop strategy that yielded an emotional victory Sunday in the Grand Prix of Spain. Kimi Raikkonen of Lotus finished a distant second, followed by Alonso’s teammate Felipe Massa.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Maaco Puts ‘Uh-Oh’ in the Rearview Mirror
text: A chain that spruces up customers’ cars is trying to spruce up its own image.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Julie Atherton joined the New York office of SapientNitro as vice president for strategy. She succeeds Steve Zaroff, who is now the chief strategy officer at McCann Erickson New York. Ms. Atherton had been a global digital director on Team Colgate, the WPP unit that is devoted to the Colgate-Palmolive account. McCann Erickson New York is part of the McCann Erickson Worldwide division of the McCann Worldgroup, which is owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: In Afghanistan, Taliban Release 4 of 8 Turks in an Image Offensive
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Even with their spring offensive under way, the Taliban seemed bent on showing their softer side on Monday.

headline: Capitals Cry Foul on Dorsett Play in Game 6
text: WASHINGTON — What would a Game 7 be without a little controversy?

headline: Fill-In | The Hidden World Under Our Feet
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first 10 paragraphs of the article “The Hidden World Under Our Feet” by Jim Robbins.

headline: Ex-Hedge Fund Manager Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
text: During the sentencing of the former hedge fund manager Anthony Chiasson on Monday, Judge Richard J. Sullivan marveled at his prodigious wealth, ticking off the annual income listed on his tax returns. “$16 million, $10 million, $23 million,” he said.

headline: A Focus on Syria for Obama and Cameron
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said on Monday that it was urgent to bring the fighting in Syria to an end. But Mr. Obama portrayed the diplomatic effort to stem the bloodshed as an uphill struggle that might well fail.

headline: Upfronts 2013: NBC
text: The Times's Bill Carter discusses NBC's programming, after the broadcaster unveiled its plans to advertisers.

headline: A Change in Temperature
text: Since 1896, scientists have been trying to answer a deceptively simple question: What will happen to the temperature of the earth if the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere doubles?

headline: As European Acquisition Struggles, Tata Takes $1.6 Billion Write-Down
text: Tata Steel, India’s largest steel producer, said on Monday that it would take a $1.6 billion write-down, citing the “weaker macroeconomic and market environment in Europe.”

headline: An S.E.C. Settlement That Seems to Favor Falcone
text: There is an adage that a good legal settlement is one in which no one leaves the courtroom happy. That appears to be the case if the terms of the tentative agreement between the hedge fund manager Philip A. Falcone and the Securities and Exchange Commission to resolve civil fraud charges are approved.

headline: Walkabout – 5/13: Fitzgerald Grave Site Attracts Fans; Small Airports Suffer
text: Paying Respects With the premiere of Baz Luhrmann’s film adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s “The Great Gatsby,” more and more fans have been visiting the writer’s grave site in Rockville, Md. (Washington Post)

headline: An Artwork Turns to Mush, All According to Plan
text: In December 2006 James Grashow, a sculptor and illustrator, went to Purchase, N.Y., to visit the family of Allan Stone, the art dealer who had recently died after representing him for four decades.

headline: Money on the Bench
text: How much money Major League baseball teams are paying to players on the disabled list. Updated daily.

headline: A Social Security Site for Smartphone Users
text: The Social Security Administration is now offering a version of its Web site that is designed specifically for smartphones.

headline: Shaking Off Loneliness
text: I now know why I gained more than 30 pounds in my early 20s: I was lonely. I had left my beloved alma mater upstate for graduate school and a job in the Upper Midwest. I knew no one and felt like a fish out of water.

headline: Hard Cases: The Traps of Treating Pain
text: I hadn’t seen Larry in a dozen years when he reappeared in my office a few months ago, grinning. We were both grinning. I always liked Larry, even though he was a bit of a hustler, a little erratic in his appointments, a persistent dabbler in a variety of illegal substances. But he was always careful to avoid the hard stuff; he said he had a bad problem as a teenager and was going to stay out of trouble.

headline: Ginsburg’s Roe v. Wade Blind Spot
text: During a “public conversation” at the University of Chicago Law School on Saturday, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg yet again expressed her well-known misgivings about Roe v. Wade—that the Supreme Court went “too far, too fast.”

headline: Geno Smith, Tim Tebow, Victor Cruz: Answers to Readers’ Questions
text: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, answers questions from readers.

headline: Indians and the Yankees Take Turns Throwing Shutouts at Each Other
text: CLEVELAND — Just before Vidal Nuno spoke to reporters after his first major league win, Lou Cucuzza, the Yankees’ clubhouse manager, handed him the lineup card from the game, an honor bestowed upon players when they reach notable achievements.

headline: A Tale of Two Coffee Shops
text: Inside the newest outposts of Stumptown Coffee Roasters and Intelligentsia Coffee.

headline: Want Coffee Brewed Your Way? Be Specific
text: When Starbucks installed its first espresso bar in downtown Seattle, in 1984, it effectively reordered the hierarchy of coffee in this country: brewed coffee might be nice, but nothing beats the theater of a latte.

headline: Philadelphia Abortion Doctor Guilty of Murder in Late-Term Procedures
text: PHILADELPHIA — A doctor who was responsible for cutting the spines of babies after botched abortions was convicted Monday of three counts of first-degree murder in a case that became a sharp rallying cry for anti-abortion activists.

headline: Family Ghosts, Kept at Bay
text: Incest, alcoholism, robbery, gunfire, murder, sensational court trials — these are among the building blocks of the dysfunctional-family memoir, and in “She Left Me the Gun” Emma Brockes puts a check mark next to each.

headline: In Performance: Leslie Kritzer
text: Leslie Kritzer, accompanied by Katherine Cherbas on cello, sings “Me and My Mother” from “The Memory Show,” a musical about the tensions of caring for someone with Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Image of the Day: May 13
text: K. Siddaramaiah sworn in as Karnataka’s new chief minister.

headline: Sales Tax Talk and Reality
text: The nation’s brick-and-mortar retailers are promoting the Marketplace Fairness Act, which would force Internet retailers to collect sales taxes based on where the product was being shipped. It passed the Senate last week, but may have more trouble in the House.

headline: Preserve24, Where Food, Exploration and Fantasy Meet
text: Starter, an occasional column, takes a look at newly opened restaurants.

headline: ‘We Embrace Our Heartaches’
text: Scenes from Cleveland, which has not had a professional sports championship of any kind since the Browns’ N.F.L. title in 1964, before the first Super Bowl.

headline: Farm-to-Hotel Dining
text: For years, most hotel restaurants could easily be dismissed as unremarkable and unsurprising, their menus seemingly unchanged from year to year. But lately, they have been following the lead of upscale restaurants and offering ingredients grown or produced nearby.

headline: European Leaders Grapple With Youth Unemployment
text: FRANKFURT — Record youth unemployment is emerging as the most urgent problem in the euro zone, if the political rhetoric of recent days is any measure. But leaders are struggling to come up with effective ways to prevent jobless young people in countries like Spain and Greece from becoming a lost generation and source of social upheaval.

headline: Google’s Developer Conference to Be Light on New Products
text: In the past few years, Google’s annual developers conference has grown from being an insiders’ event for software geeks to one in which big announcements about new hardware like Google Glass are made. But this year the conference, which starts Wednesday, will not have much to show in terms of new products, according to a company executive.

headline: Fewer Rain Forests Mean Less Energy for Developing Nations, Study Finds
text: The loss of tropical rain forests is likely to reduce the energy output of hydroelectric projects in countries like Brazil that are investing billions of dollars to create power to support economic growth.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Restaurants and seafood businesses are participating in what they are calling sustainable seafood week, with menu specials and demonstrations. The opening event is Monday from 6:30 to 9:30 p.m. at Riverpark, 450 East 29th Street in Kips Bay. Tickets are $70. The Web site has the latest schedule of events, which run through Sunday.

headline: Signals of a Stroke
text: The Times’s Andrew C. Revkin speaks about his experience of having a stroke, as well as warning signs to watch out for.

headline: Enough to Curl Your Hair
text: Q. How far are we from a medication that could change the shape of the hair follicle and therefore the texture of the hair?

headline: Test Tube Burger
text: The Times's Henry Fountain reports on one researcher's quest to show the world that meat doesn't have to come from the farm.

headline: My Typical Day in Sweden
text: “And after a time you may recognize that the proper measure of success is not how much you’ve closed the distance to some far-off goal but the quality of what you’ve done today.” — U.S. Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor

headline: Success of ‘Iron Man 3’ Hasn’t Reduced Tension Over U.S. Films in China
text: LOS ANGELES — Ticket sales for “Iron Man 3” are still piling up at the Chinese box office. By Sunday night, the film was approaching the $100 million mark there. But that success hasn’t resolved a building tension over American films at the Chinese box office.

headline: A Trudge to the Roots of Autism
text: Much of autism’s mystery and fascination lies in a paradox: On one hand, autism seems to create a profound disconnect between inner and outer lives; on the other, it generates what the neuroscientist Oliver Sacks calls an essential and “most intricate interaction” between the disorder and one’s other traits.

headline: The Commercial Side of Fast Wi-Fi on Flights
text: I WOULD last maybe one shift as a flight attendant. By the end of that initial flight, I would be so demonstrably miserable over the demands of the job that they’d fire me, assuming I didn’t beat them to the punch by pulling a Slater.

headline: Q&A: New Speeds for Old Machines
text: The new 802.11ac wireless-networking standard promises much faster data speeds, as long as you have the right equipment.

headline: Book Covers: Before and After
text: Designers discuss their work on recent book covers.

headline: Taking Jobs Versus Growing Jobs
text: In a blog post on Monday for our colleagues at Economix, Nancy Folbre talks about economic development and the comparative advantages for states that “hunt” for existing jobs and those that “garden” for new jobs. An economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, Ms. Folbre writes:

headline: Prosecution Rests in Sex Case Against Berlusconi
text: MILAN — The prosecution of former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on charges of paying for sex with an under-age prostitute and then abusing his powers to cover it up concluded on Monday with a call for a six-year jail sentence and a lifetime ban from public office.

headline: Big Retailers Quit Stalling on Factory Safety
text: After much delay and many excuses, several western retailers and brands on Monday agreed to a plan that should help improve building safety in the garment factories of Bangladesh. The announcement, which came nearly three weeks after the collapse of the Rana Plaza factory building killed more than 1,100 people, is significant because it includes big companies such as H&M, which is the largest buyer of clothing from Bangladesh, and Inditex, the world’s largest fashion retailer whose brands include Zara and Massimo Dutti.

headline: Richards Has Game 7 Experience, But Has Not Earned the Minutes
text: WASHINGTON — Brad Richards has more Game 7 experience, and more Game 7 success, than anyone else on Coach John Tortorella’s Rangers roster. But don’t expect to see much of him on the ice at the Verizon Center when the Rangers and Washington Capitals play the deciding game of their opening-round series Monday night.

headline: Forging Its Own Path, British Hedge Fund Finds Success
text: Ewan M. Kirk never quite fit the Wall Street mold.

headline: Lamborghini Surprises Its 50th Anniversary Faithful With a New Concept
text: BOLOGNA, Italy – Lamborghini surprised participants in its 50th anniversary Grande Giro celebration Saturday with a bizarre concept car.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Turkey, Bangladesh, Pakistan and Somalia.

headline: Talking Talent | Sarah Polley
text: For her latest film, the Canadian writer, director and actress Sarah Polley turned to her own life. “Stories We Tell,” her first documentary, examines her family’s secrets and mythology — including the question of Polley’s own true parentage — in the wake of her mother’s death from cancer when Polley, now 34, was 11. The documentary, which took her five years to complete, has already kindled Oscar talk for the director, who received an Adapted Screenplay nomination in 2008 for her first film, “Away From Her.” Poignant and moving, “Stories We Tell” confirms that Polley is as good behind the camera as she is on screen.

headline: A Little Improvisation Punctuates the Mundane
text: If the words “audience participation” make you queasy, then “Everyone Was Chanting Your Name” probably isn’t for you. The lights are up at the Abrons Arts Center, and the rectangular seating arrangement is small enough to mean that everyone has a front-row seat: there’s nowhere to hide in this latest production by the rising young theater company 600 Highwaymen.

headline: Upgrades on Schedule for Gowanus Canal Pumping Station Despite Hurricane
text: As Hurricane Sandy swept across the Gowanus Canal last year, a pumping station that redirects sewage to a pollution-control plant was damaged and went offline for almost 33 hours, according to a report released by the city after the storm. About 13 million gallons of raw sewage flowed into the canal before the city installed a generator that restored power to the station.

headline: Mental Evaluations Endorse Insanity Plea in Colorado Shootings, Defense Says
text: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — Mental health experts who evaluated the man accused of killing 12 people in a Colorado movie theater last year have offered a diagnosis that bolsters an insanity plea in the case, his lawyers said at a hearing here on Monday.

headline: How to Take a Break From Your Technology
text: Hello, my name is Nick, and this is my first time at Technologists Anonymous. I’m addicted to my gadgets.

headline: Poverty as a Childhood Disease
text: Poverty is an exam room familiar. From Bellevue Hospital in New York to the neighborhood health center in Boston where I used to work, poverty has filtered through many of my interactions with parents and their children.

headline: Groups Call for Deportation Suspension for Immigrants Affected by Overhaul
text: Labor, Latino and immigrant advocate groups called on President Obama on Monday to suspend deportations of illegal immigrants who could be eligible for a pathway to citizenship under a bipartisan bill to overhaul the immigration system that is under consideration in the Senate.

headline: Doctors’ Lucrative Industry Ties
text: Dr. Alfred J. Tria is the chief of orthopedic surgery at St. Peter’s University Hospital, a 478-bed facility in New Brunswick, N.J., and to the medical technology company Smith & Nephew, his good word is worth a million bucks. Well, $940,857, to be precise.

headline: My Stroke of Luck
text: Twenty-two months ago, I interrupted my nonstop reporting about paths toward a sustainable future for our species to focus on sustaining myself. The hiatus was not by choice, but was mandated by a stroke — the out-of-the-blue variant, the rare kind of “brain attack” (the term preferred by some neurologists) that is most often seen in otherwise healthy, youngish middle-aged people.

headline: Boy Toys Yearning to Be Free
text: You know you’re in a bad way when you’re having imaginary conversations with Gloria Estefan.

headline: The Envelope Please: Chandler Buckingham
text: This week, Chandler Buckingham, a student at Rogers High School in Rogers, Ark., will be the third person in her family to graduate from high school. She is headed to John Brown University this fall.

headline: More on a Sensitive Climate Question
text: June 18, 5:24 p.m. | Updated |Justin Gillis’s latest “By Degrees” report is focused on the recent flurry of findings and discussion related to one of the most important and enduring questions in climate science: How much warming will result from a given buildup of heat-trapping greenhouse gases?

headline: A Guilty Verdict in the Gosnell Trial
text: The Times's Erik Eckholm on the implications for the abortion debate after a West Philadelphia doctor known for performing late-term abortions was found guilty of three counts of first-degree murder.

headline: Walking 20 Miles for a (Canceled) Flight to Antarctica
text: I DON’T mind business travel at all. I’ve got it pretty much down to a science.

headline: Minnesota Senate Clears Way for Same-Sex Marriage
text: ST. PAUL — Gay couples will be permitted to wed in Minnesota starting in August, making it the 12th state to permit same-sex marriage and the first in the Midwest to take such a step outside of a court ruling.

headline: My Lucky Stroke
text: Twenty two months ago, I interrupted my nonstop journalistic pursuit of paths toward sustainable human progress to focus on sustaining myself. The hiatus was not by choice, but was mandated by a stroke — the out-of-the-blue variant, the rare kind of “brain attack” (the term preferred by some neurologists) that is most often seen in otherwise healthy, youngish middle-aged people.

headline: A Paternal Pull, Found Unexpectedly in Uganda
text: Here is the kind of life that Johnny O’Callaghan used to lead. When he broke up with his boyfriend (he came home to find him having sex with twins) he rushed to Chateau Marmont to get drunk, slept with an actress (“whose work I don’t respect”) and woke up to find a Post-it that said, “Gone to Pilates.” End of relationship.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Spy Drone and Revenge Pornography
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Peter Pan Creator’s Feminist Vision
text: A woman needs a man like a fish needs a bicycle.

headline: Transcendent, Populist and American All Over
text: Cowboys, horses, disaffected teenagers snapping fingers, pedestrian traffic — the three ballets danced by New York City Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater on Friday included images of all those. The music was all American, for the ballet company’s American Music Festival, and it all had populist appeal. George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins knew how to exploit that appeal choreographically while remaining themselves.

headline: Letting Go of Whimsy in Favor of Feeling
text: Here’s a traditional sitcom setup: A new person is introduced into a circle that has established relationships and routines, and high jinks ensue. Everyone regards the contagion funnily, moves around him or her to avoid confrontation, and professes not to understand the mannerisms of the intruder, which don’t neatly align with How Things Have Always Been Done. Eventually, of course, things line up — sweet, sweet resolution.

headline: The Sacred and the Secular, Both Extolling Love
text: The distinguished, ever-curious vocal quartet Anonymous 4, which recently performed the premiere of David Lang’s “love fail,” returned on Sunday afternoon to the early music that is the core of its reputation.

headline: Revival of ‘24’ Is More Like ‘12’
text: Everything’s quicker these days. Even “24.”

headline: She’s 88, and Swings From Saucy to Somber
text: One of the many reasons Barbara Carroll has been called the first lady of jazz piano is her quietly expressive breadth. At Birdland on Saturday evening, Ms. Carroll, who is 88 but exudes the spirit and enthusiasm of a very sophisticated teenager, played a set whose moods ran from playful to reflective to a light stomp, sometimes all in the same song. Ms. Carroll has always had special simpatico with the rarefied wit of Cy Coleman and Carolyn Leigh. Singing and playing the obscure “I Wanna Be Yours,” she evoked the golden age of screwball comedy with the sly, teasing innuendo of lines like, “I wanna be all the cream in your dairy/your favorite tooth fairy.”

headline: Detroit Stands Up for Ives, and Stands In for Oregon
text: Spring for Music — the annual festival of North American orchestras at Carnegie Hall, created in the main to foster imaginative and ambitious programming — did itself proud over the weekend in the last three concerts of its third season. Leonard Slatkin conducted the Detroit Symphony Orchestra on Thursday and Friday, and Christoph Eschenbach led the National Symphony Orchestra on Saturday.

headline: I.R.S. Targeting of Conservative Groups Could Resonate in 2014
text: My rule of thumb is that a vast majority of alleged political scandals will have less electoral impact than the conventional wisdom initially holds.

headline: Setting Off Political and Pianistic Fireworks
text: The rhythmic chant “The people united will never be defeated!” has become so ubiquitous at protests worldwide that it is hard to imagine that there was a time when it was actually composed.

headline: New Albums by Demi Lovato and Talib Kweli
text: DEMI LOVATO

headline: Congress’s Role in the I.R.S. Focus on Conservative Groups
text: Outrage continues to escalate over the revelation that Internal Revenue Service employees focused on conservative groups applying for tax-exempt status. The indignation is understandable: political targeting is an abuse of power, and the idea of using the I.R.S. to go after one’s enemies is a classic dirty trick. Unfortunately, the incident provides a new fuel source for the paranoid style in American politics.

headline: Notes on Southern Living’s Fried Chicken
text: So, dear readers, how have you fared so far with this month’s Recipe Lab assignment? One home cook, Erin P. of Brooklyn, N.Y., said her attempt at the featured recipe, by Norman King, a food editor at Southern Living, resulted in the best fried chicken she had ever made on her own. Does this ring true for you?

headline: No Rain on Me
text: As a photographer, I would normally avoid using my camera in the middle of a downpour. But yesterday, at the opening of “EXPO 1,” a show at MoMA devoted to ecological issues, I photographed people inside the rain, and not a drop of water fell on my equipment.

headline: Grind of Euro Crisis Wears Down Support for Union, Poll Finds
text: BRUSSELS — Europeans have never been wild about the European Union. With the region sapped by the euro crisis, confidence in the institution and the benefits it was supposed to provide is flagging faster and further than ever before, according to an influential opinion survey released Monday.

headline: Patrick Demarchelier’s Bodies of Desire
text: The French photographer Patrick Demarchelier famously started out taking passport pictures as a teenager, and ever since then he’s been creating images that take people to unfamiliar places. Now 69, he is internationally renowned for his portraits of supermodels, princesses and celebrities for publications like Vogue, Harper’s Bazaar, Elle and Vanity Fair. Since his career took off in the 1970s, he has had an outsize influence on the way artists portray fashion and stardom. “Desire,” a new exhibition of his black-and-white photographs opening tomorrow in Paris, is a testament to Demarchelier’s ability to capture the female body. The 20 images include Laetitia Casta, stretching her naked ribcage taut; Helena Christensen, crouching and eyeing the camera with a panther stare; and Kate Moss and Carla Bruni, sitting together like interlocking puzzle pieces. Every contour suggests both purity and provocation, speaking to the very essence of desire.

headline: Car Bomb Kills at Least 4 in Libya
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — A car explosion on a busy street killed at least four people and injured more than a dozen on Monday, stirring new anger at the failure of the transitional government to fill the security vacuum left by the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Basking in a Fonder Farewell, 19 Years Later
text: THESSALONIKI, Greece — No one noticed when Nick Galis, a former Seton Hall guard, left the Boston Celtics after attending their training camp in 1979 as a fourth-round N.B.A. pick with another newcomer, Larry Bird.

headline: New Musicals Continue Broadway Box Office Streak
text: Three new musicals that will be vying for Tony Awards next month continue to be big draws at the Broadway box office. Last week, “Kinky Boots,” which received 13 Tony nominations — more than any other production — was the top show among the new musicals of the 2012-13 season, grossing $1,250,718.

headline: Hedge Fund Rejects Proposal by Hess to End Proxy Fight
text: 8:22 p.m. | Updated The Hess Corporation on Monday offered a concession to an activist investor after the investor’s board nominees waived their rights to a contentious compensation plan.

headline: Examining Pakistan’s Election
text: Declan Walsh, the Pakistan correspondent of The New York Times who was expelled from the country, reports on the results of the recent election and his personal experience.

headline: Nepotism in Bavarian Politics Creates a Scandal Merkel Could Do Without
text: MUNICH — It’s a family affair, but one that is very public and very political.

headline: Dr. Joyce Brothers, On-Air Psychologist Who Made TV House Calls, Dies at 85
text: Joyce Brothers, a former academic psychologist who, long before Drs. Ruth, Phil and Laura, was counseling millions over the airwaves, died on Monday at her home in Fort Lee, N.J. She was 85.

headline: Germany Accuses Man of Being Somali Pirates’ Accountant
text: BERLIN — Who knew that buccaneers had bookkeepers?

headline: In Abortion Protests, Which to Protect, Children or Speech?
text: WASHINGTON — Kenneth T. Scott opposes abortion, and he says so in public. Sometimes he holds up large pictures of aborted fetuses. Sometimes he makes his points near churches that he believes are not doing enough to combat abortion.

headline: It Wasn’t the Day to Ask Cuomo About the Mood in Albany
text: ALBANY – Maybe it was just Monday. Maybe it’s the constant bad news regarding corruption surrounding the Capitol. Maybe it was just quitting time.

headline: Israel’s Austerity Budget Draws Citizen Protests
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government was debating the final points of a two-year austerity budget early Tuesday that would cut spending and raise taxes, outraging many Israelis who voted in a new government this year after promises of economic relief.

headline: Upfronts 2013: Fox
text: The Times's Bill Carter discusses Fox's programming, after the broadcaster unveiled its plans to advertisers.

headline: Orb’s Breezy Speed Stirs Talk of a Crown
text: The Kentucky Derby victor, Orb, does not pack light. Hay, hoses, food, blankets, stall gates and two equine travel companions were loaded onto his van to Baltimore for the second leg of his Triple Crown quest.

headline: Crucial Carbon Dioxide Reading Revised Downward
text: One of the two programs that monitor greenhouse gases said on Monday that it had revised a reading from last week suggesting that carbon dioxide in the air had surpassed the symbolic level of 400 parts per million.

headline: Barbara Walters's Memorable Moments
text: A selection of interviews conducted by Barbara Walters with world leaders and celebrities over the decades.

headline: Temporary Limit Put on Sales of Morning-After Pill
text: At least through the end of May, the Plan B One-Step morning-after contraceptive will not be sold over the counter for all ages. A federal appeals court on Monday temporarily granted the Obama administration’s request for a stay of an order by Judge Edward R. Korman of Federal District Court that the pill be available without a prescription for everyone. The Justice Department has appealed that order and the appeals court said it would keep the order from being implemented until it hears from both sides. In the interim, the pill is available without a prescription for women and girls ages 15 and older.

headline: Women Forced Into WWII Brothels Served Necessary Role, Osaka Mayor Says
text: TOKYO — The mayor of one of Japan’s largest cities, who is seen by some as a possible future prime minister, drew an outcry on Monday after he said women forced into wartime brothels for the Japanese Army during World War II had served a necessary role in providing relief for war-crazed soldiers.

headline: Preakness Field Dwindles as Contenders Complete Works
text: And then there were nine. The Preakness field continues to be in flux as two more horses defected: Vyjack (18th in the Kentucky Derby) and Normandy Invasion (fourth). Perhaps we will see one or two additions in the next day or two.

headline: Broadcast Networks Are Amply Filling Schedules
text: As the television upfronts week for the 2013-14 season gets under way in New York, one trend is already apparent: strength in numbers — or is it safety in numbers?

headline: A Colorful Bolivian Bastion, Floating Above It All
text: EL ALTO, Bolivia — Turn a corner in this sprawling, bustling, fast-growing city and the Ovando family home suddenly bursts into view, a party-colored mirage floating above the drab, brick-red metropolis like a beacon of an alternate Andean future.

headline: Leader of Teachers’ Cheating Ring in Memphis Gets 7-Year Term
text: Clarence D. Mumford Sr., a former teacher and assistant principal in Memphis, was sentenced Monday to seven years in federal prison for orchestrating a scheme to help teachers cheat on certification exams.

headline: France Confirms Second Case of Virus Linked to SARS
text: PARIS — France confirmed a second case of a new coronavirus belonging to the same family as SARS on Monday, saying a man who shared a hospital room with the first victim had been infected.

headline: Antique Bridge Closed to Traffic While It’s Open for Repairs
text: Brooklyn was still an independent city when the Carroll Street Bridge vaulted over the Gowanus Canal, allowing horse-drawn wagons to travel among the area’s farms.

headline: Look, but Don’t Touch
text: The photographer Mark Laita’s new book, “Serpentine,” seeks to capture the snake in its many colors and “the sensual forms its movement creates.” It is science best appreciated from a distance.

headline: A Star Who Jumped at the Chance to Stay
text: SEATTLE — On the day the Mariners made Felix Hernandez the highest-paid pitcher in baseball history, about 100 team employees waited for him outside an elevator, clad in gold T-shirts that read simply “King.” They held “K” signs as they clapped and screamed and chanted his name.

headline: Twisting and Turning
text: Nature photography — stills and live action — is a cultural staple, like Honest Abe Lincoln, celebrity self-immolation and the myth that Shakespeare didn’t write his own plays. But why?

headline: Balancing Anthony’s Need to Shoot and Need to Share
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Some Knicks were ill, some Knicks were aching and some Knicks were bickering, or at least giving the appearance of it, all on the eve of a game labeled a “must win” by the franchise star, who is shooting too much or not shooting enough.

headline: Matter: Cicadas
text: Carl Zimmer talks about the life cycle and evolutionary adaptations of the insect.

headline: More Clients Ask Questions of Bloomberg
text: With new concerns emerging about practices at its news division, Bloomberg L.P., the sprawling financial services company founded by Michael R. Bloomberg, scrambled to shield its lucrative terminal business and appease nervous customers.

headline: Generic Drug Maker Pleads Guilty in Federal Case
text: The generic drug maker Ranbaxy pleaded guilty on Monday to federal drug safety violations and will pay $500 million in fines to resolve claims that it sold subpar drugs and made false statements to the Food and Drug Administration about its manufacturing practices at two factories in India, the company and federal prosecutors announced Monday. The settlement is the largest in history involving a generic manufacturer and drug safety, the Justice Department said.

headline: Phone Sounds Good, but How Is the Deal?
text: The Ooma Telo is advertised as a “free home phone service,” and while it’s nowhere near free, it has excellent sound quality and may still be a better deal than your current phone service.

headline: Is the N.R.A. Un-American?
text: The more militant members of the N.R.A. and most of its leaders may be un-American.

headline: The Art of Repetition
text: In the months after my mother died, we started the task of sorting. It’s a strange process that makes you part curator and part detective. You read every letter in every file, empty every box, open every drawer. We weren’t looking for clues — my mother was remarkably transparent — but I found one anyway. A clue to why I had become a writer.

headline: A Concrete Plane, the ‘Nectar Mops’ of Bats and More
text: If you watch only one video about bat tongues this week, let it be one made by biologists at Brown University, who figured out how to illuminate the animals’ long tongues without bothering their sensitive bat eyes. “We shot color high-speed video of the bats gathering nectar, which is challenging to obtain because color cameras require a lot of light,” said Cally J. Harper, lead author of a paper on the research. The nimble camera work, she said, produced “the ‘aha’ moment” of the study — read on for the results.

headline: Once-Softer Hibbert Is Wearing Out Knicks
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Integrated Fighting Academy sits in a well-manicured office park along the southern rim of the city, sharing a flat concrete building with a security system supply company and a lawn with a flock of geese. Two truck tires, weighing about 300 pounds each, lie in the back of the parking lot.

headline: Victory in Guatemala? Not Yet
text: THE conviction last Friday of the former Guatemalan dictator Efraín Ríos Montt on charges of genocide and crimes against humanity is of monumental significance. It was the first time in history that a former head of state was indicted by a national tribunal on charges of genocide. It offers hopes to those similarly seeking justice in El Salvador, Honduras and Nicaragua.

headline: Making a Case for One Leader at JPMorgan
text: “This isn’t about good governance; it’s about busybodies without a clue, trying to do the dumbest thing — slapping and shaming a superb C.E.O. for utterly no practical reason.”

headline: The Deeper Blame for Benghazi
text: THE spectacle in Washington over the terrorist attack last Sept. 11 in Benghazi, Libya, is focusing on the wrong thing.

headline: Our Ceaseless Circus
text: Four Americans died in Benghazi, Libya: people with unrealized hopes, unfinished plans, relatives who loved them and friends who will miss them.

headline: Becoming Invisible, at Least to Microwaves
text: Using an off-the-shelf 3-D printer, nearly anyone can make an “invisibility cloak” to make objects disappear, researchers report. But if you’re thinking about using one for snooping, Harry Potter style, you should know it works only for microwave radiation, which humans can’t see anyway.

headline: Video Appears to Show Syrian Rebel Mutilating a Soldier’s Corpse
text: Supporters of the Syrian government posted a graphic video to YouTube on Sunday that appeared to show a rebel commander cutting out the heart and liver of a government soldier and threatening members of the country’s Alawite religious minority. He then held the organs up to his mouth and appeared to take a bite.

headline: Bulls’ Physical Approach to James Is Familiar
text: CHICAGO

headline: Sharif vs. Army, Round 3
text: LONDON — The last time that Nawaz Sharif had close dealings with the Pakistani Army, soldiers handcuffed him and imprisoned him in an ancient fort overlooking the Indus River, physically dragging him from office in a coup.

headline: No Time to Cut Food Stamps
text: “Families who are living in poverty did not spend this nation into debt,” says Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, “and we should not be trying to balance the budget on their backs.” That humane principle will guide the New York Democrat as she seeks to persuade colleagues to resist a proposed $4.1 billion cut in food stamps in an omnibus farm bill heading toward Senate agriculture committee vote.

headline: Soybeans and the Spirit of Invention
text: Vernon Bowman, an Indiana farmer, bought a mix of soybean seeds from a grain elevator, planted them in a late-season crop and used seeds harvested from that crop to plant his late crop the following season. Included in that mix (intended mostly for animal feed) were Monsanto’s patented genetically altered seeds, which allow farmers to use herbicide, like Roundup, to kill weeds without damaging the soybean plants.

headline: The Next Scapegoat
text: Twenty years ago, when she was a young Foreign Service officer in Moscow, Victoria Nuland gave me a dazzling briefing on the diverse factions inside the Russian parliament. Now she is a friend I typically see a couple times a year, at various functions, and I have watched her rise, working with everybody from Dick Cheney to Hillary Clinton, serving as ambassador to NATO, and now as a spokeswoman at the State Department.

headline: Laser
text: When the Navy announced last month that it was deploying a shipboard laser weapon in the Persian Gulf, it seemed that the future of warfare had arrived, in which the enemy could be blasted from the sky by a beam of light.

headline: A Bumbling Response on Talking Points
text: No matter how often Republicans denounce them, the initial talking points used by the White House to describe the attack in Benghazi, Libya are not the real point. But they have become a major political issue in large part because of the White House’s inept response to questions about how they were written.

headline: The I.R.S. Audits Are Condemned
text: The Internal Revenue Service was absolutely correct to look into the abuse of the tax code by political organizations masquerading as “social welfare” groups over the last three years. The agency’s mistake — and it was a serious one — was focusing on groups with “Tea Party” in their name or those criticizing how the country is run.

headline: Phone Records of Journalists Seized by U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — Federal investigators secretly seized two months of phone records for reporters and editors of The Associated Press in what the news organization said Monday was a “serious interference with A.P.’s constitutional rights to gather and report the news.”

headline: In Barbara Walters’s Highlight Reel, TV’s Rise and Fade
text: Pope Benedict XVI retired.

headline: 2 Waiters Arrested in Killing of Malcolm X’s Grandson
text: MEXICO CITY — The police here arrested two men on murder and robbery charges on Monday in the beating death last week of Malcolm Shabazz, the grandson of Malcolm X, though many questions about the case remained unresolved.

headline: Police Inspector Rules Out Racial Profiling
text: It promised to be a clarifying moment in a federal lawsuit against the New York Police Department: A commander whose comments about race had been secretly recorded by a patrol officer took the stand on Monday to address what he had said.

headline: Money on the Bench
text: The average Major League Baseball team has five players on the disabled list right now, but not all have been affected equally. The Yankees have the most injured players, 11, and they are costing the club $23,000 an hour.
