headline: Commander Denies U.S. to Blame in Afghan Deaths
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The highest-ranking international military commander in Afghanistan has categorically denied any American or NATO responsibility for the deaths of at least 17 women and children after nearly seven hours of intensive airstrikes near their compound in eastern Afghanistan, in the latest development in a case that has greatly raised tensions with the Afghan government.

headline: Lawyers Say DNA Clears Florida Inmate in Two Killings
text: MIAMI — Seven years after he was sentenced to death in the fatal stabbings of two Florida women, Clemente Javier Aguirre appeared in a Seminole County courtroom on Monday to present DNA evidence that could win him a new trial.

headline: Corrections: May 14, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Status-Seeking Sort
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — So I was e-mailing with Will Shortz the other day — did I mention that I know Will Shortz? — and he was telling me about all of the really cool people he’s met in his travels as the editor of the New York Times crossword puzzles. It’s fascinating stuff really, and between that and all of the insanely interesting celebrities I’ve met while cultivating the Celebrity Guest Blogging feature, why, I —

headline: Uneven I.R.S. Scrutiny Seen in Political Spending by Big Tax-Exempt Groups
text: Over the last two years, government watchdog groups filed more than a dozen complaints with the Internal Revenue Service seeking inquiries into whether large nonprofit organizations like those founded by the Republican political operative Karl Rove and former Obama administration aides had violated their tax-exempt status by spending tens of millions of dollars on political advertising.

headline: New Charge for Brooklyn Legislator Is a State Favorite: Pilfering From a Nonprofit Agency
text: William F. Boyland Jr., the Brooklyn legislator who had already been charged with soliciting more than $250,000 in bribes and filing false travel vouchers to the State Assembly worth tens of thousands of dollars, is now facing a new charge.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Traffic Eased on Brooklyn Bridge Access Ramps
text: Sinatra sang about it. Bugs Bunny schemed to sell it. Mayors Edward I. Koch and Michael R. Bloomberg traversed it in gestures of populism during separate transit strikes, and P. T. Barnum directed his fleet of elephants over it to prove its sturdiness.

headline: $10 Newsstand Umbrella? It’s No Longer Unthinkable
text: The newsstands of New York City cater to all kinds of demands: a craving for spearmint gum, an impulse to enter the lottery, a failing device in want of new batteries, a sudden downpour that makes an umbrella not only necessary, but urgently so.

headline: When the Politicians Who Should Be Helping Are Only Out to Help Themselves
text: I find Jacqueline Babich sitting on a bench in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, clasping a green bag filled with the detritus of her battle to save her home.

headline: China: Former Police Official Detained
text: A former deputy police chief in Chongqing, Tang Jianhua, has been placed under detention in the Communist Party’s disciplinary system on suspicion of taking nearly $3 million in bribes, according to an article on Monday in the online version of People’s Daily, the official mouthpiece of the party. Mr. Tang was a close associate of Wang Lijun, the former Chongqing police chief who had a falling out with Bo Xilai, the disgraced Communist aristocratic politician. Mr. Wang was sentenced last year to 15 years in prison for various crimes, and Mr. Bo awaits trial. Mr. Tang was detained last year after the fall of both of those men. Mr. Tang received an award on Feb. 28, 2010, for his role in the “strike black” campaign, a drive led by Mr. Wang that ended up with many innocent civilians under detention and being tortured. Mr. Tang was promoted to deputy police chief after receiving the award.

headline: Schools Chief Blasts Mayoral Candidates Over Remarks at Education Forum
text: Dennis M. Walcott, the New York City schools chancellor, lashed out at the Democratic candidates for mayor on Monday, saying that he did not believe any of them had a compelling vision to lead city schools and that they had been pandering to gain the support of the teachers’ union.

headline: Heat Take Control From the Start
text: CHICAGO — A placard was laid on each seat at United Center before Game 4 on Monday night between the Chicago Bulls and the Miami Heat. In capital white letters on a red background, the words encapsulated these playoffs for the Bulls, an injury-riddled team that has made its way into the second round on grit and guile.

headline: Ankiel Arrives Without a Bat, and Thus Fits Right in With the Mets
text: ST. LOUIS — Terry Collins, the manager of the Mets, a team descending ever deeper into a late-spring slump, began his workday Monday extolling the virtues of positive thinking.

headline: Young Americans Lead Trend to Less Driving
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Dan Mauney keeps misplacing his car.

headline: In Manhattan, Obama Tells Supporters That He Intends to Govern
text: President Obama, his troubles piling up in Washington, traveled to Manhattan for a busy evening of fundraising for the Democratic Party, telling audiences that progress was being stymied by a persistent wave of “hyper-partisanship” in the Capitol.

headline: Intersection: Artfully Chic in Chelsea
text: Alexis Johnson draws style inspiration from her boss at the Paula Cooper Gallery.

headline: Kenneth Battelle, 86, Hairdresser to the Stars, Dies
text: In 1961, Vogue magazine said that “almost every famous female head in the world has gone or will go” to Kenneth, the hairdresser who created Jacqueline Kennedy’s legendary bouffant and softened the golden locks of Marilyn Monroe.

headline: For Skeptical Lawmaker, Doubts on Attack Were Sown in Whirlwind Trip to Libya
text: WASHINGTON — On Oct. 6, 2012, an Air Force Gulfstream jet landed in Tripoli, Libya, carrying a four-star Army general, a brash Republican congressman from Utah, and a young State Department lawyer — an unlikely group there to investigate a harrowing tragedy.

headline: Daughter of a Detained Chinese Rights Activist Speaks
text: BEIJING — 8:32 a.m. | Updated Liao Minyue last saw her mother, the rights activist Liu Ping, in mid-April, when she returned home from college to help after Ms. Liu had an operation to remove gallstones.

headline: Down Three Goals Late, Bruins Rally and Advance
text: BOSTON — They were minutes from another playoff collapse capped by a Game 7 defeat at home. They trailed by three goals midway through the third period, unable to generate any offense. Their fans were booing. Their season was on the brink.

headline: Tax Exemptions and Political Activity
text: The Internal Revenue Service disclosed that it had more closely scrutinized applications for tax-exempt status from conservative-sounding 501(c)(4) groups to insure they were not abusing limitations on political activity.

headline: One-Sided Ending to a Tense Playoff Duel
text: WASHINGTON — The Rangers vanquished a rather significant playoff ghost Monday night. They won a Game 7 on the road for the first time in their 87-year existence with a 5-0 victory over the Washington Capitals at Verizon Center.

headline: Lundqvist Impervious to Capitals Once More
text: WASHINGTON — More eyes may have been fixated on the 5 that the Rangers had put on the scoreboard, but perhaps just as impressive was the 0 next to the Capitals, thanks to the performance of Henrik Lundqvist.

headline: Keynes and Keynesianism
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Word of the Day | surly
text: surly •\ˈsər-le\• adjective

headline: My Medical Choice
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Game 7: Rangers vs. Capitals
text: Action from the Rangers’ 5-0 victory in Washington, which sent them to the Eastern Conference semifinals.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (CBS) NCIS Gibbs (Mark Harmon) and his team are assigned legal counsel in this Season 10 finale after an investigator (Colin Hanks) from the Defense Department questions their unconventional methods in the search for the killer of Eli David and Jackie Vance. (Above, from left, Brian Dietzen, David McCallum and Pauley Perrette in the season finale.) In “NCIS: Los Angeles,” at 9, Season 4 ends as Hetty (Linda Hunt) sends Callen (Chris O’Donnell) and Kensi (Daniela Ruah) overseas, while Sam (LL Cool J) and his wife (Aunjanue Ellis) go undercover when an explosion in the desert reignites the search for stolen nuclear weapons.

headline: After Citizen Protests, Israel Approves Austerity Budget
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government approved a two-year austerity budget early Tuesday that would cut spending and raise taxes, outraging many Israelis who voted in a new government this year after promises of economic relief.

headline: News Quiz | May 14, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Rural Upstarts Move In on Colonial Lackeys
text: To understand India’s middle class as it is now, it helps to think of it as two waves that came 150 years apart.

headline: Council Speaker Recounts Her Struggles With Bulimia and Alcoholism
text: The summer she turned 16, Christine C. Quinn’s world seemed to shatter.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 14, 2013
text: “I just want people to know you can get through stuff.”

headline: American Investor Targets Sony for a Breakup
text: 3:42 a.m. | Updated

headline: IHT Quick Read: May 14
text: NEWS Europeans have never been wild about the European Union. With the region sapped by the euro crisis, confidence in the institution and the benefits it was supposed to provide is flagging faster and further than ever before, according to an influential opinion survey released Monday. James Kanter reports from Brussels.

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 14, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “The 700-Doll Question.”

headline: An International Tournament Dedicated to Medieval Battle
text: In “The Holy Grail of Battle Re-enactments,”  Mike Tierney writes about an annual full-contact medieval battle competition held in Europe every year.

headline: Economic Recovery, Made in Bangladesh?
text: A couple of years ago, I was in an industrial park in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, as a textiles executive pitched me on becoming a rich T-shirt manufacturer. It was easy, he said, to teach basic sewing to even the most poorly educated farmers. If I could spend $500,000 on used sewing machines (he knew a guy), rent a concrete building with no air-conditioning and hire a few dozen peyizan (Creole for “peasants”) for around $3 per day, I could recoup my investment within two years. And if it didn’t work out, he noted, I could sell the equipment to an entrepreneur in another poor nation.

headline: The Man Who Loved Women, and Cameras
text: Grace Coddington walked down the rain-slicked streets of East London one afternoon in 1959, clutching her model’s portfolio as she searched for Terence Donovan’s studio. All of 18 and aspiring to be a model, she knew she had to pose for him if her career was to take off.

headline: Do You Have Helicopter Parents?
text: How involved are your parents in your life? How much do they step in to help you with your schoolwork, social life, college applications, hobbies, sports or anything else? How often do they try to solve your problems? Do you like having their help, or do you find it burdensome? Why?

headline: ‘Thrilling and Maddening’ Senior Year Was an Adventure Worth Taking
text: This Friday, I will be the third person in my entire family to graduate from high school. This is so important to me, and it’s so strange that my senior year is coming to an end. Sometimes it has been exciting and sometimes it has been mundane, but it has certainly been an adventure worth taking.

headline: Wheelies: The Bearded Lady Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: For Local Businesses, the Internet Threat Isn’t Just the Sales Tax
text: I am a third-generation retailer. My father and grandfather owned a “dime store” (Google it), and working there gave me a foundation that would allow me to become a successful entrepreneur.

headline: What Is the Right Way to Come Out as Bisexual at Work?
text: Every other Tuesday,  Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners,” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: Shanty China
text: BEIJING — Western tourists who visit Beijing often remark on its lack of slums. Although it is home to seven million migrant workers, the capital appears to be without the squalid shantytowns that pockmark or ring other developing cities, like Mumbai and Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Former BlackRock Fund Manager Arrested in Insider Trading Inquiry
text: LONDON — Mark Lyttleton, a former BlackRock fund manager, has been arrested in connection with an insider trading investigation in Britain, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: Daily Report: Surging Data Center Industry Blurs Boundaries
text: Data centers in New Jersey that provide huge banks of remote computer storage, which require enormous amounts of electrical power and ultrafast fiber optic links, are commanding rents four times as high as prime high-rises in Manhattan, James Glanz reports in The New York Times.

headline: Loeb Takes On Sony
text: Daniel S. Loeb, an American hedge fund billionaire known for starting big fights, has called for a breakup of the entertainment and electronics giant Sony, possibly setting off a battle that could roil Japan’s staid corporate culture, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. “The call, which came on Tuesday, will most likely be viewed by government officials and corporate leaders in Tokyo as a shot across the bow from Wall Street, just as Western investors begin piling into Japanese stocks.”

headline: Ken Burns to Oversee ‘Emperor of All Maladies’ Project for Public Television
text: Siddhartha Mukherjee’s Pulitzer Prize-winning book “The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer,” is being developed as a six-hour documentary series for public television, with Ken Burns as executive producer. An official announcement is not expected until June, but several of the project participants confirmed their roles.

headline: Bill Hader to Leave ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: With just one departure, “Saturday Night Live” is losing its excitable “Weekend Update” city correspondent, Stefon; its frenetic incarnations of James Carville, Al Pacino, Vincent Price and Julian Assange; and any number of unctuous, self-satisfied game show hosts.

headline: In Performance: Leslie Kritzer of ‘The Memory Show’
text: In the musical “The Memory Show,” Leslie Kritzer plays a woman, identified simply as Daughter, who has moved home to take care of her aging mother, who is in the early stages of Alzheimer’s disease. In the song “Me and My Mother,” Daughter has just witnessed her mother’s first major episode of dementia. The show, with a book and lyrics by Sara Cooper and music by Zach Redler, continues through Saturday at the Duke on 42nd Street.

headline: South Korea Proposes Meeting With North
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea proposed on Tuesday to hold a border meeting with North Korea to discuss bringing finished goods and raw materials from an industrial park that the two countries jointly operated until last month.

headline: Press Play
text: Press Play is the place where The New York Times debuts noteworthy new music. Every week, we present tracks from upcoming new albums. Listen to them here exclusively.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Shaking Off Loneliness, for Your Health
text: Shaking off loneliness for your health, how to take a break from your technology, don’t go grocery shopping on an empty stomach and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Syria Gives Russia List of Envoys to Peace Talks
text: STOCKHOLM — President Bashar al-Assad’s government has given Russia the names of officials who would attend international talks intended to end the war in Syria, Secretary of State John Kerry said Tuesday, even as representatives of both sides in Syria publicly expressed skepticism about the prospect of a political settlement.

headline: Thanks, Mom, but a Care Package Is Not Needed
text: Dear Diary:

headline: From Russia, With Wig: American Spy Suspect Is Ejected
text: MOSCOW — He arrived at the meeting with two wigs — the blond one on his head held in place by a baseball cap, a brown one in his knapsack, which also held a compass, a Moscow street atlas and $130,000 in cash. He was an operative for the Central Intelligence Agency, Russian officials say, and his goal was to recruit a Russian security officer as a spy.

headline: Thiel Brings Money and Some Credibility to Europe
text: LONDON – Peter Thiel is coming to Europe.

headline: Cameron Seeks to Calm Party on Europe Vote
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron tried once again to quell mounting dissent within his party over Britain’s place in the European Union, publishing a draft law on Tuesday that promises a referendum on British membership in the bloc by the end of 2017.

headline: A Video Link With Pakistan
text: America’s drones are keeping an eye on Pakistan’s political developments.

headline: Europeans Move to Stave Off Hollywood
text: LONDON — France is spearheading a campaign within the European Union to ensure that closer trade ties with the United States do not lead to further Hollywoodization of European culture.

headline: Black Male Turnout Higher Than Official Data Suggest
text: Although a recent Census Bureau study showed a stark gap between black male turnout and black female turnout in the 2012 election, the large number of black men ineligible to vote because of felony convictions explains much of the gap.

headline: Should India Provide Direct Military Aid to Afghanistan?
text: Over the past decade, India has invested heavily in Afghanistan’s reconstruction. Recognizing India’s significant economic and development contributions, the United States has called on New Delhi to play an important role in the new Silk Road initiative aimed at transforming Afghanistan into a regional trade hub.

headline: Aquino Allies Take Lead in Election in Philippines
text: MANILA — Philippine voters appeared to have strengthened President Benigno S. Aquino III’s hand in advancing his political agenda, according to early unofficial election returns on Tuesday that showed his political allies poised to take control of the Senate.

headline: The New Case for Liberal Arts
text: LONDON — All through elementary school and junior high, whenever anyone asked me what I wanted to be when I grew up I always gave the same answer: a marine biologist. Until I got to biology class in high school and got turned off by my teacher — which does happen, even if we’d rather talk about teachers who inspire their students. By the time I applied to college an interest in government had displaced gills — or so I thought, listing political science as my intended major.

headline: U.S. Open Cup: 1958 to 1987
text: This is the third of a series on the U.S. Open Cup.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Time Out New York: Caesar salad, banana cream pie, Frank Sinatra on the jukebox: a look at new restaurants that specialize in bringing back the old. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Western Conference Semifinals: Divisional Rivalries on Display
text: The semifinals in the West feature matchups of division rivals. In a meeting of Central Division foes, the Blackhawks face the Red Wings in the playoffs for the 16th time, while Los Angeles and San Jose from the Pacific Division square off for the only the second time in the postseason.

headline: Tucked Into the City’s Budget, Thousands of Body Bags
text: Buried in New York’s $70 billion annual budget are thousands of unexpected expenses that define the city’s cradle-to-grave benefits. Take body bags.

headline: Book Covers: Before and After
text: For the first installment of a new series, I asked four book designers to discuss recent examples of their work. Each designer shared an earlier idea for a cover as well as the final design that ended up on the book.

headline: Defining ‘Submissive’ in the Vocabulary of Women’s Choices
text: Glenn Beck recently called me “one of the bravest people alive.” At the same moment, I felt as if the Internet unleashed a tidal wave of fury on me. People were up all night on Twitter, telling me I’d set women’s causes back 50 years.

headline: Indonesian Police Kill Suspect in Attempted Bomb Attack
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The Indonesian police said on Tuesday that they had shot and killed a man they suspected of being an Islamist militant who tried to bomb a roadside police traffic post in West Java Province in retaliation for a series of recent counterterrorism raids across the country.

headline: In Fight With Hess, Elliott Proposes Seating All Board Nominees
text: 11:17 a.m. | Updated

headline: Bike Share: Nimby vs. Yimby
text: New rental bicycle-share stands on streets across Manhattan and Brooklyn are drawing mixed reactions among New Yorkers, from “not in my backyard” to “yes, in my backyard” and all points in between.

headline: Bike Sharing? Sure. The Racks? No Way.
text: Bike share was easy for New York City to love in the abstract. It was not about adding bike lanes at the expense of something else; it was about sharing something that did not yet exist.

headline: Q&A: Covering Up Your Amazon Tracks
text: Q.

headline: Loeb’s Bold Bet on Sony
text: Daniel S. Loeb is taking Japan’s economic renaissance at face value. The hedge fund manager wants Sony to spin off its entertainment arm. Though activists rarely prevail in Japan, Mr. Loeb’s idea may have merit, and Sony should take him seriously.

headline: Vermont Passes ‘Aid in Dying’ Measure
text: Vermont will become the fourth state to make it legal for a physician to prescribe lethal medication to a terminally ill, mentally competent patient who wants to end his life. It has also become the first state to approve the practice through legislation, instead of via a public referendum (as in Oregon and Washington) or a court decision (in Montana).

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ to Return in January, After British Broadcast
text: The fourth season of “Downton Abbey” will begin on Jan. 5, an executive producer said on Tuesday, dashing hopes that American and British viewers could watch the hit show at the same time.

headline: Bruins Save Best for Last
text: You have to hand it to the Boston Bruins. They have this Game 7 thing down to a science. Seriously. How do you top a 2011 Stanley Cup run that featured three Game 7 victories, including a first-round tightrope walk/grudge match in overtime against Montreal? How do you make fans forget last year’s Game 7 overtime loss at home in the first round against Washington? How do you wipe away the epic face plant of 2010, losing not only a 3-0 series lead to hated Philadelphia, but also a 3-0 lead in Game 7 at home?

headline: What the Gosnell Case Doesn’t Mean
text: A jury in Philadelphia on Monday convicted Kermit Gosnell, a doctor who clearly does not deserve that title before his name, of three counts of first-degree murder.

headline: At Goldencents’ Side, a Star in His Own Way
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — They are often the unknowns. Even when they stand right in front of thousands, few know grooms’ names or acknowledge them. Yet they know more about the horse at the end of their lead line than anyone else at the racetrack.  Often, by the time the horse is loaded into the starting gate, their groom has already spent more than nine hours by their side that day.

headline: Japanese Aide Makes Rare Trip to North Korea
text: TOKYO — A political aide to the prime minister of Japan made a sudden, rare visit to North Korea on Tuesday. Japanese officials refused to say what he was doing there.

headline: Nuances of Credit Scoring Still Elude Consumers
text: Consumers still have many misunderstandings about the details of credit scoring, like the impact of having several inquiries on their report around the same time, according to the Consumer Federation of America.

headline: No Benefit Seen in Sharp Limits on Salt in Diet
text: In a report that undercuts years of public health warnings, a prestigious group convened by the government says there is no good reason based on health outcomes for many Americans to drive their sodium consumption down to the very low levels recommended in national dietary guidelines.

headline: For Republicans, Incentives to Strike a Budget Deal With Obama
text: WASHINGTON — Ask around the White House and the Capitol, and you will quickly find reasons to doubt that Republicans will compromise with President Obama on a budget deal that includes more tax increases and spending cuts in social programs.

headline: New Entrant to Venice Biennale: the Vatican
text: VATICAN CITY — It commissioned the Sistine Chapel, countless portraits of popes and even Matisse’s chapel in Vence. Now the Roman Catholic Church will host its first pavilion at the Venice Biennale, featuring the Czech photographer Josef Koudelka, the Milan-based multimedia group Studio Azzurro and the artist Lawrence Carroll.

headline: Beyoncé Cancels Show in Belgium
text: Beyoncé has canceled a concert in Belgium that was scheduled for Tuesday night because she is dehydrated and exhausted, The Associated Press reported. The pop diva’s publicist told the wire service that she has been ordered by her doctors to rest. She had been slated to perform at the Sportpaleis in Antwerp. She has another show at the arena on Wednesday, and her publicist said “she is awaiting word from her doctors before making a decision” about that performance. Beyoncé, 31, started her Mrs. Carter Show World Tour last month in Belgrade, Serbia, and it will finish on Aug. 5 at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

headline: Lots of Lancaster at Lincoln Center
text: With the possible exception of Marlon Brando, no male star of his era radiated more raw magnetism than Burt Lancaster, whose centennial is being celebrated by the Film Society of Lincoln Center this Friday through May 23. Nowadays, macho preening too often passes for the kind of feral grace radiated by Lancaster in films like “The Killers,” the 1946 noir classic adapted from a Ernest Hemingway short story and directed by Robert Siodmak.

headline: States Urged to Cut Limit on Alcohol for Drivers
text: WASHINGTON — Thousands of people are killed or injured every year by drivers who have not reached the legal standard for being drunk but who have a reduced ability to see, make decisions or operate a vehicle, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday, and it recommended that the states reduce the allowable blood-alcohol concentration by more than a third, to 0.05 percent from 0.08 percent.

headline: Travel Essentials | Taroudant, Morocco
text: In our Summer Travel issue, which hit newsstands on Sunday, Christopher Petkanas waxes poetic about Taroudant, an out-of-the-way, stylish haven from Morocco’s well-trodden tourist route. Here’s where to stay, eat and sleep in this remote market town.

headline: Billy Crystal Bringing  ‘700 Sundays’ Back to Broadway
text: If Billy Crystal keeps this up, he eventually will have performed “700 Sundays” for, well, 700 Sundays. On Tuesday, Mr. Crystal, the comedian, actor and erstwhile Oscars host, said that he will bring “700 Sundays,” his Tony Award-winning one-man show about growing up on Long Island, back to Broadway in the fall for a nine-week run that is being described as the production’s final engagement.

headline: Cellphone Case Helps to Alleviate Wi-Fi Woes
text: Cellphone cases are designed to provide protection, but Absolute Technology thinks they should offer something more: better Wi-Fi reception.

headline: Intersection: Artfully Chic in Chelsea
text: In the latest Intersection we visited Chelsea during the Frieze Art Fair and spotted people who said their style influences range from their grandmothers to the avant-garde fashion company Comme des Garçons.

headline: Video of American’s Arrest in Moscow
text: Last Updated, Wednesday, 12:06 p.m. As my colleague Ellen Barry reports from Moscow, Russia’s Federal Security Service, the successor to the Soviet-era K.G.B., announced Tuesday that it had arrested a Central Intelligence Agency officer posing as an American diplomat as he tried to recruit a Russian agent.

headline: The Gun Report: May 14, 2013
text: Last month, Brandon Holt, 6, was shot and killed by a 4-year-old boy in Toms River, N.J., kicking off a bloody month in which several toddlers accidentally shot other toddlers. The 4-year-old got a hold of his father’s .22 caliber rifle and brought it into the yard, where it went off, hitting Holt in the head. Yesterday it was announced that Anthony Senatore, 33, the father of the “gunman,” was arrested for having multiple unsecured weapons accessible to children.

headline: Regulatory Pressure Drives Commerzbank to Seek Out New Capital
text: LONDON — European banks have gone on a capital-raising binge.

headline: A New Executive Director for Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center
text: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has appointed Suzanne Davidson as its new executive director, starting on July 1. She succeeds Norma Hurlburt, the society’s director since 2000. Ms. Hurlburt is leaving to start her own consulting business for nonprofit organizations. The society also announced that its artistic directors, the cellist David Finckel and the pianist Wu Han, who are married, had renewed their contract for a third term, which will take them through the 2018-19 season.

headline: The Rickshaw Driver’s Curry
text: Kumily, India — One of the best parts of traveling, at least for me, is bringing back a food story, a new ingredient or a recipe. My family journeyed last year from the verdant tea plantations of Munnar down to the Cardamom Hills of Kerala, in southwestern India. Our driver, Janaki Raman, who had proved himself by dodging many a cow on the winding mountain roads, asked whether we might like to go to a local cooking class.

headline: More Details About the New Windows
text: Microsoft is shedding the Windows Blue code name for the next installment of its operating system. The official name of the software will be — drumroll, please — Windows 8.1.

headline: French Entrepreneurs Strive for Success
text: As immigrant enclaves in the Parisian suburbs struggle with 30 percent youth unemployment, some entrepreneurs are trying to build businesses that will create jobs for their communities.

headline: Square Unveils Hardware for iPad Registers
text: Square, the payments start-up, on Tuesday morning introduced new hardware to accompany its cash register software for iPads. The accessory is essentially a stand that doubles as a credit card reader.

headline: In Poor Margins of Paris, New Recipe for Success Is Local
text: PARIS — Mourad Benamer remembers the day his parents first visited the sleek new sushi restaurant he had just opened near the Champs-Élysées. Against all odds, Mr. Benamer had broken out of the rough suburb, or banlieue, where he grew up in a family of poor Moroccan immigrants just northeast of Paris, and hit on a formula that would soon turn into a business success beyond his dreams.

headline: A Governor and a Prince, Down at the Shore
text: SEASIDE HEIGHTS, N.J. — Chris Christie takes pride in being the unfiltered everyman’s politician.

headline: In 125 Years, Much Has Changed, but the Pastrami Is the Same
text: “I’m from out of town, and I like a good pastrami sandwich,” said Jeffrey A. Devore, a lawyer from West Palm Beach, Fla., who was sitting in Katz’s, the Lower East Side delicatessen that, like the neighborhood itself, has become a study in contrasts.

headline: Cracking Down on Drinking and Driving
text: “It’s better not to drink and drive, but if you do, keep it under 0.05.” So rhymed William N. Plymat, an Iowa insurance company president and former Prohibitionist who became one of the earliest anti-drunken driving activists in the 1950s.

headline: 3 G.I.’s Killed in Afghan Bombing
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A roadside bomb tore through an American military convoy in southern Afghanistan on Tuesday, killing at least three soldiers in a volatile district of the Taliban heartland.

headline: Deborah L. Bernstein, Private Equity Partner, Dies at 41
text: Deborah L. Bernstein, a partner at the private equity firm Aquiline Capital Partners, died on Friday in New York. She was 41.

headline: Fighting for the Union – and Equal Pay
text: Shortly after the Emancipation Proclamation declared that African-Americans, “of suitable condition, will be received into the armed service of the United States,” the governor of Massachusetts, John Albion Andrew – one of the most aggressively antislavery officials to hold public office during the Civil War – put out a call across the North for men to fill the ranks of an exclusively black volunteer regiment.

headline: The Obama Synthesis Under Siege
text: The true ideological inclinations of the Obama White House can be endlessly debated, but slightly more than halfway through this presidency I think it’s fair to make the following generalization: Obama has governed as a business-friendly social democrat and an aggressive social liberal, as a hawkish interventionist when intervention seems cheap and easy (drones, missiles, etc.) and a cautious realist when it doesn’t, and as a surprisingly vigorous defender of presidential prerogatives across a variety of fronts. A few weeks ago, I characterized Obama-era liberalism as featuring “an imperial presidency, a corporatist economic policy, and then a libertarian turn on almost every social issue,” and while that line misses various nuances and complexities, as one-sentence summaries go I think it’s pretty good.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: A Permanent Job Crisis
Jolie’s Disclosure of Preventive Mastectomy Highlights Dilemma
text: One of the defining moments in the history of breast cancer occurred in 1974 when the first lady, Betty Ford, spoke openly about her mastectomy, lifting a veil of secrecy from the disease and ushering in a new era of breast cancer awareness.

headline: If You Like Fleetwood Mac, Try the Kopecky Family Band
text: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: All-Female ‘Julius Caesar’ to Open New Season at St. Ann’s Warehouse
text: An all-female production of “Julius Caesar,” first staged at the Donmar Warehouse in London last year, will open the 2013-14 season at St. Ann’s Warehouse. It will be the first of several collaborations between St. Ann’s and other adventurous companies during the season. Others include the world premiere of Lee Breuer’s “Divina Caricatura Part 1, The Shaggy Dog” which the company is presenting with La MaMa, and a staging of Bartok’s “Bluebeard’s Castle,” a co-production with the itinerant New York City Opera.

headline: Watching Washington This Week
text: The Times’s Congressional correspondents Ashley Parker and Jeremy W. Peters analyze the key players to watch on Capitol Hill this week.

headline: Sore Knee Is Bothering Shumpert
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Iman Shumpert skipped the Knicks’ Tuesday morning shootaround because of soreness in his left knee before playing a little more than 16 minutes in the Indiana Pacers’ 93-82 victory in Game 4.

headline: Justice Dept. Defends Seizure of Phone Records
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Tuesday defended the Justice Department’s sweeping seizure of telephone records of Associated Press journalists, describing the article by The A.P. that prompted a criminal investigation as among “the top two or three most serious leaks that I’ve ever seen” in a 35-year career.

headline: A Way to Make Phone Records Not So Easy to Track
text: The ease with which the Obama administration was able to secure the Associated Press’ phone records may have demonstrated once and for all that privacy is dead.

headline: Objects | amfAR Goes for the Gold at Cannes
text: Midway through this year’s Cannes film festival, A-listers will take a break from the red carpets to attend amfAR’s annual Cinema Against AIDS benefit at the glamorous Hotel du Cap-Eden-Roc on the French Riviera. The highlight will be the Ultimate Gold Collection Fashion Show, an all-gold runway presentation curated by Carine Roitfeld. It will feature 40 models (including “It” girl Karlie Kloss and Daria Strokous, one of the faces of the current Christian Dior ad campaign) in one-of-a-kind gowns by the likes of Comme des Garcons, Alexander Wang, Giorgio Armani and Valentino, which will be auctioned after the show. They’ll be wearing bespoke jewelry made from the precious metal, commissioned by Roitfeld, including the cuffs seen above by the chic, celebrity-endorsed designers (from left) Kimberly McDonald, Hoorsenbuhs and Ana Khouri. The pieces will subsequently be made to order at LoveGold, an online community dedicated to gold jewelry. The site, in its first year as a presenting sponsor for the gala, will live stream exclusive footage of the catwalk on May 23.

headline: Eastern Conference Semifinals: No Love Lost Between Foes
text: Like the West, the East has one matchup of Original Six teams. But that is just one subplot as rivalries old and new are renewed.

headline: Pack an Umbrella, or Not?
text: Just in time for beach season, the private forecaster AccuWeather has started a 30-day forecast that aims to help people plan their trips and outdoor events. In the 1960s, AccuWeather started its five-day forecast; this new feature, accessible through the company’s Web site, follows that model, and will include high and low temperatures, sky conditions and chance of precipitation.

headline: Video: Watching Washington This Week
text: The Times’s Ashley Parker and Jeremy W. Peters, Congressional correspondents, analyze the key players to watch on Capitol Hill this week.

headline: ABC Unveils a Fall Schedule With 13 New Series
text: ABC introduced a new fall schedule on Tuesday that, like those unveiled by the network’s competitors, was heavily dependent on new series — 13 in all, in ABC’s case.

headline: Negligence Is Debated in Jackson Death Case
text: LOS ANGELES — After only two weeks of testimony, no side has a clear advantage in the civil trial pitting the mother of Michael Jackson against A.E.G. Live, the promoter of his attempted comeback concerts, over the question of who was responsible for Jackson’s death.

headline: A Quest for Justice in Guatemala
text: Daniel Hernández-Salazar is used to waiting. Two decades ago he abandoned his photojournalistic career to devote himself to documenting the search for justice in the wake of Guatemala’s 36-year civil war. He stood at exhumations alongside indigenous Maya, as they waited to spy a bracelet or scrap of muddy fabric that would allow them to finally locate the bones of a loved one. More recently, he stood among them in a Guatemala City courtroom as the former dictator, Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt, was sentenced to 80 years for genocide and crimes against humanity.

headline: Image of the Day: May 14
text: A beekeeper handling an artificial hive on the outskirts of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Freedom of No Information
text: Via ABC News

headline: A Politician’s Disclosure Offers a Lesson in Eating Disorders
text: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker and a Democratic candidate for mayor, revealed in The New York Times on Tuesday that she battled bulimia for over a decade, from her midteens until she entered a rehabilitation program at age 26. Though other public figures have discussed their struggles with bulimia – Katie Couric and Jane Fonda are two examples – it’s a rare disclosure for a politician. Ms. Quinn also said she considered herself a recovering alcoholic, which is a less unusual distinction.

headline: As Firms Line Up on Factories, Wal-Mart Plans Solo Effort
text: As American retailers face mounting pressure to join a landmark plan to improve factory safety in Bangladesh, newly found documents indicate that apparel had been produced for Wal-Mart at one of the operations in the factory building that collapsed last month, killing more than 1,100 workers.

headline: St. Louis Development Makes a Play for a Home Team Advantage
text: When the new Busch Stadium opened in 2006, the occasional mudhole along adjacent property symbolized the failure of a planned companion project aimed at revitalizing downtown St. Louis.

headline: David Stark Creates Classic Pop-Up Books
text: A few years ago, the New York-based event planner David Stark and his team began making sculptural art pieces out of paper and using them as centerpieces or decorative props. Not quite origami, the sculptures are often created with strategic cuts to antique books, so the pages open into a fruit or flower.

headline: For Chelsea, Small Consolation
text: This was not the championship match that Chelsea had in mind.

headline: New York City Tycoon Cars Heading for Auction
text: On May 31, Dragone Classic Motorcars will hold its second annual auction, featuring 65 cars (compared with last year’s 47) at its showroom in Westport, Conn. There’s plenty to savor, including a magnificent supercharged 1937 Cord 812 SC Sportsman and a 1938 Mercedes Benz 320 N Speciale Kombination Roadster bought by a American serviceman from a Berlin used-car lot in 1946, then left for decades in an Orange, Conn., barn.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: May 16
text: What the singer and songwriter Kilo Kish is wearing now; Nike and A.P.C. collaborate again; tuxedo looks for women return; and Personnel of New York opens.

headline: A Car Towing Tale of Woe
text: 5/17/13 | Updated with comment from towing company’s lawyer.

headline: Android Phones Gain Ground
text: Google’s Android operating system for smartphones, which is used in Samsung phones and devices from other manufacturers, including Huawei and LG, has expanded its domination of the market.

headline: Finding Frugal Toulouse, Despite Two Holidays
text: Some are unlucky in love, others in business. I am unlucky in calendars. Wherever I travel, local holidays materialize from thin air – shutting down attractions, slowing down public transport and sending the locals fleeing to country homes.

headline: Scolari Goes With Youth in Brazil
text: Five months into another stint as the coach of Brazil’s national team, Luiz Felipe Scolari gave a clear indication Tuesday that he would not be wedded to the past when he named his squad for next month’s FIFA Confederations Cup, which Brazil will host.

headline: Snooping and the News Media: It’s a 2-Way Street
text: Word on Monday that the Justice Department had obtained the records of more than 20 phone lines at The Associated Press sent the Fourth Estate into a frenzy. Big Government, Big Data, Big Brother, all the symbols of an increasingly surveillance-driven age were invoked.

headline: Contributions Piling Up in Race for Mayor
text: 9:15 p.m. | Updated Bill de Blasio, the New York City public advocate, reached a crucial milestone in his bid for mayor on Tuesday when his campaign reported that he had raised all the money he is allowed to spend in the coming primary.

headline: Tech Industry Weighs In as Senate Panel Works on Immigration Bill
text: 3:34 p.m. | Updated

headline: Europe Raids 3 Companies in an Inquiry on Oil Prices
text: LONDON — The authorities on Tuesday raided the offices of several oil companies and an industry data provider as part of a broader inquiry by the European Commission into potential price manipulation.

headline: Designers Unite Again for a Good Cause
text: In December, 24 New York City designers banded together to organize a charity auction for victims of Hurricane Sandy. Contributing furniture made from salvaged materials or that in some way alluded to the wreckage, the group, called Reclaim NYC, raised some $15,000 for the Red Cross.

headline: Links for the Middle of May
text: It’s a busy time for “ag-gag” bills: The Tennessee attorney general ruled that the state’s ag-gag bill is “constitutionally suspect” before it was vetoed by Gov. Bill Haslam; Indiana’s version was killed: a new one was introduced in Pennsylvania (a local newspaper wrote that it “goes against everything this country has stood for since its inception”); and a woman was arrested in Utah for taking photos of a slaughter plant from public property.

headline: BlackBerry Messaging Is Set for iPhones and Android
text: BlackBerry said on Tuesday that it would open its BlackBerry Messenger service to users of iPhones and phones running the Android operating system while it also tries to turn the instant messaging system into a competitor of Twitter.

headline: Dissecting the A.P. Phone Log Seizure
text: The Times’s Charlie Savage breaks down the government’s subpoenas of phone records of Associated Press journalists.

headline: I Believe I Can Fry
text: When did frying chicken become so intimidating? There are cooks out there who have spherified martini olives and piped buttercreams without ever biting into a piece of homemade fried chicken.

headline: Angelina Jolie’s Preventive Surgery
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tip of the Week: Customize the Windows 8 Start Screen
text: For many people who upgrade from earlier versions of the system, Windows 8 and its colorful Start screen can be a little overwhelming. The Start screen, like the Start menu in older Windows editions, is meant to be the go-to place for all the computer’s files and programs. Like the Start menu, the Start screen can be customized according to personal needs and tastes.

headline: A Focus on Border Security and Temporary Visas as Senators Return to Immigration
text: 4:53 p.m. | Updated  The Senate Judiciary Committee continued to plow through amendments to an immigration overhaul bill on Tuesday, revisiting border security provisions before moving on to measures related to temporary guest worker programs.

headline: For Fried Chicken, a Bubbly Companion
text: Sometimes the classics cannot be bested. I’m falling back on an old favorite with fried chicken: Champagne.

headline: Rutgers Reinstates Lacrosse Coach After Inquiry
text: Rutgers on Tuesday reinstated its men’s lacrosse coach, Brian Brecht, after suspending him with pay as it investigated allegations of verbal abuse.

headline: Senate Panel Approves Farm Bill
text: The Senate Agriculture Committee approved a $955 billion farm bill on Tuesday, the first step toward completing an overhaul of the nation’s food and farm policy that was derailed last year when the House failed to vote on its version of the bill.

headline: Larry Page Says Vocal Cord Paralysis Causes His Voice Problems
text: 5:28 p.m. | Updated

headline: Eating Disorders and Public Life
text: Kate Taylor, the Times reporter who interviewed the mayoral candidate Christine Quinn about her bulimia, discusses her own challenges with anorexia.

headline: Miller Theater Announces New Season
text: The highlights of the 25th season of the Miller Theater at the Columbia University School of the Arts will include a festival celebrating the 60th birthday of John Zorn, the new music maverick; and an evening of 125 short compositions modeled after John Cage, whose centennial was last year.  And back for the 2013-14 season is the Composer Portraits series, featuring the work of and discussions with Georg Friedrich Haas, Rand Steiger, Anna Thorvaldsdottir, Roger Reynolds, Unsuk Chin, Jean-Baptiste Barrière and Liza Lim.

headline: As Culture Moves Online, France Tries to Follow It With a Tax
text: PARIS — France’s “cultural exception” — the policy that creative works like books, music and movies deserve protection beyond what is accorded ordinary goods — is in line for a digital update.

headline: Paris Cancels Celebration for Soccer Champions
text: PARIS — Officials canceled a city hall ceremony for the champions of France’s national soccer league on Tuesday after hundreds of rampaging fans attacked stores, cars and police officers in the capital during celebrations on Monday night. The violence, which left 32 people injured and 38 fans in police custody, erupted at an official celebration for Paris Saint-Germain, the winning team, near a neighborhood overlooking the Eiffel Tower.

headline: Suspicious Substance Disrupts U.S. Consulate in China
text: BEIJING — Staff members at the United States Consulate in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou discovered a suspicious substance in an envelope on Monday, prompting the closing of some operations. The substance, which was found in a part of the consulate not open to the public, has yet to be identified. No consulate workers have suffered any ill effects and no visitors are believed to have been exposed, said Nolan Barkhouse, a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Beijing. “The consulate has notified Chinese authorities and is maintaining close contact with them in case any assistance becomes necessary,” Mr. Barkhouse said. The consulate was closed for visa interviews on Tuesday and will remain closed Wednesday pending an investigation. The consulate handles 121,000 visa applications annually and processes all immigrant visas for Chinese children adopted by American citizens.

headline: Tesla’s Stock Is Trading at Rich Multiples
text: Tesla’s shareholders seem to be assuming that its chief executive, Elon Musk, is infallible. Tesla, the electric carmaker, is on a roll. Last week, it recorded its first quarterly profit and received the best score that Consumer Reports has bestowed on a car for six years. The company’s stock has since surged as much as 70 percent, leaving Tesla worth more than Fiat and Peugeot combined. Its stock is also trading at a whopping 27 times estimates for earnings in 2016.

headline: Time Lapse of World Trade Center Spire
text: A time lapse of a video released by the Port Authority shows the spire being raised to the top of One World Trade Center.

headline: Front Burner
text: To Bake: Top-Notch Pizza Starts With the Dough

headline: Oddball Travelogue That Is All Detours
text: David Sedaris doesn’t write like a writer. He writes like someone who writes for a living. That’s a different thing, and not necessarily a bad one: Mr. Sedaris can be the life of your two-person party if you turn to his essays for quick, easy diversion and nothing more. But only a man with column space to fill would devote the first eight pages of a book to the experience of having dental work done in France.

headline: Ex-Wife of SAC’s Cohen Hires New Lawyer in Revived Lawsuit
text: The former wife of the hedge fund mogul Steven A. Cohen has a new lawyer in her bitter legal dispute with her former husband.

headline: The Envelope, Please: Will Walker
text: Although Will Walker, who will attend Williams College, counts himself “lucky,” he encourages other students with unfulfilled college plans to wait: “the universe usually has a way of working things o

headline: A Gala That Skipped the Kitchen Sink
text: Trying to trot out an entire stable of stars and preview the many ballet war horses that dominate an eight-week season, American Ballet Theater’s opening-night galas can be tedious affairs. The one at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday, though, was significantly less wearisome. The excerpts were fewer and more varied, and they were grounded by two full works of the highest quality and exhilaration: Alexei Ratmansky’s “Symphony #9” and Balanchine’s “Symphony in C.”

headline: Lawyers Press Pentagon to Abide by Detainee Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Lawyers for a detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who is scheduled to be transferred out of the prison in December under a 2011 plea deal have asked a judge to order the Pentagon to live up to its agreement, recently unsealed tribunal papers show.

headline: Caravaggio
text: Inside the restaurant on the Italian Upper East Side.

headline: Front-Runner in Pakistan Offers Truce, and Flowers
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s former and future prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, visited his main political rival, Imran Khan, at a Lahore hospital on Tuesday, and Mr. Sharif later said both leaders had vowed to work together without acrimony.

headline: White-Linen Italian Civility
text: IN HIS LANDMARK STUDY FROM 1971, “The Food of Italy,” Waverley Root divided that nation into 19 distinct culinary regions. The book is a classic, its insights and prose recipes still tantalizing four decades later, but it contains a major oversight. Mr. Root says nothing at all about the Italian Upper East Side.

headline: Start-Up Hopes to Help Freelance Writers Get Paid
text: It looks as if the futurists from the early days of the Internet got quite a bit wrong when it comes to business online. The idea that no one would pay for music was wrong. No one would buy books was also incorrect. And the idea that writers would have to work free in the face of so-called citizen journalists was inaccurate, too.

headline: Appeals Court Says Judge Went Too Far in Forcing Fire Dept. to Revamp Its Hiring
text: A federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled on Tuesday that the district court judge presiding over a long-running lawsuit against the New York Fire Department claiming discrimination against minority applicants went too far in forcing the department to revamp its hiring process, and that he had raised enough doubts about his impartiality to require assigning a key part of the case to another judge.

headline: Corporate Irresponsibility? Fashion’s Hidden Cost in Bangladesh’s Garment Industry
text: A look at two companies with different responses to the building collapse in Bangladesh.

headline: Dispute at JPMorgan Grows, for All the Wrong Reasons
text: The fight over whether to split the jobs of chief executive and chairman at JPMorgan Chase is a silly one. That’s not just because it’s a lot of drama over something so unimportant in the scheme of things, but because it has turned into a backdoor referendum on one man, Jamie Dimon.

headline: U.S. Budget Deficit Shrinks Far Faster Than Expected
text: WASHINGTON — Since the recession ended four years ago, the federal budget deficit has topped $1 trillion every year. But now the government’s annual deficit is shrinking far faster than anyone in Washington expected, and perhaps even faster than many economists think is advisable for the health of the economy.

headline: The Real Problem With Soccer
text: Few goals and fewer commercial breaks are not what is slowing soccer's growth, according to William C. Rhoden. Racism is, and the true lovers of the game -- its fans -- are the ones who can save it.

headline: Video: The Real Problem With Soccer
text: Few goals and fewer commercial breaks are not what is slowing soccer’s growth. Racism is, and the true lovers of the game — its fans — are the ones who can save it.

headline: Video: High-Speed Look at Trade Center’s Spire Installation
text: What could be cooler than the dizzy-making nine-minute spire’s-eye-view video of the spire being installed atop 1 World Trade Center last Friday?

headline: Off the Menu
text: Headliner

headline: Familiar Forest, Made New
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — Sometimes you can’t perceive the true beauty of something until you’ve seen it naked. This observation probably doesn’t apply to most human beings, especially those over 25. But it certainly holds true for a certain venerated, usually overdressed musical that has been kicking around for a quarter-century.

headline: Photo Replay: May 14
text: A view of the day in sports, from a baseball field in New York with Prince Harry to the Italian Open with Roger Federer.

headline: Some Kinds of Prisons Don’t Need Any Bars
text: “So what are you in for?” Patricia asks Sean. These two are inmates, as Patricia might say, not in a jail but in a nursing home in Ireland. But what they’re in for — infirmity (Patricia) and old age (Sean) — matters less to the playwright Deirdre Kinahan in “These Halcyon Days” than who they are and who they were, their accommodations, regrets and rebellions.

headline: California Governor Issues Cautious Budget, Disappointing Democrats
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Gov. Jerry Brown on Tuesday proposed a smaller budget than projected earlier this year and repeatedly cautioned against new spending, disappointing Democratic lawmakers who had hoped that rising state tax revenues would finance social programs after years of austerity.

headline: T-Mobile USA Bumps Up Price of iPhone by $50
text: When T-Mobile USA first started offering the iPhone 5, it had the cheapest deal in town: $100 up front (not including the monthly bill) — which is half the cost of the iPhone on a rival network like AT&T or Verizon Wireless. But now the cost of the iPhone on T-Mobile is closer to the competition, at $150.

headline: No, He’s Not, but the Bullies Still Won’t Give Him a Break
text: Every day of high school is a fresh hell for the unhappy young hero of “queerSpawn,” a slight but compassionate and bleakly funny play by Mallery Avidon that opened at Here Arts Center on Tuesday night. If one tormentor is not spray-painting a gay slur across his locker in vivid neon, another is shoving him in a big cardboard box and taping it shut.

headline: Feeling For | Asprey Private Collection Handbags
text: As a second act to her debut collection for Asprey last summer, the accessories designer Katie Hillier unveils another line of handbags, called the Private Collection, for the English jewelry and leather goods brand early next month. Hillier worked with a small team to create 41 bespoke pieces that, she says, “appeal to clients that are looking for a unique piece of art.” Influenced by hand-painted mosaic motifs, Hillier used a rainbow of exotic skins and semiprecious stones to dress up the simple, timeless designs. One standout is this Rothkoesque bag in crocodile with over four carats of diamonds.

headline: Vagabonds, Sharing Wine and Bonhomie, Traverse Their Inner Worlds
text: “Most rudest people I have ever met!”

headline: Revolutionary Coming-of-Age in Wisconsin
text: “Pinkolandia” runs a tad long and talks a little too much and could use a slightly sharper plot. Yet I’m not sure how much I’d change about this ambitious and often beautiful new play.

headline: A Museum Plot for Green-Wood Cemetery
text: Death may not be pretty, but for 175 years many families have chosen a grave site at the bucolic Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn to help make eternity a charming affair.

headline: Church Plans Art Pavilion at Biennale
text: VATICAN CITY — It commissioned the Sistine Chapel, countless portraits of popes and even Matisse’s chapel in Vence, France. Now the Roman Catholic Church will sponsor its first pavilion at the Venice Biennale, featuring the Czech photographer Josef Koudelka, the Milan-based multimedia group Studio Azzurro and the artist Lawrence Carroll.

headline: Leak Investigations Are an Assault on the Press, and on Democracy, Too
text: This was supposed to be the administration of unprecedented transparency. President Obama promised that when he took office, and the White House’s Web site says so on this very day. It reads:

headline: The Envelope Please: Sush Krishnamoorthy
text: In the beginning, my dream of attending college in the United States with limited funds seemed to be just that: a dream. However, I am grateful to have had friends and family who were supportive.

headline: An Opera Star, Freckles, Blemishes and All
text: A behind-the-scenes look at an Aix-en-Provence staging of Verdi’s “Traviata,” the impressionistic, handsomely shot “Becoming Traviata,” directed by Philippe Béziat, may not be fully satisfying as a documentary. But it has what any good movie needs: a star — the ever-game soprano Natalie Dessay.

headline: Wigs and Whips, Songs and Maces, and Legislation, Too
text: It was with a leaden sense of duty that I dragged myself — through a stinging March snowfall, no less — to the National Theater to see “This House,” by James Graham. What lay before me was nearly three hours of re-enactments of life in the House of Commons four decades ago. What did I know from parliamentary politics, especially from the 1970s?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Hidden Online Audiences and Cicada Math
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: A Scruffy Hound That Money Can’t Buy
text: The beast at the center of “Old Dog” — a Tibetan tale of pride, principle and family priorities — is one of the sorriest-looking creatures ever to grace a movie screen. Scruffy, matted and with a tail that resembles a filthy feather duster, this forlorn specimen, known locally as a nomad mastiff, is nevertheless the catalyst for an astonishing tug of war.

headline: Revisiting a ‘Previvor’
text: In 2007, Deborah Lindner, then 33, underwent an elective double mastectomy after finding out she had a gene carrying a high risk of breast cancer. Six years later, Dr. Lindner offers an update.

headline: Q. & A. | Daft Punk’s Secret Weapon: Producer Todd Edwards
text: The storied house music producer Todd Edwards is two decades into a groundbreaking career in which he pioneered the cut-up sample technique that gave birth to the U.K. garage style of dance music, earning him the nickname “Todd the God” with aficionados. But it feels like he’s only been warming up the decks. A frequent collaborator with Daft Punk — he wrote and sang “Face to Face” from their 2001 album “Discovery” — Mr. Edwards reunites with the helmet-wearing pair for a track on their much-anticipated album “Random Access Memories,” out May 21 (and streaming now on iTunes).

headline: Google Expected to Start a Competitor to Spotify
text: Google is set to introduce a subscription music feature to compete against fast-growing streaming services like Spotify, according to several people briefed on its plans.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Bangladesh, Turkey, Kenya and Iraq.

headline: Management Flaws at I.R.S. Cited in Tea Party Scrutiny
text: WASHINGTON — An inspector general’s report issued Tuesday blamed ineffective Internal Revenue Service management in the failure to stop employees from singling out conservative groups for added scrutiny. Congressional aides, meanwhile, sought to determine whether the Obama administration’s knowledge of the effort extended beyond the I.R.S.

headline: Living in Mariners Harbor, S.I.
text: The residential and industrial coexist in this corner of New York City.

headline: Coastal Perch; Varied Nests on Offer
text: The city trend toward transforming decayed industrial shoreline into public space has not yet made landfall in the northwestern Staten Island neighborhood of Mariners Harbor. But José Marrero, betting that the tides of gentrification wash over every area eventually, moved here a decade ago from a two-bedroom rental in Coney Island.

headline: In the Living Room, Still No Sign of Google
text: If you walk into my living room you will see a standard, flat television surrounded by a dozen gadgets. There’s a Microsoft Xbox, a Sony PlayStation, the Apple TV, and there’s even a computer with a wireless mouse. But you might not recognize one of the gadgets, a round black ball that I haven’t used in a year: the Nexus Q made by Google.

headline: Is the I.R.S. an Independent Agency?
text: There is no evidence that President Obama knew about the Internal Revenue Service’s recent practice of singling out conservative groups that applied for tax-exempt status, subjecting them to unusually detailed questioning. Calling the reports “outrageous,” he has promised to “make sure that we find out exactly what happened on this.” That’s as it should be. But the president misspoke on Monday when he said that the I.R.S. was an “independent agency.” It is not.

headline: Billie Sol Estes, Texas Con Man Whose Fall Shook Up Washington, Dies at 88
text: Billie Sol Estes, a fast-talking Texas swindler who made millions, went to prison and captivated America for years with mind-boggling agricultural scams, payoffs to politicians and bizarre tales of covered-up killings and White House conspiracies, was found dead on Tuesday at his home in Granbury, Tex. He was 88.

headline: Syrian Rebel Reportedly Defends Sinking Teeth Into Dead Soldier’s Flesh on Camera
text: A Syrian rebel commander who appeared to bite into the flesh of a government soldier’s corpse in a horrifying video clip posted on YouTube this week defended his actions in an interview with Time magazine on Tuesday. The rebel, Khalid al-Hamad, known by the nom de guerre Abu Sakkar, confirmed that he sank his teeth into an internal organ that he had laboriously carved out of the dead soldier’s chest as a colleague recorded the scene. “Our slogan,” he said, “is an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth.”

headline: If You’re a Tree-Hungry Beetle, Run
text: The tree-devouring Asian longhorned beetle has not yet been driven from the gates of the city, but, by Jove, pest-control authorities have it on the run. The state announced on Tuesday that the beetle had been eradicated from Manhattan and Staten Island.

headline: Greek Civil Servants Walk Out Over Ban on Teachers’ Strike
text: ATHENS — Greek civil servants walked off the job on Tuesday to protest the government’s use of an emergency law to ban a planned strike by teachers. But a popular rally in the capital was the smallest in several months, a sign that public support for the country’s once-mighty unions may be dwindling.

headline: Washington Projects Invite the Small Local Investor
text: The practice of crowdfunding real estate is spreading from South America — where Prodigy Network recently raised around $239 million from 3,100 Colombians to build a 66-story skyscraper in Bogotá — to New York, where the developer Urban Muse is hoping to offer a slice of a Brooklyn Bridge Park project to the public.

headline: Three Foes Unite to Keep Wrestling in Olympics
text: UNITED NATIONS — Rarely, if ever these days, do you hear the United States making nice with Russia and Iran at the United Nations.

headline: Subscribers Fear Bloomberg Is Becoming Their Rival
text: Long thought of as a company that serves the needs of Wall Street firms, Bloomberg L.P. is quietly becoming more like them, moving recently into businesses that have been the domain of the largest banks.

headline: Inspector General’s Report on I.R.S. Audits
text: A report offered new details on the scope and duration of the Internal Revenue Service’s effort to target conservative non-profit groups for scrutiny.

headline: Brooklyn Race Grows; So Does Security
text: When New York Road Runners reinvented the Brooklyn Half Marathon, turning a sleepy March race into an event that will host about 25,000 competitors this weekend, it was meant as an economic boon to Coney Island. But recent events have turned it into something bigger, including a much larger security challenge in the wake of the Boston Marathon bombings last month.

headline: A Better Picture
text: The budget deficit is now projected to be less severe than it was previously and much less than it has been in recent years.

headline: As Thieves Troll Spanish Farmland, Villagers Begin Patrols
text: ALBELDA, Spain — José Briá finds it hard to sleep these days. Sometimes when he wakes up in the middle of the night, he drives out to his farmland a few miles from the center of this tiny village just to make sure everything is all right.

headline: Bob Sickinger, Chicago Stage Innovator, Dies at 86
text: Bob Sickinger, a director whose mostly nonprofessional productions in the 1960s seeded a Chicago theater scene that evolved into one of the country’s greatest, died on May 9 at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 86.

headline: An Atrocity in Syria, With No Victim Too Small
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After dragging 46 bodies from the streets near his hometown on the Syrian coast, Omar lost count. For four days, he said, he could not eat, remembering the burned body of a baby just a few months old; a fetus ripped from a woman’s belly; a friend lying dead, his dog still standing guard.

headline: For Insurers, No Doubts on Climate Change
text: If there were one American industry that would be particularly worried about climate change it would have to be insurance, right?

headline: South Carolina: Sex Surgery Unnecessary, Lawsuit Alleges
text: A Southern legal advocacy group has claimed in a lawsuit that the State of South Carolina should not have surgically altered a 16-month-old child in its custody who was born with both male and female genitalia. The suit, filed in both state and federal courts, was brought on behalf of the child’s adoptive parents and is intended to restrict the practice of medically unnecessary sex assignment surgeries on infants, said lawyers with the Southern Poverty Law Center. The child was in the care of the South Carolina Department of Social Services when doctors, in cooperation with social services employees, removed the child’s male genitals. The child, now 8, identifies himself as a boy, according to his parents, Mark and Pam Crawford of Richland County. “They disfigured him because they could not accept him for who he was,” Mrs. Crawford said in a statement, “not because he needed any surgery.” Increasingly, doctors and those who were born with a condition once called hermaphroditism recommend that children be assigned a gender at birth but postpone surgery until they are old enough to choose. A spokeswoman for the state’s Social Services Department said there would be no comment on pending legal action.

headline: How They Do It Elsewhere
text: THE United States can boast that it has the world’s best basketball players, fighter jets and country and western singers. But hardly anyone would ever boast that the United States has the world’s best retirement system.

headline: R. Donahue Peebles
text: Mr. Peebles, 53, is the chairman and chief executive of the Peebles Corporation, one of the largest African-American-owned development companies in the country. The company, which has its headquarters in Coral Gables, Fla., specializes in residential and hospitality developments.

headline: Virginia Tech President to Retire
text: Charles Steger, the Virginia Tech University president who led the college during the 2007 mass shooting, this week announced plans to retire as soon as a successor is found. Dr. Steger,  65, has had a long Virginia Tech career, as a student, instructor, department head, dean — at 33, the youngest architecture dean in the nation  — vice president and, since 2000, president.  After the  shooting, in which a student, Seung-Hui Cho, killed 32 people, Mr. Steger was criticized for not warning the campus quickly.  Next month, in a case brought by the parents of two slain students, the State Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether he should stand trial for his actions during the massacre.

headline: Afghan Commandos Step Up Their Combat Role
text: AT A CLASSIFIED COMMANDO BASE, Afghanistan — One day this month, a pair of Russian Mi-17 assault helicopters delivered two teams of Afghan commandos, their faces obscured by black masks, in a touch-and-go landing at this camp in a lush valley encircled by frosty peaks about 50 miles from Kabul.

headline: Georgia Tech Will Offer a Master’s Degree Online
text: Starting in the fall, the Georgia Institute of Technology, together with AT&T and Udacity, an online education venture, will offer a master’s degree in computer science that can be earned entirely through so-called massive open online courses, or MOOCs. While the courses would be available free online to the general public, students seeking the degree would have to have a bachelor’s degree in computer science, and pay tuition that is expected to be less than $7,000  Initially, the program will be limited to a few hundred students from AT&T and Georgia Tech corporate affiliates, but enrollment is then expected to expand in the fall of 2014.

headline: ABC’s Programming
text: The Times’s Bill Carter discusses ABC’s programming, after the broadcaster unveiled its plans to advertisers.

headline: Chuck Muncie, Troubled N.F.L. Star, Dies at 60
text: Chuck Muncie, who blended speed and power to become one of the N.F.L.’s leading running backs of the late 1970s and early ’80s, but whose career was cut short by drug abuse, died on Monday at his home in Perris, Calif. He was 60.

headline: Iranian Officials Threaten Two Candidates for the Presidency
text: TEHRAN — Iranian officials on Monday issued blunt threats of violence against two last-minute registrants for the June 14 presidential election whose unwanted presence on the ballot has angered the country’s governing establishment.

headline: Pleased by Effort, if Not by Ending, Isles Pledge to Build on a Breakout Season
text: As the ice at Nassau Coliseum melted and workers used heavy machinery to dismantle its hockey rink, the Islanders resolutely spoke of building for the future.

headline: Minnesota: Governor Signs Same-Sex Marriage Into Law
text: Gov. Mark Dayton signed a measure Tuesday giving gay couples the right to marry, making Minnesota the 12th state in the nation to permit same-sex marriage. During a signing ceremony outside the State Capitol in St. Paul, where thousands of Minnesotans gathered and cheered in 90-degree weather, Mr. Dayton, a Democrat, praised the choices of state lawmakers as changing the course of history.

headline: French Lawmakers Loosen Labor Rules in a Victory for the President
text: PARIS — The French legislature gave President François Hollande an important victory on Tuesday, passing a modest loosening of the country’s labor code even as Mr. Hollande’s foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, revealed severe tensions within the Socialist government by criticizing the stewardship of the economics and finance minister, Pierre Moscovici.

headline: Pentagon Furloughs Are Set
text: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, left, announced Tuesday that most civilian Pentagon employees would be ordered to take unpaid furloughs of up to 11 days between July 8 and the end of September. The measure, which is a response to across-the-board spending reductions called sequestration, is less punitive than plans that would have seen Pentagon civilians forced to take 14 to 22 days of unpaid leave. “The department has been doing everything possible to reduce this shortfall while ensuring we can defend the nation, sustain wartime operations and preserve D.o.D.’s most critical asset — our world-class civilian and military personnel,” Mr. Hagel said.

text: Recent Sale

headline: Wheeler, Mets’ Top Pitching Prospect, to Miss Next Start
text: ST. LOUIS — The proper level of concern will become clearer Wednesday, but regardless, it was precisely the type of injury news the Mets and their fans did not want to hear.

headline: A Full House at an Older Age
text: Rebecca Gawboy, 60, and her husband, Jim, 76, take care of 12 adopted children.

headline: Bad Enough
text: Things are bad enough in the food world that we don’t need to resort to hyperbole to be worried or even alarmed.

headline: Filling Up an Empty Nest
text: RETIRING from work? Then it might be time to think about raising a family. Some brave older adults are turning the idea of retirement on its head by choosing to adopt children — this when many of their peers are traveling, socializing, taking up intellectual or entrepreneurial pursuits, or just plain relaxing.

headline: No Frills on the Road Back
text: LANDISVILLE, Pa. — There were a lot of tennis tournament essentials missing on Sunday at the $10,000 U.S.T.A. Pro Circuit tournament at Hempfield Recreation Center here.

headline: Univision Resets Sights After a Ratings Victory
text: AT its upfront presentation on Tuesday, Univision continued to promote its dominance of the Hispanic media landscape in the hope of attracting more advertising dollars to the network’s expanding empire.
