text: SANA, Yemen

headline: A Long Ride Toward a New China
text: Every summer, the blogger “Tiger Temple” bikes around China to report on rural news stories censored by state-run media.

headline: Doubts About Restricting Salt
text: After years of warnings to cut sodium consumption to reduce heart attacks and strokes, it is disturbing to learn how little evidence exists that such reductions would actually be beneficial to health. There is even emerging evidence that some groups in the population could suffer harm from levels that are too low.

headline: The Knicks’ One-Man Play Badly Needs Stagehands
text: INDIANAPOLIS

headline: Sony Meets Outspoken Activist Investor, but Courtesy Reigns
text: For a hedge fund manager whose fame first came on writing invective-filled letters, Daniel S. Loeb’s latest missive was a model of politeness.

headline: ‘A Long Ride Toward a New China’
text: Every summer, the 59-year-old Chinese blogger Zhang Shihe rides his bicycle thousands of miles to the plateaus, deserts and hinterlands of North Central China. In this Op-Doc video, we meet Mr. Zhang, known to his many followers online as “Tiger Temple,” as he goes to great lengths to document the stories of struggling rural villagers whose voices are seldom heard in China’s state-monitored media.

headline: Brazilian Court Council Removes a Barrier to Same-Sex Marriage
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The council overseeing Brazil’s judiciary ruled on Tuesday that notary publics cannot refuse to perform same-sex marriage ceremonies, a decision that opens the way for gay couples across Latin America’s largest country to marry.

headline: With Detroit Under State Control, Candidates Seek Posts Stripped of Power
text: DETROIT — Candidates seeking to become the next mayor of this deeply troubled city are calling it a historic election. They spend their days dashing around the potholed streets they hope to save, their schedules a tireless series of living-room meetings and church gatherings, nursing homes and barbershops.

headline: Grotesque Speed for Florida Capital Cases
text: The Timely Justice Act, a grotesquely named bill passed by the Florida Legislature, could get to Gov. Rick Scott as soon as this week for him to sign into law. The measure would require a governor to sign a death warrant within 30 days of a review of a capital conviction by the State Supreme Court, and the state would be required to execute the defendant within 180 days of the warrant.

headline: In Role Reversal, Goldman Chief Advises Dimon
text: Jamie Dimon has consulted lawyers, public relation experts and bankers as JPMorgan Chase wrestles with the fallout from a multibillion-dollar trading loss. But the bank chief has received advice from an unexpected corner: Lloyd C. Blankfein of rival Goldman Sachs.

headline: In World of Wrestling, Trying to Keep It Real
text: Dave Meltzer was gravely ill, but the phone would not stop ringing. It was December 1993, and someone had circulated the number of the hospital where Meltzer was being treated for a ruptured appendix, the delayed diagnosis of which had caused a life-threatening abdominal inflammation.

headline: Uninvited Guest Gives Japan’s Business Culture a Jolt
text: TOKYO — Devil. Vulture. Saboteur.

headline: A Roller Coaster Comes Down
text: The submerged Jet Star roller coaster in Seaside Heights, an iconic image of the destruction of the Jersey Shore from Hurricane Sandy, was dismantled on Tuesday.

headline: Pakistan’s Hopeful Election
text: The news from Pakistan is often terrible, as it was last week when the government expelled a New York Times bureau chief. There was also violence leading up to the parliamentary election over the weekend. At least Pakistan did manage to have an election in which about 60 percent of voters participated and has achieved a peaceful transition of power in a country where coups have predominated. The election was a welcome repudiation of militants who are trying to overthrow the state.

headline: Spying on The Associated Press
text: The Obama administration, which has a chilling zeal for investigating leaks and prosecuting leakers, has failed to offer a credible justification for secretly combing through the phone records of reporters and editors at The Associated Press in what looks like a fishing expedition for sources and an effort to frighten off whistle-blowers.

headline: Making a Move Abroad, and Working There, Too
text: WHEN Patrice Wynne shuttered her independent bookstore, Gaia, in Berkeley, Calif., and retired, she knew three things. She wanted to move to a place where she could slow down the tempo of her life, and it was cheaper to live, but where she could continue to work in some fashion.

headline: Rangers, Bruins and a Rivalry That Once Raged
text: Yankees vs. Red Sox, Giants vs. Patriots, Knicks vs. Celtics. Postseason clashes among those teams in recent years have poured fuel on the New York-Boston rivalry.

headline: Austerity in the New York Review of Books
text: I have been spending my time doing my best to take a break from the alleged real world, and will continue doing so for a bit. I should, however, let readers know that my longish-form essay on the great austerity debacle is now up at The New York Review of Books.

headline: Test Gas Attack Is Coming to the Subway, This Time With Fair Notice
text: Rolling along the back roads and highways of the Internet, a picture of a poster hints faintly at sinister doings underground.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 15, 2013
text: “How can we reach a point of national forgiveness?”

headline: After a Rough Move, a Much Easier One
text: It is possible that teams should stop underestimating the opinion of Hisashi Iwakuma. As the Seattle Mariners’ starting pitcher continues to prove his critics wrong, he is making any number of baseball people look foolish for doubting his ability.

headline: Granderson Is Back Under Lights, but Out in Left Field
text: While his teammates considered Tuesday’s matchup against the Seattle Mariners only another May game at Yankee Stadium, Curtis Granderson anxiously prepared as if there would be pageantry similar to opening day.

headline: Doctor Avoids Death Penalty in Murders at His Clinic
text: Kermit Gosnell, the doctor convicted of murdering babies after failed abortions in his Philadelphia clinic, avoided the death penalty on Tuesday by agreeing to a sentence of life in prison without parole.

text: IN his 2014 budget, President Obama proposed limiting how much money a person could put into a retirement account on a tax-deferred basis.

text: Two of the hot topics trending on Twitter Tuesday were Angelina Jolie and the I.R.S.

headline: What Worries You, Masters You
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m not sure why it took me as long as it did to see the theme here, but when I did, I thought it was very clever and a bit different than the usual hump day fare.

headline: 4% Rule for Retirement Withdrawals Is Golden No More
text: ONE thing most retirees want to avoid is outliving their money. Since the mid-1990s many of them have relied on a staple of retirement planning known as the 4 percent rule to avoid that. Although the name says 4 percent, the rule is that if retirees withdraw 4.5 percent of their savings every year, adjusted for inflation, their nest egg should last 30 years, the length of time generally used for retirement planning.

headline: And the Award Goes to...
text: When should spouses be retroactively considered in the presentation of an award, honor or place in history?

headline: Robert Lindgren, 89, Ballet Dancer and College Dean, Is Dead
text: Robert Lindgren, a Canadian-born dancer who appeared with major American ballet companies before becoming the founding dean of the influential dance school at the North Carolina School of the Arts, died on Friday at his home in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 89.

headline: Taking the Measure of Risk
text: BIG market moves always give investors a bit of portfolio vertigo. Are you too close to the edge in terms of risk? Could you get burned again as in 2008?

headline: Army Sergeant Is Accused of Sexual Abuse
text: WASHINGTON — An Army sergeant who served as a sexual assault prevention and response coordinator at Fort Hood, Tex., is under investigation for allegations of pandering, abusive sexual contact, assault and maltreatment of subordinates, Pentagon officials said late Tuesday.

headline: Gone, but Still Linked to the Home Office
text: A FEW years after John McGowan, a former contracts negotiator at Hewlett-Packard, took early retirement in 2006 at age 59, a friend persuaded him to join the H.P. Agilent Retired Employees Club-Bay Area, one of more than a dozen H.P. retiree clubs in the United States and abroad. Last fall he became president of the 1,300-member group, whose activities include lunches, hikes, bowling, golf outings and community service.

headline: Special Parking Rules in New York City
text: On Wednesday and Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City because of Shavuot. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Bigger Knicks Fall Just as Hard
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The stakes were higher, the desperation greater and the Knicks bigger, or at least as big as the laws of physiology and N.B.A. rosters would permit. They upsized. They expanded. They tinkered. Mostly, they hoped — for a turnaround, for a spiritual lift, for some magic solution to match the might of the Indiana Pacers.

headline: To Run Victim Fund, Boston Calls on the Specialist
text: BOSTON — In the aftermath of a national tragedy, Kenneth R. Feinberg has become the essential man.

headline: John LaMontaine, Pulitzer-Winning Composer, Dies at 93
text: John LaMontaine, a Pulitzer Prize-winning American composer whose works were performed widely and included the orchestral music for John F. Kennedy’s presidential inauguration, died on April 29 at his home in Hollywood, Calif. He was 93.

headline: U.S. Now Paints Apple as ‘Ringmaster’ in Its Lawsuit on E-Book Price-Fixing
text: WASHINGTON — The e-mail, from Steve Jobs of Apple to James Murdoch of News Corporation, reads as if one old sport were trying to cajole another into joining a caper: “Throw in with Apple and see if we can all make a go of this to create a real mainstream e-books market at $12.99 and $14.99.”

headline: Covering the Rising Cost of Long-Term Care
text: FEW sticker shocks are as bracing as the price of hiring someone to help with the simplest activities — bathing, toilet use, dressing, eating and moving. Whether recovering from surgery or a stroke or suffering a chronic illness like arthritis, those needing skilled help need deep pockets indeed.

headline: Suit by a Prosecutor’s Rival Seeks to Block a TV Show
text: The news that Charles J. Hynes, the longtime Brooklyn district attorney, had provided television producers access to his office to film a six-part series provoked an immediate outburst of criticism from rival candidates that it would give him an unfair edge in the Sept. 10 primary. On Tuesday, one opponent filed a lawsuit asking a state court to block CBS from broadcasting the series, calling it an “unlawful campaign contribution” and saying it would cause “irreparable harm” to his campaign.

headline: Turning Hobbies Into Profits, With a Little Help
text: THE newest breed of entrepreneur may not be the digital whiz kid, but the retirement-age grandparent looking to replenish savings, become his or her own boss or just keep busy.

headline: House to Vote Yet Again on Repealing Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — The 37th time won’t be the charm. But House Republicans are charging forward anyway this week on a vote to repeal President Obama’s signature health care overhaul, which will put the number of times they have tried to eliminate, defund or curtail the law past the three-dozen mark.

headline: Not Moving on, but Still Starting a New Chapter
text: NOAH AND BERNA LEVINE were making those steps toward retirement two years ago — trying to figure out where they wanted to live. They had moved to Marietta, Ga., about 30 years before from their native New Jersey with three young children. Mr. Levine, 62, had taken a job with the Atlanta Jewish Federation, and Mrs. Levine figured her teaching skills would quickly land her a job, which they did soon enough.

headline: Two Musical Minds Seek a Different Kind of Mogul
text: LOS ANGELES — The record producer Jimmy Iovine and his business partner Dr. Dre have a keen eye for talent. Between them, the two have jump-started the careers of stars ranging from Lady Gaga to 50 Cent to the Black Eyed Peas.

headline: Celebrating, in Spite of the Risk
text: NEW ORLEANS — Each year in the weeks leading up to Mother’s Day, when the members of the Original Big 7 Social Aid and Pleasure Club drew up the sheet outlining their parade’s route through the back streets of town, they would include a warning: “Leave your guns and foolishness at home.”

headline: Back to School, but for the Degree, Not Just the Fun
text: SCHOOL was out, and Jack Kaufmann, who teaches 8th and 9th grade Latin at the elite Hewitt School in Manhattan, was on his way to catch the train home to Westchester.

headline: Big Forum? For Cuomo, It’s Always a ‘Summit’
text: ALBANY — Some call them conferences. Others prefer forums. For old-timers, of course, they were just meetings.

headline: A Slim Travel Budget, but Otherwise No Limits
text: THE first time I video-chatted with my 67-year-old mother, she was staying at a youth hostel in South Africa. As we talked, young, tanned adventurers crossed the screen behind her. “Only $19 a night. What a deal, right?” she exclaimed, and then called over a woman half her age whom she had been biking with that day.

headline: Game 4: Knicks vs. Pacers
text: Roy Hibbert and the Pacers handed the Knicks another loss to take a 3-1 lead in their Eastern Conference semifinal.

headline: Archbishop Presses Cuomo Over Abortion
text: ALBANY — Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan declined on Tuesday to say whether Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was “a Catholic in good standing,” as he ratcheted up his criticism of the governor’s continued advocacy for abortion rights.

headline: Shumpert, Kidd, Martin: 61 Minutes and 0 Points
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The defining number for the Knicks in Game 4 — and perhaps the series at large — was zero, the astounding absence of any offensive production from three of their key supporting role players: Iman Shumpert, Jason Kidd and Kenyon Martin.

headline: Record Auction Price for Barnett Newman, $43.8 Million, Is Set at Sotheby’s
text: In a hushed salesroom at Sotheby’s on Tuesday night, a packed audience watched intently as six bidders fought over Barnett Newman’s “Onement VI,” a deep blue abstract composition from 1953. The winner, a telephone bidder speaking Italian, ended up paying $43.8 million, a record price for the artist’s work at auction — beating out the previous record of $22.4 million, paid just a year ago for another canvas in the same series. Faint applause could be heard from the onlookers.

headline: Lottery Numbers
E-Book Sales a Boon to Publishers in 2012
text: E-book sales, especially in the thriving romance genre, gave the book business a lift in 2012, according to a survey of publishers released Wednesday.

headline: Granderson’s Return Steps to the Side of the Yankees’ Comeback Victory
text: The Yankees have cobbled together a first-place team with an offense of spare parts, a Frankenstein roster of sorts, while several of their stars are on the disabled list.

headline: When Athletic Shoes Cause Injury
text: Sometimes innovative science requires innovative machinery, like a moveable, four-legged robotic sled that can wear shoes, a contraption recently developed and deployed by researchers at the University of Calgary to test whether grippy athletic shoes affect injury risk.

text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Fatal Encounter With Police Is Caught on Video, but Kept From the Public
text: LOS ANGELES — When Maria Melendez emerged from Kern Medical Center in Bakersfield, Calif., just before midnight last Tuesday, she said, she heard screams that have kept her awake at night for an entire week.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (13) GREAT ZEBRA EXODUS In its final episode of the season, “Nature” travels to the Kalahari Desert in Botswana, where 20,000 zebras go in search of grass and water each year in a trek across the lunarlike landscape of the arid Makgadikgadi Pans. This documentary from the husband-and-wife filmmakers Adrian Bailey and Robyn Keene-Young views the journey through a single family: a stallion, its three mares and their offspring, which will walk more than 2,500 miles to feed themselves.

headline: News Quiz | May 15, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Meet the Upwardly Mobile Middle-Class Indian
text: Yogesh Chile is the real face of India’s new middle class. Mr. Chile, 30, earns the equivalent of $500 a month supplying sand to construction sites in Mumbai, and after decades of urban poverty and living in the slums, his family has finally broken into the lower end of India’s middle class.

headline: Taiwan Recalls Its Envoy in Manila Over a Killing
text: BEIJING — Taiwan announced the withdrawal of its representative in Manila on Wednesday and said it had stopped accepting applications for Filipino workers, a retaliatory step for the killing of a Taiwanese fisherman by the Philippine Coast Guard last week.

headline: IHT Quick Read: May 15
text: NEWS As the United States and Russia work to organize peace talks next month between the Syrian government and its opponents, the ever more extreme carnage of combat makes the prospect of reconciliation seem more remote. Anne Barnard and Hania Mourtada report from Beirut.

headline: Euro Zone Politics Hinder Response as Slump Persists
text: PARIS — Europe slipped deeper into a widespread recession, according to data released Wednesday. But when European heads of state meet next week in Brussels, no big announcements about plans to stimulate growth are expected.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, May 15, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article “Two Promising Places to Live, 1,200 Light-Years From Earth.”

headline: Cameron Survives Challenge on Europe Policies, but Vote Is Closer Than Expected
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron survived a potentially humiliating challenge to his policies toward the European Union on Wednesday by a closer margin in Parliament than had been forecast, illuminating the depth of dissent within his party over an issue that has divided it for decades.

headline: Angelina Jolie’s ‘My Medical Choice’
text: Note: As a general rule, we don’t use Op-Eds for this feature — but, as a general rule, movie stars don’t break news by writing them. Given the content of, and the response to, this piece, we thought an exception was warranted.

headline: Honoring a Fallen Photographer’s Spirit
text: Tomás Munita has won the second annual Getty Images and Chris Hondros Fund Award, and Bryan Denton was named a finalist. The award is a memorial to Chris Hondros, who was killed two years ago while photographing in Misurata, Libya.

headline: When Has a Sports Team Most Disappointed You?
text: What sports teams do you follow or play for? How loyal a fan are you? What bitter defeats have they suffered, and how did you react? When have you been most disappointed by a team? Why?

headline: Arctic Council Adds 6 Nations as Observer States, Including China
text: KIRUNA, Sweden — The Arctic Council agreed on Wednesday to expand to include six new nations, including China, as observer states, as a changing climate opens the Arctic to increasing economic and political competition.
