headline: The ‘Long and Unacceptable’ Wait for a Veterans’ Benefit
text: We wrote last fall about a form of government assistance for aging veterans called the Aid and Attendance pension benefit (A&A), which reimburses veterans and their families for the costs of caregivers working in the home (including sons and daughters who are paid to be caregivers, though not spouses) or can be used to pay for assisted living or nursing home care. The benefit is worth as much as $2,019 monthly for a veteran and spouse, and up to $1,094 for the widow of a veteran.

headline: Another College Search Outside the Familiar, This Time for a Roommate
text: Such a big part of my high school experience has been spent thinking about how I could prepare for the college application process.

headline: The Silence of the Shams
text: NEW DELHI — Ten suicides, one murder, $5.5 billion in losses and more than 1,300 journalists without a job — the toll from one of India’s biggest Ponzi schemes continues to mount.

headline: Daily Report: Prosecutors Say Apple Had Greater Role in Fixing E-Book Prices
text: The Justice Department said on Tuesday that Apple was the “ringmaster” in a conspiracy to fix e-books prices, a more direct leadership role than portrayed in the department’s April 2012 antitrust lawsuit, Edward Wyatt and Nick Wingfield report in The New York Times.

headline: HSBC Plans More Job Cuts in Effort to Save Up to $3 Billion
text: LONDON — After two years of far-reaching cost cuts and asset sales, HSBC said on Wednesday that it planned to find an additional $2 billion to $3 billion in savings by 2016 that would include the elimination of as many as 14,000 jobs.

headline: Some Nissan NV200 Vans Will Wear Chevrolet Bow Ties
text: General Motors will begin selling Nissan’s small cargo van, with Chevrolet badging, by the end of 2014. In a joint announcement on Tuesday, G.M. and Nissan said they had signed an agreement for Nissan to produce the 2015 Chevrolet City Express, which is based on the Nissan NV200. The compact commercial vehicle is sold in many international markets, including the United States and Canada.

headline: How a Fast-Growing Start-Up Practices Decision-Making
text: Last week in my post — “If Practice Makes Perfect, Why Don’t Companies Practice More?” — I described the types of training programs and practice sessions that we use at H.Bloom. The comments that I received at the end of the column were especially insightful and offer a great segue to today’s post.

headline: Kobo’s New E-Reader Is Sharp, but Maybe Not Sharp Enough
text: Kobo has produced what it said was the highest-resolution e-ink reader, the Aura HD, which means it should have the best-looking screen, right?

headline: The Nomad’s Kitchen
text: When “The Hakka Cookbook” appeared last year, I immediately set up a cooking date with its author, Linda Lau Anusasananan, who lives in the exotic and far-flung city of San Mateo, south of San Francisco.

headline: Some of My Best Friends Are Germs
text: I can tell you the exact date that I began to think of myself in the first-person plural — as a superorganism, that is, rather than a plain old individual human being. It happened on March 7. That’s when I opened my e-mail to find a huge, processor-choking file of charts and raw data from a laboratory located at the BioFrontiers Institute at the University of Colorado, Boulder. As part of a new citizen-science initiative called the American Gut project, the lab sequenced my microbiome — that is, the genes not of “me,” exactly, but of the several hundred microbial species with whom I share this body. These bacteria, which number around 100 trillion, are living (and dying) right now on the surface of my skin, on my tongue and deep in the coils of my intestines, where the largest contingent of them will be found, a pound or two of microbes together forming a vast, largely uncharted interior wilderness that scientists are just beginning to map.

headline: Drones Take Off in Silicon Valley
text: American skies aren’t supposed to open for another couple of years to drones flown by commercial operators, but they’re already getting liftoff with Silicon Valley investors.

headline: British Water Utility Rejects Takeover Offer
text: LONDON – The British water utility Severn Trent rejected a takeover approach on Wednesday from a consortium of investment firms that could have valued the company at more than $8 billion.

headline: Daft Punk Gets Human With a New Album
text: LOS ANGELES — Thomas Bangalter, half of the influential French dance-music act Daft Punk, has a house high in the Hollywood Hills here. He and his musical partner, Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo, divide their time between Los Angeles and Paris, where their families live. But for all their jet-setting, there’s little evidence of rock star flash to be seen (well, apart from the Porsche that Mr. de Homem-Christo has parked in the driveway). Built in the midcentury style called post and beam, the bungalow exudes a subtle retro feel, with white carpeting, a cross section of a tree trunk as a coffee table, and a gravel fireplace in the living room. The swimming pool, a small square of radiant Hockney blue, is visible through the glass walls.

headline: Q&A: Closing (or Merging) Two LinkedIn Accounts
text: Q.

headline: Dimon and Blankfein, Foxhole Buddies
text: Jamie Dimon, wrestling with the fallout from JPMorgan Chase’s multibillion-dollar trading loss, has received advice from a rival, Lloyd C. Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. “The two executives have talked privately a number of times in recent months about the challenges that Mr. Dimon is facing, people with knowledge of the relationship but not authorized to speak on the matter, have said.”

headline: Japanese Reactor Is Said to Stand on a Fault Line
text: TOKYO — Seismologists said Wednesday that a nuclear reactor in Tsuruga, in western Japan, stands above an active seismic fault, a finding that could lead to the first permanent shutdown of a reactor since the Fukushima crisis two years ago.

headline: Science Tackles Mystery of the Teenage Brain
text: LONDON — Science may have split the atom and put a man on the moon but it has yet to solve the mysteries of the teenage brain.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Discovering Frugal Toulouse, Despite the Holidays
text: Discovering frugal Toulouse despite holidays, the 4 percent rule for retirement withdrawals may be outdated, no benefit seen in sharp limits on salt intake and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: A Window Concert in Brooklyn Heights
text: Dear Diary:

headline: For His Latest Transformation, Shia LaBeouf Discusses His Short Film ‘Haunted Love’
text: Though there’s been no shortage of talk in recent weeks about work that Shia LaBeouf didn’t do, here’s a look at something that this unpredictable actor did do. Mr. LaBeouf, 26, is better known for his acting roles in movies like “Transformers,” “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull” and “The Company You Keep,” but he has also dabbled in the occasional bit of film directing, including his short films “Maniac” (with the hip-hop star Kid Cudi) and “Born Villain” (with Marilyn Manson).

headline: Market Report | The G.M.T. Watch Makes a Comeback
text: Rolex debuted the first G.M.T. watch, which featured an additional hour hand to represent Greenwich Mean Time, in the 1950s. Pan Am pilots popularized the dual-time display, which allowed them to keep track of local time while flying across time zones, and inspired a slew of watchmakers to create their own G.M.T. products. Although they’ve been less popular in recent years, a recent wave of releases shows that these watches are coming back in a big way. Here are 12 of the best newcomers.

headline: Battlefield Update: The Fight for Isolated Government Outposts in Northern Syria
text: In recent weeks considerable public attention has turned to questions of whether government forces in Syria have used chemical weapons. And all the while, conventional fighting with conventional weapons – the dominant form of violence and source of killing in this and most every war of our time – has continued to rage. As world leaders and commentators of every stripe have debated President Obama’s “red line,” there have been developments on the ground, which might herald tactical shifts and point to the verifiable, actual slog that is the Syrian civil war.

headline: In Andhra, Maoist Rebels Pin Hopes on Memories of the Dead
text: On April 16, Maoist rebels, operating in the dense forests of central and eastern India received a major blow when security forces killed one of their senior commanders, along with his wife and seven other rebels in Chhattisgarh, very close to the border of Andhra Pradesh. The slain commander, Marri Ravi, alias Sudhakar, was entrusted by the outlawed rebel group Communist Party of India (Maoist) to revive its movement in Andhra after the rebels were crushed seven years ago in their erstwhile bastion following a sustained military operation against them.

headline: Bank of England Raises Outlook for British Economy
text: LONDON — After five years of dire warnings about the state of the British economy, the governor of the Bank of England raised the outlook for growth on Wednesday and said a recovery was “in sight.”

headline: Krawcheck Agrees to Buy the Women’s Network 85 Broads
text: Sallie L. Krawcheck, a former executive of Bank of America and Citigroup, has agreed to buy 85 Broads, a global organization that supports women.

headline: The Daddy Business Trip
text: I was in a pile of men on the floor of a suite at the Ritz-Carlton in Laguna Niguel, Calif., a wineglass in one hand and a remote in the other. My pilemates brandished cocktails and bonbons. One of them had his head lodged in the open minibar. Two dozen fellow conference-goers surrounded us, their iPhone cameras flashing at the slovenly heap. Isn’t this what business trips are all about?

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Guardian: Sometimes, Emma Sturgess argues, white bread is the right bread. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: A Team Approach to Get Students College Ready
text: When Parker Sheffy, a first-year teacher in the Bronx Leadership Academy II, a high school in the South Bronx, talks shop with friends who are also new teachers, he often hears about the problems they are facing: students not showing up to class on time, not understanding their work, not doing homework. “I’m thinking: I don’t have that problem… I don’t have that problem…” Sheffy recalled. In his ninth grade integrated algebra class, he estimates that 80 to 90 percent are on track to pass the Regents exam, more than double last year’s figure.

headline: Building a Playground
text: As the wildly successful “Goodnight, Goodnight, Construction Site” has shown, stories about trucks need not be tough. There can be warm, fuzzy elements amid the concrete and scrap metal. Even a teddy bear can find its way in. Perhaps there’s just something appealing about the juxtaposition of soft, fluffy animals and heavy-metal loaders, which feature in two new picture books this season. In both “Construction Kitties,” by Judy Sue Goodwin Sturges, with illustrations by Shari Halpern, and “Dig, Dogs, Dig,” by James Horvath, a crew of smiling pets get to work building — what else? — a playground.

headline: Statement by the Richmond County District Attorney Regarding Vito J. Lopez
text: Read the full statement from Daniel M. Donovan, Jr., the Richmond County District Attorney, concerning the investigation into Vito J. Lopez

headline: As Larger British Rivals Perk Up, a Heralded Small Bank Stumbles
text: Just as larger banks in Britain are recovering from the financial crisis, a smaller one championed by lawmakers as an alternative to institutions like Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland is floundering, complicating the government’s plan to shake up the industry and testing its new regulatory system.

headline: About That Debt Crisis? Never Mind
text: Link fixed

headline: CBS’s Schedule Adds 4 Comedies, Each Guarded by a Successful One
text: Four new comedies are coming to the CBS schedule in the fall, each guarded by comedies that are already successful, like “How I Met Your Mother” and “The Big Bang Theory,” the network announced on Wednesday morning.

headline: Why Retirement Savings Are Falling Short
text: It’s not just the recession that has set back Americans’ retirement savings, a new survey from Ameriprise Financial says.

headline: Report Finds Lawmaker Was Shielded by Leaders
text: One woman who worked for Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez said she contracted pink eye after he pressured her to put drops in his eyes. Another woman described being repeatedly groped by him until he forced his hands up her legs. Several employees said Mr. Lopez told them to wear low-cut blouses and high heels, or stay in hotel rooms with him overnight. Two women were so repulsed that they began secretly taping their interactions with Mr. Lopez.

headline: Food Matters | Get Your Kicks at River Styx
text: Disco globes and vintage car pulleys dangling from the ceiling. A fire-engine-red wood-burning oven capped by a wooden, wagon-wheel-like formation. Handcrafted tables that form a heart shape when pushed together. It’s clear from these quirky design details what River Styx — the newest restaurant from the team behind Brooklyn’s Roebling Tea Room, which opened last night on a quiet, riverside street in Greenpoint — is not: another neighborhood eatery that takes itself too seriously.

headline: Image of the Day: May 15
text: Demonstrators protest poor development in Assam.

headline: Meanwhile, Syria Burns
text: ISTANBUL — The first request of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, when he visits the White House on Thursday, will surely be that his hosts stop dragging their feet on Syria. Turkey wants the United States to show the same muscle there that it displayed in Libya in order to bring down Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Jana Reveals Big Stakes in Groupon and Zynga
text: Barry Rosenstein seems to think he has found bargains in the Internet company aisle.

headline: Online Hiring Tools Are Changing Recruiting Techniques
text: It can seem improbable given the still-sluggish monthly unemployment reports, but in some sectors small businesses are desperate to find qualified candidates to fill jobs.

headline: Israel Hints at New Strikes, Warning Syria Not to Hit Back
text: WASHINGTON — In a clear warning to Syria to stop the transfer of advanced weapons to Islamic militants in the region, a senior Israeli official signaled on Wednesday that Israel was considering additional military strikes to prevent that from happening and that the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, would face crippling consequences if he retaliated.

headline: Wheelies: The Change the Batteries Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Dwindling Support
text: A team falls behind, three games to one, in a seven-game series, and the verdicts are quickly delivered.

headline: A Black Nurse, a German Soldier and an Unlikely WWII Romance
text: The nurse and the soldier may never have met – and eventually married – had it not been for the American government’s mistreatment of black women during World War II.

headline: Has LinkedIn Changed the Way You Hire?
text: A small-business guide we’ve just published discusses several examples of how companies are using online tools to revamp their hiring processes. One example is Eldridge Capital, an asset-backed lender based in Toronto that recently introduced an offshoot, Zillidy, to issue small loans to small businesses.

headline: Despite Focus on Spectacle, Russia Hints Spy Case Won’t Disrupt U.S. Ties
text: MOSCOW — Senior Russian and American officials said on Wednesday that they were prepared to put a bizarre spy case behind them, even as the episode remained a matter of intense fascination to the Russian news media and the public.

headline: Playing Host to Reality
text: Louisiana has become home to many new reality TV shows, including ones featuring alligator trappers, garbage collectors, “bad girls” and pawnshop owners.

headline: Lincoln Center Turns to Broadway for Its Next Chief
text: In a sign that the country’s largest nonprofit performing arts center may be taking a page from the world of commercial theater, Lincoln Center has chosen a Broadway producer as its next leader.

headline: Seeking Fame in the Bayou? Get Real
text: NEW ORLEANS — “If I had a dollar every time they asked me for the next Honey Boo Boo Child,” said James Bearb, a Louisiana native and the president of Hollywood South Casting, “I swear I would be the next millionaire.”

headline: Why Fund Managers May Be Right About the Fed
text: The economics world has been having a lot of fun with hedge fund managers.

headline: Should Baseball Right Umpire Wrongs?
text: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on The Times’s sports blogs.

headline: Hunting Pesky Pigs in Paradise
text: Our plan the first day was not to kill the beast but to follow him, to observe his home and habits, to see the evil that he did and maybe get in his face.

headline: How Ken Burns Explores New England
text: In 1979, Ken Burns, then a little-known documentary filmmaker, up and left New York City for Walpole, N.H. What first drew him to the small New England town was its cheap rent. “I thought I had just taken a vow of anonymity and poverty, if I was going to be a documentary filmmaker concentrating in American history for PBS,” he said.

headline: Seeking Solitude (With a Guide)
text: The farthest I’ve ever felt from civilization was when I spent two nights in an old fire lookout in the Sierra Nevada of Northern California. Built in the 1930s and situated at almost 6,000 feet, the tower had tremendous views of the dense pine forest blanketing Tahoe National Forest. What I remember most was the retreat of city lights, the lack of cellphone reception and the kind of stillness that makes the hours seem to hold more time: for reading, for hikes, for star-spotting, for meandering conversations around the campfire.

headline: New York State Joint Commission on Public Ethics Report on Vito J. Lopez
text: Read the full investigation report from the New York State Joint Commission on Public Ethics regarding complaints against Vito J. Lopez.

headline: Criticized on Seizure of Records, White House Pushes News Media Shield Law
text: WASHINGTON — Under fire over the Justice Department’s use of a broad subpoena to obtain calling records of Associated Press reporters in connection with a leak investigation, the Obama administration sought on Wednesday to revive legislation that would provide greater protections to reporters in keeping their sources and communications confidential.

headline: The Secret to One Cab’s Success: Candy
text: Most cabdrivers in New York pick passengers up and drop them off without much of a fuss. But Mansoor Khalid is trying something different.

headline: ‘I Do’ and the A.C.L.U.
text: For a marker or metric of just how rapidly the marriage-equality movement has progressed, consider this:

headline: The Gun Report: May 15, 2013
text: Did you know that the gun lobby doesn’t want you discussing handgun safety with your doctor? In June 2011, Florida governor Rick Scott signed a bill that made it the first state in the nation to prohibit doctors from asking patients if they own guns. Oklahoma, Tennessee and West Virginia all introduced “physician gag law” bills that would restrict physician firearm counseling. Shortly thereafter, the American Academy of Pediatrics reaffirmed its commitment to advocating for the strongest possible firearm regulations, arguing that fewer guns means safer homes for children.

headline: House Hunting Outside Buenos Aires
text: A three-bedroom with a geometric theme is on the market for $1.35 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Argentina
text: A THREE-BEDROOM HOUSE WITH A POOL OUTSIDE BUENOS AIRES

headline: Warner Music Gains Approval to Buy Parlophone, a Last Piece of EMI
text: European regulators on Wednesday approved the Warner Music Group’s purchase of the Parlophone Label Group, tying up one of the last loose ends from the $4.1 billion breakup of EMI.

headline: Did Japan ‘Need’ Comfort Women?
text: In recent years, Toru Hashimoto, a 43-year-old former television commentator who is mayor of Osaka, Japan’s third largest city, has been making political waves, challenging the status quo with a brash, very un-Japanese approach. He’s known for provocative right-wing statements, quick, the-buck-stops-with-me decisions, and a willingness to battle labor unions and the establishment in a culture known for consensus-building. Last September, he formed a new political party, the Japan Restoration Association, and named about 350 candidates, most political neophytes, to run in the next parliamentary elections.

headline: The Envelope, Please: Candice Childress
text: I, for one, do not believe that a roommate profile is the proper place to demonstrate one’s self-restraint. Or it could be that my profile is utterly repugnant.

headline: Picasso Museum Reopening Is Delayed
text: PARIS—The grand doors of the Musée National Picasso Paris will remain closed for another summer, extending a nearly four-year wait for its reopening.

headline: What You Get for ... $1 Million
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: Google Introduces New Features for Android Apps and Games
text: Google kicked off its annual developers conference in San Francisco on Wednesday with no new products to show. But it highlighted new tools and services that will allow software makers to make Android apps and games more powerful.

headline: U.S. Envoy Talks With Chinese About North Korea
text: BEIJING — The State Department’s senior envoy on North Korea said Wednesday that he had discussed “all aspects of the North Korea issue” with Chinese officials, including sanctions on the North, during a one-day visit to Beijing.

headline: Homes for $1 Million
text: An 1883 house in Philadelphia, an adobe in New Mexico and a cottage in Seattle.

headline: The Obama Synthesis, Vindicated?
text: Having noted the ways in which the the recent scandals (and other developments) pose a challenge to this administration’s distinctive political/policy synthesis, I should also take note of the piece of recent news that makes that synthesis look better than it sometimes has. That news would be the latest deficit projections, as summarized by my colleague Annie Lowrey:

headline: Roundabout Theater Announces Changes to Fall Season
text: A Broadway revival of Philip Barry’s classic comedy “The Philadelphia Story,” which the Tony Award nominee Alex Timbers (“Peter and the Starcatcher”) was to direct this fall, has been postponed, Roundabout Theater Company announced on Wednesday. Replacing that show will be a revival of Terence Rattigan’s 1946 drama, “The Winslow Boy,” starring Roger Rees (a Tony winner for “The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby”) and Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio and directed by Lindsay Posner, who recently staged the play at the Old Vic in London.

headline: For Rent: Airstreams
text: If ever a recreational vehicle could be called iconic, it would be the Airstream. The sausage-shaped silvery aluminum trailer has been a fixture of American road trips since the company’s founding in 1931, but before this year it was available only for purchase. Starting this month, the travel company Airstream 2 Go will rent current-model Airstream trailers outfitted with flat-screen televisions, camping chairs, tables and barbecue grills, as well as GMC Yukons to pull them for journeys of at least five days. Initial rental locations include Las Vegas and Los Angeles, but there are plans to expand to other cities across the country.

headline: Subaru to Recall 5,400 Vehicles for Possible Steering Failure
text: Subaru will recall nearly 5,400 2013 Outback and Legacy models because the steering may fail, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. In a report posted on the agency’s Web site, Subaru said the inner and outer shafts of the steering column assembly could lose contact with one another, in which case “the driver would lose the ability to steer the vehicle.”

headline: Advice on Practicing Yoga in Middle Age, Part 2
text: This is the second set of answers to reader questions from Dr. Loren Fishman, a back-pain and rehabilitative medicine specialist who has long incorporated yoga into patient care. In 1972, before applying to medical school, he studied yoga with B.K.S. Iyengar for a year in Pune, India. Dr. Fishman is the medical director of Manhattan Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation in New York City, an assistant clinical professor at Columbia Medical School and an associate editor of the journal Topics in Geriatric Rehabilitation. He is also an author of eight books, including “Yoga for Osteoporosis: the Complete Guide.”

headline: Myanmar’s President to Visit White House
text: Myanmar’s president, U Thein Sein, will visit the White House on May 20, another step in the warming of relations between the United States and the military-backed regime that rules Myanmar, once known as Burma.

headline: Guest Lesson | Gearing Up for a Summer of Making, Connecting and Learning by Doing
text: We asked Suzie Boss, who has done a series of guest posts on project-based learning for us, to focus her final post of the school year on ideas for summer.

headline: I.R.S. Chief Out After Protest Over Scrutiny of Groups
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced Wednesday night that the acting commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service had been ousted after disclosures that the agency gave special scrutiny to conservative groups. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., meanwhile, warned top I.R.S. officials that a Justice Department inquiry would examine any false statements to see if they constituted a crime.

headline: The Taxman Cometh
text: Gail Collins: David, as you know, I’m from Cincinnati. Some people may think of it as just another city in Ohio, but there has been a lot of drama coming out of Cincinnati over the years. One of the stars of the savings and loan scandal of the ’80s, Charles Keating, used to lecture at the Catholic girls’ high school I went to. The lectures were not about finance but rather on the sinfulness of wearing shorts in the summertime. However, my point is that stuff happens in Cincinnati.

headline: The Envelope, Please: Candice Childress
text: In her final post, Candice Childress, a high school senior in Las Vegas, describes her ambition to become the next Kevin Brownlow.

headline: Archbishop Clarifies Remarks About Cuomo
text: ALBANY – Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan did not intend to question Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s standing in the Roman Catholic Church, despite the governor’s support for abortion rights, the cardinal’s spokesman said on Wednesday.

headline: See Topless Woman? Just Move On, Police Are Told
text: In the cold of February, as New York City police officers gathered for their daily orders at roll call, they were given a rather unusual command, for both its timing and its substance: If they happened upon a topless woman, they were not to arrest her.

headline: A Photographer’s Unfiltered Account of the Iraq War
text: “Photojournalists on War,” an oral history of the Iraq war by those who documented it from the front lines, was published this month by the University of Texas Press. The book consists of interviews conducted by Michael Kamber, who covered the war for eight years for The New York Times and is a co-founder of the Bronx Documentary Center.

headline: Kirk and Spock, in Their Roughhousing Days
text: There is some intermittent complaining, in “Star Trek Into Darkness,” about the militarization of the Federation’s Starfleet. You may recall that the historic mission of the starship Enterprise was “to explore strange new worlds, to seek out new life and new civilizations.” While the crew on the first television series found its way into plenty of fights, the show itself always tried to stay true to the ideals of peaceful intergalactic ethnography.

headline: The Music Teacher’s Raid
text: After months of failed efforts to take Vicksburg by assaults from the north, by the early spring of 1863 Ulysses S. Grant had settled on a radically different approach. He would send a force over to the western bank of the Mississippi River; his troops would then march down through northern Louisiana, cross back over the river and establish a base of operations at Grand Gulf, Miss., about 30 miles south of Vicksburg, where there was less of a rebel presence. Grant could thus exploit advantageous terrain and weaker rebel defenses to move against the Confederate stronghold from the south.

headline: Photos Take the Spotlight in Updates to Google’s Social Network
text: Google may dominate Web search, but when it comes to social networks, the company’s Google Plus service is an underdog against Facebook and Twitter. As of December, Google Plus users were spending about 12 minutes a month on the service, according to the company, a smidgen of time compared with the hours that Facebook users spend on that site every month.

headline: Google to Sell Its Own Version of Samsung’s Galaxy S4
text: 11:46 a.m. | Updated This post was updated to add the price of Google’s version of the Galaxy S4 phone.

headline: In the Candy Cab, Sweets That Delight, and Heal
text: “No eating or drinking inside this car,” reads a sign in Mansoor Khalid’s cab, “Except candies.”

headline: Google Introduces New Search Tools to Try to Read Our Minds
text: Google keeps trying to read our minds.

headline: Giving Students Credit for Programming Classes
text: SEATTLE — One of the great frustrations for advocates of computer science education is that programming classes are treated as electives in most high schools across the country, rather than as a core part of students’ education.

headline: Yankee Stadium Will Host Two N.H.L. Games
text: The N.H.L. officially announced on Wednesday what had been widely reported for weeks: Yankee Stadium will host two hockey games in January as part of a series of outdoor stadium contests to be played across North America next season.

headline: Lady Antebellum Bests ‘Great Gatsby’ on Album Chart
text: The country-pop trio Lady Antebellum, and Jay-Z’s soundtrack to the new “Great Gatsby” film lead a passel of new releases on the Billboard album chart this week.

headline: Knicks Get Away From What Worked
text: All stretching limbs and sturdy trunks, the Indiana Pacers once again turned the paint into an impenetrable thicket of defenders in their Game 4 victory over the visiting Knicks on Tuesday night. The Pacers’ starting five may be the biggest in the N.B.A., and Coach Frank Vogel uses every last inch to swallow up drives and obscure passing angles.

headline: Cranky Is Contagious (Part Two)
text: Earlier this spring I wrote a post describing the ways I am trying to teach my children all of the lessons surrounding the idea of emotional contagion. “You catch more flies with honey than you do with vinegar,” I tell them (they say they don’t want flies). “You get what you give,” I say. A soft answer turneth away wrath, but grievous words stir up anger.

headline: Graham Motion Praises Animal Kingdom’s Versatility
text: Animal Kingdom, winner of the 2011 Kentucky Derby and the 2013 Dubai World Cup, is the first Derby winner to win a Grade 1 race at age 5 and the first Derby winner to win a major race at age 5 since Citation in 1950.

headline: Major Redesign of Google Maps Is Unveiled
text: Google is taking on a new challenge in mapping — creating real-time, personalized maps for everyone on the planet.

headline: A Tech M.&A. Machine Hits the Brakes
text: Over the last decade, Nuance Communications has been on a frenetic shopping spree.

headline: New Chief Revamps Warner Brothers, Clearing Way for Rival to Leave
text: LOS ANGELES — In his first moves as the new chief executive of Warner Brothers, Kevin Tsujihara on Wednesday revamped the studio’s TV and home entertainment operations, clearing the way for a onetime rival’s departure.

headline: Objects | Chopard’s Red Carpet Collection
text: The French premiere of “The Great Gatsby” isn’t the only high-profile event at the opening of the 66th annual Cannes Film Festival. Also making its debut this evening is Chopard’s decadent collection of 66 one-of-a-kind pieces, one for each year of the festival’s history. Jewelry made with pastel-colored gems like kunzite, paraiba tourmaline and mauve spinel plays a supporting role to diamond pieces. But the real showstopper is a choker and ring set (above) featuring poppy flowers fashioned with rubies, emeralds and tsavorites. Festivalgoers will get to view the collection up close on beguiling beauties on the red carpet, where the likes of Cara Delevingne and other A-listers will model it over the course of the festival.

headline: The Suggestion of Fried Chicken
text: Outtakes is a behind-the-scenes glimpse of images in the Dining section. Andrew Scrivani (@AndrewScrivani on Twitter and Instagram) is a freelance photographer and a regular contributor to The New York Times. He writes the blog making SundaySauce.

headline: Reacting to Angelina Jolie’s Breast Cancer News
text: We have to be careful not to conflate Jolie’s situation and choices with those of an average woman or even with those of a woman who receives a diagnosis of low-grade breast cancer.

headline: Pininfarina and BMW Collaborate on a Concept Car
text: CERNOBBIO, Italy — Pininfarina, the Italian design house, and BMW have collaborated on a design study called the Gran Lusso Coupe, which will be officially unveiled here next week in connection with the Concorso d’Eleganza at the Villa d’Este. Although this is not the first BMW-Pininfarina collaboration, it may be the most extensive. Last year at the concours event, BMW showed the Zagato Coupe concept that built upon a creative exchange between the two companies.

headline: Google Isn’t Afraid of Building for Apple’s Turf
text: At its annual developers conference, Google reinforced that it isn’t afraid to set up shop on the territory of its biggest rival, Apple. Several of the new services that it announced Wednesday are available for Google’s devices as well as Apple’s.

headline: Flu in Pregnancy Is Linked to Bipolar Disorder
text: Flu infection during pregnancy may increase the risk for bipolar disorder in the child, according to a new report.

headline: Idzik Continues Jets Shakeup
text: Two more high-ranking Jets officials will not be retained as John Idzik continues his purge of the previous regime. The latest departures are Scott Cohen, the assistant general manager, and Ari Nissim, the director of football administration.

headline: Bronx Judge Dismisses Charges in ’12 Killing by Officer; New Indictment Is Possible
text: A Bronx judge dismissed manslaughter charges on Wednesday against a New York City police officer who had shot and killed an unarmed 18-year-old in his family’s home.

headline: Estimated Health Costs in Retirement Drop
text: In its annual update of retirees’ medical costs, Fidelity Investments reports that its estimate of those expenses for a 65-year-old couple has dropped by about $20,000.

headline: For the Spurs, Parker Is the Steady Hand (Again)
text: Throughout Golden State’s first-round upset of the Denver Nuggets, and for fleeting moments in their series with the San Antonio Spurs, Stephen Curry and Klay Thompson have taken turns as the toast of the N.B.A. playoffs. But with the Spurs now leading 3-2 in the series, the spotlight has begun to illuminate the steady presence of San Antonio’s Tony Parker.

headline: Breakdown Imperils NASA’s Hunt for Other Earths
text: NASA’s planet-hunting Kepler spacecraft has been shut down by the failure of one of the reaction wheels that keep it pointed, the space agency announced Wednesday.

headline: Taming Your Mane With a Topknot
text: You’ve seen them on the street, looking like Pebbles Flintstone running late for ballet practice. They’ve sat in front of you at the movies, their giant, messy hairdos obliterating your view of the screen. Their chunky buns have brushed against your chin on the subway. They’ve invaded your television screen, from “Girls” to “Bunheads,” which is named for dancers who pile their hair high up on the crown of their heads in a defiant challenge to gravity.

headline: E.L. Doctorow and Mark di Suvero Strike Gold at American Academy of Arts and Letters
text: The novelist E.L. Doctorow and the sculptor Mark di Suvero have been awarded gold medals for the arts by the American Academy of Arts and Letters. The awards were announced on Wednesday at the academy’s headquarters in Upper Manhattan, as part of a ceremony inducting three new regular members and one honorary member, Bob Dylan, to the 250-person group.

headline: Attorney General Clashes With Rep. Issa
text: While answering questions about Thomas E. Perez, the president’s Labor nominee, Attorney General Eric H. Holder, Jr. exchanged sharp words with Representative Darrell Issa.

headline: Chia Seeds Are Latest Wonder Ingredient for Skin
text: Chia seeds have gone from being the basis of Chia Pets to becoming one of the biggest so-called superfoods on the market. They are rich in omega-3 fatty acids and high in antioxidants, protein and fiber. Now they are cropping up in skin care products. Proponents say the seeds, often pressed into an oil, increase skin hydration and have anti-inflammatory properties.

headline: At Hearing, Holder Calls Issa’s Accusations ‘Shameful’
text: The possibility of contentious moments during the testimony of Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. at a House subcommittee hearing on Wednesday already seemed high, coming just days after the administration faced anger over seizures of journalists’ records. However, the tensest exchange of the hearing seemed to catch both Mr. Holder and members of the House Judiciary Committee’s oversight panel off guard, and ended with Mr. Holder calling a congressman’s behavior “shameful.”

headline: Scouting Report
text: Openings

headline: Injury Likely to Keep Murray Out of French Open
text: A balky lower back prompted Andy Murray to retire from his second-round match at the Italian Open on Wednesday, and he said he doubted that he would be able to play in the French Open.

headline: Still Hitching the Plow
text: Horses work the fields at Cedar Mountain Farm.

headline: Farm Equipment That Runs on Oats
text: HARTLAND, Vt. — It was a perfect day for plowing, a little overcast with a cool breeze. You could hear the sound of the birds, the chink-chink-chink of the harness.

headline: Moscow Rejects Bid to Hold Gay Rights Parade
text: MOSCOW — Moscow officials rejected on Wednesday an application by gay rights advocates to hold a parade this month, saying the event could undermine a campaign to instill patriotic values in the city’s youths.

headline: Choose One: Marriage Or Passion
text: There are no happy endings in “Onegin,” John Cranko’s three-act ballet inspired by Alexander Pushkin’s narrative poem. There are, however, many swooning pas de deux. By backbend standards, this is a heavy-dipping ballet.

headline: Recipe Lab Video Chat on Frying Techniques
text: It’s time to turn off the burner and join Julia Moskin of The Times and Norman King, the author of “The Way to Fry,” to talk about fried chicken, and frying in general.

headline: Sexagenarians Gone Wild
text: I had dinner with an age-appropriate fellow from out of town recently and when talk turned to his 14-hour drive home, he said rather than spend money on a motel, he just put the passenger seat down, got out his sleeping bag and slept in the car.

headline: Roving Downtown, From Opera to Folk
text: Introducing a concert at Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday evening, Peter Gelb, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, thanked the club for “putting their downtown cred at risk by supporting the Met.”

headline: Cholesterol Levels No Longer Declining
text: Average levels of LDL, the so-called bad cholesterol, declined significantly in Americans from 2001 to 2008, but have remained steady ever since. No one knows why.

headline: Car-Sharing Service Suspended Over Insurance Concerns
text: The car-sharing service RelayRides has agreed to stop operating in New York, after state authorities said the company was violating state insurance laws.

headline: There’s a Wilder Kingdom When a Marriage Expands
text: In Abby Rosebrock’s promising new play, “Different Animals,” a broke, deeply unhappy husband and wife in the South take on a couple of ill-fitting lovers. The wife, Jessica, picks the local pastor (and heartthrob), Will, while the dumpy Leo chooses his effusive, unbalanced office mate, Molly. After some blackmail, an unplanned pregnancy and other semi-Gothic meanderings, Jessica, Leo and Molly come to an unconventional romantic arrangement that would make even Jerry Springer blush.

headline: Conservatives and Health Care Costs
text: Nested within the news about falling deficits is news about slowing health care cost inflation, which seems to be outlasting the recession and which is driving the long-term projections for Medicare spending downward. Since one of the big questions in the Great Obamacare Debate was whether the new health care law would accelerate cost growth (as expanded subsidies and regulations often tend to do) or reduce it (thanks to the various cost-containing experiments and pilot programs embedded within the bill), the news that costs are falling in advance of the bill’s implementation has some liberals crowing. Jonathan Chait, in particular, has taken to explaining why “the growing mass of evidence that the health-care-cost inflation problem is indeed solvable” cuts the legs out from under the entire right-of-center take on health care, deficits and entitlements, and puts the data squarely on the side of health care reform’s proponents. Here’s his elaboration on this theme:

headline: Couple Settle Fraud Case Involving Chinese Company
text: A husband-and-wife team that ran a Chinese maker of pollution control equipment agreed on Wednesday to pay $3.75 million to settle accusations that they had defrauded American investors.

headline: Horns Find a Haven in a Sacred Setting
text: After a long season that recently culminated in punishing marathon performances of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle, the brass players of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra could have been forgiven for taking a breather. Instead, they assembled in full force on Tuesday evening at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine for a scintillating if acoustically challenging concert of sacred and secular music arranged and conducted by John Sheppard.

headline: The Thrill of Visiting Japan. . . And Thinking You’re in Ireland
text: What feeds wanderlust better than Google Street View? GeoGuessr, which is like “Where in the World is Carmen Sandiego?” for computer-bound grown-ups.

headline: Travel Essentials | Spoleto, Italy
text: In our Summer Travel issue, which hit newsstands on Sunday, Elaine Sciolino talks to Carla Fendi, who aims to revive the faded glories of the once majestic Spoleto Festival in Italy. Here’s where to stay, eat and sleep in this Umbrian hill town.

headline: Bossa Nova Civic Club
text: From the fratty pubs of Murray Hill to the kiddie beer gardens of Park Slope, bars reflect the spirit of their neighborhood. Bossa Nova Civic Club, which opened deep in Bushwick last December, is no exception. Co-owned by John Barclay (who was involved with 285 Kent and other underground Brooklyn spaces), Bossa Nova is another indicator that this industrial hinterland has become a destination for more than just warehouse parties of dubious legality.

headline: Another Ratner, Another Brooklyn
text: The last name “Ratner” usually conjures up one of two images among New Yorkers. There’s Ratner’s, the bygone Jewish dairy, and then there’s Bruce Ratner, the developer of the Atlantic Yards in Downtown Brooklyn, on whom opinion is notably more mixed. One thing that doesn’t often come up, however, is literature.

headline: As Cisco Adapts, Profit Rises 14.5%
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Trends in technology are being good to Cisco Systems.

headline: A Leader Behind the Curtain Shows His Creative Side
text: It has been 30 years since the death of George Balanchine, the unsurpassed choreographer and co-founder of New York City Ballet, which also means it has been 30 years since Peter Martins took over the stewardship of the company. In addition to running City Ballet and its affiliate School of American Ballet, Mr. Martins has choreographed nearly 90 ballets for the troupe. Yet only once, in 2000, did he present a program made up exclusively of his own shorter works. On Tuesday night at the David H. Koch Theater, he did it again.

headline: Oh, How the Humble Has Risen
text: Along with midriff-baring tops and all things Gatsby, another trend has swept the spring social circuit: kale salads.

headline: Seeking Retrial, Simpson Is Demure but Unbowed
text: LAS VEGAS — His hands cuffed to his belt, his legs shackled, O. J. Simpson shuffled to the front of a courtroom here Wednesday after four years in prison, testifying in an effort to overturn the kidnapping and armed robbery conviction that sent him to state prison after he was acquitted of the double murder that made him notorious.

headline: The Man Who Cried Filibuster Reform
text: Republicans will get yet another chance to block the confirmation of a totally uncontroversial nominee next week, when Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid holds a vote on Richard Cordray, the would-be director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Jerusalem and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Jerusalem, Spain, Afghanistan and Turkey.

headline: Big Banks Get Break in Rules to Limit Risks
text: 9:33 p.m. | Updated

headline: Jimmy Kimmel on Mean Tweets and Upfronts
text: The Times’s Bill Carter talks with Jimmy Kimmel about the Upfronts, “Jimmy Kimmel Live” and his upcoming plans.

headline: Attorney General on the I.R.S.
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. addressed the issue of the I.R.S.’s specifically targeting conservative groups during a House Judiciary Committee hearing on Wednesday.

headline: Leaping to Conclusions on a Pilot’s Speculation
text: An article on the Bloomberg News Web site on Wednesday noted an airline pilot’s claim that an iPhone could interfere with a plane’s compasses during takeoff and landing.

headline: Early E-Mails on Benghazi Show Internal Divisions
text: WASHINGTON — E-mails released by the White House on Wednesday revealed a fierce internal jostling over the government’s official talking points in the aftermath of last September’s attack in Benghazi, Libya, not only between the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency, but at the highest levels of the C.I.A.

headline: Rediscovering a Tune Unplayed Since 1942
text: The Gil Evans Project, a large-format repertory band in residence at the Jazz Standard this week, brings painstaking precision to its task but also an air of unburdened pleasure. Its driving purpose isn’t re-enactment so much as revelation, which helps guard against the pull of nostalgia. That’s tantalizingly rare in the jazz repertory game. And sometimes the band’s chosen music proves rarer still.

headline: A Child of Two Lands
text: “When things fall apart, the children of the land scurry and scatter like birds escaping a burning sky,” NoViolet Bulawayo writes in her deeply felt and fiercely written debut novel. “They flee their own wretched land so their hunger may be pacified in foreign lands, their tears wiped away in strange lands, the wounds of their despair bandaged in faraway lands, their blistered prayers muttered in the darkness of queer lands.” They leave behind their mothers and fathers and “the bones of their ancestors in the earth” — they leave behind “everything that makes them who and what they are, leaving because it is no longer possible to stay.”

headline: Band Flies in From Norway to Say Hello and Goodbye
text: As high-profile debuts go, the circumstances could hardly be odder for Kaizers Orchestra’s first American performance, on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Hair Goop, Presented With Wit
text: SIMON DOONAN is slumming.

headline: Keeping Wi-Fi Always Within Range
text: It’s enough to give tech devotees the shivers: imagine being stuck on a train with no Wi-Fi, or out of range of the free access provided by coffee shops and bookstores.

headline: A Franchise Boldly Continues
text: Images from “Star Trek Into Darkness.”

headline: Practicing for the Bermuda Bowl Trials
text: The open trial to pick the two United States teams for this year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship will start in Orlando, Fla., on May 31.

headline: Arena-Rock Masters, Unafraid to Leave the Lights On
text: The Killers made an unconventional entrance for their Madison Square Garden show on Tuesday night. The arena didn’t go dark.

headline: Cloning Is Used to Create Embryonic Stem Cells
text: Scientists have finally succeeded in using cloning to create human embryonic stem cells, a step toward developing replacement tissue to treat diseases but one that might also hasten the day when it will be possible to create cloned babies.

headline: Wounded Soldiers Race to the South Pole
text: This November, I will join a team of three other wounded American veterans — Therese Frentz, Ivan Castro and Margaux Mange — on a 225-mile race across Antarctica for the Walking With the Wounded South Pole Allied Challenge. We will travel on skis while dragging sleds packed with approximately 150 pounds of survival equipment through the harshest climates on the planet. We will be racing for more than two weeks against similar teams of wounded veterans from the United Kingdom, Canada and Australia. Our goal is not just to win the race, but also to raise awareness.

headline: Larry Page Gets Personal at Google’s Conference
text: Google’s I/O developers conference was light on major announcements. But the company’s chief executive, Larry Page, made news with a surprise appearance on stage, during which he took questions from software developers in the audience.

headline: Inspiration in Self-Acceptance
text: A look at the work of the artist Jeffrey Gibson.

headline: At Peace With Many Tribes
text: HUDSON, N.Y. — One sunny afternoon early this month Jeffrey Gibson paced around his studio, trying to keep track of which of his artworks was going where.

headline: Meet Orb
text: After impressively winning the Kentucky Derby, Orb tried to become the first horse to conquer the Triple Crown in 35 years.

headline: Carey Mulligan Arrives in Forties Glamour at Cannes
text: The Girl: The leading actress of “The Great Gatsby” at its French premiere at the Cannes Film Festival.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Anonymous Sharing and Historic Embarrassment
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Cambodia Presses U.S. Museums to Relinquish Antiquities
text: Buoyed by the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s decision this month to return two stolen statues, Cambodia is asking other museums to examine any Khmer antiquities they acquired after 1970, when a 20-year period of civil war and genocide gave thieves free range to loot the country’s ancient temples.

headline: Little Is Said About Google Glass at Developers Conference
text: 12:04 p.m. | Updated to reflect the role of Sergey Brin, Google’s co-founder, in a demonstration of Google Glass.

headline: Frog Once Used in Pregnancy Tests Spread Deadly Fungus
text: A species of frog that was used from the 1930s to the 1950s in human pregnancy tests is a carrier of a deadly amphibian disease that is now threatening hundreds of other species of frogs and salamanders.

headline: Third Point Sells Morgan Stanley Stake
text: Daniel S. Loeb has ended his engagement with Morgan Stanley.

headline: A Rise in Military Suicides
text: Military suicides hit an all-time high in 2012.

headline: Still Shooting After the End of War
text: Stacy Pearsall never wanted to stop being a combat photographer.

headline: The Wind Collector
text: This week, Merel Karhof, a 34-year-old Dutch designer who lives in London, set up a small, temporary factory in the Netherlands to make furniture with wind. For the project, called Windworks, she collaborated with the owners of two neighboring windmills in Zaanse Schans, in the province of North Holland: one, a sawmill that cut the wood used in her collection of chairs, stools and benches; the other, a paint mill that ground the minerals with which she dyed wool upholstery fabric produced through her own wind-powered knitting machine. Speaking by phone from the Netherlands, Ms. Karhof, who studied at the Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands and at the Royal College of Art in London, discussed the evolution of her interest in the invisible forces of nature.

headline: And the Best Part Is, No Grass to Mow
text: A houseboat in San Francisco sits in a small marina with 20 floating homes.

headline: Their Floating World
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Sarah and Kimo Bertram never imagined living in a floating house. But nearly three years ago, after being outbid on more conventional homes, Ms. Bertram spotted an ad on Craigslist offering a furnished houseboat for rent. On a lark, they checked it out.

headline: Owner Takes a Chunk Out of an Unofficial Community Garden
text: For years, the Children’s Magical Garden de Carmen Rubio on the Lower East Side has been known for the peach and nectarine trees that grow there and the roosters that roam the lot. Although the garden is not recognized by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, it has existed since 1982 with little official objection.

headline: Eat My Dust
text: For the allergy sufferer, there is truth to that adage linking April with cruelty. May isn’t much kinder.

headline: Heavy Metal Accessories
text: Kara Mann first became known for interiors with a subversive side when her former home in Chicago appeared in Metropolitan Home six years ago. “It was all dark, and it had a lot of Chrome Hearts pieces and Blackman Cruz skull lamps,” she said. “It was truly an expression of me. I don’t want things too pretty or too decorated — I like a twist.”

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. I have a turntable and a large collection of records. Do I need to remove them before showing my home to buyers?

headline: Where Basic Ingredients Rule
text: The town of Hudson, N.Y., is where people go to renovate Victorian houses, sell chunky raw-edged wood furniture and install restaurants in former blacksmith shops. Zakary Pelaccio, the chef behind the Fatty Crew group of restaurants, went down the third path with Fish & Game.

headline: Shopping for Heavy Metal Accessories
text: Kara Mann, an interior designer known for her Goth-inspired subversive side, goes shopping for heavy metal accessories.

headline: In Defense of an Impatiens Abuser
text: A selection of comments from readers of the Home section, drawn from letters and postings at nytimes.com, about Anne Raver’s article on a mysterious strain of downy mold killing one of the home gardener’s favorite annual flowers, Impatiens walleriana.

headline: Bedding Fit for a Dreamer
text: The Milanese designer Paola Navone is famous (at least in Europe) for mixing North African and Asian artisanal handicrafts into modern goods. But now her reputation is about to make an Atlantic crossing. She recently introduced an outdoor furniture collection for Janus et Cie, and she’s working on interiors for the Como Hotel in the South Beach district of Miami, which will be presented in the fall. This week, Anthropologie, the quirkily stylish lifestyle chain, will release what Ms. Navone has described as her “dream bedroom collection.” This 20-piece line includes bed linens, furniture, suitcases, lighting and accessories. Prices range from $10 for a mercury-glass mushroom to $4,200 for a four-poster bed. Information: (212) 343-7070 or anthropologie.com.

headline: Even Duchesses Have Tag Sales
text: Most people don’t associate bathrooms with patinated floor lamps that have carved bronze birds for feet. Then again, most people don’t live in a palace. In the early 1920s, Armand Albert Rateau, an Art Deco master, created furniture for the Liria Palace in Madrid for the apartments of the Duchess of Alba, María del Rosario de Silva y Gurtubay, who married the 17th Duke of Alba in 1920. The palace was damaged in the Spanish Civil War, and some of Rateau’s pieces are lost to time. Now, the House of Alba is selling the rest of her collection at Christie’s France. Among the seven Rateau pieces included in the May 23 sale are the lamps (estimated at about $1.95 million to $2.6 million each); a carved and gilded wood daybed (shown, $520,000 to $780,000); and a Carrara marble tub (about $195,000 to $260,000). If only we could all scrub like royalty. Information: christies.com.

headline: Wireless Accessories and More
text: From Friday through Sunday, Modernica will take 15 percent off all furniture, lighting, ceramics and garden accessories on its Web site, including items already on sale (a Case Study fiberglass rocker, originally $439, will be about $373; a George Nelson medium saucer Bubble lamp, originally $329, will be about $280). Use “FactorySale” as the code at checkout; modernica.net, (323) 933-0383.

headline: A Construction Set for Enterprising Adults
text: Paola Petrobelli grew up in Padua, Italy, only 30 miles from Venice and its celebrated glassmakers.

headline: Grading on the Curve
text: Pregnant women add to the conversation about who is wearing what, and how, on the red carpet.

headline: Pregnancy Takes a Turn on the Red Carpet
text: Last week, the most talked-about moment from the Met Gala, the annual black-tie event to benefit the museum’s Costume Institute, did not involve Anna Wintour, the host committee headlined by Rooney Mara and Beyoncé or Madonna going pantless.

headline: Swipe Away Photo Imperfections on a Smartphone
text: Not so many years ago, when photographers needed to adjust a photo, they’d have to spend time in the darkroom tinkering with equipment and chemicals. Then along came digital imagery and the magic of Photoshop, which brought photo manipulation out of the dark. Nowadays, smartphone apps can manipulate photos in myriad ways.

headline: Channeling the Flapper Girl
text: Slick.

headline: You Snooze, You Lose
text: Marc Jacobs in his new jammies uniform is the belle of the ball. Rihanna, Rita Ora and Elisa Sednaoui, in pajamas on the red carpet, obviously were invited. Why not you?

headline: Pakistan: Imran Khan Seeks Vote Inquiry
text: Imran Khan, the politician and former cricket star, gave a three-day ultimatum to the national election commission on Wednesday to look into his political party’s claims of vote-rigging in the contests for 25 parliamentary seats during last week’s general election. Mr. Khan warned that his party would start countrywide protests if the grievances were not addressed. Most of the accusations of voter fraud concern election districts in Lahore and Karachi. Election officials say repolling of 43 election stations in a wealthy Karachi district will take place on Sunday. According to the latest official tally, the party of Nawaz Sharif, the presumptive prime minister, leads with 124 seats in the 272-seat assembly. The Pakistan Peoples Party, the former governing party, won 31 seats, while Mr. Khan’s party won 27. The counts for 11 seats have yet to be officially verified.

headline: Scene City: Park Gala on a Pier
text: Friends of the High Line held a benefit that honored Ethan Hawke and other supporters.

headline: A Party That’s Outgrown Its Park
text: Strangely enough, the Friends of the High Line benefit did not take place on the High Line, but at the semi-abandoned Pier 57 across the street. Blame it on the park’s success.

headline: Egypt: Reports of Embassy Plots
text: Three Egyptian men arrested last week and accused of plotting terrorist acts in Egypt sought to carry out suicide attacks against the United States and French Embassies, the state news media said Wednesday. One of the men had been deported from Iran and another from Algeria for engaging in militant activities. All three were imprisoned in Egypt in 2009, but broke out during the uprising that toppled President Hosni Mubarak in 2011. The men, who the government says have ties to Al Qaeda, said they planned to attack the French Embassy in revenge for France’s military intervention against militants in Mali, the state news media said. After their arrests were announced Saturday, a Western official identified the United States Embassy as one of their targets.

headline: A World and an Artist Transformed
text: A few words of warning to the Hamptons socialites and view-to-the-ocean magnates who mingle with the artist Eric Fischl on their summer rounds: He’s watching you.

headline: Derby Winner Orb Draws the Rail for the Preakness
text: Orb, the Kentucky Derby winner, drew the inside post for the Preakness Stakes on Saturday, but does it matter?

headline: N.B.A. Owners Vote to Keep Kings in Sacramento
text: In a decision that may end a long struggle over the Sacramento Kings, N.B.A. owners voted on Wednesday to prevent the team from moving to Seattle.

headline: On Capitol Hill, Sanford Picks Up Where He Left Off
text: In some ways, Mark Sanford, the newly elected Republican representative from South Carolina, felt as if he had never left Capitol Hill.

headline: The White House’s Benghazi E-Mails
text: The White House released 100 pages of e-mail exchanges among top officials as they negotiated talking points about the attacks in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: Upfronts 2013: CBS
text: The Times's Bill Carter discusses CBS's programming, after the broadcaster unveiled its plans to advertisers.

headline: Delivering KFC by Tunnel, Not Too Fast but Satisfying
text: GAZA CITY — The French fries arrive soggy, the chicken having long since lost its crunch. A 12-piece bucket goes for about $27 here — more than twice the $11.50 it costs just across the border in Egypt.

headline: From Jungle to Museum and Back?
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s recent decision to return two statues to Cambodia may put pressure on other museums that own works said to be from the same 10th-century Khmer temple, Prasat Chen.

headline: A Tribute to Boston Bombing Victims, a Step at a Time
text: BOSTON — This city is full of history, but mostly devoid of outsize monuments — there is no Statue of Liberty, no Space Needle. A blinking LED sign for Citgo might be the most prominent landmark in the popular consciousness here, while the city’s storied past is, for the most part, embedded more quietly in graves, buildings and statues visible only when one happens to be near them.

headline: U.N. Calls for Political Transition in Syria
text: UNITED NATIONS — As the bloodletting continued unabated in Syria, the 193-member General Assembly passed a nonbinding resolution on Wednesday calling for a political transition to end the civil war there, putting the onus on the government of President Bashar al-Assad to stop the killing.

headline: Doctor Starts His Life Term in Grisly Abortion Clinic Case
text: PHILADELPHIA — Dr. Kermit Gosnell was sentenced on Wednesday to life in prison without parole for the murder of a baby born alive in a botched abortion, who prosecutors said would have survived if the doctor had not “snipped” its neck with scissors.

headline: Suddenly, It’s Woodson’s Fault
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — On the day he inherited the Knicks — the Linsanity, the insanity and the rest of it — Mike Woodson was handed a singular challenge: get Carmelo Anthony to play like Carmelo Anthony. Everything else would fall into place.

headline: After Bangladesh, Seeking New Sources
text: SEMARANG, Indonesia — Bennett Model helped pioneer the exporting of garments from China in 1975, the year before Mao Zedong died, and ever since, his New York fashion company has searched for other countries, from Guatemala to Vietnam to Indonesia, capable of supplying top retailers like Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman Marcus.

headline: Training for Mass Production
text: A national training center for seamstresses in Indonesia helps produce thousands of highly trained workers for the country.

headline: Bid for Cash by Tesla Motors Is Likely to Energize Company and Critics Alike
text: Tesla Motors announced plans on Wednesday to tap the markets for more cash, a move that will buy it time to meet its ambitious goals but will also fuel debate over its prospects.

headline: Mexico: Official Whose Daughter Forced Restaurant Closing Is Fired
text: The head of the federal consumer protection agency was fired Wednesday, weeks after his daughter got inspectors to briefly shut down a restaurant that refused her the table she wanted. Four officials from the agency had been suspended after the episode became a Twitter sensation highlighting the deep sense of entitlement of the privileged in Mexico. The father, Humberto Benítez Treviño, had defied calls to resign, but President Enrique Peña Nieto, who had promised more accountability from his government, decided to fire him. A government statement said that while Mr. Benitez Treviño did not play a role in the inspection that led to the closing, the case had damaged the image and prestige of the agency.

headline: Jets Know Bizarre: Balky Knee Forces Garrard to Retire
text: The Jets had a plan. They would sign a veteran quarterback, which they did. They would draft a dynamic rookie, which they also did. And they would put both in an honest-to-goodness competition, challenging the incumbent for the right to start the season opener.

headline: Acting Chief Wins Confirmation to Run Medicare and Medicaid
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday approved President Obama’s nominee to run Medicare and Medicaid, Marilyn B. Tavenner, providing the agency with its first confirmed chief in six and a half years.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Signs Bangladesh Safety Plan
text: Abercrombie & Fitch said on Wednesday that it had signed on to a landmark plan to improve factory safety in Bangladesh, becoming just the second American company to join an accord that more than two dozen European retailers and brands have embraced.

headline: Weighing Bid for City Hall, Weiner Is Said to Be Struggling to Fill Out His Team
text: In a city with no shortage of political strategists and pollsters, Anthony D. Weiner has long stood out as a do-it-yourself candidate, known for trusting his own instincts.

headline: Nigeria’s President Gives Military More Power in Struggle Against Militants
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Struggling to contain a smoldering Islamist insurgency, the president of Nigeria, Africa’s most populous country, has ordered in more troops and granted the military more powers to arrest, more authority to seize “any building or structure” and more leeway in “any area of terrorist operation.”

headline: Inquiry on Potential Oil Price Manipulation Intensifies
text: When a BP rig exploded in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010, Richard Fry, a top executive at a trucking company, said he noticed something strange about the oil market. Prices spiked quickly, he recalled, and they took much longer to drop.

headline: Media Companies Aim to Woo Advertisers and Latinos
text: Hispanic media companies continued to aggressively target advertisers this week with some major announcements from Fox Hispanic Media executives kicking off Wednesday’s upfront presentations.

headline: At 41, Jagr Is Bruins’ Elder Statesman
text: BOSTON — There are flecks of gray in Jaromir Jagr’s playoff beard. He turned 41 three months ago, and he is the only player in the Eastern Conference semifinal series between the Boston Bruins and the Rangers who was alive in 1973, when the two franchises last met in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

headline: Childhood Friends Battle in Western Conference Playoffs
text: LOS ANGELES — There are many intense rivalries in the Stanley Cup playoffs, but few have a competition that dates back to puberty, PlayStation and pond hockey.

headline: Thomas M. Messer, Museum Director Who Gave Guggenheim Cachet, Dies at 93
text: Thomas M. Messer, whose leadership of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum over more than a quarter-century established its place among the world’s great museums of modern art, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Favorite in Preakness Will Start on the Rail
text: BALTIMORE — He is the Kentucky Derby champion, after all, so Orb’s installation Wednesday as the even-money favorite to run away with the 138th running of the Preakness Stakes is hardly surprising. Two weeks ago, he caught a sloppy track for the first time but still came from the clouds to effortlessly defeat 18 rivals.

headline: Knicks Face Elimination
text: William C. Rhoden of The Times talks with the Knicks coach Mike Woodson about Game 5 — an elimination game for the Knicks — against the Pacers on Thursday.

headline: Driver’s Seat
text: I got a letter the other day from Joe Arpaio — Sheriff Joe Arpaio, that is, the sheriff of Maricopa County, Ariz., scourge of undocumented immigrants and of anyone who might look like one. He was, remarkably enough, asking me for money to combat an effort to recall him from the office he has held for 20 self-aggrandizing years.

headline: Shareholders Denied Access to JPMorgan Vote Results
text: When it comes to shareholder votes, the running tallies are a closely guarded secret. Only a handful of parties get a peek into how these corporate battles are shaping up.

headline: Melanoma Treatment Harnesses Immune System to Combat Cancer Cells
text: Cancer researchers are growing increasingly enthusiastic about harnessing the body’s own immune system to fight tumors. And new research shows that two drugs that use this approach may be even better than one.

headline: Raucous Cheers for Iran’s Wrestlers in Grand Central Terminal
text: Cheered on by a raucous crowd waving flags and chanting, a team of Iranian wrestlers defeated the United States, 6-1, in an exhibition match staged in New York’s Grand Central Terminal on Wednesday.

headline: Tired of Bad News, Rutgers Makes News With Its New Athletic Director
text: Four years ago, Rutgers made an unconventional choice when it selected Tim Pernetti, a television executive, to lead its athletic department.

text: DENVER

headline: The Real I.R.S. Scandal
text: WASHINGTON

headline: USA Network Turns to Vignettes to Draw Viewers and Advertisers to Its Daytime Schedule
text: A popular show that takes place on the stoop of a brownstone in Brooklyn is to get national television exposure as a cable channel seeks new ways to engage viewers and woo advertisers.

headline: The Migrant Cash Lifeline
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Scandalous vs. Scandal Lust
text: I have watched in recent days as a parade of conservatives have used specific and real governmental missteps to justify their wide-ranging paranoia and irrational hostilities. “Aha!”

headline: On the Plus Side ...
text: Let’s try to come up with some positive thoughts about the recent political fortunes of the Obama White House:

headline: D’Amato Puts Money on Democrat in Race for New York Mayor
text: He was the rough-and-ready boss of the New York State Republican Party for a quarter-century, the senator from the suburbs who helped make “liberal” a dirty word in American politics.

headline: Phipps Family’s Plan Breeds Success
text: The Phipps family stable is half the size that it once was but still spends more than $4 million annually maintaining a band of mares, raising their foals into racehorses and paying exorbitant fees for the mares to couple with the finest stallions. Over nearly a century, the family has invested hundreds of millions of dollars in the horse business.

headline: Mandela Fades Amid Battles Over Who Will Claim Legacy
text: JOHANNESBURG — “Smile!” the visitor implored, an edge of forced bonhomie in his voice, as he held up a cellphone camera to take a snapshot.

headline: Baffling Rise in Suicides Plagues the U.S. Military
text: After Specialist Freddy Hook, a medic with the Army’s 82nd Airborne Division, killed himself in 2010, the trail of possible causes seemed long.

headline: After Attacking The A.P., a Peace Offering
text: After coming under scorching bipartisan criticism for secretly going through the phone records of reporters at The Associated Press in a leak investigation, the Obama administration now says it supports a law that might have prevented this outrageous conduct.

headline: Pension Predators
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has done retirees and military veterans a great service by ordering New York’s top banking regulator to investigate “pension advance” firms that persuade customers to sign over all or part of their monthly pensions in exchange for immediate cash payments. The payments, advertised as advances, are, in fact, cleverly disguised loans that can carry ruinously high interest rates and eventually strip older citizens of their meager assets.

headline: Take Politics Away From the I.R.S.
text: President Obama’s decision on Wednesday to dismiss the acting commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service was a largely symbolic demonstration of anger and authority. The official, Steven Miller, was not directly involved in the misguided decision to single out Tea Party groups for special scrutiny in granting tax exemptions. What is more important is Mr. Obama’s promise to clarify the extremely vague tax laws, which are the root cause of the problems in both the I.R.S. and the political system.
