headline: Long Journey to College, but I Was Never Alone
text: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student from New Delhi, is part of “The Choice” class that includes student-bloggers from Nairobi, Kenya; Topeka, Kan.; Seattle; Rogers, Ark.; Las Vegas; New York City; and Hunting Valley, Ohio. Her final post is below. — Tanya Abrams

headline: Balloon Animals and Snow White
text: Images from new exhibitions of works by Jeff Koons and Paul McCarthy.

headline: Chilean Judge Upholds Manslaughter Charges Linked to 2010 Tsunami
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — A judge dismissed an appeal to suspend involuntary manslaughter charges against four government officials accused of failing to issue a tsunami alert after the 8.8-magnitude earthquake that struck Chile in 2010.

headline: What Elliott Management Sees in NetApp
text: What does Elliott Management see in NetApp Inc.? A lot of potential to improve a stagnant stock price.

headline: An Intrepid Foundling and Her Unlikely Mentor
text: Guy Pearce is an award-winning actor with dozens of film and television roles on his résumé, but in “33 Postcards” he is eclipsed by an unknown young actress named Zhu Lin, whose charming performance gives this sweet if not very credible film its heart.

headline: Juvenile Inmates Found to Be at No Greater Risk for Prison Rape
text: Youth advocates have long argued that juveniles incarcerated in adult prisons and jails are at heightened risk for rape and other forms of sexual abuse because of their age. But a government survey released on Thursday found that juveniles did not report significantly more sexual victimization than adult inmates.

headline: Just Us Girls, They Thought. Oops.
text: One of the funnier television comedies in recent years has been “The League,” a bawdy FX series about a fantasy football league. Fans of that show might expect a lot of laughs from “Black Rock,” since it was written by a “League” cast member, Mark Duplass, and stars another, Katie Aselton, who also directed it.

headline: Clip: ‘Pieta’
text: A scene from "Pieta," directed by Kim Ki-duk.

headline: In a Vicious Sadist, the Faintest Glimmer of Soul
text: Morally cunning and with a tone as black as pitch, “Pieta,” the 18th film from the South Korean director Kim Ki-duk, is a deeply unnerving revenge movie in which redemption is dangled like a cat toy before a cougar. The beast in question is Kang-do (Lee Jung-jin), a merciless bag man for a powerful moneylender who cripples slum-dwelling debtors to collect on their insurance claims. As cold to himself as to his clients, he lives in a comfortless flat where the entrails from the previous night’s chicken dinner still decorate the bathroom floor. So when a strange woman (Cho Min-soo) begins to stalk him, claiming to be the mother who abandoned him long ago, Kang-do barely hesitates: he rapes her.

headline: Performing From Space, Canada’s Low-Orbit Star
text: OTTAWA — As far as YouTube hits go, Canada’s contribution has not yet approached the popularity of South Korea’s “Gangnam Style.” And perhaps because of the limitations of weightlessness, the music video lacked any dance moves at all.

headline: Out of Necessity, Yanks Call Up Betances
text: Before the 2012 season, Dellin Betances was a top 50 prospect in baseball and one of the Yankees’ most promising young players. But after a season in which he posted a 6.44 earned run average, Betances dropped off top prospect lists and was thought to be far away from making the majors.

headline: Keeping Kosher in Nigeria, a Tiny but Fervent Minority
text: Are the Ibo people of Nigeria a lost tribe of Israel? A longstanding tradition among the Ibo says they are, and points to similarities in Ibo and Jewish cultures: a prescribed day of rest, circumcision (male, that is), the prohibition of pork. And now some Ibo have embraced Judaism, considering it the religion of their ancestors.

headline: As Japan Courts Growth, Europe Keeps Up Its Love Affair With Austerity
text: BERLIN — For years, Japan and Europe have been the sick men of the world economy. This week, their paths diverged.

headline: New Fracking Rules Proposed for U.S. Land
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday issued a new set of proposed rules governing hydraulic fracturing for oil and gas on public lands, moving further to address industry concerns about the costs and reporting burdens of federal regulation.

headline: Battle of the Bullhorns as a Wind Project Beckons
text: From the initial proposal in 2001, the Cape Wind project — 130 turbines across a 24-square-mile stretch of Nantucket Sound — has stirred furious dissent. The installation would be the nation’s first offshore wind farm, reducing the fossil fuel emissions around coastal Massachusetts and helping to develop a clean-energy industry. But residents howl that the project would despoil a pristine seascape, damage fishing grounds, foul ferry and air traffic and even disrupt the religious practices of the Wampanoag tribe.

headline: Greece: Teachers Abandon Strike Plan
text: Greek high school teachers on Thursday called off a planned strike after the government essentially banned it by enacting an emergency law that threatened strikers with arrest or dismissal. The teachers were unable to attract widespread political and public support for the planned Friday walkout, and after the government’s move a vote by the teachers failed to secure a majority. Only 23 percent voted in favor of joining the strike. The two main labor unions also refused to back the proposed strike, instead staging a four-hour walkout on Thursday that disrupted public services and flights. The teachers object to the government’s plans to increase their working hours, fearing the move will lead to job cutbacks. Amnesty International condemned the government’s “blanket prohibition on the teachers’ right to strike,” describing the use of an emergency law as “unnecessary and disproportionate” and a human rights violation.

headline: Sudden Impulse, and a Warrior Is Born
text: At the end of 2008, Tim DeChristopher, a young economics student at the University of Utah, strolled into a federal auction of oil and gas drilling rights to prime Utah wilderness. Although he was opposed to the auction, which he considered “illegal and unethical,” he had no plans to disrupt it, but when he was mistakenly handed a paddle, he chose to use it, knowing that he had no way to pay for the parcels he would eventually win.

headline: A Benz With a Virtual Chauffeur
text: HAMBURG, Germany — Hangar doors slid open to reveal a fleet of white Mercedes-Benz vehicles arrayed on a rain-slicked runway.

headline: That Elusive Seat at the U.N. Table
text: The United Nations currently has 193 member nations. The dream of, and the work toward, member status for Palestinians is the subject of “State 194,” an intelligent, evenhanded Israeli documentary by Dan Setton about a two-state solution for coexistence. Mr. Setton, a Peabody Award- and Emmy-winning director and producer, was inspired by a 2009 radio speech by Prime Minister Salam Fayyad of the Palestinian Authority, who left office last month.

headline: The Morning Nine
text: The horses for the 138th running of the Preakness Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Both have also selected their win-place-show horses for the race. The morning-line odds were set by Frank Carulli of Pimlico Race Course.

headline: Clips, Quips and Snips: A Wrap-Up of Upfronts
text: HERE is a look back at some highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the annual upfronts week, which took place from Monday through Thursday as television executives offered Madison Avenue previews of their schedules for the 2013-14 season.

headline: Jockey Is Atop the Favorite, and All of Racing
text: BALTIMORE — It was a claiming race with a modest purse of $30,000, but Joel Rosario strode into the paddock of Belmont Park last Sunday with the laser focus that has made him the top jockey in America. He was riding the mare Delightful Dawn for the first time, but had watched video replays of her races and knew she liked to stalk the leaders and try to get past them in the stretch.

headline: Uzbek Man in Idaho Is Held in Bomb Plot
text: WASHINGTON — Federal authorities arrested an Uzbek man on Thursday in Boise, Idaho, on charges that he provided a foreign terrorist group with help in building an explosive device.

headline: A Last Stand for Nature Against Mighty Odds
text: The back-to-basics title of “Elemental” seems to herald another pious lesson about a world out of balance, but the filmmakers, Gayatri Roshan and Emmanuel Vaughan-Lee, have made a documentary that is more about environmentalists than about environmentalism. Following an indigenous Canadian activist, a crusading government official in India and a struggling inventor, this sensitively scored film complicates the typical missionary’s-progress arc by acknowledging its would-be heroes’ weaknesses and the day-to-day obstacles to doing good.

headline: Concerns Arise on U.S. Effort to Allow Internet ‘Wiretaps’
text: Surveillance can be a tricky affair in the Internet age.

headline: Apple Fights Back in Antitrust Case Over E-Book Prices
text: WASHINGTON — Don’t mess with the legacy of Steve Jobs.

headline: Syria Begins to Break Apart Under Pressure From War
text: CAIRO — The black flag of jihad flies over much of northern Syria. In the center of the country, pro-government militias and Hezbollah fighters battle those who threaten their communities. In the northeast, the Kurds have effectively carved out an autonomous zone.

headline: Obama Tells Pentagon Leaders Sexual Assault Is ‘Shameful’
text: WASHINGTON — With arrests in the military continuing to shadow its program to combat sexual harassment, President Obama summoned the Pentagon’s senior leaders to the White House on Thursday, telling them that the levels of sexual assault across the armed services were a disgrace that undermined the trust essential for the military to carry out its mission effectively.

headline: Debating the Legal Basis for the War on Terror
text: WASHINGTON — A top Pentagon official said Thursday that the evolving war against Al Qaeda was likely to continue “at least 10 to 20 years” and urged Congress not to modify the statute that provides its legal basis.

headline: Aiming for the Top, Again
text: On Wall Street, the wheel of fortune can spin around and around, from enormous cash bonuses and luxurious perks one year to the unemployment line the next.

headline: Outrunning Assassins, Sulky Daughter in Tow
text: For his first film in English, the German director Philipp Stölzl travels a long way from the cheeky flirtations of “Young Goethe in Love” to “Erased,” a bearable if unremarkable composite of the “Taken” movies and “Three Days of the Condor.”

headline: Gunshots on Warm Spring Evenings
text: NEWARK — A FEW Saturdays ago, at the early evening hour when children linger outside to wring the last fun they can from the day, a series of gunshots split the air near the corner of Chadwick and Avon Avenues. Everyone scattered. After the cops arrived and taped off the intersection and determined that no one at the scene had been hit, the street slowly stirred back to life.

headline: Learning From Litigation
text: LOS ANGELES — MUCH of the discussion over the Affordable Care Act has focused on whether it will bring down health care costs. Less attention has been paid to another goal of the act: improving patient safety. Each year tens of thousands of people die, and hundreds of thousands more are injured, as a result of medical error.

headline: How Latin Culture Got More Gay
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — BRAZIL is potentially poised to become the third and largest country in Latin America to legalize same-sex marriage, following a judicial order on Tuesday. Argentina was the first, in 2010, after the government brushed aside objections from Cardinal Jorge Bergoglio of Buenos Aires, now the pope. The Uruguayan legislature followed suit last month. Mexico City has allowed such unions since 2010, and the Mexican state of Quintana Roo since 2011.

headline: Stacks of Bibles, and Graphic Novels
text: To readers of philosophy, “logos” means reason and rational argument. To readers of the Gospels, it is the word of God made incarnate in Jesus Christ. But for seekers of all kinds on the Upper East Side, Logos is also a cozy bookshop with a lumpy recliner and a black cat named Boo Boo, who sleeps near a stack of Bibles.

headline: Can Obama Save Turkey From a Syrian Quagmire?
text: WASHINGTON — WHEN Turkey’s prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, met President Obama at the White House on Thursday, the most pressing topic was the war in Syria. Turkey has not faced a threat on this scale since Stalin demanded territory from the Turks in 1945.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Logos Bookstore
text: Logos, on the Upper East Side, caters to readers looking for religious texts, fiction, holiday cards, or chats about life and faith.

headline: Foxconn Audit Finds a Workweek Still Too Long
text: Foxconn Technology, the company that manufactures Apple’s popular iPads and iPhones, has made substantial progress toward improving safety and other working conditions at three of its Chinese plants dedicated to making Apple products. But it has not yet achieved the most difficult goal: reducing the average workweek to the maximum allowed by Chinese law, a global monitoring group said on Thursday.

headline: When Governments Go Bad
text: Government, Clinton Rossiter once wrote, is something like fire: “Under control, it is the most useful of servants; out of control, it is a ravaging tyrant.”

headline: The Jets’ Quarterback Vortex Has Sanchez’s Head Spinning
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — David Garrard’s locker contained a football, a couple of pairs of sandals and some deodorant. A few workout shirts hung on a bar, and a Jets hat rested on a shelf. It looked as if he had stepped away for a few minutes, to take a shower or answer a phone call, and not wandered straight into retirement.

headline: Russia Sends More Advanced Missiles to Aid Assad in Syria
text: WASHINGTON — Russia has sent advanced antiship cruise missiles to Syria, a move that illustrates the depth of its support for the Syrian government led by President Bashar al-Assad, American officials said Thursday.

headline: A President Tries to Regain His Footing
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama was in the middle of a careful answer to a question about whether anyone in the White House knew that the Internal Revenue Service was targeting conservative groups, when the rain started to fall. Intermittently, at first; then a steady patter.

headline: Cold War Malaise at Launch Control
text: It sounded like an alternative ending to “Dr. Strangelove,” subtitled: “How They Grew Careless Managing Nuclear Missiles.” Seventeen Air Force officers assigned to launch control for nuclear-tipped Minuteman missiles were removed from their posts last month for violating safety and code protection procedures and showing poor attitudes.

headline: Scandal Machine
text: When politicians want to turn scandals into metaphors, actual details of wrongdoing or incompetence no longer matter. In fact, the details of the troubles swirling around the White House this week are bluntly contradicting Republicans who want to combine them into a seamless narrative of tyrannical government on the rampage.

headline: The Murky World of Hospital Prices
text: Last week, the federal government made public a vast trove of information on the list prices charged by hospitals for a large array of procedures commonly performed on hospitalized patients. It was a good start toward providing greater transparency in hospital billing, which has long been shrouded in secrecy. But it fell short of providing full information that patients need to make informed decisions about which hospitals to use and which insurance to buy.

headline: A Lower Standard for Drunken Driving
text: It is surprising how few drinks can impair a driver’s judgment. A report from the National Transportation Safety Board estimates that alcohol-impaired driving contributes to thousands of deaths and tens of thousands of serious injuries each year. It is right to urge states to reduce that toll by lowering the allowable blood-alcohol concentration for drivers from 0.08 percent to 0.05 percent.

headline: Too Drunk to Drive
text: Is lowering the blood alcohol limit the best way to minimize traffic fatalities?

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

Genetic Testing for Women at Risk of Cancer

text: To the Editor:

headline: Trial on Guatemalan Civil War Carnage Leaves Out U.S. Role
text: MEXICO CITY — In 1999, President Bill Clinton went to Guatemala and apologized. Just two weeks earlier, a United Nations truth commission found Guatemalan security forces responsible for more than 90 percent of the human rights violations committed during the country’s long civil war.

headline: A Prudent Move by Rose, if Not a Popular One
text: CHICAGO — The Bulls’ exit from the playoffs with a 3-point loss to the Miami Heat will only add fuel to Chicago’s latest sports furor. Much of the city is livid that Derrick Rose did not return to the court after a year of rehabilitation from knee surgery.

headline: Rebuilding of Mali Faces Daunting Obstacles, Despite Outside Aid
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The outpouring of support may be more a sign of nervousness than altruism.

headline: Weiner’s Wife Didn’t Disclose Consulting Work She Did While Serving in State Dept.
text: The State Department, under Secretary Hillary Rodham Clinton, created an arrangement for her longtime aide and confidante Huma Abedin to work for private clients as a consultant while serving as a top adviser in the department.

headline: G.O.P., Energized, Weighs How Far to Take Inquiries
text: WASHINGTON — The investigations ensnaring the White House have unified the Republican Party, energized a political base shattered by election losses and given common purpose to lawmakers divided over a legislative agenda.

headline: Veeck’s Son Dusts Off Old Idea and Crowdsources the Umpiring
text: ST. PAUL — The left-handed batter tried to check his swing in the first inning. In a reflex honed through thousands of innings behind the plate, Dwight Childs, a catcher for the St. Paul Saints of the independent American Association, pointed up the third-base line, appealing for a swinging strike call.

headline: Nerdy Passions of the Stand-Up Patriot
text: As the cultural status of stand-up comics has risen, these restless gypsies who moved from hotels and coffee houses to comedy clubs and alternative rooms have migrated in growing numbers to the theater. One pioneer is Colin Quinn, who after two solo shows on Broadway (the first in 1998), now mounts off Broadway a pleasingly funny amble through American history in “Unconstitutional.”

headline: Love Away From the Battlefield
text: The clash of armies is not to be heard during “Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812,” the vibrant, transporting new musical adapted from a potent slice of Tolstoy’s “War and Peace.” True, Napoleon is nominally present, presiding with a stern semi-smile over the proceedings from within a copy of a Jacques-Louis David portrait. But the roiling sounds of battle do not intrude on the romantic drama unfolding before us in Dave Malloy’s freshly imagined pop opera, which opened on Thursday night at a custom-built cabaret called Kazino, in the meatpacking district.

headline: Dangerous When Leaked
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — You can always get on my good side by stretching DR. STRANGELOVE across the middle of a grid. Oddly, the name of the Peter Sellers character hasn’t been seen since 1988, so we might as well consider it sort of a debut. It’s crossed by SILICON VALLEY, another debut, and the other two 13s include “DEATH IN VENICE,” another favorite of mine and POST-MODERNISM. We’re off to a good start on this Josh Knapp puzzle.

headline: 16 Accused of Smuggling Cigarettes Worth Millions
text: One of the men had once lived in the same Brooklyn building as the personal secretary of a senior Hamas member, the authorities said. Another was something of a father figure to the terrorist who fatally shot at a van full of yeshiva students on the Brooklyn Bridge. And a third is said to have once received an investment from Omar Abdel Rahman, the so-called blind sheik, who is now serving a life sentence for a terrorism plot.

headline: Man May Face Jail for Refusing to Testify in Bomb Case, Again
text: A 24-year-old self-described Brooklyn anarchist may be headed to jail after refusing on Thursday for the second time to testify before a grand jury believed to be examining the explosion of a homemade bomb that damaged an armed-forces recruitment center in Times Square in 2008.

headline: De Blasio Offers Plan to Help Immigrants Assimilate
text: Bill de Blasio, the New York City public advocate and a Democratic mayoral candidate, unveiled a set of initiatives on Thursday that he said were intended to help integrate more undocumented immigrants into the mainstream.

headline: Case Casts Harsh Light on Family Art Business
text: For years, high-end auctions at Sotheby’s and Christie’s have featured a familiar tableau — members of the Nahmad family spread out in the front row, sometimes six or seven people across. Little known outside the art market but a pivotal force within it, the family, whose worth is estimated at $3 billion, has amassed one of the largest collections of Impressionist and Modernist art in the world, including one of the largest holdings of Picasso in private hands. They did it with a purchasing style that has never been subtle: they chase as many as a third of the works offered in an evening and then warehouse them for years until it is the right time to sell.

headline: Quinn Camp Excoriating Thompson on D’Amato
text: Early in the mayoral race, Christine C. Quinn, the New York City Council speaker and presumed Democratic front-runner, has tended to stay above the fray, sometimes defending herself but rarely initiating an attack.

headline: For M.T.A., Flood Plan Is Still a Work in Progress
text: Inside a crew room at the new South Ferry subway station, once flooded wall to wall with the waters of Hurricane Sandy, transit officials on Thursday offered a sobering progress report on a system that continues to feel the storm’s effects.

headline: Trial Opens in the Killing of a Young Basketball Star
text: In the final moments of her young life, she danced in the playground next to her apartment building with her big sister and friends, joyfully oblivious to the bloody turf fights roiling from block to block all around her.

headline: Lawyer Criticizes Brooklyn Prosecutor Over TV Show
text: A decision by the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, to let his office be the subject of a six-part CBS News series has prompted another volley of criticism — this time from a lawyer complaining that the show, “Brooklyn D.A.,” would prejudice prospective jurors when his client goes on trial.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Scientists Agree Overwhelmingly on Global Warming. Why Doesn’t the Public Know That?
text: THE HAGUE — Most climate scientists agree that global warming is caused by human activity, according to a new survey of published papers on climate science.

headline: Missouri: Diocese Settles Abuse Case
text: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph has settled a lawsuit for $600,000 brought by the family of a girl who was 2 years old when Rev. Shawn Ratigan took pornographic pictures of her in 2006. The diocese discovered hundreds of lewd photos of young girls on Father Ratigan’s laptop in 2010, and the case involving the 2-year-old is one of several civil suits against the priest and the diocese brought by the girls and their families. Father Ratigan pleaded guilty last year and is awaiting sentencing. His bishop, Robert W. Finn, was convicted on a misdemeanor charge of failing to report suspected child abuse to authorities.

headline: Fecal Matter Found in Public Pools
text: More than half of water samples from about 150 public swimming pools in Atlanta contained traces of fecal matter, a level of contamination that is most likely similar to levels across the country, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found in a study.

headline: Louisiana: 2 Arrested in Shootings at New Orleans Parade
text: The police in New Orleans arrested two brothers and charged them both with 20 counts of attempted murder in connection with a shooting spree at a parade on Sunday that left 20 people wounded, 3 of them in critical condition. Akein Scott, 19, was arrested late Wednesday night and Shawn Scott, 24, was arrested on Thursday morning. The police also arrested and charged four others, ages 19 to 32, for providing “comfort and aid” to Akein Scott after investigators identified him as the likely gunman. The police said that the younger brother was a member of a gang, and several news outlets reported that he had been targeting a rival gang member from another neighborhood, who is recovering from bullet wounds.  Akein Scott was already out on bail for gun and drug possession charges. His bail on the attempted murder charges was set at $10 million.

headline: House Votes Again to Repeal Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — One by one, they queued up in the aisles of the House of Representatives, eager for their one minute to unload on President Obama’s signature legislative achievement.

headline: Urging Government Action on Water, Roads and Power in Texas
text: Touting Texas’ low taxes and light regulations, Gov. Rick Perry has relished trying to poach jobs from other states. In February, he described building a business in California as “next to impossible.” Last month, he warned Illinois entrepreneurs to “get out while there’s still time.”

headline: Two Congressmen Invite Texans From Both Parties to Breakfast
text: Kevin Brady and Pete Gallego have a lot in common. They are both Texans. They entered the State Legislature together in 1991. And each now serves in the United States Congress.

headline: Eclipsing D.C. in Home Stretch of Legislature
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: Teetering Knicks Gain Foothold
text: Elimination hovered over the Knicks, menacingly, like the cartoon version of death, waving his pointed sickle, threatening their postseason existence. The end seemed near Thursday night, with only the details to be determined and the last rites recited.

headline: Bipartisan House Group Reaches Preliminary Immigration Deal
text: A bipartisan group in the House working on an overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws reached a deal in principle Thursday evening, aides said. The group plans to introduce its bill in June.

headline: On Overtime Rush, Bruins Slip Past Rangers
text: BOSTON — Henrik Lundqvist held off a Bruins overtime barrage for more than 15 minutes, kicking out shots left and right, hearing vulcanized rubber clanging off the goal posts behind him. Finally, at 15 minutes 40 seconds of the extra session, he was beaten by Brad Marchand.

headline: Man in Much-Viewed Web Video Is Arrested in Connection With New Jersey Killing
text: A hitchhiker who became an Internet sensation early this year when he used a hatchet to hit a man who had struck a utility worker with his car was arrested on Thursday night, on charges that he killed a man in his home near Elizabeth, N.J., on Sunday, the authorities said.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Seeking a Milestone, Pettitte Instead Joins a Long List of Injured Yankees
text: At some point, the Yankees’ rash of injuries will reach the point of absurdity. Perhaps Thursday was the night.

headline: Benfica: A Curse to Rival the Bambino’s
text: It is not quite the Curse of the Bambino, but the hoodoo that the Hungarian coach Bela Guttmann put on Benfica in the early 1960s was alive and well on Wednesday when the Portuguese club lost to Chelsea in the Europa Cup final — its seventh consecutive loss in a continental championship match.

headline: Word of the Day | notoriety
text: notoriety •\ˌno-tə-ˈri-ə-te\• noun

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 17
text: “It is not that Syria is melting down — it has melted down. So much has changed between the different parties that I can’t imagine it all going back into one piece.”

headline: Corrections: May 17, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Warhol Painting Is the Star of a Modest Auction
text: After the historic $495 million sale of postwar and contemporary art at Christie’s, there was considerable curiosity surrounding Phillips’s far more modest one on Thursday evening.

headline: Some Relief for Smith, From Critics and Slump
text: A warm ovation greeted J. R. Smith when he checked into Game 5 on Thursday with about five minutes left in the first quarter, but there was always a sense that the tenor could change quickly, and boos would re-emerge, if Smith’s current trend continued plummeting downward.

headline: Lawmakers Show Concerns About Google’s New Glasses
text: Eight members of Congress on Thursday formally demanded that Google address a range of privacy concerns about its new wearable technology device, Google Glass.

headline: Concussion Sidelines Pacers’ Hill
text: Pacers point guard George Hill flew on the team plane to New York and participated in a shootaround on Thursday morning. But 90 minutes before Game 5, the team announced he was out with a concussion — a potentially pivotal turn of events in the Eastern Conference semifinal matchup with the Knicks.

headline: Steve Jobs’s Widow Steps Onto Philanthropic Stage
text: Marlene Castro knew the tall blonde woman only as Laurene, her mentor. They met every few weeks in a rough Silicon Valley neighborhood the year that Ms. Castro was applying to college, and they e-mailed often, bonding over conversations about Ms. Castro’s difficult childhood. Without Laurene’s help, Ms. Castro said, she might not have become the first person in her family to graduate from college.

headline: Marchand Feels Pain in the Morning and Inflicts It at Night
text: BOSTON — For a good hour Thursday, Bruins fans were seriously worried about Brad Marchand’s status for Game 1 of the team’s Eastern Conference semifinal series against the Rangers.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 9 P.M. (13) RIGOLETTO Michael Mayer, who won a Tony Award for directing “Spring Awakening,” made his Metropolitan Opera debut with this Verdi work, in a new production known as “the Rat Pack ‘Rigoletto,’ ” which moved events from a decadent 16th-century Italian court to the Las Vegas strip around 1960. The Polish tenor Piotr Beczala is the Duke, here a Sinatra-like playboy whose entourage includes the world-weary comedian Rigoletto, sung by the Serbian baritone Zeljko Lucic. The German soprano Diana Damrau, above with Mr. Lucic, plays the innocent Gilda, Rigoletto’s daughter and the victim of the predatory Duke. The Italian Michele Mariotti leads the ensemble in what Anthony Tommasini, writing in The New York Times, called “an excellent outing for this rising conductor.” Mr. Tommasini also noted that Mr. Mayer “had modeled Rigoletto on aggressive comics like Don Rickles, who could crack up Sinatra.” But “the vagueness of the concept undermines Mr. Lucic’s otherwise affecting performance,” he added, writing “the production was a frustrating mix of inventive and half-baked thinking.”

headline: Game 5: Knicks vs. Pacers
text: Carmelo Anthony provided the offense, Tyson Chandler the muscle and Chris Copeland the 3-point shooting in the Knicks’ win over the Pacers.

headline: Game 1: Rangers vs. Bruins
text: With the help of Brad Marchand, the Bruins edged the Rangers in overtime of Game 1 in the Eastern Conference semifinal series.

headline: For ‘Idol,’ a Mild Finale to a Bumpy Season
text: If this was the year that “American Idol,” the deeply influential but troubled singing competition, hoped to prove its worth as a minter of future music stars, it came up short. If this was the year it hoped to bring stasis to its lately evolving judges’ panel, it also missed the mark. And if this was the year it hoped to demonstrate continued dominance over the other vocal contest shows that have arrived in the wake of its juggernaut success, then consider that strike three.

headline: News Quiz | May 17, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Conversation With: Cricket Board Official Niranjan R. Shah
text: Niranjan Rasiklal Shah, 68, is one of the vice presidents of the Board of Control for Cricket in India, or B.C.C.I., which is among the world’s richest sporting bodies. He has been associated with the cricketing body for well over 30 years, serving as the board’s secretary for two terms.

headline: IHT Quick Read: May 17
text: NEWS Russia has sent advanced antiship cruise missiles to Syria, a move that illustrates the depth of its support for the Syrian government led by President Bashar al-Assad, American officials said Thursday. Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt report from Washington.

headline: In Age Before Fergie Time, a Manager’s Finest Hour and a Half
text: As a mark of how Alex Ferguson has come to embody soccer’s biggest club, it is often said the Scottish manager became Manchester United. But before Ferguson was United he was something else. He was Aberdeen Football Club.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, May 17, 2013
text: The question was written by Katherine Schulten. It comes from the article “The Art of Repetition.”

headline: Obstacles Get in the Way of Obama’s Second Term Goals
text: In the news analysis article “An Onset of Woes Raises Questions on Obama Vision,” Peter Baker writes about the frustrations of President Obama’s still early second term.

headline: What Would Your Dream Home Be Like?
text: Do you ever dream about what your perfect house would be like? Would it be a grand mansion with Greek-style columns and a vast front lawn? Or a cute colorful cottage on the beach? Maybe a loft apartment in the middle of a big city?

headline: After 25 Years, Confronting Alienation in Astoria
text: Photographers have long turned to New York’s ethnic enclaves for stories of cultural tenacity in the face of sweeping change. When Niko J. Kallianiotis came to Astoria, Queens, on a 1987 family visit from Greece, he got none of that.

headline: Republicans Expand I.R.S. Inquiry, With Eye on White House
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans, not resting with the Internal Revenue Service scandal, are moving to broaden the matter to an array of tax malfeasances and “intimidation tactics” they hope will ensnare the White House.

headline: The Early Word: Rain
text: In Today’s Times:President Obama’s recent woes have energized and unified Congressional Republicans, but the G.O.P. is taking a measured approach in its responses to the controversies that have ensnared the president and his administration, as the party seeks to avoid the kind of backlash that followed President Clinton’s impeachment trial, Jonathan Weisman writes.

headline: Long Journey to College, but I Was Never Alone
text: Applying to college has been a long journey, one that I could not have made alone. In the beginning, my dream of attending college in the United States with limited funds seemed to be just that: a dream. However, I am grateful to have had friends and family who were always supportive.

headline: Daily Report: Workweek Still Too Long at Apple Supplier, Audit Says
text: Foxconn Technology, the company that manufactures Apple’s popular iPads and iPhones, has made substantial progress toward improving safety and other working conditions at three of its Chinese plants dedicated to making Apple products. But it has not yet achieved the most difficult goal: reducing the average workweek to the maximum allowed by Chinese law, a global monitoring group said on Thursday, Vindu Goel reports in The New York Times.

headline: This Week in the Global Arts Guide
text: The Chinese artist Cai Guo-Qiang is well-known for creating pyrotechnic spectacles and for his epic installations.

headline: Race to the Top
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — While the U.S. Supreme Court considers whether American universities should take account of race when they admit new students, Brazil is implementing what are arguably the most radical affirmative action measures for universities in the West.

headline: A Grrrl’s Life
text: Fliers, lyrics and zines from Kathleen Hanna, the vocalist and songwriter for the band Bikini Kill.

headline: The Plane Was About to Crash. Now What?
text: I woke to a nudge. “The pilot’s going to make an announcement,” the flight attendant said. I palmed at my eyes, nodded and looked around, feeling my hangover creep back in. The girl next to me was flicking at her nails while she paged through a fashion magazine. I slumped back against the window after the flight attendant passed. White clouds blanketed the sky floor.

headline: Does the Postal Service Owe Me Money?
text: I recently sent a parcel via U.S. Express Mail. It was guaranteed to be delivered the next day by noon. The final delivery scan was at 12:03 p.m. I am entitled to a full refund of the postage I paid. However, the difference between noon and 12:03 is negligible — it did not affect me or the recipient. I simply needed the item delivered overnight and received the service I paid for. I’m fully satisfied. Is it ethical to request a full refund under these circumstances? ROSS NIZLEK, BURLINGTON, VT.

headline: Khaled Hosseini on How the Iraq War Hurt Afghanistan
text: In your new book, “And the Mountains Echoed,” one of the main characters is an Afghan-born physician in America, like you. He is embarrassed that he’s sweating the details of his new home theater while his countrymen are suffering. Do you have similar guilt?  Of course. I always have. The only reason I’m not where they are is just pure luck, it’s just a stupid genetic lottery. It’s an unmerited gift to have this life. My books became successful way beyond any reasonable expectation and were about those people on the streets. I felt that in some way I had profited from their wretchedness.

headline: Julie Delpy Dreams of Being Joe Pesci
text: Julie Delpy has many funny lines in the new film “Before Midnight,” but the funniest one — in which she mockingly runs through her boyfriend’s lackluster sexual routine, a line that starts with “Kissy, kissy” and ends with the sound of snoring and is otherwise far too graphic to repeat here — is delivered with such vigorous crudeness that I couldn’t resist asking her to recite it for me in person. Which she did, over and over, despite the fact that we were surrounded by fellow diners at the Chateau Marmont in Los Angeles.

headline: Europeans Rate Their Neighbors
text: Pew Research Center released a report this week about decaying sentiment in the European Union, based on its polls showing disintegrating support for the mission of the union. Of all the tidbits in the report, though, this table is probably the most interesting:

headline: Who Made That Motorcade?
text: “Here is a fine new word,” wrote an Iowa sports columnist in 1911. Back then, the slang term “motorcade” — a riff on “cavalcade” — described any kind of derring-do by a team of drivers. Before there was a highway system, auto enthusiasts tore off on 1,000-mile safaris to prove the mettle of their horseless carriages. In 1912, representatives of Indiana car companies traveled the Midwest in a motorcade that drove into towns accompanied by a rain of confetti and a blast of organ music — pipes were hooked up to the fan shaft of one of the cars.

headline: Rajat Gupta’s Lust for Zeros
text: Late one Friday morning, Rajat Gupta was rushing through security at Philadelphia International Airport, carry-on in tow, when his cellphone rang. When Gupta heard from Goldman Sachs, on whose board he sat, it was often from its chief executive, Lloyd Blankfein. But on this morning, it was Gregory K. Palm, his old Harvard Business School classmate and the bank’s general counsel, on the line. Palm sounded unusually serious. So Gupta asked if he could call him back from the other side of security.

headline: George Sauer’s Love-Hate Connection With Football
text: George Sauer was on his way to a possible Hall of Fame career when, in 1971, he suddenly retired, at age 27. By that time, he was the most prominent of a group of players who had become harsh critics of the game and its role in American society. For Sauer, the decision to walk away was also personal. Sauer died on May 7 of congestive heart failure in Westerville, Ohio, after battling Alzheimer’s disease. He was 69. A few thoughts:

headline: At Google Conference, Cameras Even in the Bathroom
text: 6:55 p.m. | Updated

headline: Elliott and Hess Shake Hands
text: BITTER STANDOFF AT HESS GIVES WAY TO SETTLEMENT  |  It wasn’t until dawn on Thursday, just hours before the annual meeting, that the Hess Corporation finally settled a proxy fight waged by the activist hedge fund Elliott Management. The oil company agreed to give Elliott three board seats in exchange for the fund’s support of the company’s slate of five directors; all told, nine new directors are joining the board, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports.

headline: Cooking the Books
text: A survey of officers and employees of large companies in 36 countries in Europe, the Middle East, Africa and India found that a fifth of them were aware of financial chicanery at their own company.

headline: A Troubling Survey on Global Corruption
text: CORRUPTION is a growth business.

headline: Why Indian Elites Like to Call Themselves ‘Middle Class’
text: If you are an Indian reading this, you are very likely among the top 10 percent in the country, since you have Internet access. It is also very likely that you, just like me, consider yourself middle class, though we are not anywhere close to the middle of this country in income or standard of living. We may well have trended the hashtag #IamSoMiddleClass last month, but being in the top decile of a 1.2 billion population, perhaps it’s time to ask #WhyICallMyselfMiddleClass?

headline: Friday Reading: Marathon Training, Minus the Long Run
text: Marathon training minus the long run, working out with your dog, renting cars by the minute and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: France Fights Racism by Outlawing ‘Race’
text: LONDON — In a move aimed at undermining the bogus foundation of racist ideology, France’s National Assembly has decided to drop the word “race” from the country’s laws.

headline: European Auto Sales Rebound, but With an Asterisk
text: European auto sales broke an 18-month losing streak in April, industry data showed on Friday. But don’t pop open the Champagne just yet: the increase was mostly a trick of the calendar.

headline: A Skittish Bird at the Airport
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Too Much Talk About Liquidity
text: Antonio Fatas is annoyed at Gillian Tett, who talks to the I-see-bubbles crowd and assumes that they have The Truth — namely, that those crazy central banks are flooding the world with liquidity, driving asset prices to crazy levels, and it will all end in terrible grief. Pretty much the same discussion we’ve been having about the armageddon hedgies.

headline: Andrew Mason’s Life After Groupon
text: Andrew Mason is back.

headline: The Rabbis’ Campaign
text: JERUSALEM — The two presiding rabbis of Israel’s Chief Rabbinate — one Ashkenazi, the other Sephardic — completed their 10-year term three months ago, but they were asked to stay until new chief rabbis are elected. The new rabbis can’t be chosen until a so-called electing body — 150 members, including mayors, rabbis and other assorted appointees — is selected by a committee of five, comprising two politicians, two rabbis and a judge appointed by the minister of religious affairs. And the new electing body can’t be selected until Israeli politicians can agree on how.

headline: Objects | Chris Lehrecke and Gabriella Kiss’s Wooden Wonders
text: The furniture designer Chris Lehrecke and the jewelry designer Gabriella Kiss have been married for more than two decades, and their upstate studios are a stone’s throw from one another. Given their mutual affinity for nature — he treats wood in an organic way, and her subject matter includes plants and insects — it’s a bit surprising that they’ve never done a big project together. Until now, that is. “After the Storm,” a collection that makes its debut on Monday at Ralph Pucci International, is the couple’s first major collaboration. Although the show features solo designs by each (wooden tortoises and lily-pad tables by Kiss, and tree-mushroom-shaped wall shelves by Lehrecke, to name a few), their joint efforts include a series of pieces in white oak designed by Lehrecke with cast-bronze pulls (also mushroom-shaped) by Kiss. The long, lean chest of drawers shown here, which incorporates a branch from a dead oak tree, is $22,000 at Ralph Pucci International (44 West 18th Street).

headline: That Hideous Strength
text: The FT has an interesting article on problems with Irish GNP (not GDP) accounting; essentially, measured Irish income is being inflated by foreign companies with no real activity there that nonetheless find ways to make profits materialize in a low-tax jurisdiction. We sort of knew this was happening — that, for example, a lot of the apparent rise in productivity was just a shift to pharma companies that produce a lot of reported value-added but add little to the Irish economy. But the new ESRI report suggests that the problem is bigger than realized.

headline: For Extra Credit: A Little Light Reading on Press Rights
text: With press rights very much in the news this week, here are some of the most noteworthy pieces I’ve come across on the subject.

text: I picked a good week to be away — and I am still away, mostly, although playing a bit of hooky on the notebook right now. For it has been the week of OBAMA SCANDALS, nonstop.

text: WASHINGTON — For the better part of a decade, Jay Carney sat slumped in his tiny chair in the White House briefing room, parsing, challenging and at times pillorying the words of an array of press secretaries.

Penney has gone back to some of its old pricing strategies, including this one: “Penney has already started to reverse Mr. Johnson’s overhaul by restoring a pricing system in which it artificially marks some items up and then down to give the appearance of a discount.”

headline: Women Know More About Finances Than They Get Credit For
text: ON occasion, when my female friends and I are sitting around talking, the issue of money will come up. And generally, most will readily admit that they don’t know anywhere near as much about their family finances as they should.
