headline: The Role of a Dictionary
text: When it happens I feel as if I have stepped into a Far Side cartoon. I am a magazine editor, and the galley of an article will come back from a proofreader with a low-frequency word circled and this comment in the margin: “Does this word even exist?” or “Is this a real word?”

headline: At Least One Enchanted Evening
text: On a recent spring night, the folks at Taiim Cellar — a new Middle Eastern wine bar tucked into a corner of the suburban souk that is downtown Scarsdale — had opened their door wide to let in a soft breeze. Petals floated from trees in the nearby public garden. Tidy place settings awaited guests. The scent of caramelized sugar hovered near the tiny kitchen, and jazz guitar drifted through speakers. Who could resist the spell? Zamir Iosepovici and his partners, Erion Hasko and Altin Sinai, have transformed a shoe repair shop using exotic veneers and furnishings: toffee-colored leatherette banquettes, plush chocolate-brown ottomans, brunet wood alcoves, jet-black bar stools and a stylish wine rack of latticed wood and copper.

headline: Searching for the Blues
text: Juke joints, the Blues Highway and the Deep South.

headline: A Blackhawk Hushes Doubters and Goal Horns
text: CHICAGO — For most of Wednesday’s game against the Detroit Red Wings, Chicago Blackhawks goaltender Corey Crawford stood in his crease, watching the action on the other end of the ice. He tapped his stick against his blocker, then against a goal post. He shifted his weight from leg to leg. He skated in circles and took sips from his water bottle.

headline: Abortion Law in Arkansas Is Blocked by U.S. Judge
text: A federal judge on Friday temporarily blocked enforcement of one of the country’s most stringent abortion laws, an Arkansas ban on the procedure at the 12th week of pregnancy, saying the law was likely to be declared unconstitutional.

headline: Rights Group Says It Finds Proof of Torture in Syria
text: CAIRO — An international human rights group said Friday that visits to two Syrian security centers recently captured by rebel fighters contained proof of widespread, arbitrary detentions and torture by the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: The Harvey Weinstein Show
text: CANNES, France — If there are lines separating art and commerce in the film world, they are obliterated annually at the Cannes Film Festival. The world’s most respected auteurs see their films have premieres in the Grand Palais, just above the Marché, the international film market in the basement, where distributors sell the rights to those same films as well as to B-movie action sequels like “Outpost III: Rise of the Spetsnaz” — whatever that is and wherever it’s rising from.

headline: Bye-Bye Bohemia
text: THE other evening I passed by 82 University Place in Greenwich Village, where a new European Wax Center was being constructed on the first floor, in a space once occupied by a fabled artists’ hangout, the Cedar Tavern.

headline: Dueling Budget Proposals
text: The President’s budget proposal for 2014 would reduce spending and combined with increased tax revenue, would reduce the deficit. But the Republicans’ and Democrats own plans are far apart.

headline: Former I.B.M. Chief to Lead Bloomberg Privacy Review
text: In a continuing effort to address concerns that reporters at Bloomberg L.P.'s news division looked at terminal subscribers’ data, the company on Friday appointed Samuel J. Palmisano, the former chairman and chief executive of I.B.M., to review its privacy and data standards.

headline: Hard of Hearings
text: Before Congress is finished with the Internal Revenue Service, there’s a serious danger some of us are going to wind up feeling sorry for the auditors.

headline: U.S.-Russian Diplomacy, With a Personal Touch
text: WASHINGTON — When Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, clashed over Syria last year with Hillary Rodham Clinton, then the secretary of state, he called her hysterical, the sort of impolitic remark that showed just how sour their relationship had become.

headline: What the Woodpecker Told Me
text: Last September, in one of those early red-gold days of autumn, I was awakened by a tap-tap-tapping out in the backyard. A woodpecker was hammering at the old Box Elder out past the prickly pears near the back alley. I lay in bed awhile letting my thoughts circle:

headline: A Black Mound of Canadian Oil Waste Is Rising Over Detroit
text: WINDSOR, Ontario — Assumption Park gives residents of this city lovely views of the Ambassador Bridge and the Detroit skyline. Lately they’ve been treated to another sight: a three-story pile of petroleum coke covering an entire city block on the other side of the Detroit River.

headline: The Salacious and the Sober Collide, Illustrating Hurdles for Italy’s Government
text: ROME — A young Moroccan woman embroiled in a sex scandal with former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi took the witness stand on Friday, recounting wild parties in which an attractive politician once dressed up as a nun and performed a striptease for Mr. Berlusconi.

headline: Trying Unlikely Comeback, Ex-Iran President Strikes Chord With Public
text: TEHRAN — There was a time when Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani seemed to have it all. A founder of the Islamic Revolution, he headed a family empire that owned the second biggest Iranian airline, Mahan, had a near monopoly on the lucrative pistachio trade and controlled the country’s largest private university, Azad.

headline: Investor Group Wants Real-Time Access to Proxy Votes
text: The Council of Institutional Investors asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to intervene after Broadridge, the main company that provides real-time tallies of shareholder votes, stopped giving the information to the groups that sponsor proposals. At the behest of the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association, a group that lobbies for Wall Street, Broadridge stopped giving shareholder sponsors real-time updates. The move drew fire from some who say the ability to obtain real-time votes helps both sides devise their campaigns.

headline: Angelina Jolie’s Disclosure
text: Angelina Jolie’s revelation on The Times’s Op-Ed page that she had a double mastectomy to reduce her risk of breast cancer greatly raises public awareness of the genetic testing she used, as well as concerns about insurance coverage for this kind of testing. Ms. Jolie had a family history of cancer and tested positive for genetic flaws in the BRCA1 gene, which indicates an elevated risk for breast and ovarian cancer. Her doctor estimated that she had an 87 percent chance of developing breast cancer.

headline: Toronto Mayor Is Besieged by Questions of Crack Use
text: OTTAWA — Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto has long been dogged by controversy over his often boorish behavior and less than diligent attention to work. On Friday, Mr. Ford faced his greatest political test following two reports that he is seen in a video apparently using crack cocaine.The Toronto Star and the Web site Gawker reported on Thursday night that they were shown the video on a smartphone by two men who were trying to sell it. The Star, which said that two of its reporters had watched the recording, reported that it was made by a man who said he had sold crack to Mr. Ford.

headline: Sales Taxes and the Internet
text: Twenty-one Republicans voted with 46 Democrats (and 2 Independents) recently to pass the Marketplace Fairness Act, a long-overdue bill allowing states to require online retailers to collect sales taxes and remit them to the state where the customer lives. Will the House be so rational? It’s a long shot.

headline: Unforgivable Conduct in Albany
text: The sordid details of how a once-powerful Brooklyn politician pawed, groped and taunted young women on his staff are more than an indictment of one politician, Assemblyman Vito Lopez. They provide a galling picture of the way Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker and one of New York’s top legislative leaders, failed to provide an environment in which young women could work without fear of being sexually assaulted by a bully like Mr. Lopez.

headline: Cracking the Brand-New 1940 Census
text: All pack rats should be as creative as the New York Public Library, the obsessive collector of the most complete sets of bulky, outdated telephone directories in the world. Skeptics in the cellphone era might wonder why. But the library’s Milstein Division, a rich trove of national and local history archives and free genealogy resources, digitalized old New York phone directories to create a free Web site. It cross-references residents’ names and addresses with the long-awaited 1940 census data made public last year, which includes the person’s age, income, education, job and migration record.

headline: Europe’s Economics Chief Tries to Peel Off ‘Mr. Austerity’ Label
text: BRUSSELS

headline: At Preakness, Orb’s Challengers Include Childhood Friend
text: BALTIMORE — They shared the same paddock and gamboled in the same Kentucky bluegrass as weanlings and yearlings. Orb hit the ground first at Claiborne Farm, with Departing tumbling out of his mother a month later. Now 3 years old, the two horses will be reunited Saturday in the 138th running of the Preakness Stakes.

headline: Pettitte Goes to 15-Day Disabled List
text: The mounting list of injured Yankee stars added another member on Friday when Andy Pettitte was placed on the 15-day disabled list with a strained trapezius muscle.

headline: Americas Coalition Puts Marijuana Legalization Up for Discussion
text: MEXICO CITY — A comprehensive report on drug policy in the Americas released Friday by a consortium of nations suggests that the legalization of marijuana, but not other illicit drugs, be considered among a range of ideas to reassess how the drug war is carried out.

headline: Long Before Crack Cocaine Allegations, Toronto Mayor Was a Source of Controversy
text: As our colleague Ian Austen reports, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto angrily dismissed allegations on Friday that he had used crack cocaine in a 90-second cellphone video that is being peddled to United States and Canadian news organizations for more than $100,000.

headline: Immigrant Workers Give New Direction to Los Angeles Unions
text: LOS ANGELES — As the head of the hotel workers’ union here in the 1990s, Maria Elena Durazo negotiated a contract with provisions rarely seen by labor unions: The jobs of workers who were deported or lost authorization to work in the United States would be held open for two years, with the same pay.

headline: Corrections: May 18, 2013
text: NATIONAL

headline: N.B.A. Concussion Policy Becomes Major Factor in Series
text: Professional basketball players do not routinely collide at full speed, or fire small objects at one another with extreme velocity. They do not tackle, ram or body-check. Their heads may rise to startling heights, but they are not in harm’s way as often as the skulls of football, hockey or baseball players.

headline: Not Just Another Face in the Crowd
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Do you ever have, even for the briefest instant, a slight feeling of dread when you see all that wide open white space in a quad stack? I do, especially on a Saturday puzzle, because I know I’m in for quite a tussle between the 15-letter entries and the crossings. Oh, and don’t forget the ramped-up, cryptic nature of the clues. Did I mention that this is Saturday?

headline: Energy Exports Are Good!
text: What first caught my eye was the op-ed article in The Wall Street Journal. Published in late February, it was written by Andrew N. Liveris, the chairman and chief executive of the Dow Chemical Company. Liveris, an Australian, has become quite the Washington player in recent years. Among other things, he heads President Obama’s efforts to revive manufacturing.

headline: After Many Miles in a Chevy Van, a Rough Gig in a Place Called Hindsight
text: There are joyless pockets of New York City that should be renamed Hindsight, based on the stories from visitors. “In Hindsight,” these tales begin, rarely ending well.

headline: Tortorella Stays Positive Despite the Rangers’ Latest Overtime Failure
text: BOSTON — Rangers Coach John Tortorella insists his players’ psyche has not been affected by the team’s 0-3 overtime record in the playoffs.

headline: Resonance Resistant
text: Whether one thinks the demiscandals being howled about in Washington should or should not resonate more widely, they don’t.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Developer May Swap Land for More in Hudson Yards
text: There has never been a lot of love lost between the rival developers Gary Barnett of Extell and Stephen M. Ross of Related Companies.

headline: Images From Connecticut Train Derailment
text: Two Metro-North trains collided after a derailment near Bridgeport, Conn., on Friday, injuring at least 60 people, five of them critically, according to Governor Dannel P. Malloy. Commuters on the trains, and local reporters, began posting images from the scene almost as soon as the collision occurred.

headline: Schools Chancellor to Strike Back at Candidates Critical of Mayor’s Policies
text: Charter schools would no longer be allowed space in traditional school buildings. Neighborhood school boards would be given more oversight over superintendents and principals. Cellphones, long considered contraband in schools, would again be permitted past the door.

headline: Merkel Offers a Peek Into Her Private Life
text: BERLIN — Throughout her rise to power and as Germany’s chancellor, Angela Merkel has kept her personal life strictly private, to an extent that is hard to achieve in the age of social media.

headline: Nathaniel Hawthorne’s Funny Civil War
text: In early 1863, Nathaniel Hawthorne wrote a letter to his friend Henry Bright in England. In it, he informed Bright that he had become a pariah in his close-knit community of Concord, Mass. “The war-party here do not look upon me as a reliably loyal man, and, in fact, I have been publicly accused of treasonable sympathies.” What had the silver-haired author of “The Scarlet Letter” done to upset his neighbors?

headline: Newark Mayor Discloses $1.3 Million in Speaking Fees
text: NEWARK — Mayor Cory A. Booker has turned his office into a platform for national celebrity, and he has been richly compensated for it, taking in more than $1.3 million in speaking fees over the last four and a half years.

headline: Kuroda Stifles Toronto Over 8 Innings
text: On any given day this season, the Yankees’ clubhouse can  be crowded with reporters, team employees and, most recently, a host of players rotating back and forth from the minor leagues in place of Alex Rodriguez, Derek Jeter and Mark Teixeira. Almost each day there is a new face to make even the most slightly recognizable player seem like a longtime regular.

headline: Trial Weighs Importance of Arrests in Police Stops
text: It was only a single word — “yes” — but it stands as one of the more interesting acknowledgments in two months of testimony in the federal trial over the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk tactics.

headline: 5th Ave. Poker, With $25,000 Chips and an F.B.I. Ace in the Hole
text: The all-night games were held in rarefied settings like a suite at the Plaza Hotel. One pink chip was worth $25,000. Masseuses were on hand to help relieve the tension, while the players were fueled by food and drink. And the stakes climbed into the stratosphere, with as much as $2 million on the table to be lost or won.

headline: Albert Seedman, Chief of Detectives in New York for Short, Tumultuous Time, Dies at 94
text: Albert Seedman, the New York Police Department’s chief of detectives in the early 1970s who became something of a celebrity as the savvy, cigar-chomping personification of the tough-guy cop while modernizing a tradition-bound force, died on Friday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 94.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Full Bloom
text: A focus of fashion is the length of the leg, seen in tights or just bare.

headline: In Document, Lhota Puts His Worth at $13 Million
text: Joseph J. Lhota, a Republican candidate for New York City mayor, has amassed a fortune of at least $13 million from real estate and investments, a new document shows.

headline: McIlroy Charts a New Path, Again
text: Three years after he won his first PGA Tour title, Rory McIlroy returned last month to Quail Hollow, the scene of that inaugural victory, as the recently dethroned world No. 1 in search of his game and his first win of the new season. The simplicity that characterized McIlroy’s swing thoughts and his life in 2010 was a bygone memory, so he was asked what sticks out in his mind when he looks back at the 20-year-old who won for the first time on tour.

headline: Kennett Love, Times Correspondent in 1950s, Dies at 88
text: Kennett Love, a foreign correspondent for The New York Times who covered tumultuous events in the Middle East in the early days of the cold war, died Monday in Southampton, N.Y. He was 88.

headline: As Obama Pushes Overhaul of Food Aid, Panels in Congress Favor Smaller Changes
text: WASHINGTON — In response to the Obama administration’s plans to overhaul the nation’s international food aid program, which provides food to disaster-stricken regions, Congress this week began laying the groundwork for its own changes.

headline: Witnesses to Horse Racing’s Two Sides
text: Joe Miller and Jimmy McCue work in different environments at the same racetrack. McCue, 66, has been a staff photographer at Pimlico Race Course since 1970. Miller, 50, has been the track’s equine ambulance driver since 1997, though he has worked there since 1981.

headline: In Response to Sex Assaults, Military to Review Staffing
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel signed an order on Friday requiring the military to review and recertify each person assigned to programs for preventing sexual assault and assisting victims.

headline: Ken Venturi, U.S. Open Golf Champion and Broadcaster, Dies at 82
text: Ken Venturi, who won the 1964 United States Open while nearing collapse from heat exhaustion and who was later the longtime chief golf analyst for CBS Sports, died on Friday in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Idaho: Uzbek Man Pleads Not Guilty to Charges of Supporting Terrorism
text: An Uzbek man pleaded not guilty on Friday to three federal terrorism charges that accuse him of providing support to a terrorist group in Uzbekistan. Wearing slippers and yellow and white striped prison garb, the defendant, Fazliddin Kurbanov, entered the federal courtroom in Boise in shackles and spoke primarily through a Russian interpreter. Federal agents arrested Mr. Kurbanov, 30, a truck driver, on Thursday after an extensive investigation into his activities in Idaho and Utah over the last nine months. A federal grand jury has charged him with providing support to a terrorist group in Uzbekistan. He is scheduled to appear Tuesday for a detention hearing.

headline: Subpoena for Head of Benghazi Panel
text: The chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee on Friday issued a subpoena to the chairman of the independent panel that investigated the attacks last year on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya. The congressman, Darrell Issa of California, issued the subpoena to Thomas R. Pickering, a retired diplomat, to force him to appear at a deposition Thursday to answer questions about his panel’s report. Mr. Issa and other Republicans have criticized the report, saying it did not hold senior State Department officials accountable. Mr. Pickering and Adm. Mike Mullen, the retired chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who also led the five-member panel, have agreed to testify at a public hearing, but they have balked at a private deposition.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 18, 2013
text: “It’s hard to hold this market down.”

headline: Preakness Champion, and Mother, Toughs It Out
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — On a sun-drenched May morning on the 460-acre Stonestreet Farm, Rachel Alexandra, a member of racing royalty, emerged from a 16-by-16 oak-paneled stall in a barn named Cabernet.

headline: A Survey of the Region’s Battered Beaches
text: With summer looming, The Times looked at the condition of public beaches in the region battered by Hurricane Sandy, surveying three states and hundreds of miles of coastline.

headline: No Politics, Just Our Preakness Picks
text: The Rail’s contributors welcome this year’s Preakness Stakes guest picker, Mayor Stephanie C. Rawlings-Blake, who became Baltimore’s 49th mayor in 2010 and in November 2011 was elected to her first full term, receiving 87 percent of the vote in the mayoral general election. There’s a similar level of consensus surrounding who will win on Saturday.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (Starz) BRAVE (2012) Kelly Macdonald lends her voice to Pixar’s first female protagonist: Merida, above, a Scottish princess and ace archer crowned by a mass of wild and woolly persimmon-hued tendrils and riding a high-stepping Clydesdale, Angus. Her mother, Queen Elinor (Emma Thompson), wants her to behave more like a lady. The queen has also beckoned local clan leaders to bring their sons by the castle to compete for her daughter’s hand, causing a furious Merida to rebel. When her defiance doesn’t work, she seeks help from a witch (Julie Walters), who casts a spell that sidelines the queen — and eventually prompts Merida to embark on a mission to rescue her mother and, in the process, save her family. Entering “the big business of little girls,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, “hasn’t been easy, to judge by the deep divide between the movie’s seductive pictorial splendor and its discouragingly uninspired script by Mark Andrews, Steve Purcell, Brenda Chapman and Irene Mecchi. (Ms. Chapman, the first woman hired to direct a Pixar feature, either left or was removed from “Brave” and now shares directing credit with Mr. Andrews.)” Still, “the animation, particularly in the outdoor scenes, can be transfixing with the photorealist details — every blade of grass and each hair in Angus’s mane looks perfectly individuated — blending seamlessly with the cartoon impressionism,” Ms. Dargis wrote, adding: “The association of Merida with the natural world accounts for some of the movie’s most beautifully animated sequences, and in other, smarter or maybe just braver, hands it might have also inspired new thinking about women, men, nature and culture.”

headline: A Racer Known to Many, and Now a Mystery
text: CONCORD, N.C. — Dick Trickle had a name that was so easy to mock that anchors on ESPN’s “SportsCenter” made him famous by mentioning him regularly during the network’s auto racing reports in the 1990s. If that playful teasing ever overshadowed what he accomplished as a short-track racer in the Midwest and as a mentor to some of Nascar’s best, it never diminished Trickle’s impact on the sport.

headline: The Art of the Playoff Jumper
text: Ivorie Manning, an N.B.A. shooting consultant, highlights the key components of a good jumper, using sharp shooters from the N.B.A. playoffs.

headline: Restoring the Rockaways
text: The city of New York is investing $140 million to restore Rockaway Beach.

headline: Racing the Clock in the Rockaways
text: In mid-March, a waterline still marked the wall in the basement of the Robert Moses-era parks building at Beach 97th Street in Rockaway Beach, Queens. It was Hurricane Sandy’s calling card, a vestige of the wall of seawater that broke down doors and gushed through the interior, destroying mechanical equipment and soaking Sheetrock, more than four months earlier.

headline: Rebuilding the Coastline, but at What Cost?
text: When a handful of retired homeowners from Osborn Island in New Jersey gathered last month to discuss post-Hurricane Sandy rebuilding and environmental protection, L. Stanton Hales Jr., a conservationist, could not have been clearer about the risks they faced.

headline: Racing to Save a Champion
text: Rachel Alexandra, who in 2009 became the first filly to win the Preakness Stakes in 85 years, nearly died from an infection she developed after giving birth.

headline: Looking Beyond the Mediterranean
text: On the last day of 2011, the chef Shelley Deproto packed up her kitchen and closed Lupo, the Mediterranean-style restaurant she had owned and operated in Chester since 2003. Her new venture, Red Hen Restaurant in Old Saybrook, opened last fall. The name is borrowed from a children’s book and evokes no particular culinary culture. This is intentional. After 8 ½ years of hewing to Mediterranean cuisine, Ms. Deproto wants to take inspiration where she finds it.

headline: Keep an Eye Out for the Sliders
text: Five.Five 2, a restaurant named for its address on North Country Road in St. James, makes a good first impression. The cheery copper-topped bar has a fireplace, and the rabbit warren of dining rooms is charming: one is small and cozy, another light and airy, and a third enhanced by bright colored paintings.

headline: A Long Menu, and Swift Servers
text: The Boston Market on Route 1 North in Edison serves fast, casual food, with choices that include chicken and lots of vegetables. But turn in before you reach that chain outpost and head for the strip mall behind it, and you will discover Chung Sol Bat.

headline: A First Fest for Local Tastes
text: Melody Kettle said she began planning the Montclair Food and Wine Festival in 2011, after writing about food events in towns like Summit and Madison on her blog, Hot From the Kettle. “I started wondering,” she said, “Why don’t we have our own festival?”

headline: In a Painter’s Home, Works From Local Closets
text: Works by the artist John F. Peto are in the permanent collections of major museums including the Newark Museum, the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington and the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. But even locals in the small, waterfront town of Island Heights, where he lived and worked from 1889 until his death in 1907, are not always familiar with his name.

headline: A Tale of College, Romance and the Big Game
text: If college rankings had been around in the Roaring ’20s, Tait College would belong at the bottom. On this campus, football comes first with the guys, football players come first with the coeds — yes, that’s what female students were called back then — and school events usually culminate in ecstatic eruptions of tap dance.

headline: An Old Technology, Transformed
text: On a recent afternoon, Carla Rae Johnson riffled through an array of cards in one of the narrow wooden drawers of a card catalog at the Greenburgh Public Library. But she wasn’t doing research, and the cards she was examining had nothing to do with books. She was inspecting her installation, the “Alternet,” a 50-drawer card catalog that she repurposed to hold more than 15,000 three-by-five-inch works of original visual art.

headline: Another Dark Corner of the Holocaust
text: The photographs of proud Greek Jewish families in the early 1900s and the richly decorated artifacts from centuries past on display at the Holocaust Memorial and Tolerance Center of Nassau County reflect a vibrant community. But images from the 1940s, of sobbing people on their way to Nazi death camps and of postwar commemorations of the murdered, document a darker era.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Few State Laws Restrict Plastic Bags
text: Where laws have been enacted or proposed to curb the use of plastic bags.

headline: First, Four Lattes. Then, the Ballet.
text: Ballet often figures into a Sunday for Patsy Tarr, 65, the philanthropist and publisher who runs the 2wice Arts Foundation, which specializes in digital and print projects uniting dance and design. Her latest endeavor, an interactive iPad app in which Tom Gold, a former New York City Ballet soloist, dances with an image of himself to a score by Charles Yang, will be available in mid-June. She lives on the Upper West Side with her husband, Jeff, 68, a former Wall Street risk arbitrageur who runs the JCT Foundation, and their Shih Tzu, Coco. Their children, Jeff Tarr Jr. and Jennie Tarr Coyne, and five grandchildren all live nearby.

headline: A Comedian for Life
text: The wall of fame at the Comic Strip on the Upper East Side of Manhattan is lined with publicity shots of comedy legends like Eddie Murphy, Chris Rock, Adam Sandler and many others whose careers have roots at the club. There is even Jerry Seinfeld’s audition sign-in sheet from his first appearance in the late 1970s.

headline: A Cloudy Revelation From a Mayoral Candidate
text: The current issue of Vogue features a portrait of the mayoral contender Christine C. Quinn standing on the steps of the New York Public Library with a windswept lift to her pageboy, wearing beige stilettos and a cobalt blue sheath designed by Carolina Herrera.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Brooklyn’s Champs-Élysées
text: Looking down Eastern Parkway from Grand Army Plaza’s Memorial Arch, past the Brooklyn Public Library, past the Botanic Garden and McKim, Mead and White’s Brooklyn Museum, you might be reminded of Paris and the broad avenues that radiate from the Arc de Triomphe. Mapped out in 1868 by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, Eastern Parkway extends a little over two miles, from Prospect Park to Ralph Avenue.

headline: Why We Take the F.D.R. to La Guardia
text: Alfred Stieglitz titled his stark 1910 photograph of the percolating Lower Manhattan skyline “City of Ambition.” Fittingly, Mason B. Williams borrows the name for a book about two transformative figures whose political and civic genius helped New York deliver on that promise.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. Can you tell me anything about the African-American holiday Pinkster that used to be celebrated in New York?

headline: Bringing Back the Sand
text: Since Hurricane Sandy hit last October, workers have been manually shoveling sand back onto Staten Island’s beaches.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: North Korea Reportedly Launches Short-Range Missiles
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea launched three short-range missiles into the sea off its east coast on Saturday, the South Korean Defense Ministry said. The tests broke the recent relative silence from the North, but the move was much less provocative than what had been feared in the tense weeks after the country’s nuclear test in February.

headline: The Weekend Word: Moving On
text: Today’s Times

headline: Why My Heart Aches When Worthless Cars Go to the Crusher
text: Expanding upon my previous rumination about today’s worthless cars becoming tomorrow’s relatively pricey classics, I had another experience involving a car that isn’t worth a whole lot that was dumped, whole, into a line of cars to be crushed at a scrap yard on the outskirts of Denver.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir:  Prime Minister Manmohan Singh has promised a package of 7 billion rupees, or $128 million, over a span of five years to promote sports in Jammu and Kashmir, according to a Press Trust of India report in The Business Standard. With the funding, the state proposes to build hockey and soccer grounds, as well as an indoor stadium in every town with a population of more than 50,000, the state’s sports minister said Friday.

headline: The Liquidationist Urge
text: I’m stayed out of the fracas over Mike Kinsley’s somewhat bizarre attack on my recent writings; Mark Thoma, Brad DeLong, and Dan Drezner have it covered. And I owe a debt to Kinsley, who hired me to write for Slate way back when, letting me establish a reputation as someone who could write short-form pieces about economics for a broad audience, which led down a path to, well, you know.

headline: Almost 80, He Continues the Ruckus
text: There are artists who burn out at 30 and others who, accelerating as they mature, begin to seem like forces of nature. One such force is Ken Jacobs, who turns 80 next Saturday — an occasion marked by a recent tribute at the Museum of Modern Art, with another next weekend at Anthology Film Archives.

headline: Vows: Travis and Tom
text: Two Steves fell in love during a national tour of “Blues Clues Live!” That is, actor Tom Mizer fell for his understudy, Travis McGhie.

headline: Is It Time to Bag the Plastic?
text: IN my New York City apartment, the kitchen drawers, the coat closet, even the wine rack are overflowing with a type of waste that is rapidly disappearing elsewhere — the used plastic shopping bag.

headline: The Government’s Worst Face
text: THE reported targeting by the Internal Revenue Service of conservative organizations seeking tax-exempt status has led some to revisit the long history of presidents, or their administrations, using tax regulations to punish enemies. Some have drawn comparisons with the crimes of Watergate, when President Richard M. Nixon loosed the I.R.S. on an array of Democrats (including potential challengers to his re-election in 1972). Another example, parallel to the current episode, came in 1961, when President John F. Kennedy, alarmed by the growing strength of right-wing groups, “asked the director of audits at the I.R.S. to gather intelligence on organizations receiving tax exemptions,” as Rick Perlstein wrote in “Before the Storm,” his 2001 history of Barry M. Goldwater’s 1964 presidential campaign.

headline: How to Be a ‘Woman Programmer’
text: I WAS an ordinary computer programmer. I wrote code that ran at the levels between flashy human interfaces and the deep cores of operating systems, like the role of altos in a chorus, who provide the structure without your taking much notice of their melodic lines. I made realistic schedules and met my deadlines. Those were decent accomplishments.

headline: Bernanke Says Better Days Lie Ahead
text: Ben S. Bernanke is, of course, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, but he always seems most comfortable as an educator, a role he slips into for a commencement address on Saturday at Bard College at Simon’s Rock.

headline: Get a Life? No Thanks. Just Pass the Remote.
text: ALL I want to do is watch “Breaking Bad.”

headline: Promoters Circling One Another as M.M.A. Takes Root in Asia
text: SINGAPORE — It was late on a Friday night at Singapore Indoor Stadium. The 12,000 seats were full. The shouts in English, Mandarin and Malay were reverberating, and between sending Twitter messages from his cage-side chair, Victor Cui kept leaping to his feet in response to the takedowns, submissions and other codified mayhem happening at close range.

headline: Haunting Relic of History, Slave Cabin Gets a Museum Home in Washington
text: EDISTO ISLAND, S.C. — The floors creaked. The walls swayed in a strong breeze. Rot and termites had destroyed parts of the rickety structure built before the Civil War.

headline: Hollande Signs French Gay Marriage Law
text: PARIS — The rush toward France’s first same-sex marriage officially began Saturday morning, after President François Hollande signed the country’s “marriage for all” act into law.

headline: Tangling in Shadow of Wrigley’s Ivy Walls
text: CHICAGO — About the time the first pitch was thrown at Wrigley Field in a game between the Cubs and the St. Louis Cardinals on a recent night, a local group, the East Lake View Neighbors, called a meeting to order two blocks away. The agenda was to discuss proposed Wrigley renovations that the Cubs had submitted to the City Council.

headline: Jackie Robinson and a Barrier Unbroken
text: Two big surprises have emerged from the film“42,” which deals with Jackie Robinson’s breaking major league baseball’s color barrier with the Brooklyn Dodgers. One, it appears that many people who never set foot in Ebbets Field in the 1940s and ’50s have been flocking to see it. And two, the chief tormentor of Robinson, Philadelphia Phillies Manager Ben Chapman, is portrayed exactly as he was in life: a meanspirited, unreconstructed bigot.

headline: Scandal Involving Gifts and Theft Charges Complicates Politics in Virginia
text: RICHMOND, Va. — A celebrated chef. A political donor with a private jet to lend and a product to pitch. The state’s top two elected officials.

headline: Prisoners Onstage
text: Every year, the inmates at Prison Volterra in Tuscany put on plays. They are directed by Armando Punzo, who established the “Compagnia della Fortezza” in 1988. About a third of the 170 men imprisoned participate. Many are dangerous felons, in prison for life. Most of them come from criminal gangs.

headline: Disease and the Public Eye
text: I’M in line at the supermarket holding three items close to my chest. But I might as well be juggling my Kleenex box, toothpaste tube and an orange. Because — as you’d surely notice if you were behind me in line — I‘m bent forward at a sharp angle, which makes holding things difficult. I know you don’t want to stare, but you do. Maybe you think you’re being considerate when you say, apropos of nothing, “You look like you’re in pain.” Well, thanks, I am — but I’ll resist replying the way I want (“You look like you’re having a bad hair day”). I’m sorry. I know you mean well. Anyway it’s my turn at the register which means I’m closer to being at home where I can lie down and wait for the spasms to subside.

headline: Prisoners Onstage
text: At a Prison Volterra in Tuscany, Italy, inmates become actors.

headline: Afghanistan Hit by Wave of Violence
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A spate of violence across Afghanistan has claimed the lives of nearly two dozen Afghan police officers and civilians in the past few days, including a district police official assassinated over a recent anti-Taliban campaign.

headline: Variety: A Lovely Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Today’s quote by short story author Alice Munro is a lovely and evocative sentiment: the idea that HATE is infectious and spreads through the soul like A DROP OF BLACK INK IN MILK. Not only did I love the idea that hate, if it has to exist, needs to be curbed within one’s self so that it doesn’t spread, but the stark contrast of the ink and the milk is a lovely mental picture. Finally, the idea that, as a child, Ms. Munro was more enchanted by the idea of trying the ink in milk experiment but was hesitant to WASTE THE MILK is particularly moving. I’m truly not sure which part of the quote I liked best.

headline: The 1 Percent Are Only Half the Problem
text: Most recent discussion about economic inequality in the United States has focused on the top 1 percent of the nation’s income distribution, a group whose incomes average $1 million (with a bottom threshold of about $367,000). “We are the 99 percent,” declared the Occupy protesters, unexpectedly popularizing research findings by two economists, Thomas Piketty and Emmanuel Saez, that had previously drawn attention mainly from academics. But the gap between the 1 percent and the 99 percent is only half the story.

headline: Former Ski Racer Developed Swing That Sounds as Good as It Looks
text: The Austrian teenager Marina Stuetz’s path to the L.P.G.A. Tour did not go through an American college program, Golf Channel’s “Big Break” or the Ladies European Tour. She arrived like a snowstorm in spring, catching everyone by surprise.

headline: Top 16-Year-Old Runner Has a Long To-Do List
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — In anticipation of her first marathon, Alana Hadley did a test run late last month on the quiet, tree-lined streets near her home here. She set out on a three-mile loop that was as familiar to her as the cadence of her breathing. Soon, the laps and miles began to fall away.

headline: Raising Bar for Female Jockeys
text: BALTIMORE — As Rosie Napravnik prepared to become the third woman to ride in the 138-year history of the Preakness Stakes, she reflected on how far she had come.

headline: Ivorie Manning,  Shot Doctor, Drops In for a Visit
text: About a week before the playoffs, Knicks point guard Raymond Felton, who had never been on a team that won a playoff series before this season, his eighth in the N.B.A., thought he needed extra time on the court. So he sent a text message to his shooting coach, Ivorie Manning.

headline: China Tries to Improve Image in a Changing Myanmar
text: MADAY ISLAND, Myanmar — The pipelines are finished. The oil storage tanks gleam in the tropical sun. The deep-sea port set in jade-colored waters awaits the first ships bearing crude from the Middle East.

headline: Assad Suggests Peace Talks Would Fail Because West Wants to Prolong War
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, in a rare interview with a foreign newspaper, appeared to dismiss the possibility of serious progress arising from any peace talks, and to back away from earlier statements by Syrian officials that the government was willing to negotiate with its armed opponents.

headline: Calls for Change
text: Some of the Democratic candidates running in the 2013 mayoral election have been vocal critics of certain aspects of educational policy under the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Belgium to Bring ‘A’ Team to Play U.S.
text: Belgium’s soccer team, which is having a renaissance under Coach Marc Wilmots (the former captain of the national team), is bringing a top-flight team to the United States for a friendly game in Cleveland on May 29.

headline: Without Water, Revolution
text: TEL ABYAD, Syria — I just spent a day in this northeast Syrian town. It was terrifying — much more so than I anticipated — but not because we were threatened in any way by the Free Syrian Army soldiers who took us around or by the Islamist Jabhet al-Nusra fighters who stayed hidden in the shadows. It was the local school that shook me up.

headline: Le Grand Jerry Lewis
text: CANNES, France — EVERY year the organizers of the Cannes Film Festival choose to recognize one towering figure in cinema. This year, they are paying homage to Jerry Lewis with a special screening of “Max Rose,” the latest film for the 87-year-old American. In it, he plays an aging jazz pianist.

headline: All the Lonely People
text: OVER the last decade, the United States has become a less violent country in every way save one. As Americans commit fewer and fewer crimes against other people’s lives and property, they have become more likely to inflict fatal violence on themselves.

headline: We Need to Talk
text: Avoiding any frank talks with your children about the dangers lurking “out there” in the universe is completely natural. Pointing out a full moon or the Big Dipper is way easier than telling your little Johnny flat-out that a single meteorite the size of his school bus would wipe out everything in the region, including us, and so all his crying now isn’t going to change that.

headline: Card Company Changes Numbering System Collectors Counted On
text: When Cee Angi was young, a neighborhood bully forced her to trade her 1992 Topps Dave Winfield card for a David Segui. The bully did not know much about baseball, but he knew that the number Topps had assigned to the back of Winfield’s card, 5, made it more valuable than Segui’s, which was 477.

headline: Effort to Strengthen an Afghan Law on Women May Backfire
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Even with some legal protections in place, Afghan women, and sometimes even little girls, can be sold to pay family debts. In the country’s vast rural areas, just talking to a man who is not a close relative can be punishable by death. And in some places, girls are routinely married at puberty.

headline: Show Us Your Woe
text: IN the service of what I’m about to write, an admission I’m loath to make: I watch “The Voice.”

headline: The Giant of Shareholders, Quietly Stirring
text: AT 11 a.m. on a Wednesday earlier this month, Michelle Edkins and her team began wheeling extra chairs into a cramped conference room in a San Francisco office tower, preparing for the corporate-governance equivalent of speed dating.

headline: Beware Social Nostalgia
text: AS a historian, I’ve spent much of my career warning people about the dangers of nostalgia. But as a mother, watching my son graduate from medical school on Thursday, I have been awash in nostalgia all week.

headline: Wesley Schultz
text: Wesley Schultz is the lead singer and guitarist for the Lumineers, a folk-rock band based in Denver. The group’s eponymous debut album has reached platinum sales status and its singles “Ho Hey” and “Stubborn Love” are among the most streamed and shared songs on Internet music sites.

headline: Taxing Times for Obama
text: WASHINGTON — I WENT to New York last week to cover the TV presentations for the new season, shows like “Scandal,” “Shark Tank” and a faltering “American Idol.”

headline: Plane Makes Belly Landing at Newark Airport
text: The pilot of a US Airways plane with malfunctioning landing gear managed to successfully land the aircraft on its belly at Newark Liberty International Airport early Saturday, transportation officials said.

headline: Tattoo Removal on the Photo Desk
text: A POWERFUL picture taken by the Swedish photographer Paul Hansen last year, of men carrying the bodies of dead children through the streets of Gaza City, was artfully composed and filled with anguish.

headline: Beyond the Brady Rule
text: Fifty years ago, in the landmark case Brady v. Maryland, the Supreme Court laid down a fundamental principle about the duty of prosecutors — to seek justice in fair trials, not merely to win convictions by any means. The court said that due process required prosecutors to disclose to criminal defendants any exculpatory evidence they asked for that was likely to affect a conviction or sentence.

headline: The Immigration Bill Presses On
text: When the Senate Judiciary Committee meets on Monday to resume marking up an immigration bill, it will have two weeks of solid achievement to build on. The bipartisan “Gang of Eight” that drafted the deal has so far held together. The full committee has rejected an array of amendments designed to cripple or kill the bill, while adopting technical fixes and other amendments to make the system fairer, smarter and more generous.

headline: Climate Warnings, Growing Louder
text: The news that atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide, the most important global warming gas, have hit 400 parts per million for the first time in millions of years increases the pressure on President Obama to deliver on his pledges to limit this country’s greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: The Corporate-Friendly Court
text: There is little doubt, statistically, that the Supreme Court presided over by Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. has been more sympathetic to corporate interests than any court since World War II. A comprehensive study of more than 1,750 decisions from 1946 to 2011, published recently in the Minnesota Law Review, found that the Roberts court has repeatedly shielded business from lawsuits involving class actions, workplace disputes and consumer complaints. (The Times’s Adam Liptak has reported about this and related studies.)

headline: Before You Buy That T-Shirt
text: The deaths and injuries of thousands of garment workers in Bangladesh raise the question of how American and European consumers might assert their power to change appalling factory conditions half a world away. Stop buying clothes made in Bangladesh? Look for labels from other countries, like Indonesia, where conditions might be a little better? Seek out “sweatshop free” clothes, like “fair trade” coffee?

headline: If the Boss Rides a Harley, He Must Be Human
text: This interview with  Harry Herington, chief executive of NIC Inc., a provider of online services for federal, state and local governments, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Hours Before the Race, Tension and Buzz Are Building
text: It’s 8:52 on Preakness morning.

headline: Old-fashioned Austerity
text: Matthew Yglesias piles on Michael Kinsley too, and makes a point I’ve also tried to make in the past: if the real problem is that we overspent and lived beyond our means, we should be working harder, not throwing millions of people into unemployment. Yglesias makes his point with the case of Iceland, which has indeed restored relatively full employment while continuing to suffer somewhat reduced real income.

headline: Trains May Not Run for Days in Crash Area
text: Metro-North and Amtrak train service through New Haven will remain suspended, perhaps for several days, the authorities said Saturday, as investigators continued to seek the cause of a train derailment and collision during the Friday evening rush that injured at least 70 people, five of them critically.

headline: Dueling Jobs (and Big Paydays)
text: ALTHOUGH it carries something of a dubious pedigree, the PennyMac Mortgage Investment Trust has generated pretty good profits for investors since it went public in 2009. Overseen by former executives at Countrywide Financial, ground zero for the subprime mortgage mess, PennyMac has generated a total return of 32 percent to shareholders over that time. Its current annual payout rate of 9 percent is generous among other mortgage real estate investment trusts.

headline: Telling It Like It Is
text: Like many writers, I was interested from a very early age in the relationship between the way a story was told and what it was telling.

headline: Lopez Says He Will Quit Assembly on Monday
text: Facing expulsion from the New York State Legislature over accusations that he sexually harassed several female staff members, a once-powerful assemblyman, Vito J. Lopez, said on Saturday that he would resign on Monday morning.

headline: Big Bets on Many Horses
text: BlackRock, the investment management company, is the largest shareholder in many of the world’s best-known companies.

headline: Rolling Up Their Sleeves, as a Team
text: AS a 14-year-old Boy Scout who went on backpacking trips in western Massachusetts, Gihan Amarasiriwardena couldn’t find a fleece jacket that would protect him from the wind. His solution was to make his own wind-blocking coat from scratch, using plastic garbage bags, spray-on adhesive and fleece.

headline: Coffee Rites, and the Stories They Tell
text: THE caffeine rituals of my co-workers are many and varied. In the morning, there are at least eight places where you can buy coffee on 40th Street in Manhattan between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, including the cart where the lady says “Hi, beautiful!” and puts your $1 cup in a brown paper bag with a little white napkin.

headline: Next Up for the Spurs: A Look in a Mirror
text: In a league dominated by superstars, the San Antonio Spurs built the most mundane of dynasties. There was never any question that Tim Duncan belonged on the short list of the greatest power forwards in N.B.A. history, or that Tony Parker and Manu Ginobili were fantastic players, but the team was seemingly easy to forget in a world of Kobe Bryants and LeBron Jameses.

headline: Pacers’ Hill Is Working His Way Back From Concussion
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Pacers point guard George Hill participated in the team’s shoot-around Saturday as part of the exertion testing he must pass to be cleared to resume play after sustaining a concussion in Game 4 of Indiana’s playoff series against the Knicks.

headline: Cashman and Injury-Riddled Yanks Keep Dealing
text: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman continues to tweak his roster at the margins, making yet another move aimed at upgrading the talent on a team riddled with injuries. Late Friday, he acquired infielder Reid Brignac from the Colorado Rockies for cash and designated Alberto Gonzalez for assignment to make room on the roster.

headline: Confusion and Staff Troubles Rife at I.R.S. Office in Ohio
text: During the summer of 2010, the dozen or so accountants and tax agents of Group 7822 of the Internal Revenue Service office in Cincinnati got a directive from their manager. A growing number of organizations identifying themselves as part of the Tea Party had begun applying for tax exemptions, the manager said, advising the workers to be on the lookout for them and other groups planning to get involved in elections.

headline: Grizzlies Make Up for Lack of Flash With Grit
text: When Tony Allen was interviewed on live television after an otherwise meaningless midseason game in 2011, nobody could have known that he would wind up altering the culture of the Memphis Grizzlies, or that the words he delivered would soon adorn billboards and T-shirts, posters and towels.

headline: Orb Fails to Deliver for Baltimore-Born Owner
text: BALTIMORE — When Orb rallied in the slop May 4 for a Kentucky Derby victory, the first for the trainer Shug McGaughey and the Phipps family, it evoked images of horse racing’s rich past and made it seem as if they had all been there before.

headline: In Shadow of the Stonewall Inn, a Gay Man Is Killed
text: Mark Carson did not hide that he was gay, and when he went out on the town he would often head to Greenwich Village, where years before he was born, much of the struggle for gay liberation unfolded. Yet late Friday night, just blocks from the Stonewall Inn, among the most important landmarks of that struggle, he was confronted with a man screaming antigay slurs, who then stalked him before pulling out a silver revolver and fatally shooting him, the police said.

headline: China Embraces Corporate Social Responsibility
text: With its projects challenged by activists energized by Myanmar’s democratic opening, China has been trying to repair its tarnished reputation.

headline: So Far, the Battery Charger Is Working in Japan
text: A GENERATION ago, Japan was a colossus on any investing map of the world.

headline: A Life-Changing Trip
text: MY parents came from a working-class area in the north of England. Being bohemians at heart and wanting to follow the sun, they quit their jobs in London in the mid-1960s and moved to the Mediterranean coast. I was conceived on the Italian Riviera, in Lerici. My father, a painter, felt that Italy was already overexploited so they moved to Spain. I was born in Barcelona but we lived in a nearby beach town with bad roads and worse water.

headline: What’s ‘Pro-Business’?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Right Corporate Directors
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Medical Bills  Weigh on Job Applicants
text: To the Editor:

headline: What Stock to Buy? Hey, Mom, Don’t Ask Me
text: OVER the last few weeks, as the stock market has reached new highs, my thoughts have turned to my 85-year-old mother.

headline: With Simona De Silvestro
text: With Danica Patrick driving in Nascar full time, Simona De Silvestro is the top woman of IndyCar racing. De Silvestro, a 24-year-old from Switzerland, was trying to qualify this weekend for her fourth Indianapolis 500, which takes place next Sunday. She was rookie of the year in her first Indy 500 in 2010, with a 14th-place finish. Four races into the 2013 season, she is ninth in the IndyCar Series standings after three top-10 finishes. This is her first season with KV Racing Technology.

headline: In Leading the Yankees, Cano Makes His Boss Take Notice
text: Hal Steinbrenner was at Yankee Stadium on Saturday morning, saying hello to players and fans before the Yankees’ game against the Toronto Blue Jays.

headline: Rookie Defensemen Blunt Rangers’ Attacks
text: The result of one Stanley Cup game does not determine a series, but the Rangers will need to make adjustments if they hope to beat the Boston Bruins.

headline: With Mets Back to Being Punchless, Hefner Remains Winless
text: CHICAGO — A pattern has developed for the Mets in this young season: when Jeremy Hefner pitches, the Mets lose.

headline: Sony’s Unwanted Genre: Suspense
text: NOWHERE is the opulence of Old Hollywood more palpable than on the Sony Pictures lot in Culver City. Arching just inside the front gate is an eight-story rainbow. This grand $1.6 million sculpture, a condition of a lot expansion, rose last year and became a symbolic link between past glories — “The Wizard of Oz” was filmed here — and current ones. Years of cutbacks have taken the shine off many studios, which now look like glorified factories. But Sony has preserved its lot as a perfect little movieland town: executive suites overflow with orchids, and cafes border a new park where employees sip lattes and stretch on the grass.

headline: From Germany, Playing a Sport He Once Gave No Thought
text: Several years later, Donald Lutz recalls the scene with a mix of amusement and embarrassment. He was a camper at Major League Baseball’s International European Academy in Italy, and the other teenagers lined up to get the autograph of an instructor. Lutz followed their lead, but he did not know why he should care about having Rod Carew’s name on a baseball.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, May 19
text: “If the next start-up that becomes Facebook happens to be one of our kids, that’s what we are looking for.”

headline: Highlights: Oxbow Derails Orb’s Crown Quest With Win in Preakness Stakes
text: BALTIMORE — Oxbow, one of three starters for the Hall of Fame trainer D. Wayne Lukas, held off Itsmyluckyday by a length and three-quarters to win the 138th running of the Preakness Stakes on Saturday at Pimlico Race Course.

headline: Befitting
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Jean O’Conor not only appears to be making a debut today, but she is also pulling the old switcheroo on us. What starts out as a very good idea becomes a berry good one, if you get my drift.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 19
text: The White House battled several controversies last week, facing questions not only about the September attack in Benghazi, Libya, but also about the targeted scrutiny of conservative groups by the Internal Revenue Service and the seizure of phone records from The Associated Press by the Justice Department.

headline: New York Schools Chief Warns Against Changes
text: Warning that the fate of New York City education was “hanging in the balance,” Dennis M. Walcott, the schools chancellor, suggested on Saturday that the school system was at risk of falling into disarray in the hands of a new mayor.

headline: Concern for Scottish Banks in Independence Effort
text: LONDON — An independent Scotland could find its banks too big to rescue in the event of another crisis, according to a British government report that compares the Scottish financial sector with those of debt-laden Iceland and Cyprus.

headline: The Old Men and the Ice
text: BOSTON — The demands of old age were a theme here on Saturday. On the one hand was the Bruins’ Jaromir Jagr, at 41 the oldest player in the series. On the other was Rangers Coach John Tortorella, talking about how older players were affected by what they did — or didn’t do — during the lockout.

headline: Police Say Officer Mistakenly Killed Hofstra Student in Hostage Standoff
text: A 21-year-old Hofstra University student who was killed in a home invasion on Friday was mistakenly shot in the head by an officer who fired eight times at a man who was holding a gun to the student’s head and then pointed it at him, the police said on Saturday. Seven of the bullets hit the man, who was also killed.

headline: The Health Toll of Immigration
text: BROWNSVILLE, Tex. — Becoming an American can be bad for your health.

headline: Disputed Election Sends Malaysian Politician Back to Fight on the Streets
text: KUANTAN, Malaysia — Not long ago he was flirting with the idea of semiretirement, maybe a teaching job at an American university. But now Anwar Ibrahim, the leader of the Malaysian opposition, former political prisoner and longtime bugbear of the establishment, says those plans are firmly on the shelf.

headline: A Prison Site’s Future Stirs Up the Ghosts of Its Notorious Past
text: MAZE, Northern Ireland — On a quiet country road south of Belfast, only the sudden appearance of a watchtower and portions of walls offer any hint of what was once Europe’s most notorious prison. After the last inmates walked out the gates in 2000, the bulldozers moved in, leaving little of the top security fortress intact.

headline: Coach Says Hagelin ‘Stinks’ on Power Play
text: BOSTON — The Rangers’ power play has been bafflingly ineffective, and one of the biggest mysteries is why the speedy left wing Carl Hagelin does not skate on it. He is the team’s second-highest playoff scorer with 5 points in eight games, its plus-minus leader at plus 5, and a player praised often by Coach John Tortorella.

headline: On Hong Kong Shelves, Illicit Dirt on China’s Elite
text: HONG KONG — Visitors from mainland China climb the narrow stairs to a cramped room here filled with forbidden delights: shelves of scandal-packed exposés about their Communist Party masters.

headline: Switzerland and Sweden to Play for Gold Medal
text: STOCKHOLM — Switzerland will play Sweden in the gold medal game of the International Ice Hockey Federation world championships after beating the United States, 3-0, in the semifinals on Saturday. The Islanders prospect Nino Niederreiter scored the winning goal midway through the second period.

headline: Banned in China, but Popular in Hong Kong
text: These are some of the books, prohibited in China, that have been selling well in bookstores in Hong Kong, according to booksellers.

headline: Two Kings of Racing Spoil Orb’s Bid for Crown
text: BALTIMORE — They are a couple of old guys, D. Wayne Lukas and Gary Stevens, and for nearly 30 years, they have fallen in love on the racetrack, traded harsh words off it and fallen back in love enough times to be made honorary Kardashians. Trainers fire riders. Jockeys cheat on trainers with faster horses.

headline: A Sampling of Pakistan’s Troubles
text: A train journey across Pakistan presents sweeping landscapes and troubling images of a country plagued by natural disasters; sectarian, nationalist and Islamist violence; poverty; and corruption.

headline: Pakistan, as Seen Through Its Railways
text: At every major stop on the long line from Peshawar to the turbulent port city of Karachi lie reminders of why the country is a worry to its people, and to the wider world.

headline: After Decades of Neglect, Pakistan Rusts in Its Tracks
text: RUK, Pakistan — Resplendent in his gleaming white uniform and peaked cap, jacket buttons tugging his plump girth, the stationmaster stood at the platform, waiting for a train that would never come. “Cutbacks,” Nisar Ahmed Abro said with a resigned shrug.

headline: Criticism of Veterans Affairs Secretary Mounts Over Backlog in Claims
text: The 30-second Web video has the edgy quality of a campaign-season attack ad, including ominous music, grainy photos and a closing demand: “It’s time for new leadership.”

headline: Seeing Transparency as a Burden
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: As Towns Say No, Signs of Rising Resistance to Smart Meters
text: BRADY, Tex. — In October, the City Council of this Central Texas town voted unanimously to purchase advanced electric meters, known as smart meters, for the city-owned electric utility. But some residents resisted, and the smart meter vote played a large role in last weekend’s recall of the city’s mayor and the electoral defeat of two council members.

headline: With Cliburn Gone, Competition Tries to Adjust
text: On Wednesday, 30 pianists from 13 countries will gather at a hotel ballroom in downtown Fort Worth for a drawing of names, a tradition that will establish the performance schedule for the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition.

headline: Kenneth Waltz, Foreign-Relations Expert, Dies at 88
text: Kenneth N. Waltz, a pre-eminent thinker on international relations who was known for his contrarian, debate-provoking ideas, not least his view that stability in the Middle East might be better served if Iran had a nuclear weapon, died on May 12 in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: With Consensus and Money, State Takes on Mental Health Care
text: SAN ANTONIO — Ray Gutierrez’s green eyes twinkle and his cheeks dimple with a shy smile when he looks across the table at Evita Morin, the former intake worker at Haven for Hope, who he said helped save his life.

headline: Christine White, Actress in a Classic ‘Twilight Zone,’ Dies at 86
text: Julia Wilson wore pearls and a face of reassurance as she and her husband, Robert, took their seats on an airplane operated by Gold Star Airways half a century ago. Robert Wilson had just been released from a sanitarium. Six months earlier he had suffered a mental breakdown — on an airplane.

headline: U.S. Titles End Up in Familiar Hands
text: Gata Kamsky and Irina Krush have turned the United States Championships into something of their personal playground in the last several years, and this year was no different.

headline: Joseph Farman, 82, Is Dead; Discovered Ozone Hole
text: Joseph Farman, a British researcher whose single-minded and at times officially derided study of atmospheric changes in the Antarctic established the existence of a hole in the ozone layer over the South Pole approximately the size of the United States — one of the most important environmental discoveries of the 20th century — died on May 11 in Cambridge, England. He was 82.

headline: William Miles, Maker of Films About Black History, Dies at 82
text: William Miles, a self-taught filmmaker whose documentaries revealed untold stories of black America, including those of its heroic black soldiers and of life in its signature neighborhood, Harlem, where he himself grew up, died on May 12 in Queens. He was 82.

headline: Amenities in the Sky
text: A new apartment building being constructed at 432 Park Avenue will be the tallest residential building in the Western hemisphere.

headline: Sky High and Going Up Fast: Luxury Towers Take New York
text: Only 10 floors have been completed in what is intended to be the tallest residential building in the Western Hemisphere — a slender, 84-story tower on Park Avenue at 56th Street in Manhattan. But the top penthouse is already under contract for $95 million.

headline: Bullet Kills Girl, 14, Riding M.T.A. Bus in Queens
text: A 14-year-old girl was shot in the head and killed on Saturday evening as she rode a Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus in Queens, the police said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 19
text: “The I.R.S. is pretty dysfunctional to begin with, and this case brought all those dysfunctions to their worst.”

headline: Knicks’ Path Through Playoffs Is Blocked
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Carmelo Anthony launched himself from the baseline, rising swiftly, his arm cocked, his eyes on the rim, carrying the Knicks’ playoff existence, a city’s hopes and his own postseason legacy with him. In that moment, ever so briefly, all things still seemed possible: A date with the Miami Heat. A run to the finals. A championship.

headline: George Johnston, Eric Price
text: George William Johnston and Eric Quinn Price were married Saturday on Gibson Island in Maryland. Judge M. Brooke Murdock of Baltimore Circuit Court officiated at the home of Jonathan Hyde, a friend of the couple.

headline: Daniel S. Chao, Jeffrey E. Berkowitz
text: Daniel See Chao and Jeffrey Edward Berkowitz are to be married Sunday evening at Oxon Hill Manor, an event space in Fort Washington, Md. Rabbi Erica Asch is to officiate.

headline: Stephanie Wertkin, Zachary Gold
text: Stephanie Bess Wertkin and Zachary Robin Gold were married Saturday evening at Water’s Edge, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Melissa Zalkin Stollman officiated.

headline: Andrea Lofgren, William Schneider
text: Andrea Ruth Lofgren and William Joseph Schneider were married Saturday at Battery Gardens, a restaurant and event space in Manhattan. Sara Curtin, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Colleen Darnall, Zachary Dietz
text: Colleen Rebecca Darnall and Zachary Dale Dietz were married Monday by the Rev. Gary B. Putnam, a United Methodist minister, at the Full Moon Resort in Big Indian, N.Y.

headline: Sara Lindenbaum, Joshua Goldfarb
text: Sara Elizabeth Lindenbaum is to be married Sunday to Capt. Joshua Lawrence Goldfarb. Rabbi Philip Billy Lewkowicz is to officiate at the Omni Tucson National Resort, a hotel in Tucson, with Cantor Avraham Alpert taking part.

headline: Carol Duh, Terence Leong
text: Carol Jiarou Duh and Terence Yuwen Leong were married Saturday at the Central Park Conservatory Garden in New York. Monica Weiss, an officiant of the American Ethical Union, officiated, with Joan Javier-Duval, a candidate for ministry with the Universal Unitarian Church, assisting.

headline: Alexandra Tegenborg, James Weichert Jr.
text: Alexandra French Tegenborg, a daughter of Patricia L. French of Bedminster, N.J., and Lars A. Tegenborg of Rutherford, N.J., was married Saturday to James Martin Weichert Jr., the son of Pamela M. Weichert and Mr. Weichert of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Patrick G. O’Donovan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, where he is the pastor.

headline: Sarah Nam, Gordon Liao
text: Sarah Hyunee Nam and Gordon Yu Liao were married Saturday at Harvard’s Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Jonathan L. Walton, a Baptist minister and the Pusey Minister of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Glenna Gross, Daniel Fix
text: Glenna Drew Gross, a daughter of Kim Johnson Gross and David E. Gross, both of Rye, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Daniel Brett Fix, a son of Barbara Fix of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Milton S. Fix. Rabbi Israel Singer is to officiate at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

headline: Alix Rogers, John Flynn
text: Janine Alix Rogers and John Patrick Flynn were married Saturday at the Old Marylebone Town Hall in London. Mark Tiller, a ceremonies and registration officer, officiated. Next Sunday, the Rev. Louise L. Kingston, an Episcopal priest and an aunt of the groom, will perform a second ceremony at the Villa Cortine Palace Hotel in Sirmione, Italy, before friends and family.

headline: Dina Gordon, Robert Kinner
text: Dina Gordon and Dr. Robert Luke Kinner were married Saturday in Philadelphia. Gabrielle Kaplan-Mayer, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts.

headline: Daphne Hasbani and J.J. Balaban
text: Dr. Daphne Maya Hasbani and Jack Jeffrey Balaban are to be married Sunday. Rabbi Lauren Grabelle Herrmann is to perform the ceremony at the Cira Center in Philadelphia.

headline: Alexandra Epstein and William Gordon
text: Dr. Alexandra Sara Epstein, the daughter of Dr. Karen T. Isselbacher and Dr. Alan Epstein of Newton, Mass., was married Saturday evening to Dr. William Joseph Gordon, the son of Stasi A. Lubansky and Dr. Bruce R. Gordon of New York. Rabbi Elias J. Lieberman officiated at the Seaport Hotel in Boston.

headline: Kurt Roggin, Jimmy Serrano
text: Kurt Landon Roggin and Jimmy Israel Serrano were married Saturday at the Plaza Hotel in New York. Lisa Traina, who was ordained by the Life Unification Church, officiated.

headline: Alice Suh, Edward Jou
text: Alice Jean Suh and Edward Shih-Tong Jou were married Saturday at the Hotel Monaco in Washington. The Rev. Heather Sawyer Zempel, a minister of the National Community Church, officiated.

headline: Paulette Aniskoff, Matthew Tinning
text: Paulette LaRay Aniskoff and Matthew Reid Tinning were married Saturday evening at WeatherLea Farm and Vineyard in Lovettsville, Va. Malcolm Forbes Baldwin, the owner of the farm and a civil celebrant licensed by the County of Loudoun, Va., officiated.

headline: Rachael Shapiro, Daniel Lipton
text: Rachael Adams Shapiro and Daniel Seth Lipton are to be married Sunday at India House, a private club in New York. Sheera Ben-David, a cantor and friend of the couple, is to officiate.

headline: Sara Nelson and Sam Radin
text: Sara Nelson and Sam Radin were married Friday evening at the Century Association in Manhattan. Ira Silverberg, a Universal Life minister and friend of the couple, officiated.

headline: Genevieve Thornton and Grey Baker
text: Genevieve Marie Thornton, the daughter of Linda and Peter Thornton of Bronxville, N.Y., was married Saturday to Grey Donaldson Baker, a son of Kathryn and Geoffrey Baker of Washington. Canon Norman N. Lynas, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Church in Hamilton Parish, Bermuda.

headline: Hsin-Mei Hsu, Oscar Tang
text: Hsin-Mei Agnes Hsu and Oscar Liu-Chien Tang were married Saturday in Irvington, Va. The Rev. Dr. Barbara A. Cullom, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at Historic Christ Church.

headline: Sarah Pickard, Philip Michaelson
text: Sarah Naree Pickard and Philip Aaron Michaelson were married Saturday evening at the Birchwood Country Club in Westport, Conn. Rabbi Mark Lipson officiated.

headline: Salua Baida, David Mack
text: Salua Vianeey Baida, a daughter of Maria de los Angeles Baida of El Paso, Tex., and the late Miguel Baida Nazif, was married Friday evening at the Dyker Beach Golf Course in Brooklyn to David Joseph Mack, the son of Irene Pasyanos and Fredric E. Mack, both of Middletown, R.I. Hope Mirlis, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated.

headline: Crystal Hung, Ronald Ho
text: Dr. Crystal Hung and Ronald Ho were married Tuesday at San Francisco City Hall. Estrella Bryant, a deputy marriage commissioner for San Francisco County, officiated.

headline: Alpana Gowda, Rajat Batra
text: Dr. Alpana Raghava Gowda and Rajat Batra were married Saturday at the Peterloon Mansion in Cincinnati. Pandit Ramesh Rajamani officiated.

headline: Katharine Bosland, Royal Kastens III
text: Katharine MacLean Bosland and Royal Frederick Kastens III were married Saturday in Richmond, Va. The Rev. Nicholas G. Bacalis performed the ceremony at SS. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Cathedral.

headline: Stephanie Janssen, Wallace Krantz Jr.
text: Stephanie Ann Janssen and Wallace Eugene Krantz Jr. are to be married Sunday evening at the Green Building, an event space in Brooklyn. Emily N. Voorhees, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, is to officiate.

headline: Thomas Mizer, Travis McGhie
text: Thomas Patrick Mizer and Matthew Travis McGhie were married Saturday at the Castello Plan, a wine bar in Brooklyn. Nicole Burley, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Alison Jill Rauch, Martin Seth Burger
text: Alison Jill Rauch and Martin Seth Burger were married Saturday evening at Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi David J. Gelfand officiated.

headline: Melody Calvo, Reeve Hohlt
text: Melody Ann Calvo and Reeve Canfield Hohlt were married Saturday at Meadowood Napa Valley, a resort in St. Helena, Calif. Kimberly Thompson, a California marriage commissioner, officiated.

headline: Caitlin Elen, Louis Morin III
text: Caitlin Marie Elen, the daughter of Leslie Elen and Robert W. Elen of Los Angeles, was married Saturday evening to Capt. Louis George Morin III, the son of Doris K. Morin of Irvington, N.Y., and Mr. Morin Jr. of New York. The Rev. Dr. Robert A. Schuller, a minister with the Reformed Church in America, and the son of the televangelist Robert H. Schuller, officiated at the Lakeside Golf Club in Burbank, Calif.

headline: Aja Falker and Shukree Tilghman
text: Aja Iman Falker and Shukree Hassan Tilghman were married Saturday at Central Baptist Church in St. Louis. The Rev. Dr. Robert Charles Scott, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Ashley Ford, Patrick Haggerty
text: Dr. Ashley Elizabeth Ford, the daughter of Dorothy A. Ford and Jack R. Ford of Spring Lake, N.J., was married Saturday to Patrick Andrew Haggerty, a son of Janice Haggerty and Daniel L. Haggerty of Lawrenceville, N.J. The Rev. Msgr. Thomas A. Luebking, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Catharine Church in Spring Lake, with the Rev. Raymond A. Schroth, also a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the groom, taking part.

headline: It All Led Up to the Ringing of Bells
text: Diana Al-Hadid and Jonathan Sinclair Lott are to be married Sunday at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens. Bruce Smith, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

headline: A Scientist and the Value of Meddling
text: Alexandra Buck McCullagh and Riley Sutthoff Newman were married Saturday at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco. The Rev. Jude A. Harmon, an Episcopal priest and a minor canon at the cathedral, performed the ceremony.

headline: Carolina Aguilar and Julian Dawes
text: Carolina Hildegard Aguilar, the daughter of Renate Porges de Aguilar and Carlos F. Aguilar of Comus, Md., was married there Saturday evening to Julian Morgan Dawes, a son of Nicholas M. Dawes and Rosemarie Dawes of Millburn, N.J. Gordon Ron Tomlinson, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life Minister for the occasion, officiated at a farm owned by the bride’s family.
