headline: Mistrial Set in Penalty for a Killer in Arizona
text: PHOENIX — It took jurors 15 hours to convict Jodi Arias of first-degree murder in the 2008 killing of a former boyfriend, and less than three hours to deem her eligible for the death penalty. When it came time to decide her punishment, though, they could not agree, leaving the judge no option Thursday afternoon but to declare a mistrial in the penalty phase of the trial.

headline: Additional Embassy Guards Will Come With a Steep Price
text: WASHINGTON — When the State Department fields the first of 350 additional Marine security guards at high-risk embassies and consulates around the world later this year, the price tag will be steep: about $1.6 million per Marine.

headline: Quirks of the Game: How Tennis Got Its Scoring System
text: When Billie Jean King was first learning about tennis, she said, her coach explained that the point system went, “15, then 30” at which point the eager and exuberant student proclaimed, “and then 45, right?”

headline: Growth in Options Trading Helps Brokers but Not Small Investors
text: Some of the brokerage firms that helped pique American’s interest in stocks are now luring them into something much riskier: stock options.

headline: Can a Tree Grow in the Bronx?
text: LAST week the Central Park Conservancy, the nonprofit group that manages Central Park, announced a $40 million fund-raising campaign to improve the park’s playgrounds, an initiative that will surely benefit thousands of children who play in the park.

headline: Abscesses Reported After Steroid Injections
text: At least seven people have reported complications after being injected with a potentially contaminated medication made in a pharmacy in Tennessee, federal and state health officials said. The Food and Drug Administration said that it had not yet determined the nature of the illnesses, but that at least one person seemed to have a fungal infection. Last fall, fungal contamination of the same type of medication, an injectable steroid produced by a compounding pharmacy in Massachusetts, caused the deaths of more than 50 people. Officials in North Carolina, where two of the new cases were found, said that the symptoms were skin abscesses and that there had been no reports of meningitis, stroke or other life-threatening conditions. Illinois said it was investigating five cases of patients who developed abscesses after receiving the medication, which is used to treat back pain and swelling in joints, among other conditions.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Off the Charts: Under Obama, Stocks Do Better
text: President Obama this month became the fifth president to have the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index double from the level when he took office.

headline: On the Front Lines of Food Safety
text: MOSS LANDING, Calif. — With piles of fresh strawberries beckoning consumers at markets and stores this season, an alliance of a major retailer, fruit growers and farm workers has begun a program to promote healthy produce and improve working conditions.

headline: Lessons in Emoting From an Oblivious Teacher
text: There is a funny thing about fame. It shows. It is written all over Sarah when she bursts through the door in Charles Evered’s “Class,” an alluring if sentimental one-act drama having its New York premiere at the Penguin Rep Theater.

headline: To Rescue Survivors, He Pursued the Storm
text: MOORE, Okla. — Phillip Wise on Monday chased one of the most ferocious tornadoes to touch down in Oklahoma in years. Through his windshield from a half-mile out, the Category 5 twister was not so much a funnel but a shapeless, swirling wall of mud, pieces of homes, and airborne cars and horses.

headline: Measured by S.&P. Returns, Obama Is on a Short List
text: IN the 84 years that the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index has been calculated, it doubled during the terms of only four presidents before Barack Obama’s election in 2008. This month that number rose to five as the index climbed to more than twice what it was when he took office.

headline: Raiding the Keokuk
text: Late on an April night in 1863 a flotilla of small boats circled a partially sunken ship off the coast of Morris Island, S.C., not far from Fort Sumter in Charleston Harbor. Soon two iron towers studded with bolts rose like islands from the dark waters. Onboard the ship, a Union ironclad called the Keokuk – sunk a few days before in the failed Union attempt to bombard Fort Sumter into submission – stood several men, silently waiting, their eyes on Adolphus W. LaCoste, the civilian in charge of the Confederate salvage operation. His hand raised, they held their breath as a Union picket boat rowed past, towards the lights of the blockading fleet. As the voices of the rowers faded, LaCoste gave the signal to resume. In water up to their waists, with hands and wrenches tugging and turning, they strained at the armored decks over the guns of the sunken ironclad. They had one thing in mind: the guns.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire Does the Clash
text: No particular reason, but found this running through my head at the end of a crazy day. Some love it, some hate it; but the dedication and respect are something to watch.

headline: The Women Versus the Ted
text: Let’s discuss how much better Congress would work if most of the members were women.

headline: Messy Fight Over Mandela Trust Goes Public
text: JOHANNESBURG — Nelson Mandela was livid. He believed that two of his daughters, working with a lawyer he had recently fired, were trying to meddle in his financial affairs. So he summoned the daughters, Makaziwe Mandela and Zenani Dlamini, to his home here for a family meeting in April 2005. According to two people present, he gave them a withering talking-to.

headline: Hometown Driver Now a Local Hero
text: INDIANAPOLIS — After Ed Carpenter won the pole for Sunday’s Indianapolis 500 last weekend with a blistering speed of 228.762 miles per hour, he celebrated by taking a police escort from the Indianapolis Motor Speedway to Bankers Life Fieldhouse. There he watched his favorite basketball team, the Pacers, dispatch the Knicks in Game 6 of the teams’ Eastern Conference semifinal.

headline: For Obama’s Global Vision, Daunting Problems
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, in one of his most significant speeches since taking office, did not simply declare an end to the post-9/11 era on Thursday. He also offered a vision of America’s role in the world that he hopes could be one of his lasting legacies.

headline: Ailing Bridges, Budget Woes
text: The bridge that collapsed near Seattle is part of a nationwide infrastructure that some say is crumbling beneath us.

headline: Press Sees Chilling Effect in Justice Dept. Inquiries
text: President Obama’s conciliatory gesture toward the press this week — a review of Justice Department investigations involving journalists — struck some national security reporters as closing the door after the sources have already bolted.

headline: Fox Overseer of ‘Idol’ and Its Kin Will Depart
text: Not only is “American Idol” expected to lose all four of its judges, it is also bidding adieu to Mike Darnell, the Fox executive who judged correctly at the very beginning that the show would be a hit.

headline: Recalling a Girl, 14, Laughing, Before She Was Shot on a Bus
text: Standing before hundreds of mourners at a church in Jamaica, Queens, on Friday, Shaquanna Almonds told the family and friends of 14-year-old D’aja Robinson about her last moments.

headline: A Lot of Elephants in the Room
text: Some people have been waiting to see the house in “Clybourne Park” for 50 years. And there it is, on Long Wharf Theater’s Mainstage — not at its best, because the owners are leaving and the living room is strewn with moving boxes. But look at all that space and the handsome wooden staircase and the door that leads to a real backyard. No wonder Lena Younger, the heroine of Lorraine Hansberry’s seminal 1959 drama “A Raisin in the Sun,” was so proud to be able to move her five-member family there, after living in a cramped two-bedroom apartment on the South Side of Chicago. To hell with the fact that everybody else in the neighborhood was white.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Simple or Impossible
text: My last contribution to The Times was on a dead man. I now try to write about a living art.

headline: Good News for Teixeira, Not as Good for Nova
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Shortly before Joe Girardi announced that Ivan Nova had been demoted from the starting rotation, Nova spoke at his locker in the visitors’ clubhouse at Tropicana Field. Two lockers away, the rookie Vidal Nuno, who will start Saturday, sat and watched.

headline: Battle for Syrian Town Spurs Sectarian Fighting in Northern Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The all-out battle for the Syrian town of Qusayr, pitting the Lebanese Shiite Muslim militant group Hezbollah and Syrian armed forces against Sunni Muslim rebels, has spurred the worst sectarian fighting in years in the north of Lebanon.

headline: Russia: Earthquake Hits Eastern Coast
text: An 8.3-magnitude earthquake struck Russia’s Far East on Friday, sending tremors that prompted evacuations as far away as Moscow, more than 4,000 miles to the west of the epicenter. The United States Geological Survey recorded the earthquake at 5:44 p.m. local time at a depth of approximately 373 miles below the Sea of Okhotsk, off the coast of the Kamchatka Peninsula. Officials initially told residents on Sakhalin and the Kurile Islands to head for higher ground in case of a tsunami. Russia’s Emergency Ministry later lifted the tsunami warning and said in a statement that no injuries had been reported. Tremors were felt in more than a dozen regions spanning Russia; in Moscow, local law enforcement officers evacuated 850 people from two apartment buildings after residents said the buildings were shaking.

headline: Impressionists of the Coast
text: The Jersey Shore attracted Impressionist painters starting in the late 19th century, along with other areas in the Northeast like Cos Cob, Conn., and New Hope, Pa. But while the artists’ communities of Cos Cob and New Hope were rediscovered in the late 1970s and the 1980s, those of the Jersey Shore were “generally overlooked” by art scholars, according to Richard Boyle, a historian and former director of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia.

headline: France: Investigators Tie I.M.F. Chief to Fraud Inquiry Involving Sarkozy
text: Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, was made an “assisted witness” on Friday in an investigation by French judges into allegations of possible fraud and misuse of public funds that date from her time as finance minister. As an assisted witness, Ms. Lagarde has not been placed under formal investigation but is considered to have been closely implicated in the case, which involves a half-billion-dollar state payout to Bernard Tapie, a businessman and politician who once served time in prison for his involvement in the fixing of soccer matches. Ms. Lagarde oversaw that payout in 2007 and 2008, while serving as finance minister under President Nicolas Sarkozy, whose candidacy Mr. Tapie had supported. The board of the International Monetary Fund has expressed its confidence in Ms. Lagarde. In a statement Friday, she said she had “always acted in the best public interest and in accordance with the law.”

headline: Goalie Loses His Balance but Keeps Sense of Humor
text: BOSTON — He has seen the replay more times than he would care to remember. He has gone over the play countless times in his mind. And every time, the reaction is the same.

headline: Little Debate on Big Issues in Race to Fill Kerry’s Seat
text: BOSTON — For an election that was supposed to be about the big issues of the day, the special election in Massachusetts to fill the Senate seat vacated by John Kerry seems to be about everything but.

headline: Canada: Mayor Denies Drug Allegations
text: After a week of avoiding journalists, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto on Friday denied accusations that he smoked crack cocaine. “I do not use crack cocaine, nor am I an addict of crack cocaine,” Mr. Ford, left, said as he read a statement during a brief news conference. He did not take questions. Last week Mr. Ford dismissed as “ridiculous” reports by The Toronto Star and the Web site Gawker that their reporters had viewed a video recording of Mr. Ford that appeared to show him smoking crack cocaine. The two organizations said they were shown the recording by drug dealers who hoped to sell it. The mayor’s statement followed the release of an open letter from six of Mr. Ford’s allies on the City Council asking him to address the reports. Some other members of the council told reporters on Friday that they found the mayor’s statement inadequate, given his history of initially denying embarrassing episodes only to later acknowledge the accusations as true.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Judge Finds Violations of Rights by Sheriff
text: PHOENIX — A federal judge ruled on Friday that Sheriff Joe Arpaio and his deputies had violated the constitutional rights of Latinos by targeting them during raids and traffic stops here and throughout Maricopa County.

headline: Strategic Ignorance
text: In an age when knowledge is power, restricting knowledge is a power grab, creating the conditions of ignorance that allow bias, ideology and propaganda to flourish, unchallenged and unchecked.

headline: Get Churches Out of Public Schools
text: New York City prohibits the use of public school facilities for regular religious services. That policy makes sense for buildings that are used and maintained by taxpayers. But the City Council wants to eliminate that policy through a new state law. It voted 38 to 11 on Wednesday to pass a resolution asking the Legislature and Gov. Andrew Cuomo to approve legislation to permit religious services on public school properties when they are not in use.

headline: Deception on Gun Background Checks
text: A strange thing happened after 45 senators killed a bill to expand background checks for gun buyers five weeks ago: many of those same senators suddenly discovered a profound affection for background checks. They had been for them all along, it turns out, and wanted nothing more than to keep guns out of the hands of felons.

headline: Exercise and Academic Performance
text: As schools everywhere strive to improve the academic performance of their students, many have cut physical education and recess periods to leave more time for sedentary classroom instruction. A sensible new report from the Institute of Medicine, a unit of the National Academy of Sciences, shows how shortsighted this trend can be. It found that exercise can significantly improve children’s cognitive abilities and their academic performance, as well as their health.

headline: Rangers Ask a Do-It-All Defenseman to Do a Little More
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — A potential solution to the Rangers’ power-play woes surfaced in Game 4 against the Boston Bruins, and Coach John Tortorella only wished he had thought of it earlier. After all, it seemed so obvious.

headline: As Tourists Come and Go, Harlem Churches Lose a 10% Lifeblood
text: The tourists started lining up two hours before morning worship service on West 116th Street in Harlem. Most were dressed in everyday clothes, contrasting with the dark suits and prim dresses of the largely African-American congregation in the historic sanctuary of Canaan Baptist Church of Christ.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Vows: Emmania and Henry
text: Teenagers from separate worlds fell in love playing Dance, Dance Revolution. Henry Blum proposed to Emmania Rodriguez by installing an arcade version of the game in his grandmother’s basement.

headline: Creating Order From Chaos
text: As Syrians flee their homes, many end up in the sprawling refugee camp in Zaatari, Jordan. Kilian Kleinschmidt is tasked with settling thousands of families facing an uncertain future.

headline: Subway Doors Slammed Shut Just in Time to Save Her
text: Off the platform at the first station on the downtown No. 4 line is an office for subway employees, with cubbies for their bags, bulletin boards, video monitors and a break room. The conductor arrived for her late shift at 1:20 a.m. and signed in. Fifteen minutes later, her work began. She greeted the train operator — they are no longer known as motormen — in the first car before taking her place in the booth in the sixth, in the middle of the train. It left the terminal to begin its long journey through the Bronx and Manhattan to Brooklyn.

headline: This Is Not 2009
text: With the scent of scandal encircling the White House, some Republicans are already licking their chops over the 2014 midterm elections, while some Democrats are pre-emptively licking their wounds.

headline: Calm Boss Overseeing a Syrian Refugee Camp’s Chaos
text: ZAATARI, Jordan — Kilian Kleinschmidt had a problem. The afternoon before Kuwait’s ambassador to Jordan was scheduled to visit the overcrowded Syrian refugee camp here, children vandalized mobile homes that Kuwait had donated, stealing windows, doors and floor mats.

headline: Where a Tribe’s History Comes to Life
text: On a recent afternoon, Jason Johnson, clad in buckskin leggings, a breechcloth and a headdress of turkey feathers, was tending a fire and stripping the bark from tupelo logs in a wooded, two-acre plot behind the Shinnecock Nation Cultural Center and Museum in Southampton.

headline: Dispute Over Budget Deepens a Rift Within the G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans are locked in a widening internal dispute over future budget negotiations, splitting along generational and ideological lines on the party’s approach to the central issue that drove the conservative surge in the Obama era: how to deal with the federal debt.

headline: Corrections: May 25, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: They’re Tan and Toned, but They’re Not Very Nice
text: Mick is sick of the city. He misses lightning bugs and children on lawns and driving. And the New Yorkers in Joshua Conkel’s comedy “I Wanna Destroy You” are so hideous that you almost have to agree with him.

headline: Irreverent Sermonettes
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I don’t believe I’ve had an easier and more fun entry into a Saturday puzzle in, well, ever. PURPLE HAZE is “all in my brain,” and even if you were never a fan of Jimi Hendrix, I’m sure you know this classic rock song. It was enough to get me rocking and laughing at one of my favorite clue/entry pairings in a long time: a “labor leader’s cry” might be “PUSH!” and if you’re like me, the response is likely to be to grab the labor leader by the collar and shriek “Shut up!  More ice chips!”

headline: New Alliance Emerges to Tighten Chemical Rules
text: WASHINGTON — The first credible effort in years to revamp the nation’s outmoded chemical safety law grew in part from the Senate’s failure in April to enact a gun buyer background check bill.

headline: The Power Behind Manchester City Is Content to Stay Out of Sight in New York
text: The setting was modest, the mood jovial, the dignitaries on hand pretty impressive. In the school cafeteria of P.S. 72 in East Harlem on Wednesday morning, professional soccer was nudged forward in New York City, with talk of a new team with prestigious owners and a new stadium designed specifically for the sport.

headline: Obama’s Gitmo Problem
text: Late Wednesday afternoon, less than 24 hours before President Obama made his big national security speech — in which he said, for the umpteenth time, that the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, should be closed — a group of American lawyers representing Guantánamo detainees filed an emergency motion with the Federal District Court in the District of Columbia. The motion asked the court to order the removal of “unjustified burdens” that the military command at Guantánamo has placed on the detainees, making it nearly impossible for them to meet with their lawyers.

headline: Mexican Official Defends Accuracy of Data on Organized Crime
text: MEXICO CITY — Rejecting concerns that the government’s statistics were foggier than ever, Mexico’s top security official argued Friday that real progress was being made in reducing organized crime killings and that the number of people previously reported missing was inflated.

headline: All of City’s Public Swimming Beaches to Reopen by Memorial Day
text: Under leaden skies, officials on Friday fulfilled a pledge made after Hurricane Sandy wreaked havoc on 14 miles of New York City beaches, announcing that all eight public swimming beaches would reopen in time for Memorial Day.

headline: Burgers and the Big Talk
text: The doors were thrown open onto Lenox Avenue’s broad sidewalk, Michael Jackson boomed from the sound system — sometimes life in the big city isn’t so hard. Harlem Shake, which opened at 124th Street and Lenox Avenue earlier this month, already has lines out the door and unreasonable waits for its burgers and shakes. But on a summery evening last week, no one seemed to mind. The décor is retro diner, the restroom an homage to Jet magazine covers past. It’s what you’d expect a Harlem-themed restaurant in Tokyo to look like transported to Harlem. The principal owner Jelena Pasic, 38, said that the neighborhood reminds her of the small island in Croatia where she grew up. “People are much more personal than in the rest of New York,” she said. Proof that the restaurant isn’t located somewhere out of town: kale salad on the menu.

headline: New Computer Attacks Traced to Iran, Officials Say
text: SAN FRANCISCO — American officials and corporate security experts examining a new wave of potentially destructive computer attacks striking American corporations, especially energy firms, say they have tracked the attacks back to Iran.

headline: For Now, Davis’s Struggles Stay in the Major Leagues
text: After a day off for the Mets, Manager Terry Collins returned to Citi Field on Friday afternoon and picked up where he left off, answering questions about the job security of Ike Davis, the team’s struggling first baseman.

headline: States’ Policies on Health Care Exclude Some of the Poorest
text: WASHINGTON — The refusal by about half the states to expand Medicaid will leave millions of poor people ineligible for government-subsidized health insurance under President Obama’s health care law even as many others with higher incomes receive federal subsidies to buy insurance.

headline: Running a League, From Behind the Plate
text: Rich Ritchie is the commissioner of the Queens Lighted Softball Association, a nighttime league of which he is also the chief umpire.

headline: Softball’s Iron Fist
text: Rich Ritchie, 61, has been organizing ballgames since he was a kid.

headline: Doctor Gets Eight Years in L.I.R.R. Fraud Scheme
text: A Long Island doctor was sentenced Friday to eight years in prison for his role in a fraud scheme that allowed hundreds of retired Long Island Rail Road workers to collect disability benefits to which they were not entitled.

headline: Kentucky Operator to Cease Enrichment of Uranium
text: WASHINGTON — The only American-owned plant for enriching uranium, a cold war relic near Paducah, Ky., will be shut down next month, its operator said on Friday. The closing could pose a problem for the American nuclear weapons arsenal over time but is not likely to affect civilian nuclear electric plants.

headline: ‘Oklahomans Don’t Stop Fighting’
text: Several Moore, Okla., residents, whose lives were somehow connected by Monday’s tornado and its aftermath, shared their experiences of enduring the storm.

headline: Bill on College Financial Aid for Undocumented Students Seems Stalled in Albany
text: As immigration legislation moves forward on Capitol Hill, generating widespread debate and providing glimpses of an emerging bipartisan consensus, a less ambitious effort in Albany is playing out differently.

headline: Some of His Best Customers Are Canine
text: Pete Van Leeuwen started Van Leeuwen Artisan Ice Cream in 2008 with his brother Ben, their partner, Laura O’Neill, and two classic yellow trucks. Now in their sixth year of business, they have six trucks and three stores in Brooklyn and Manhattan, as well as a Balinese restaurant (Selamat Pagi) in the front of their production facility. The first summer Mr. Van Leeuwen drove around, scooping ice cream. These days, with the food truck boom in New York City and their growing business — just this week they introduced vegan ice cream — Mr. Van Leeuwen, 36, spends his time organizing and troubleshooting, with occasional breaks for a pistachio cone, his favorite flavor.

headline: Rangers Game and Wedding Form a Blissful Union
text: For the longtime Rangers season-ticket holders Phil and Joan Boening and their two sons, Justin and James, tensions were agonizingly high Thursday evening.

headline: Militant Says He Is Behind Attack in Niger
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Mokhtar Belmokhtar, the mastermind of the January seizure of an Algerian gas plant that left dozens of foreign hostages dead, has claimed responsibility for another terrorist attack: the suicide bombings on Thursday in Niger that killed about 30 people, including 24 soldiers and at least six jihadists.

headline: Come 5:30, She’s on the Bus
text: Some people go to great lengths to avoid getting stuck in Long Island beach traffic. Marianna Scandole does it for a living. Ms. Scandole, 26, is a host on the Hampton Jitney and the Hampton Ambassador, which carry lower- and higher-paying passengers through some of the region’s most illustrious clogged arteries. For Ms. Scandole, who previously worked as a nanny, the job is something of a career trial balloon. “I want to become a flight attendant, so I thought that would be an excellent way to get some practice in,” she said. She lives with her mother and younger sister in Hampton Bays.

headline: As Lacrosse Grows, the Diversity of Players Remains Largely Unchanged
text: On a team in Southern California, more than 2,500 miles from the center of lacrosse’s universe on the Eastern Seaboard, Kyle Harrison no longer feels unsettled.

headline: Ex-Guatemalan President Extradited to U.S. in Corruption Case
text: MEXICO CITY — Guatemalan officials rousted an imprisoned former president on Friday, loaded him onto a jet and whisked him to New York to face long-pending corruption charges.

headline: Carousel Horses Return Home to Brooklyn
text: This weekend, the B&B Carousell horses will once again spin in the salubrious breezes on Coney Island.

headline: Time Lapse: The Making of a Carousel
text: As a part of Coney Island’s makeover, the B&B Carousell was dismantled and restored at a facility in Ohio. Workers reassembled the antique wooden carousel over several days in May.

headline: Summer’s Steeds, Back Home
text: One at a time, they loaded the horses into the truck. The dapple grays and the chestnut mares were maneuvered onto a tractor-trailer where they nestled snugly together, wrapped in moving blankets.

headline: Rio Struggles With Sex Crimes
text: Sexual assaults in Rio de Janeiro have cast a light on class differences in the city and have raised fears for women’s safety ahead of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Summer Olympics.

headline: Public Rapes Outrage Brazil, Testing Ideas of Image and Class
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The attacks have stunned this city. In one, an assailant held a gun to the head of a 30-year-old woman while raping her in front of passengers on a bus as the driver proceeded down a main avenue. In another, a 14-year-old girl from a hillside slum was raped on one of Rio’s most famous stretches of beach.

headline: Yankees End Two-Game Skid but Lose Granderson to Injury
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — In a season characterized by a staggering run of injuries, the Yankees’ misfortune reached an almost absurd level Friday when Curtis Granderson sustained another broken bone in only his eighth game of the season.

headline: Haynes Johnson, Journalist and Author, Is Dead at 81
text: Haynes Johnson, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, television commentator and author known in particular for his long association with The Washington Post, died on Friday in Bethesda, Md. He was 81.

headline: Now That’s a Souvenir
text: They’ve been standing on the Flushing Bay Promenade, just north of the Mets’ stadium and across the water from La Guardia Airport, for nearly 50 years: two identical fiberglass shells. Not quite buildings, not quite sculptures, the twin structures look simultaneously retro and modern — a past vision of futurism.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 25, 2013
text: “We like to believe in Brazil that we live in a peaceful, happy place, when the truth of our existence is far more complicated. It’s like we’re Narcissus gazing into a pool of sewage.”

headline: Application and Affidavit for Rosen Search Warrant
text: An affidavit details what information the United States government gathered from conversations between Stephen Jin-Woo Kim, a government employee, and an unnamed journalist believed to be James Rosen, the chief Washington correspondent for Fox News.

headline: Joyful Noise in Silent Barn, an Alt-Arts Mecca
text: The D.I.Y. arts scene — that illicit and usually itinerant cultural milieu — may have found a legal, if not a permanent, home for this summer in New York. It is called the Silent Barn, and it could be thought of as Brooklyn’s First Church of the Perpetual House Party.

headline: Georges Moustaki, Poetic French Singer, Dies at 79
text: PARIS — Georges Moustaki, a singer and songwriter who wrote Édith Piaf’s hit song “Milord” and won wide popularity in France for his poetic lyrics and melancholy ballads, died on Thursday in Nice, France. He was 79.

headline: Rogers Returning to M.L.S. With Galaxy
text: Robbie Rogers is expected to join the Los Angeles Galaxy on Saturday, becoming the first openly gay player on a major men’s professional team in North America.

headline: Flynn Robinson, Scorer on Dominant N.B.A. Club, Dies at 72
text: Flynn Robinson, a sharpshooting guard who came off the bench to add scoring punch for one of the greatest teams in N.B.A. history, the 1971-72 Los Angeles Lakers, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 72.

headline: A Painter Amid Friends
text: In the summer of 1949, John Ashbery, unleashed to the world from Harvard, arrived in New York to begin his long and productive creative life in a small loft building on Third Avenue near 16th Street. Mr. Ashbery was to spend the season in the apartment of his college friend Kenneth Koch, who was visiting his parents in Cincinnati, and he was to pick up the key from a woman, Jane Freilicher, who lived one floor up. The consequence of this quotidian exchange was a deeply connected friendship now in its sixth decade, nourished by the bohemian reverie that characterized Greenwich Village for so much of the 20th century and migrated to the east end of Long Island with the arrival of Memorial Day.

headline: Rogers Set to Join Los Angeles Galaxy
text: Robbie Rogers is expected to join the Los Angeles Galaxy and become the first openly gay player on a major men’s professional team in North America.

headline: Across U.S. Companies, Tax Rates Vary Greatly
text: Last week, in a Congressional hearing, Apple got grilled for its low-tax strategy. But not every business can copy that approach. Here is a look at what S.&P. 500 companies paid in corporate income taxes — federal, state, local and foreign — from 2007 to 2012, according to S&P Capital IQ.

headline: James’s Miscues Help Pacers Stop Heat to Tie Series
text: Give LeBron James an inch or two, a second or two, a half-step or a slight gap, and he will turn you into a historical footnote, a foil for his Hall of Fame highlight reel. This much, the Indiana Pacers had already learned, painfully, deeply, in the opener of the Eastern Conference finals.

headline: James L. Tolbert, 86, an Early Lawyer to Black Hollywood, Dies
text: James L. Tolbert was in love. Marie Ross was too. But she had little interest in marrying a man who pieced together his income by hosting parties and concerts in empty buildings. One of his gimmicks: selling food and drink out of an old hearse.

headline: Stuck in the City? There’s Lots to Do
text: New York City cannot bear to be anything but the best. Even its notorious summer heat and humidity have to compete on the world stage, giving the tropics an annual run for their money. But while the less intrepid (and more affluent) flee to beach towns and other breezier climes, the city offers a wealth of summer diversions to those who stay put and embrace the swelter. The following is a sampling of worthy seasonal pursuits, across all five boroughs, that will make the months from Memorial Day to Labor Day much more bearable.

headline: Alton T. Lemon, Who Challenged State Aid to Religious Schools, Dies at 84
text: Alton T. Lemon, a civil rights activist whose objection to state aid to religious schools gave rise to a watershed 1971 Supreme Court decision, died on May 4 in Jenkintown, Pa. He was 84.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) MAGIC MIKE (2012) In a role loosely inspired by his stint as a stripper in Florida, Channing Tatum (above left, with Matthew McConaughey) stars as the gyrating main attraction at the Xquisite dance club, in what Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called “Steven Soderbergh’s funny, enjoyable romp about male strippers and the American dream.” Alex Pettyfer plays Adam, a college dropout who is pushed onstage at Xquisite. At first Adam is resistant. Then Madonna’s “Like a Virgin” begins to throb. “What happens will be familiar if you’ve ever seen one of those variations on the fallen-woman movie,” Ms. Dargis wrote. “In the past the movies were very much preoccupied with the moral regulation of women, but here the stress is on Mike’s struggle to succeed as he juggles his part-time gigs (dancing, auto detailing and construction) with his desire to build custom furniture.” She added: “The collaboration between Mr. Soderbergh and the relatively untested Mr. Tatum is itself a gamble, one that has brought out the best in each. What could have been an embarrassing misfire hinted at by the movie’s misleading trailers is instead a smoothly distilled collaboration that balances Mr. Tatum’s heat and charm — and ambitions that are as transparent as Mike’s — with Mr. Soderbergh’s cool, cinematic intelligence and ongoing preoccupations.”

headline: Failing to Convince Assad
text: AMMAN, Jordan – As Secretary of State John Kerry and 10 European and Arab foreign ministers gathered here this week to discuss grand strategy, President Bashar al-Assad was taking decisive action. With the help of thousands of fighters from Hezbollah, Iran and Iraq, he was close to achieving some of his largest military gains in two years.

headline: Davis’s Woes Suspended, With Game, After the 8th
text: The number of strikeouts collected by Ike Davis during the Mets’ 45th game, which began Friday night, will not be officially determined until Saturday. The series opener between the Mets and the Braves at Citi Field was suspended before the start of the ninth inning with the score tied at 5-5, and the game will resume at 6:10 p.m.

headline: IHT Quick Read: May 25
text: NEWS For more than a century, the Museum of Medical History in Berlin has exhibited assorted limbs, bones, tubercular lungs and fetuses, all in the name of science and enlightenment. Yet lately the curators are re-evaluating the principles that govern their displays as they confront a growing debate over what cultural organizations should be doing to preserve the dignity of the dead. Many of the world’s grand museums are hearing increasing demands for the return of human remains from former colonies or conquered peoples. Some are giving back bones and skulls that were once viewed as exotic trinkets and were traded by native peoples for calico or plundered in the late 1800s by scientists exploring racial differences. Doreen Carvajal reports from Berlin.

headline: Liberty Look to Laimbeer, Off Court as Well
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Bill Laimbeer turned 56 on Sunday, but his identity in basketball has not changed.

headline: School Van Fire in Pakistan Kills 15 Children
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Fifteen schoolchildren and a teacher were killed Saturday when their school van caught fire in eastern Punjab Province, rescue and government officials said. Seven other children were injured, two of them critically.

headline: A Rising French Star, Complete With Fast Food
text: When the French Open begins Sunday, the locals will have a new matinee idol to root for.

headline: North Korea Glosses Over Tensions After Its Special Envoy Visits China
text: BEIJING — North Korea put a positive spin Saturday on the visit of its special envoy to China, but made no mention of China’s push for the North to resume negotiations aimed at ridding the country of its nuclear weapons program.

headline: The Weekend Word: Remembrance
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Century-Old Racing Columns Still Quicken the Pulse
text: You can read old editions of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle online if you are interested in issues that appeared from 1841 to 1902, but thanks to Old Fulton NY Postcards, a quirky site featuring scanned-in articles from many New York papers, I have read many of W. C. Vreeland’s racing pieces, which appear in later issues. Vreeland’s writing rang with the nerve, excitement and depth of racing. Part gossip, part handicapping, part pure racing fandom, Vreeland’s columns made horses into celebrities and readers into racing insiders.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: A woman from Pakistan was caught by the Border Security Forces in the Samba District of Jammu and Kashmir along the Indian-Pakistani border Thursday, according to a Press Trust of India report in Hindustan Times. The initial investigation revealed that she had accidentally crossed into India and nothing incriminating was recovered from her, an officer told the wire service.

headline: Up, Up and Away
text: THE values of gold and silver have dropped like a stone in international trading markets. Coffee futures are hovering near a three-year low. But the price of one commodity has been rising as if it were lighter than air — and in this case, well, it is.

headline: Kerry, in Africa, Presses Nigeria on Human Rights
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — Making his first visit to sub-Saharan Africa as secretary of state, John Kerry urged Nigeria on Saturday to uphold human rights as it steps up its fight against Islamic extremists.

headline: Players to Watch at Roland Garros
text: MEN

headline: Players Not to Watch at Roland Garros
text: It is easy to spot the players coming into a Grand Slam tournament with a head of steam, arriving in Paris with an impressive roster of victories that make them ones to watch at the tournament. For this year’s French Open, players like Benoit Paire, Grigor Dimitrov, Simona Halep and Bethanie Mattek-Sands would easily fit into that category, among others.

headline: Vintage Apple-1 Sells for Record $671,400
text: Apple’s stock price may be well down from its peaks last year, but the market for the company’s oldest computers continues to set records.

headline: Europe’s Keynesian Problem
text: Brad DeLong tries to find nice things to say about Ken Rogoff’s latest. But he tries too hard.

headline: The Oil Extremists
text: The federal Energy Information Administration reported in March that at some point this year — maybe in the fall, maybe next month, maybe tomorrow — United States crude oil production will surpass imports for the first time since 1995. This is an important milestone. It does not mean that America has reached energy independence, not by a long shot. That is and will remain an elusive dream for a country that uses one-fifth of the world’s oil while possessing little more than one-fiftieth of its reserves.

headline: Rape Behind Bars
text: A new federal report shows that the nation’s prisons and jails have a long way to go before they comply with the Prison Rape Elimination Act. That 2003 law requires institutions receiving federal money to adopt a zero-tolerance policy on rape and to embrace rigorous prevention measures like those outlined last year by the Justice Department.

headline: ‘A’ Is for Avoidance
text: Even before last week’s Senate hearing on Apple, it was clear that the aggressive use of tax havens and other tax avoidance tactics had become standard operating procedure for global American companies.

headline: Preventing a U.S.-China Cyberwar
text: When President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China have their first meeting next month in California, addressing the issue of China’s cyberattacks on American institutions will be an important priority. Both nations need to take steps to avoid drifting into an all-out cyberwar.

headline: The Deer on the Wall
text: A little more than 60 years ago, when he was still a young man, my dad shot a mule deer while hunting in northwestern Colorado. Like so may things in his early life, this was a fact, not a story.

headline: Postscript in Pink: Rule Kept Bats in Rack
text: A little over two weeks ago, a bat was dropped off in the visitors’ clubhouse at Target Field in Minneapolis. It was intended for Baltimore Orioles outfielder Nick Markakis, and it was stained his standard black — except for Markakis’s signature and the bat’s name and model number, all of which were in pink. Nearby, in the Minnesota Twins’ clubhouse, third baseman Trevor Plouffe had just received a similarly marked bat.

headline: The Closing of the Conservative Mind
text: Jonathan Chait has an interesting portrait of Josh Barro; Mike Konczal, citing this and also a longer discussion of “reformish” conservatives by Ryan Cooper, argues that there really isn’t much to see here. I agree, and have been trying to pin down what I mean by that.

headline: From Franchisee to C.E.O.
text: MY parents moved from San Luis Obispo to the Mojave Desert, about four hours to the east, after my dad, a physicist, got a job at what is now the Naval Air Weapons Station, China Lake. My younger brother Chris and I grew up catching lizards and snakes and riding motorcycles. We were also on the local swim team.

headline: A Final Inspection for Prospects Hoping to Hear Their Names in the Second Round
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Several rows of long tables were arranged around the basketball court, each covered by a black cloth with a white sheet of paper bearing one word, “Reserved.” Decision makers for the 30 N.B.A. teams chose their seats.

headline: Hone the Job You Have Into One You Love
text: OVER the past few months, American workers have been suffering from a major case of spring fever. Many of them, for the first time in years, are thinking about testing the waters of the slowly improving economy. They are looking for better jobs than those they’ve been clinging to throughout the recession. Maybe, they think, they can even find a job they love.

headline: A Shortage of Child Support, but a Surplus of Blame
text: LET’S start, as we often do, with a tangent.

headline: The C.E.O. Triumphant (at Least at Apple and Chase)
text: NO taxpayer is obliged to pay the government a penny more than the law requires, the Supreme Court said in 1935. But the court also said no corporation was permitted to use “elaborate and devious” means — known nowadays as “gimmicks” — for the express purpose of evading taxes.

headline: A Baseball Academy in a Talent-Poor Part of Mexico
text: SAN BARTOLO COYOTEPEC, Mexico — In this tiny town just south of Oaxaca’s state capital, some of Mexico’s most talented young baseball players are taking their first real steps toward the big leagues.

headline: Misplaced Honor
text: IN the complex and not entirely complete process of reconciliation after the Civil War, honoring the dead with markers, tributes and ceremonies has played a crucial role. Some of these gestures, like Memorial Day, have been very successful. The practice of decorating the graves arose in many towns, north and south, some even before the war had ended. This humble idea quickly spread throughout the country, and the recognition of common loss helped reconcile North and South.

headline: On the Horizon, Five Reasons to Smile
text: THE state of the economy is far from ideal, but some very definite positives are brewing. It’s not just that we are continuing to recover from a deep recession; we are also seeing signs that America’s long-term future may be looking up, too.

headline: Bequeathing the Keys to Your Digital Afterlife
text: IT’S tough enough to write an ordinary will, deciding how to pass along worldly goods like your savings, your real estate and that treasured rocking chair from Aunt Martha in the living room.

headline: Late Start in the Sport, Brilliant Start to a Career
text: Kevin Towers was scouting for the Yankees in 2010 when a trade got his attention. The Arizona Diamondbacks, spiraling toward a last-place finish in the National League West, dealt pitcher Dan Haren, a three-time All-Star, to the Los Angeles Angels for a package that included two promising left-handers in Class A.

headline: A Student of Indy History, Hoping to Make Some
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The lights from a photo shoot had dimmed, but the gleam in Dario Franchitti’s eyes remained. The five-foot sterling silver Borg-Warner trophy stood before him, the history of the Indianapolis 500 told through the miniature busts of each year’s winner carved into its side. Franchitti, a Scot, traced the years with his fingers and found his countryman Jim Clark, the 1965 winner. He scanned for Ray Harroun, the 1911 winner. Then, near the bottom of the trophy, he settled on his own face — or, rather, the three of them.

headline: If My Data Is an Open Book, Why Can’t I Read It?
text: OUR mobile carriers know our locations: where our phones travel during working hours and leisure time, where they reside overnight when we sleep. Verizon Wireless even sells demographic profiles of customer groups — including ZIP codes for where they “live, work, shop and more” — to marketers. But when I called my wireless providers, Verizon and T-Mobile, last week in search of data on my comings and goings, call-center agents told me that their companies didn’t share customers’ own location logs with them without a subpoena.

headline: Nascar’s Vocal Leader, Even if Few Follow Him
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Fresh off winning the 2012 Sprint Cup championship, Brad Keselowski stood at the lectern during the annual awards dinner in Las Vegas last November and declared to the Nascar gathering before him, “As a champion, I want to be your leader.”

headline: Jump to Pros Is Quite a Leap
text: Shortly after Memorial Day, the Colorado Avalanche will introduce Patrick Roy as their coach, a hiring the team announced Thursday. He will also be vice president for hockey operations, sharing roster decisions with Joe Sakic, his former Avalanche teammate, who was named an executive vice president earlier this month.

headline: Joe Thornton Doesn’t Let Sharks Lose Their Edge
text: LOS ANGELES — The jovial San Jose Sharks captain, Joe Thornton, has managed to laugh off plenty of criticism in his career, once joking that he would much sooner spend his time perusing Playboy than reading anything in the hockey press.

headline: With Orb, It’s Still Wait and See
text: Shug McGaughey has been guided by the condition of his horse throughout his Hall of Fame career. He is not about to change now as he debates whether Orb, his first Kentucky Derby champion who finished a disappointing fourth in the Preakness, should compete in the Belmont Stakes on June 8.

headline: Ten Years Later, a Growing Appreciation for Sorenstam’s Breakthrough
text: Annika Sorenstam’s participation in the PGA Tour event at Colonial Country Club 10 years ago did not change people’s thinking overnight the way Billie Jean King’s exhibition tennis match against Bobby Riggs in another part of Texas had 30 years before.

headline: Two Who Did Not Return
text: More than 500 major league baseball players served in the military during World War II, including stars like Ted Williams, Stan Musial and Joe DiMaggio. But little attention has been paid to the two who died, Elmer Gedeon and Harry O’Neill, because their playing days were brief.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: What Eisenhower Taught Me About Decision-Making
text: This interview with  J.W. Marriott Jr., known as Bill, executive chairman and former C.E.O. of Marriott International, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — This is Fred Piscop’s first solo byline as a Split Decisions constructor, and even though Mr. Piscop has had a plethora of solo bylines both as editor and constructor, I still had a moment of nostalgia remembering the late George Bredehorn and his Split Decisions puzzles.

headline: Hagel Calls Sex Assaults in Military a ‘Scourge’
text: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Saturday called the increasing reports of sexual assault a “scourge” on the military and urged the Army’s newest officers to help build “a culture of respect and dignity” in the armed forces.

headline: Those Caffeine Rituals at the Office
text: Those Caffeine Rituals

headline: Newark Monsignor Loses Job for Failing to Stop Priest’s Work With Children
text: One of the top officials in the Archdiocese of Newark has been forced out for failing to properly monitor the activities of a priest who had been forbidden from having contact with children, the archdiocese announced on Saturday.

headline: Improbably, Missionary Trains Stars in Kenya
text: The world’s most unlikely track coach had never attended a meet in the United States. The map said New York, but the cold, rainy, windy weather stirred memories of a distant home.

headline: As Boozy Invaders Hit Beach, Hamptons Sound a Snooki Alert
text: AMAGANSETT, N.Y. — For generations, few beaches in the Hamptons were more coveted and jealously protected than Indian Wells.

headline: Sally Jewell
text: Sally Jewell had a varied career as a petroleum engineer, banker and the chief executive of the outdoor retailer REI before the Senate confirmed her last month as  secretary of the interior.

headline: Shareholders Are Speaking Up, but Who’s Listening?
text: WE are nearing the end of proxy season, that once-a-year moment when shareholders can speak their minds, sort of, to the officers and directors overseeing their companies. But that doesn’t mean corporate boards always listen.

headline: Call for Calm After 3 New Arrests in British Soldier’s Death
text: LONDON — The police made three new arrests on Saturday in the killing of an off-duty soldier on a London street, while British politicians and religious leaders called for calm in response to a rise in threats and invective against Muslims across the country.

headline: In Surprise, Pacers Are Driven by Their Offense
text: For a brief moment, LeBron James had an angle to the rim. With the clock ticking down, James drove hard to his right and tried to wedge his shoulder between Indiana Pacers wing Paul George and the hoop. Instead, James ran into George’s chest, turned away from the basket and fired a pass that was tipped, then collected, by the Pacers.

headline:
Hezbollah Commits to an
All-Out Fight to
Save Assad
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The leader of the powerful Lebanese militant group Hezbollah decisively committed his followers on Saturday to an all-out battle in Syria to defeat the rebellion against President Bashar al-Assad. He said the organization, founded to defend Lebanon and fight Israel, was entering “a completely new phase,” sending troops abroad to protect its interests.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Treating Mental Illness
text: Readers discuss the benefits of talk therapy versus medication.

headline: Showdown at the Airport Body Scanner
text: I have never walked through an airport body scanner — or, as I think of it, “the cancer machine.” In the years since these radiation chambers began appearing in airports across the United States, I have developed a variety of tricks to avoid submitting myself to them.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Champions League Final, Bayern Munich 2, Dortmund 1
text: The Goal blog provided live analysis and commentary of Saturday’s Champions League final — Bayern Munich’s thrilling 2-1 win over Dortmund at Wembley Stadium in London. Read on to follow the game as it happened.

headline: Who Will Crack the Code?
text: WASHINGTON — IRELAND and Singapore have no natural resources that make them obvious places to manufacture the concentrate used in soda, nor have they developed innovative new soda-making techniques. Yet they have nonetheless become global capitals for making soft-drink concentrate.

headline: When Numbers Mislead
text: IT’S always seductive to know where one stands in relation to the average. As an overly confident college freshman, the first time I received a below-average score on an exam was a needed wake-up call. Today, I find it encouraging to read that I exercise more than the average woman my age.

headline: Can 44 Subtract 43 From the Equation?
text: DALLAS — DO we dare to hope that the Bush administration is finally at an end?

headline: Rich Tourist, Poor Tourist
text: As the travel season kicks into full swing this Memorial Day weekend, many of us are anticipating the rites of the modern vacation with a quiver of dread — crawling along the Long Island Expressway; stalling in endless security lines; gnawing on pretzels while squeezed into ever-smaller airplane seats. It’s hard not to envy today’s über-rich, whose getaways, on private jets to Caribbean villas, take place far above the sweaty fray of mortal tourists.

headline: Obama’s Artful Anguish
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA’S speech on national security last week was a dense thicket of self-justifying argument, but its central message was perfectly clear: Please don’t worry, liberals. I’m not George W. Bush.

headline: Untangling What Companies Pay in Taxes
text: The tax filings of companies, like those of individuals, are confidential. When individual companies want to make the case that they pay large amounts of tax – as many do – they often point to complex calculations from their financial statements that portray the companies in the best light. For an outsider, it can be hard to know how many accounting assumptions go into these calculations and how accurately they reflect the company’s actual tax payments.

headline: Gesture Writing
text: Five years ago, I walked into a third-floor art studio on the campus of the University of California, Berkeley, climbed atop a wooden stage covered in stained padding and dropped my ratty yellow bathrobe. A panel of strangers asked me to pose, and then to freeze. I had never modeled for artists, and had no idea how I would feel standing naked as people I had just met stared at me. The idea held some bohemian appeal, but more urgently, I needed to supplement my income as a freelance writer while I worked on a novel.

headline: Obamacare’s Other Surprise
text: LISTENING to the debate about President Obama’s health care plan, some critics argue that Obamacare is going to need Obamacare — because it’s going to be a “train wreck.” Obama officials insist they’re wrong. We’ll just have to wait and see whether the Affordable Care Act, as the health care law is officially known, surprises us on the downside. But there is one area where the law already appears to be surprising on the upside. And that is the number of health care information start-ups it’s spurring. This is a big deal.

headline: Intricate Rituals for Fallen American Troops
text: At the Dover Port Mortuary, where the bodies of service members are brought to be prepared for funeral, no detail is too small.

headline: Leak Inquiries Show How Wide a Net U.S. Cast
text: WASHINGTON — Even before the F.B.I. conducted 550 interviews of officials and seized the phone records of Associated Press reporters in a leak investigation connected to a 2012 article about a Yemen bomb plot, agents had sought the same reporters’ sources for two other articles about terrorism.

headline: The Gift of Siblings
text: GIVEN what a mouthy thing I grew up to be, it’s shocking to me that I began talking later than most children do. But I didn’t need words. I had my older brother, Mark.

headline: More Guns in the Sky
text: Confidential. For N.R.A. internal. Now that the Senate has voted down new gun control laws and we have the president on the defensive — never thought I’d say it, but God bless the I.R.S.! — we have a real opportunity to guide Congress along a common-sense path that will further ensure the freedoms of peaceful, law-abiding citizens. Herewith, talking points on the next crucial phase of our work. Please distribute to all concerned elected officials who share our love of liberty and public safety.

headline: Foreign Projects Give Afghans Fashion, Skate Park and Now 10,000 Balloons
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Braving jeers and provoking smiles, volunteers spread through Kabul on Saturday, giving away 10,000 pink balloons as part of a performance art project called “We Believe in Balloons.”

headline: Francis’ Humility and Emphasis on the Poor Strike a New Tone at the Vatican
text: VATICAN CITY — He has criticized the “cult of money” and greed he sees driving the world financial system, reflecting his affinity for liberation theology. He has left Vatican officials struggling to keep up with his off-the-cuff remarks and impromptu forays into the crowds of tens of thousands that fill St. Peter’s Square during his audiences. He has delighted souvenir vendors near the Vatican by increasing tourist traffic.

headline: Turbine Plans Unnerve Fans of Condors in California
text: The California condor’s slow 20-year climb back from the brink of extinction has long been a fragile not-quite-success story in the conservation world. So when the news came on Friday that developers of a wind-energy project near the Mojave Desert would not face criminal charges if the blades killed a single condor, environmental groups expressed grave concern.

headline: Arizona’s Illegal Sheriff
text: How do we know that Joe Arpaio, sheriff of Maricopa County, Ariz., is a racial profiler, an abuser of power who has subjected Latinos for years to unconstitutional arrests, detention and harassment?

headline: Seeking Serenity in a Patch of California Land
text: FRESNO, Calif. — Like Scotch broom and dandelions, despair can be invasive. This is why, every Monday, Lee Lee, a Hmong refugee, puts on her sun hat and flip-flops, grabs the hoe handmade by her father and brother in Laos and heads to the Hmong Village Community Garden here, where she tends rows of purple lemon grass, bitter melon and medicinal herbs along with other Hmong women.

headline: In California, Gardening for Mental Health
text: Community gardens for immigrant groups can provide more than just familiar foods hard to find in the grocery store; they can be a balm for alienation.

headline: What Mideast Crisis? Israelis Have Moved On
text: FOR years, conventional wisdom has held that as long as Israel faces the external challenge of Arab — especially Palestinian — hostility it will never come to terms with its internal divisions. The left has sometimes used it as an argument: we must make peace with the Palestinians so that we can set our house in order — write a constitution, figure out the public role of religion. Others have viewed the threat as almost a silver lining keeping the place together: differences among Israeli Jews (religious or secular, Ashkenazic or Sephardic) are so profound, the argument goes, that if the society ever manages to turn its attention inward, it might tear itself apart.

headline: Verdicts Expected Soon for 2 Milosevic Agents
text: THE HAGUE — He was the president’s man for all seasons, prosecutors said, ready to organize hit squads, permit the killing of prisoners, sign off on covert weapon shipments or mediate the release of peacekeepers. Jovica Stanisic, the onetime chief of the secret police, was widely thought to be the second most powerful man in Serbia during Slobodan Milosevic’s presidency.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 26
text: Still echoing through Washington, President Obama’s speech Thursday on shifting the nation’s approach to counterterrorism will be up for debate on the Sunday shows.

headline: Amma’s Multifaceted Empire, Built on Hugs
text: THERE are entourages — and then there is the retinue of Mata Amritanandamayi, a 59-year-old Indian guru known simply as Amma, or “mother.” On Friday, she began a two-month North American tour during which she will be accompanied by 275 volunteers. They plan to ride in four buses across the continent from Bellevue, Wash., to Marlborough, Mass., visiting 11 cities, including New York. And at each stop along the way, Amma will sit on stage for 15 hours at a stretch, greeting her thousands of devotees.

headline: Breeding the Nutrition Out of Our Food
text: WE like the idea that food can be the answer to our ills, that if we eat nutritious foods we won’t need medicine or supplements. We have valued this notion for a long, long time. The Greek physician Hippocrates proclaimed nearly 2,500 years ago: “Let food be thy medicine and medicine be thy food.” Today, medical experts concur. If we heap our plates with fresh fruits and vegetables, they tell us, we will come closer to optimum health.

headline: Nutritional Weaklings in the Supermarket
text:
Heirloom varieties and wild species of produce
have been found to outshine their cultivated cousins.

headline: Made-for-TV Movies
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — There was a time after I had my kids when I thought I would never get out to the theaters to see a movie again, at least not one that didn’t involve Pokemon. The Boy was not big on sitting for long periods of time, even with his small lap loaded with candy, so very often The Girl was left to watch a large portion of the movie by herself while I chased The Boy up the aisle and out into the lobby. Now that they’re older, of course, things are different and they are much more likely to chase me up the aisle as I stomp out (“What?! Bruce Willis was dead all along?? What the heck is that?! I want my money back!”)

headline: Indians Grow Impatient With Taciturn Premier Amid Troubles
text: NEW DELHI — He speaks so softly that even his public comments are sometimes nearly inaudible. He has not held a formal news conference in India since 2011. And a pack of reporters were driven to hold a protest recently when he refused to participate in the routine political act of being photographed while filing for re-election in Assam State.

headline: Maoist Attack Kills at Least 16 in India
text: NEW DELHI — At least 16 people, including a prominent politician, were killed Saturday when Maoist guerrillas ambushed a convoy of political leaders in Chhattisgarh State, the authorities said. Among the dead were five police officers.

headline: Bayern Munich, Champion of Germany, Adds European Title
text: LONDON — Some saw this as the opening to an age of German soccer dominance, and maybe it will be. Maybe years from now Saturday’s Champions League final between Bayern Munich and Borussia Dortmund will be viewed as the start of the Bundesliga’s rise to the pinnacle of European sports.

headline: At the Bottom of the Top 10, but No. 1 at a Norway Event
text: The Norway Chess 2013 tournament was among one competitor’s greatest triumphs, and the results offered hope to two others but were a disappointment — again — for the world champion.

headline: A Long Way From Church Street but Still in Sync
text: On a 1988 live recording of “The Front Porch Song,” which he wrote with Lyle Lovett when they were students at Texas A&M in the late ’70s, Robert Earl Keen pauses midway to describe the song’s inspiration. “We used to sit on this old porch on Church Street, right across from the Presbyterian church, and play bluegrass and folk music, and talk about girls and where we were going to move to when our parents got our grades,” he says. “Talk about someday becoming big songwriters.”

headline: Texas Lawmakers Put Down Their Swords
text: If Texas’ less-than-theatrical 83rd legislative session is remembered at all, it will be known for accords, not discord.

headline: Morris Renek, a Novelist of Gift and Determination, Dies at 88
text: Morris Renek, a critically admired New York novelist who wrote comic tales about historical criminals and modern urban life but never achieved the commercial success many thought he deserved, died on May 10 in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Wayne Miller, Photographer of War and Peace, Dies at 94
text: Wayne Miller, a photographer whose intimate images from the front lines of war, the streets of Chicago’s South Side and his own family life captured a world in transition in the middle of the 20th century, died on Wednesday at his home in Orinda, Calif. He was 94.

headline: Teixeira Teary-Eyed Over Granderson’s Latest Setback
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Somehow, Mark Teixeira was far more emotional about Curtis Granderson’s broken left pinkie than Granderson appeared to be Friday night. Teixeira was at Tropicana Field when Granderson learned he would miss at least a month after he was hit by a pitch and broke the fifth metacarpal.

headline: Wayne Miller, Magnum Photographer, Dies at 94
text: Mr. Miller once said that what he wanted to do was “to photograph mankind and explain man to man.”

headline: A Clash Over Who Is Allowed to Give You a Brighter Smile
text: GUNTERSVILLE, Ala. — In the middle of the enduring conflict between liberty and public welfare stands Joyce Osborn Wilson and her teeth-whitening business.

headline: Giffords Urges Graduates at Bard to ‘Be Courageous’
text: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — Speaking uncertainly but smiling broadly, Gabrielle Giffords, the former Arizona congresswoman who became a public face of the gun control movement after she was shot in 2011, delivered a kind of blessing in her commencement address to Bard College graduates here on Saturday afternoon, urging them to “be bold, be courageous, be your best.”

headline: Interpol Rebuffs Russia in Its Hunt for a Kremlin Critic
text: MOSCOW — Interpol has rejected a Russian request for a worldwide police hunt for William F. Browder, a British investment banker and a Kremlin nemesis who has made no secret of his whereabouts or of his battle against the government of President Vladimir V. Putin over accusations of human rights abuses.

headline: Last Inspection: Precise Ritual of Dressing Nation’s War Dead
text: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del. — The soldier bent to his work, careful as a diamond cutter. He carried no weapon or rucksack, just a small plastic ruler, which he used to align a name plate, just so, atop the breast pocket of an Army dress blue jacket, size 39R.

headline: A Day Later, Play Resumes, and So Do the Mets’ Woes
text: There was one encouraging thing that could be said for the Mets at the end of a dismal Saturday during which they rang up two more losses in what is shaping up as a long season. Ike Davis, the monumentally struggling first baseman teetering on the verge of a demotion to the minor leagues, got a single.

headline: Yemen Making Strides in Transition to Democracy After Arab Spring
text: For more than two months, 565 people representing a cross section of Yemen’s population have gathered in a luxury hotel on the outskirts of Sana, the capital, trying to hammer out the shape a future government will take.

headline: California Faces a New Quandary, Too Much Money
text: LOS ANGELES — After years of grueling battles over state budget deficits and spending cuts, California has a new challenge on its hands: too much money. An unexpected surplus is fueling an argument over how the state should respond to its turn of good fortune.

headline: What to Watch on Sunday at the French Open
text: Six recommended matches to catch on Day 1 of the French Open.

headline: U.S. Shift Poses Risk to Pakistan
text: From multibillion-dollar military aid to stealthy and secretive drone strikes, Pakistan, perhaps even more than Afghanistan, has been the central focus of America’s 12-year war on Islamist militancy.

headline: Rogers Says He’s Ready for a Role as a Pioneer
text: CARSON, Calif. — Robbie Rogers thought he had stepped away from his career as a professional soccer player the moment he pressed the button publishing a blog post announcing that he was gay. At the time, in February, he said, he could not imagine that he could be himself on and off the field.

headline: Offense Vanishes; Rangers Follow
text: BOSTON — The Rangers trailed by a goal, nine minutes from elimination, when the puck found Ryan Callahan alone outside the blue line. The crowd at TD Garden fell silent. The Rangers stood on their bench and leaned over the boards as Callahan churned in on Boston goalie Tuukka Rask, their season on his stick blade.

headline: Japanese Lab Workers Exposed to Low Levels of Radiation
text: TOKYO — As many as 55 workers at a national laboratory may have been exposed to low levels of radiation after an experiment overheated, releasing radioactive particles into the air, the agency operating the lab said Saturday.

headline: Overbay’s Homer in the 11th Caps a Stirring Comeback Against the Rays
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Joe Girardi was being debriefed by reporters in his office after one of the Yankees’ most remarkable games in this remarkable season, going through the list of contributions made by various players after the eighth inning.

headline: Syracuse Engineers a Comeback Win; Duke Holds One Off
text: PHILADELPHIA — Duke was 15 minutes from a cakewalk to the national title game, sailing through its semifinal against Cornell with Saturday’s blustery wind at its back, looking undaunted and largely unobstructed, all of its diversified offensive machinations firing in full.

headline: A Supporting Role
text: In a recent mission, the Americans adjusted to a new role, biting their tongues even as they followed Afghans into what they saw as dubious missions.

headline: In Afghan Transition, U.S. Forces Take a Step Back
text: CHAMKANI, Afghanistan — The American soldiers were climbing the steep ridgeline, fractured shale cracking underfoot and sweat pouring off their faces, when their Afghan allies up ahead took off without warning.

headline: Fourth Line Gives Bruins an Advantage Once Again
text: BOSTON — The victory was secured. The Bruins were moving on to the Eastern Conference finals after their series-clinching 3-1 victory over the Rangers, and all Boston forward Shawn Thornton could think of was the one that got away.

headline: Yankee Stadium Hosts an Exhibition That Has the Feel of a Rehearsal
text: It was a preliminary rendering for curious observers, a rough sketch of one possible future for soccer in New York City.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 26
text: “If I knew the story of every individual who went through here, I would probably be in a padded cell.”

text: Lauren Rebecca Consky, a daughter of Helene I. Consky and Dr. Charles L. Consky of Niagara-on-the-Lake, Ontario, is to be married there on Sunday at the Ravine Vineyard to Daniel Moshe Scolnic, a son of Dorene T. Scolnic and Rabbi Benjamin E. Scolnic of Hamden, Conn. headline: Corrections: May 26, 2013
text: NATIONAL

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (HBO) BEHIND THE CANDELABRA (2013) Michael Douglas, above, stars as the piano showman Liberace, and Matt Damon is Scott Thorson, his chauffeur, lover and adopted son, in this film biography from the director Steven Soderbergh and the screenwriter Richard LaGravenese. Set in Las Vegas, Los Angeles and Palm Springs, the film chronicles the men’s relationship as Liberace picks up and possesses Mr. Thorson, has him cosmetically altered in his image and legally adopts him before discarding him for a younger model. “There’s something uncanny, even brilliant,” about Mr. Douglas’s impersonation of Liberace, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “Sashaying across Las Vegas stages and epic suburban living rooms with a drum major’s puffed-up grandeur and a lounge lizard’s predatory smile, Mr. Douglas gives a performance so assured, so free of camp or cringe, that you quickly surrender any doubts you might have had about his playing a  famously flamboyant, closeted-in-plain-sight gay entertainer.” At the same time, he said, “there’s something limited, and limiting, about Mr. Douglas’s portrayal. Its brilliance feels as if it were all on the surface, a matter of expertise and professionalism.” And the same could be said of Mr. Soderbergh’s film, he added. “A cerebral gloss on, and satire of, a big old Hollywood biopic, it’s full of smart, funny details — perfectly sewn in place, like the rhinestones on one of Mr. Douglas’s blinding costumes — but it’s short on heart, or heat.”

headline: Game 5: Rangers vs. Bruins
text: As the Bruins move on to play Pittsburgh in the conference finals, the Rangers face an off-season of self-reflection and of change.

headline: Trying to Revive Mideast Talks, Kerry Pushes Investment Plan for West Bank
text: DEAD SEA, Jordan — In an effort to revive the moribund peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians, Secretary of State John Kerry announced a plan on Sunday to invest as much as $4 billion to develop the economy of the West Bank.

headline: The Last Sweet Year of High School Slips Away
text: It began with the last PTA “Back-to-School Coffee.” This season of lasts, when every ritual, every event, seems freighted with extra meaning. It’s my only child’s senior year of high school, a year in which we are preparing to transition to the next phase of our lives. Perched on metal bleachers with the other team parents, my husband and I watched the sun go down behind the scoreboard of what would be Anna’s last high school water polo game. We trundled through her schedule of classes during the last back-to-school night. I had Anna pick the tulips we would plant for her last spring at home (for now, anyway), and they bloomed in a riot of lovely, bulbous pastels.

headline: Errani Outplays Rus in Early Match
text: PARIS — The last time Sara Errani of Italy played a match at the French Open, the stands were filled with more than 15,000 spectators. It was the women’s final last year, when she lost to Maria Sharapova of Russia.

headline: Nadal’s Knee
text: Rafael Nadal’s style of play and his two-handed backhand put a lot of stress on his injured left knee.

text: Brad DeLong interprets the Keynes-bashing opening of Ken Rogoff’s latest as strategic hippie-punching (see definition 2.2), designed to soften up his readers for the easy-money, debt-forgiveness message that follows.

headline: Obama Consoles Town Flattened by Tornado
text: MOORE, Okla. — President Obama walked among 10-foot-tall piles of tornado debris littered with children’s schoolbooks on Sunday as he offered the condolences of a nation to a town nearly wiped off the map by a storm.

text: Perhaps the best way to predict how society will react to so-called wearable computing devices is to read the Dr. Seuss children’s story “The Butter Battle Book.”
