headline: Kljestan: Back in U.S. Camp, and Back in the Champions League
text: CLEVELAND — As the United States national team prepares to start its busy summer with an exhibition on Wednesday night against a powerful Belgian team, the game will have added meaning for Sacha Kljestan since he will be facing off against some familiar faces.

headline: The Next Kevin Brownlow Drafts Her Summer Plans
text: The Douglas Fairbanks Jr. of 1928 and the Douglas Fairbanks Jr. of 1929 are not so different to me. In fact, when I think of him, even in his old age, he is always young, a well-preserved specimen of modern manhood, perpetually 23 and dashing as the day is long.

headline: Rocket and Gun Attacks Add to Fears That Syria’s Strife Is Reaching Lebanon
text: HERMEL, Lebanon — Four rockets hit this village near the Syrian border on Tuesday afternoon, badly wounding a woman who was sitting under an olive tree in her yard, residents said. Shortly before, gunmen killed three Lebanese soldiers at a border checkpoint in the Bekaa Valley, adding to fears that the crisis in Syria is spilling into Lebanon.

headline: Daily Report: The Fast-Approaching Future of Driverless Cars
text: Last month, on a freeway from Jerusalem to the Dead Sea, John Markoff sat in the driver’s seat of an Audi A7 while software connected to a video camera on the windshield drove the car at speeds up to 65 miles an hour — making a singular statement about the rapid progress in the development of self-driving cars, he writes in The New York Times.

headline: China Divides Europe in Fight Against Tariffs
text: HONG KONG — Adroitly alternating the threat of a trade war with the lure of its huge import market, China appears to have driven a deep wedge between Germany and the rest of the European Union. And it may even have caused a rift within the German business world.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Be a Plumber
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: The Case for a Profit Motive in Conserving the Environment
text: I think you may appreciate this recent chat I had with Mark Tercek, the president of The Nature Conservancy and co-author of “Nature’s Fortune: How Business and Society Thrive by Investing in Nature.”

headline: Europe Seeks to Press Russia and Syria on Arms
text: PARIS — The European Union’s decision to lift its arms embargo on Syria, after a bitter, 13-hour debate in Brussels, is intended to put pressure on Russia and President Bashar al-Assad of Syria before peace talks scheduled in Geneva next month, with a message that the West will not allow the rebels to be defeated, senior European diplomats said Tuesday.

headline: China Adds Sparkle to Champagne Sales
text: LONDON — France’s Champagne producers will doubtless be raising a glass or two this week to toast a decision by authorities in China, one of their fastest growing overseas markets, to recognize the uniqueness of their product.

headline: Hope Amid the Dams and Dangers
text: Jeff Opperman, a senior freshwater scientist with the Nature Conservancy, took a once-in-a-lifetime trip down the Mekong River in Southeast Asia with his wife and two children, ages 8 and 10. This is his final post. Previous posts can be found here.

headline: Tuesday Reading: The New Rules for Sunscreen
text: The new rules for sunscreen, New York’s bike sharing program begins, rescuing lost videos from YouTube and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Despite Wade’s Decline in Scoring, Nobody Is Counting Him Out
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Miami Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra went out of his way on Monday, as he has done many times the past three seasons, to paint a glowing picture of Chris Bosh. Describing Bosh’s role, Spoelstra said, “It’s to be our most important player, the way he always is.”

headline: Masterworks for One and All
text: AMSTERDAM — Many museums post their collections online, but the Rijksmuseum here has taken the unusual step of offering downloads of high-resolution images at no cost, encouraging the public to copy and transform its artworks into stationery, T-shirts, tattoos, plates or even toilet paper.

headline: In Performance: Larry Pine in ‘Death of Walt Disney’
text: Larry Pine plays the title character in Lucas Hnath’s new play, “A Public Reading of an Unproduced Screenplay About the Death of Walt Disney,” a darkly comic riff on the Disney legacy. In this scene Walt talks about some of the celebrities, politicians and evildoers who were fans of Disney films. The show continues through June 9 at SoHo Rep.

headline: Europe Warns Google It Could Face Further Concessions

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Advertising Hall of Achievement, Washington, which honors industry professionals ages 40 and younger, selected its inductees for 2013. They are Adam Bain, president for global revenue at Twitter; B. Bonin Bough, vice president for global media and consumer engagement, Mondelez International; Robert Candelino, vice president of branding for skin care, Unilever; Tara Walpert Levy, managing director for ads marketing at Google and YouTube; Lynn Lewis, global managing partner, J3 UM, part of Universal McCann; Todd Pendleton, chief marketing officer at Samsung Telecommunications America; and Emmanuel Seuge, head of global sports and entertainment at the Coca-Cola Company. Ms. Lewis will also receive the Jack Avrett Volunteer Spirit Award, for public service. The honors are to be presented on Nov. 5 at a luncheon at the Beverly Hilton hotel.

text: Online technologies have made us question lots of assumptions. What is privacy? Which is better, ownership or sharing? Is the crowd wiser than a lone genius?

headline: No Partisan Fire at the Shore: An Obama-Christie Reunion
text: POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N.J. — Politics makes strange beachfellows. President Obama and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey affirmed this notion, and enjoyed its benefits, on Tuesday in a drizzly reunion on the Jersey Shore, seven months after Hurricane Sandy punished the famous coastline and united them in an unlikely political partnership.

headline: A Worried Israel Prepares for War

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘The City Went Soft’
text: Almost 1,000 people took us up on the challenge we issued in our Fourth Annual Found Poem Student Contest to make verse from any Times article or articles they liked. It took us weeks to choose our favorites, but we’ve finally settled on 12.

headline: Dance in the Birthplace of Pesto
text: BOGLIASCO, Italy — The Ligurian region of Italy is better known for its magnificent coastline and its delicious cuisine (the birthplace of pesto!) than for dance. But Danza Contempo Ligure, a small festival based in Genoa, suggests that there is no shortage of choreographic activity. The final day of the new weeklong festival took place in Bogliasco, a small coastal village just beyond the Genoa city limits. The location was the Villa dei Pini, the grand house that belongs to the Bogliasco Foundation, an organization that provides residencies to artists and humanities scholars, and the participating choreographers made fine use of the villa’s beautiful gardens and coastal location despite unseasonally chilly weather.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Daniel Bergner on the Female ‘Viagra’
text: Daniel Bergner, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about the development of a pill to stimulate female desire. His new book, “What Do Women Want?: Adventures in the Science of Female Desire” comes out next week.

headline: SAC Could Give the Justice Dept. a High-Value Target
text: The subpoenas issued to executives at SAC Capital Advisors to testify before a grand jury provide a powerful indication that prosecutors have made the firm the focus of their latest effort to crack down on insider trading. Unfortunately for SAC, it may also be a case of being in the wrong place at the wrong time.

headline: The Challenges of Raising Prices and Competing With Online Retailers
text: At the last She Owns It Business Group meeting, the owners talked about several issues related to pricing. This post focuses on the prices charged by the two family businesses in the group, and the particular challenges of selling a product that is sold online for less.

headline: Home Prices Rise, Putting Country in Buying Mood
text: Americans are in a buying mood, thanks largely to the housing recovery.

headline: The Gun Report: Memorial Day Edition
text: Remember 6-month-old Jonylah Watkins, who was shot and killed on March 11 while sitting in her father’s lap in a minivan in Chicago? Authorities said Monday that the man accused in the shooting, which also wounded her father, was seeking revenge for the theft of a video game console. Koman Willis, a documented gang member with 38 previous arrests, was charged with first-degree murder.

headline: Divided Court, in 2 Rulings, Makes It Easier to Challenge Criminal Convictions
text: WASHINGTON — In a pair of 5-to-4 decisions that divided along ideological lines, the Supreme Court on Tuesday made it easier for inmates to challenge their convictions.

headline: Indian Cows Find Patrons in U.S.
text: BARSANA, Uttar Pradesh — The cow’s status as a sacred being in Hinduism is increasingly being threatened as more wealthy Indians, even Hindus, are turning carnivorous, as Gardiner Harris of The New York Times recently reported. Meanwhile, the increasing demand for beef is driving gangs to steal cows that are wandering around Delhi so that the animals can be sold to slaughterhouses.Still, cows have plenty of protectors in India, and even beyond its borders. Thousands of miles away, Indian citizens living in the United States regularly send money to cow shelters in India like Mataji Gaushala, located in Barsana, near Mathura in Uttar Pradesh.

headline: New Ways to Use ‘Ancient’ Grains
text: “Ancient grains” seems to be a new buzz phrase in the world of whole foods (or maybe I’ve been missing something for a long time). The words describe grain varieties that have been eaten as staples for hundreds if not thousands of years. Some of these have fed people in far-flung parts of the world for a very long time but have been of little interest as a food on the American market. Grains like sorghum have been grown here but fed primarily to animals, whereas sorghum has been a staple for centuries in Africa and India.

headline: Online Currency Exchange Accused of Laundering $6 Billion
text: The operators of a global currency exchange ran a $6 billion money-laundering operation online, a central hub for criminals trafficking in everything from stolen identities to child pornography, federal prosecutors in New York said on Tuesday.

headline: Sorghum Salad With Cucumbers, Avocado and Cherry Tomatoes
text: One thing I’ve learned about cooking sturdy grains like this (and the other grains we’re working with this week) for salads is that they will absorb dressing better if you let them cook until they burst or splay. In the case of sorghum, the grain is done after 50 minutes, but if you let it go for another 10 the grains will burst and the lemon juice and olive oil won’t slide off.

headline: Mack Emerman, Founder of Criteria Recording Studios, Dies at 89
text: Mack Emerman, a jazz lover whose hobby recording bands at nightclubs led him to found Criteria Recording Studios in Miami, where dozens of celebrated pop and rock records were made, died on May 17 in Miami Beach. He was 89.

headline: Who Will Stay the Longest? Spurs Have Edge on Red Wings
text: For a while this playoff season, the San Antonio Spurs and the Detroit Red Wings were locked in a battle for supremacy in the “team that wouldn’t go away” category and they were taking this battle quite seriously, despite coming at it from vastly different directions. The Red Wings were a somewhat faded version of their dynastic selves, stalwarts having retired and a new generation of players making Wings fans check their programs repeatedly, but still, making the N.H.L. playoffs for a 22nd straight season — and needing a big late-season push to do it — forced everyone to stop and pay homage.

headline: Women in Congress Confront the Military on Sexual Assault
text: WASHINGTON — Shocking the gridlocked Congress into action, a half dozen or so bipartisan female senators are escalating their war on sexual crimes in the military and deploying their outrage, clout and legions of supporters against a rigid military structure and its male-dominated ranks.

headline: A Rare, Pristine Subway Station: See It While You Can
text: What’s spotlessly clean, freshly painted and doesn’t have rust stains and grime oozing down the walls like the backdrop of an ’80s horror/dystopian future flick? Chances are good that your first answer would not be “a New York City subway station” (except for some of the stations on the Upper East Side, which don’t really count).

headline: Image of the Day: May 28
text: The Taj Mahal in Agra, Uttar Pradesh,

headline: The Only Investing Pattern That Matters Is Behavioral
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: Anti-Polio Campaign Worker Is Shot Dead in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A volunteer in a polio vaccination campaign was killed and her colleague wounded in an attack by militants near Peshawar on Tuesday, a district administration official said.

headline: Popular Governors, and Prospects for 2016
text: Last month, we examined the most unpopular governors facing re-election in 2014. Many of the governors with the poorest job approval ratings were Republicans in Democratic-leaning and swing states.

headline: Kipling Letter Says He Borrowed ‘Promiscuously’ for ‘The Jungle Book’
text: While Rudyard Kipling spun beloved characters out of creatures like a bear, a tiger, a snake and a panther for his classic story collection “The Jungle Book,” he may have been a bit of a vulture himself and made monkey’s uncles of his readers — at least according to a letter that suggests he made use of outside sources for a portion of the work.

headline: At the Biennale, Venice’s Locals Stage a Show of Their Own
text: Every other year, the art world descends on Venice for the Biennale, a six-month-long flurry of artistic activity. This year’s Biennale, which opens for previews tomorrow, comprises an international exhibition, 88 different national pavilions and a host of collateral events and shows. The missing piece of the pie, according to Caroline Corbetta, the curator behind Il Crepaccio, a tiny exhibition space based out of the window of a restaurant in Milan, is the involvement of the young artists who actually live and work in Venice. “Every two years their city becomes the real center of the art world, but they draw no particular benefit in terms of visibility,” Corbetta said.

headline: One Area in Which Congress Excels: Naming Post Offices
text: Pillory Congress all you want as do-nothing or dysfunctional, as its critics often have. But in one respect, lawmakers in the Capitol are remarkably productive: they name post offices like nobody’s business.

headline: Wheelies: The Happy German Worker Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Tamping Down Expectations on China’s Growth
text: The prospects for China’s economy look so challenging for the remainder of 2013 that increasing numbers of usually cheerleading investment bank economists are cutting their rosy growth forecast for China. The release last Thursday of preliminary manufacturing data for May, which surprisingly indicated a contraction in manufacturing activity, was just one more in a series of weak data points.

headline: Jarring Injuries Marked Previous Bruins-Penguins Series
text: The Boston Bruins and the Pittsburgh Penguins don’t have a lot of playoff history between them. What they do have – at least from the Boston perspective – as they head into the Eastern Conference finals, which starts in Pittsburgh on Saturday night, is a history of cheap shots and dirty plays that felled two Bruins, one of them the widely admired Cam Neely, who was entering the prime of his Hall of Fame career.

headline: Seared Tofu With Sugar Snap Peas and Sesame Seeds
text: In What’s for Dinner?, a column appearing every other week on Diner’s Journal, Melissa Clark answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Rebecca Hall to Make Broadway Debut in Revival of 85-Year-Old Play
text: The British actress Rebecca Hall will make her Broadway debut next winter in a revival of Sophie Treadwell’s 1928 play, “Machinal,” playing a young woman who rebels against the cultural norms of 1920s America, Roundabout Theater Company announced on Tuesday. Ms. Hall is a regular presence on London stages, including in several Shakespeare productions directed by her father, Peter Hall. She performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 2009 in the Bridge Project productions of “The Winter’s Tale” and “The Cherry Orchard.”

headline: Lulzsec Hacker Pleads Guilty
text: 6:27 p.m. | Updated with additional comments from prosecutors and the defendant.

headline: Finding the Route to Happiness
text: Travel booking sites have caught on to the fact that people are willing to pay a little extra to avoid headaches like a four-hour layover in Dallas-Fort Worth airport. Hipmunk’s “agony” rating, for example, sorts flights by price, duration and the number of stops.

headline: Two Globe Reporters Plan Book on Marathon Bombings
text: Two Boston Globe reporters have made a deal to write “the definitive book” on the Boston marathon bombings and their aftermath, their publisher said on Tuesday.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Our Regulatory System
Judge in Trayvon Martin Case Puts Limits on Defense
text: MIAMI — Lawyers for George Zimmerman, who is charged with second-degree murder in the killing of Trayvon Martin, will be barred from mentioning Mr. Martin’s marijuana use, history of fights or high school suspension during opening statements in Mr. Zimmerman’s trial, which begins June 10.

headline: Dean in E-Mail Searches Steps Down at Harvard
text: The undergraduate dean at Harvard will step down this summer, she and the university announced on Tuesday, months after she came under fire for her handling of a search of some junior faculty members’ e-mail accounts.

headline: After Day 1, a Look at the Bike Share Program
text: On Monday, New York City’s bike share program finally reached the streets — unlocking 6,000 bikes for public use across more than 300 stations in Manhattan and Brooklyn. With the skies clear and the streets relatively bare because of the Memorial Day holiday, riders engaged in a series of trial runs and joy rides, saving the commuting for Tuesday morning.

headline: Hobbled Vandeweghe Falls to Shvedova in First Round
text: PARIS — Coco Vandeweghe shrugged off a disastrous first set but could not overcome a determined Yaroslava Shvedova of Kazakhstan, losing, 0-6, 6-3, 2-6, in a rain-interrupted first-round match at the French Open Tuesday.

headline: Obama to Name New Leader of Economic Advisers Council
text: WASHINGTON — The White House is expected to name Jason Furman, the deputy director of the National Economic Council, as the chairman of the president’s Council of Economic Advisers, according to a person familiar with the matter who declined to comment on the record.

headline: Grape-Nuts Wants You to Climb Every Mountain
text: A venerable cereal brand is using an anniversary as a way to reintroduce itself as well as to introduce a line extension meant to appeal to more contemporary tastes.

headline: Taxing the Rich
text: For my sins (and, yes, an honorarium too), I’m doing this. So it’s worth putting out some of the basics.

headline: Incentives to Start a 529 College Savings Plan
text: College graduation season is in full swing, marking an annual rite of passage — and serving as a reminder that higher education isn’t getting any cheaper. One option available to help families put away money for college, and avoid borrowing too much, is a 529 college savings plan.

headline: The World As Wonkblog Sees It
text: Jonathan Chait’s Atlantic profile of Josh Barro, the Bloomberg View blogger and columnist who’s gradually transitioned from reform-minded center-right pundit to entertaining scourge of the contemporary G.O.P., has launched a lot of discussion about conservative reform projects in general, and (for my sins) I’ll probably write a post or two on that theme later this week. To start with, though, I think it’s worth saying something in response to this post from Ezra Klein, which uses Barro’s recent arc as a case study in the Republican Party’s intellectual self-marginalization:

headline: A Brief, Useless Note On Being Bashed
text: Fairly often I receive comments or other communications asking me to respond to X or Y, who has said Z about me and/or my arguments. For the most part, I am not going to oblige. Why?

headline: Returning Wood to the Cooking Fire
text: When Matthew Semmelhack and Mark Liberman, the owners of AQ in San Francisco, open their new restaurant nearby later this year, they won’t have a stove. Or an oven.

headline: Health Care Is Spread Thin on Alaskan Frontier
text: BETHEL, Alaska — Americans in some rural places fret at how far away big-city medical help might be in an emergency, or at the long drives they are forced to make for prenatal care, or stitches, or chemotherapy.

headline: Tough Politics, Easy Math
text: No two governors better represent the Tea Party ethos than Governors Rick Perry of Texas and Jan Brewer of Arizona. As required by the rigid ideology of the far right, the two are pretty much in sync on the major issues of the day — like gun control.

headline: After the Thaw: Outdoor Fun in Berlin
text: Berlin might be a young, vibrant, creative city, but during the long, cold dark winter all that youth and vibrancy and creativity is cooped up indoors. This winter was particularly long and cold: average March temperatures were below freezing and it snowed on Good Friday.

headline: Haas Happy to Escape First Round at a Major
text: PARIS –Tommy Haas of Germany raced to a 7-6 (4), 6-1, 6-3 victory over Guillaume Rufin of France on Tuesday to reach the second round of the French Open.

headline: Bankia Shares Tumble After a New Stock Issue
text: MADRID — Shares in Bankia, the giant Spanish mortgage lender that was at the heart of the country’s banking crisis, fell sharply on Tuesday after a large share issue that was meant to herald a new start.

headline: Chinese President to Seek New Relationship With U.S. in Talks
text: BEIJING — China’s new president, Xi Jinping, took a hands-on approach on Monday while meeting with President Obama’s national security adviser to prepare the agenda for the California summit meeting between the two leaders next week.

headline: Rutgers Athletic Director Faces New Questions
text: In the weeks since Rutgers hired Julie Hermann to forge a new path for the university’s athletics program, which was still reeling from the fallout of a coaching abuse scandal, Rutgers officials have unexpectedly had to defend their selection of Hermann against accusations of her misconduct dating to a coaching job she held in the 1990s.

headline: Valeant Shows How M.&A. Can Favor the Brave
text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals shows how some M.&A. favors the brave. Buying $8.7 billion Bausch & Lomb is the biggest deal yet for the acquisitive company, but it comes with huge cost savings that investors glorified. Chief executives elsewhere should take note.

headline: China’s Central Bank Has Its Own Worries
text: HONG KONG — While developed economies have worried whether international investors will keep showing up at their bond auctions if their central banks keep printing money, China has had a different worry.

headline: Central Banks Act With a New Boldness to Revitalize Economies
text: When James Bullard, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, arrived in Frankfurt last week, he issued an unusual public warning to the European Central Bank: Be bolder.

headline: Father and Son Travel Across America to Meet Veterans
text: Amber Atchley has held more than one man’s life in her hands. She served as an Army medic in Iraq, where her skill kept some soldiers together and alive under enemy fire. You’d think with such experience, Amber could become a civilian paramedic, but her military training does not automatically qualify her for those jobs.

headline: A Setback Made Possible by a Big Leap Forward
text: The American Alex Kuznetsov, a runner-up at the 2004 French Open juniors, was unable to find similar success in his first appearance in the main draw of the men’s event, falling to a fellow wild card, Lucas Pouille, in straight sets Tuesday.

headline: Tragedies Inspire Sock in French Open Breakthrough
text: PARIS — Not since the era of Andre Agassi and Jim Courier have American fans had anyone to genuinely get excited about in the men’s draw at Roland Garros. But after watching Jack Sock over the past week, it seems Sock, a big-serving Nebraskan, may develop into a clay-courter of note in the years to come.

headline: The Suicide Debate, Revisited
text: Last week I had an exchange with The New Republic’s Nate Cohn over whether the seemingly strong state-by-state link between population density and suicide rates meant that trends in religious affiliation and family structure could be discounted as drivers of the recent rise in suicide. Now Sean Trende of RealClearPolitics has very kindly supplemented those ramblings with some actual regression analysis, which suggests that our entire focus on density was misplaced:

headline: Hudson County’s Bounty
text: The family restaurants of Hoboken and Jersey City.

headline: Only the Food Is Exotic
text: When I was growing up in the 1970s in Hudson County, N.J., there was plenty to complain about: toxic waste, political corruption, blighted buildings. The one thing people never knocked was the food.

headline: Q&A: Sending an Automated Vacation Reply With Outlook.com
text: Q.

headline: Ending the ‘Friendly’ Fat Talk
text: In the Health section, Jan Hoffman writes that “‘Fat Talk’ Compels but Carries a Cost.” What’s “fat talk”? Here’s her example:

headline: Metro-North Track Worker Fatally Hit by Train in Connecticut
text: 4:46 p.m. | Updated A Metro-North Railroad track foreman was struck and killed by a commuter train on Tuesday near a rail station under construction in West Haven, Conn., the authorities said.

headline: Europe’s Reservations on Immigration Grow
text: BASEL, Switzerland — Carolina Porta Nova, 19, had dreams of becoming a schoolteacher in her native Portugal. But the grinding recession, government cuts to education and an unemployment rate of about 40 percent among young people put an end to those plans.

headline: An All-Terrain Sound System
text: Known primarily for its emergency radios and backup batteries, the Etón Corporation broadened its offerings last year with the Rukus Solar, a wireless boombox. This week, Etón introduced the Rukus’s smaller sibling, the Rugged Rukus.

headline: Newborn Rescued From Sewer Pipe in China Reportedly in Good Condition
text: Video broadcast repeatedly on Chinese state television in recent days showed the rescue of a newborn who spent his first few hours on Earth trapped in a sewer pipe directly beneath the toilet where his mother said she had unexpectedly given birth.

headline: Push for Antiracism Bill Leads to Rift in Greek Coalition
text: ATHENS — The issue of how to deal with a surge in racist violence in Greece opened a rift within the country’s fragile governing coalition on Tuesday, when its two junior parties said they would push ahead with an antiracism bill over the objections of the conservative senior party.

headline: Clinton Aides Are Focus of Subpoena for Benghazi Talking Points
text: WASHINGTON — Several top aides to Hillary Rodham Clinton, the former secretary of state, are targets of the latest subpoena for information about the drafting of talking points after the siege last fall on an American compound in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: Broadway Attendance Fell Six Percent This Season
text: Attendance at Broadway shows shrank by 6.2 percent during the 2012-13 theater season to its lowest level in eight years, with theater producers blaming Hurricane Sandy as well as a weak lineup of musicals and plays during the fall and winter. Approximately 11.57 million people attended Broadway productions during the season, compared to 12.33 million in the previous one, according to statistics released on Tuesday by the Broadway League, the trade association of theater owners and producers. The last time that attendance numbers were so low was the 2004-5 season, which drew 11.53 million people.

headline: The Holiday Masses Descend, and Bruckner Reverberates
text: There may be some systemic problems within the field of classical music. But now and then something happens that makes you feel proud of institutions and the music-loving public. One such event is the New York Philharmonic’s annual free Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, which took place on Monday night. For this program, the music director Alan Gilbert conducted the orchestra in just one work: Bruckner’s 60-minute Symphony No. 3 in D minor.

headline: Tomic Retires From First-Round Match, Drama Trailing as He Limps Off
text: PARIS — When Bernard Tomic took the court for his first-round match Tuesday, he was in a rare position for a professional athlete: much more attention was focused on who was in the crowd than who was on the clay.

headline: Criticisms, Favorite Gags and Other Reactions to the New ‘Arrested Development’
text: It’s been just over 60 hours since the new season of “Arrested Development” started streaming on Netflix. Some superfans had the  fortitude to watch all 15 episodes not long after sunrise on Sunday morning. Many of the rest of us are working our way through the show as much as the commitments of daily life  will allow. But just about everyone has an opinion about  favorite Bluth family moments from the new episodes, and whether it’s been worth the time to binge on the show.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Pakistan, Afghanistan, England and Syria.

headline: ‘Joe Is New York’
text: A new ad from the Lhota campaign focuses on the candidates history in New York City,

headline: Chinese Filmmaker in Deal to Make Films for Theaters and Online
text: BEIJING — Zhang Yimou, China’s most famous filmmaker, on Tuesday announced a partnership to make movies with a Beijing-based production company, Le Vision Pictures, best known for distributing its content online.

headline: The Ties That Bind Two TV Siblings
text: Showtime’s “Homeland” and the Israeli television series on which it’s based, “Prisoners of War,” are like an experiment in genetics: Sharing DNA but raised by different parents in different environments, they’re entirely distinct while maintaining a strong family resemblance. Also, they’re both very good.

headline: Renovation Plans in Limbo, Roland Garros Faces Future
text: PARIS — Another day’s play at the French Open was about to begin, and the tournament’s director, Gilbert Ysern, sat in his office chair with clenched fists and delivered a series of mock blows to his own chin.

headline: ‘A Mayor for Every New Yorker’
text: The Catsimatidis campaign released its first television ad of the race.

headline: If You Like  Melissa  Etheridge,  Try Serena Ryder
text: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Triple Play: Week 8 Results
text: None of the players in Question No. 1 were very Ruthian, but Pablo Sandoval, Carlos Santana and Nick Swisher all hit one home run to be the correct answers.

headline: Thinking Big: Four Visions of a New Penn Station
text: The Municipal Art Society asked four design firms to draw big: Reimagine the ideal Pennsylvania Station and Madison Square Garden. “We think it’s an important part of the process, for people to start to see ideas,” said Vin Cipolla, the society’s president, in an interview. “The present station isn’t sustainable — it can’t meet the needs of New Yorkers and the needs of the region.”

headline: The Roving Runner Rides a Bike
text: On a day like Memorial Day — clear skies, comfortable temperatures, day off from work — I would normally ride the subway to a corner of the city and do some exploring on the run.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Lhota’s First Ad Highlights Biography
text: “Joe Is New York,” a 30-second television advertisement for Joseph J. Lhota’s campaign for the Republican nomination for mayor, will run on cable channels across New York City starting on Thursday. The spot was produced by Wilson-Grand Communications.

headline: If You Think You Can Dance, Keep It to Yourself
text: Can everybody please stop dancing?

headline: Still Young, Even at 50
text: Since 1984, the New York Youth Symphony has awarded commissions to 102 composers age 30 and under, whose works have won three Pulitzer Prizes and the Grawemeyer Award, among other accolades. Those commissioned by the ensemble include Michael Torke, Aaron Jay Kernis, Augusta Read Thomas, Kevin Puts and Derek Bermel.

headline: Creating One World of Uninterrupted Movement
text: It’s a famous part of dance history that Diaghilev’s Ballets Russes blasted color across the stages of Western Europe and America in the early 20th century, as we’re reminded in a new show at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. Yet, oh! How even those costumes and décors would pale beside the gloriously bright hues of DanceAfrica last weekend.

headline: Street Style: Paint Splatter
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of May 20.

headline: Salvation Taco and Taqueria Tlaxcalli
text: Inside two taco restaurants located in Murray Hill and the Bronx.

headline: Florida Teenager Loses French Open Debut
text: PARIS — Lauren Davis of Boca Raton, Fla., rallied from a disastrous first seven games to make a match out of a rout. But she still lost, 6-0, 7-5, to Kristina Mladenovic on Tuesday in the first round of the French Open.

headline: Two Roads Down Mexico Way
text: Expectations are everything.

headline: A Nation, Its Seams Fraying
text: If you were to take apart George Packer’s ambitious new book, “The Unwinding,” as if it were a car’s engine, and spread the parts across your garage, you’d essentially be looking at 5 large pieces and 10 small ones — the nuts and bolts and cotter pins.

headline: Original Six Rivalry Goes to a Game 7
text: The postmortems began a few days ago for the N.H.L.’s top team, the Chicago Blackhawks, who were down, 3-1, to the Detroit Red Wings. Pause the grim epitaphs, for now. The Blackhawks have made a sharp turnaround in the Western Conference semifinals, winning Game 5 in Chicago and Game 6 in Detroit to force a Game 7 at the United Center on Wednesday.

headline: Three Measures of Central Banks’ Effectiveness
text: As the financial and economic crisis of 2008 and 2009 deepened, governments relied heavily on their central banks to lift their economies. Central banks, however, possess only a few limited, but powerful, tools. And it isn’t always clear whether their actions — or lack of actions — are even responsible for the results. But increasingly central bankers are being bolder in their attempts to get the world’s major economies moving again.

headline: FIFA Congress Takes Flight in Mauritius
text: The Dodo, a flightless bird native to the island of Mauritius, has been extinct since late in the 17th century.

headline: Restaurant Report: L’Escalier in Cologne, Germany
text: There are a couple of German words for restaurant, but most of the people who use them were around before the Wall fell. The younger generation, raised on a diet of American movies and European solidarity, just says “restaurant.” Yet though language may be headed in an international direction, an increasing number of German chefs are cooking with a more native idiom, sometimes combining it with other cuisines in intriguing ways.

headline: Hotel Review: The J House Greenwich in Riverside, Conn.
text: Rates

headline: How It Looks to Think: Watch Her
text: My only real problem with “Hannah Arendt” is that it’s not a mini-series. Arendt was a writer of long books and a maker of complex arguments, so the two hours of Margarethe von Trotta’s ardent and intelligent film about her are bound to feel somewhat superficial. And the movie, even as it answers a hunger for engagement with the life of an extraordinary mind, may also awaken an appetite for more. Arendt’s work, a heady amalgam of philosophy, history, journalism and political theory, does not easily align with the academic fashions of the moment.

headline: Onstage Tasting Menu in a Feast of One-Acts
text: It’s spring, which means it’s time for the Ensemble Studio Theater’s annual marathon of one-act plays, now in its 34th year. Series A (the first of three), which features five short works, starts out weak but finishes strong.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Headliner

headline: Excerpt: 'Dancing Fools'
text: The new series on ABC Family combines video clips with a dance competition.

headline: A Little Meat Goes a Long Way
text: Recipes using different meats, cooking techniques and, of course, vegetables.

headline: Make Peace With Meat
text: I probably eat a third as much meat as I used to and, on the not-rare (three times a week?) occasions that I do indulge, I eat less of it.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Catsimatidis Emphasizes Business Background
text: It is perhaps no surprise that the first mayoral candidate to begin running a costly television advertisement is the wealthy businessman John A. Catsimatidis, a Republican with a $3 billion fortune at his disposal. (His ad went up a few days before one for a Republican rival, Joseph J. Lhota, is to appear.) Eager to increase his name recognition and unhampered by spending limits because he is not participating in New York City’s voluntary public matching funds program, Mr. Catsimatidis commissioned this highly biographical 60-second ad, which will be shown on cable and broadcast television, from the Victory Group, which is based in Florida. The firm has worked with former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

headline: 16 Not-Quite-Meatless Recipes
text: A selection of recipes by Mark Bittman, all of which use pork, beef, lamb or veal as supporting or even bit players, letting vegetables and grains move to center stage.

headline: Historic Tujague’s Will Remain Open in New Orleans
text: Tujague’s, the historic New Orleans restaurant in the French Quarter whose fate had hung in the balance since its owner died in February, will continue serving brisket and Sazeracs, it was announced Tuesday.

headline: Front Burner
text: To View: The Influence of His HomelandLike his grandfather Diego Rivera, the artist Pedro Diego Alvarado-Rivera takes his inspiration from his native Mexico. His oils are vibrant, ripe still-life and landscape paintings that focus on the country’s fruits and vegetables, like his “Sandia Melonera,” right. A sampling will be on display through June 30: Refined Abundance II is at Ruiz-Healy Art, 900 Park Avenue (79th Street) by appointment from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Monday to Friday, ruizhealyart.com, (212) 452-1662.

headline: Wines for an Asian-Style Stew
text: Wine with Chinese food may seem counterintuitive, but the combination can work quite well, especially with the gentler spicing of Cantonese cuisine. Many wine lovers take advantage of bring-your-own-bottle policies to drink great wines at Cantonese restaurants. You could open either red or white with the Asian-style vegetable-and-veal stew in Mark Bittman’s Flexitarian column this week, as long as the wine has lively acidity so it isn’t buried under the assertive flavors of the food. I would lean toward a white, like a peppery grüner veltliner, especially one of the more age-worthy specimens. An Austrian riesling would also work well, and for a full dose of umami, why not a fino sherry? Among reds, a fresh, fragrant Chinon or Bourgueil from the Loire Valley would match well, and if you prefer a bolder wine, maybe a zinfandel from the lighter side of the spectrum.

headline: Rift Over Air Crash Roils Poland’s Artists
text: WARSAW — On a foggy April morning in 2010, the Polish president’s plane crashed over Smolensk in western Russia, killing him and 95 other members of Poland’s political and military elite, traumatizing the nation and opening a bitter political divide over what caused the disaster. Now the fissures have spread to the cultural realm, as filmmakers, writers and artists fiercely debate how — or even whether — to portray this still-visceral history.

headline: Jesper Just’s Paradoxical Danish Pavilion at the Venice Biennale
text: The menagerie of exhibitions opening this week at the 55th Venice Biennale are a celebration of internationalism. But the pavilions dotted throughout the Giardini and beyond can also feel like a study in displacement, with the art and architecture mounted by various nations feeling less like a representation of those countries’ identities and more like a reflection of the globalized playground that is the contemporary art world.

headline: Discuss Rape and Justice in Pakistan With Reporters From The Times and ‘Frontline’
text: Readers of The Lede are invited to join a discussion of the issues raised by the documentary “Outlawed in Pakistan,” to be broadcast Tuesday night on PBS. The film, part of the “Frontline” series, followed the case of Kainat Soomro, a young woman who accused four men of gang-raping her when she was just 13 years old.

headline: The Ceremonial First Pitch
text: Baseball’s ceremonial first pitch was once reserved for dignitaries and sitting presidents. Today nearly anyone can take the mound.

headline: Witnesses Describe Killings in Syria to BBC

headline: Tejada, Still Working on His Swing, Remains Atop the Order
text: Ruben Tejada’s swing remains a project, one that will play out in plain sight as he continues to man the Mets’ leadoff spot.

headline: Some Germans Balk at Plan to Use Drones to Fight Graffiti
text: BERLIN — Germans have no trouble agreeing that the graffiti covering many of the nation’s commuter trains in a most un-Germanic scrawl is intolerable. But what they cannot agree on is the main railway operator’s proposed cure: small drones to patrol the rail yards by night.

headline: As Hurricane Season Nears, Con Ed Shows Off Equipment’s New Protections
text: Before another big tropical storm can surge into the Consolidated Edison substations that were flooded by Hurricane Sandy, it will have to breach a mile of concrete walls and steel gates.

headline: Drab Office in New Jersey Gets the Cinderella Treatment
text: PLAINSBORO, N.J. — Novo Nordisk, the Danish pharmaceutical company, moved into its North American headquarters here this month, after a $225 million gut renovation transformed an aging structure into a glassy corporate campus updated for a modern work force.

headline: Baseball Stadium Bolsters El Paso’s Resurgence
text: EL PASO — Staccato explosions cracked across the cloudless desert sky, to be drowned out by a deeper rumble that shook the earth as this city’s 10-story former City Hall came rolling down upon its foundation in a blinding cloud of dust and debris in mid-April.

headline: Obama and Christie: Moderate Friendship
text: On the Jersey Shore, Gov. Chris Christie’s friendly welcome toward President Obama suggested he cared little about criticism from Republicans.

headline: Colorado: Court Upholds System for Financing Schools
text: Colorado’s highest court on Tuesday rejected a major challenge to how the state finances public schools, saying the system, while imperfect, conforms to the State Constitution. The ruling by the Colorado Supreme Court, which overturned a lower court’s decision, handed a stinging defeat to parents and school districts that argued that the financing formula was fundamentally unfair and unbalanced, and widened the gaps between “have” and “have-not” school districts. Many state officials welcomed the court’s ruling. They said it would remove the heated educational battle from the courts and return it to the hands of elected lawmakers, who have already taken steps to try to improve how Colorado finances its schools.

headline: Nike Chooses to Sever Its Ties With Livestrong
text: Nike stuck by Tiger Woods in the wake of his infidelity and gave Michael Vick an endorsement deal after Vick had served time in prison for his role in a dogfighting ring, which included killing dogs that underperformed.

headline: Myles J. Horn
text: Mr. Horn, 62, is a real estate investor and developer who specializes in co-op and condominium conversions and the acquisition of large blocks of unsold shares and units. He is currently involved in a major renovation of the Printing House, a residential building in the West Village where he and his partners own the majority of the apartments.

headline: Angelo J. Errichetti, 84, Camden Mayor Convicted of Bribery, Dies
text: Angelo J. Errichetti, a former two-term mayor of Camden, N.J., whose career as a state Democratic power broker ended in the early 1980s when he was ensnared in the Congressional corruption scandal known as Abscam and served nearly three years in prison, died on May 16 at home in Ventnor, N.J. He was 84.

headline: Keeping It Zany in a Losing Year
text: Baseball’s postgame ritual of interrupting an on-field interview with a shaving cream pie to the face is a comforting one, sometimes even for the recipient. It neatly punctures the me-first notion so prevalent in sports; even a player’s moment in the spotlight can be taken from him by his teammates. Watching a utility player slap some shaving cream in the face of a $15-million-a-year All-Star is the kind of humility delivery system most people can really get behind.

headline: Anti-West Hard-Liner Gains in Iranian Race

His movements were hampered by a prosthetic leg, a badge of honor from his days as a young Revolutionary Guards member in Iran’s great trench war with Iraq.

headline: With Money at Risk, Hospitals Push Staff to Wash Hands
text: At North Shore University Hospital on Long Island, motion sensors, like those used for burglar alarms, go off every time someone enters an intensive care room. The sensor triggers a video camera, which transmits its images halfway around the world to India, where workers are checking to see if doctors and nurses are performing a critical procedure: washing their hands.

headline: A Front-Runner Emerges in Iran’s Election
text: Saeed Jalili, 47, who many say has been groomed for a top position in Iran’s establishment, is by far the most outspoken hardliner among the eight candidates approved to run.

headline: The Trouble With Taxing Corporations
text: Everybody does it.

headline: Interleague? Fans Shrug in Down Year for Baseball
text: Even during other down years, the Mets were guaranteed of at least one thing: selling out their home games against the Yankees. Since the advent of interleague play in 1997, these games determined temporary bragging rights within New York City and had an edge to them that put fans in every seat.

text: Two picks for first-round matches to watch on Tuesday (Benoit Paire vs. Marcos Baghdatis and Jamie Hampton vs. Lucie Safarova) were not able to be completed because of intermittent rain, but they remain recommended viewing for Wednesday.

headline: Officer Shot in Head in 2012 Makes an Arrest Near the Same Spot
text: For Police Sgt. Kevin Brennan, his visit to the Bushwick Houses on Tuesday was supposed to be uneventful. He was there to familiarize himself with where he had been on the night of Jan. 31, 2012, when he was shot in the head. The trial of the man charged with trying to murder him is approaching, and Sergeant Brennan needed to prepare.

headline: Subway Ballet
text: Young men perform daring aerial dances in a crowded New York City subway car.

headline: Switzerland Weighs Deal in Tax Cases
text: The Swiss government is considering a proposal to disclose bank client names and pay a multibillion-dollar fine to the United States to help resolve a long-running dispute between the two countries over the handling of tax-evasion cases, American and Swiss sources briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Subway Ballet’
text: The first time I saw these young men perform, in a tightly packed New York City subway car, I imagined we were all flying. I later learned that their dances and aerial moves were named “the part-time stripper,” “walking on air” and “the Kid and Larry.” Their physicality, bravado and humor captivated me. While some riders considered them a nuisance, I felt they transformed the subway car into a remarkable sort of public theater.

headline: In Thailand’s Schools, Vestiges of Military Rule
text: SAMUT PRAKAN, Thailand — Put aside for a moment the image of Thailand that tourists often see, a laid-back, anything-goes country of libidinous night life.

headline: My Near Miss
text: IT was probably our eighth or ninth admission that day, but my intern and I had given up counting. I was midway through my medical residency, already a master of efficiency. You had to be, or you’d never keep up. This one was a classic eye-roller: a nursing home patient with dementia, sent to the emergency room for an altered mental status. When you were juggling patients with acute heart failure and rampant infections, it was hard to get worked up over a demented nonagenarian who was looking a little more demented.

headline: Shuttle Diplomacy, Kerry Style
text: Secretary of State John Kerry has seemed perpetually in motion in the Middle East since he assumed office, shuttling from one meeting to another with top Israeli and Palestinian officials over the last four months in an effort to revive peace negotiations. He has divulged few details, and his overall strategy is unclear. But it would be foolish to write off his peacemaking diplomacy, as some have. So far, he seems to be moving in a determined and encouraging fashion on a series of interlocking steps.

headline: Exceptions to Harsh Rules
text: On Tuesday, the Supreme Court handed down two important criminal procedure decisions, both allowing defendants to seek habeas corpus review of their convictions in federal court. The 5-to-4 majority, with Justice Anthony Kennedy joining the court’s four moderate liberals, reached the right result in each case. But, in a larger sense, the two decisions show how much the scope of habeas review has been curtailed by the Supreme Court in the last three decades, so that it now must work around earlier precedents to avoid doing injustice.

headline: How to Get a Job
text: Underneath the huge drop in demand that drove unemployment up to 9 percent during the recession, there’s been an important shift in the education-to-work model in America. Anyone who’s been looking for a job knows what I mean. It is best summed up by the mantra from the Harvard education expert Tony Wagner that the world doesn’t care anymore what you know; all it cares “is what you can do with what you know.” And since jobs are evolving so quickly, with so many new tools, a bachelor’s degree is no longer considered an adequate proxy by employers for your ability to do a particular job — and, therefore, be hired. So, more employers are designing their own tests to measure applicants’ skills. And they increasingly don’t care how those skills were acquired: home schooling, an online university, a massive open online course, or Yale. They just want to know one thing: Can you add value?

headline: The Wisdom of Bob Dole
text: Bob Dole no longer recognizes the Republican Party that he helped lead for years. Speaking over the weekend on “Fox News Sunday,” he said his party should hang a “closed for repairs” sign on its doors until it comes up with a few positive ideas, because neither he nor Ronald Reagan would now feel comfortable in its membership.

headline: Finding Democrats to Run Where Republicans Win
text: SIOUX FALLS, S.D. — Many Democrats in this state and beyond saw in Stephanie Herseth Sandlin an ideal candidate to help the party retain the Senate seat that Tim Johnson is giving up next year.

Don’t worry if introspection really isn’t your thing; all he’s asking you to do is figure out which words make up phrases using the word “in” that he has managed to cross (symmetrically, yet) six times in his puzzle.

headline: Defendant in Terror Case Gets Lawyer of His Choice
text: A lawyer who is under federal indictment in Syracuse and under federal investigation in Manhattan will be able to represent a high-profile defendant in a terrorism case, a judge ruled on Tuesday.

headline: France: Man Dies From New SARS-Like Infection
text: A 65-year-old man infected with a virus causing SARS-like symptoms died Monday, health authorities said, the first French patient to be killed by the condition known as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome. The man, who died of multiple organ failure in an isolation chamber in a hospital in Lille, is believed to have been infected while vacationing in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, in April. He was first hospitalized late last month, shortly after his return to France, with symptoms described only as digestive problems. While hospitalized, he infected a neighboring patient who remains hospitalized. The virus, known as a coronavirus, has killed 23 of the 44 people confirmed infected since September, most of them in Saudi Arabia.

headline: It’s Dark, but We See You: Release the Horseshoe Crabs
text: A police helicopter thundered over a darkened Jamaica Bay in fast pursuit of a boat with no lights and a load of ill-gotten quarry.

headline: Making His Mayoral Debate Debut at Education Forum, Weiner Basks in Attention
text: He took off his jacket and rolled up his shirt sleeves, setting himself off visually from the four other men onstage. When asked a question, he stood up to answer, holding the microphone as though he were roaming the room at a town hall, while the other candidates remained sedately seated. At moments he seemed to mock the debate rules, answering one question, “I’ve got no bloody idea,” and at one point offering to give his “instant rebuttal” to another candidate.

Quinn, the City Council speaker and mayoral candidate.

headline: Marshall Lytle, 79, Bassist With Bill Haley, Dies
text: Marshall Lytle, whose spirited, percussive bass work was heard on one of rock ’n’ roll’s seminal recordings, “Rock Around the Clock” by Bill Haley and His Comets, died on Saturday at his home in New Port Richey, Fla. He was 79.

headline: Jean Bach, Jazz Documentarian and Fan, Dies at 94
text: Jean Bach, a lifelong jazz zealot whose fascination with a photograph of the titans of jazz gathered in front of a Harlem brownstone in 1958 led her to make a prizewinning movie about that moment, “A Great Day in Harlem,” 36 years later, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

text: How prosecutors say Liberty Reserve’s money laundering scheme operated.

text: John C. Bierwirth, who led the Grumman Corporation, one of the nation’s largest aircraft makers, through challenging times in the 1970s and ’80s, died on Sunday at a hospice in Freeport, on Long Island. He was 89.

headline: Is It Better to Walk or Run?
text: Walking and running are the most popular physical activities for American adults. But whether one is preferable to the other in terms of improving health has long been debated. Now a variety of new studies that pitted running directly against walking are providing some answers. Their conclusion? It depends almost completely on what you are hoping to accomplish.

headline: Mets Stun Rivera and Yankees in Ninth
text: Terry Collins, the Mets’ manager, admitted on Tuesday afternoon that he once allowed himself to worry about Matt Harvey, his young ace, before big occasions. He feared the fiery pitcher’s emotions would boil over amid lofty circumstances. But Collins said he knew better now, after watching Harvey thrive one start after another.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (NBC) HEALING IN THE HEARTLAND: RELIEF BENEFIT CONCERT  Blake Shelton organized this concert, to be broadcast live from the Chesapeake Energy Arena in Oklahoma City and featuring performances by his wife, Miranda Lambert, above; Reba McEntire; Vince Gill; Luke Bryan; Rascal Flatts; and Ryan Tedder of OneRepublic. The event will raise money for the United Way of Central Oklahoma May Tornadoes Relief Fund, which will help finance recovery and rebuilding efforts in the state after the tornadoes that devastated Moore and the surrounding area on May 20.

headline: Pakistan Says U.S. Drone Killed Taliban Leader

headline: Papua New Guinea Acts to Repeal Sorcery Law After Strife
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The Parliament of Papua New Guinea has voted to repeal the country’s Sorcery Act and to reinstate the death penalty in certain cases to help stem an increase in violence against people accused of practicing black magic.

headline: Bachmann, Facing Inquiries, Will Not Seek Re-election in 2014
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Michele Bachmann, the Minnesota Republican whose status as a leading Tea Party voice in Congress has faded in the wake of a failed bid for president and a widening investigation into her campaign spending, said Wednesday that she would not seek re-election.

headline: C.E.O.’s Don’t Need to Earn Less. They Need to Sweat More.
text: One recent Thursday, G. Steven Farris, the chairman and C.E.O. of the poorly performing oil-and-gas company Apache, stood before a few hundred shareholders who were about to vote on his salary. Farris, who was hoping to earn well over $10 million for this year, listed a number of his accomplishments. “We’re the No. 1 driller in the Permian Basin,” he said, referring to the oil reserves in West Texas and New Mexico. But some shareholders, most likely mindful of the company’s falling stock price, noted that the proposed pay package seemed out of whack. Still, the tally was a nail-biter: 49.8 percent of the votes favored giving Farris the bump.

headline: Is Drinking and Driving Still a Problem for Teenagers?
text: Research shows that high school students are drinking and driving less than they were 30 years ago, and the number of people killed by drunken drivers is down by more than half. Still, about 10,000 people die each year in traffic accidents involving impaired drivers.

headline: Bill W. – Famous, Yet Seldom Seen
text: Kevin Hanlon and Dan Carracino figured they would face a steep learning curve when they started making their first documentary in 2004. They expected to make the usual newbie mistakes when it came, for example, to finding the right visuals. But considering their subject, they should have known better.

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: ‘One Book at a Time’
text: After the hubbub and sensory overload of the Kentucky Derby, I always take a few days to explore Lexington, Ky. These are peaceful days. I usually visit the Keeneland Library researching topics for future stories. But there are so many books, and so little time. This year, I decided to check out Lexington’s award-winning used book store, Black Swan Books.

headline: British Defense Chief Confirms Detentions of Afghans at Base

headline: Dymaxion Car Plans Resurface
text: Every once in a while, a car so brilliant and forward thinking comes along, it just can’t be ignored. Only it can. Some have a few moments of glory – the Tucker Torpedo, the General Motors EV1, and perhaps even the Fisker Karma, for example – and others don’t. The three-wheel Dymaxion car is one of those; the teardrop-shaped, 1930s-vintage car of the future that never made it into production.
