text: To the Editor:

headline: Kingsley’s Kindness
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Loop
text: To the Editor:

headline: Operation Faline
text: To the Editor:

headline: From Quinn, a Memoir More Personal Than Political
text: When her future wife made clear during one of their early dates that she could only be with a Yankees fan, Christine C. Quinn did not hesitate: “I dumped the Mets in a hot second.”

headline: Maison Premiere
text: Inside the lively oyster bar in Williamsburg that expanded its menu but kept its French Quarter feel.

headline: Revel in the Roar of the Crowd
text: The tight room is astonishingly loud, verging on raucous, but still the waiters murmur, hands behind their backs.

headline: Questions, and Opinions, About Flickr
text: My column this week about the new, revised Flickr has generated plenty of responses from readers.

headline: Resisting Conformity in Thailand
text: Thai schools are a drill sergeant’s dream. Discipline and conformity rule, but some students have begun calling for the abolition of the “mechanistic” education system.

headline: The Icing on the Cake
text: Outtakes is a behind-the-scenes glimpse of images in the Dining section. Andrew Scrivani (@AndrewScrivani on Twitter and Instagram) is a freelance photographer and a regular contributor to The New York Times. He writes the blog making SundaySauce.

headline: Why We Are Hiring Outsiders to Critique Our Performance
text: Sonu Panda is an animal.

headline: Lee Radziwill and Sofia Coppola, on Protecting Privacy
text: Sofia Coppola’s own life is the very picture of elegant discretion. Who better to critique a celebrity-obsessed generation that overshares and hyperconsumes?

headline: The Gun Report: May 30, 2013
text: On April 4, we reported that in ten U.S. states, gun deaths now outpace auto deaths.

headline: Mayor’s Fierce Stand Against Guns Creates Lightning Rod
text: Not long after the Connecticut school massacre in December, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took to television, radio and the Web to demand action on gun control.

headline: Why I Want to Choose the ‘Disadvantaged’ Local School (and Why I Might Not)
text: When I ask other parents of preschoolers in my urban San Diego neighborhood where they’re planning to send their little ones to kindergarten, the name of our local K-5 virtually never comes up. Because of the “Choice Program” in our district, parents can apply to send their kids to almost any public school in the system. So parents in our neighborhood opt for magnet schools, charter schools or even the garden-variety public school a couple of miles away that gets better test scores than our “zone school” does. Or they skip the public options altogether and commute to schools with the words “Country Day” or “Our Lady” in their names.

headline: Unions Press to End Special Trade Status for Bangladesh
text: WASHINGTON — After several deadly factory disasters in Bangladesh — including the collapse of an eight-story garment factory last month that left at least 1,127 people dead — labor advocates are stepping up pressure on the Obama administration, calling for it to convey its disapproval of working conditions in the country by revoking its special trade status.

headline: A Workout With Plenty of Bounce
text: A group of 25 men and women jumped to the beat of Lady Gaga’s “Americano” in a darkened room amid the glittering of a disco ball, the flashing of neon lights and the streaking of green, blue and red lasers. The scene could have been mistaken for a happening nightclub, but it was actually a recent class at JumpLife, a fitness studio in TriBeCa where the bouncing takes place on personal, low-to-the-ground trampolines, not a dance floor.

headline: ‘The Big Bang Theory’ and ‘The Mary Tyler Moore Show':  A Comparison
text: This past weekend’s Riff essay looked at “The Big Bang Theory” — a hit network sitcom that I was late to accept but quick to love. The show’s strong ensemble cast also brought to mind an unlikely comparison: “The Mary Tyler Moore Show,” a more critically lauded success that featured, arguably, the best sitcom ensemble cast of all time. Here, an unscientific analysis of the main characters on “Mary Tyler Moore” with their surprising “Big Bang Theory” doubles.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: A Time to Step Back

headline: The Brooklyn Breaker of Ancient Codes
text: The events of the past grow more alien as our distance from them increases, receding until they become, finally, unknowable. Unknowable, that is, but for those who take it upon themselves to decode the symbols, to examine what others see as indecipherable or unimportant, to sift a story from the chaff and to resurrect names, places, actions and ideas that would otherwise be lost.

headline: Dots, a Highly Addictive Game, Passes 3 Million Players
text: On Sunday afternoon my entire family sat in my sister’s living room, fingers jabbing at our iPhones, as we yelled a series of numbers aloud: “124!” “217!” “Oh, I just got to 400!” We were playing Dots, the highly addictive free game from Betaworks. (I won, with 474 points.)

headline: When Painters Showed the War in More Than Blue and Gray
text: If you’ve seen the awesome, soul-wrenching “Photography and the American Civil War” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, you might suppose that a second exhibition about the war would be redundant. It’s not. “The Civil War and American Art,” also at the Met, is a gripping show that sheds further light on how the nation experienced its fratricidal conflict. Organized by Eleanor Jones Harvey, senior curator at the Smithsonian American Art Museum, it is not the broad survey that its title suggests. It is a lean, pointedly selective show, consisting of about 60 paintings, from 1852 to 1877 — including outstanding works by Frederic Edwin Church, Sanford Robinson Gifford and Winslow Homer — and 18 photographs taken during the war.

headline: Youth Brigade at French Open Is Dwindling
text: PARIS — The last teenager in the men’s singles draw at the French Open lasted until 4:04 p.m. Paris time on Thursday, and Lucas Pouille, a young Frenchman, would have been eliminated sooner by Grigor Dimitrov if not for a couple of rain delays.

headline: Succession Carousel at General Electric
text: The potential exit of GE Capital’s chief shifts the spotlight onto his boss, Jeffrey Immelt. Michael Neal, who has led General Electric’s erstwhile high-flying lending unit for eight years, may be soon handing the helm to someone else, according to The Wall Street Journal. His departure raises the question of who will eventually succeed the conglomerate’s top dog.

headline: Can’t Smell or Breathe, but Checks Keep Coming
text: Things have changed in Rock Valley in 2016.

headline: Weight Loss May Ease Psoriasis
text: Losing weight may help reduce symptoms of psoriasis, a new study shows.

headline: This Time, a Growing Economy Stirs Unease
text: The American markets are getting worried again. But this time the fear is refreshingly different.

headline: Fastballs, Not Dunks, for 6-Foot-10 Hoosier
text: The gag works because it plays off an easy presumption. Who expects a nearly 7-foot athlete at Indiana University to play anything but basketball?

headline: Bloc Challenges Britain on Welfare Rules
text: BRUSSELS — In a move certain to stoke British frustrations with the European Union, the 27-nation bloc’s executive arm is taking Britain to court over restrictions on who can receive social security benefits.

headline: A New Childhood Hazard: Medical Marijuana
text: Accidental ingestion of marijuana may be on the rise, according to a new report.

headline: Bank-Friendly Financial Reform
text: Treasury Secretary Jack Lew has defended financial reform recently, but on closer inspection, his defenses are oddly ambiguous.

headline: A Lunch That Tastes Like Nostalgia
text: “I’M in your hands,” I told Patricia Volk as she led me through the Beauty Level of Bergdorf Goodman — otherwise known as the basement — into Goodman’s Cafe.

headline: Eastern Conference Finals Preview
text: The Pittsburgh Penguins and the Boston Bruins have not met in the playoffs in 21 years, but you would not know from the simmering resentment Bruins fans feel toward the Penguins about Ulf Samuelsson’s hit during the 1991 playoffs that left Cam Neely with a career-shortening leg injury and Matt Cooke’s blindside hit during the 2009-10 season that gave Marc Savard a career-shortening concussion. Boston forward Milan Lucic noted this week that the Savard hit was “still in the back of your mind, but it’s not the focal point.”

headline: Western Conference Finals Preview
text: The N.H.L. Western Conference finals feature the 2012 champion Los Angeles Kings and the Chicago Blackhawks, who won the 2013 Presidents’ Trophy. This matchup features the last two teams from the West to win the Stanley Cup, though each team had its mettle tested by semifinal showdowns that reached seven games.

headline: Diverse Mix of Candidates Weigh In on an Obscure Jewish Ritual
text: It is a measure of the multicultural finesse it takes to run for mayor in New York City that seven Democratic candidates — including some of Chinese, Latino, Irish and Italian backgrounds — have staked out positions on an Orthodox Jewish circumcision ritual that is obscure even to most Jews.

headline: Clip: 'American Mary'
text: A scene from "American Mary," directed by Jen and Sylvia Soska.

headline: At Venice Biennale, Sarah Sze’s ‘Triple Point’
text: VENICE — The Biennale doesn’t open to the public until Saturday, but the art world arrived early for a peek. Artists, curators and creators responsible for this vast assemblage of exhibitions here have been on hand to meet, greet and explain their work.

headline: Directors, and Twins, Who Distrust the Normal
text: Lots of siblings make movies. The brothers Coen (“No Country for Old Men”) are Oscar winners. Andy and Lana Wachowski (“Cloud Atlas”) are a prominent brother-sister team (although Lana was once Larry). But sister directors? And not just sisters, but identical twins?

headline: Their Bedside Manners Need Work
text: If Dr. Giggles ever took the Hippocratic Oath, his eyes must have glazed at the “abstain from doing harm” part. Otoscopes are meant to examine noses and ears, not be plunged into brains. But often in horror movies, doctors don’t heal, scalpels aren’t for surgery and “medicine” only makes life worse. Fans know that syringes crave eyeballs, not upper arms.

headline: Improvised Music at a Purposeful Home
text: SKYE STEELE had just raced through an intricate tune called “Man-Made Nemesis” last week at ShapeShifter Lab when he tucked his violin under one arm, issuing an invitation in the form of an order. All the musicians in the audience — he called out half a dozen by name — were implored to join his band, the Railroad Rodia, for a chantlike finale.

headline: What Is Reform Conservatism?
text: As I noted earlier this week, there’s been a lot of liberal discussion of conservative reformers recently, ranging from the Washington Monthly’s attempt at a taxonomy of the tendency to Mike Konczal’s recent piece expressing doubts (echoed by my colleague Paul Krugman) about whether the reforming tendency within conservatism adds up to anything significant at all. Reading through the responses to Konczal’s post from “reformish” types, I’m in the rare position of disagreeing ever-so-slightly with my friend and co-author Reihan Salam, who writes:

headline: A Traveling Tennis Fund-Raising Party Hits Paris
text: PARIS — Since 2006, Robert R. Kinas, tennis fanatic, blood cancer survivor and bankruptcy lawyer with the Las Vegas firm of Snell & Wilmer, has toured the world’s major tennis tournaments with friends and colleagues. They party, play tennis and raise money for cancer research.

headline: ‘Rain Room’ at the Barbican Center
text: The “Rain Room” is a 5,000-square-foot field of falling water that uses motion detectors to create a dry path for viewers as they walk through a downpour. It is currently installed at the MoMA.

headline: The Fall of Gnomes: Tasteful to Tacky
text: Posting statues of bearded gnomes in gardens is considered a kitschy affront to nature. But until well into the 1800s it signified that a homeowner had elite tastes for rustic landscape design and pleasant melancholy.

headline: Sexual Violence in India Among Hot-Button Topics at Edinburgh Fringe Festival
text: The gang rape and subsequent death of a 23-year-old woman in New Delhi last year forms the basis for “Nirbhaya,” a new play by the writer and director Yael Farber, to be presented at the 2013 Edinburgh Festival Fringe this summer. Ms. Farber, whose production of “Mies Julie” was one of the hottest Fringe shows last year (going on to play in New York and London), has assembled an all-Indian cast for the production, which explores sexual violence through personal stories from the performers.

headline: Plenty of Substance in a New Style
text: PARIS — The dress made of tennis balls, the blue hair, the knee socks: together they had come to define Bethanie Mattek-Sands, a fashion iconoclast in a polo-shirt sport.

headline: Fastest Network? It All Depends
text: In a survey of 20 cities, Tech Hive found AT&T to have the fastest LTE service in America. An earlier survey of 77 cities by RootMetrics, a company that measures network performance, got similar rankings, but recorded very different speeds.

headline: Falling for the Anarchy She Was Sent to Fight
text: “The East” is a neat little thriller about ends and means and ethical quandaries. The title refers to a mysterious network of anti-corporate militants whose activities — called “jams” — shade from prankish agitprop toward outright terrorism. The members of the group, who live off the grid in an abandoned house in the wilderness somewhere near the Mason-Dixon line, are determined to hold the poisoners and polluters of the executive class accountable for their actions. Sometimes, as in the case of a pharmaceutical company that has peddled dangerous antibiotics, this means giving the bosses a literal taste of their own medicine.

headline: James Among 3 Fined for Flopping
text: MIAMI — It was not exactly Oscar night, but the N.B.A. singled out some of its best actors Thursday, and promptly penalized them for their work.

headline: City’s 911 Operators Use Pen and Paper as Computers Fail
text: Emergency operators in New York City have been forced on at least three occasions since Wednesday to resort to using pen and paper to record 911 calls and dispatch workers after their computer system went dark.

headline: Andreas Schulze: ‘Windows’
text: Team Gallery

headline: Laddie John Dill: ‘Elementary’
text: Nyehaus

headline: Wall Street Turns to ‘Boot Camps’ to Train New Workers
text: Newly minted university graduates who have landed coveted jobs on Wall Street may have impressive résumés and sought-after references. But often, nuts-and-bolts skills like spreadsheet building and database extraction are not part of university curriculums.

headline: Margaret Weber
text: Ramiken Crucible

headline: Lisa Ross: ‘Living Shrines of Uyghur China’
text: Rubin Museum of Art

headline: A Mystery of Smithfield’s Big China Deal: What Continental Grain Will Do
text: Investors in Smithfield Foods, the pork processor, appeared largely pleased on Wednesday with its proposed $4.7 billion sale to a giant meat producer in China.

headline: Gallery | A Melting Pot of Celebrities Makes Immigration Reform Look Fashionable
text: What do the actress Julianne Moore, the funnyman John Leguizamo, the supermodel Christy Turlington Burns and the director George C. Wolfe have in common? They’re among the 15 celebrities brought together by We Belong Together, a new national initiative to promote immigration reform. On a rainy day last week, this melting pot of talent gathered at a West Village studio to have their portraits taken by the fashion photographer Albert Watson, who immigrated to the United States from Scotland in 1970. The resulting black-and-white photos are the calling card for Fedoras for Fairness, an ad campaign created by We Belong Together that makes its debut today with support from the celebrity activist Rosie Perez. “I’m really proud of being a first-generation Puerto Rican-American,” said the actress, adding that America is “supposed to be known as the nation of fairness of democracy and of justice. And right now, the way immigration stands, that is not applied.”

headline: U.N. Court Acquits 2 Serbs of War Crimes
text: PARIS — In one of the most surprising verdicts of its checkered prosecution of Balkan war crimes, a United Nations court on Thursday acquitted two close aides of the former Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic, spurning the prosecution’s demand for life sentences for his once all-powerful secret police chief and the chief’s deputy.

headline: Watch Your Back, Even in the Family
text: In the prologue of James Marsh’s taut, somber conspiracy thriller “Shadow Dancer,” the 12-year-old Collette McVeigh (Maria Laird), idly stringing beads into a necklace, ignores her father’s request to go out and buy cigarettes. It is 1973 in Belfast, and the city is a powder keg. Her younger brother goes instead, and is shot to death outside the house in cross-fire between British and Irish Republican Army forces. As the McVeigh home erupts in anguished chaos, the father casts a recriminatory glare at Collette, who is guilt-stricken.

headline: MARIA PETSCHNIG: ‘Petschnigs’ ’
text: On Stellar Rays

headline: 20 More Cookbooks
text: THE ANIMAL FARM BUTTERMILK COOKBOOK: Recipes and Reflections From a Small Vermont Dairy. By Diane St. Clair. (Andrews McMeel, $27.99.) A cult is gathering around buttermilk, and St. Clair may well be its high priestess, supplying her product to the French Laundry in California and specialty stores in the Northeast. Buttermilk makes biscuit light, takes the cloying sweetness out of French toast and works wonders in lasagna.

headline: Section A, Airplane Fragment
Policy Lessons From Texas
text: Evan Smith, editor in chief of The Texas Tribune, on how the 83rd Texas legislative session may inform the national debate on Medicaid expansion, immigration policy and the Tea Party.

headline: Plague of Corruption Rises Anew in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA — Fifteen years ago, Indonesia took its first step toward democracy with the ouster of an authoritarian president. By 2009, the country had one of the most open electoral systems in Asia, with direct balloting to elect government officials, from the president all the way down to district chiefs and mayors.

headline: Cooking
text: A great rift has developed in the world of food. On one side, the unapologetic consumers of meat, red-faced and sweaty from their exertions over the barbecue grill and the smoking hog pit. On the other, the gentle leaf eaters, pale but confident — actuarially, ecologically and ethically. Judging by this season’s cookbooks, Team Green seems to be winning in a rout. But the carnivores are not going quietly.

headline: Fall Out Boy at Terminal 5
text: The band, back on tour after a nearly four-year hiatus, performed at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night.

headline: If Only the Grapes Were the Whole Story
text: Wine has been described as the perfect beverage because the grapes contain all the ingredients necessary to create their transformation. Put grapes in a vat, and over time the yeasts coating the skins set alchemy in motion, converting the sugar in the juice into alcohol.

headline: Gardening
text: Why do we have to go all the way around the world to find what’s in our own backyard? Gardeners have the answer, and it isn’t philosophical; it’s botanical. The way much of our “plant material,” as the nurserymen call it, arrived on American soil is as varied and inspiring a story of immigration as you can hope to hear. And for those of you who like what I think of as the “grain of sand” trend — the world in a bowl of salt or a mackerel — you’re in luck. Now we can find the world in a water lily or a ginkgo.

headline: Travel
text: The best of this season’s travel books are marked by a generational split. Three footloose writers in their 30s and 40s probe the back alleys of Ho Chi Minh City, the bike-choked streets of Amsterdam and the ­Taliban-haunted steppes of northern Afghanistan — sometimes paying a price for their curiosity. At the other end of the spectrum stand three recently minted septuagenarians with more than a century’s worth of globe-­trotting among them. Yet their own stumbles and setbacks prove that older doesn’t always mean wiser.

headline: ‘James’
text: James, a resident from the West Village, explains why he won't vote for Christine C. Quinn.

headline: A Choice Not as Easy as It Looked
text: When my husband’s friend Maggie asked him if he would donate his sperm to get her soon-to-be wife pregnant, he said he had to ask me first. It’s the kind of hypothetical question one might pose at a dinner party: “If your friends, a lesbian couple, ask your husband to donate sperm so they can have a child, would you agree?”

headline: If Only This Comedian Could Dish It Right Back
text: Watching the parade of comedy heavyweights and cultural heroes assembled for the biographical documentary “Richard Pryor: Omit the Logic,” my mind wandered to the roast of Pryor by the cast of his 1977 NBC television show. (The unedited version is on YouTube.) As you watch him being flayed by the largely unknown group that included future stars like Tim Reid, Robin Williams, Marsha Warfield, Sandra Bernhard and John Witherspoon — as usual, Pryor was ahead of the times — you can’t wait for him to get to the microphone and take revenge. When he does, he ad-libs a 13-minute rejoinder that’s as cruel and foul (and homophobic) as you might fear and as coruscatingly funny as you could hope.

headline: Retired in America, Reborn in Guatemala
text: Mark Kendall’s quietly moving documentary, “La Camioneta: The Journey of One American School Bus,” is as modest and farsighted as its cast of Guatemalans who make a living resurrecting discarded American school buses. The movie begins in rural Pennsylvania, where yellow buses — decommissioned after 8 to 12 years of use but still in good condition — are auctioned to bidders, many from Central America.

headline: No Sitting Duck
text: I am a nanny and work full time for a single family. Occasionally, I take baby-sitting jobs for other families on my free evenings and weekends. On these jobs, I have been asked often, by several different parents, if I will lower my hourly rate because their children will be sleeping for most of the time I am there. I am inclined to say no. My fee is fair. But since I’ve been asked so often, I thought I might check with you. How should I handle these requests?

headline: European Officials Move to Curb Overfishing
text: PARIS — The European Union on Thursday agreed to an overhaul of the region’s fisheries policy, a deal intended to make commercial fishing more sustainable.

headline: Section A, The Making of Struggle
‘Les Misérables’ Sets Broadway Opening Date
text: A Broadway revival of “Les Misérables” will run at the Imperial Theater and begin previews on March 1, 2014, with an opening night of March 23, the producer Cameron Mackintosh announced on Thursday. Casting is expected to be announced later this summer. The original production ran on Broadway from 1987 to 2003. A revival from 2006 to 2008 was described by Mr. Mackintosh as ill-conceived.

headline: Will Rangers Look to the Past for a New Coach?
text: Almost immediately after the Rangers fired John Tortorella on Wednesday, the idea with the storybook appeal was in the air: Mark Messier as the next Rangers coach.

headline: Suspending Disbelief, as 4 Flee Handcuffs
text: It’s one thing to watch a magician pull a rabbit out of a hat. It’s quite another to watch a movie of the same thing. Movies are themselves a kind of magic, dependent on technological wizardry. That’s why, when watching a film of a humble magic trick, you feel no sense of wonder, for the stunt has already been accomplished in a medium that’s all about illusion. So what, you shrug.

headline: Mystery in Seattle, but Paris Beckons
text: “The Killing,” a spooky crime thriller set in a rain-soaked Seattle that was canceled after its second season, then revived, returns to AMC this Sunday for a third season with a new case, a mostly new cast and a conundrum.

headline: Candidates on Circumcision Ritual
text: At a Jewish center, mayoral candidates were asked if they backed the city requirement of parental consent forms for metzitzah b'peh, in which a circumciser uses his mouth to suck blood from the wound.

headline: Jack Vance’s Influential Prose Will Live On
text: He was famously brusque, and he didn’t like to talk about the craft of writing. But the joy he took in language on the page was contagious.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Group Frames the Choice as Anyone but Quinn
text: A political action committee dedicated to thwarting Christine C. Quinn’s mayoral ambitions released three new advertisements on Thursday, featuring New Yorkers explaining why they do not like Ms. Quinn, the City Council speaker, and will not vote for her. The committee, called NYC Is Not for Sale 2013, was founded by the president of Local 1180, which represents communications workers; an animal rights group that has sparred with Ms. Quinn over horse-drawn carriages; and a wealthy businesswoman. It is legally allowed to spend unlimited amounts on political advertising as long as it does not coordinate its activity with a candidate. The ads began running Thursday on several cable channels in the city, and was produced by The Advance Group.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Myanmar and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Myanmar, India, France and Czech Republic.

headline: Returning With Punk and Pop Cred Intact
text: Fall Out Boy purposefully displayed its punk credentials at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night. Back on tour after a nearly four-year hiatus, with its first studio album since 2008, “Save Rock and Roll” (Decaydance/Island), Fall Out Boy slammed out its songs to a euphorically squealing, singing, moshing, crowd-surfing full house.

headline: Section B, The Search for Shepard’s Tone
Shifting Geometries and Swirling Dynamics
text: The striking originality of Justin Peck’s choreography for “In Creases,” which had its New York City premiere with City Ballet on Wednesday, is often strange. It includes constantly changing quasi-dramatic situations and pictorial configurations, all formally arranged and fluently connected, as if springing from some private dream world. The arrangement of its eight dancers abounds in novel geometries and other organizations. The patterns and angles change so regularly that it’s as if the stage itself were revolving.

headline: FX Adds to Comedy Slate With a Pilot for Tracy Morgan
text: The cable channel FX continued its aggressive expansion into comedy on Thursday with the announcement that it has signed Tracy Morgan, formerly a star of “30 Rock” and “Saturday Night Live,” to headline a pilot for a new situation comedy.

headline: Into the Hormonal Wild
text: Sometimes the strife between parents and their teenage children can be so bitter that even the tiniest set-to is charged with hostility that threatens to erupt into violence. The most amusing — and darkest — moments in Jordan Vogt-Roberts’s flighty comedy “The Kings of Summer,” set in suburban Ohio, pit Joe (Nick Robinson), a smart, hormonally overcharged 15-year-old, against his loving but cruelly sarcastic widowed father, Frank (Nick Offerman of “Parks and Recreation”).

headline: Workouts Continue as Belmont Field Swells
text: There is a little more than a week to go before the Belmont Stakes, and many of the contenders completed workouts this week. Some of those will complete a final workout over the weekend or early next week.

headline: A Father-Son Outing Goes Terribly Wrong
text: A father-son encounter session tricked out with science-fiction clichés and steeped in motivational uplift, “After Earth” opens with a teenager, Kitai Raige (Jaden Smith), washing out from some kind of ranger academy. It’s a bummer because all he wants to do is please his father (Will Smith, Jaden’s father), a heroic if unfortunately named general, Cypher. Daddy Dearest has risen having honed tremendous self-control and a useful protective technique, “ghosting,” which renders him invisible to the monsters plaguing human civilization: the nonbearlike Ursa.

headline: Comedy Listings for May 31-June 6
text: Comedy

headline: Theater Listings for May 31-June 6
text: Theater

headline: Warning: Woman Wields a Scalpel
text: “I don’t think it’s really fair that God gets to choose what we look like on the outside, do you?” says Beatress Johnson (Tristan Risk) in “American Mary,” a new horror movie from the twins Jen and Sylvia Soska. So Beatress has had work done. Lots of work: “14 different surgeries to get me to look like this” — a nightmare Betty Boop, with a synthetic, cartoonish face to supplement her ’50s homemaker dresses and a Kewpie-doll voice uttering the occasional obscene epithet.

headline: Movie Listings for May 31-June 6
text: Movies

headline: Emma Stone Is Out of ‘Cabaret’ Revival
text: The movie actress Emma Stone (“The Amazing Spider-Man,” “The Help”) has pulled out of the planned Broadway revival of “Cabaret,” in which she was expected to make her Broadway debut in early 2014 as Sally Bowles opposite the Tony Award-winner Alan Cumming as the M.C. Ms. Stone’s publicist said on Thursday that the actress now has scheduling conflicts with a feature film that prevent her from joining the musical, which Roundabout Theater Company is planning to mount at one of its Broadway theaters, Studio 54.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for May 31-June 6
text: Pop

headline: Jazz Listings for May 31-June 6
text: Jazz

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for May 31-June 6
text: Classical

headline: Market Report | The ID Bracelet Gets a Makeover
text: The ID bracelet is making a comeback, but it looks nothing like the standard-issue, heavy chain version that was de rigueur in the 1980s. Instead, today’s styles have sparkling diamond accents and clever designs — hospital bracelets fashioned from thin sheets of yellow gold and chain-link bands made of rose gold and closed with a toggle.

headline: Section B, Shepard’s Tone
Dance Listings for May 31-June 6
text: Dance

headline:
Museum & Gallery Listings for May 31-
June 6
text: Art

headline: Spare Times for Children for May 31-June 6
text: KIDSFILMFEST

headline: Spare Times for May 31-June 6
text: TALKS AT THE 92ND STREET Y (Sunday through Thursday) Magic, music and politics — with a dash of fashion — will be in the mix next week during talks at the Y. On Sunday at 7 p.m., the magician Steve Cohen, below, will talk with Dick Cavett, who began his show business career doing magic tricks, and Robert Palumbo, the writer, director and one of the executive producers of a recent History Channel special that featured Mr. Cohen.

headline: BBC Faces New Allegations of Sexual Abuse
text: LONDON — Since the case involving the television personality Jimmy Savile came to light in October, the British Broadcasting Corporation has received 152 new allegations of sexual abuse and harassment by 81 current and former employees, the broadcaster said Thursday.

headline: Siblings. Can’t Live With Them ...
Penn Station, Old and New
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fate of the Earth Rests on a Banjo
text: Thanks to groundbreaking work by Hollywood over the years — “Men in Black,” “Coneheads” and many more — we know that space aliens are all around us, looking and living like humans. Some of these visitors are downright charming, few more so than the two guys from the planet Hondo in “The History of Future Folk.”

headline: Dyslexia and the Poor
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Natural World: Here, It’s Had Work
text: Behind a white door in the basement of MoMA PS1, there’s a room that’s literally freezing cold. Inside are nearly a dozen boulder-size chunks of blue-tinged ice, fragments of a glacier in Iceland recovered by the celebrated artist Olafur Eliasson and transported here to create one of the more chilling artworks in “Expo 1: New York,” a sprawling, multisite extravaganza including a multitude of installations, shows-within-shows and events relating to the current and future state of our planet’s ecology.

headline: Behold the Latest in Trash Trucks and Police Three-Wheelers
text: When the Unisphere at the 1964 World’s Fair was brand new, the crowds marveled at the Mercury capsule that had carried Scott Carpenter into space, a replica of a two-person Gemini capsule and, for those who remained earthbound, a Picturephone that could make videocalls. It was the latest in technology, they said.

headline: Health Care Innovation
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Beatriz’ of El Salvador, Denied a Lifesaving Abortion
text: To the Editor:

headline: Angry Young Man in Kazakhstan
text: Can a crime set you free? For the sullen young man at the center of “Student,” directed by the Kazakh filmmaker Darezhan Omirbayev, an experimental act of violence seems to yield moral clarity. Set in modern-day Kazakhstan, where the quiet is broken only by brutishness, this classically shot and edited film is a spare yet entrancing tale drawn with precise strokes.

headline: ‘Expo 1: New York’
text: A look at the multisite show featuring works by Olafur Eliasson, Chris Burden and others.

headline: Donald Judd’s SoHo Home and Studio
text: The building in SoHo where the artist lived and worked off and on for 25 years is opening for public tours.

headline: The Artist’s Force Field, Frozen in Time
text: “Things that exist exist,” the Minimalist sculptor Donald Judd once wrote, “and everything is on their side.” His words are in a sense the credo of an empiricist, which was Judd’s preferred description of himself. He disdained the term Minimalist, along with the whole idea of art movements.

headline: Santander Sells 50% Stake in Asset-Management Arm to Investment Firms
text: Banco Santander said on Thursday that it had sold a 50 percent stake in its asset-management arm to two investment firms, Warburg Pincus and General Atlantic, as the bank continues to raise money to bolster its balance sheet.

headline: Trapped by an Invisible Force
text: In a few weeks CBS rolls out a mini-series called “Under the Dome” based on a Stephen King novel. It’s about a Maine town cut off from the world when a clear dome materializes over it.

headline: Troubled Souls, Screaming to Be Heard
text: The brothers Evangelos and George Giovanis, who directed “Run It,” have made films before (“Taking the Turn” and “Land of Nod”), but the experience doesn’t show in their latest. An entwined triptych of sorts unified by invective, slurs and characters demanding that others shut up, “Run It” is a very patchy affair.

headline: The Majesty of Classicism
text: Henry Hope Reed, the cranky genius of classicism who died last month, was expert at turning a phrase in favor of traditional architecture.

headline: About Those Visitors From Other Planets
text: Before “The X-Files” there were cable-television U.F.O. shows, raising spooky questions and little shivers of wonder about the cosmos, with testimony from assorted astrophysicists and freethinkers. Amardeep Kaleka’s documentary “Sirius,” which seeks to induce government transparency about extraterrestrial life, rolls out eyewitnesses to U.F.O.’s and such, but also cross-pollinates with a more recent vintage of economic doomsaying.

headline: Financing for Foreigners
text: The foreigners streaming into New York to buy housing often pay in cash, but with interest rates low, more have been seeking to finance their purchases.

headline: Health Law Is Fostering Competition, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — The new health care law is injecting more competition into health insurance markets nationwide, drawing additional insurance companies into states long dominated by a few carriers, Obama administration officials said Thursday.

headline: Two Artists on a Long Construction Journey
text: There’s a reason that breaking rocks is a time-honored form of hard labor. In “Triumph of the Wall,” the first-time filmmaker Bill Stone all too faithfully records his morbid fascination with a stonemason’s attempt to build a 1,000-foot wall on a Quebec estate. Neither the very relaxed pace of this builder, Chris Overing, nor Mr. Stone’s sporadically amusing neuroses about his filmmaking make for a gripping documentary.

headline: No Toys, but a Park Nearby
text: If only New Yorkers knew what all those toy marketers must have known — that the Toy Building North has some of the best views of the city’s most striking buildings — it might have become residential long ago.

headline: A Good Manager Must Be More Than a Messenger
text: This interview with Roman Stanek, chief executive of GoodData in San Francisco, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: G.O.P. Sizes Up Obama as Midterm Target
text: WASHINGTON — His name won’t be on any ballot in 2014. Or ever again, for that matter.

headline: Uncle Sam Stands in the Way of Uncle Jack
text: “I’m just the gay uncle,” Jack keeps saying in Glenn Gaylord’s plodding drama “I Do.” But is he? The movie shows one thing but insists on another.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: The Honorable William Wall
text: The Honorable William Wall is an oasis on the Hudson River that offers urban sailors, and those who just wish they were sailors, a place to relax and have a drink or two.

headline: This Week’s Movies: May 31, 2013
text: The New York Times critics on “The East,” “After Earth” and “The Kings of Summer.”

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: The Drone War Is Far From Over
text: WHEN people in Washington talk about shrinking the drone program, as President Obama promised to do last week, they are mostly concerned with placating Pakistan, where members of the newly elected government have vowed to end violations of the country’s sovereignty. But the drone war is alive and well in the remote corners of Pakistan where the strikes have caused the greatest and most lasting damage.

headline: Federal Program for Distressed Homeowners Is Extended
text: WASHINGTON — Despite signs of revival in housing, the Obama administration announced on Thursday an extension of its principal program for helping distressed homeowners to get mortgage modifications and avoid foreclosure.

headline: Will Perry Run Again? And if So, for What?
text: Outside a 2008 meeting of the Republican Governors Association in Grapevine, Tex., a reporter asked Gov. Rick Perry if he was running for re-election.

headline: What Happened on Frontier Airlines Flight 727
text: Updated | June 20, 2013

headline: Comeuppance for the Rich, at Least on the Screen
text: MEXICO CITY — “Why are they taking everything away from us, like in Venezuela?” wails Barbie Noble, a spoiled rich girl crammed into a getaway cab with her two brothers as the family flees a police raid on their sumptuous mansion.

headline: Heights of Fancy
text: AMES, Iowa — THE installation of the 408-foot spire atop One World Trade Center earlier this month made it, according to some reports, the tallest building in the United States.

headline: What I Love | Richard Kind
text: At home on the Upper West Side with Richard Kind, known for his role in ‘Spin City.’

headline: The Perfect Apartment, From Memory
text: When, back in 2000, the sitcom “Spin City” moved production to Los Angeles from New York, few could have been happier than Richard Kind, a born-and-bred Easterner who played a clueless press secretary on the long-running series. He and his wife, Dana, bought a grand old house in majestic Hancock Park, complete with marble steps and a living room they never set foot in.

headline: Data Point to Radiation Risk for Travelers to Mars
text: Astronauts traveling to Mars, bombarded by the radiation of outer space, would face modestly higher risks of cancer, new NASA measurements confirm.

headline: Water Everywhere, and a Drop to Drink
text: ABOARD THE HONORABLE WILLIAM WALL, northeast of Ellis Island — Can anyone entirely explain the unquestionable pleasure of drinking by the sea? Perhaps there is a natural felicity in casually consuming one form of liquid while gazing at another — or perhaps the coastal cocktail is an atavism of our lost amphibian past.

headline: Illinois Lawmakers Race for Compromise on Guns
text: CHICAGO — Here in Illinois, the only state in the nation that does not have a statewide law allowing private citizens to carry a concealed gun in public, a Democrat sits in the governor’s seat and his party holds strong majorities in both chambers of the legislature, where President Obama once served.

headline: U.S. Retailers Announce New Factory Safety Plan
text: Feeling pressure from consumer and labor groups for not doing more to ensure factory safety in Bangladesh, Wal-Mart, Gap and numerous other retailers along with the nation’s main retail federations are seeking to forge a new plan to promote safety in that country’s apparel industry.

headline: El Salvador: Doctors Can Induce Birth to Save Woman, Official Says
text: A 22-year-old woman who was denied an abortion by El Salvador’s Supreme Court can terminate her pregnancy at the first sign of danger, the health minister, María Isabel Rodríguez, said Thursday. “At this point, the interruption of the pregnancy is no longer an abortion,” Ms. Rodríguez said, “it is an induced birth.” Doctors say that the woman, known only as Beatriz, is carrying a fetus with a severe birth defect and almost no chance of surviving, and that she faces serious health risks if her pregnancy continues because she has lupus and related complications. After the Supreme Court’s ruling, the Inter-American Court of Human Rights called on the government to  “immediately adopt the necessary measures to protect the life, personal integrity and health” of Beatriz. Ms. Rodríguez said the woman could be induced to have either an abdominal or vaginal birth “because the important thing is saving Beatriz’s life.”

headline: Seen as Offensive, Beer Can Has a Shortened Shelf Life
text: The special cans of Coors Light beer started popping up in New York City in recent weeks ahead of the coming parade. The vitriol followed soon after with elected officials and others saying that the cans were tasteless and sent the wrong message.

headline: In the Run-Up to Television’s Season, a Steady Stream of Ad Sales
text: TELEVISION is an industry known for reruns. So it may be appropriate that the process of selling commercial time before the start of the 2013-14 season is, so far, repeating the process of selling commercial time before the start of the 2012-13 season.

headline: Leading a Red Sox Revival
text: PHILADELPHIA — It was not so much that John Farrell was sitting pretty in the visitors’ dugout Wednesday evening at Citizens Bank Park, his team narrowly holding onto first place in the American League East. More to the point on Farrell’s location, or relocation, he was nowhere near Toronto.

headline: Clinton Hires Ex-State Dept. Aide and Joins Husband’s Foundation
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — Settling the question of whether she would be part of her husband’s foundation or start her own, Hillary Rodham Clinton has hired a former State Department aide to join her at what is now being called the Bill, Hillary and Chelsea Clinton Foundation. Until recently it was called the William J. Clinton Foundation.

headline: Hate Speech on Facebook
text: Facebook belatedly moved to further restrict hate speech that glorified violence against women after an organized social media campaign caused some companies like Nissan, the automaker, to withhold advertising from the site. The companies said they acted after they became aware that their ads might have appeared next to the offensive content.

headline: Grim Task of Identifying Factories’ Dead Overwhelms Bangladeshi Lab
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Inside a small government laboratory here, there are about 300 test tubes, each labeled with masking tape and containing an extracted tooth or a shard of bone. Day and night, dozens of these tubes rest on metal trays that vibrate with a motorized monotony. The shaking decalcifies the bone in a process that requires two weeks before material can be gleaned for a DNA profile.

headline: Self-Driving Cars for Testing Are Supported by U.S.
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Companies from Silicon Valley to Detroit to Germany are developing cars that park, steer and even drive themselves. Now the federal agency for traffic safety has said it wants to come along for the ride.

headline: Bridge Collapse Tears at a Town’s Economy
text: BURLINGTON, Wash. — Interstate 5, before last week’s bridge collapse over the Skagit River on the south end of town, was the great pumping arterial source of economic life here. It brought Canadians, shopping for furniture or clothes. It brought day-tripping outlet mall lovers from Seattle. Through an embrace of retailing begun as a town plan in the 1980s, Burlington, population 8,500, grew to have the highest level of retail sales per capita of any city in the state.

headline: M.L.S. Club Owner Has Latinos-Only Policy, Suit Says
text: Chivas USA became the 11th member of Major League Soccer nearly a decade ago, beginning play with the cachet that its parent club was Chivas Guadalajara, an immensely popular Mexican team.

headline: The Imperfect Immigrants
text: VISNJA GORA, Slovenia — Exactly 100 years ago a man of 22 left this village on the eve of a great war to build a life in the United States. To Ignac Vrhovec, the tired old ground of his homeland was tangled in his ancestors’ encumbrances and spent by time. After he left, much of that land would change hands, from the Austro-Hungarian Empire, to Italy, to Nazi Germany.

headline: The A Train Returns to the Rockaways
text: A time-lapse video of the A train crossing Jamaica Bay, reconnecting the Rockaway Peninsula with the rest of New York City.

headline: Getting a Fair Share From Multinationals
text: How can the United States government get more tax revenue from global corporations while letting them stay competitive?

headline: No Replacement for Corporate Taxes
text: In response to the recent Senate hearing on tax avoidance at Apple, some pundits have argued that the best solution is to abolish the corporate income tax altogether. Their contention is that multinational corporations — which hold trillions of dollars in mostly untaxed profits offshore — are so complex and so expert at avoidance that even trying to tax them is pointless. It would be better, they say, to quit trying and to raise needed tax revenue in other ways. This would be a completely wrong approach.

headline: Promising African Development Fund Collapses
text: The initiative began two decades ago, with the best of intentions, after apartheid fell and southern Africa’s future brightened.

headline: Attacks on Muslims in Myanmar
text: Terrifying anti-Muslim violence surged this week in Myanmar, exposing deep ethnic and religious tensions that are undermining efforts to stabilize the country and move forward with political and economic reforms. Myanmar’s democratic aspirations can never be fully realized if Muslims, who make up about 5 percent of the population, continue to be attacked and marginalized by Buddhists, the majority of the population. At least 44 people have died since March in sectarian mob violence.

headline: The Questions Keep Coming for Rutgers
text: It was a few weeks after Rutgers hired a well-regarded recruiting firm to identify and vet candidates to lead the university’s athletic program, which was still reeling from a scandal involving an abusive coach, when Julie Hermann, a leading applicant, turned to one of the firm’s final questions.

headline: Just in Time for Summer, the A Train Is Fully Restored
text: The trains returned, at last, on a proper beach day, carrying toddlers in sundresses and men in shorter-than-short shorts, high school students prone to impromptu dance-offs and women whose toes dangled from their sandals.

headline: Owner Makes All-Out Push for Indian Point
text: At a break in the testimony, a few cordial people took seats near me and introduced themselves. Among them was Norris McDonald, who came to the legislative hearing in Lower Manhattan to testify about the future of the Indian Point nuclear power plant.

headline: From the Mouths of Babes
text: Like many observers, I usually read reports about political goings-on with a sort of weary cynicism. Every once in a while, however, politicians do something so wrong, substantively and morally, that cynicism just won’t cut it; it’s time to get really angry instead. So it is with the ugly, destructive war against food stamps.

headline: New Rules May Rein In Prosecutors in Leak Investigations
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., under fire over investigative tactics in leak cases, has opened internal discussions over tightening rules on when prosecutors may seek phone logs and other information that could identify reporters’ sources as he began a series of a meetings on Thursday with leaders of news media organizations.

headline: McIlroy’s Struggles Continue in First Round of the Memorial
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — With so much on his plate, Rory McIlroy used breakfast at Muirfield Village Golf Club to beg Adam Scott for a few morsels on Merion Golf Club, site of the United States Open in two weeks.

headline: The Romantic Advantage
text: In the race to be the world’s dominant economy, Americans have at least one clear advantage over the Chinese. We’re much better at branding. American companies have these eccentric failed novelists and personally difficult visionary founders who are fantastic at creating brands that consumers around the world flock to and will pay extra for. Chinese companies are terrible at this. Every few years, Chinese officials say they’re going to start an initiative to create compelling brands and the results are always disappointing.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 31, 2013
text: "If I give them blood, I will learn where my father is, which body is his.”

headline: Franca Rame, Italian Actress and Playwright, Dies at 83
text: Franca Rame, an Italian actress and playwright whose work — including mordant, highly charged critiques of the Italian government, the Roman Catholic Church and the status of women — was often done in collaboration with her husband, the Nobel Prize-winning playwright Dario Fo, died on Wednesday at her home in Milan. She was 83.

headline: A New Step in Wrestling With the Bra
text: They are the measurements that many American women (and not a few American men) know so well: 32A, 34B, 36C.

headline: Man Tied to Boston Suspect Is Said to Have Attacked Agent Before Being Shot
text: WASHINGTON — A man who was killed in Orlando, Fla., last week while being questioned by an F.B.I. agent about his relationship with Tamerlan Tsarnaev, one of the Boston Marathon bombing suspects, had knocked the agent to the ground with a table and ran at him with a metal pole before being shot, according to a senior law enforcement official briefed on the matter.

headline: U.S. Combat Commanders Should Handle War Zone Investigations, Panel Says
text: WASHINGTON — Concerned about possible flaws in criminal proceedings against American troops accused of killing or abusing civilians in a war zone, a Defense Department panel has proposed that investigations and prosecutions of crimes be carried out by a senior commander in the theater of combat and not the branch of the armed services in which the accused serves.

headline: At Giants’ Practice, Just Another Face, if Not Just Another Name
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Kyle Bosworth, the newest Giant, cannot enter a football locker room unnoticed. His name precedes him.

headline: Words of Praise, and Loss, for Malcolm X’s Grandson
text: Malcolm Shabazz never knew his grandfather, Malcolm X, but in his struggle to understand his legacy, he learned to quote the man verbatim, his aunt, Ilyasah Shabazz, recalled on Thursday during a memorial service for Mr. Shabazz at a church in Harlem. So studious was Mr. Shabazz that he would correct others, even if only a single word was out of place.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Scintillating Start for a Bruin Who Was Overlooked in the Draft
text: BOSTON — The shot from just inside the left circle made its way past a diving Derek Stepan and through a maze of Bruins and Rangers in front of Henrik Lundqvist. Lundqvist, the reigning Vezina Trophy winner, was a second too late in folding his left arm into his body, and the puck bounced into the net.

headline: Bush Terrorism Fight May Be Fodder in F.B.I. Confirmation
text: WASHINGTON — The pending nomination of James B. Comey to be director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation will probably shine a fresh light on some controversial chapters in George W. Bush’s war on terrorism, with Republicans more likely than Democrats to question his role in the Bush Justice Department.

headline: What Was Once Yours
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I believe Josh Knapp is feeling a little insecure today, so let’s see what we can do to cheer him up. With statements in the northwest like “AM I WRONG?” and “I’M HURT,” it sounds like he can use all the solace we can provide.

headline: Corrections: May 31, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Little Groucho Marx, a Little King Solomon
text: “Terrible is the temptation to do good!” That observation lands with a satisfying sting in the new production of “The Caucasian Chalk Circle,” by Bertolt Brecht, that opened on Thursday at the Classic Stage Company. With his walking-dead demeanor and a slightly savage glint in his eye, Christopher Lloyd, portraying the narrator in the first part of the play, imbues that wry morsel of philosophy with a vivid jolt of irony.

headline: Special Session Puts Governor in Driver’s Seat
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: New Animal Law Is Welcome but, at the Outset, Expensive
text: Some Texas animal shelters have until January to comply with a new law that bans the use of compressed carbon monoxide to euthanize dogs and cats. Although the shelter operators say they welcome the change, they also say that adapting to the new requirements will be neither easy nor cheap.

headline: Massachusetts: State Sues Over Cod Limits
text: Attorney General Martha Coakley filed a lawsuit on Thursday against the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in an effort to block federal rules that severely limit the amount of cod New England fishermen are allowed to catch annually. Effective May 1, federal regulators cut the catch for Gulf of Maine cod by 77 percent, saying the limit is the only way to rebuild stocks that scientists say are heavily depleted. Ms. Coakley’s complaint says regulators violated federal law by not giving due consideration to the economic impact of the cuts on fishermen and by failing to use the best available science.

headline: In Wake of Japanese Market Dip, Investors Find Comfort in Higher Factory Output
text: TOKYO — Japan inched closer to the end of deflation and factory output picked up, government data showed Friday, offering proof that the real economy is slowly catching up to the high expectations set by its recent bold economic policies.

headline: Returning Teixeira Will Displace Valuable Contributor for Yankees
text: A few years ago, Lyle Overbay was standing at first base at Yankee Stadium chatting with Mark Teixeira, as opposing baseball players often do between pitches. Both men are in the fraternity of first baseman, but at that moment Overbay was a base runner for the Toronto Blue Jays, and Teixeira, the fielder, had only recently joined the Yankees.

headline: Varied Enrollment of Disadvantaged Students
text: Undergraduates receiving Pell grants, 2010-11, at selected elite universities.

headline: Income-Based Diversity Lags at Some Universities
text: Opponents of race-based affirmative action in college admissions urge that colleges use a different tool to encourage diversity: giving a leg up to poor students. But many educators see real limits to how eager colleges are to enroll more poor students, no matter how qualified — and the reason is money.

headline: What to Watch on Day 6 at the French Open
text: On Thursday, 14 second-round singles matches were unable to be completed, including two of the recommended matches (Schiavone-Flipkens and  Haas-Sock). Those two remain worthy picks, as do the following six third-round matches. Seeded players cannot play each another until the third round, and as it happens all six selected Friday matches feature two seeds.

headline: Where No Mets Have Gone Before
text: Bobby Valentine’s 1997 Mets were a plucky group of overachievers who won their first Subway Series game against the Yankees, the defending World Series champions, but they did not sweep the series. The 1998 and ’99 Mets were brash contenders, but they could not do it, either. Nor could the 2000 Mets, who won the National League pennant, or the 2006 team that went deep into the playoffs.

headline: The Campaign Against President Clinton
text: Ahead of the 1998 midterm elections, Republicans tried to use the Monica Lewinsky affair to their advantage to win more Congressional seats.

headline: James B. Comey in 90 Seconds
text: The former Justice Department official, named by President Obama to lead the Federal Bureau of Investigation, prosecuted Martha Stewart and stood up to President George W. Bush.

headline: New York Business Leaders Plan a Push in Council Races
text: A group of real estate executives and corporate leaders, bracing for the departure of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, plans to spend up to $10 million to make sure the City Council elected this fall is friendly to business.

headline: Injury Ends Debate on Whether Tejada Should Be Sent to Minors
text: The Mets’ predicament at shortstop was simplified Thursday when Ruben Tejada, the regular starter there since last season, was placed on the 15-day disabled list with a strained right quadriceps muscle.

headline: Vatican Bank Looks to Shed Its Image as an Offshore Haven
text: VATICAN CITY — From the cheerful ease with which the newly minted president of the Vatican Bank fielded questions on a recent morning, it could be easy to forget how the bank has long been a mystery wrapped in an enigma, tangled up in some of the most opaque scandals in Italy.

headline: Award Is Presented to Top Lacrosse Players
text: Rob Pannell of Cornell and Katie Schwarzmann of Maryland on Thursday won the Tewaaraton Award, given to the top men’s and women’s players in the country. Pannell, an attackman, helped the Big Red make the Final Four. He finished his career with 354 points, an N.C.A.A. record. Schwarzmann, a midfielder, won the award for a second consecutive year after helping the Terrapins to the N.C.A.A. title game, where they lost to North Carolina in triple overtime.

headline: Queens Boy, 13, Wins Scripps Spelling Bee With ‘Knaidel’
text: The fourth trip to the Scripps National Spelling Bee was the charm for Arvind V. Mahankali, 13, from Bayside, Queens.

headline: James Leads Third-Quarter Charge as Heat Gain Edge
text: MIAMI — There was only one way to cut through the clutter and the mayhem, the flagrant fouls and flopping charges, the sniping and the posturing that threatened to turn the Eastern Conference finals into an angry carnival of sneers.

headline: A Few Wins Transform the Mood for the Mets
text: A boisterous song by the rapper Ace Hood called “Bugatti” reverberated through the visitors’ clubhouse at Yankee Stadium late Thursday night as the Mets players laughed and bobbed their heads.

headline: The Art of Houghton Hall Comes Home
text: An unparalleled collection, including countless works by Rubens, van Dyck and Velázquez, returns to one of Britain’s finest Palladian houses.

headline: Bernard-Henri Lévy on Art and Philosophy
text: Bernard-Henri Lévy, France’s most famous public intellectual, becomes a curator with a heady new exhibition about the eternal struggle for truth.

headline: Deeda Blair’s Elegance of Conviction
text: Whether she’s tackling the complexities of science or style, the medical philanthropist, fashion icon and social mover Deeda Blair approaches all facets of life with quiet but unwavering discipline.

headline: Yoga in Africa
text: The language of yoga is universal. That is the message of Robert Sturman, an artist from Santa Monica, Calif., who has traveled across the United States to capture the tranquillity and beauty of yoga. A month ago, Mr. Sturman traveled to Kenya to document the work of the Africa Yoga Project, a nonprofit organization that teaches and employs more than 70 local yoga teachers and conducts up to 300 free yoga classes for more than 5,000 people weekly in orphanages, prisons and other locales throughout the country.

headline: Word of the Day | chivalrous
text: chivalrous •\ˈshi-vəl-rəs\• adjective

headline: Suspect Sought in Fatal Shooting of Queens Girl on Bus
text: The police identified a suspect on Thursday in the killing of a 14-year-old Queens girl who was shot in the head as she rode a city bus home from a friend’s birthday party on May 18.

headline: Fending Off the Heat of the Dog Days of Spring
text: On Thursday, New Yorkers in Brooklyn rallied to the challenge of the area’s first hot day of the season. Eli Belizaire, in Park Slope, tackled an ice cream cone. John Loftin sold cold water at the intersection of Kings Highway and Remson Avenue in East Flatbush. And the driver of a red convertible, with a towel on his head to cool off, decided he might as well go shirtless.

headline: Ryan Says Garrard Didn’t Shock Jets
text: Coach Rex Ryan said Thursday that the Jets were not surprised when David Garrard, signed to compete for the starting quarterback job, abruptly chose to retire two weeks ago. Garrard’s decision, spurred by the condition of his left knee, narrowed the competition to Mark Sanchez and Geno Smith. Garrard was placed on the reserve/retired list Thursday.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 8 P.M. (WE) BRIDEZILLAS This reality series kicks off its 10th and final season with the promise that these will be the worst-behaved brides ever. The temper tantrums begin as one woman feuds with her wedding planner, who just happens to be her future mother-in-law, and another (Ariel, above, with her husband, Brook) makes it clear to her entourage that she’s the boss. In “Marriage Boot Camp: Bridezillas,” a new series at 9, five former bridezillas and their husbands share a house as they try to save their marriages with help from counselors, including Jim and Elizabeth Carroll, a married team. And in “Pregnant & Dating,” a new series at 10, five women with a fondness for highlighting their baby bumps with various permutations of spandex search for Mr. Right as their pregnancies progress.

headline: Economist Who Fled Russia Cites Peril in Politically Charged Inquiry
text: MOSCOW — Hours after the economist Sergei M. Guriev said that he had fled Russia because he feared he would be prosecuted in a politically tinged case, Russia’s largest bank announced that its shareholders had overwhelmingly re-elected him to its board of directors, a show of support that points to rifts within Russia’s ruling class.

headline: News Quiz | May 31, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Speak More Chinese, Ambassador Tells Thais
text: BEIJING — Some Thai police are corrupt and the justice system is slow, but perhaps more importantly, not enough Thais speak Chinese — that’s the gist of “a long list” of complaints by China’s Ambassador to Thailand, Guan Mu, delivered at a meeting with Thai officials Wednesday on the popular vacation island of Phuket, the Phuket News reported.

headline: U.S. Colleges Report 2013 Admission Yields and Wait-List Offers
text: Every year, as one cohort of incoming students is accepted and another crop starts filling out applications, colleges across the country calculate one last measurement of their admission season success: the yield.

headline: IHT Quick Read: May 31
text: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria displayed a new level of defiance on Thursday, warning Israel that he could permit attacks on the Golan Heights and suggesting that he had secured plenty of weapons from Russia — possibly including an advanced missile system — as his opponents faltered politically and Hezbollah fighters brought momentum to his military campaign to crush the Syrian insurgency. Anne Barnard reports from Beirut, and Neil MacFarquhar from the United Nations.

headline: This Season’s Broadway Stages Feature Many Child Actors
text: In the article “Broadway Babies,” Robin Pogrebin writes that this season’s Broadway shows feature many child actors.

headline: Do You Enjoy Reading Tabloid Gossip?
text: What do we find so appealing about watching celebrities like Charlie Sheen and Lindsay Lohan unravel? Do we take pleasure in hearing about their pain? Do their troubles somehow make us feel better about ourselves? Or, are tabloid scandals just entertainment?

headline: Tickled by America’s Quirky Coincidences
text: Inauguration day in President Abraham Lincoln’s time was on March 4. That’s also the photographer Joshua Yospyn’s birthday — and if you’re given to seeing meaning in coincidences, as he is, it’s a pretty big deal.

headline: What They Said: India’s Growth Slumps to a Decade Low
text: The Indian economy grew 5 percent in the 2012-2013 fiscal year, the smallest rise in a decade, according to government data released Friday. The figure, which was in line with a February estimate of the Central Statistics Office, or C.S.O., dampened hopes of a swift revival of a once-booming economy.

headline: Protests Block Large Part of Central Frankfurt
text: FRANKFURT — Demonstrators blocked a large swath of central Frankfurt on Friday to protest a variety of issues ranging from economic austerity in Europe to capitalism to labor conditions for workers in developing countries.

headline: How to Cure the College Dropout Syndrome
text: Jeffrey Selingo, the former editor of The Chronicle of Higher Education and currently an editor at large there, is the author of a new book, “College (Un)Bound.” In it, he argues that the higher-education system is both vital to the American economy and “broken.” (An essay adapted from the book was published in the Education Life section of The Times last month.) My exchange with him, edited slightly, follows.

headline: Nashville’s Frist Center Shows Off Art Deco Cars
text: When Nashville’s main post office opened in 1934, New Deal federal government programs were on the rise and the architectural style of federal buildings was stern and modernist. It was one of those big stately, solid buildings suggestive of the federal government’s power; tough-looking stone eagles stood sentinel on its facade.

headline: Unemployment Hits Record High in Euro Zone
text: LONDON — Unemployment in the euro zone continued its relentless march higher in April, according to official data published Friday, hitting yet another record, amid a prolonged recession and the absence of a coordinated response by policy makers.

headline: Does Spelling Matter?
text: LONDON — A professor of English at one of the world’s most venerable centers of learning has outraged language purists by challenging whether spelling matters.

headline: Thanks, and I Do Wear Sun Protection Now
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lloyds to Sell $5 Billion in Mortgage Securities to Increase Reserves
text: LONDON – Lloyds Banking Group is on a selling spree.

headline: How Two Owners Got the Web Sites They Wanted
text: In my last post — The Problem Social Media Cannot Solve — I profiled DCC Waterbeds, a company that makes waterbeds for cows – yes, really – and that generously shared a tale of what went wrong when the owners hired a friend to build a Web site. This week, I’ve found two small businesses eager to talk about how they managed to build Web sites they love.

headline: Dell Begins Campaign to Support Leveraged Buyout
text: Dell Inc. on Friday began its official campaign to support a proposed $24.4 billion sale of itself to Michael S. Dell and the investment firm Silver Lake, amid continued opposition to the deal.

headline: Daily Report: U.S. Says Self-Driving Cars Could Save Lives
text: The Transportation Department says that driverless cars should not yet be allowed, except for testing, but noted that some safety features could save lives, Claire Cain Miller and Matthew L. Wald report in The New York Times.

headline: China’s Ethnic Song and Dance
text: In China’s worst single outburst of ethnic violence in four years, 21 people died last month in the far western region of Xinjiang. But never mind that. According to the deputy governor of Xinjiang, Shi Dagang, the region’s Muslim Uighur population is far too busy treating guests “to meat and wine, with song and dance” to create any problems. In fact, Shi insisted to reporters this week, “The ethnic minorities are simple-hearted and honest, very kind and unaffected. They love guests.”

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Barbie’
text: This poem, one of 12 winners of our Found Poem Student Contest, was written by Scott, 18, from Phoenix.

headline: D.I.Y.-Style Public Spaces
text: As more and more educated Americans seek alternatives to suburbs and cars, they’re reframing the demand for public space.

headline: A Streetcorner Serenade for the Public Plaza
text: In Brooklyn, the No. 3 subway line ends at New Lots Avenue, where passengers descend from the elevated tracks to what used to be a nasty intersection, trafficked by prostitutes, drug dealers — “You name it,” as Eddie Di Benedetto, the owner of Caterina’s Pizzeria, put it the other day. Not long ago, a coalition of local merchants and community leaders turned to the New York City Department of Transportation, which runs a program to make traffic circles, triangles and streets into pedestrian plazas.

text: Dear Diary:

headline: Chinese Buyers for A.I.G. Plane Leasing Unit Miss Payment
text: The consortium of Chinese firms that has agreed to buy the American International Group‘s airplane leasing division missed a deposit payment, the American insurer disclosed on Friday, threatening to unwind the multibillion-dollar transaction.

headline: Japan and South Korea Bar Imports of U.S. Wheat
text: Japan and South Korea suspended some imports of American wheat, and the European Union urged its 27 nations to increase testing, after the United States government disclosed this week that a strain of genetically engineered wheat that was never approved for sale was found growing in an Oregon field.

headline: Newt Economic Thinking
text: OK, we had our Munk debate, and I have a few minutes to blog here at Pearson airport; for what it’s worth, my side “won” the audience vote.

headline: Finding Inner Peace, iPhone in Hand
text: HeartMath, a creator of science-based solutions to reduce stress, recently turned to a stress inducer, technology, to create a tool to help users achieve serenity.

headline: Tip of the Week: Make a Mac Screen Recording
text: The QuickTime Player program included with recent versions of Mac OS X can do more than just play back video clips. It can also make a recording of the action on the computer screen, which can be helpful when creating tutorials or demonstrating how to do a  task. To get started, just go to the Mac’s Applications folder and open the QuickTime Player program.

headline: The 1913 Belmont: A New Look and a Dubious Upset
text: Fans noticed a new Belmont at the opening of the 1913 season; renovations had altered the familiar plant. Underneath an extensive diagram of the refurbished courses, The Daily Racing Form wrote that, “Since racing has been resumed over the most extensive and commodious plant in America it is fitting that readers should have an opportunity to refresh their memories as to its various courses.”

headline: At HSBC, a Board Member Who Can Keep Secrets
text: LONDON – From spy vs. spy to spy vs. banker?

headline: A Conversation With: Author and Filmmaker Vivek Bald
text: The filmmaker and author Vivek Bald’s book “Bengali Harlem and the Lost Histories of South Asian America” created a buzz within the South Asian-American community when it was released in November. Mr. Bald documents the histories of seldom-acknowledged groups of early South Asian migrants to the United States, like Muslim silk and cotton traders from West Bengal in the 1880s and Indian sailors who deserted British steamships in the early 20th century. They settled in New Orleans, Harlem in New York and New Jersey and formed strong community bonds with African-American and Hispanic communities.

headline: Debt and Growth: The State of the Debate
text: So, after a brief diversion into issues of manners and etiquette, I hope we’re back to the substance. And there are really three points that have been established; I’m not sure that everyone understands that any one of those points is enough to refute most of the debt/deficit discussion of the past three years.

headline: Dell Fights Back
text: DELL FIGHTS BACK  |  The fight over Dell Inc. has climbed to a new level.

headline: Confronting Regulators on the JPMorgan Leaks
text: Richard E. Farley is a partner in the leveraged finance group of the law firm of Paul Hastings. He is writing a book titled “The Crisis Not Wasted: The Creation of Modern Financial Regulation During F.D.R.’s First Five Hundred Days,” a book on the creation of modern financial regulation during President Franklin Roosevelt’s first term of office.

headline: OPEC Maintains Its Target for Daily Oil Production
text: LONDON — With the price of oil relatively strong, OPEC decided on Friday to maintain its current target for oil production at 30 million barrels a day, a move the markets had expected.

headline: Friday Reading: Keeping Children Away From Medical Marijuana
text: Medical marijuana may pose risk for children, a new approach to sizing bras, federal program for distressed homeowners is extended and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
